Body Text: Once in a while , new startling and exciting discovery filter through even in this data-drenched Internet-accelerated world . The classical music community wa surprised and thrilled around a year and a half or so ago when a long-lost score by Felix Mendelssohn and Ignaz Moscheles , which came to light in 2009 after a hiatus of close to 200 year , wa restored to it former glory and unveiled to the public.Internationally renowned pianist Tomer Lev and his MultiPiano Ensemble are now proffering the work to local audience , with the Israeli Philharmonic Orchestra ( IPO ) in tow.The four-date series kick off at the Charles Bronfman Auditorium in Tel Aviv tonight , April 3 ( 7 p.m . ) , followed by two further concert there on April 4 and 6 ( 8 p.m . and 9 p.m . respectively ) , closing at the Jerusalem Theatre on April 7 ( 8 p.m . ) . The Fantasy and Variations on a Theme by Weber ( aka Fantasia and Variations ) ha a fascinating subtext and will be featured in forthcoming concert . The program also includes an intriguing and now highly poignant work from 2012 by Israeli composer Arie Levanon , who died on October 31 at 91 , called Land of Four Languages.The full lineup includes Orawa by Polish composer Wojciech Kilar , who died in 2013 , Dvorak & rsquo ; s Carnival Overture , and Beethoven & rsquo ; s Violin Concerto in D major , with Vadim Gluzman a soloist.Fantasia and Variations had the perfect marketing springboard regarding the performing artist , debut set , and the hit parade of the time . The original ivory tickler were it composer Mendelssohn and Moscheles , with whom Mendelssohn studied for a while.Lev say the venture wa destined to get the ticket office rolling from the off . & ldquo ; The work is based on a theme by Weber , & rdquo ; Lev explains . The score in question wa riding high in the popularity stake of the day . & ldquo ; It is quite a story . In 1833 , Mendelssohn wa enjoying the best stage of his career . He wa a superstar in England . That wa the country where he wa most admired . & rdquo ; THAT PUBLIC profile led to an offer that wa too good to refuse . & ldquo ; His teacher , Ignaz Moscheles , lived in London . Both were of German Jewish origin and the most idolized piano virtuoso in England and Europe . They were the two great Jewish virtuoso . & rdquo ; That wa also recognized in lofty societal circle . & ldquo ; They were invited to be the key performer in a charity event under the aegis of the royal palace in London . It wa a high-brow charity event , & rdquo ; Lev notes.The organizer sought something that would do justice to the occasion and wow the audience . They chose a proven product and asked the artist to run with it . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; They went for the two biggest musical celebrity . Each performed part of a recital , but the event 's highlight wa when they were asked to jointly prepare something based on one of the hit number at that time : Gypsy March , written by Weber for a musical theater production called Preciosa . Everyone wa mad about Gypsy March . & rdquo ; Back in the early 19th century , classical composer and musician frequently allowed themselves to stray from the compositional straight and narrow . That suited Mendelssohn and Moscheles down to the ground . & ldquo ; They were asked to improvise variation on this theme , the Gypsy March , & rdquo ; say Lev . & ldquo ; They were both excellent improvisers and played like in a jam session ; you take a tune with a chord chart and improvise . & rdquo ; That come across in Fantasia and Variations . & ldquo ; You have one piano playing something elaborate while the other play more in line with the chart , and then they switch . It wa an open approach . & rdquo ; It worked well . & ldquo ; The event wa an amazing success , and they asked them to do it again , & rdquo ; Lev remark , noting that it wa not just a matter of reprising the crowd-pleaser . `` They had more time to plan it for the second event . They were both so busy . They decided to turn the improvisation into a written composition . They also added an orchestra . & rdquo ; Hence , the format for this week & rsquo ; s Tel Aviv and Jerusalem concerts.NOT THAT Mendelssohn and Moscheles were exactly scratching around for work at the time , but , presumably , the response to their effort must have had them rubbing their hand with anticipation of thrilling audience elsewhere . However , a with all good yarn , there wa a dramatic twist . & lsquo ; Shortly after the second concert , the sheet music disappeared , and it wa forgotten . & rdquo ; There wa more drama when Mendelssohn died 14 year after the charity event doubleheader , at only 38 . Undeterred , his partner in box office success decided to make some hay while the sun still filtered through before the memory of the triumph lingered . & ldquo ; Moscheles tried to restore the sheet music , & rdquo ; say Lev . That , it transpired , wa easier said than done . & ldquo ; In fact , he came up with a different composition . He didn & rsquo ; t really manage to restore the original work . & rdquo ; Nevertheless , a they say in certain commercial quarter , you can regain your public profile if you hang around long enough . & ldquo ; Suddenly , they discovered the original manuscript in archive in Saint Petersburg , of all place , & rdquo ; Lev chuckle . That proved to be a game changer.Plenty of elbow grease had to be invested before the work could become a practical proposition for public performance . & nbsp ; That is precisely what Lev and his MultiPiano counterpart & ndash ; Berenika Glixman , Nimrod Meity-Haftel , and Lior Lifshitz & ndash ; have done in the past year or so , in London and Berlin and , a couple of week ago , at Carnegie Hall in New York.Sheet music wa languishing in the archive , and it wa deplorable , just a the international classical community began gearing up for the bicentennial of Mendelssohn & rsquo ; s birth in 2009 . It wa a mess . & ldquo ; There were many thing scribbled on the page and many thing added , and the paper wa in a bad state , & rdquo ; Lev advises . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; They took expert from the state conservatory in Moscow , with expert in ink and paper . Eventually , they had a good copy of the original work 1833 . & rdquo ; All & rsquo ; s well , and that end well . When Lev got wind of the development , he invited the chief restorer of the sheet music to come to Israel to give a talk about the whole process . Much to the quartet leader & rsquo ; s surprise and pleasure , the lecturer gave him the score after the lecture.Lev wa determined to grace the work with commensurate respect and revive public interest . That led to the aforementioned concert worldwide , with the Berlin date filmed and recorded , the recording due out soon on the Hyperion label , and a rendition of an intriguing composition by Moscheles . & ldquo ; We are one of the only ensemble in the world to have a copy of the sheet music and to perform it , & rdquo ; Lev note proudly.Lev : thrilled to play the original work in IsraelLev say he is thrilled to be able to play the original work here . & ldquo ; The concert with the IPO close a lovely circle , after concert in London , Berlin , Carnegie Hall in New York , Tel Aviv and Jerusalem . You could see this is a sort of resurrection of the work , bringing it back to the surface . The audience have responded amazingly so far . We have had standing ovation everywhere . & rdquo ; There is , surely , more rapturous applause due for the ensemble and IPO when they present Fantasia and Variations here . And Levanon should rightly be well received , too . His composition feed off the sound , rhythm , and sensibility of four culture that the Romanian-born composer considered to be core to the State of Israel & mdash ; Hebrew , Yiddish , Arabic , and Ladino.Levanon wrote the piece for MultiPiano , which performs work on two piano for four , six , or eight hand , with or without an orchestra.Lev belief the time is particularly ripe for the work to resound from the concert hall and , hopefully , change mindset & ndash ; and possibly make some difference to the dismal state of regional affair . & ldquo ; When we started touring internationally with MultiPiano , we saw that people don & rsquo ; t know about Israel & rsquo ; s multiculturalism . So we decided we wanted to perform something that would reflect the pluralist face of this country . & rdquo ; Levanon wa up for that . & ldquo ; He composed Land of Four Languages . He chose four traditional tune in different language . His message wa that if the four can live together harmoniously , in the score , maybe they will learn to live together in the real world . & rdquo ; The composition ha been well received thus far , but in the wake of October 7 , Lev feel the cross-cultural creation ha taken on added significance . & ldquo ; After Levanon & rsquo ; s passing , and after everything Israel ha been through in the past few month , the value and message of this work are more relevant than ever . & rdquo ; For ticket and more information : http : / / www.ipo.co.il/en /
title: ' loved but not lost ' : piano ensemble present new classical music restored

Body Text: This week , a number of voice , many of them linked to Israel & rsquo ; s former ruling Likud Party , claimed that the Mughrabi bridge , which link the Temple Mount to an area near the Western Wall and is used by non-Muslims to visit the Temple Mount , is in danger of collapse . Former transportation minister MK Miri Regev said & ldquo ; it is forbidden to wait another moment with the demolition of the bridge and the construction of an appropriate replacement . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; The concern about the bridge ostensibly date from a month ago when an engineer & rsquo ; s report said that the wood the bridge wa constructed with doe not enable safe use of the bridge . This raise question about why the previous government of Benjamin Netanyahu didn & rsquo ; t replace or reinforce the bridge recently , despite being in office for a decade . How did a bridge suddenly become unsafe around the same time Israel got a new government ? Why is there now a new potential crisis at the sensitive holy site ? Did the crisis emerge precisely when the Kingdom of Jordan and Israel are working to repair tie ? Jordan is sensitive to any change to the status quo and previous attempt to alter the bridge have met with protest and also conspiracy spreading about al-Aqsa being in danger . These kind of conspiracy have led to conflict in the past , including the recent Gaza war . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; So how did we get here ? In 2011 , a temporary structure , often called the Mughrabi bridge after an early ramp and neighborhood that once existed underneath the temporary bridge , wa closed due to safety concern . At the time , report said that & ldquo ; official closed the Mugrabi Bridge on Sunday , three day before the municipality deadline to close the ramp leading from the Western Wall plaza to the Temple Mount . The Jerusalem city engineer , Shlomo Eshkol , ha warned over the past year in a series of letter to the prime minister and the Western Wall Heritage Foundation & ndash ; which oversees the area & ndash ; that the temporary bridge is unsafe . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Let & rsquo ; s recall what happened at the time , 10 year ago . & ldquo ; The municipality originally set November 28 , 2011 a the deadline to destroy the bridge , but . . . Netanyahu intervened to stop the demolition , worried about triggering riot across the Arab world . In the most recent letter , sent last week , the municipality insisted the entrance must be closed to the public until a new bridge is built . & rdquo ; Netanyahu chose to cancel the demolition of the bridge because of concern in Egypt and Jordan . The Jerusalem Municipality tried to close the structure on December 12 . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Oddly the issue then disappeared from the headline . Somehow , the unsafe bridge continued to exist with some modification . In 2014 , a new report emerged . A new part of the bridge had been added . & ldquo ; Erected less than two week ago , the bridge had not officially been opened when . . . Netanyahu ordered it be dismantled after it became clear that the project wa not approved by the relevant authority , and amid mounting Jordanian protest . & rdquo ; Once again , the temporary bridge , erected after the ramp collapsed partially in 2004 , had become permanent and any change were seen a a & ldquo ; status quo & rdquo ; issue threatening peace in the region . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; It appears that in 2011 and 2014 the Netanyahu government chose to forego change in order to maintain calm . Now , suddenly , there are call to remove the bridge by member of the same party that didn & rsquo ; t remove it for a decade . This , despite the fact that it is well known that previous change have always resulted in a crisis . Is this controversy about the bridge or creating stumbling block for the new government in tie with Jordan ? Jordan & rsquo ; s Foreign Minister Ayman Safadi ha met his Israeli counterpart in what the Jordan Times call a & ldquo ; semblance of normality . & rdquo ; There is a new deal to supply Jordan with water . Prime Minister Naftali Bennett ha been outspoken on the importance of tie with Jordan . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; For Netanyahu , the Kingdom of Jordan wa always a sour point . He ran into many controversy with the kingdom dating back to his time in office in the 1990s . Netanyahu didn & rsquo ; t make progress on the plan to develop the Arava peace valley with Jordan , and Jordan harshly slammed Israel during the 25-year anniversary of the peace agreement between the country , demanding Israel return land that were part of the agreement . In 2017 , an incident with an Israeli security guard in Jordan , in which two Jordanians were killed , led to another crisis . Most recently , Netanyahu canceled a short trip to the UAE on the eve of election after a stop in Jordan apparently wa nixed . In addition Jordan & rsquo ; s crown prince canceled a trip to Jerusalem in March . Relations were at their lowest point in memory . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Netanyahu ha slammed Jordan in recent day , critiquing the water deal and accusing Jordan of having tie to Iran . The insinuation wa that Jordan had transported oil from Iraq to Egypt and that somehow , this help Iran . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; It is in this context that there are rising call for the government to make change to the Mughrabi bridge . Any chance are likely to cause a crisis . Closing the bridge would anger some of the Jews who visit the Temple Mount weekly . It would also mean non-Muslims could not visit the historic area near the mosque and Dome of the Rock . Any change to the bridge would lead to complaint from Jordan unless there wa coordination . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; There is no doubt the bridge need to be safe , both for those who use it and because it stretch over a part of the woman & rsquo ; s section of the Western Wall . There are many question to be asked why this bridge issue wa never responsibly addressed for more than a decade . It appears convenient that suddenly those who were in office for many year and made no change now want it closed , demolished , changed or removed . Like many thing that took place over the last decade in Israel where problem were managed , or what some call & ldquo ; mowing the grass , & rdquo ; wa done to postpone addressing major issue . The bridge is a symbol of how Jerusalem and Israel were managed . This crisis management meant postponing many major problem , such a dealing with Gaza & rsquo ; s constant crisis , to the issue facing Bedouin in the Negev , to ignoring the crowding at Meron that led to a disaster , and then not investigating it . The current government want to address the issue , but stoking up issue like the Mughrabi bridge appears to be a way to create a crisis with Jordan precisely when Jordan and Israel are keen on working together again . Whether the kingdom might be interested in being flexible regarding the bridge might be address , but such status quo issue usually take time and are sensitive because of the position of the Palestinians and the Wakf and other authority and stakeholder . The King of Jordan is meeting the US president on July 19 . Perhaps responsible policy regarding the bridge will prevail . & nbsp ; & nbsp ;
title: is jerusalem ’ s mughrabi bridge in news to spark jordan crisis ? - analysis

Body Text: The Palestinian Authority accused Israel of carrying out & ldquo ; extra-judicial execution , & rdquo ; and called on the United Nations to provide protection for the Palestinians . Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad ( PIJ ) , meanwhile , called on Palestinians to step up the & ldquo ; resistance & rdquo ; against Israel , in response to the killing of a gunman near Jenin and a woman who tried to stab police officer in the Old City of Jerusalem early Thursday . In the village of Burkin , near Jenin , soldier shot and killed 22-year-old Alaa Zyoud , a member of PIJ & rsquo ; s al-Quds Brigades . Hours later , police officer shot and killed Israa Khuzaimia , a mother of three from Kabatiya , also near Jenin . The woman wa shot while she tried to carry out a stabbing attack near the Temple Mount in Jerusalem . The PLO accused Israel of killing the two & ldquo ; in cold blood , & rdquo ; and called on the international community to assume it responsibility toward & ldquo ; the enforcement of international and humanitarian law in the occupied territory . & rdquo ; The Palestinian Foreign Ministry condemned & ldquo ; in the strongest term the two heinous field execution committed by the occupation force and it police in both Jerusalem and Burkin . & rdquo ; According to the ministry , the killing are the direct result of Prime Minister Naftali Bennett & rsquo ; s evasion of the Palestinian issue during his speech at the UN General Assembly earlier this week . The killing are also & ldquo ; an extension of a long series of criminal field execution order issued by the political and military echelon in the occupying state to it soldier to facilitate the process of shooting at the Palestinians , & rdquo ; the ministry said in a statement . The ministry also condemned settler assault on Palestinians in the Masafar Yatta area near Hebron , claiming they were carried out & ldquo ; under the supervision and protection & rdquo ; of the IDF . & ldquo ; The ministry hold the Israeli government headed by Naftali Bennett fully and directly responsible for these crime and their serious repercussion on the situation in the entire region , & rdquo ; the statement read , urging the UN to provide international protection for the Palestinians . It also called on the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights to establish an investigation committee & ldquo ; for Israeli crime and violation . & rdquo ; The Palestinian Prisoners Club revealed that the IDF arrested 54 Palestinians in the Jenin area since the beginning of September , most of them after the escape of the six security prisoner from Gilboa Prison earlier in the month . The Prisoners Club accused Israel of imposing a policy of & ldquo ; collective punishment & rdquo ; against Palestinians in the Jenin area , including the family of the six escaped inmate . The six were recaptured by Israel Police . PIJ mourned the death of it member , Alaa Zyoud , and pledged to pursue the fight against Israel . It said the increased violence in the West Bank wa & ldquo ; an authentic expression of the will of the Palestinian people who do not accept surrender , and whose resolve is not frustrated by conspiracy . & rdquo ; Responding to Thursday & rsquo ; s killing , Hamas said that & ldquo ; the armed resistance and the comprehensive confrontation with the occupation is capable of stopping it aggression and expelling it settler from our occupied land . & rdquo ;
title: israeli ‘ extra-judicial execution ' slammed by pa , demanding international protection

Body Text: Masa Israel Journey , a leader in global Jewish and Israel-focused programming , is set to solemnly commemorate Remembrance Day with a ceremony at Yad L & rsquo ; Shiryon in Latrun , Israel on Sunday.The ceremony is expected to bring together over 5,000 attendee and countless viewer worldwide , making the event the largest English-language ceremony of it kind , dedicated to honoring the fallen soldier of Israel and victim of terror.This year & rsquo ; s observance of Remembrance Day hold particular significance amidst profound grief and shock following the October 7 Massacre , ongoing conflict , and a concerning surge in global Antisemitism . Under the resonant theme & ldquo ; We Are One , & rdquo ; the ceremony aim to serve a a powerful reminder of the mourning of Jews worldwide , and the resilience needed to rebuild and nurture hope.Stories of valor and sacrifice were set to be shared during the ceremony , highlighting fallen Masa alumnus such Staff-Sergeant Omer Balva , an American-born IDF soldier in the Nahal Brigade , who wa killed on the northern border from Hezbollah fire , and Sergeant Rose Lubin , a Border Police officer from Atlanta , Georgia , who wa killed in a stabbing attack in east Jerusalem . Rose fought and defended Kibbutz Sa'ad on October 7 . Omer 's father , Eyal , will read the Kaddish prayer on behalf of the bereaved family . & nbsp ; Family member of Nathan Leor Hai , originally from France , who wa tragically killed on October 7 , have been invited to light a commemorative torch during the ceremony , that will also see the participation of many bereaved family and representative from the Israeli government and Knesset.The ceremony is also set to pay tribute to Captain Denis Krokhmalov-Veksler , Dr . Daniel Levy , Lucy , Maia and Rina Dee Z '' L , and the victim of the terror attack in the Amia , Jewish Center in Argentina.Additionally , the program includes a mass prayer for the safe return of the hostage , including Andrei Kozlov , a Masa alum from Russia who remains captive in Gaza after being kidnapped at the Nova music festival.Among the distinguished guest that are set to be present at the event are government representative such a Minister of Strategic Affairs , Ron Dermer , and Cabinet Secretary of the Government of Israel , Yossi Fuchs , alongside prominent Jewish leader like Chairman of the Jewish Agency , Major General ( re . ) Doron Almog , Acting CEO of Masa Israel Journey , Yael Sahar Rubinstein , Senior VP of Global Operations & amp ; Director General of JFNA Israel , Rebecca Caspi and CEO and Director General of The Jewish Agency for Israel , Amira Ahronoviz , alongside Masa Fellows and alumni.The ceremony will be broadcast on the Jerusalem Post website . & ldquo ; We Are One people , wherever we are , & rdquo ; emphasized Yael Sahar Rubinstein . & ldquo ; Our Remembrance Day is essential to Israel and the Jewish people , & rdquo ; she added . & ldquo ; This ceremony is for u to focus on the hero , cherish the world they left behind , and try to be worthy of their sacrifice . May their memory be a blessing & rdquo ; . Major General ( Res . ) Doron Almog added , & ldquo ; We will remember the fallen of Israel 's battle with respect , pain , longing , and gratitude . & rdquo ; Masa Israel Journey , founded in 2004 by The Jewish Agency and the government of Israel , ha provided over 200,000 young people from more than 60 country with immersive , long-term educational experience in Israeli society , culture , politics , and history . & nbsp ;

Body Text: Thousands of protester gathered at dozen of location across Israel on Saturday night calling for a hostage deal and election just hour after news of the rescue of the four hostage & ndash ; Noa Argamani , Almog Meir Jan , Andrey Kozlov , and Shlomi Ziv & ndash ; broke.Demonstrators turned up in Tel Aviv , Beersheba , Ra & rsquo ; anana , Haifa , Caesarea , Karkur , Jerusalem , and other location around the country . In Tel Aviv alone , according to organizer , ten of thousand attended.The protest in Tel Aviv ended late Saturday night . According to the Israel Police , several hundred protester violated public order , lit bonfire , and engaged with the police in clash . This resulted in the arrest of 33 of the demonstrator . & nbsp ; Hostages released today told their family member that , while in captivity , they saw the protest and knew that people were fighting for them at home , according to the N12 news site.Organizers used this report a a rallying cry to encourage Israelis to take to the street on Saturday night , and , alongside the celebration of the rescue , continue to fight for the 120 hostage still remaining in Hamas captivity.Mother vow to fightEinav Zangauker spoke at a protest in Tel Aviv , addressing her son , Matan , who is still being held hostage , telling him that she will & ldquo ; not let the prime minister torpedo the [ hostage ] deal . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; My Matan , if you can hear me , I will fight for you day and night . I will not rest and I will not be silent , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; I want to shift from the momentary and important euphoria to the challenge we are facing and the depth of the strategic failure we are in , & rdquo ; said former IDF intelligence chief Lt . - Gen Amos Malka , speaking at a protest in Tel Aviv . & ldquo ; Woe to the captain of the country if they use this uplifting moment for political gain . Blatantly ignoring a strategic , diplomatic possibility would mean missing another lever of pressure and distancing u from the country of the world toward dangerous international isolation , & rdquo ; he added .
title: protester gather across israel , calling for hostage deal , election

Body Text: An Israeli citizen in his 60 who entered Kalkilya on Saturday morning with his car wa shot dead by local resident , according to Palestinian report cited by Israeli media.IDF closed the entrance to Kalkilya following the murder and have begun vehicle check and arrests.According to a security source , the shooting wa a terrorist attack , Kan News later reported Saturday evening.It wa later announced that Amnon Mokhtar , from Petach Tikva , is the Israeli who wa murdered , Israeli medium reported . & nbsp ; A large number of IDF troop entered the city after an Israeli citizen who had entered the city center with his vehicle wa shot at around seven on Saturday morning.The shooting wa carried out on the main street , after which his vehicle wa were set on fire . About an hour ago , the victim wa brought by a medical team of the Red Crescent to the entrance to the city . An IDF medical team pronounced the victim dead.Photos from the scene show his car being set on fire and his driver 's license being taken . Local Palestinians told Israeli medium the car wa torched well after the shooting.The man wa apparently known to local merchant , from whom he would buy vegetable on a regular basis . A bag of vegetable wa found in the man 's car , according to Israeli media.Kalkilya hotspotThis is the third event in Kalkilya in the last 48 hours.On Thursday , an Israeli in his 70 wa robbed and attacked . The paramedic team met him at the Eliyahu checkpoint , where he wa pronounced dead.On Friday afternoon , two Islamic Jihad operative , who were on their way to carry out a terror attack against Israelis , were eliminated by the IDF in Kalkilya.The operation wa carried out after the Shin Bet ( Israel Security Agency ) gathered intelligence that the two intended to carry out an attack soon.As a result , the soldier of the police 's Gideon unit were rushed to the area . After identifying the two , they started an arrest procedure , at the end of which they fired at the two terrorist .
title: for second time this week : local resident of kalkilya murder israeli citizen upon entry into city

Body Text: All the window in the Hamamdeh family & rsquo ; s small stone home are broken . The shattered jagged glass is one of the many visible scar of the violent event that took place in Khirbet al-Mufaqarah on September 28 , when the small , dusty South Hebron Hills Palestinian herding village of some 122 people wa transformed into a battleground that left 12 Palestinians and five settler injured . & ldquo ; All the home are like this , & rdquo ; said Mahmoud Hamamdeh , adding that & ldquo ; this wa a battle for our home . . . . We were attacked with stone and stick . & rdquo ; His three-year-old grandson Muhammad Baker Mahmoud Hamamdeh suffered a head wound in the attack serious enough to require a three-day hospital stay at Soroka-University Medical Center in Beersheba . A week later , dressed in gray pajama and sandal , the brown-haired boy sat on the concrete floor in his home playing with large , multicolored Lego that two Israeli visitor had brought him . The room wa mostly bare . A number of small , thin , colored foam mattress were laid on the floor for seating . Muhammad had fitted the red , green , yellow and blue piece together , a his mother , Bara & rsquo ; a , and his grandfather Mahmoud described how their home wa pelted by stone thrown by Jewish extremist who they presumed were settler . & ldquo ; This is the room where the child hid , & rdquo ; Mahmoud explained , because it steel shutter could provide safety . His grandson Muhammad , however , never made it into the safe room , because he had already been hit by rock that went through two different window of the bedroom he had been napping in . The room wa filled with glass and blood , recalled Mahmoud , explaining that they thought he had died . Mahmoud walked over to the bedroom , where he held up the bloodstained sweatshirt Muhammad had slept in , to underscore how frightening the moment had been . The attack , which occurred about 2 p.m . on the Simhat Torah holiday , is the worst such incident of violence in that West Bank village that anyone can remember . The community is not linked up to an electricity or water grid and is located off a dirt road between the two settler outpost of Avigail and Maon Farm . The three community are all unauthorized , and a a result the status of all three community is tenuous . Both Palestinians and Israelis hold that their right to the land supersede the IDF regulation that govern Area C of the West Bank where they are situated . Area C is under IDF military and civilian rule . Palestinians hold that this land should be part of the permanent border of a Palestinian state , while the Israeli Right belief that this land , which is part of the biblical heartland , should be included within Israel & rsquo ; s sovereign border . PALESTINIAN FLAGS flutter in al-Mufaqarah , and Israeli flag can be seen in Avigail and Maon Farm . The historical narrative of these community differ , a do their language . Similarly , there is a wide gap between their narrative of how and why the attack on the village unfolded . A South Hebron Hills Regional Council spokesman claimed a group of some 20 settler had walked in the morning from Avigail to Maon Farm and were on their way back when they were attacked by Palestinians . There wa only a small army presence in the area , and they took action to defend themselves , he said . The security officer from Maon Farm came to their assistance , and he wa attacked , with rock thrown at his vehicle , the spokesman said . He provided The Jerusalem Post with photo that depict Palestinians holding rock , including one that showed a masked Palestinian with a slingshot . Another photo showed Palestinians beside a building with stone and a stick . Channel 12 posted a video from the event , which showed army soldier during the event accusing a Palestinian & ndash ; Basel Adra , from the area , who volunteer with the left-wing group B & rsquo ; Tselem & ndash ; of setting brush aflame . Channel 12 then added that this wa done so that Palestinians could accuse Jews of setting their village on fire . Adra took to Twitter to debunk the Channel 12 charge , posting a video that showed that the fire in question wa started by a tear-gas canister . & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s a lie . The fire wa caused by an army gas bomb . I literally filmed it , so I have proof . Also , there aren & rsquo ; t any home there & ndash ; just a pile of wood , & rdquo ; Adra tweeted . He added that & ldquo ; I saw the fire , filmed it , and called resident to fetch water . & rdquo ; Initially , he wrote that two soldier helped him , but then another soldier filmed him & ldquo ; to fabricate a false accusation against me . & rdquo ; According to B & rsquo ; Tselem the incident started around 2 p.m . when settler attacked a shepherd in nearby Khirbet a-Rakeez while he wa grazing his flock . B & rsquo ; Tselem alleged that the settler killed four of the shepherd & rsquo ; s goat . Adra said the shepherd called for help , and then a stoning incident broke out between the settler and the Palestinians , with the army arriving shorty after and shooting tear gas and stun grenade at the Palestinians . He charged that , at it height , the event included a many a 80 settler , and that the violence spread beyond al-Mufaqarah and also included attack on some home in his village of al-Tuwani . Violence at this level , he speculated , could occur only if it had been preplanned in an attempt to scare Palestinians into leaving the area . & ldquo ; They don & rsquo ; t want u to live here , & rdquo ; he added . The attacker , he said , vandalized home , vehicle and cut water line . B & rsquo ; Tselem published a video that showed a stoning attack by Jewish extremist against a home in al-Mufaqarah . In the video one can hear the sound of breaking glass and the explosion of stun grenade and tear gas . One settler source blamed the attack on outside Jewish extremist , primarily teen , adding that it wa clear the violence there wa unacceptable and went above and beyond any claim with respect to self-defense . He said that the army and the police have to be the one who take step to prevent the violence . The army declined to be interviewed for the article and the police did not respond a of press time to a request for detail about their investigation into the incident . Police initially arrested six Israelis and one Palestinian in connection with the September 28 event . In an unusual move OC Central Command Maj . - Gen . Yehuda Fox visited al-Mufaqarah last week and spoke with Mahmoud Hamamdeh to learn firsthand about the incident . Palestinians , including Mahmoud , said that from their perspective the incident could not have occurred without the army , which they said wa on the scene almost from the start . The village of al-Mufaqarah is close to the scene of a September 17 incident in which an IDF major and his unit prevented a group of left-wing activist from reaching a small Palestinian hamlet near the Avigail outpost so a to deliver a truckload of water . The soldier were captured on film using what appeared to be undue force to dispel the activist , who had been marching on both side of a narrow paved road that lead to the outpost and that also pass by Khirbet al-Mufaqarah . Less than two week later , it wa this same IDF unit that wa unable to prevent a group of extreme right-wing teenager from reaching al-Mufaqarah and pelting it home and resident with stone . According to the UN , a of October 4 , there have been 264 attack this year by settler and Jewish extremist against Palestinians in the West Bank and east Jerusalem that resulted in property damage and 101 in which there were injury . This is compared to data from all of 2020 in which there were 270 settler and Jewish extremist attack that resulted in property damage and 82 in which there were injury . Separately , UN data showed , 69 Israeli civilian have been injured by Palestinians in the West Bank and east Jerusalem , compared with 16 last year . According to South Hebron Hills Regional Council head Yochai Damri , & ldquo ; There are 1,500 incident of rock-throwing on Jews on the road in the Judea-Samaria area every year . & rdquo ; STILL , A wide-ranging group attack such a the one that occurred last week is rare . Rubber bullet , stun grenade and tear-gas casing are littered in the village . He rolled up his sleeve to show how he had two wound on his arm , which he said were from the stun grenade and tear gas canister that were thrown . Representatives from Avigail and Havat Maon went to visit the boy , Damri said , adding that & ldquo ; I , too , a the local elected leader of our Jewish community , asked the child & rsquo ; s family if I could visit . The family politely refused & ndash ; concerned that the Palestinian Authority would retaliate against them . & rdquo ; Avigail resident Reut Malichi said she had gone to see the three-year-old Muhammad this week , having already visited him at Soroka last week a well . Israelis and Palestinians in this area live together , side by side , and have to be good neighbor , even though they hold diametrically opposed belief , including on their relationship to the land , Malichi said . The Palestinians do not recognize the State of Israel and do not want the Jews living on land that they hold belongs to them , she added . In turn , she said , & ldquo ; we are Zionists and we are returning to . . . the land of the Bible . & rdquo ; Initially , Malichi said , she wa unaware of the attack , a she celebrated the holiday with her family , with a barbecue lunch after service , which included her mother and some of her sibling . Malichi learned about the violence , she said , mostly after the fact . She blamed the incident on a group of teenager that visited the community for the holiday , explaining that it did not represent the people of Avigail itself . The teenager were not properly supervised , she explained . Already when she met them over the holiday , she feared for a situation that could get out of control . Malichi wa also able to speak with the teenager after the incident , so she said she understands that & ldquo ; they did terrible thing . & rdquo ; Malichi added , & ldquo ; I am embarrassed to tell you what they told me , and it can not be justified . & rdquo ; She ha already warned her own teenage son that if he ever engages in such activity , she will personally turn him in to the police . & ldquo ; I can understand why Palestinians threw stone & rdquo ; in response , & rdquo ; she said . This is not how Jews or the resident of Judea and Samaria should behave , she said . Israelis living here should be a force for peace . & ldquo ; Nothing like that ha happened here before , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; This land can no longer tolerate the blood , the hate , and we have to help it love u . Body Text: & nbsp ; Portugal would relocate it embassy to Jerusalem only when the city is the capital of both the State of Israel and the state of Palestine , Portuguese Foreign Minister Santos Silva told The Jerusalem Post during his two-day visit . His country ha no plan to follow the United States on this issue , he said a he sat on the veranda of Jerusalem @ @ @ s King David Hotel , located in the western part of the city . Portugal would contemplate such a move he said , only on & quot ; the day when I can put the two embassy in Jerusalem , the embassy of Portugal in Israel and the embassy of Portugal in Palestine . & quot ; When asked if he considered that the location where he sat wa part of Israel , he said , & quot ; I think it is a matter of fact . & quot ; But when it came to the question of whether he considered Jerusalem to be Israel @ @ @ s capital , he said carefully , & quot ; You know the Portuguese Embassy is in Tel Aviv . & quot ; Silva arrived in Israel late Sunday night , on the sideline of a much more publicized visit by US White House senior adviser Jared Kushner on Monday , followed by a departure Tuesday of a joint Israeli-US delegation to Morocco to sign the initial document with regard to the normalization of tie between Jerusalem and Rabat . Silva braved the COVID-19 pandemic to travel visit Israel and the Palestinian territory just day before the Christmas holiday , a part of his preparatory work in advance of his country @ @ @ s January ascendancy to the presidency of Council of the European Union . It @ @ @ s a rotating half year position , which his country will take over from Germany . Germany used that position to attempt to sooth over tension between the EU and Israel on two major issue ; the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and Iran . It invited Foreign Minister Gabi Ashkenazi to a meeting of his EU counterpart and spoke of reconvening the EU-Israel Association Council , which last met in 2012 . Silva in Jerusalem spoke of the need for warm Israel-EU tie and of the importance of an EU-Israel Association Council meeting . He noted the point of disagreement with Israel but said that he wanted to address issue from a place of dialogue . In a manner similar to the Germans , he said that Israel @ @ @ s pledge to suspend the annexation of West Bank settlement in exchange for normalization deal with the Untied Arab Emirates and Bahrain had opened the door for improved Israel-EU relation a well . & quot ; It wa important that the normalization process meant suspension of the annexation plan , & quot ; Silva said when he spoke with the Post on Monday night . & quot ; It allowed u to see future conversation and cooperation with Israel in a much more positive way , & quot ; Silva said . He warned that should Israel backtrack on that pledge , the potential of improved Israel-EU tie would be harmed . & quot ; It would be a huge problem for u . It would be an obstacle for deepening the cooperation between the two entity , & quot ; he said . It wa explained to him , Silva said , that & quot ; normalization wa the opposite of annexation . & quot ; Silva spoke positively of the US-brokered Abraham Accords under whose rubric Israeli-Arab deal have been reached . Silva said the Accords breathed life new life into the region and the frozen peace process with the Palestinians . The entry of US President-elect Joe Biden to the White House would also open new possibility in that sphere , he said . & quot ; We have to look carefully at the recent change in the region , and then we have to create condition for the relaunch of direct negotiation between Israelis and Palestinians , & quot ; he said . & quot ; Palestinians and Israelis & quot ; need this , Silva said , adding that the EU want to help facilitate this process . It wa a message that he carried with him when he went to Ramallah on Tuesday before flying back to Portugal in the late afternoon . Palestinian Authority Prime Minister Muhammed Shtayyeh and PA Foreign Minister Riyad Malki both asked that Portugal unilaterally recognize Palestinian statehood . It @ @ @ s a request that Portugal ha rebuffed because it belief that such a step should only be taken by consensus with the entire European Union , and at present the bloc is divided on the issue . The Portuguese parliament ha called on it government to recognize Palestinian statehood ; But to date the EU and the Portuguese government hold that Palestinian statehood recognition could only come upon completion of a final status agreement for a two-state resolution to the conflict . But Portugal and the EU agree with the PA that the contour of a two-state solution should be based on the pre-1967 line with east Jerusalem a the Palestinian capital . Both Portugal and the EU oppose Israeli settlement activity . Silva spoke with Post about this disagreement , explaining that his country and the EU oppose all settlement activity and the Israeli practice of demolishing illegal Palestinian structure . & quot ; We have to pursue our Israeli friend not to pursue the demolition , & quot ; Silva said , adding that he wa particularly concerned by Israel @ @ @ s demolition of EU-funded structure for Palestinians . The EU @ @ @ s decision to pursue such building without permit , which are difficult to obtain , ha been a point of contention between the EU and Israel . He noted that despite the disagreement with Israel , he held the relation between the two country to be very important , both because of the historic tie , and because of the contemporary tie and similar characteristic . & quot ; We are close country , & quot ; he said .
title: portuguese fm : we @ @ @ ll move embassy when jerusalem is capital of two state

Body Text: The Meir Amit Intelligence and Terrorism Information Center on Monday published a report explaining why Hamas did not fire rocket in response to the Jerusalem flag march last month , despite threatening to do so.The decision to back off it threat wa multipronged , according to the intelligence center & rsquo ; s report , which wa prepared by former senior Israeli intelligence people who have ongoing contact with current Israeli intelligence officials.The reasonsFirst , Hamas said it had succeeded in getting Israel to change the path of the march to a less provocative one a far a al-Aqsa Mosque wa concerned . Even though Israel never intended that the flag march route would go near the mosque , Hamas made the statement for propaganda purpose , the report said.Second , Hamas said Israel wa extraordinarily well prepared both because it wa carrying out a major national IDF training exercise and wa on heightened security alert following the Hamas threat . This meant that Hamas would be unable to achieve a surprise a it did in May 2021.Third , Hamas said many country had begged it not to fire rocket . Although the Gaza Strip & rsquo ; s ruler said they had not been influenced by these appeal , their spin doctor put forth the communication a evidence of the increased stature of the organization in the region.As time went on , Hamas became more defensive a it endured more verbal attack from various group in Gaza for having failed to follow through on it threat.Hamas restated some of it original defense for not having attacked in a more apologetic manner , but it also said it wa not the right time to put the Gaza Strip through an entire wide round of conflict with Israel following the May 2021 war.Hamas official said the terrorist group did fire eight rocket on May 28 , the day before the flag march , into the sea , demonstrating that it still had rocket-firing capabilities.Israel responded to that demonstration by sending message to Hamas that it had no intention of escalating the flag march issue , but if Hamas actually fired on Israel , it would face extreme repercussions.Part of Hamas & rsquo ; s problem wa that it leader in the Gaza Strip , Yahya Sinwar , made a very strong speech on April 30 that appeared to directly commit it to conflict with Israel.Ultimately , Hamas & rsquo ; s true intention were not to get Gaza drawn into another conflict , but rather to try to incite east Jerusalem resident , Arab-Israelis and West Bank Palestinians into a conflict with Israel over the flag march , the Meir Amit Center said.In addition , though it is still too early to say , the spring spike in terrorist attack seemed to wane in mid - and late May , and this may have influenced any Hamas plan to inflame the situation , the report said .
title: why didn ’ t hamas fire rocket at the jerusalem flag march ? - intel report

Specifically , the book described & ldquo ; the Jews are people of treachery and betrayal , & rdquo ; emphasizing that & ldquo ; they are always like this & rdquo ; and asked student to use the internet to search for Qur & rsquo ; anic verse about & ldquo ; the treachery of the Jews . `` The textbook also didn & rsquo ; t refer to & lsquo ; Israel & rsquo ; , rather substituted the name for & ldquo ; enemy & rdquo ; and & ldquo ; usurping Jews . & rdquo ; Under the new version of the textbook , lesson celebrate an underlining tolerance and coexistence between Jews and Muslims.IMPACT-se Marcus Sheff commented that & ldquo ; The fiftieth anniversary of the Yom Kippur War give opportunity to reflect on Israel-Egyptian relation today . Body Text: Israel will not hold discussion with Jordan about the status quo on the Temple Mount in the coming week in light of Amman & rsquo ; s incitement against Israel , a senior Israeli diplomatic official said on Thursday.The official referred to Jordanian Prime Minister Bisher Al-Khasawneh & rsquo ; Body Text: For the 19th consecutive year , Bank Hapoalim 's Passover project is set to offer a cultural feast across Israel . The initiative also celebrates Israel 's defense heritage with free entry to Defense Ministry museum , including the Hagana Museum and the Palmach House.This year 's event coincides with the anniversary of the ' Iron Swords ' war , honoring the IDF and security force by granting access to additional defense-related site . The project 's extensive offering also include tour through historical landscape and modern exhibition , from the hanging rope bridge in Nesher Park to the blossoming trail of Nahal Oran.For those interested in science and nature , attraction like the Plantaniya Science and Space Center and the Museum of Biblical Lands provide informative and engaging educational experience . Historical tour such a `` From David to David `` in Jerusalem offer a deep dive into the nation 's rich past.The project also emphasizes support for small business and local tourism , with eight site in the Shkama Beshor area providing unique experience like glassblowing workshop at Ron Art Judaica and the heritage-rich Iron Sheep Museum in Kibbutz Tze'elim.Pre-register , do n't just show upPre-registration is mandatory for all visit , ensuring organized and safe access to all site according to the guideline set by the Home Front Command . Body Text: THERE & rsquo ; S A changing of the guard at Hadassah Academic College where Prof . Ariela Gordon-Shaag is succeeding Prof . Bertold Fridlender , who ha held the position for the past 12 years.Gordon-Shaag will officially take up her position on July 1.HAC ha grown considerably over the past decade , offering BA and MA degree and doubling it student population , which now stand in excess of 4,500.Gordon-Shaag completed her BA in 1990 at Columbia University with a major in chemistry ( magna cum laude ) . She earned her MSc and PhD in 2002 at the Hebrew University , specializing in genetics and molecular biology.Her interest in vision science developed during her post-doctoral training at the University of Washington and continued at the Hebrew University , where she studied phototransduction.In 2007 , she established HAC & rsquo ; s master & rsquo ; s program in optometry and directed it until 2013 . She subsequently became the chairperson of the Department of Optometry at the college , serving in that position from 2014-2023 . She wa recently appointed chair of the Interdisciplinary Faculty for Sciences , Health and Society.Gordon-Shaag & rsquo ; s current research interest are in the cornea , keratoconus , and the etiology of myopia . She ha published numerous scientific paper in peer-reviewed journal on these topics.Her study in environmental and behavioral factor associated with myopia have been aided by a grant from the Binational Science Foundation.In recent year , HAC ha undergone significant development in it curriculum and research project and is now in the process of planning future strategies.Gordon-Shag is a great believer in innovation and ha taken innovative approach in her own research.Purim fun in Jerusalem ■ BEARING IN mind that Purim this year will not be quite a merry a festival a usual , Danny Bonfil , chairman of the Jerusalem district division of the Histadrut labor federation , and Avi Edery , CEO of Cinema City , put their head together to devise a memorable and exciting Purim event , designed particularly to bring some cheer to all the displaced child in Jerusalem who were evacuated from their home . They came up with & ldquo ; Fantasy in the Circus & rdquo ; directed by Yaniv Suissa , which is part of a larger carnival and will thrill both adult and child & ndash ; thereby making it a family affair . It will , of course , be open to the permanent resident of Jerusalem . Entrance is free of charge , which is a real boon to parent of large families.A tribute to a late president ■ THE ENGLISH-SPEAKING Sophie Udin Club of Na & rsquo ; amat will hold a memorial tribute to it late president Judy Telman at 1 p.m . on Wednesday , March 27.Telman , who spent more than half of her life in Chicago , came on aliyah in 1983 , joined the Sophie Udin Club and spent many year a it president , continuing until her death on February 26 at the age of 92 . Her friend say that even a she lay dying in hospital , she continued to care for Na & rsquo ; amat and it fundraising project , and to direct the operation of the club.She wa particularly interested in raising fund for project that help advance and strengthen the status of woman in the family , in the workforce , and in society.The tribute luncheon , at the Meshanot building & ndash ; corner of Shalom Aleichem and Jabotinsky street , where Telman wa such a frequent presence over the year & ndash ; will be addressed by Na & rsquo ; amat National President Chagit Pe & rsquo ; er ; International Coordinator Shirli Shavit ; and head of Jerusalem Na & rsquo ; amat Ilana Daniel . Telman & rsquo ; s son Muki Telman , who life at Kibbutz Grofit , and Edith Paller , representing the Sophie Udin Chapter , will also speak.Jewish heroine ■ OPINION IS divided a to whether Mordechai or Esther is the true hero of Purim , although conventional wisdom ha credited Esther with being the savior of her people . But hero and heroine often depend on how much one know of the story . There are some who would give kudos to Vashti , who defied the king by refusing to appear at his banquet . It & rsquo ; s not certain whether she wa banished or executed by way of punishment , but suffice it to say that she disappeared , and the path wa open for Esther . History might have turned out quite differently had Vashti been more obedient . In fact , there would not be a Purim on which to celebrate.Esther wa neither the first nor the last of Jewish heroine . We have seen ample evidence of that in the current Swords of Iron war.Many book have been written about outstanding Jewish woman . Some have focused on only one ; others , on a group . Former MK Aliza Lavie recently published her book Iconic Jewish Women : Fifty-nine inspiring , courageous , revolutionary role model for young girl . A launch wa held in Jerusalem on Monday night at which Lavie engaged in conversation with Elana Sztokman and Yudit Sidikman . Body Text: The IDF shot down a drone belonging to Hezbollah which wa heading from Lebanon towards Israel 's territorial water last week , just day before three drone were shot down while headed towards the Karish gas field off the coast of northern Israel , the IDF Spokesperson 's Unit announced on Wednesday.The drone wa dropped a far distance from the maritime border , without posing a threat or danger to Israel.Earlier on Wednesday , the Lebanese Al-Akhbar news reported that Hezbollah had launched a drone towards the gas field last Wednesday , three day before three drone belonging to the terrorist movement were shot down by the IDF.Hezbollah-affiliated Al-Manar TV reporter Ali Shoeib claimed on Wednesday that the drone wa not downed and returned without being hit.On Saturday , the IDF announced that it had shot down three unmanned aerial vehicle launched by Hezbollah toward Israel & rsquo ; s economic water over the Mediterranean Sea.One of the three UAVs wa shot down by an F-16 and two others were downed by the naval Barak 8 medium-range surface-to-air missile system on the INS Eilat , marking the first time the system wa used against aerial threats.The UAVs were identified at an early stage in their flight by the IDF , monitored throughout their flight and intercepted at the most appropriate operational point by the fighter jet and missile ship.Maritime border demarcation talk continueThe latest report of a drone being intercepted come amid continuing effort by Israel and Lebanon to reach an agreement concerning the demarcation of the maritime border between the two country in indirect talk mediated by the US.Lebanese President Michel Aoun stated on Wednesday that a solution regarding the maritime border demarcation negotiation with Israel would be reached soon , saying `` I believe that we have reached an understanding with the Americans who are mediator between u and Israel , `` according to Lebanese medium . `` The result of the demarcation will be positive for the benefit of both party , and if the atmosphere wa not positive , we would not have followed the negotiation process , `` added Aoun.On Tuesday , Hezbollah-allied Free Patriotic Movement head Gebran Bassil stated that there is a `` serious opportunity `` in the maritime border talk and that the gap in the dispute wa narrowing , but stressed that the solution are `` still not clear `` and that Lebanon should insist on an equation in which Israel would get the Karish gas field if Lebanon get the Qana gas field . `` Most importantly , the demarcation is to allow u to dig , and this is the right time for Lebanon to implement just diplomatic solution for it , while using it strength , and we are not weak , `` said Bassil.Lebanese official have expressed outrage at Hezbollah 's launching of drone towards the gas field , stressing that the country is committed to avoiding provocation during negotiation . `` Lebanon considers that any action outside the framework of the state 's responsibility and the diplomatic context in which the negotiation are happening is unacceptable and expose ( Lebanon ) to unnecessary risk , `` a statement by the office of Prime Minister-designate Najib Mikati office said on Monday.Lebanese medium reported earlier this week that US mediator Amos Hochstein had warned Lebanese official that the drone launch could harm the negotiations.Anna Ahronheim contributed to this report .
title: idf shot down additional hezbollah drone last week

Body Text: White Bird is a new Holocaust drama that open in theater around Israel on Thursday , book-ended by a framing device that feature Helen Mirren , and most of it is gracefully done and quite moving.Based on a novel by R.J . Palacio , the author of the best-selling Wonder , which is referenced at the beginning , it ha moment of heavy kitsch toward the end , but by then you may be so caught up in the story , that you can forgive the lapse . & nbsp ; Were the narrator who tell the story in the framing device anyone other than the incomparable Mirren , one of the greatest actress of all time , White Bird wouldn & rsquo ; t have worked nearly a well a it doe . & nbsp ; What is White Bird about ? The movie open with a short section showing Julian ( Bryce Gheisar ) , Mirren & rsquo ; s grandson , starting at a new , fancy private school in New York . This actor played the same character in Wonder , a bully who tormented the hero because of his facial deformity . At the end of Wonder , he is being transferred to a new school , and in the opening of White Bird , we see him coming home , feeling dejected after a day at that school . The cool kid have rejected him , leading him to be mean to an earnest , uncool minority student who invite him to a political club . When he get into his apartment , he hears a noise and is startled , not expecting anyone , since his parent are usually out at rich people & rsquo ; s fundraiser . As soon a he see that the unexpected visitor is his grandmother , played by Mirren , we are a pleased to see her a he is . & nbsp ; She know the story of how he bullied the other boy and wa made to switch school , and she chides him for being & ldquo ; unkind . & rdquo ; In order to explain to him the importance of kindness , she say she & rsquo ; d like to tell him a story about her girlhood in France during World War II , and we settle down happily because if you can & rsquo ; t see Mirren on screen every moment , the next best thing is hearing her voice . & nbsp ; We then move into the main part of the story , which focus on his grandmother , Sara ( Ariella Glaser ) at the age of 15 , when she wa living in a village in the Alsatian region of France in the early 1940s , where the Nazis were in control but were not harming Jews & ndash ; at first . Sara & rsquo ; s mother ( Olivia Ross ) is a teacher and her father ( Ishai Golan , who is very good in a small role ) is a surgeon , and she ha a comfortable life . Popular at school , she hang out with her girlfriend , ha a crush on the handsomest guy in the class , and is a gifted artist . Her teacher advises her to embrace her artistic gift and not hide her true self . & nbsp ; But soon , there is no hiding the fact that she is Jewish , and after antisemitic law are passed , her father make a plan for them to flee . Before he can put his plan into effect , the Nazis and French collaborator stage a roundup of Jews at Sara & rsquo ; s school . Hiding in the wood , she is approached by Julien ( Orlando Schwerdt ) , a classmate with a limp due to polio , whose father is a workman , who brings her to see his parent ( Gillian Anderson and Jo-Stone Fewings ) , who embrace her unquestioningly and hide her in their barn . They would have taken her into their home but are afraid that their taciturn upstairs neighbor are Nazi supporter . & nbsp ; The heart of the film is the connection that form between Sara and Julien a she realizes she wa wrong to have teased him with her friend and begin to see that she wa spoiled and led a privileged existence up until the Nazi takeover . Julien is considerate and bright , and they begin to fall in love , a they sit in his parent & rsquo ; old car , which is parked in the barn , and imagine they are taking trip around the world . There is a white bird that fly in & ndash ; hence the title & ndash ; and they see it a a harbinger of better time . The young lead are very appealing and this section is lovely , although we know it can & rsquo ; t last . & nbsp ; As White Bird move along , I couldn & rsquo ; t help wishing that the movie had allowed it compelling , mostly young cast and the power of it story to carry the drama , without resorting , in the final 15 minute or so , to speech that are so literal they are unnecessary and annoying and a few other quasi-supernatural flourish , almost a magic realism approach . I know this sort of storytelling ha it fan , but I feel that in a Holocaust narrative , it & rsquo ; s more effective and more honest to stick close to the truth . However , I understand that this is meant to be a film that will attract teen and tweens , a well a their parent , and so an approach that showed the horror in a realistic way & ndash ; like in the movie , & nbsp ; Son of Saul & ndash ; wa not in the card here . Everyone speaks English with slight accent , too , and you just have to accept that . & nbsp ; Despite it flaw , it doe not trivialize the Holocaust , and just barely manages to avoid being part of that mini-genre I have named & ldquo ; Feel-Good Holocaust Films . & rdquo ; There have been other Holocaust movie that have made egregious and dishonest evasion , softening the horror in a misguided attempt to attract audience , such a The Boy in the Striped Pajamas or La Rafle ( & ldquo ; The Round Up & rdquo ; ) , which wa also set in France . I wrote about La Rafle , in a review titled , & ldquo ; The Good , the Bad , and the Cute , & rdquo ; that , & ldquo ; A viewer who knew nothing of the true event of World War II would think there wa a guardian angel that looked out for sweet young child . & rdquo ; In White Bird , at least , it is clear that innocent people , even very cute one , suffered terribly at the hand of the Nazis and their collaborator , and even paid with their life . The two likable young lead and Mirren elevate this to a film that doe have genuinely touching moment and I hope it will be seen by the young viewer it seems to have been made for . & nbsp ;
title: ' white bird ' : a holocaust movie saved by helen mirren - review

attack near Jalma in the Menashe region.عاجل | مصادر عبرية : طيران الاحتلال قصف مركبة فلسطينية شمال جنين . pic.twitter.com/doIVMyzOLT & mdash ; شبكة قدس الإخبارية ( @ qudsn ) June 21 , 2023According to the statement , this same terror cell ha recently carried out a number of shooting attack throughout Judea and Samaria.Once the cell wa identified , the IDF gave a rapid order to have the drone Body Text: As the condition of the IDF troop seriously wounded in the anti-Hamas operation in the West Bank continue to improve , a senior IDF medical officer said that the two men might not have survived if not for the quick thinking of the paramedic who treated them . & ldquo ; They got the most advanced medical treatment in the world , & rdquo ; the senior officer said . & ldquo ; Those two men , anywhere else in the world , would have likely died before getting to the hospital . The chance of getting to the hospital alive were really small . & rdquo ; Rambam Health Care Campus in Haifa , where the two men are being treated , announced Monday that their condition were improving . One of them regained consciousness and is expected to be removed from a ventilator , and ha communicated with his family . The other is scheduled to undergo a lengthy operation for his wound . The two troop , a platoon commander and his soldier , were seriously injured during a firefight in the West Bank village of Burkin when they engaged armed Palestinian terrorist . The IDF & rsquo ; s preliminary investigation is looking into the circumstance surrounding their injury but is leaning towards the possibility that they were injured by friendly fire . One of the men wa shot in the chest and lost one of his lung while the other man wa shot in the jaw and stomach . The two are also suffering from shrapnel wound . & ldquo ; They were very seriously injured . . . and from the moment they were shot , the 18-year-old EMT-P went straight to treat them . The time we have to get to an injured person and give them medical treatment is second , & rdquo ; the officer said , adding that while & ldquo ; most army around the world have their paramedic in the back , in the IDF they are in the front . & rdquo ; According to the officer , Sgt . T controlled the hemorrhaging of the soldier to stop their bleeding , performed a chest drainage , and intubated one of the men . The paramedic also did three additional thing that saved the life of the troop : he provided freeze-dried plasma , gave them TXA and actively decided only to intubate one of them . The powdered , freeze-dried plasma given to the troop helped to clot their blood and prevented the badly wounded men from bleeding to death on the battlefield . TXA ( tranexamic acid ) meanwhile help to stabilize the patient by coagulating the blood . Both were carried in the vest of the paramedic . Then he chose to go outside the protocol and not to do something . & ldquo ; Our reflex is to go to someone who is severely injured and intubate them . But , what we & rsquo ; ve found over the last decade is that such a decision is not always best . If you have a bleeding problem then intubation might help , but if you are bleeding and have low blood pressure it can actually harm the patient , & rdquo ; the senior officer said . & ldquo ; We & rsquo ; ve found that with specific type of casualty , intubation actually hastens their death because you put pressure on the lung and heart and reduce their already low blood pressure even more . & rdquo ; Had Sgt . T intubated the second man who had been shot in the lung , & ldquo ; he might not have made it to the hospital . & rdquo ; It wa a & ldquo ; very challenging scenario & rdquo ; and the paramedic & ldquo ; did a really great job under fire , & rdquo ; the senior medical officer said . & ldquo ; We all do our best to save our troop . There & rsquo ; s no technology in the world that we don & rsquo ; t use . We are very aggressive in adopting new technology and even admitting when we are wrong . We keep on changing , all the time . & rdquo ; According to the officer , it took approximately an hour from the time the two were injured until they reached Rambam in Haifa . They were evacuated by helicopter and given several whole blood transfusion while en route . When they reached the hospital , their Ph level wa so severe that their life were at risk . & ldquo ; Just imagine what their state could have been had they not received all the treatment that they did in the field . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; IDF Chief of Staff Lt . - Gen . Aviv Kohavi visited the two injured soldier on Monday and told their family that the two are & ldquo ; warrior & rdquo ; who showed & ldquo ; great courage & rdquo ; during the operation . & ldquo ; It is important for you to know that if we had not stopped this network , of the Hamas terrorist organization , they would have been at an advanced stage and would have carried out attack in Israeli city , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; Your son prevented these attack . & rdquo ;
title: condition of wounded idf soldier improves in hospital

Body Text: The Knesset National Security Committee held a meeting on Wednesday to examine action to & ldquo ; prevent harm to an elected official at a demonstration or protest near his house , & rdquo ; following stormy protest since last week against the government and in favor of a hostage deal.The session , which wa convened at the request of Likud MK Amit Halevy , came two day after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu headed a meeting on the same subject with National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir , Justice Minister Yariv Levin , Israel & rsquo ; s police commissioner , and other minister . The Prime Minister & rsquo ; s Office did not put out a statement on the content of Monday & rsquo ; s meeting.A number of minister and Knesset member from the coalition publicly criticized protest group last week after a torch wa thrown at a police cavalry officer and after protester succeeded in evading the police and approaching Netanyahu & rsquo ; s private residence on Aza Street in Jerusalem . Some argued that the prime minister & rsquo ; s life had been in danger , but the Israel Police denied this . On Saturday night , a man rammed into protester in Tel Aviv , injuring five people.Netanyahu addressed the event in remark at the beginning of Sunday & rsquo ; s government meeting , saying that & ldquo ; most of the people , including me , condemn violence among u & ndash ; rioting and lawlessness , ramming into protester or attacking police officer , reckless and violent incitement for murder on social medium . & rdquo ; Police data show 141 elected official are currently designated a threatened & nbsp ; According to data presented by Dep . - Ch . Shlomi Sagi , head of the police & rsquo ; s operation division , during Wednesday & rsquo ; s Knesset National Security session , 141 elected official are currently designated a being & ldquo ; threatened . & rdquo ; Sagi added that according to the law , citizen do not need approval from the police to demonstrate , but do need approval for marches.He also rejected claim by Knesset member from the coalition that the police were conducting selective enforcement and not doing enough to prevent law-breaking during the anti-government protest , stating that & ldquo ; the police is not interested in which side the protester are , but that all who participate return home safely , while maintaining the balance between the freedom of assembly and the freedom of movement of the general public . & rdquo ; Knesset member from the opposition criticized the topic of the session . Labor MK Gilad Kariv argued that the session should focus not on the protester but on police use of force against the protester . Yesh Atid MK Karin Elharrar added that violence on all side must be condemned , and that she did not hear condemnation from member of the coalition of the ramming incident . & ldquo ; I understand that you are having a hard time , it is not pleasant when people demonstrate against you . On the other hand , freedom of expression and the right to demonstrate is a fundamental value in democracy . & rdquo ; Other Knesset member from the opposition pointed out that at the same time a the National Security Committee session , a Knesset caucus to support the hostage being held by Hamas in Gaza wa also meeting , but that while over five Knesset coalition member attended the committee session , only one Knesset member from the coalition attended the caucus session & ndash ; the caucus & rsquo ; s co-chair , Likud MK Boaz Bismuth .
