Body Text: Israel and the US have targeted Iranian-backed force in Syria over the last several day , according to report . The airstrikes on Sunday evening triggered Syrian air defense , according to Iranian regime medium . The strike may have been in response to an attack on an Israeli-owned vessel in the Gulf of Oman . & nbsp ; Last week , in response to an attack on US military force in Iraq , the US also carried out airstrikes in Syria . The US said that President Joe Biden had ordered the strike against Iranian-backed militant group in eastern Syria . The strike were authorized a a response to attack against American and coalition personnel in Iraq . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Specifically , the strike destroyed multiple facility located at a border control point used by a number of Iranian-backed military group , including Kataib Hezbollah and Kataib Sayyid al-Shuhada , & rdquo ; the US said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; It wa a deliberate and planned retaliation , & rdquo ; the US said in an unambiguous message , adding that it would act to protect American personnel . & nbsp ; The report of Israeli airstrikes on Sunday in Syria come in the wake of the visit by US Central Command Air Force Commander Lt . - Gen . Gregory Guillot to Israel on Friday . The visit underpinned & ldquo ; strategic cooperation with American force , & rdquo ; IAF Commander Maj . - Gen . Amikam Norkin said . & nbsp ; The double blow to Iran from the US and Israel is not the first time Iran ha been hit in Syria by both country . Israel had carried out more than 1,000 airstrikes against Iranian target in Syria , according to January 2019 report . That number is likely closer to 1,500 airstrikes by now . The US carried out retaliatory airstrikes against Iranian-backed force in Syria in December 2019 after an attack that killed a contractor at K-1 base in Iraq . & nbsp ; In January , US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo acknowledged US intelligence support for Israeli airstrikes in Syria , according to Al-Monitor , a Washington-based news website . Can the US force Iran out of Syria , pondered Jared Szuba in a piece at Al-Monitor last December . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Are we ever going to get to a place where Iran doe not have force in Syria ? & rdquo ; Michael Mulroy , a former US deputy assistant secretary of defense for the Middle East , asked during a think-tank event on December 17 , the report noted . & ldquo ; I mean , people that are smarter on this than I have told me , no , that & rsquo ; s not going to happen . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Mulroy , a veteran CIA paramilitary officer who worked on Syria during his time at the Pentagon , suggested that minimizing Tehran & rsquo ; s influence in the Levant should remain a US goal , & rdquo ; Szuba wrote . & ldquo ; & lsquo ; Maybe we should have a smarter take to it , & rsquo ; he added . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; It is known that the US under the previous administration , including national security advisor John Bolton and secretary of state Mike Pompeo , sought to support Israel & rsquo ; s action regarding Iran & rsquo ; s entrenchment in Syria . & nbsp ; Iran rapidly increased entrenchment since 2018 , and Iran & rsquo ; s force have suffered accordingly . A strike in June 2018 hit a KH headquarters in Albukamal . Iraqi medium at the time , reporting statement by the pro-Iranian Hashd al-Shaabi , blamed the US and Israel for the strike . & nbsp ; IN AN interview in January , former US Syria envoy James Jeffrey showcased how Israel and the US are working together in Syria . In Foreign Affairs , the former American envoy on Syrian policy said : & ldquo ; US-supported Israeli strike on Iranian target in the country further limited the [ Syrian ] regime & rsquo ; s military option . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Jeffrey also told Szuba in an interview for Al-Monitor about the US support for Israeli airstrikes in Syria . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The US only began supporting that when I came on board , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; I went out there and we saw Prime Minister [ Benjamin ] Netanyahu and others , and they thought that they were not being supported enough by the US military , and not by intelligence . And there wa a big battle within the US government , and we won the battle . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The argument [ against supporting Israel & rsquo ; s campaign ] wa , again , this obsession with the counterterrorism mission . People didn & rsquo ; t want to screw with it , either by worrying about Turkey or diverting resource to allow the Israelis to muck around in Syria , a maybe that will lead to some blowback to our force . It hasn & rsquo ; t . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Supporting Israel in Syria wa a pillar of US policy on Syria . & nbsp ; The changeover in US administration in January led to many question about whether the US would continue to support Israel & rsquo ; s freedom of action in Syria and also whether the US would respond to Iranian attack . Now we know that the support appears to be continuing and that both Israel and the US are willing to strike Iranian-backed force or threat in Syria . & nbsp ; Linking Syria to Iran & rsquo ; s attack elsewhere is a key aspect of the strike over the last several day . That mean Iran may be getting a message that if it doe something in the Gulf of Oman , it militia could be targeted 2,000 kilometer away . The US appears to have said the same thing . & nbsp ; The idea that the militia unit in Syria are responsible for guiding policy that target a ship in the Gulf of Oman or strike at a sensitive location in Erbil appears overwrought . It is the linkage and messaging and context of US support for Israeli action in Syria that is important . & nbsp ; David Shor , who commentates on regional issue , noted on Twitter in a thread on the attack : & ldquo ; Time will tell before we can ascertain precisely what wa attacked tonight in Syria , and whether these target can be differentiated at all from the hundred of others targeted over the year in Syria . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; That is a key point , beyond the linkage , of what the strike have hit and whether this matter to Iran . & nbsp ; Airstrikes have long been part of a larger Clausewitz-style , air-power diplomacy in the region , whereby an action in one place result in a reaction in another . & nbsp ; For instance , Iran wa establishing a permanent military base in Syria at Al-Kiswah , a & ldquo ; Western intelligence source & rdquo ; told the BBC in November 2017 . Al-Kiswah ha been struck several time since then , in May 2018 , June 2019 and in January 2021 . & nbsp ; Airstrikes in eastern Syria on Iranian-linked target were carried out by Israel with intelligence provided by the US , a senior US intelligence official said this January . & nbsp ; There is now a long timeline from the Kiswah revelation in November 2017 , the warning about Iranian entrenchment in 2017 and 2018 , the increasing entrenchment , the strike on the Hezbollah killer-drone team near the Golan Heights in August 2019 and then the revelation of increased US support for Israel & rsquo ; s action in 2020 , a well a US airstrikes against Iranian element in Syria in 2019 and now in 2021 . & nbsp ; The map of Israel-US involvement in Syria is growing and converging on Iran & rsquo ; s network of base in the region , which stretch across it plethora of proxy force from Iraq to Lebanon . This may pave the way for increased US-Israel cooperation in the region , or at least underpin a shared strategy .
title: israel-us attack against iran in syria pave way for increased cooperation

Body Text: There ha been a sharp rise in misinformation in reporting about Israel in the international medium , according to Adam Levick , director of the public diplomacy ( hasbara ) organization CAMERA ( Committee for Accuracy in Middle East Reporting and Analysis ) . `` Lately , we have seen a sharp rise in misinformation and biased reporting against Israel , `` Levick told Maariv , The Jerusalem Post 's sister publication . & nbsp ; `` Journalism is important , but journalist know that they need to stick to the fact , so they have to be careful how they report , `` noted Levick . `` When it come to the BBC , for example , for the past 12 year , they have been publishing article against Israel , and BBC Arabic ha even celebrated Hamas 's action against u . `` & nbsp ; He also noted that the British newspaper The Guardian is also biased against Israel . & nbsp ; `` Time after time , they write a if we are the bad guy . `` Where doe the misinformation come from ? According to him , some of the reporting come from a lack of knowledge or misunderstanding of the fact , caused by , among other thing , certain op-eds being published in Israel.Levick cited the example of an article published in The Guardian comparing Gaza to an concentration camp . He explained that when the newspaper wa contacted about the article , it wa said that `` the information written in the article wa published in an opinion column a few year ago in Haaretz by a senior reporter . `` `` We must be careful about how thing are presented in the medium , `` he noted . & nbsp ; On the issue of whether to throw Al Jazeera reporter out of Israel , he said : `` I believe in freedom of the press , yes there is a precedence for throwing the press out of the country , but I do n't think it 's good . We must put their word in the context of hasbara and continue to show that they are wrong . `` Christina Jones , a non-Jewish woman who work for CAMERA a a campus manager , said : `` My family ha a deep connection with Israel , one of my brother 's friend wa killed at the Supernova music festival and the image and story from the massacre are shocking . `` & nbsp ; According to her , she ha never seen such antisemitism in university a she is right now . `` What we see right now on campus in the US , we may soon also see in the UK and in other part of the world . Students are afraid , `` she say , adding that even in Scotland , where she life , there are serious problem . `` It is important to understand that we need to work together so that the international medium report objectively , `` Levick said . & nbsp ; `` I call on the reporter of the world : Report objectively and check your fact before publishing . This is important for Israeli public diplomacy . It is important to show that Israel is not the enemy . ``
title: camera : ' israel is not the enemy , reporter should check their fact '

Body Text: The Tribeca Festival announced Thursday that Come Closer , a movie by Israeli director Tom Nesher , won the Viewpoints Award , the top prize in it category.The jury said in it statement : & ldquo ; The diverse film of the Viewpoint category inspired all of u to think and feel deeply . However , when choosing a winner , our decision wa unanimous . This film pulled u all in from the first few frame , and we felt that we were in skillful hand . It wa fiercely executed and superbly performed . & rdquo ; Tom Nesher said , `` I do n't have enough word to describe the huge excitement , joy , and pride I feel right now . I give thanks to my talented cast , the production , the festival director Jane Rosenthal and Robert De Niro , who stood up to the pressure and chose an Israeli film for the festival , and the judge who chose it a the winner . `` Come Closer is her directorial debut.Israeli film taking the leadIsraeli film have often won important prize and critical acclaim at the Tribeca Festival , which wa created by Rosenthal , De Niro , and Craig Hatkoff to help revitalize lower Manhattan following the 9/11 terror attack . & nbsp ; David Volach & rsquo ; s My Father My Lord and Talya Lavie & rsquo ; s Zero Motivation each won the Best Narrative Feature Award . Ohad Knoller received the Best Actor Award for Yossi & amp ; Jagger , while Shira Haas and Joy Rieger won Best Actress Awards there for the film , Asia and Virgins , respectively.The Nora Ephron Prize , named in honor of the great American Jewish writer , wa given to Israeli director Ruthy Pribar for Asia and Lavie for Zero Motivation.But this year , Nesher & rsquo ; s movie wa the only film by an Israeli director chosen to take part in the festival , which prompted concern that the organizer may have bowed to pressure from anti-Israel faction to keep the number of Israeli film competing in the festival low this year . & nbsp ; The festival take place despite Israel-Hamas warThe festival wa held this year amid a rise in antisemitism and anti-Israel sentiment in the US following the October 7 massacre by Hamas and the war in Gaza . & nbsp ; Just day before Thursday & rsquo ; s prize ceremony , footage wa posted on social medium of a New York subway train , reportedly at the Union Square station , where masked pro-Hamas protester chanted in cultlike fashion that any Zionists should identify themselves and leave the train . & nbsp ; Union Square is just a few stop away from the main venue of the Tribeca Festival.The Nova Music Festival Exhibition , which commemorates the more than 360 victim murdered at the Nova Music Festival in Israel on October 7 , a well a the 40 taken hostage , is also being held near the Tribeca Festival in downtown Manhattan.Pro-Hamas protester demonstrated outside the exhibit earlier this week , carrying flag of Hamas & rsquo ; s armed al-Qassam Brigades terror wing and of the terrorist Hezbollah group , and holding sign with slogan that included & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Long live October 7 & rdquo ; and & ldquo ; The Zionists are not Jews and not human . & rdquo ; Protesters called the exhibit `` pro-genocide Zionist propaganda . `` In addition to being a win for Israel , the prize is a personal triumph for Nesher , whose father , Avi Nesher , is one of Israel & rsquo ; s most acclaimed director . & nbsp ; The movie wa inspired by the death of her brother , Ari Nesher , in an accident in 2018 , although it is not strictly autobiographical . & nbsp ; It tell the story of Eden ( Lia Elalouf ) , a troubled young woman from an upper-class Tel Aviv family whose brother dy suddenly . In the aftermath of his death , she discovers he had a girlfriend , Maya ( Darya Rosen ) , whom he kept hidden from the family . & nbsp ; Eden becomes obsessed with Maya and track her down , convincing Maya to go with her to Sinai . The two young woman are drawn together in an intense bond forged in pain , and their story take a passionate and dangerous turn . `` In these difficult day , when we see boycott of Israeli art and huge demonstration around the world ( and in New York in particular ) , it is a [ matter of ] great pride for u that the film wa chosen to be shown at a prestigious festival like the Tribeca Festival , in the heart of Manhattan , & rdquo ; Nesher said in a statement when the film wa accepted to Tribeca.The lead actress , Elalouf and Rosen , are both newcomer , and the rest of the cast includes Ido Tako , Yaakov Zada-Daniel , and Neta Garty . Musician Shlomi Shaban also ha a role . & nbsp ; Among the film & rsquo ; s producer is Anthony Bregman , an American producer who ha made indie classic such a Michel Gondry & rsquo ; s Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind , a well a such recent film a Nicole Holofcener & rsquo ; s You Hurt My Feelings and John Carney & rsquo ; s Flora and Son.Nesher , who ha made several acclaimed short film , most recently And Now Shut Your Eyes , and who wa a correspondent for Reshet 13 , added , & ldquo ; My heart is full of pride for my dear partner in the creation of the film - - the actor and actress , the crew , and everyone who took part in this long and exciting journey . Our soul is completely invested in this film , which wa created out of great pain and with a lot of love for life and their strength . Come Closer is intended for everyone who chooses life , even after loss and endless pain . . . I 'm waiting for the day when the film meet the Israeli audience . `` The movie is tentatively scheduled to be released in Israel in the fall .
title: israeli director tom nesher ’ s film win top prize at tribeca festival

Body Text: The mayor of the Israeli central city of Lod , Yair Revivo , penned a letter to the government in which he express grave concern about the escalating crime rate and the influence of local gang in the city just 15 minute from Tel Aviv.Revivo noted the lack of action to combat these gang , both Arab and Jewish , which he said are increasingly armed and pose a significant threat not just to the city but to national security & mdash ; and a problem he ha been & ldquo ; shouting about for over ten year . & rdquo ; He pointed out that Arab gang , in particular , are amassing more weapon and could potentially target civil aircraft with shoulder rocket due to the city 's proximity to Ben Gurion 's airstrip . This follows report in Israeli medium that police had found a missile and launcher during a criminal investigation into one of the central city & rsquo ; s kindergarten , which Revivo noted in his letter , calling it & ldquo ; intolerable . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The mayor & rsquo ; s letter also questioned the effectiveness of security measure such a the IDF and Shin Bet , continuing , & ldquo ; If such a missile is luckily found by the police in Lod , God forbid we are close to the shooting of an El Al plane full of 500 passenger ; a plane that will take off from Ben Gurion Airport near our city , get hijacked , hit directly , and crash . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Perhaps only such an event can make you wake up ! & rdquo ; Revivo wrote . & ldquo ; Unfortunately , there is no need to wait for the drone from Iran ; everything is already here . `` Amid these security concern , the cityscape of Lod is marked by empty shop and neglected street littered with trash , sign of a community under strain . Few people are seen outdoors , and the few who are keep a wary eye on those entering and leaving the main road . The local economy suffers not only from a lack of domestic tourism from Palestinians coming from the West Bank due to Israeli restriction after the war broke out but also from the absence of foreign tourists.Tensions in LodThe atmosphere in Lod is heavy with silence , broken occasionally by gunshot . The city & rsquo ; s social dynamic are further complicated by it demographic composition ; about 30 % of it population is Arab , contributing to a sense of detachment from the rest of Israel and exacerbating the city 's challenge . & nbsp ; Near the mosque in the Arab part of the city , inside a hookah shop full of Arab customer either living or working in Lod , one of them catch attention for a tattoo of an M16 on his arm , a well a an image of a rose and a person covered with a balaclava on his hand . & nbsp ; One citizen , Muhammad , expressed his concern to The Media Line , & ldquo ; There is a lot of criminality here . Despite living in East Jerusalem , I work here and come very often after work . With the war currently going on , the situation is getting worse day by day . & rdquo ; He added : & ldquo ; The situation is not completely under the police & rsquo ; s control due to the power of many local gang . However , I can also say that there is always a stereotype related to u a Arabs . Jews portray u a troublemaker and are racist towards u . In the case of Lod and Ramla , the problem is mostly caused by both side , not just u . There is , in fact , criminality among Jews too . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; I just wish peace for this land and further help for mixed city , such a Lod , in this process . We should coexist , but , so far , we mainly live separately from one another . & rdquo ; In the Jewish part of the city , the situation is the same . & nbsp ; Yossi , a Jewish citizen who ha lived in the city for seventeen year , told The Media Line : & ldquo ; Aside from the security granted by the city , a Jewish citizen , we pay an extra 25 shekel per month each . It doesn & rsquo ; t matter about one & rsquo ; s salary , but this hasn & rsquo ; t brought more police or any change . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; We need to learn to coexist ; we have no choice . It is difficult after the 7th of October to trust one another again . Sincerely , I think that Arabs live overall well in Israel , way better than other Arab country , & rdquo ; he said.Yossi added , `` Our mayor didn & rsquo ; t do the right thing here . There is no structural plan for both Jewish and Arab citizen . This exacerbated the distance between the two community . & rdquo ; Gavi , another Jewish citizen , also acknowledged the lack of security in the city . & ldquo ; During the night , it is impossible to feel safe going out ; our major promised to everyone better condition , but this hasn & rsquo ; t happened yet , & rdquo ; he told The Media Line . & ldquo ; In this state of sort of anarchy , I think that Arab gang may be capable of throwing rocket from here against plane in Ben Gurion , & rdquo ; Gavi added.Regarding Jewish gang , it seems that they have lost power over the year and are not a relevant a Arab one in Lod . & nbsp ; Gavi said , `` I know for sure that they do not cooperate . Maybe it wa like this at the beginning . Now we see the overall control and power in the hand of the Arab one . & rdquo ; Revivo did not respond to a request for comment from The Media Line .
title: lod 's mayor express concern over terrorism in neglected mix arab-israeli city amid rising tension

Body Text: Hezbollah Secretary-General Hassan Nasrallah warned that Hezbollah will not stop attacking Israel until the war in Gaza is ended , rejecting effort by the international community to prevent an expansion of the conflict in the region during a speech on Tuesday afternoon . `` The front in southern Lebanon is a front of support , assistance , solidarity , and participation in weakening the Israeli enemy until it reach the point where it is convinced that it must stop it aggression . In Lebanon , a strong Israel is a danger to Lebanon , and a deterred Israel is the one whose danger to Lebanon can be reduced . `` Nasrallah complained about the international delegation that came to Lebanon in recent week in an attempt to calm the situation , saying that they were only concerned with protecting Israel and refused to address Hezbollah 's demands.Nasrallah addressed the Lebanese government a well , calling on them to make new demand to add to UNSC Resolution 1701 . `` Lebanon is in a strong and proactive position , `` insisted the Hezbollah leader .

Body Text: Ch . - Supt . Nivi Ohana , the commander responsible for security at the Supernova music festival at Re'im near the Gaza border , shared the harrowing event that unfolded on October 7 . At 6:30 a.m . , having just finished his night shift , he wa waiting for his replacement when rocket siren were heard . `` We saw the rocket above u , and I decided to stop the music , `` Ohana recalled . `` I told the people that the party wa over , and we needed to leave quickly - some managed to escape . `` Head of the music festival , Ohana sought additional security and had insisted on more armed personnel . `` I wa the event commander , `` he said . `` The IDF approved , and despite no unusual warning , I got 42 police officer on the scene , eight of whom were from Yasam [ riot control ] . In retrospect , this decision saved life . `` As the on-site rocket siren went off , Ohana ordered the music to stop , ordering the audience to get down amid the sound of siren and gunfire . Ohana 's decision to halt the party allowed hundred to leave safely.After receiving a report of a vehicle shot in the Urim area at 6:50 a.m . , Ohana understood just how severe the situation wa . Then , more report came in , indicating that terrorist shot at civilian in the Gaza border area . Ohana quickly took charge , ordering emergency road ' opening and the evacuation of civilians.Battling Hamas terrorist in OfakimOhana then heard report of terrorist near Ofakim . When his replacement arrived , he ordered him to take over dispersing the crowd without wasting time gathering equipment . After that , he and another officer went to the Ofakim area , passing by the scene of carnage at Re'im and Urim . Then , he got a call from a police officer in Ofakim , who said there wa a shootout erupting within the city . The police officer entered the city with his gun drawn and headed to the neighborhood where the battle wa being fought , being met with nonstop gunfire and even an RPG . `` I recognized my police officer , some of them wearing flip-flop or in their underwear , and next to them were civilian armed with knife who joined them - they just jumped out of the house , `` he recounted.Ohana took command of the situation , eliminating terrorist despite being wounded by shrapnel . Unconscious , he later discovered the impact of his earlier insistence on additional police presence at the party . However , some of those very police officer would end up killed in the fighting with Hamas.Evacuated to a hospital , Ohana , fueled by determination , returned to the station with a dislocated shoulder and shrapnel wound . Despite the loss , he emphasized the heroism of the police officer , declaring them the first and last line of defense for Israel . `` If not for their heroism , thousand more civilian would have been murdered , `` Ohana concluded.The Jerusalem Post and OneFamily are working together to help support the victim of the Hamas massacre and the soldier of Israel who have been drafted to ensure that it never happens again.Become a partner in this project by donating to OneFamily & gt ; & gt ;
title: at supernova music fest , police heroism saved hundred from hamas

Body Text: The Israel-Hamas war ha resulted in displacement and disruption for people in both Israel and the Gaza Strip , and donation and NGOs are playing a crucial role in providing meal , clothing , shelter , and other necessary item during a chaotic time . & nbsp ; The Media Line reached out to two non-profit organization , one in Israel and one in the Palestinian territory , to discus how each is assisting it people.The Ezrat Achim Medical Assistance Center , based in the Israeli town of Beit Shemesh , west of Jerusalem , provides medical equipment and assistance across the country . & nbsp ; Rivky Tyberg , the organization 's director of donor relation , said that before the war , Ezrat Achim mainly assisted people in the Beit Shemesh area , which ha no hospital . However , following Hamas ' murderous rampage in Israel on Oct . 7 and the subsequent outbreak of the war , more than 200,000 Israelis from the northern and southern border area were displaced from their home to other part of Israel , necessitating a shift in the organization 's operational approach . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; As soon a the war began , we kind of mobilized all the volunteer and the whole network that we had already set up , `` she said . `` We were able to be cooking and delivering 2,500 meal a day , which were for the family who were displaced by the war . We also opened a pop-up shop , which wa free . They had really come with nothing , and especially a it started to turn wintry , even if they brought a bag with some clothing , they certainly did n't have winter clothing and coat and thing . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Tyberg said that the large-scale displacement ha become a pressing issue . Many family who came to Beit Shemesh are from area that suffer frequent rocket bombardment from the Gaza Strip , but they are not from the border area that were officially ordered to evacuate , and therefore they are not eligible for hotel stay funded by the government . However , many of those family are from poor socioeconomic background and can not afford to pay for extended stay in hotel . Donors sent the organization fund to help pay for such family . & ldquo ; Ultimately , we also were able to get a donation from someone in America that enabled u to pay for short-term rental for some of the family , `` Tyberg said . `` We were calling all the real estate agent if there were any empty apartment and trying to find place for people to stay . & rdquo ; Meanwhile , veteran American non-profit organization Anera ( American Near East Refugee Aid ) provides humanitarian and development aid to refugee in the West Bank and Gaza Strip , Jordan , and Lebanon . & nbsp ; Sandra Rasheed , the organization 's country director for Palestine , told The Media Line that while Anera 's operational approach ha remained unchanged during the war , it ha significantly intensified it effort to aid civilian in Gaza . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We started almost 55 year ago . It started in 1967 after the [ Six-Day ] war that left so many Palestinians displaced , `` Rasheed said . `` It wa created by Palestinian-Americans , Arab-Americans , people who are interested in social justice , who wanted to find a way to support the mass exodus of Palestinians out of Palestine . Prior to this war , we worked in education , focusing on early childhood development , shelter , food security , health , medical donation , and community infrastructure . All of that wa put on hold . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; It is estimated that some 1.9 million Gazans , over 85 % of the population , have been displaced in the current war , and the World Health Organization ha reported an increase in disease attributed to overcrowded condition in the refuge area . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Since the response started , we have distributed more than 6 million meal to people who have been displaced . That includes food parcel , vegetable basket , and hot meal , `` Rasheed said . & nbsp ; `` We have facilitated 55 psychosocial session for child , so they have guided activity for play and stress relief . We have 55 shelter that we clean on a rotation basis . It 's not just our team that is working . We 've been able to mobilize a network of over about 450 volunteer , partner , farmer , vendor , and other partner organization to support u in the work that we 're doing . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The formidable challengesBoth woman acknowledge encountering formidable challenge in delivering assistance.Tyberg said that urgent call from displaced Israelis seeking assistance are repeatedly forced to end abruptly because of rocket alert . & ldquo ; I would say that the hardest part for all the people here in the organization and all the volunteer wa really that point where we had just gotten hundred of phone call coming in from family who were desperate . They would suddenly tell u there wa a warning siren and hang up , `` she said . `` We would wait by the phone fearing for their life . Then they would call back , like , 20 minute later and say , ' OK , everything 's OK . So , listen , when could you come and get u out of here ? We 're desperate . We need a place to go . ' & rdquo ; & nbsp ; In the Gaza Strip , one of the major challenge faced by many volunteer and worker is fear for their own life . & ldquo ; We try to provide the coordinate so that people , so Israel , know that these are shelter for staff of an American organization working for the displaced , `` Rasheed said . `` But our team have said time and time again that if we 're going to die , we 're going to die serving our people . We 're going to die serving the people that need support . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Rasheed said that fuel is crucial to the organization 's ability to deliver food to Gazans . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Our work is reliant on being able to deliver the food to people in shelter , `` she said . `` Having our team go to these shelter and provide the intervention and fuel is more precious than gold right now , and it 's one of the hardest thing to attain . And without fuel , we ca n't operate . & rdquo ; Tyberg said the war is exacting a heavy psychological and emotional toll on the Israeli population . `` There are just so many people who know people who 've been affected terribly . And it 's just this very heavy feeling that we all have that it 's just inescapable , just hanging over everyone , & rdquo ; she said . & nbsp ; Rasheed called for a permanent cease-fire to end the conflict . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I think what we 're asking for is people to advocate for a permanent cease-fire . The situation is very critical . We need a permanent cease-fire . We need a solution , `` she said.Lana Ikelan is a recent graduate of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and an intern in The Media Line & rsquo ; s Press and Policy Student Program .

Body Text: The current campaign between Israel and Hamas is the fiercest one since the 2014 war . It should end because of several reason . & nbsp ; Israel & rsquo ; s Iron Dome is successful in intercepting rocket , but a the campaign continues , the chance that one or several rocket will cause heavy Israeli casualty rapidly increase . A significant blow , harming dozen of Israelis , might push Israel to launch a large-scale ground offensive , deep inside the Gaza Strip . Such an attack might seek to defeat Hamas once and for all , but toppling it rule would likely force Israel into the position of conquering the Strip altogether , an outcome Israel doe not ultimately desire . & nbsp ; The Gaza Strip is a small area ( 365 square kilometer ) , and it ha been highly monitored by Israel , making it easier for the IDF to gather vital information about Hamas and other group there . The IDF also ha been training to confront Hamas . Nevertheless , in retaking the Gaza Strip , hundred of Israeli troop will be killed or injured , fighting their foe above and underground . & nbsp ; Hamas dug long tunnel in the Gaza Strip , preparing itself for war , including a part of an IDF territorial seizure . The fight would therefore not be over after the IDF captured the entire Gaza Strip . The IDF would have to destroy the existing military infrastructure . Palestinian combatant , not only from Hamas , would aspire to harm Israelis , including taking them a prisoner . Israelis in the Gaza Strip would inevitably be target for ambush , IEDs , etc . & nbsp ; As in prior similar campaign , Israel ha relied on firepower , mostly through aircraft , to make significant achievement . However , these accomplishment fall short of the chance for complete victory . Since Israel will not retake the Gaza Strip , Hamas will keep it base , recover and produce additional and more sophisticated rocket and missile with longer range , accuracy etc . Following Israeli strike , Hamas might need month , and in certain area , year to rebuild it strength . Hamas , including it naval commando , were hit hard . Overall , Israel managed to inflict Hamas quite a blow in this round . & nbsp ; Israel theorizes that more strike in the current round will be adequate to cripple the military wing of Hamas , delaying another round , but there is no guarantee of that . Hamas will still have a capability to challenge Israel . & nbsp ; This round started following clash in Jerusalem , which are capable of occurring again at any time for a variety of reason . Israel need to be careful in this matter , but predicting in advance what will ignite riot , let alone another round with Hamas , is a speculative undertaking . The latter can easily rely on friction between Jews and Arabs in Jerusalem a an excuse for striking Israel , producing yet another extended campaign . & nbsp ; Hamas is an Iranian proxy , although independent in many respect . Its self-determination ha been demonstrated in several instance , such a when it refused to fight for Assad , Iran & rsquo ; s ally , during the Syrian civil war . Nevertheless , Iran recognizes the importance of Hamas due to it location , near Israel , and since it is Sunni . The mostly Shi & rsquo ; ite Iran us this religious factor to present itself a one that assist Sunnis , and not only Shi & rsquo ; ite group such a Hezbollah . & nbsp ; IN RECENT YEARS , Iranian training and knowledge helped Hamas upgrade it missile and rocket , with the result being shown in this latest round . Iran hereby hit Israel indirectly , a part of the ongoing conflict between them . Israel return the favor by bombing Iranian target inside Syria , and by conducting covert operation against Iran & rsquo ; s nuclear program . & nbsp ; Israel & rsquo ; s most crucial national security concern is stopping or at least delaying the development of Iran & rsquo ; s nuclear program . It is a top priority for Israel , more important than any issue Israel ha with Hamas or any other national security concern for that matter . & nbsp ; Talks between Iran , the United States , and other power about containing Iran & rsquo ; s nuclear program are ongoing . Israel doe not have much leverage in those negotiation , but a long a Israel is occupied with Hamas , Israel can not focus on what matter most : handling Iran & rsquo ; s nuclear program . In that sense , Hamas serf Iran even if Hamas fight Israel for it own reason . This is another major reason why Israel should end the current campaign with Hamas . & nbsp ; Israel and the United States have close tie , but the Biden administration doe not have very friendly relation with the Israeli government . Israel need it American patron in order to reach the best outcome for the current round with Hamas . Israel relies much more on the United States to make sure the talk with Iran will be effective at restraining Iran & rsquo ; s nuclear program . & nbsp ; If Israel annoys the Biden administration with respect to the Gaza Strip , the United States might be less willing to listen to Israel about Iran . The Biden administration lends Israel time in fighting Hamas but it is clear the Biden administration want this campaign to subside . If Israel insists on persisting with this round , it risk increasing friction with the Biden administration . The Gaza Strip ha been under the rule of Hamas since 2007 . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Hamas , due to it mismanagement and eagerness to confront Israel , caused a deep economic and social crisis in the Gaza Strip . Some predict that this area might collapse , driving thousand of desperate Palestinians to infiltrate Israel and ask for help . Obviously , Israel doe not prefer this outcome . If Israel continues with this round , the probability of further decline in the Gaza Strip increase . & nbsp ; Many Arab state oppose Hamas , and some , like those in the Gulf , have tie with Israel . Arab state can & rsquo ; t openly support Israel in this round , fearing public opinion inside their country and across the Arab world . Arab criticism of Israel is not a pronounced a it used to be , but this can easily change for the worse . The longer this round is continued , the higher the burden of casualty amongst the Palestinian population will reach , forcing even Arab state that have normalized relation with Israel , to speak and maybe even to act against Israel . & nbsp ; All in all , ending the current campaign will frustrate many in Israel who wish to defeat Hamas . However , Israel should cut it loss , and not extend this campaign , because it is simply not worth the cost and the risk . & nbsp ; Dr . Ehud Eilam ha been dealing with and studying Israel & rsquo ; s national security for more than 25 year . He served in the Israeli military and later worked for the Defense Ministry a a researcher . He ha had six book published in the US and UK , the latest being Containment in the Middle East ( University Press of Nebraska , 2019 ) . & nbsp ;

Body Text: Some see the world in one or two dimension and others in three . When Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich , who also ha a portfolio within the Defense Ministry , responded to the Palestinian terrorist attack in which two Jews were murdered in Huwara in the northern West Bank by calling for using tank and helicopter against the Palestinians , he certainly wa not thinking three-dimensionally.Nor wa National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir , who picked a fight with the Shin Bet ( Israel Security Agency ) , which recommended unsealing the residence of a terrorist who killed three Jews earlier in February.These view are indicative of narrow thinking . Lessons from the Second Intifada and the Knife Intifada showed that substantially increased IDF physical presence in West Bank area , especially Palestinian area , were part of the necessary mix of ingredient for restoring calm and security.But that presence rarely involved tank and helicopter & ndash ; blunt instrument for open battlefield or for targeting large , concentrated enemy positions.Those position do not exist in the West Bank , which doe not have the massive volume of rocket , other destructive weapon and well-structured Hamas militia that exist in Gaza.Why wo n't tank , helicopter in the West Bank secure quiet with the Palestinians ? The Palestinian Authority , while it might not control all area and might be turning a blind eye to terrorist element , is actively avoiding conflict with the IDF . Non-PA terrorist element do not pose anywhere near the same magnitude of threat a Hamas . Neither do they present a useful large target for tank or helicopters.Militarily , the tactic that worked before , and would likely work now if it need to be unleashed , would involve huge number of soldier going door to door , with intelligence support from drones.Likewise , despite Ben-Gvir & rsquo ; s attack on the Shin Bet , the security agency ha been a big supporter of house demolition to deter future terrorism.However , part of the Shin Bet & rsquo ; s rationale is that Palestinians know in their heart of heart that the agency is focused on family who hold some joint responsibility for the terrorism of their family members.In contrast , the Shin Bet found that the Ramot terrorist from earlier this month wa psychologically unstable and that the family did not assist him in any way and might even have tried to temper his violent leanings.A house demolition in that case could just create more terrorist , even according to the Shin Bet , because not a single Palestinian would see it a legitimate.But the Second Intifada wa also brought under control by the eventual completion of the West Bank security barrier to limit infiltrations.One problem in a dimension where using force can not solve everything & ndash ; and tank and helicopter are useless and impractical to police a long border & ndash ; is that , a IDF source told The Jerusalem Post , completing those portion of the barrier where Palestinians are still sneaking through into sovereign Israel could take another 18 months.And this doesn & rsquo ; t even address east Jerusalem , where there is not any initiative being entertained that could handle the security situation . Arabs from east Jerusalem travel freely in Israel . Even presuming that nearly all of them aren & rsquo ; t looking to act against Israel , anyone with violent intention is unrestrained . Tanks and helicopter are even less relevant there.Sunday & rsquo ; s terrorist attack occurred in an overlapping Palestinian area , where Palestinians and Israelis mix , the least secure type of location.The Knife Intifada wa partially put down by Israeli security force using social medium and drone surveillance to predict and prevent terrorist attack by & ldquo ; lone wolf & rdquo ; attacker before they happened . Yet , many say another ingredient to ending the Second Intifada wa Israel & rsquo ; s announced withdrawal from Gaza.In contrast , there is currently no diplomatic dimension ( or & ldquo ; carrot & rdquo ; ) on the table from Israel to follow a new Operation Defensive Shield ( or & ldquo ; stick & rdquo ; ) , such a then-prime minister Ariel Sharon used.In parallel to demolishing more house , taking away terrorist & rsquo ; citizenship and calling for capital punishment for terrorist , the current government is also in negotiation with the PA , Jordan and Egypt to try to calm the broader situation before it transforms into another intifada . Part of the & ldquo ; deal & rdquo ; that seems to have emerged includes freezing unilateral action on both side for some months.For Israel , this referred to new settlement and outpost , whereas for the Palestinians , it might have referred to legal move against Israel in the UN system.But a those effort continue , element of the coalition oppose any dialogue whatsoever with any Palestinians , even though the Shin Bet belief dialogue is critical to restoring security cooperation with the PA.In past year , some intelligence official told the Post that the PA had helped Israel stop 20 % or more of terrorist attack against Israel & ndash ; not insignificant number . And tank and helicopter in the West Bank would not make thing quieter with Hamas in Gaza.To date , the current government ha failed to convince Hamas to fully disconnect itself from issue with Palestinians in other conflict areas.All of this come down to the idea that using force , and more of it , may absolutely be part of the equation to end the almost yearlong up-and-down current wave of violence.But there will also likely need to be a & ldquo ; carrot & rdquo ; in there somewhere , whether economic , diplomatic or both . Might the new deal be enough in this area , or is it inadequate to escape the current quagmire ? Other ingredient could be the unfinished security barrier in the West Bank , which will take time , coming up with a unique security solution to east Jerusalem security issue and figuring out a way to restore deterrence with Hamas in Gaza.This would mean the current government will need to try some new and creative idea on multiple playing field instead of only doubling down with populist slogan in one dimension.There are many idea , short of a messianic peace vision , that can help restore calm , and the latest deal might help with that . But tank and helicopter are either a tiny part or a nonexistent part of the solution .

Egypt ha long played a role a a mediator between Hamas and Israel . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We appreciate Egypt & rsquo ; s ongoing effort , & rdquo ; Blinken said , adding that in his conversation with Showery , he reiterated & ldquo ; the urgent need to halt the Hamas attack . & rdquo ; In his conversation with Turkish Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan Blinken said he encouraged Ankara 's engagement in the situation . Body Text: On July 9 , the Security Cabinet decided by a majority of eight to one ( National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir voted against ) with one abstention ( Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich ) that Israel would act to prevent the Palestinian Authority & rsquo ; s collapse . These include the construction of a new industrial zone in Tarkumiye , near Hebron , a move supported by the Israeli security establishment . & nbsp ; As part of the effort by Israel and Egypt to boost the Palestinian economy , the Prime Minister 's Office recently approved the development of a natural gas field off the Gaza coast to be administered by the PA . & nbsp ; Why doe Israel want to save the PA ? According to Israeli official , the decision to help the PA is aimed at countering the influence in the West Bank of Iran , which back both Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad . The official say that the collapse of the PA could cause a similar situation to that in Gaza , where Hamas seized control in 2007 . They argue that the PA & rsquo ; s loss of control , particularly in the northern West Bank , ha empowered terrorist group and forced the IDF to conduct counter-terror operation in the territory . & nbsp ; Ben-Gvir called the decision to strengthen the PA & ldquo ; delusional . & rdquo ; He said : & ldquo ; There is no greater absurdity than the fact that a body that encourages terrorism , pay salary to terrorist and their family , encourages in the education system incitement in favor of the murder of Jews , and take over territory in Judea and Samaria , will receive a basket of reward from the Israeli government in the midst of a wave of terrorism . & rdquo ; It is worth noting that the Israeli government collect some NIS 800 million annually in tax for the PA , accounting for up to 70 % of it revenue , excluding foreign aid . & nbsp ; On July 10 , the PA rejected Israel & rsquo ; s demand for helping to prevent it collapse . & ldquo ; Yesterday , the Israeli government came out with decision concerning the Palestinian Authority on the pretext that they want to offer gesture to the Palestinians , & rdquo ; PA Prime Minister Mohammad Shtayyeh told a PA cabinet meeting . & ldquo ; On behalf of the Palestinian government , we say that what is required of Israel is to halt it aggression on our people , killing , settlement , and the piracy of our money . & rdquo ; Established 30 year ago a part of the 1993 Oslo Peace Accords with Israel , the PA ha weakened considerably over recent year amid allegation of corruption and incompetence , and opposition to it security cooperation with Israel . No matter how hard it wa to go back to the lookout post , I will continue . & ldquo ; I understand the importance . The combat fighter need u so much . The most significant message for all young woman who are afraid of taking this job in the IDF : The mission is so important . It is the greatest pride you can have , & rdquo ; she said.Besides some of the above individual story , there wa also encouraging data month into the war at the end of 2023.According to the data , the number of female draftee seeking combat position in the shadow of the war broke every pre-war set goal.Regarding female draftee & rsquo ; participation , border patrol unit were at 116 % ; battle-related intelligence collection wa at 133 % ; artillery wa at 132 % ; air defense wa at 101 % ; rescue unit were at 122 % ; and border police wa at 119 % . An additional 12 % of woman draftee requested to serve in combat unit since the start of the war.In addition , two woman passed the vetting process for the elite Air Force search and rescue Unit 669.They have started a 20-month elite training course to join the unit & rsquo ; s combat ranks.Just getting to the point where woman can be considered for such a unit ha been a long and winding path.A petition to the High Court of Justice filed a few year ago helped pressure the IDF High Command into opening some new combat unit to women.These included Yahalom and mobile deployment unit in the Infantry Corps in summer 2023.That woman would be able to compete for spot in the IAF & rsquo ; s 669 Combat Search and Rescue Unit wa announced in October 2022 and only came to fruition in January 2023.Some group still view this progress a inadequate.They note that there are other military in which woman are already allowed to serve in all elite combat units.Still , there is no question that the recent trend , especially since the outbreak of the current war , ha led to the integration of more woman into unit in which they previously could not serve . 
title: woman are shattering the idf elite unit ' glass ceiling

Body Text: Local Palestinian leader Mohammed Nasser of Dura ha been called a traitor for speaking with Israelis.He wa not afraid , therefore , to attend a kosher iftar meal in the West Bank city of Hebron with Israeli guest , including settler leader from the city & rsquo ; s Jewish community . & ldquo ; If you mention Mohammed Nasser in the West Bank , they will tell you he is the first man for Israel , & rdquo ; Nasser told the several dozen guest who sat on the porch of Hebron businessman Ashraf Jabari on Tuesday night.A veteran peacemaker , Nasser ha spoken with Israeli president , prime minister , parliamentarian , congressman , writer , and poet . He ha also traveled to Washington to advocate for peace.Nasser said he is in conversation with South Hebron Hills Regional Council Yohai Damri and ha spoken with the Knesset Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee chairman Ram Ben-Barak . & ldquo ; I know each and every president of Israel , even prime minister , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; Either they were at my home or I met them in their office , & rdquo ; he told the several dozen guest at the iftar meal , which offered kosher guest meal prepared in the nearby Kiryat Arba settlement.An electrician by trade , Nasser recalled how in 1982 when he wa & ldquo ; chief of the village league , & rdquo ; he called for a conference under the & ldquo ; slogan & lsquo ; yes to peace & rsquo ; . & rdquo ; Even the Israelis were concerned he wa a traitor , Nasser recalled.Nasser explained that these tie have come at a cost . & ldquo ; We are suffering a lot because of our relationship with you , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; You will enjoy the night and you will go back , but everyone in the area will start saying Ashraf Jabari , he received Jews , he is a quisling [ traitor ] . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; You have to protect those people who have sympathy with you [ & hellip ; ] I ask you to support those people who are saying peace to you , & rdquo ; Nasser advised.The event wa hosted by both Jabari and the Judea and Samaria Chamber of Commerce , of which he and Ariel resident Avi Zimmerman are co-founders . Jabari began the tradition of a kosher Iftar in 2019 when US President Donald Trump wa in the White House and saw Palestinians like Jabari a grassroots alternative to the Palestinian Authority . That same year Jabari ignored a PA ban and attended the US-sponsored economic conference in Bahrain.Jabari & rsquo ; s first iftar included a number of Israeli-Arab business people . In 2020 , he held a virtual iftar event and last year there were a number of Yesha member at the meal.Hebron ha a bitter history of Israeli-Palestinian violence , but on Jabari & rsquo ; s porch , he and his Muslim and Jewish guest showed another side of relation in the city.Members of the Hebron Jewish community have attended each of Jabari & rsquo ; s four iftar celebration . One of it spokespeople , Yishai Fleisher , recalled for the guest on Tuesday how Jabari had helped him fulfill his mother & rsquo ; s wish to have firework explode over the Tomb of the Patriarchs in honor of his daughter & rsquo ; s bat mitzvah , which occurred just before the advent of the COVID-19 pandemic.Fleisher recall that when those in the bat mitzvah party saw the night sky light up they said : & ldquo ; & rsquo ; What a coincidence . & rsquo ; I said , & lsquo ; No , I organized this , I have friend on the Arab side & rsquo ; and they said , & lsquo ; No , no , you don & rsquo ; t , you are joking . & rsquo ; & rdquo ; The guest didn & rsquo ; t believe him , Fleisher recall , but the friendship is very real . & ldquo ; For u , this relationship is very important , & rdquo ; Fleisher said . & ldquo ; Maybe for Ashraf it & rsquo ; s important , but , for u , maybe it & rsquo ; s more important . A lot of people around the world want to accuse u of racism and want to say that we hate Arabs . No , we hate jihadist . We hate people who want to make war against u . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; There is a lot of joint activity the two community can do together to improve the city , & rdquo ; Fleisher said , adding that people like Jabari make such joint activity possible.Attorney Kobi Kamar of Jerusalem , invited by a friend , said he had imagined that he wa going to a left-wing event and found himself instead in a room of right-winger . & ldquo ; I have found here a reality I had not imagined , & rdquo ; he said , explaining that it wa a reality that did not conform to the stereotypes.Hebron Jewish community spokesman Noam Arnon said that Jews and Muslims had been neighbor in Hebron for century and were neighbor a well today . & ldquo ; We have to make sure that the future of this area will be a future of peace , & rdquo ; Arnon said.Given the biblical root of the city that date back to Abraham , Hebron could be a thriving tourist city , Arnon said.Zimmerman said it wa important to emphasize that the tie that brought Jews and Muslims together on the porch were those of & ldquo ; neighbor to neighbor . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; The idea that the rest of the world is looking at this region a Palestinians and settler doesn & rsquo ; t help anyone understand the reality of neighbor to neighbor , & rdquo ; he said .
title: ' peace to you ' : palestinian , israeli settler share kosher iftar meal in hebron

Body Text: The question of whether photo depicting Hamas terrorist in submissive position contribute to Israel 's war objective or hinder them intensifies with the increasing frequency of such image being released.As the IDF intensifies operation in the southern Gaza Strip , the security establishment must take a stance on this matter , which appears to divide opinions.While these photo may humiliate Hamas , a former senior security official suggests they may not truly serve our interest . `` These photo are intended to resonate with the Israeli public , albeit within a specific demographic , but their effectiveness is uncertain , `` the former official said.Are the photo of surrendering Hamas terrorist in Gaza staged ? The same official raise concern about some event appearing staged . For instance , in a recently released video , an elderly man in his underwear can be seen moving to the front of the line and placing his weapon down . This particular photo raise numerous question , according to the official . `` Under what circumstance would someone undress before surrendering their weapon ? `` they pointed out . `` Logically , the weapon should be surrendered first , followed by removing clothes . `` Additionally , the official point out that not everyone there is a terrorist . Some people are questioned in the field and released , while only a few undergo further investigation in Israel.The official concludes that engaging in a humiliation contest with Hamas is not worth it . He highlight that Hamas possesses video from October 7 of Israelis in equally humiliating position . Attempting to boost national morale through this , he warns , may result in psychological damage on the international stage .
title: humiliating picture of hamas terrorist may harm israel - ex-official

Body Text: The politics is getting out of control , and the question is whether it put the fate of the hostage and the objective of defeating Hamas at risk . & nbsp ; White House official insist that they were taken aback by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu & rsquo ; s announcement that he wa calling off a trip to Washington by a delegation headed by National Security Adviser Tzachi Hanegbi and Strategic Affairs Minister Ron Dermer , after the US refused to thwart a UN Security Council resolution which called for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza.The Biden administration is familiar with the player in Netanyahu & rsquo ; s circle . Hanegbi and Dermer , the latter in particular , are the prime minister & rsquo ; s people . US official acknowledge that with this decision to call off the trip , Netanyahu wa & ldquo ; putting his foot down , & rdquo ; feeling increasing heat personally from the administration over how he is running Israel & rsquo ; s affair . & ldquo ; Minister Benny Gantz wa here earlier this month , Defense Minister Yoav Gallant is here now , [ and ] the defense establishment are in constant contact , & rdquo ; a White House aide argued . & ldquo ; Calling off the Hanegbi-Dermer delegation is political window dressing by the prime minister . & rdquo ; In response to the question of whether the administration wa also acting politically & ndash ; by supporting Israel but looking over it shoulder amid the president & rsquo ; s re-election campaign to make sure it didn & rsquo ; t alienate it electorate too much & ndash ; a White House aide insisted : & ldquo ; Israel ha no better friend than the Biden administration , in general & ndash ; and regarding Gaza , in particular . & rdquo ; On the one hand , the aide seemed to be charging that Netanyahu wa not sufficiently appreciating the administration & rsquo ; s obstacle course in navigating it policy regarding Gaza , and that calling off the visit to Washington by his delegation only exacerbated the public impression & ldquo ; that the two country are not on the same side . & rdquo ; On the other hand , the aide reiterated that & ldquo ; on the ground , our cooperation is not affected . & rdquo ; Biden on Netanyahu 's governance & nbsp ; In a recent MSNBC interview , President Joe Biden charged that Netanyahu wa doing more harm than good ; he ha also publicly questioned Israel & rsquo ; s plan for a Rafah operation . However , a White House aide insisted that the president & rsquo ; s endgame remains & ldquo ; the defeat of Hamas . & rdquo ; Yet , regarding Hanegbi and Dermer staying home , instead of visiting Washington at least right now , administration official seem fine with holding high-profile contact in the US capital with high-level Israeli official who themselves have tense relation with Netanyahu.The president and his people are aware of domestic issue in Israel , including the resistance by Gallant and Gantz to Netanyahu & rsquo ; s move on the matter of haredi ( ultra-Orthodox ) enlistment in the IDF.Within the Biden administration , there isn & rsquo ; t totally smooth sailing either . Officials have acknowledged that Vice President Kamala Harris ha been the & ldquo ; weak link & rdquo ; in support for the Israeli campaign in Gaza . Yet , said one official , & ldquo ; she is toeing the line and in principle support what the Israeli mission is all about , & rdquo ; even if her pronouncement at time & ldquo ; seem more blunt about what Israel is doing wrong . & rdquo ; Biden ha stronger support for his Gaza policy , say aide , from Secretary of State Antony Blinken , Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin , and National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan . Some aide seem to hint that having Harris playing & ldquo ; bad cop & rdquo ; with some of her declaration on Israel allows Biden to hope he can placate those who say they would vote for him in November , but are threatening not to do so over what some even call his support for & ldquo ; genocide . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; Listen , the [ UN ] Security Council called for a ceasefire , but it also called for a release of the hostage , & rdquo ; argued a Biden aide . & ldquo ; We have not abandoned Israel , [ and ] we have not abandoned the Israeli mission in Gaza . We have also not abandoned the need for humanitarian aid and working toward the overall well-being of Palestinians in Gaza.Cooperation is key - but difficult in attaining & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The question is what is the best way to achieve all these goal ; it is challenging , & rdquo ; the aide said . & ldquo ; We want to work with the Israelis . We want to work with them on how to achieve victory over Hamas in general , and how best to achieve the aim of a Rafah operation in particular , but not in a way & ndash ; a both the president and vice president have said & ndash ; that would lead to a civilian bloodbath . And yes , we want the return of the hostage . & rdquo ; Biden & rsquo ; s re-election campaign adviser continue to watch the Gaza policy closely . The president is said to be feeling the heat over warning he is receiving that he ha a very thin tightrope to walk on : promoting his policy but not risking defeat in November . & ldquo ; Gaza is not the only reason for concern , & rdquo ; conceded a Biden political adviser , & ldquo ; but it & rsquo ; s a big reason . & rdquo ; Netanyahu & rsquo ; s announcement & ndash ; calling off the visit by the Hanegbi-Dermer delegation to Washington to discus Rafah policy and how to release the hostage & ndash ; came a the prime minister wa battling for his political life , warning coalition naysayer to the proposal regarding haredi military recruitment that if an agreement is not reached , the government would fall.So apparently , the US and Israeli landscape both currently abound with political window dressing by the two leader , Biden and Netanyahu . Such behavior is not rare in the political world , but right now , if these maneuver by the president and prime minister do in fact get out of control , the ramification could be extremely dangerous and deadly.The writer is op-ed editor of The Jerusalem Post .

Body Text: Thousands of protester gathered throughout Tel Aviv on Saturday evening , calling for the return of hostage held in Hamas captivity and demonstrating against the government , Israeli medium reported.The protest took place in various location in the city . Protesters also called for immediate election in the country . & nbsp ; The parent of US-Israeli citizen Itay Chen , an IDF soldier who wa killed on October 7 and whose body is being held by Hamas , called for the government to approve a hostage deal immediately . Reflecting on the loss of their son , they said , `` The country did not defend you or save you . Body Text: The Israeli public must force the government to secure the release of the four Gaza captive , said Tzur Goldin at the start of a three-day march to highlight their plight , including that of his twin brother , Hadar . & ldquo ; No one in this government intends to bring my brother home , & rdquo ; said Tzur . & ldquo ; We the public will bring them home . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; No one in this government intends to bring my brother home . We the public will bring them home . & rdquo ; Tzur GoldinTzur set out on Wednesday morning from the family & rsquo ; s Kfar Saba home with his father , Simha , his mother , Leah , and hundred of other supporters.They marched to Rishon Lezion , from where they planned to set out on Thursday with an eye toward reaching the Erez Crossing at the Gaza border on Friday.At issue is the plight of four men : Hadar Goldin , Oron Shaul , Avera Mengistu and Hisham al-Sayad.Shaul and Goldin , both IDF soldier , are believed to have been killed during the 2014 Gaza war , and their body have been held by Hamas.The captured boysMengistu and Sayad are both Israeli civilian who suffer from psychological illness , which led to their wandering into Gaza . We will reach the Gaza border and broadcast the message that this is one big bluff . & rdquo ; At issue for the Goldin family , in particular , is Israel & rsquo ; s failure to link the passage of good into Gaza with the release of the captives.At the start of the march , Simha recited the prayer for a safe journey , and Leah thanked the participant at the end of the first day of the event . & ldquo ; We are marching to bring the boy back home , & rdquo ; she said.Despite her inclusive message , much of the publicity around the march spoke of only Goldin , Shaul and Mengistu . This included T-shirts and flag calling for the return of the boys.A spokesman for the march said he had no idea why all the publicity material had not included all four of the men.The Goldin family ha been at the forefront of the publicity battle for the return of the men , who are often referred to a & ldquo ; the son . & rdquo ; According to a spokesperson for the march , they were the only family member present on the first day , however , representative from other family are likely to join the march on Thursday and Friday .

Body Text: Hezbollah & rsquo ; s action endanger Lebanon and can bring the entire region toward unnecessary escalation , Prime Minister Yair Lapid warned Tuesday during a tour of the IDF & rsquo ; s Northern Command . & ldquo ; The State of Israel is prepared and ready to act against any threat . Body Text: The United Nations Security Council plan to hold it second closed-door meeting this week on the escalating violence in the Israel-Palestinian conflict . The UN Security Council will publicly discus the worsening violence between Israel and Palestinian militant on Sunday a well , diplomat said , reaching a compromise over US objection to a meeting on Friday . Diplomats said the United States , a close ally of Israel , had initially suggested a virtual public meeting could be held on Tuesday . US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said on Thursday he hoped waiting a few day would allow for & ldquo ; diplomacy to have some effect and to see if indeed we get a real de-escalation , & rdquo ; adding that Washington wa & ldquo ; open to and supportive of a discussion , an open discussion , at the United Nations . & quot ; The 15-member body met on Monday in the aftermath of Jerusalem violence , but wa unable to reach the consensus needed for a joint statement . Officials from individual member state , including China which hold the UNSC presidency this month , issued statement calling on both Israelis and Palestinians to de-escalate the situation . Five permanent UNSC member have veto power : the US , China , Russia , France and the United Kingdom . The Trump administration gave it unqualified support to Israel , blocking any potential statement and resolution critical of it action . US President Joe Biden ha sworn to also support Israel at the UN . Washington delayed Security Council effort to issue a public statement on Monday , fearing that it could be harmful to behind-the-scenes effort to end the violence , according to diplomat and a source familiar with the US strategy . Speaking on condition of anonymity , the source said Washington is & quot ; actively engaged in diplomacy behind the scene with all party to achieve a ceasefire & quot ; and wa concerned that a council statement might be counterproductive at the moment . That statement would have expressed concern over the Jerusalem violence ; called on Israel to cease Jewish settlement activity , demolition and eviction ; and urge general restraint . This next UNSC meeting come amid the heaviest barrage of Gaza rocket fire since the 2014 Gaza war . The IDF ha launched intensive military counter strike . & quot ; The United Nations is working with all relevant party to de-escalate the situation urgently , & quot ; spokesperson Stephane Dujarric said on Tuesday . He said Secretary-General Antonio Guterres is saddened by & quot ; the increasingly large number of casualty , including child . & quot ; & quot ; Israeli security force must exercise maximum restraint and calibrate their use of force . The indiscriminate launching of rocket and mortar towards Israeli population center is unacceptable , & quot ; Dujarric told reporter . Palestinian Authority Prime Minister Mohammed Shtayyeh called on the UNSC to take serious step to halt Israeli strike on the Gaza Strip and it attack against Palestinians in Jerusalem , including in the Sheikh Jarrah neighborhood and the Temple Mount , known to Muslims a Al-Haram Al-Sharif .

Body Text: A new weapon deal with Israel is under consideration by US official , Politico reported on Monday.50 F-15 fighter jet , 30 AID-120 advanced medium-range air-to-air missile , and a & ldquo ; number of joint direct attack munition kit , which turn dumb bomb into precision-guided weapon , & rdquo ; are being considered for the American weapon sale to Israel , according to Politico.While the sale is still waiting for US approval , a congressional aide revealed that the Biden administration is very likely approve the sale . However , it is important to note that according to Politico & rsquo ; s report , it would & ldquo ; be year before the weapon arrive in Israel . & rdquo ; Politico further reported that when asked for a response , the US State Department spokesperson said `` the department doe not comment on potential future sale . & rdquo ; This development occurs amid mounting criticism of the Biden administration 's stance on arm sale to Israel , `` a the death toll rise in Gaza . & rdquo ; In another sign of growing tension between the two ally , Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer 's recent call for Israeli election sparked a controversy last month among Israeli political leaders.Politico further report that the sale & ldquo ; come amid a rift among Democrats & rdquo ; regarding the question of Biden & rsquo ; s responsibility in pressuring Israel & ldquo ; not to launch a large-scale invasion & rdquo ; of Rafah through arm sales.Israeli hostage , US concern , and weapon dealPolitico noted the concern for the remaining Israeli hostage , and that & nbsp ; official are still attempting to negotiate for their release in exchange for Palestinian prisoners.Additionally , the US expressed concern about Israeli plan for an operation in Rafah , emphasizing the need to protect civilian . `` Going into Rafah without a plan to protect civilian would be a mistake , `` US official said.Meanwhile , recent Israeli airstrikes in Syria have heightened tension in the region .
