This deal would include additional arm not mentioned in this new deal.Responses to the considered weapon dealDemocratic senator Chris Van Hollen said that `` blocking sale of offensive weapon should be under consideration , & rdquo ; according to Politico & rsquo ; s report.Former State Department official Josh Paul , who resigned from his position & ldquo ; in protest over America & rsquo ; s continued lethal assistance to Israel , & rdquo ; alleged that the proposed arm sale is & ldquo ; further proof & rdquo ; of continued US support for Israel .
title: u considers new arm deal with israel amid criticism and division over policy

Body Text: Haifa Mayor Yona Yahav revealed at a toast in the Sephardic House Hotel in Jerusalem his intention to name a neighborhood in the city after President Joe Biden a a token of appreciation for his support for Israel , Israeli medium reported on Tuesday.During the traditional Passover toasting ceremony of the Sephardic House , Yahav revealed for the first time his intention to name a neighborhood in the city after US President Joe Biden . A similar proposal led to the creation of Ramat Trump in the Golan in 2020 . & nbsp ; The mayor pledged that he would introduce Jewish diaspora heritage study into the curriculum of Haifa school so that `` we would all really know each other `` . As part of his desire for a real connection between all the people who live in Haifa , Yahav also plan to implement the study of spoken Arabic in all school starting from the second grade.Another distinguished guest at the ceremony wa Haim Cohen , the chairman of the World Spanish Federation in Israel.Along with Cohen came most of the head of the organization included in the federation.Attorney Yosef Gilaur , chairman of the Haifa Sephardic Jewish Community Committee , did not hide his excitement : `` Haim is a mentor and a true friend for the community committee and a close friend for me personally . `` Sadness , worry , resilience and comfortIn his word for the holiday , Gilaur detailed the sadness and worry that we all experience . At the same time , he also offered consolation : `` We knew how to overcome cruel enemy and serious crisis in the past . We have mental strength . If we cling to despair , the flower of spring will not grow . If we cling to hope and nurture it , we will have a real revival . `` Yossi Azari , chairman of the Sephardic House 's Day Center , also spoke at the ceremony and emphasized the center 's activity ' contribution to the community in Haifa and beyond.Netali Ben , the CEO of the Sephardi House , discussed the hardship leading up to the ceremony and the importance of maintaining tradition in dealing with the complex reality.She also complimented the employee : `` We maintained emotional and team resilience even after the horror of 7/10 . We continued to provide the tenant with wholehearted service and also a sense of security . `` At the end of the ceremony , all those present expressed hope that all the hostage would return to u soon and that we would all have a happy and peaceful holiday .
title: haifa mayor yona yahav commits to naming a haifa neighborhood after joe biden

Body Text: & ldquo ; Nineteen arrested in large brawl at Soroka hospital in Beersheba , & rdquo ; a headline read in November . A fight broke out between two Bedouin family from Rahat , about 20 km . north of Beersheba . The reason it made the news wa the location & ndash ; brawl happen all the time . There are thousand of Bedouin living in the Negev ; their story must extend deeper than crime-ridden headline . So , who are the Bedouin of the South ? The clash took place in one of the parking lot at Soroka-University Medical Center in Beersheba , with two people being injured . By the end of a long night , which included gunshot and stone-throwing , 19 people were arrested . Beersheba Deputy Mayor Shimon Tuval said at the time that the situation wa madness . & ldquo ; Not only did we lose Beersheba , we lost the whole country . Shots in a hospital are a redline that can not be crossed . & rdquo ; Hospitals are not a place for incident like these and are not equipped to deal with them , Dr . Shlomi Kodesh , director of Soroka , said at the time . The Beersheba Municipality did not respond to a request for comment for this article . Soroka When the incident in Soroka occurred , it wa in the context of a string of attack happening inside or near hospital space , which are supposed to be safe and immune . Dr . Zeev Feldman , chairman of the Association of Public Health Doctors in Israel and acting chairman of the Israeli Medical Association , explained to The Jerusalem Post at the time that hospital are merely a microcosm of society . & lsquo ; Lawlessness & rsquo ; in the Negev The lack of governance in the Negev is an ongoing issue , and Prime Minister Naftali Bennett said at the time : & ldquo ; We are dealing in an orderly manner with problem that we have already become accustomed to having nothing to do with , that are chronic problem that are used to being pushed off . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; If the State of Israel doe not protect the land on which it stand , it will cease to exist , & rdquo ; Naomi Linder Kahn , director of the International Division at Regavim , told the Magazine . Regavim is an NGO that describes itself a & ldquo ; committed to protecting Israel & rsquo ; s land resource . & rdquo ; Land , Kahn explained , is the most basic resource of a state . And the organization , in the 16 year since it founding , ha found that Israel fails to protect it in the Negev . According to Regavim , lawlessness lead to abuse in land use , which is significant because the Negev comprises more than 60 % of the landmass of Israel . & ldquo ; The land is being chewed up at an incredibly alarming rate by illegal Bedouin construction , & rdquo ; Kahn said . Regavim warned that & ldquo ; if we continue on the trajectory we are on right now , we will lose the Negev . & rdquo ; A story within a story & ldquo ; There & rsquo ; s an entire culture here : Towns , settlement , MKs and even the police play a small part in this story , & rdquo ; Israel Police said . & ldquo ; Police [ play the part of dealing with the ] criminal story , but the story here in the Negev is about culture . Everyone who life in the South engages with this dialogue every day . & ldquo ; To understand what the Bedouin do , you need to understand their culture . Police are a tiny part in this giant story of Bedouin settlement in the Negev ; talking about [ how the ] police [ should intervene ] give good headline , but it is not the story . & rdquo ; In November , the Knesset & rsquo ; s Research and Information Center published a staggering report showing that the highest crime rate in the country are in the South . & ldquo ; Our worst fear is that the State of Israel created a state within a state . They don & rsquo ; t pay tax , they don & rsquo ; t have proper address ; people are living off the grid and are not accountable under the law , & rdquo ; said Kahn . On a tour in the area in December , Bennett proclaimed : & ldquo ; The law of Beersheba and Rahat is like the law of Tel Aviv . We will continue to act until we restore the sense of security to the resident of the South . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The Bedouin community is on the lowest socioeconomic rung in Israel , Kahn said , with there being gap in education and in infrastructure . & ldquo ; These are thing they have a legal right to a citizen of Israel , but the money that the government invests in the Bedouin sector is getting lost along the way . & rdquo ; When Bennett went south , he met with Beersheba Mayor Ruvik Danilovich , who delivered a clear message : Stronger governance is needed in the Negev to begin to regulate Bedouin settlement . Danilovich wa one of the only town leader Bennett met with on his tour , catching flak for only going to an observation point that overlook Rahat and not entering the city itself . Faiz Abu Sahiban , mayor of the largest Bedouin city and the second-largest Arab city in Israel , called the trip an insult . & ldquo ; Rahat is a city well inside the border of Israel , not outside of it . The itinerary of the tour is problematic and disgusting in how it treat a city that is in the heart of the state a a threat . & rdquo ; What would happen if the state intervenes ? & ldquo ; [ We would have ] a completely protected minority that can live fully under the law and protect their own culture , & rdquo ; Regavim said . In Regavim & rsquo ; s eye , there are two step that are necessary to take to ensure stability in the region : Putting people on the map & ndash ; making sure that everyone is registered to a real address , for accountability and tracking & ndash ; and resolving land ownership dispute . In October , Bennett & rsquo ; s government wa threatened over a bill introduced by Ra & rsquo ; am ( United Arab List ) , later passing in the plenum a the electricity law . The law allows thousand of illegally built home to be hooked up to the national electricity grid . & ldquo ; The government woke up and realized that 300,000 Bedouin are living here [ without proper infrastructure ] and that this is a ticking time bomb . So , the government started to change it tune , & rdquo ; the police said . Beersheba is the fastest growing city in Israel , but it can & rsquo ; t grow because of the illegal encampment surrounding it . If that is the case , & ldquo ; we & rsquo ; re finished , & rdquo ; Regavim & rsquo ; s Kahn said . According to the Israel Police , a solution could be found by taking the right approach in the dispute between the two culture & ndash ; Western-Israeli and Bedouin . & ldquo ; Anyone who try to understand the Bedouin culture with Western eye will fail , & rdquo ; it said . ■
title: israel 's bedouin : what is the truth behind the crime-ridden headline ?

Body Text: Transportation Minister Miri Regev , who is in charge of the array of upcoming state ceremony commemorating Remembrance Day and Independence Day , held a briefing on Thursday regarding the 76th torch-lighting ceremony , and said that during the ceremony , 12 commemorative torch will be lit , with the October 7 attack at the center of the ceremony . & nbsp ; Regev detailed the change that were made for this year 's ceremony , including the fact that the torch will be lit by group and not by individuals.According to the minister , there will be no firework at this year 's ceremony and the artistic section will be adapted to accommodate the event . The ceremonial section will be reduced , and during the ceremony , reference to fighting in the north and south , the hostage , the evacuee , the wounded , the disabled , and the reservist , and the security and rescue force will be incorporated . The aforementioned ceremony will be filmed in advance and will take place without an audience , following consultation with security personnel . & nbsp ; `` This year there will be no celebration like last year . It 's hard for u to celebrate during a war and when there are 133 hostage still in Hamas captivity , `` Regev said . & nbsp ; Uncertainty of war influence ceremony & nbsp ; `` The task of choosing torch lighter from thousand of recommendation is impossible . This year , the torch will be lit in group . `` She also announced that `` the ceremony will be held on video , without an audience , because the war is in progress and we do n't know how the different front will develop . `` `` We do n't know what will happen in Gaza , what will happen in Rafah , how it will develop in the north , and in light of that , I want to ensure that the ceremony will take place because there is no question that the ceremony should take place like every year , `` said Regev and added : `` I made a decision that the right thing to do is not to cancel the ceremony , and rather film it without an audience . `` Regev clarified that she will ask Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to deliver a short recorded speech at the torch-lighting ceremony , noting `` The length and scope of the video depends on reality . It is important to have a video of the Prime Minister speaking of the current reality . . . `` According to Regev , this is anchored in the regulation of the ceremony .
title: this is what this year ’ s independence day torch-lighting ceremony will look like amid the war

Body Text: Israel Aerospace Industries ( IAI ) launched it Global Control Center ( GCC ) , which can significantly reduce conversion time from passenger aircraft to freight aircraft.The GCC system , developed in-house , can manage and monitor significant project , notably the international aircraft conversion program that IAI conduct in Israel and worldwide . It will be managed by an advanced control and monitoring center at IAI & rsquo ; s facility.These conversion have experienced a boom in recent year , with a significant increase in the demand for air freight . Data from 2023 show a 15 % increase in demand compared to 2022 , according to IAI , and this is expected to continue in the future.IAI CEO Boaz Levy say the company expects the system & ldquo ; will have a great impact on [ it ] activity , both internally and externally , first in the aviation sector and then in other IAI activity . & rdquo ; The system is now in operation after being tested by all levelsThe system is now in operation after being tested by all level , from aeronautical division manager to project manager and general worker , and it not only reduces conversion time but also optimizes all the logistical process and allows for a targeted and horizontal management of error or challenges.According to IAI , the GCC system allows the company to present the conversion process in real-time to it customer , both new and existing , in a way that wa not previously possible and with a degree of detail that wa until recently considered impossible.IAI ha been converting aircraft for year , including the Boeing 737 , the 767 series , the 777-300 , and the Airbus A330 aircraft , the last two of which are in the final stage of acquiring a license.VP and GM of IAI & rsquo ; s Aviation Group Shmuel Kuzi explained , & ldquo ; Now that it is in full operation , we expect to be able to reduce the working time on each aircraft , improve the response to our customer , and allow new customer to share in the success and enjoy IAI & rsquo ; s converted freighter . & rdquo ;
title: new iai system optimizes passenger-to-freighter aircraft conversion

Body Text: Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas is enraged because Egypt , Qatar and other party chose to hold direct contact on way of preventing further escalation with Israel in the aftermath of the recent tension in Jerusalem and the West Bank , a senior official with the ruling Fatah faction said.The official , who wa not identified by name , told the London-based pan-Arab medium outlet Al-Araby Al-Jadeed that Abbas & ldquo ; did not hide his anger & rdquo ; over being sidelined during the mediation effort with his rival in Hamas . & ldquo ; These effort show that President Abbas is no longer the only party that Arabs turn to when talking about the escalation in al-Aqsa Mosque and the West Bank , & rdquo ; the official added.On Sunday , Abbas abruptly called off an emergency meeting of the Palestinian leadership that wa supposed to discus the rising tension with Israel . The meeting wa scheduled to take place in Ramallah on Sunday evening.Palestinian official said that the PA leadership wa called to discus the implementation of a resolution by the Palestinian Central Council ( PCC ) to terminate all signed agreement with Israel , halt security coordination and suspend PLO recognition of Israel until the Israeli government recognizes a Palestinian state on the pre-1967 line , with east Jerusalem a it capital.The resolution wa announced by the PCC in 2018 and again earlier this year during a meeting in Ramallah.Since the beginning of the tension , Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh , who is based in Doha , Qatar , ha been holding a series of contact with Egypt , Qatar , the United Nations and other party on way of averting an all-out confrontation with Israel.Haniyeh wa in touch with senior Egyptian intelligence official , Qatari ruler Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani and his foreign minister , and the UN Special Coordinator for the Middle East Peace Process Tor Wennesland.The Hamas leader also contacted Arab League Secretary-General Ahmed Aboul Gheit and Oman & rsquo ; s Foreign Minister Sayyid Badr Albusaidi.On Saturday , report surfaced in a number of Arab medium outlet concerning a truce agreement that ha been reached between the Gaza-based terrorist group and Israel.The report created the impression that Abbas and the PA were no longer seen a relevant and influential player . In addition , the report implied that the Hamas leadership wa the only address for restoring calm.Following the news about the truce deal , the PA leadership issued a statement in which it said that Abbas and the Palestinian leadership & ldquo ; continue their action at the international level , including sending message and making contact with a number of world leader and international organization . & rdquo ; According to the statement , & ldquo ; These contact aim to brief world leader and international organization on the dangerous situation that the Palestinian territory are going through , including incursion into city , camp and village , especially what is happening in Jerusalem . & rdquo ; The statement wa clearly intended to show that Abbas and the PA leadership were not sitting on the fence while several country and party were negotiating with Hamas.A PA official insisted on Monday that the Ramallah-based leadership wa & ldquo ; directly involved & rdquo ; in all the contact with international party over the past few day . & ldquo ; The Egyptians and Qataris know that the Palestinian leadership is the only address , & rdquo ; the official told The Jerusalem Post . & ldquo ; Any attempt to sideline President Abbas and the legitimate leadership of the Palestinian people won & rsquo ; t succeed . & rdquo ; The official pointed out that Abbas and Jordan & rsquo ; s King Abdullah discussed the latest development in the Palestinian arena during a phone conversation on Monday.Abbas also held similar discussion with Russian President Vladimir Putin , the emir of Qatar and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan , he said.But a Fatah official told the Hamas-affiliated Shehab news website that Abbas & rsquo ; s insistence on maintaining tight and exclusive control of the decision-making process ha created a crisis in the PA.The official claimed that Abbas wa only consulting with his confidant , senior PLO and Fatah official Hussein al-Sheikh , a well a the commander of the PA security forces.The unnamed official also said that Abbas wa outraged with the Arab and foreign mediator for ignoring him and talking directly to Hamas.Abbas & rsquo ; s decision to call off the planned meeting of the Palestinian leadership raised eyebrow and drew sharp criticism from many Palestinians . It wa unclear , however , if the decision wa the result of Abbas & rsquo ; s reported frustration with the mediator for allegedly sidelining him .
title: pa ’ s abbas ‘ outraged ’ a hamas take center stage in mediation effort

Body Text: An Israeli court ha acquitted the police officer charged with causing the death of 18 - year-old Solomon Tekah of the Ethiopian community , five year ago , Israeli medium reported on Tuesday.The police officer claimed that when he arrived with his wife and child at a playground in a grove in Kiryat Haim he broke up a brawl between teenager , after which the group , Tekah included , threw stone at him and his family.Feeling their life were in danger , the police officer said he shot at the ground.Despite many version of the incident , the evidence showed that the bullet ricocheted off the asphalt and hit Tekah.The killing triggered widespread protest in 2019.Tekah 's family comment on verdict & nbsp ; Tekah & rsquo ; s mother stated , & ldquo ; We are in pain and live in pain , not only we , the parent , but also our child . For a whole month we and the child did not sleep , we knew that the judge would not convict the police officer . We left the court in the middle because tolerating the judge & rsquo ; s word or hearing what he said wa impossible . & rdquo ; Tekah & rsquo ; s father said at the end of the trial , & ldquo ; We didn & rsquo ; t try , and we didn & rsquo ; t think we would get a fair trial from lawyer in Israel . We struggled for four year because we thought we might be able to bring change , but we were deceived . & ldquo ; The 13 young people killed from the Ethiopian community were not killed by the brutal Hamas , but by our people , by policeman whom we finance with our money . They were killed because they were black . How can a policeman 30 meter away from the child dressed a a civilian shoot a boy just because he asked who he wa and to introduce himself ? & ldquo ; There is no police to protect the Ethiopian community and no judge to give u a fair trial , & rdquo ; he added.Leaving court , Tekah & rsquo ; s sister stated , & ldquo ; Now all policeman have a right to kill , & rdquo ; according to Israeli media.Speaking with Maariv , the Tekah family & rsquo ; s lawyer said , & ldquo ; The family is disappointed with the result ; we expected to hear a different decision but hope that the prosecutor & rsquo ; s office will decide to file an appeal.Judge Ziad Falah said following the acquittal , & ldquo ; There is a lacuna in the procedure - in an event in which a police officer is in tangible and immediate danger . . . the policeman ha the authority to shoot at the body of the person endangering him , and to forgo all the warning step preceding the shooting . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; Along with this authority , the policeman must reduce , a much a possible , the danger arising from his authority to shoot at the body of the person endangering him , & rdquo ; the judge added . & ldquo ; The accused acted in self-defense when he carried out the shooting , which unfortunately led to the death of the deceased , & rdquo ; he concluded.Public Committee Against Torture condemns rulingThe Justice Ministry & rsquo ; s Police Investigation Department ( PID ) released a statement which read , & ldquo ; The court ruled today that the filing of the indictment by the PID wa justified and that the PID acted properly and professionally , both in the conduct of the investigation and at the time of the decision on the filing of the indictment and the management of the case . However , the court found that there wa room to acquit the accused for several reason . We will study the verdict and consider our step . & rdquo ; According to Maariv , the PID wa reportedly considering an appeal.The Public Committee Against Torture in Israel said , & ldquo ; Once again the system stand up and back up a violent policeman , who shot to death a young man of Ethiopian origin claiming that he & lsquo ; felt a real threat to his life . & rsquo ; It seems that a far a it concern minority community , any norm or directive that is intended precisely for this type of case , such a shooting warning shot in the air , for example , doe not apply , & rdquo ; the committee continued . & ldquo ; The wheel can not be turned back , nor the life of the late Tekah , but it wa possible to obtain a little justice for his family and the community from which he come , with a conviction that would send a clear and resounding message that police violence is wrong and that violent police officer must be brought to justice . In it decision today , the court turned a cold shoulder to the victim and his family and added another injustice to the pile of injustice already caused in this sad case , & rdquo ; the committee noted.Maariv , Yonah Jeremy Bob , and Mark Weiss contributed to this article .
title: ' license to kill : ' court acquits israeli officer who shot solomon tekah dead in 2019

Body Text: A Palestinian wa killed after firing towards Israeli security force in the village of Burqin , near Jenin & nbsp ; in the West Bank on Thursday morning , according to the Palestinian WAFA news agency . Body Text: The Eurovision 2024 slogan is & ldquo ; United by Music , & rdquo ; but Israeli Eurovision fan fear that the true slogan this year may be & ldquo ; United by Hate and Antisemitism . & rdquo ; It wa never going to be easy for Eden Golan , Israel & rsquo ; s contestant , to compete in Eurovision in 2024 during the war with Hamas , but the fact that the international song contest will be held this year in Malmo , Sweden , considered to be one of the most antisemitic city in the world , ha made it infinitely more complicated and dangerous for Israel to take part . & nbsp ; The war would have affected Israel & rsquo ; s participation in any city , but last year , when Sweden & rsquo ; s Loreen won the competition with her song , & ldquo ; Tattoo , & rdquo ; it guaranteed that the competition would move to Malmo , since the contest is held in the home country of the previous year & rsquo ; s winner . & nbsp ; A city known for antisemitic threat and harassmentMalmo , Sweden & rsquo ; s third largest city , is a port city connected by the Oresund Bridge to Copenhagen , but it location , unfortunately doe not ensure that it is cosmopolitan or tolerant . Malmo ha a population of a little over 350,000 and there are about 100,000 Muslims in the region . In recent year , the small Jewish community in the city ha reported serious antisemitic threat and harassment from Malmo & rsquo ; s Muslim residents.Israeli Eurovision contestant have always performed under heavy security , but according to multiple medium report , security measure have been heightened greatly in advance of this year & rsquo ; s contest , which will open on May 7 . & nbsp ; Golan is set to perform in the semi-final on May 9 . She and the entire Israeli delegation & ndash ; consisting of her dancer , musician , stylist , and others & ndash ; is said to have been told by the Shin Bet , Israel & rsquo ; s security service , to stay in their Malmo hotel room at all time , except when Golan is actually performing . & nbsp ; While Israelis have always needed security , past Israeli delegation to Eurovision contest have had at least some opportunity to mingle with the other delegation and enjoy the city in which the contest ha been held , an important part of participating in an international competition . But this year , the focus will be on keeping them safe to the exclusion of everything else in the wake of anti-war protest and threats.A recent report by Keshet 12 News correspondent Ohad Hemo and Elad Simchayoff on Malmo revealed a disturbing level of antisemitism among the Muslim population of the city . The reporter and their crew were threatened , assaulted , and spit on many time by Muslim resident of Malmo who heard them speaking Hebrew . Being filmed did not deter these harasser . & nbsp ; One Jewish resident of an upscale Malmo neighborhood told the Keshet correspondent that she wa alerted to the Hamas attack on the morning of October 7 by hearing cheer from the street that were so loud that they woke her . Yair Elsner , also a Jewish Malmo resident , told them that in the first week after October 7 , he would walk from his building to his car carrying a knife to protect himself . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; You go outside and you see exactly the same people who did October 7 , but here . There is no difference & ndash ; there is no reason to assume that they wouldn & rsquo ; t be able to commit the same atrocity on u here if only they could , & rdquo ; he told them . & nbsp ; Keshet reported that seven out of 10 Swedish Jews testified in a recent survey that their life had become more difficult following October 7 and about half of them said they had considered or were considering leaving the country.Perhaps the most chilling aspect of their report wa that guard at a Malmo mosque , who did not realize that the Keshet correspondent were Jewish , told them that they had heard there would be a bomb attack at Eurovision and that everyone they knew wa going to stay away from Malmo Arena , where the contest will take place . & nbsp ; UNFORTUNATELY , antisemitism in Malmo is nothing new . Fourteen year ago , the Simon Wiesenthal Center issued a travel warning for Jews to southern Sweden and especially to Malmo . In 2015 , a Swedish journalist walked around the city wearing a kippah and a Star of David had to stop filming earlier than planned because so many people threatened him , cursed him , and threw egg at him . & nbsp ; In 2016 , Danish Jewish actor Kim Bodnia quit the hit detective series , The Bridge , which wa filmed in Malmo and Copenhagen , saying in an interview , & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s not very comfortable to be [ in Malmo ] a a Jewish person . & rdquo ; It isn & rsquo ; t only antisemitism that is on the rise in Sweden , but lawlessness in general . According to report , in 2022 , in Stockholm , the number of gun murder wa 30 time higher than that of London . & ldquo ; These are difficult time for Sweden , & rdquo ; Olaf Kristersson , the prime minister said . & ldquo ; Sweden ha never seen anything like this before & ndash ; no other country in Europe ha seen anything like this . & rdquo ; While Sweden may have the reputation of being a clean , prosperous country with great social service such a health care and a high standard of living , in recent year , it ha been coping with an epidemic of drug gang violence that includes bomb and grenade attack . & nbsp ; In an article headlined , & ldquo ; Sweden & rsquo ; s new normal : Bombs in the suburb on a weeknight & rdquo ; in Politico , Charles Duxbury wrote in early October 2023 : & ldquo ; The upswell of [ gang ] violence ha been so intense , widespread , and chaotically executed & ndash ; inexperienced teenage boy are often recruited to carry out the attack & ndash ; that there is a growing sense here that no one is safe from it . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; According to The Guardian , in 2023 there were 149 successful bomb detonation and 62 attempted bombing in Sweden , in a country with a total population of about 10.5 million people . & nbsp ; THE LAWLESSNESS and antisemitism have combined to give Israeli security the challenge of a lifetime , while the delegation will also have to cope with hostility from other Eurovision contestant . Some artist have called for Israel to be banned from Eurovision , a Russia wa following it invasion of Ukraine , but the European Broadcasting Union ( EBU ) , which run Eurovision , ha reiterated it stance that it is a contest for broadcaster , not government , and that Israel & rsquo ; s Kan broadcaster ha done nothing wrong . & nbsp ; Yet , despite the threat level , Eden Golan & rsquo ; s song , & ldquo ; Hurricane & rdquo ; ha consistently been in the top 10 in the Eurovision betting table , considered a reliable measure of success in the contest ; at presstime , & ldquo ; Hurricane & rdquo ; wa in the seventh spot out of 37 country . & nbsp ; Israel & rsquo ; s original choice for it song , & ldquo ; October Rain , & rdquo ; wa rejected by the EBU . Eurovision & rsquo ; s policy is that song should avoid specific political content and the song wa seen a a comment on the Hamas massacre , which it unquestionably wa . & nbsp ; The new song , & ldquo ; Hurricane , & rdquo ; made the lyric vaguer , although the sentiment expressed is essentially the same . The music video released for the song show Golan singing at a location that look much like the Supernova music festival , where about 10 % of the attendee were murdered and taken hostage on October 7 , with dancer seemingly writhing in agony . & nbsp ; Israel began taking part in Eurovision in 1973 , even though it is not in Europe , since it would not have been welcomed in a Middle Eastern regional song contest . Body Text: US President Joe Biden @ @ @ s plan to work to reopen the Palestinians @ @ @ diplomatic mission in Washington could be held up over a law that expose Palestinian official to US anti-terror lawsuit , official and adviser to the Palestinians say . & nbsp ; The Biden administration hope to repair relation with the Palestinians after a sharp deterioration under former President Donald Trump , who closed the Palestine Liberation Organization @ @ @ s Washington office in 2018 and cut million of dollar in aid to the West Bank and Gaza Strip . & nbsp ; But under an anti-terror amendment passed by Congress and signed into law by Trump in 2019 , the Palestinians would become liable for $ 655.5 million in financial penalty against them in US court if they open an office in the United States . & nbsp ; There are also question about how Biden will fulfill a pledge to resume economic aid to the Palestinians . The Taylor Force Act , passed by Congress in 2018 , restricts some aid until the Palestinians end payment to people jailed by Israel over violent crime , among other condition . & nbsp ; Speaking to the United Nations Security Council on Tuesday , Acting US envoy Richard Mills said Washington & quot ; intended to take step to reopen diplomatic mission that were closed for the last US administration , & quot ; without giving a timeline . & nbsp ; The legal hurdle underscore the range of challenge Biden may face in restoring tie with the Palestinians and reversing action taken by Trump , who overturned longtime US Middle East policy with a series of pro-Israel step including ending US opposition to Israeli settlement in the West Bank . & nbsp ; Palestinians say his action discredited the longtime US role a chief mediator in their conflict with Israel and further dimmed any chance of a peace deal envisaging a Palestinian state in Israeli-occupied territory . & nbsp ; Palestinian leader have welcomed Biden @ @ @ s pledge of rapprochement , but while he can reverse some measure through executive order , others involve law passed by Congress and are not a easily changed . & nbsp ; Asked for comment , a US State Department official told Reuters : & quot ; In administering aid , the Biden-Harris Administration will fully comply with US law including the Taylor Force Act . & quot ; & nbsp ; The official did not comment on whether the Biden administration would look into working around the anti-terror amendment to help rebuild relation with the Palestinians . & nbsp ; TALKS ON A @ @ @ FIX @ @ @ & nbsp ; Talks are ongoing with the administration and Congress about finding a & quot ; fix & quot ; to the amendment that would allow the PLO mission to reopen , an American legal adviser to the Palestinians said , adding that the Palestinians & quot ; don @ @ @ t have the money to pay & quot ; the financial claim against them . & nbsp ; Palestinian official declined to comment . & nbsp ; A Biden adviser told Reuters just before the Nov . 3 election that Biden would seek to reopen the PLO mission to Washington but added : & quot ; There is a law that could make that more challenging . & quot ; & nbsp ; The anti-terror amendment make the Palestinians liable for the hefty financial penalty that a US jury awarded against them if they establish or maintain any facility in the United States , conduct activity on behalf of the PLO or the Palestinian Authority , or make payment to Palestinians imprisoned over violent crime against Americans , among other condition . & nbsp ; The jury award stem from lawsuit by 11 American family who sought to hold the PA and PLO liable for shooting and bombing by between 2002 and 2004 in Jerusalem that killed 33 people , including several Americans . & nbsp ; Palestinian leader have condemned the attack and blamed them on rogue individual . & nbsp ; But the US Supreme Court in 2018 refused to consider awarding those claim , upholding a lower court finding that there wa no jurisdiction for attack outside US territory .

Body Text: The IDF thwarted a stabbing attack against civilian at a bus stop at the Giti Avishar junction in the Samaria region of the West Bank , killing the Palestinian terrorist . I shot in order to neutralize him . & rdquo ; The IDF explained that the terrorist had run in the direction of a bus stop where both soldier and civilian were standing . Earlier this week , Defense Minister Benny Gantz held a meeting with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas in an effort to thwart a violent Palestinian uprising in the West Bank . The rare meeting , which took place in Gantz & rsquo ; s Rosh Ha & rsquo ; ayin home , wa the second one between the two leader . They had met in August in Ramallah . Ghassan Alian told Army Radio that the situation wa tense and that the PA wanted to maintain stability and de-escalate the situation . After praising the soldier & rsquo ; conduct during the incident , Dagan blamed the government & rsquo ; s policy of not acting strongly enough against terror . & ldquo ; The Israeli government , unfortunately , is harming it deterrence and losing it time and time again ; we see this in severe attack attempt , over and over again , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; I call on the Israeli government to wake up , and to learn from IDF soldier how to fight terrorism . Terrorism is not negotiated , terrorism is not embraced : Terrorism is defeated and terrorism is fought and eradicated . & rdquo ; According to IDF data released midweek , the number of Palestinian shooting and stabbing attack against Israeli civilian and security force in the West Bank ha doubled to the highest it ha been in four year . Amit Ben Yigal , 21 , killed in a military operation in the West Bank village of Yabad , and Esther Horgan , a civilian who wa killed while jogging near her home in the Tal Menashe settlement . Body Text: Cruelty , suspicion , and complete indifference to the suffering of his family and his people & mdash ; these are some of the quality that are revealed when reading the testimony of Yahya Sinwar , the leader of Hamas in Gaza , from his day a a young and particularly dangerous operative in the rank of the terrorist organization.The quality cited here were referenced by Sinwar during a recently revealed police interrogation in 1989 . Body Text: A group of 40 West Bank Palestinian civilian made history on Monday when they flew to Cyprus from Ramon Airport near Eilat , which they had been banned from using until now.Physicians and pharmacist and their family from Bethlehem and Hebron were among member of a group who were allowed to board a regularly scheduled Arkia flight to Larnaca . & ldquo ; Until today , flight for Palestinians in a unique framework , and in particular from Ramon Airport , were just a dream , & rdquo ; Arkia Israeli Airlines CEO Oz Berlowitz said . & ldquo ; And indeed , the dream ha been fulfilled . & rdquo ; `` The dream ha been fulfilled . `` Arkia CEO Oz BerlowitzMost Palestinians who go abroad fly out of Amman , entering Jordan via the Allenby Bridge crossing.So can Palestinians go to Ben-Gurion Airport ? & nbsp ; Some 10,000 Palestinians , including senior PA official who hold Israeli-issued VIP card , have been permitted to travel through Ben-Gurion Airport.Amir Assi , a strategic consultant for Arkia who helped organize the trip , said West Bank Palestinians currently can access Ramon Airport only through special group option , such a this one . The airport is not open to individual West Bank Palestinians.The Airport Authority had initially planned a pilot program of two weekly flight to Turkey for West Bank Palestinians , one through Antalya and another through Istanbul . The plan would have been executed through two Turkish airline company , but there were difficulty organizing flight time and available aircraft . On Sunday , the Airport Authority said the plan had been delayed.Who is against the decision ? & nbsp ; The Palestinian Authority on Monday renewed it call for Palestinians not to use Ramon Airport.The owner of travel and tourist agency in Jordan have protested the Israeli decision to open Ramon Airport to Palestinian passenger , arguing that it would cause huge financial damage to their company and the Jordanian economy.The opening of Ramon Airport to Palestinian passenger drew mixed feeling from Palestinians . Some expressed support for the move , saying it would facilitate their travel abroad , while others dismissed the idea for political reason , dubbing it an act of & ldquo ; normalization & rdquo ; with Israel . & ldquo ; We have already stated and appealed to the resident not to use the [ Ramon ] airport because this is an Israeli interest , and it & rsquo ; s harmful to Palestinian sovereignty , & rdquo ; PA Transportation Ministry spokesman Musa Rahhal wa quoted a saying by the Palestinian Al-Watan Voice medium outlet . `` This is an Israeli interest and it & rsquo ; s harmful to Palestinian sovereignty . `` Musa Rahhal , the spokesman of the PA Ministry of TransportThe PA continues to demand that Israel allow Palestinians to travel through the airport located north of Jerusalem and the airport in the southern Gaza Strip , he said.Jerusalem International Airport in Atarot , north of Jerusalem ( also known a the Kalandiya Airport ) , ha been closed to civilian traffic since the Second Intifada in 2000.The airport in the Gaza Strip , which wa inaugurated in 1998 and named Yasser Arafat International Airport , also ceased operation in 2000 . In 2001 , Israel bombed the radar station and control tower . The following year , Israeli bulldozer cut the runway , rendering the airport inoperable.Rahhal said the PA wa also demanding that Palestinians be permitted to establish a new airport in the West Bank that would be under exclusive Palestinian control .

Body Text: As swiftly a a hurricane , Israel & rsquo ; s Eurovision contestant , Eden Golan , shot up the betting table from eighth place to the number two spot following her performance in the second semi-final at the 68th Eurovision Song Contest in Malmo , Sweden on Thursday night , in which she secured a place in the Grand Final , which will take place on Saturday.Although there were protest outside the arena and the 20-year-old Golan wa booed by a she sang & ldquo ; Hurricane , & rdquo ; she also received thunderous applause , winning heart around the world with her grace under pressure . The result of each country & rsquo ; s vote is meant to be secret , but RAI , the Italian broadcaster , briefly showed the detailed breakdown on screen which revealed that Golan had won 39.3 % of it country & rsquo ; s votes.RAI ha since said that the result it released were `` incomplete . `` And here is a graphic of the televoting odds , showing Israel in first place : http : / / eurovisionworld.com/odds/eurovision-teleWhether she will do a well in the Grand Final , in which the result will be determined by national jury from the participating country a well a by fan from around the world , remains to be seen . Israel is now predicted to win the televote , with the oddsmakers giving Golan a 43 % chance of a televote win . But she is predicted to come in fifth in the jury vote , which will mean that she will ultimately finish second to the favorite , Croatia 's Baby Lasagna with the high-energy song , `` Rim Tim Tagi Dim . `` & nbsp ; But her performance Thursday and the resulting score were a triumph for Golan and for Israel . Each shout from the crowd seemed only to enhance the preternaturally poised Golan & rsquo ; s performance , a she hit every note and dance move perfectly.Far more experienced performer might have cracked under the kind of pressure and distraction that Golan faced , but she tuned them out and did her best work to date . `` I did n't hear the boo , `` she said in a press conference following the semi-final . `` I wa completely focused . I felt no apprehension and no fear . `` Sometimes a song is just a song and Eurovision is just a fun song contest that Israel tends to do well in , which it ha won four time in the past.But not this year.Israel 's journey through Eurovision conflictAt first , it wasn & rsquo ; t even clear that Israel would send a contestant because of the war that started following the Hamas massacre in Israel on October 7 . It wa decided that the best choice would be to participate , but to use the song and the platform to acknowledge the tragedy.The shadow of the war hovered over the Next Star for Eurovision contest , a Shaul Greenglick , who appeared in early December , wa killed in the fighting in the Gaza Strip . The judge were enthusiastic about his performance , and he would have advanced to the next round.Golan , a polished and experienced performer , who wa a child star in Russia , where she spent much of her childhood due to her father & rsquo ; s work , won the contest and Israeli Eurovision fan rejoiced . But even while Israelis were pleased with Golan , there were difficulty over the first song chosen by Israel , & ldquo ; October Rain , & rdquo ; because it contained reference to the massacre , which the European Broadcasting Union ( EBU ) , sponsor of the contest , found too overtly political . It wa eventually replaced by & ldquo ; Hurricane , & rdquo ; which contains softer lyric , but still seems to refer to recent events.The music video released with the song seemed to show Golan and dancer in a field like where the Supernova Music Festival , where almost 400 concertgoers and staff were killed on October 7 and another 400 were kidnapped , took place.The song by Avi Ohayon , Keren Peles , and Stav Berger , contains these lyric in English , & ldquo ; Every day , I 'm losin ' my mind . . . Dancin & rsquo ; in the storm/I got nothing to hide/Take it all and leave the world behind/Baby promise me you & rsquo ; ll hold me again/I & rsquo ; m still broken from this hurricane , & rdquo ; with additional lyric in Hebrew : & ldquo ; We don & rsquo ; t need big word , just prayers/Even if it & rsquo ; s hard to see/You always leave me one little light . & rdquo ; The costume are sand-colored strip of cloth , very different from the usual body-baring , flashy Eurovision look , and were designed by Alon Livne and styled by Itay Bezaleli , that look like torn clothes or bandage and the dancer moved in a loose-limbed but focused way that wa reminiscent of Batsheva choreographer Ohad Naharin & rsquo ; s Gaga technique.It isn & rsquo ; t a stretch to see the song a the word of a young woman who ha lost the love of her life in the massacre looking back and honoring his memory.But it wasn & rsquo ; t only Israel & rsquo ; s song choice that raised the stake this year . Thousands of artist , mainly from Ireland and Scandinavia , called for Israel to be banned and for artist to boycott the event , although none did.Malmo ha a large Muslim population much of which , according to medium report , are particularly hostile to Israel . The Israeli government issued travel warning for Israelis attending to the event and the head of the Shin Bet security agency , Ronen Bar , went to Malmo to personally supervise Golan & rsquo ; s security . Not many people outside Sweden know that Thunberg & rsquo ; s mother , Malena Ernman , is a professional singer who represented Sweden in Eurovision in 2009 , finishing in 21st place.That wa the year that Israel sent Noa and Mira Awad , a Jew and a Christian Arab , to compete . The duo finished in 16th place with their song , & ldquo ; There Must Be Another Way , & rdquo ; which celebrates coexistence , although if her mother ever told her about that , Thunberg seemed to have forgotten on Thursday.Golan and the Israeli delegation had security like a head of state , with a motorcade comprised of dozen of car accompanying her from her hotel to the venue . But Golan said in numerous interview that she had felt only & ldquo ; good vibe & rdquo ; from her fellow contestant , although there were sign that not everyone wa so accepting of her presence.During a press conference after she advanced to the final , a Polish journalist asked Golan , & ldquo ; Have you ever thought that by being here , you bring risk and danger for other participant ? & rdquo ; Told she did n't have to answer the question , Golan responded , nonetheless , & ldquo ; I think we & rsquo ; re all here for one reason , and one reason only . Body Text: Two of Israel & rsquo ; s top international law official have published a rare public article to challenge the International Criminal Court prosecution and others who say that Israel still illegally occupies Gaza . The article , published in the journal Iyunei Mishpat ( Legal Studies ) recently but being reported now for the first time in English , is important both regarding addressing case of alleged Israeli war crime in ongoing fighting with Hamas , a well a regarding what humanitarian obligation Jerusalem ha to Gaza , during coronavirus and other period . These issue ultimately have major long-term implication at the national security and diplomatic level , including whether Israel & rsquo ; s naval blockade and other periodic closure of Gaza are legal . Just a important are the author : Deputy Attorney-General ( International Law ) Roy Schondorf and IDF International Law Division chief Col . Eran Shamir-Borer , two official who have led much of Israel & rsquo ; s handling of ICC issue and humanitarian dilemma with Gaza . Schondorf rarely writes publicly or appears in public with the exception of specific conference or at the Knesset , and Shamir-Borer appears even less often . It seems that the impetus for their article wa to address prior statement by ICC Prosecutor Fatou Bensouda a well a a current article by prominent Israeli prof . Eyal Gross in the same journal , declaring that Israel still legally occupies Gaza , despite having withdrawn in 2005 . If Bensouda , Gross and a number of Israeli critic in UN and international body are correct that Israel occupies Gaza , it could mean that the Jewish state might be restricted in what category of force it could use to combat Hamas attack , let alone protest or riot on the border . Further , it could mean that any humanitarian crisis in Gaza put Israel at fault . When there are debate about Israeli blockade to prevent rocket and other weapon smuggling , these legal question could have a decisive impact . Essentially , Bensouda , Gross and much of the international community say that it is irrelevant that the IDF withdrew and that Israel withdrew it settlement from within the Gaza Strip . Rather , they argue that UN General Assembly decision , International Committee of the Red Cross ( ICRC ) guidance , a decision by the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia ( ICTY ) and other point prove that Israel can & ldquo ; occupy & rdquo ; Gaza a long a it exerts functional control . To support their argument , they note that Israel control Gaza & rsquo ; s airspace , maritime border , wherever there is a blockade , and most of it land border . Gaza doe have one border crossing with Egypt . They broaden these argument by saying that Israel & rsquo ; s ability to control Gaza & rsquo ; s interaction with the outside world mean it can also control the economic and humanitarian situation there . In this light , they say that Israel is also obligated to maintain Gaza from a humanitarian perspective , whether with special need during coronavirus time or with sufficient medical , food , utility and other item during more normal period . IN CONTRAST , Schondorf and Shamir-Bohrer say that there is no basis to rely on the decision of the UN General Assembly or other political body to decide international law . Regarding the ICTY decision , they say that critic & rsquo ; understanding of the decision is misplaced . In the ICTY case in question , the court wa dealing with a situation where a foreign state controlled an internal group within another state in order to impose it will on the other state . In any event , the Israeli official & rsquo ; article say that the ICTY decision wa an outlier creating a new doctrine which no one else ha adopted . Moreover , the article say that the idea Israeli critic are bringing to the Gaza question are & ldquo ; wishful thinking & rdquo ; or & ldquo ; aspiration & rdquo ; to create a new law which doe not exist . Instead , they say that to be considered an & ldquo ; occupier , & rdquo ; a country can not merely have aspect of functional power over a territory . Rather , it must have at a minimum & ldquo ; effective control . & rdquo ; This traditionally ha required boot on the ground and , at the very least , involvement in running the day-to-day affair of the foreign territory and population . As the article say , Israel ha zero involvement in running Gaza & rsquo ; s day-to-day affair , which are run by Hamas . Further , the article cite a legal brief filed by Germany in the Israel-Palestinian proceeding before the ICC to support it view . All of this mean that Israel ha not occupied Gaza since 2005 . Rather , when Israel facilitates food , economic and medical aid to Gaza , it is on a voluntary humanitarian basis and balanced along with valid security consideration , say the article . In December 2019 , Bensouda requested that the ICC Pretrial Chamber endorse by March her desire to conduct a full criminal probe of Israel and Hamas regarding the 2014 Gaza War , the 2018 Gaza border crisis and the settlement enterprise . The chamber ha still not decided the issue , with the question remaining whether it will decide after US President-elect Joe Biden take office or wait for Bensouda & rsquo ; s successor to take over in June 2021 .

Body Text: The world & rsquo ; s climate is changing & ndash ; again . But instead of getting warmer the last time like it is now , in around 6,200 BCE , it wa getting colder.A drought resulted and launched what wa called the 8.2ka ( kiloyears & ndash ; thousand of year & ndash ; ago ) , which began about 8,200 year ago and lasted for the next two to four century in the southern Levant that includes modern-day Israel , the Palestinian territory , Jordan , Lebanon , southern Syria and the Sinai desert.Until now , archaeologist thought that this sudden cooling in global climate led to the widespread abandonment of coastal settlement in the southern Levant . However , researcher at the University of Haifa , Bar-Ilan University ( BIU ) in Ramat Gan , and the University of California at San Diego have produced new evidence suggesting that at least one village formerly thought abandoned not only remained occupied but thrived throughout this period . They said the study helped fill a gap in our understanding of the early settlement of the Eastern Mediterranean coastline.They have just published their study in the journal Antiquity under the title & ldquo ; Continuity and climate change : the Neolithic coastal settlement of Habonim North , Israel . & rdquo ; The village of Habonim North wa discovered off the Carmel Coast in the mid-2010s and later surveyed by a team led by the University of Haifa & rsquo ; s Dr . Ehud Arkin Shalev . The study wa led by Prof . Assaf Yasur-Landau , head of the Leon Recanati Institute for Maritime Studies at the University of Haifa , and Roey Nickelsberg , a doctoral candidate there . BIU Prof . Ehud Weiss and Dr . Suembikya Frumin also participated . & ldquo ; This study helped fill a gap in our understanding of the early settlement of the Eastern Mediterranean coastline , & rdquo ; said Prof . Thomas Levy , a co-author on the paper , co-director of UC San Diego & rsquo ; s Center for Cyber-Archaeology and Sustainability ( CCAS ) and chairman of Archaeology of Ancient Israel and Neighboring Lands in the anthropology department of the university & rsquo ; s graduate division.Unearthing the Levantine coastline & ldquo ; It deal with human resilience , & rdquo ; he said . An experienced scuba diver , Levy spent 40 year carrying out archaeological field work in the desert of Israel and Jordan.Before it excavation and analysis , there wa little evidence for human habitation along the southern Levantine coast during the 8.2ka event . The dig , which involved a weeks-long , 24/7 coordinated effort between the partner in the two country , wa the first formal excavation of the submerged site.Animal bonesLED BY Yasur-Landau and Nickelsberg , the international team excavated the site using a combination of sediment dredging and sampling , a well a photogrammetry and 3D modeling . Team member uncovered pottery shard or & ldquo ; sherd & rdquo ; ; stone tool , including ceremonial weapon and fishing-net weight ; animal and plant remains ; and architecture.Using radiocarbon dating , the researcher tested the recovered bone of wild and domesticated animal , the charred seed of wild plant , crop like wheat and lentil , and weed that tend to accompany these crop . Their result traced these organic material back to the Early Pottery Neolithic ( EPN ) , which coincided with both the invention of pottery and the 8.2ka event.Pottery sherd , stone tool and architecture in the village were also evidence of activity at the site to the EPN and , surprisingly , to the Late Pottery Neolithic , when the village wa thought to have been abandoned.As for how the village likely weathered the worst of the climate instability , the researcher point to sign of an economy that diversified from farming to include maritime culture and trade within a distinct cultural identity . Evidence includes fishing-net weight ; tool made of basalt , a stone that doe not naturally occur along this part of the eastern Mediterranean coast ; and a ceremonial mace head . & ldquo ; Our study showed that the Early Pottery Neolithic society displayed multi-layered resilience that enabled it to withstand the 8.2ka crisis , & rdquo ; noted Yasur-Landau , a senior author on the paper . & ldquo ; I wa happily surprised by the richness of the find , from pottery to organic remains . & rdquo ; Although scientist debate the cause of the 8.2ka event , some speculate that it began with the final collapse of the Laurentide ice sheet , which shaped much of the North American landscape in it retreat from modern-day Canada and the northern US . As it melted , the ice sheet would have changed the flow of ocean current and affected heat transport , leading to the observed drop in global temperatures.Many of the activity uncovered at the village , including the creation of culturally distinct pottery and trade , formed the basis for later urban society . & ldquo ; To me , what & rsquo ; s important is to change how we look at thing , & rdquo ; said Nickelsberg . & ldquo ; Many archaeologist like to look at the collapse of civilization . Maybe it & rsquo ; s time to start looking at the development of human culture , rather than it destruction and abandonment .
title: joint us-israeli underwater excavation reveal ancient human resilience despite climate change

Body Text: September 17 , 2021 mark 43 year since the signing of the Camp David Accords between former Israeli prime minister Menachem Begin and former Egyptian president Anwar Sadat , under the auspex of then US president Jimmy Carter . It paved the way for the 1979 Israeli-Egyptian peace deal , the first such treaty between Israel and one of it Arab neighbor . The Camp David Accords wa the culmination of considerable political machination and came just year after the conclusion of the Yom Kippur War in 1973 , widely regarded a Israel 's darkest hour and where Egypt played a major role a the aggressor . The war wa devastating , with the Jewish state flanked in a surprise attack by Egypt and Syria . Though Israel achieved a military victory over it adversary and came within shelling range of Damascus , the war shocked the Jewish state out of complacency , prompting the resignation of Israel 's prime minister Golda Meir . After the war Israelis viewed the Egyptian military in a new , more dangerous light . However , Egypt had seen the conflict differently . Despite Egyptian military success in the conflict , some in Cairo were convinced that Israel simply could not be beaten on the battlefield . As such , it seemed doubtful they could use force of arm to destroy the Jewish state . But one thing it undoubtedly achieved wa to shift the region 's status quo . & nbsp ; Two event then further changed everything and set the scene for the eventual peace talk . The first event wa on May 17 , 1977 . This wa Israel 's general election and saw the right-wing Likud Party , led by Begin , achieve a historic upset with a landslide victory , giving Israel a right-wing government for the first time ever . The second event wa Sadat 's historic interview on CBS News with Walter Cronkite on November 14 of the same year . During this interview , Sadat shocked the world by saying that he wa more than willing to actually visit Jerusalem for peace negotiation . & nbsp ; `` I want to discus the whole situation with the 120 member of the Knesset and put the full picture and detail of the situation from our point of view , `` he said at the time . & nbsp ; This wa not the first time Sadat expressed willingness to go to Israel , and he had said a much in a speech before the People 's Assembly just five day earlier . However , now his intention were made public to the world . That same day , Cronkite interviewed Begin and asked for his response . & ldquo ; I can assure you , Mr . Cronkite , a we really want the visit of president Sadat , we really want to negotiate the peace , to establish permanent peace in the Middle East , & rdquo ; Begin said . & ldquo ; Any time , any day he 's prepared to come , I will receive him cordially at the airport , and go together with him to Jerusalem , also present him to the Knesset and let him make his speech to our parliament . I will follow him onto the platform and greet him , receive him . & rdquo ; Shortly after , this exact situation happened . Sadat , in an unprecedented and historic moment , arrived at Lod Airport ( known today a Ben-Gurion Airport ) . On November 20 , Sadat then made history by addressing the Knesset . & nbsp ; Sadat 's move threw out the rulebook , taking Washington by surprise . It led to negotiation that culminated in the Camp David Accords , which were signed at the White House by Sadat and Begin in 1978 after 12 day of secret talk at Camp David . There were two framework in the accord . The first dealt with the Palestinians and faced condemnation for a lack of participation from the Palestinians themselves . However , the second framework wa between Egypt and Israel , winning both Begin and Sadat the Nobel Peace Prize and directly leading to the treaty being signed a year later . Notably , a part of the accord , Israel pledged to fully withdraw from the Sinai Peninsula in it entirety . Israel had taken the peninsula following the Six Day War , and Israeli settlement did exist in the area . But now they all had to be withdrawn . But ultimately , it wa seen a a good thing in Israel , where it continues to enjoy support . & nbsp ; According to a 2001 poll by the Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies , 85 % of Israelis support the accord . In Egypt , however , the response wa less positive . The nation of the Arab world were harshly critical of Egypt 's move , costing them their membership in the Arab League and causing unrest and sedition to fester , particularly among Islamist group . Ultimately , on October 6 , 1981 , Sadat wa assassinated at a victory parade by Islamists belonging to the Egyptian Islamic Jihad organization . In total , 11 people were killed at the event outright , including Sadat , an Omani delegate and the Cuban ambassador , while 28 were wounded . Sadat wa ultimately succeeded by his vice president , Hosni Mubarak , who stayed in power for 30 year until the 2011 Arab Spring . Today , Egypt 's relation with Israel are tense , particularly regarding the Palestinian conflict , and security remains strong at the Sinai border . However , Cairo ha maintained an active role in regional affair , particularly regarding the Hamas-ruled Gaza Strip , with which it share a border . & nbsp ; Egypt played a critical role in the restoration of calm that ended the 11-day May war between Israel and Hamas , known a Operation Guardian of the Walls . Despite this , the peace remains cold , and following 2011 , Israeli and Egyptian leader went a decade without meeting , until Prime Minister Naftali Bennett and President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi met at Sharm e-Sheikh . Ultimately , the Camp David Accords are remembered positively a the first truly successful peace negotiation between Israel and an Arab nation . It marked Israel 's first act of normalization with an Arab nation and wa followed decade later by Jordan in 1994 and then 26 year later in 2020 with the Abraham Accords forging peace between Israel , Bahrain , Morocco , Sudan and the United Arab Emirates . Further , the now-iconic image of Sadat and Begin shaking hand remains a testament to the effort of diplomacy .

Body Text: Interior Minister Moshe Arbel of Shas is unlike many other Israeli politicians.For one thing , he doesn & rsquo ; t particularly want to be a politician , and doesn & rsquo ; t have higher political aspiration . If it were up to him , he would be far from the public eye , working on his doctorate in law or spending time with his family.For another , at the outbreak of the Israel-Hamas war on October 7 , Arbel requested of party leader MK Arye Deri to relieve him of the dual duty of interior minister and health minister and leave him just with the former , due to the immense workload of running these two major ministry during wartime . Power and influence are currency for politician , and who else in Israel & rsquo ; s political scene today volunteer to give up a major ministry ? & ldquo ; I see myself in the political arena a a reservist and not a career officer , & rdquo ; Arbel said . His use of military jargon is also rare for a haredi politician & ndash ; indeed , Arbel served in the IDF and in the reserve for year until he became a member of Knesset.He said he is & ldquo ; not motivated by survivability , & rdquo ; and that it doe not matter to him whether he serf another term in politics or not . As a result , he is focused not on reaping short-term achievement but & ldquo ; preparing the ministry & rsquo ; s foundation & rdquo ; so that , when he & ldquo ; hand the key over & rdquo ; to his successor , the ministry will be better than it is now . & ldquo ; The State of Israel need people who enter public role with modesty and with the understanding that they have not conquered territory but are there to serve the public , & rdquo ; he said.Moshe Arbel 's political , rabbinic , and IDF careerARBEL , 40 , is a father of four and life in Petah Tikva . Public service run in the family , a his father served on the Petah Tikva Religious Council and wa a Shas activist . But Arbel himself wa a full-time Torah student until his mid-twenties , and wa ordained a a rabbi . He then joined the IDF Home Front Command in a unit responsible for identifying corps ; earned bachelor & rsquo ; s and master & rsquo ; s degree in law from the Ono Academic College ; served in the IDF reserve a a military prosecutor ; earned a business administration certificate from Harvard University ; and began a doctorate in law at Reichman University.Following the 2013 national election , Arbel served a a legal adviser for Shas , a a legislation adviser to then Knesset member and current Labor Minister Yoav Ben-Tzur , and a a chief of staff for Deri . In April 2023 he wa appointed a both health minister and interior minister , after Deri wa blocked from the position due to previous criminal convictions.The Jerusalem Post interviewed Arbel in his Knesset office on April 8 , and the first issue to be discussed wa the ongoing crisis over the haredi exemption from IDF service . As both a longtime haredi yeshiva student and a long-serving IDF reservist , Arbel & rsquo ; s perspective is important.His approach can be summarized a follows : The IDF ha a real need for soldier , and haredi men who do not study Torah full-time should commit to IDF or other national service . At the same time , Torah study isn & rsquo ; t just a spiritual vocation but an enterprise of national importance.Arbel called this & ldquo ; the national story of a group of Torah student . . . who labor day and night over the Torah , & rdquo ; out of which will grow & ldquo ; great Torah [ scholar ] with broad shoulder . & rdquo ; According to Arbel , these & ldquo ; broad-shouldered & rdquo ; talent are necessary in order to uphold the tradition of & ldquo ; the power of leniency , & rdquo ; a leading policy in the halachic ruling of former Sephardi chief rabbi and Shas spiritual leader Rabbi Ovadia Yosef . & ldquo ; The day where we enter the debate with the deep understanding that there is a national , ethical duty to maintain these Torah student , along with the duty to maintain an economic , military , and socially prosperous state , we can create an ecosystem of understanding that doe not wish to erase the identity of the other side , & rdquo ; Arbel said.This fundamental premise is more important than the detail of a specific haredi conscription plan , he added.Furthermore , Arbel argued that enabling haredi men to serve in the IDF while maintaining their lifestyle is a liberal value a well & ndash ; IDF service isn & rsquo ; t just a duty , it is also a right . The IDF currently doe this & ldquo ; sufficiently & rdquo ; and should continue doing so , he said . He stressed that yeshiva student who were not actually studying and who were & ldquo ; catching a ride & rdquo ; on the blanket exemption should serve in the IDF like all other citizens.Arbel & rsquo ; s approach regarding Torah study and IDF service reflects a broader view on haredi education in general . He explained that the major haredi school system teach a core secular curriculum of some form , but that this need to be expanded and improved . His son , for example , studied at a haredi high school yeshiva , which combined long hour of Torah study with full matriculation exam . There are many such initiative sprouting up , and & ldquo ; good thing are happening & rdquo ; & ndash ; but the state need to facilitate this & ndash ; for example , by lowering the high cost of the institution that offer these sort of combinations.Arbel didn & rsquo ; t rule out giving haredi teen the option of studying Torah full-time . He himself studied only Torah in his teen and completed matriculation requirement later on , and the year of Torah study granted him a work ethic and analytic skill that served him later on in life . But such a system is not appropriate for everyone and should not be forced on haredi teen who aren & rsquo ; t equipped for it , he argued.ARBEL & rsquo ; S WORK in the Interior Ministry ha garnered praise from both side of the political divide , and the ministry wa favorably mentioned for it work following the October 7 Hamas massacre.Asked about this , Arbel wa quick to give credit to the ministry worker . He explained that the ministry includes three branch and described it adaptation post-October 7 in each branch . These change led to a learning process that led to broader initiative not just related to war.The three branch are the local authority ; immigration and citizenship ; and urban planning and development.Following October 7 , the local authority required receiving special power and funding , especially those whose resident were attacked and/or evacuated . On the issue of immigration and citizenship , many of these evacuee left their home without their passport or other identification paper , and the ministry created roaming emergency office that went to hotel in order to provide service for the evacuee . Finally , on the issue of urban planning and development , Arbel had the ministry pas temporary executive order to cut bureaucracy in order to speedily construct new school and medical center for the evacuees.In the day and week after the massacre , some of the survivor were traumatized to the extent that they were not willing to leave their hotel room in order to meet with the roaming immigration office . This led Arbel to wonder why they could not order new document online , and he worked with the defense and other authority to begin providing this service , whose pilot is set to begin at the end of April . Wait time in Israel for immigration service such a renewing a passport are notoriously long , and the ability to order a new passport online could drastically improve this . The idea to enable online documentation order wa an example of how the ministry & rsquo ; s ad hoc adaptation to war need led to broader initiative , Arbel explained.He said he also put a specific emphasis on service to Arab municipality . & ldquo ; On the day I entered office I said that we must understand that we are public servant of all of the citizen of Israel & ndash ; those who voted for u and those who didn & rsquo ; t , even those who are acting against u , & rdquo ; Arbel said.He added that at a certain point when there were protester outside of his home , he said to his child that he is happy to live in a country in which people can protest outside the home of elected official , which is not to be taken for granted.Dealing with Arab municipality includes unique challenge & ndash ; a major one , for example , wa Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich refusing in 2023 to channel NIS 200 million of funding due to the concern that it could end up in the hand of criminal organization . Arbel confronted Smotrich and succeeded in getting the fund through . In some rare case , there were also management problem , such a certain family who won the municipal election refusing to provide service to other family . Arbel added that & ldquo ; good thing & rdquo ; are happening in Arab local authority , citing a an example the town Jatt near Haifa , which elected in the recent municipal election a young engineer who is unaffiliated with large family . This show that resident understand the importance of proper governance aimed first and foremost at improving their daily lives.Arbel view local authority a key factor in bridging social gap . & ldquo ; The goal of local authority is to break through cement ceiling , & rdquo ; he said . Socioeconomic gap in Israel are unacceptably high for a country the size of a district in California , and correct investment by municipality , such a in fundamental aspect of formal and informal education & ndash ; schoolroom , teacher , hot meal , etc . & ndash ; could serve a the basis for real social mobility , which Arbel said is & ldquo ; one of the most significant tool in our national resilience . & rdquo ; The war between Russia and Ukraine and the rise in antisemitism worldwide since October 7 ha led to increased interest by Diaspora Jews in moving to Israel . Another notable initiative that Arbel mentioned wa creating an & ldquo ; aliyah eligibility document . & rdquo ; What happens , Arbel explained , is that potential olim sometimes express interest in moving to Israel but do not follow through with the process , such that if they want to renew it later on they will have to start afresh . Instead , Arbel proposed enabling these family to complete all of the necessary paperwork without actually making the move & ndash ; and thus enabling them to make aliyah immediately in the future if they wish.Arbel preferred not to express his view on the situation in Gaza and the public debate about how much Israel should concede in a hostage deal . But perhaps more important than his work in the Interior Ministry and his support of haredi enlistment is his sympathy for the family of the hostages.He said he is concerned by criticism that minister had not met enough with the family of hostage since the war broke out , and said that he meet at least once a week with a family . The meeting are difficult , and the family are experiencing immense pain and anger , but a a government minister Arbel said he doe not have the right to avoid the family . He added that he & ldquo ; allows himself to cry with the family , & rdquo ; and that his moral duty is & ldquo ; first and foremost to see their pain . & rdquo ; & nbsp ;
title: haredi , harvard , home front command : the enigma of moshe arbel

Body Text: Simona Steinbrecher had no information about her youngest daughter , Doron , for more than 100 day after Hamas kidnapped her from Kibbutz Kfar Aza on the morning of October 7 . Now I can & rsquo ; t even think about how terrible it is for her to be in Gaza all this time , & rdquo ; Simona added.According to Simona , Doron ha a serious hormonal health issue and need to have medicine every day . & ldquo ; I can see from how she look in the video that they didn & rsquo ; t give her the medicine , & rdquo ; Simona said.The hostage who have returned from Gaza have shared with Simona alarming report .
