What did she do to them ? Why take her ? They took baby , little kid , woman , elderly & mdash ; everyone ! For what ? & rdquo ; she asked.Despite experiencing unimaginable emotional pain and horror , Simona continues to fiercely fight for the world to recognize the heinous crime being committed against hostage and unite to combat terrorism once and for all . & ldquo ; The world need to know how brutal Hamas is , & rdquo ; Simona insisted . & ldquo ; They are not people ; they just want to kill . I don & rsquo ; t understand why the world doesn & rsquo ; t scream about what is happening . The world need to tell them to stop . & rdquo ; Simona belief that the problem in the ongoing conflict is not Israel but rather Hamas & rsquo ; refusal to engage in negotiation and reach an agreement . & ldquo ; Sinwar doesn & rsquo ; t want a deal , & rdquo ; she said , referring to Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar . & ldquo ; When we [ Israel ] are close to the deal , he always ha new condition he want Israel to do . How can you make a deal with someone who change his mind all the time ? It is impossible , & rdquo ; she claimed.Simona & rsquo ; s message is clear and urgent : We must unite a a global community with a singular objective & mdash ; to exert pressure on Hamas to release the hostage and agree to a cease-fire . Only collective effort can make a difference , according to Simona . & ldquo ; We need Qatar , Egypt , Saudi Arabia , the United States and all the other country to tell Hamas : & lsquo ; now you have to make this deal , & rsquo ; & rdquo ; Simona pleaded . & ldquo ; I want the world to see the real picture of what happened here , & rdquo ; she said.Simona strongly belief that there is a frightening connection between terrorism in Israel and the recent attack happening around the world . She emphasizes that the world need to recognize this trend and understand that what Israel is going through now is just the tip of the iceberg of a much larger , global problem . & ldquo ; We see the attack that are happening in France , in England , in the United States , in Russia . People need to think and realize that if we don & rsquo ; t stop them [ terrorist ] now , they will come to your country , & rdquo ; she explained.Even amid the fear and desperation of not having seen her daughter in six month , Simona & rsquo ; s thought extend to the innocent people in Gaza . She belief that defeating Hamas will be the key to providing relief to those who are currently enduring the harsh reality of war , a Hamas is responsible for the fact that people in the region do not have food . & ldquo ; The whole world must stop Hamas also to save innocent people in Gaza . Hamas doesn & rsquo ; t let them take food , and this is the real picture , & rdquo ; asserted Simona , who continued to share detail of some of the crime committed by Hamas and it leader , Sinwar , towards people in the region.She also asserted that despite receiving aid from other country and Israel , Hamas hoard food for themselves and prevents civilian from accessing it by resorting to violence and killing Gazans who attempt to take the aid . & ldquo ; People in Gaza don & rsquo ; t have food not because Israel doesn & rsquo ; t give it to them , but because Hamas doesn & rsquo ; t let anyone have it , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; The world need to know the truth . Sinwar doesn & rsquo ; t care about his people . If the world want good for the civilian in Gaza . they must tell Sinwar to make a deal , & rdquo ; added Simona.Simona Recounts the Horror of Oct . 7 & ldquo ; It began at six and a half in the morning . It wa terrible for them , and until now , child speak about this , & rdquo ; said Simona.Recalling what she saw with her own eye , Simona added : & ldquo ; I saw how they [ Hamas terrorist ] kill people . I remember a house that burned slowly until there wasn & rsquo ; t any more fire , and I knew that a couple wa there , and I knew they were burning alive . & rdquo ; According to Simona , Hamas killed 63 people in Kfar Aza alone . & ldquo ; I want everyone who ha a daughter , sister , or mother to think about what they would do if their family had to go through the same thing . Everyone who ha a grandmother , grandfather , daughter , son , nephew , brother & mdash ; what would you do ? & rdquo ; Simona asked rhetorically.About DoronSimona & rsquo ; s daughter Doron , 31 , is a veterinary nurse . & ldquo ; She like animal and kid , and she is like a second mother to her little nephew . Body Text: & ldquo ; I played sport ever since I wa a child . I used to play soccer but mainly basketball , a I have been blessed with a height of 1.95 meter , & rdquo ; said Saleh Shaheen , 41 , a Druze paralympic athlete from Shfaram.Shaheen & rsquo ; s life began in a typical fashion . He enlisted in the IDF in 2003 a a paratrooper and also served a a commander . After his mandatory service , he enrolled in a course led by the Airports Authority and worked at the Karni Terminal on the border of the Gaza Strip a a security guard . & ldquo ; Then , on January 13 , 2005 , my life changed in just one night . & rdquo ; Three terrorist from Hamas , the PFLP , and the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade penetrated the Karni Terminal by planting an explosive device in the wall ; they killed six civilian . & ldquo ; I arrived at the area of the explosion to fight the terrorist , but it wa pitch dark , a electricity wa down due to the explosion , leaving me exposed . I faced the first terrorist , and we exchanged fire . He shot four bullet towards my left leg , also damaging my stomach and intestine , & rdquo ; Shaheen said . & ldquo ; It wa pretty serious damage , though I didn & rsquo ; t feel at all that I wa injured . I shot , and the terrorist and I fell together . Two other terrorist infiltrated , and the rest of the security guard arrived . There I wa , with a dead terrorist lying next to me and an exchange of fire taking place between the guard and the terrorist over my head . I managed , with my last bit of strength , to crawl and make it to safety , where another Druze security guard saw me . He tried to lift me , but I weighed 115 kilo , so it took him two or three more attempt until he managed and brought me to the back office . & ldquo ; They put me in an ambulance and sped to Soroka [ Hospital ] . I remember the ride ; it & rsquo ; s probably the longest one I & rsquo ; ve ever had in my life . I started to feel the pain . I wanted to fall asleep , but the medic wouldn & rsquo ; t let me . When the ambulance door opened , I put my hand over my face so that no one would recognize me , and there & rsquo ; s a famous picture showing that scene . I wa in the operating room for 17 hour straight . When I woke up , I saw my parent next to me and began to fathom what had happened . I tore a main artery in my leg , and somehow , I stayed alive . & rdquo ; Shaheen stayed for three more week in Soroka until his situation wa stabilized , and then he wa sent to Rambam in Haifa , which wa more convenient for his family . & ldquo ; I spent three challenging month at Rambam , and although many people came to visit , it wasn & rsquo ; t a particularly easy time for me . I got metal implant for my leg , and I needed to train to rehabilitate them so I could attempt to go back to sport . My entire life revolved around sport until that point , & rdquo ; he reminisced.First step in Paralympic sport An acquaintance approached Shaheen a little over five year ago and suggested he try wheelchair basketball . & ldquo ; It seemed unnatural to me at first , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; I tried and fell several time and ended up thinking that I don & rsquo ; t have the strength for more fall and injury and recovering . At end of the day , I had learned to accept my injury and looked at it a my fate . I told myself that I must get up ; I can & rsquo ; t stay in the same place . So I continued training and playing wheelchair basketball in Haifa and Tel Aviv , and even tried out wheelchair badminton . & rdquo ; Shaheen ended up joining a mixed Jewish-Arab group in Majd Al-Kroum in the North , winning a national cup in the first year and making it to the Premier League.In 2019 , Shaheen wa approached again , this time with an offer to join paralympic rowing . & ldquo ; I had no idea what it wa at first . I wa told that it involved two training session every day and much traveling , & rdquo ; he recounted . & ldquo ; I hesitated at first , but I saw the challenging aspect and took my ability to the limit , and decided that this is a sport I want to be a part of . & rdquo ; Shaheen started training with a group of four , but then the condition of his leg deteriorated . The implant fell out , and he wa hospitalized again & ndash ; until he wa classified a PR2 , which is defined a having functional use of arm and trunk but with weakness or absence of leg function to slide the seat of the boat , rowing on a double boat for a duo of a man and a woman . & ldquo ; When I started this classification , they were only missing a female rower , and I wa on hold for a while . Then , one day , I received a call saying that they found a young woman , Shahar Milfelder , who had cancer at the age of 16 and had to have part of her pelvis removed . I jumped right in and went back to rowing . & rdquo ; Shaheen and Milfelder began training together only two year ago . & ldquo ; Every day , I drive around 230 kilometer , wake up at five in the morning , perform two training session , and go back . This routine is very demanding , especially at the expense of family and work . I own a convenience store and had to hire a local employee so that I could be devoted to sport alone , & rdquo ; Shaheen explained.Supported by scholarship and aid from the Israel Paralympic Committee , Shaheen and Milfelder made a significant leap and advanced to the World Championship less than a year ago . There , they missed the chance to get a ticket to the Paralympic game due to some change in category for qualification . & ldquo ; We missed the ticket by 30 hundredth of a second and even came in first place in the second round ; we were really bummed . Then , two week ago , there wa a & lsquo ; last chance & rsquo ; competition for the last two ticket . People believed in u ; we arrived a prepared a we could be . Then we finished first in the first round , and in the second one , we finished second with a difference of 40 hundredth of a second . & rdquo ; This wa enough to send the duo to the Paralympic Games . & ldquo ; I wa literally in tear , & rdquo ; said Shaheen . & ldquo ; Now we are getting back to preparing for the Olympics . Next month , we will fly for a long training camp , and then in August , we will move to Paris to give our performance at the Olympics . I want to thank the Paralympics Association for it trust and support in all field , from nutrition to treatment , scholarship , and even travel reimbursement . & rdquo ; Back at home , Shaheen said that his community had barely heard of this branch of sport . & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s not really well known in my society . Not many people at home contacted me , except the sport department in the municipality . Truth be told , I myself didn & rsquo ; t know anything about it before I started , and I didn & rsquo ; t realize how fascinating and challenging the world of rowing can be . & rdquo ; For this reason , Shaheen said he hope to change thing in the future . & ldquo ; Hopefully , after the Olympics , I will work to promote rowing in Israel generally and in the North more specifically , & rdquo ; he said.Asked what he is looking forward to most , Shaheen said that , more than anything , he is excited to leave a mark in history . & ldquo ; My message is that to achieve your dream , you must stop everything and focus on the goal . It & rsquo ; s true that I had to put my business to the side and that it come at the expense of other thing . But this is what it take to make your dream come true . & rdquo ;
title: druze rower qualifies for paralympic game with jewish counterpart

Body Text: A powerful exhibition featuring the personal testimony of 25 brave woman who experienced the horror of October 7th is launching at the Museum of Tolerance Jerusalem in the presence of the President of the State of Israel.Museum of Tolerance Jerusalem is launching a first-of-its-kind exhibition called `` 06:29 - From Darkness to Light `` , featuring personal testimony of the horrific event of October 7th . The exhibition & rsquo ; s producer , Malki Shem Tov , is the father of Omer Shem Tov , who ha been held captive in Gaza for over 200 days.The exhibition is aimed at taking visitor through the agonizing event experienced by the hundred of people who fell victim to the Hamas attack , hiding in shelter for hour , and the one whom Hamas terrorist brutally murdered . Two mobile shelter were created for this exhibition , taking visitor through the moment of fear civilian endured while hiding from terrorist and rocket . Visitors will then continue to 25 personal testimony from brave woman with harrowing stories.The exhibition will feature 25 virtual video testimony in Hebrew and English , filmed and produced by producer Noam Shalev . The firsthand testimony are by woman who experienced the atrocity of October 7th . Women who were injured , fought terrorist , saved the life of wounded civilian and soldier , were taken hostage , lost their husband , lost their loved one , or had a family member taken captive by Hamas.The woman featuredAmong the woman : Noam Ben David , who wa seriously injured at the Nova festival ; Ricarda Louk , mother of the late Shani Louk , who wa murdered at the Nova festival ; Avital Schindler , whose husband wa seriously injured by Hamas terrorist who broke into their home in Kibbutz Kerem Shalom ; Miriam Beit Talmi , a Holocaust survivor from Kibbutz Zikim who wa rescued under fire ; Chen Almog Goldstein from Kfar Gaza , who wa taken captive into Gaza with her child after her daughter and husband were murdered in their home ; Mali Shoshana , the commander of the Sderot Police Station on that Saturday ; Tal Hayon , a nurse in Soroka Hospital who treated hundred of wounded civilian and soldier on that day ; Lt . Col . Or Ben Yehuda , commander of the Karakal battalion on the Egyptian border who fought against dozen of terrorist in the Gaza Envelope ; Linor Attias , a United Hatzalah medic , among others.In the last part of the exhibition , a series of clip shot by producer Kobi Sit will present the solidarity of the Israeli public who came together on October 7th and the month following . Each clip wa created to ignite a light of hope in the darkness and remind u that even in the most difficult time , there is good in the world.This exhibition is an important addition to the Museum of Tolerance Jerusalem 's overall narrative , which aim to highlight bravery , unity , and heroism alongside the deep sorrow of October 7th and the war that followed.Isaac Herzog , President of the State of Israel , said , `` For far too many month , week , and day , the light ha been blocked by the dark shadow of a cloudy sky . And even though the sun seems to keep shining , we wake up to this cruel darkness each morning , which stay with u throughout the day . In this harsh reality , this important exhibition in the Museum of Tolerance brings such a precious and important voice that must be heard loud and clear . & rdquo ; Yoni Riss , CEO of the Museum of Tolerance Jerusalem , added , `` The testimony presented in the exhibition are a winning proof of the strength the citizen demonstrated on October 7th . With courage and kindness , the Israelis and the Jewish people found the strength to rebuild , rise , contribute , help , lend a hand , and not give in to evil . The endless giving that will build a better future here grows out of the pain and grief . & rdquo ;

Body Text: Heading in a north-easterly direction from the Arc de Triomphe down Avenue Hoch to number 37 , one reach Le Royal Monceau hotel ; at it entrance , a red portico and statued head that cast their gaze over everyone who pass through.The hotel , once a beehive of activity for diplomat , intellectual , artist , celebrity , and even the commander of the Allied Armed force during World War II , in 1946 hosted one of the more curious chance meeting between two political luminary of the 20th century.Fresh from Black Saturday & ndash ; the arrest of 3,000 Jews , including most of the Zionist executive leadership across Palestine & ndash ; and the sealing of Jewish Agency building on June 28 , David Ben-Gurion , then-leader of the Jewish Agency , sat in his hotel room pondering his organization & rsquo ; s next move . & nbsp ; Paris , in the early post-war year , wa the European center of Zionist activity . While in the city , Ben-Gurion wa helping to coordinate the westward migration of Jews who had survived the Holocaust in Eastern Europe , Jews he had hoped would be interested in emigrating to Palestine to help found a new Jewish state . & nbsp ; Staying on the floor above Ben-Gurion at Le Royal Monceau wa a & nbsp ; skinny gentleman with the elliptical eye distinct to native of Indochina , his hairline receding , and a thin , wispy goatee resting on his chin . To his family , growing up , he wa known a Nguyễn Sinh Cung , but by 1946 , he wa the prime minister of the newly-found Democratic Republic of Vietnam ( North Vietnam ) and known to the rest of the world a Ho Chi Minh.That summer , Ho Chi Minh wa in Paris for follow-up talk surrounding Vietnamese independence from the French . Although captured by the Japanese during WWII , French Indochina had long been a colonial jewel in the French empire & rsquo ; s crown with important natural and strategic resource , it prominent location close to China and other trade routes.Ben-Gurion related to former Maariv correspondent Shmuel Segev , who would write a book on Vietnam , that each day for two week , Ho Chi Minh would come down to his room or he would climb a flight of stair to the Vietnamese leader & rsquo ; s quarter , and the two would talk.During one conversation , Ben-Gurion shared insight into his ongoing problem , prompting Ho Chi Minh to suggest the establishment of a Jewish government in North Vietnam . & ldquo ; He gave the impression of being a nice man , & rdquo ; Ben-Gurion would later recall of Ho Chi Minh . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; During one of those conversation , he proposed that I immediately establish a Jewish government-in-exile on Vietnamese territory . I thanked him and said that when the time came , I would consider his offer . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Despite sharing a roof , and becoming & ldquo ; very friendly & rdquo ; over the week a the former Israeli prime minister stated , & ldquo ; for obvious reason , [ the offer ] wa unacceptable . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; I am certain that we shall be able to establish a Jewish government in Palestine , & rdquo ; Ben-Gurion reportedly said , adding that if he wrote to Ho Chi Minh , the latter might invite him to visit North Vietnam . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; He didn & rsquo ; t use Communist slogan , & rdquo ; Ben-Gurion said , adding that Ho Chi Minh desired to give the impression that he wa a nationalist leader fighting only for his people & rsquo ; s independence . & nbsp ; Ben-Gurion also related how he had been able to judge how the Vietnamese negotiation were proceeding with the French by the length of the red carpet at Ho Chi Minh & rsquo ; s door . & ldquo ; At first , the red carpet extended from the street to HoChi Minh & rsquo ; s door , & rdquo ; the Jewish leader recalled . & ldquo ; In stage , it wa removed from the pavement outside , the lobby , and the staircase . & ldquo ; When the carpet outside his door wa removed , I knew the talk had failed , and sure enough , a few hour later , he came to my room to say goodbye . He wa tired , worn out , and disappointed , and he told me nothing remained but to fight . & rdquo ; A few month later , the First Indochina War began between Vietnamese force and France.Two road to independenceDESPITE THE close relationship developed over only a couple of week one Paris summer , diplomatic relation between Vietnam and Israel took decade to come to fruition.On Friday , May 14 , 1948 , David Ben-Gurion stood in Tel Aviv and formally declared the independent State of Israel . The next day , the Arab army of Egypt , Syria , Jordan , and Iraq invaded , along with a corp of volunteer from Saudi Arabia , Lebanon , and Yemen . The burgeoning Jewish State prevailed , although it would face many more obstacle down the road for it freedom.The fight for Vietnamese independence would take a much darker and longer path.While Vietnam wa formally partitioned into South and North Vietnam in 1954 , at the end of the First Indochina War , with Israel supporting the Geneva Agreements , diplomatic relation between the two nation never materialized . & nbsp ; Communist North Vietnam maintained a strong relationship with the socialist power of the day , the Soviet Union and Maoist China , while also cultivating tie with the Arab nation . Israel , on the other side of the metaphorical global Iron Curtain , provided technical aid to South Vietnam without establishing formal diplomatic channels.In June 1967 , a Israel launched a pre-emptive strike against the army of Egypt , Syria , and Jordan , North Vietnam & rsquo ; s President Ho Chi Minh wrote in a personal wire to Egyptian President Gamal Abdel Nasser , & ldquo ; We are highly indignant at the action of Israeli reactionary agent of the United States and British imperialist . They are doomed to ignominious defeat . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; By 1967 , the North Vietnamese and their communist army , the Viet Cong , were busy themselves fighting a guerilla war against the South Vietnamese and their US ally . By 1969 , over half a million US troop were stationed in the country , and the Vietnam War would claim the life of almost 60,000 US serviceman and women.Ho Chi Minh would die in September 1969 , never living to see the united , communist Vietnam that he had dreamed of and fought so long for . In 1975 , two year after the official end of US military involvement , South Vietnam & rsquo ; s capital , Saigon , fell to the Viet Cong and wa renamed Ho Chi Minh City . & nbsp ; Ben-Gurion & rsquo ; s death would follow that of his revolutionary friend a few year later , in December 1973 . After his final year following his retirement from politics living in a modest home in Kibbutz Sde Boker in the Negev Desert , he wa buried there alongside his wife , Paula.Israel-Vietnam relationsISRAEL AND VIETNAM & rsquo ; S path would cross relatively infrequently over the following decade , with one particular infamous encounter taking place . & nbsp ; On June 10 , 1977 , a remarkable rescue operation unfolded when the Israeli freighter ship , the Yuvali , bound for Taiwan , spotted a group of passenger in need . This group , consisting of approximately 66 Vietnamese refugee , marked the beginning of a series of arrival in Israel between 1977 and 1979 of over 300 people fleeing communist Vietnam.Israeli prime minister at the time , Menachem Begin , drew a poignant parallel , likening the plight of these refugee to that of Holocaust survivor . & nbsp ; Begin famously remarked , & ldquo ; We have never forgotten the boat with 900 Jews , St . Louis , having left Germany in the last week before the Second World War . . . traveling from harbor to harbor , from country to country , cry out for refuge . They were refused . . . Therefore , it wa natural . . . to give those people a haven in the Land of Israel . & rdquo ; Inspired by this ethos of compassion and solidarity , Begin directed Israeli diplomat to extend a lifeline to the Vietnamese refugee , offering them asylum in Israel . In a poignant moment captured by an Associated Press broadcast on October 26 , 1979 , a grateful refugee expressed profound appreciation to the government of Israel and to Begin , acknowledging their role in opening their homeland at a time when other nation hesitated to offer assistance in the face of communist oppression.Vietnam and Israel would finally establish official diplomatic relation on July 12 , 1993 , followed by Israel opening it resident embassy in the capital Hanoi in December 1993Ben-Gurion & rsquo ; s recollection of his Paris meeting with the tall , skinny Vietnamese man , spotlight the convergence of two revolutionary movement in one place and offer a unique perspective on one of the most important & ndash ; and instrumental & ndash ; period in the 20th century . & nbsp ; In the post-WWII world , with national border being redrawn , either along class line or ethnicity line , two dedicated men had found themselves in a Parisian hotel room , drawn together by history and the common bond of their enduring fight for their people & rsquo ; s independence . 
title: a tale of two leader : the paris meeting between ben-gurion and ho chi minh

Body Text: Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian joked a day after Israel & rsquo ; s strike in Iran that the weapon used were & ldquo ; more like toy that our child play with & ndash ; not drone , & rdquo ; according to a Saturday article from Iran & rsquo ; s semi-official Mehr News Agency . & nbsp ; Making the comment in an interview with NBC News , Abdollahian said `` As long a there is no new adventurism by Israel against our interest , then we are not going to have any new reaction . & rdquo ; Threats against Israel '' If Israel take a decisive action against my country and this is proven to u , `` he said , `` our response will be immediate and to the maximum and will cause them to regret it . `` The foreign minister went on to threaten that his comment were only a warning , and that & ldquo ; We could have hit Haifa and Tel Aviv & hellip ; We could have also targeted all the economic port of Israel . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Abdollahian said that the only reason that Iran had not successfully hit Haifa , Tel Aviv or any major port wa because Iran & rsquo ; s & ldquo ; red line [ were ] civilian & hellip ; We only had a military purpose . & rdquo ; A 7-year-old Arab girl wa killed during Iran & rsquo ; s mass drone attack which saw hundred of UAVs and multiple ballistic missile fired seemingly randomly at Israel . Body Text: & nbsp ; On Wednesday , the US-Israel relationship seemed , well , normal . [ and ] conveyed his unwavering support for Israel & rsquo ; s security and for Israel & rsquo ; s legitimate right to defend itself , while protecting civilian . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Secretary of State Antony Blinken emphasized that & ldquo ; there is a very clear and absolute distinction between the terrorist organization Hamas that is indiscriminately raining down rocket targeting civilian , and Israel & rsquo ; s response defending itself , targeting the terrorist raining down rocket on Israel . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Blinken dispatched Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Israel and Palestinian Affairs Hady Amr to Israel to help in the de-escalation effort . & nbsp ; But all that happened on Wednesday , three day after Hamas shot rocket into Jerusalem and five day after a serious uptick in violence in Jerusalem . We also stand against extremism that ha inflicted violence on both community , & rdquo ; White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki said . & nbsp ; Psaki soon moved on to adopt the Palestinians & rsquo ; narrative that this is about the Sheikh Jarrah/Shimon Hatzadik land dispute & ndash ; the ruling on which ha yet to be made , and whose resident have not actually been evicted & ndash ; rather than taking in the context of rising Palestinian and Arab violence for the past month . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We believe Palestinians and Israelis deserve equal measure of freedom , security , dignity , and prosperity , & rdquo ; Psaki said . & ldquo ; And US official , in recent week , have spoken candidly with Israeli official about how eviction of Palestinian family who have lived for year , sometimes decade , in their home and of demolition of these home work against our common interest in achieving a solution to the conflict . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Similarly , State Department spokesman Ned Price said minute earlier that & ldquo ; Israel ha the right to defend itself and to respond to rocket attack . Similarly , in Jerusalem , where there reportedly have been hundred of Palestinians injured , a well a Israeli police , we call on all side to exercise restraint and to exercise calm . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Emerging from bomb shelter soon after those statement were made , the Israelis paying attention to Psaki and Price may have scratched their head a to why Israel & rsquo ; s greatest ally wa lecturing them while they were rushing their family to safety from rocket launched indiscriminately at civilian by a terrorist organization . & nbsp ; Over the past week , the Biden administration & rsquo ; s message also focused on & ldquo ; de-escalation . & rdquo ; They & rsquo ; re engaging at all level , official and spokespeople said , to encourage Israelis and Palestinians to de-escalate . Pushed by journalist in numerous press briefing to explain what that mean , what they & rsquo ; re actually doing to bring the side away from the brink of war , the member and representative of the administration didn & rsquo ; t have much to say . & nbsp ; MORE THAN one senior Israeli official said they & rsquo ; re satisfied with the US position , pointing to statement by Biden and Blinken , a well a another by National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan , a & ldquo ; very supportive , & rdquo ; a well a to American effort in the UN to block the statement against Israel . & nbsp ; In other word , the thing that they are doing , on a practical level , are supportive of Israel , and they are keeping Israel in the loop , a an ally would be expected to do . & nbsp ; Israeli official also said they don & rsquo ; t feel that the US is pressuring them to stop the operation in Gaza , another clear sign of support . & nbsp ; But one of those Israeli official also said that they & ldquo ; don & rsquo ; t have a clue . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; For four month , the Biden administration made Israel and the Palestinians a low priority . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; They didn & rsquo ; t even think about Gaza and Hamas , & rdquo ; the official said . & ldquo ; When the Palestinian election came up , they didn & rsquo ; t know how to handle it . US statement calling to stop hostility weakens Israel in pursuit of that strategy . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The American response overall ha been timid , disappointing and irrelevant . . . saying Palestinians in Gaza have the right for safety and security just a Israelis do . . . a if this is a confrontation between equal , & rdquo ; Gilboa said . & ldquo ; Both side are called on to reduce hostility & ndash ; Israel and a terrorist organization designated by the US . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s not evenhandedness . Body Text: Matanyahu Englman ha become the first Israeli State Comptroller and Ombudsman to hold the position of president of the European Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions ( EUROSAI ) , on Monday.This make Englman will be the only senior public figure in Israel to serve a head of an international organization.Englman spoke of his new role , during an appointment ceremony , saying : `` I would like to extend my deepest gratitude to nearly 50 state for trusting me to lead this esteemed organization , especially in this difficult time , after the severe terrorist attack Israel experienced on October 7 , and with our hostage still in Gaza . `` `` I see great importance in the European acknowledgment of the State Comptroller 's Office of Israel , `` he continued . `` I expect the States of Europe to stand with Israel and bring the Israeli hostage home , `` he added.EUROSAIEurosai is an organization which promotes cooperation between European State Audit Institutions ( SAIs ) and & nbsp ; encourages knowledge-sharing between different countries.It hold a Congress every three year , and & nbsp ; is the official start of the new president . & nbsp ; This year , it wa held online due to the war in Israel . & nbsp ; President Isaac Herzog opened the ceremony with a speech about the importance of international effort to bring the hostage home . He also spoke of the role the public audit system play in safeguarding `` the democratic freedom of our society `` . The outgoing president of EUROSAI , President of the Supreme audit office of the Czech Republic , Miloslav Kala , handed over the EUROSAI Crystal to Englman . & nbsp ; Committing to the value of EUROSAI , Englman expressed his desire to prevent corruption , calling it `` paramount to our mission . `` He also spoke of his desire to make EUROSAI `` a driving force for innovation and excellence in public audit `` which he said would be achieved through `` robust peer review process . `` Englman concluded by saying that the organization would `` enhance our interface with esteemed international body such a the OECD , UN , and World Bank , reinforcing our role a a leading voice in the global audit community . ``
title: state comptroller englman to be first israeli to serve a head of an intl . organization

Body Text: A 35-year-old settler from Beit El ha been arrested on suspicion of murdering a Palestinian boy during settler riot that raged in the West Bank last month in the aftermath of the murder of 14-year-old Israeli shepherd Binyamin Achimair , medium reported on Friday.Several Palestinians were killed during the riot , during which home and car were torched in several village surrounding the area where Achimair & rsquo ; s body wa found.Riots erupted in the aftermath of the murder of 14-year-old Israeli shepherd Binyamin Achimair in April.Several Palestinians were killed during the riot , during which home and car in several village surrounding the area where Achimair 's body wa found were torched.Five people were arrested a week ago on suspicion of rioting and inciting the riots.The suspect is accused of murdering 17-year-old Omar Ahmad Abdulghani Hamed from the village of Beitin , just north of Ramallah . Before the beginning of his hearing , he proclaimed his innocence and called his arrest & ldquo ; false . & rdquo ; He accused the Shin Bet ( Israel Security Agency ) of orchestrating the arrest , because he refused to answer question the agency had about settler activity in the area.The suspect claim he wa not told he wa a suspect and , for that reason , did not call a lawyer until he had already been arrested.The suspect claim he wa not told he wa a suspect and , for that reason , did not call a lawyer until he had already been arrested.His lawyer said the only reason for his arrest wa due to his vehicle being seen driving around the area where Hamed wa murdered.Police responded , saying that initially , he wa not a suspect , but a the investigation developed , he became one.Police requested that his extension be extended for 10 day in order to allow them to conduct a full investigation without interference from the suspect.The judge gave the police a four-day extension , meaning the suspect will be released on Monday unless another extension is granted.Giving his reasoning , the judge said , that & ldquo ; it appears from the material that there is reasonable suspicion . The suspect maintains his right to remain silent & ndash ; which , although it is a fundamental right , ha a particular significance . & rdquo ;
title: settler arrested on suspicion of murdering palestinian boy during riot in april

Body Text: Hundreds of supporter of Iranian-backed Iraqi paramilitary group gathered on Friday at Iraq 's main border crossing with Jordan to express solidarity with Gaza and call for an end to the blockade imposed by Israel.Some 800 supporter of Iraq 's Popular Mobilisation Forces ( PMF ) , an umbrella group of mainly Shi'ite militia , departed from Baghdad late on Thursday in bus and arrived at the Iraqi-Jordanian border crossing in the early hour of Friday in the western Anbar province , which is the closest access point from Iraq to the West Bank.Amid heavy security presence at the crossing , protester set up tent and staged a sit-in , demanding Israel lift it blockade on Gaza and allow aid to flow in . & ldquo ; No to Israel and normalization , & rdquo ; protester chanted while waving Palestinian flags.Israel return fire against HamasIsrael ha vowed to wipe out the Hamas terrorist group that rule Gaza , after it gunman burst through the barrier fence surrounding the enclave on Oct . 7 and rampaged through Israeli town and kibbutz , killing 1,400 people , mainly civilians.Israel ha pounded Gaza with air strike and put the enclave 's 2.3 million people under a total siege.Since Oct . 7 , at least 4,137 Palestinians have been killed and 13,000 wounded in Gaza in Israeli strike since Oct.7 , the Hamas-run health ministry said . & ldquo ; We are going to support our people in Palestine , & rdquo ; said 26-year-old Hussein Samir , a he sat in a bus just before leaving Baghdad late on Thursday . & ldquo ; We condemn them , and we will give them a period of time ; if they don & rsquo ; t lift the blockade , the resistance will begin , God willing , and the war against them ( Israel ) will begin , & rdquo ; he added.On Thursday influential Iraqi cleric Muqtada al-Sadr called for a peaceful sit-in at the Palestinian border in Syria , Lebanon , Egypt and Jordan until Israel lift the blockade on the enclave and aid is delivered to people in Gaza . Sadr said protester should only carry shroud and not arm . & nbsp ;
title: iraqi stage sit-in at iraq-jordan border calling for end to gaza blockade

Body Text: In the stark confines of Eshel Prison near Beersheba , Israel , an unconventional class of student recently completed an extraordinary educational journey . Last week , a group of 13 inmate graduated from a groundbreaking Holocaust education project unlike any traditional academic setting . These were n't ordinary student ; they were prisoner , some serving life sentence for serious crime , others detained for minor offense . Yet , they all shared a new academic pursuit & mdash ; understanding the Holocaust , it historical significance , and the indelible lesson it imparts on courage and humanity.Across Israel , this initiative is part of a broader educational movement within the penal system . Over the past few month , more than 150 inmate engaged in similar program , and a total of 300 were expected to complete their study by the year 's end . The program 's uniqueness lie not only in it setting but in it transformative impact on it participant , challenging them to rethink value and personal accountability.A glimpse inside the prison education systemFor the first time , Yad Vashem , Israel 's official memorial to the victim of the Holocaust , together with the Israeli Prison Service , allowed insight into these transformative session . During a rare and enlightening meeting with inmate , they shared how their initial encounter with story of the Holocaust moved them profoundly . The tale of suffering and heroism opened their eye to a world where human value such a courage , sacrifice , and perseverance played pivotal roles.Educating beyond the basicsThe program , known a `` Victory of the Spirit , `` provided rigorous weekly session where inmate from various background came together to learn about the Holocaust . Rabbi Tehila Heitman Demony , head of the community value sector at the prison , explained that the program aimed to instill a deep understanding of the Holocaust 's historical event while intertwining lesson on personal and communal values.This year 's curriculum , under the theme `` Communities , `` focused on fostering a sense of collective identity and responsibility & mdash ; poignant subject for individual often isolated from society . The curriculum wa scheduled to culminate in June with a day trip to Yad Vashem for prisoner who met certain behavioral and educational criterion , thus providing them with a tangible connection to the story they had studied.Transformations on a personal levelAmong the poignant narrative wa that of A ' , a young man from central Israel , convicted of manslaughter . A ' wa initially indifferent to the program but found himself profoundly affected a the course progressed . `` At first , I did n't see the relevance of the Holocaust to me , `` A ' shared . His perspective dramatically shifted when he discovered that his own grandfather wa a Holocaust survivor . This revelation deepened his engagement with the material and provided a personal connection to the history being taught.Idit , the education officer at Eshel Prison who coordinated the `` Victory of the Spirit `` project , observed significant change in the prisoner ' attitude and understanding . `` They become ambassador of knowledge , eager to share what they 've learned and inspire others within the prison community , `` Idit noted.Impacts beyond individual growthAyelet Aviv , an instructor from Yad Vashem involved since 2016 , highlighted the diverse composition of her class , which included many prisoner from minority background . `` Their thirst for knowledge is incredible , `` Aviv said . `` They are eager to learn , to ask question , and to write about their thought and feeling . It 's about educating and transforming these individual , providing them with tool for personal growth and a deeper understanding of human value . `` For M ' , an Arab Israeli imprisoned for money laundering , the program offered an insight into a crucial part of history that he had never known before . `` The only place I thought I could learn such thing wa in prison , `` M ' reflected . His statement underscored the transformative potential of education , even & mdash ; or perhaps especially & mdash ; in the most unlikely settings.As these prisoner reached the end of their course , the impact of `` Victory of the Spirit `` extended beyond the confines of their cell . It fostered a broader dialogue about history , humanity , and redemption , proving that education can indeed be a powerful catalyst for change . This project not only educates but also rebuilds individual , enabling them to emerge a informed citizen ready to contribute positively to society . M ' summed up the sentiment by stating , `` If everyone learns from the Holocaust , perhaps we can finally achieve justice . ``
title: yad vashem , prison service reveal holocaust education for inmate

Body Text: North of the Gaza Strip , the surf is pounding the beach south of Ashkelon . One of these beach is known a Zikim , and it share a name with a kibbutz on a hill above it.This is a beautiful area . There is a small pond and stream near the beach , and dune with small stout layer of brush stretch up from the waterfront toward the east . The dune form a kind of frame to the area , setting off the kibbutz and a road that run down to the sea from an industrial area of Ashkelon.Today , this area is deserted . The beach , which once hosted the toned body of young men and woman from the area who came to enjoy the spot , and the fisherman who would come on weekend to try their hand at a catch , are gone . It is all gone because Hamas attacked this beach on October 7 , when it invaded two dozen point along the border with Israel and carried out it massacre.I came to this area on October 8 , trying to reach the coastal area because there are several IDF post here . I thought that with the war unfolding , it might be a good place to find a story . At the time , I didn & rsquo ; t know there wa still fighting going on in this area , and terrorist were lurking in the bush and dunes.I learned the area wa an active combat zone when I came upon the body of two terrorist , and a still-running Savannah van parked next to them , on October 8 near the fence that run around Kibbutz Zikim . The fighting here continued for days.On October 11 , several soldier from the Maglan special unit were killed in this area . Flags with their name are now draped on a concrete shelter along the road . Inside , their comrade have written their name and left candle and a kippah in their memory.Six month laterIT HAS been six month since that day . October 8 wa the second day of the war . Six month later , I wa in Kibbutz Zikim , looking out onto the road where I had encountered the dead terrorist and the van . A member of the community recalled the same scene unfolding on October 7 from inside Zikim.Although terrorist were able to attack and infiltrate the IDF post near the border , killing soldier and massacring civilian on Zikim Beach , the kibbutz itself wa saved by the quick response of it emergency response team and soldiers.Today , the kibbutz seems like it is slowly returning to life , and some of the resident have returned . The community is laid out in a large circle , with house facing the perimeter fence , looking toward the sea . It & rsquo ; s bucolic and beautiful . It is also filled with peacock for some reason . The bird apparently escaped from a local small zoo and have infested the community for year . Because there are so few human resident , the animal seem to have the run of the place.I spent October 7 and 8 traveling along the border with Gaza , seeing community that faced the brunt of the attack on October 7 and also seeing those that were saved from the massacre . Each community ha a story & ndash ; story of tragedy , bravery , and sometimes good luck that kept people safe.Six month after the war began , it & rsquo ; s important to recall that these community are still evacuated , their resident scattered around Israel . In many case , the community tried to stick together , but they face an uncertain future.On the afternoon of October 8 , the IDF said it had evacuated Be & rsquo ; eri , Nahal Oz , Netiv Ha & rsquo ; asara , and Zikim . While Zikim had been saved from the massacre , nearby Netiv Ha & rsquo ; asara , which is directly on the border with Gaza , wa breached , and the terrorist murdered numerous member of the community . The terrorist also carried out massacre at Be & rsquo ; eri and Nahal Oz.Nahal Oz is one of the hardest community & rsquo ; s to reach today because it is close to the border , and there is an IDF checkpoint on the road leading to it . All of these community now have soldier at their front gate , and permission is required to enter.Nahal Oz is a unique case . To get to it , the road snake down by the border . Several year ago , a large concrete wall wa erected to shield the road from Gaza , and the wall wa then painted with pastoral scene and a giant mural indicating that the community wa celebrating 70 year since it founding . Unlike Zikim , there is a sense it will take time before anyone can return to this area.On October 8 , the IDF also evacuated Nir Am , Mefalsim , Kfar Aza , Gevim , Or Haner , Ivim , Yad Mordechai , Karmiya , Kerem Shalom , Kissufim , Holit , Sufa , Nirim , Nir Oz , Ein Hashlosha , Nir Yitzhak , Magen , Re & rsquo ; im , Sa & rsquo ; ad , and Alumim.Today , these community have the same struggle that Zikim and Nahal Oz face . Their resident are living in different part of Israel , and it is not clear when service will be available for people to return to or if people will feel secure enough to return.In some community , people return only for a few hour a day or several day a week . They might have job nearby , or they come to tend a garden or to do some kind of other work for the community . In the community dining hall , where there once would have been crowd or laughter , or plan for community event , there is often silence or only a few people huddled to eat.IT & rsquo ; S HARD to make sense of this . On the one hand , the war in Gaza feel like it is winding down . At the highest point in Zikim , for instance , there is an old home built in 1920 by an Arab notable who had a citrus grove near here . From the roof of the old stately home , where sandbag are piled , probably from the early day of the war , one can see into Gaza . Smoke rise , and there is a rat-tat of machine-gun fire . But the sound of artillery and explosion is no longer common.Further down the border , this is not always the case . Near the site of the Supernova music festival massacre , the sound of artillery is present . Everywhere along the border , the buzzing of drone is clear . But the heavy military presence of the first month of the war is gone.It & rsquo ; s not normal , because normal would mean the civilian resident have returned . It & rsquo ; s abnormal . But it & rsquo ; s also not war , because much of the war seems to have paused , like a country taking a deep breath and then wondering what to do next.What come next at Kibbutz Sufa , for instance ? It sits near the border and feel forlorn . At nearby Nir Yitzhak , there are square hay bale stacked in small mountain in warehouse . Clearly , the agricultural work ha gone on at a fever pitch.In fact , that & rsquo ; s another contrast on the border . Work go on everywhere in the field . In some case , it is done by foreign worker , who can be seen riding motorized bike to their work . Small Thailand flag flutter from the bikes.In one field , a giant machine with long metal arm , like a massive mechanical bug in some kind of future apocalyptic movie , ambled along watering the field . It wasn & rsquo ; t even clear if there wa a person on the machine , bringing a sense that the future here hang in the balance between civilian returning and machine taking over.This is not what the kibbutz pioneer of the late 1940s and 1950s had in mind when these community were founded . They lived in tent and farmed . They took their bolt-action rifle , and later automatic , to the field with them . They danced , and sang , and played sport . They served in elite unit . They grew old.Their descendant want to return , but so far , it is mostly the older people who express steadfastness and confidence . Those with child who were abandoned for many hour on October 7 , and had to leave on October 8 , face an uncertain future . How can they return and trust the state again to protect them ? The state hasn & rsquo ; t returned the hostage held in Gaza . There & rsquo ; s also a sense the government ha abandoned these community , that there is lack of caring for them , and that there is no government here . They are fending for themselves , like in the era of the British Mandate.These community were once the heart of the state & rsquo ; s endeavor to carve out the border of Israel . But now they feel like they have become the ultimate periphery . & nbsp ;
title: gaza border community struggling to recover six month after evacuation

Body Text: & lsquo ; What a night , & rdquo ; wrote Zvika Klein , Editor-in-Chief of The Jerusalem Post , on Facebook . & ldquo ; It wa filled with inspiration , sadness , hope , and prayer . & rdquo ; On Sunday evening , June 2 , the Post hosted a special gala evening at 583 Park Avenue , prior to it Annual Conference in New York on Monday . The invitation-only cocktail reception for some 200 VIP guest wa organized with Bank Leumi and wa held in cooperation with the Israel Defense and Security Forum ( IDSF ) . AMIR AVIVI , founder of the forum , interviewed by Klein , stated that Israel is facing a global war on behalf of Western society but must seek strategic independence for war material to ensure the country & rsquo ; s defense . & ldquo ; We are facing a global war ; this is a Chinese/Russian front , & rdquo ; he said . Consequently , the US position on military operation & ldquo ; endangers not only Israel but all of Western society . & rdquo ; Avivi advocated for Israeli strategic independence in munition and other military equipment to counter the arm embargo that Israel is facing from some of it Western ally . For Israel to be able to stand on it own without relying on others is a Zionist principle , he explained.Though the IDF is destroying Hamas on the battlefield , the forum & rsquo ; s founder said , the Gazan terrorist group belief that it can survive by fostering international pressure on Israel and sparking an Israeli election.RONIT FARKASH , Director of Strategic Partnerships at IDSF , said that her son is among the soldier fighting Hamas in Gaza . A Hamas sniper shot him , and while his ceramic vest saved him , he suffered shrapnel wound and burns.Though still recovering from his wound , Farkash & rsquo ; s son returned to his unit in Gaza only a few day later because his brother in arm needed him . & ldquo ; That is the power of being united . That is the meaning of being connected to something bigger than just yourself , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; Our nation & rsquo ; s strength lie in it people and in our ability to come together in the face of adversity . We draw courage from each other , from the story of bravery and sacrifice , from the unwavering support of friend , neighbor , and even stranger . & rdquo ; IDSF CEO Lt . - Col . ( re . ) Yaron Buskila , who served in the Gaza war , described the chaos he witnessed on Oct . 7 , when people were calling him for help . Beyond the tragedy and trauma of the massacre , Buskila said he had also seen image of victory . He recalled the score of car and bus carrying thousand of reservist headed south to answer the call to arm , a well a people coming from all over the world to donate food and volunteer with the soldier . & ldquo ; We are a generation of victory , & rdquo ; he said.DIASPORA AFFAIRS and Combating Antisemitism Minister Amichai Chikli , speaking with Klein , discussed the challenge Israel face in reducing Hamas & rsquo ; s military capability and the need for sustained effort similar to those following Operation Defensive Shield in 2002 . Chikli predicted that another two year of reduced military activity would be necessary in order to reach the desired level of security for Israel & rsquo ; s South.He then turned his attention to antisemitism in the US , drawing parallel between the situation in Gaza and the need for vigilance in America . He noted that despite the increase in antisemitic incident , the majority of Americans continue to support Israel.Chikli outlined his ministry & rsquo ; s multifaceted approach to combating antisemitism . & ldquo ; First of all , the main mission is to support the community in term of security , monitoring antisemitism , [ and ] investigating these organization such a SJP [ Students for Justice in Palestine ] , & rdquo ; he explained.The ministry is also focused on tracing funding source for these organization , which often receive significant contribution from charity and state like Qatar . In addition , it support local organization and campus group such a Hillel , Olami , and Chabad . Chikli mentioned the importance of delegation , such a those of the family of hostage and victim from Oct . 7 , in raising awareness and garnering support.The minister stressed the importance of continued vigilance and support for Jewish community worldwide . He said his ministry is dedicated to ensuring the safety and security of these community while also fostering a deeper connection to their heritage and the State of Israel.JERUSALEM MAYOR Moshe Lion commented that the current surge in antisemitism is reminiscent of Germany in the 1930s . & ldquo ; Far from home , we see the terrible scene you have experienced & ndash ; on campus , on the street , with attack on Jews & ndash ; like we have not seen since 1930s Germany , & rdquo ; the mayor said . & ldquo ; Have no doubt & ndash ; the Jewish people are under attack . & rdquo ; Lion described the difficult war that Israel is waging against it enemy . & ldquo ; On our border sit terror army , shooting missile on our head . Courts and parliament worldwide try to stop u from defending our people . & rdquo ; Despite the difficulty , he said , Jerusalem is ready to face the challenge . & ldquo ; We are continuing to build , across the city , for the benefit of all the community : Jews , Muslims , Christians , and more . & rdquo ; Lion also mentioned the plight of the hostage in front of some 70 of their family member who attended the event . & ldquo ; In Gaza , our brother and sister , men , woman , child and baby , are being held captive by the worst terrorist , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; We all pray to have them home with their family . & rdquo ; A GROUP of 70 relative attended the reception . Several addressed guest at the gala and described the harsh reality they have encountered since Oct . 7.On that horrific day , the Idan family wa in their home in Kibbutz Nahal Oz . Hamas terrorist broke into the building , shot and killed 18-year-old Maayan , and held the family at gunpoint for hour , streaming live video from the phone of her mother , Gali , on her Facebook account . Her father , Tsachi , wa taken hostage . & ldquo ; I wa in Tel Aviv , & rdquo ; Devorah Idan , Tsachi & rsquo ; s mother , recounted on stage . & ldquo ; We saw what wa happening & ndash ; we watched for hour . We saw the child cry , asking the terrorist why they killed their sister . & rdquo ; Eventually , Tsachi wa taken away . & ldquo ; For u , that day ha never ended , & rdquo ; Idan said . & ldquo ; We live in a perpetual nightmare . My granddaughter wa killed , and my son wa kidnapped . He did not get to go to her funeral . He did not get to mourn for her . I came [ here ] all the way from Israel to ask for help . & rdquo ; MOSHE EMILIO LAVI , a former IDF captain from Sderot who now work a a management consultant in New York , criticized the Israeli authority , including some of the official attending the gala evening . Lavi & rsquo ; s brother-in-law Omri Miran is being held in Gaza . & ldquo ; Every time I addressed an international body or foreign government official , I asked them to keep Hamas accountable , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; At the same time , I hold my government accountable . We know there is an Israeli proposal for an agreement on the table . On October 8 , we were promised that bringing the hostage home wa the most important short-term objective of the war because time wa of the essence . After that , we could tackle the challenge of destroying Hamas . & rdquo ; Lavi recounted the horror experienced by Omri , his sister Lishay , and his young niece Roni and Alma at Kibbutz Nahal Oz at the hand of the Hamas terrorist . Lishay and the girl survived and were rescued by the IDF ; Omri wa taken hostage . & ldquo ; Roni will turn three in July , and all she is asking is that her father is with her for her birthday , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; She know he already missed her mom & rsquo ; s birthday and her little sister & rsquo ; s first birthday . She just want him back . & rdquo ; RONEN NEUTRA described his son Omer , a 22-year-old soldier kidnapped on Oct . 7 , a the & ldquo ; poster boy & rdquo ; for the American Jewish dream . & ldquo ; Omer is an American kid . Growing up , he loved sport , and he wa very involved with his Jewish youth movement , & rdquo ; he recalled.Neutra explained that he and his wife , who both hold dual American and Israeli citizenship and are child of Holocaust survivor , understood and supported Omer & rsquo ; s desire to serve in the IDF . & ldquo ; On October 6 , he called u , and he said he wa expecting a quiet Shabbat after a month of very intense work , spending some 18 hour a day on his tank , & rdquo ; Neutra recounted . When the attack began , he and his comrade rushed to the border with their tank . & ldquo ; His whole team wa taken , & rdquo ; Neutra said . & ldquo ; Two of them were killed , and two were taken captive . & ldquo ; Since then , my wife and I are fighting to bring my son and all the other hostage back , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; We feel the American authority have been very supportive , but we are not sure about the Israeli government . Everyone should remember that redeeming captive is a central value in the Torah . I ask everyone in this room to do what they can to help bring my son and all the other hostage home . & rdquo ; After the panel , all the family member of hostage attending the event went up on stage . The reception ended with the singing of & ldquo ; Hatikvah . & rdquo ; This article wa written in cooperation with the Israel Defense and Security Forum .
title: a night for hope

Body Text: The Beersheba District Court on Tuesday sentenced Israeli Arye Schiff to nine month of community service for shooting and killing an Israeli-Arab that broke into his car last November , Walla reported . Schiff wa sentenced in a plea bargain over his role in killing Mohammad al-Atrash , who the defendant claimed had been trying to steal his car and that he therefore acted in self-defense . The plea bargain and sentencing follow his conviction in July , where the court rejected his claim of self-defense . In fact , the prosecution said security-camera footage of the incident showed that Schiff wa in no danger and wa not even in his car when the car thief arrived . The prosecution had originally sought a sentence of 4-6 year in prison , but the plea deal averted that , Walla reported . Dozens had come out to the courtroom to support Schiff , including Religious Zionist MK Itamar Ben-Gvir . & nbsp ; `` Aryeh Schiff should receive a medal , not be prosecuted & ndash ; and certainly not receive a sentence of community service or prison , `` Ben-Gvir said in response to the verdict . `` The ruling sends a message to the resident of the South that they must not defend themselves , or else they will face charge and imprisonment . The huge gap between the sentence and the long prison sentence the prosecution demanded show the racist treatment shown to Jews forced to defend themselves . `` Also coming out against the verdict & ndash ; saying that it wa too lenient & ndash ; wa Meretz MK Mossi Raz . `` The sentence given to Aryeh Schiff is an embarrassment , `` Raz said in a statement . & nbsp ; `` It 's important for everyone to feel safe in their own home , but we must never allow it to become normalized that citizen can take the life of others into their hand . I ca n't help but think that if Schiff wa an Arab , his punishment would have been far more severe . `` But others welcomed the verdict . `` After many long month of public struggle , we are glad public pressure succedded , `` the right-wing NGO Im Tirtzu said in a statement . `` There wa no need at all to convict Aryeh , but at least the judge understands well that a very clear message must be conveyed that a citizen is allowed to defend himself against criminal . It will take a long time to restore the Negev 's security , but at least Aryeh Schiff can have his life back . `` Clashes soon erupted outside the courtroom between Schiff 's supporter and local Bedouin resident , notably when Ben-Gvir arrived . As the MK came to the court , the Bedouin resident began shouting at him , calling him a racist . & nbsp ; Ben-Gvir replied that `` We came to support and say that Aryeh Schiff is the hero of Israel , and it is time to bring order to the South , `` adding that , `` if the Police had been a deterrent in the South , Schiff would not have had to shoot the burglar . `` Other member of the Israeli Right have voiced their support of Schiff in the past . & ldquo ; The indictment against you should not have been filed , and having been filed , it should be withdrawn , & rdquo ; then-public security minister Amir Ohana told Schiff in March . & ldquo ; As usual , and despite conventional thinking , the problem is not the law or the wording of the law , `` he said . `` The problem is those interpreting the law . They are giving the law a restrictive interpretation until it is effectively negated , `` which is generally how the issue of self-defense is treated . `` They give themselves the power to fill up or empty the substance of a law . & rdquo ; Yonah Jeremy Bob contributed to this report .
title: israeli sentenced to 9 month community service for killing arab

Body Text: Arab Israeli activist Yoseph Haddad ha taken on the task of exposing the horror that occurred on the morning of Saturday , October 7 , a role that many government official have neglected . Speaking to Arabs in their own language , Haddad explains the implication of Hamas 's surprise attack.In a prime time segment on Channel 12 , Haddad directly addressed Hamas in Arabic , saying , `` Let 's speak Arabic . Do you want to go on like this ? OK then . . . Israel will prevail ! The people of Israel will prevail . You do n't have the support of the Israeli Arabs ! Get it into your head ! You are terrorist ! You are ISIS-Hamas , that 's who you are ! And the whole world will know you are ISIS-Hamas ! `` Yoseph Haddad : Hamas , you are on your way to hell ! He continued , `` Long live Israel , long live the people of Israel , long live the State of Israel ! Body Text: In his speech on Thursday , President Herzog expressed his support for Jewish community around the world and gave them a message of strength in light of the proliferation of antisemitism against Jewish student on campus across the US . & nbsp ; President Herzog said , & ldquo ; To our sister and brother , to our friend on campus and in Jewish community across the United States and all over the world , to those who stand by and defend the Jewish people and the state of Israel , to all people of good will : from Jerusalem , the capital of the State of Israel , I say to you : The people of Israel are with you . We share the apprehension and concern . `` He continued by saying that academia had been `` contaminated by hatred and antisemitism fueled by arrogance and ignorance `` and condemned the way in which the atrocity of October 7 are being celebrated and justified . `` Do not fear `` `` In the face of violence , harassment and intimidation , a masked coward smash window and barricade door , a they assault the truth and manipulate history , together we stand strong . `` Despite call for `` intifada and genocide `` , Herzog reiterated Israel 's commitment to freeing the hostage , and securing peace and security for the Jewish nation and Jews worldwide.Speaking on the upcoming Holocaust Remembrance Day , the PM said , `` We will speak of the dark time of the past , and we will remember the miracle of our rebirth : in our ancient homeland , the Jewish , democratic State of Israel , and throughout the Jewish world . `` He finished with the word , `` do not fear . Body Text: A Bulgarian prosecutor provided detailed evidence to the Bulgarian court handling Hezbollah & rsquo ; s involvement in the 2012 Burgas bus bombing which killed five Israelis and their Bulgarian-Muslim bus driver , but the court refused to accept it , The Jerusalem Post ha learned . & nbsp ; Despite an official court transcript of these detail and an appeal by the Israeli victim & rsquo ; lawyer Yaki Rand to convince the Bulgarian appeal court to issue conviction , including terrorism charge against Hezbollah , the Post also understands there is a high chance that Bulgaria & rsquo ; s judiciary is looking to put the case to bed . & nbsp ; Throughout the trial there wa a dispute about Bulgarian official allegedly trying to charge only the individual , while seeking to avoid angering Hezbollah by naming it in the case . & nbsp ; For year , Bulgarian prosecutor claimed that they had no evidence with which to tie the two defendant , who were eventually given life sentence in absentia , directly to Hezbollah and terrorism . & nbsp ; Yet , on September 17 , 2020 , after the full trial and conviction and only four day before the sentencing hearing , the prosecutor finally admitted on the record that there wa significant evidence on the issue . & nbsp ; The prosecutor proceeded to detail the evidence into the court record , but since the conviction had already been set , the Bulgarian trial court said it hand were tied and that it could not reopen the case to charge Hezbollah and add terrorism charge . & nbsp ; Rand ha asked the Bulgarian appeal court to order the case reopened in order to add the new charge raised by the prosecutor & rsquo ; late additional comment , but there are indication that the judiciary want to be done with the case . & nbsp ; It is highly unusual for prosecutor to raise new fact and charge post-conviction , and it is still unclear why the prosecutor did not raise the evidence during the trial itself . & nbsp ; The case shook Europe to it foundation for it audacity , but left the family of the victim and Israel partially unsatisfied because Hezbollah itself wa not formally indicted or convicted . & nbsp ; At a July 2019 anniversary ceremony for the victim , their family had demanded that Hezbollah itself be charged in the Bulgarian trial for committing an act of terrorism . & nbsp ; In his speech , Kobi Price , one of the family member , noted that , & ldquo ; three year ago & hellip ; four year after the attack , the criminal trial opened & hellip ; In the indictment & hellip ; only two attacker & rdquo ; were charged . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We , the mourning family , ask the Government of Bulgaria to rise above narrow political consideration and to add the terror organization Hezbollah to the indictment without delay , & rdquo ; said Price . & nbsp ; Price continued , & ldquo ; Without Hezbollah , there is no morality in the trial . Without Hezbollah , the trial is ineffective . Without Hezbollah , there is no justice for the murdered victim . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; He reiterated to the Post on Monday that it wa unclear how much deterrence or justice could be achieved against the attacker if Hezbollah a an organization is left untouched . & nbsp ; In January 2018 , the Post exclusively disclosed that the Bulgarian state prosecution had decided not to charge Hezbollah a an organization with involvement in the 2012 bomb attack at the Burgas airport . & nbsp ; Instead , the prosecutor indicted the two men allegedly involved in the attack a if they were terrorist or even regular criminal who acted without connection to an organization . The word & ldquo ; Hezbollah & rdquo ; doe not appear in the indictment . & nbsp ; In addition , the indictment did not mention standard terrorism offense such a & ldquo ; acting a part of a terrorist organization & rdquo ; or connecting the murder offense to terrorism , referring instead merely to disturbing public order . & nbsp ; Sources close to the case told the Post at the time that when the Bulgarian prosecutor wa confronted with these anomaly , he claimed that no one provided him with evidence demonstrating Hezbollah & rsquo ; s involvement . & nbsp ; This directly contradicted evidence that came to light immediately after the attack from Bulgarian Interior Minister Tsvetan Tsvetanov naming Hezbollah a the culprit . & nbsp ; In 2013 , Tsvetanov & rsquo ; s successor , Tsvetlin Yovchev , told reporter before a commemoration ceremony , & ldquo ; There are clear sign that say Hezbollah is behind the Burgas bombing . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Also in 2013 , then-Bulgarian foreign minister Nikolay Mladenov and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu both confirmed the solid evidence linking Hezbollah to the Burgas attack . & nbsp ; Bulgaria & rsquo ; s investigation into the Burgas bombing even led to the EU placing Hezbollah & rsquo ; s armed wing on it blacklist . & nbsp ; The ruling party in Bulgaria ha changed numerous time since 2012 with some observer saying politics ham-strung the trial . & nbsp ; Toby Dershowitz , senior vice president for government relation and Strategy at the Foundation for Defense of Democracies , a nonpartisan think tank focused on national security , told the Post at the time of sentencing that & ldquo ; Bulgaria ha long known that Hezbollah wa behind this horrific attack and ha been clear about it . The fact that Bulgaria say it only ha a mechanism to prosecute individual , and not organization , should not permit Hezbollah to yet again murder with impunity . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The Post previously reported that Bulgaria sent extradition order to Lebanon & rsquo ; s government regarding the two Hezbollah operative who were then charged with the act of terrorism . & nbsp ; The Lebanese-Australian Meliad Farah and Lebanese-Canadian Hassan El Hajj Hassan , who have been convicted of blowing up the tour bus in Burgas , Bulgaria , are believed to be in Lebanon . & nbsp ; There are also US court document from other terror and Hezbollah-related case which have confirmed that the two convicted men a well a the third attacker who died in the attack , French-Lebanese national Jacques Felipe Martin ( aka Mohammad Hassan el-Husseini ) , were connected to Hezbollah . & nbsp ; According to medium report , the two convicted murderer are alleged to have entered Bulgaria using false driver & rsquo ; license printed in Lebanon . The Post sent press query to Bulgaria @ @ @ s embassy and foreign ministry on Tuesday evening . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Benjamin Weinthal and Jerusalem Post Staff contributed to this story .
title: bulgarian official admitted hezbollah involvement in bus bombing

Body Text: Medical personnel gathered in protest outside Sheba Medical Center in Tel Hashomer on Wednesday morning , a scientist from the Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovot held a strike against police violence at protest , especially against medical teams.The protest and strike followed recent incident in which protester were hurt.Police used & ldquo ; disproportionate violence alongside illegal use of mean to disperse protest , & rdquo ; protest organization Change Generation said in a statement . Police shot water cannon directly at protester , causing some to lose consciousness and sending others to emergency room , it said.Dr . Tal Weissbach wa injured at a protest in Jerusalem earlier this week after the spray from a water cannon hit her in the eye , even though she wa clearly identifiable a a medical professional . & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s interesting that specifically I , with the bright orange [ vest ] with & lsquo ; doctor & rsquo ; on the back , got a direct spray , & rdquo ; Weissbach said in a video released by protest organization Yalla Tikva . & ldquo ; Is [ National Security Minister Itamar ] Ben-Gvir ordering [ police ] to harm medical professional specifically ? & rdquo ; she asked.In response , the Israel Police said it take seriously the & ldquo ; disruption of public order and violent riot that occurred on Aza Street , & rdquo ; which included setting fire on the road , physical altercation with officer , and attacking officer , a well a trying to pas police barricades.Violent incidentsAll of this occurred after police & ldquo ; allowed the freedom of protest and the coordinated parade for hour , a well a securing them , & rdquo ; the police said . & ldquo ; As far a there are claim against those police who acted [ at the protest ] , they should be referred to the body that are authorized to handle them , a usual . & rdquo ; The incident followed another one in which a doctor wa dragged violently by police while providing medical treatment to a protester , said medical professional protest organization the Whitecoats.Organizers also accused the police of violence when removing protester blocking the exit from Jerusalem on Tuesday . Protest organization Change Direction blocked the road with protester who climbed ladder held aloft by other protester with ropes.Footage of police clearing the protest appears to show police knocking the ladder to the road and one officer hitting a protester in the head with his fist repeatedly.One of the protester on the ladder knocked to the ground wa taken to a hospital emergency room . & ldquo ; This is what a police [ force ] that is losing it way look like , & rdquo ; said Change Direction on X , sharing a video in which police appear to pull the ladder out from under the protester . & ldquo ; They are willing to risk the life of a protester to clear a road . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; We did not believe that the police would be willing to knock a protester down from a height of three meter , & rdquo ; it said . & ldquo ; They could have easily taken her down safely , but chose the violent way . & rdquo ; In response , the police said dozen of protester had disturbed public order and endangered themselves by climbing ladder while blocking the main access road to Shaare Zedek Medical Center and a main artery out of the city . & ldquo ; When force arrived , an order wa given to them to disperse by the police commander on site , & rdquo ; the police said . & ldquo ; After they did not heed this , police began pushing those disturbing the public order toward the sidewalk to try to open the road . & rdquo ; Protest organization cited additional incident this week in which protester were harmed by the police or prevented from receiving medical treatment . The Whitecoat organization said a man & rsquo ; s leg wa broken after a water cannon stream threw him into a wall.Many of the incident occurred this week during what protest organization are calling an escalation of action taken by them to bring back the hostage or to replace the government.On Monday and Tuesday , there were large rally at the Knesset . The rally on Monday wa attended by an estimated 150,000 people , according to protest organizer . There were also protest and strike held at high school throughout the country , and protest are scheduled to take place in the North and South . Protest convoy are also scheduled for this week , the protest organizer said.Israel Police Insp . - Gen . Kobi Shabtai on Wednesday addressed the public & rsquo ; s confidence in and the role of the police , a well a accusation of the politicization of police , at a conference at Tel Aviv University . & ldquo ; When a police officer exercise authority toward a citizen , he must see the law , and only the law , before his eye , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; The citizen must know that the policeman standing in front of him represents the law only and is certainly not acting on behalf of one minister or another . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; The police in a democratic country must be free , with absolutely no politics , & rdquo ; Shabtai said . & ldquo ; It must remain autonomous & ndash ; free of any political bias , one way or another . This is the only way to guarantee police independence . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; The clear boundary between the political echelon and the enforcing entity are cracking , and I fear what might happen if they are completely erased , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; The only way to avoid this is to maintain the clear separation between the political echelon and the law-enforcing entity . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; During my tenure a police commissioner , I worked under three minister , & rdquo ; Shabtai said . & ldquo ; Naturally , every minister ha a different professional outlook . Unfortunately , especially in the past year , the current minister & rsquo ; s attempt to blatantly violate the required balance have been multiplying . There are many example of this .
