Body Text: As a global innovation powerhouse , Israel is actively integrating cutting-edge artificial intelligence ( AI ) technology across all facet of society , recognizing the vital importance of these advancement . & ldquo ; AI will lead to unimaginable transformation at all level and impact every aspect of our life and the life of future generation . This is the next industrial revolution , & rdquo ; stated President Isaac Herzog.But doe this avant-garde spirit extend to the creative realm , where generative art offer a captivating glimpse into the fusion of human ingenuity and machine intelligence ? On the screen , digital dream come alive with lush vegetation , ephemeral flower , and flowing water.This is the AI-created world of & ldquo ; Botanic Reverie & rdquo ; by Ronen Tanchum , an Israeli artist working at the forefront of technology . & ldquo ; My aim is for audience to feel my artwork and engage with it on a deep emotional level , & rdquo ; say Ronen.Inspired by nature , he us generative algorithm to explore new aesthetic territory that exist on the boundary between the natural and the imagined . AI allows u to take a fresh look at familiar image , revealing unexpected facet of beauty . & ldquo ; My work pulsates with theme of synthetic nature , blooming phenomenon , and digital-human synchrony , exploring the human-machine-environment relationship , & rdquo ; Tanchum said.Contemporary artist are increasingly experimenting with generative technique , bringing their boldest creative idea to life . But how doe this art of the future work ? Algorithms trained on vast datasets can create image , video , and even music in response to textual prompt or visual example . Utilizing complex mathematical model , neural network identify pattern and generate content that aligns with user-defined parameter . Then , with additional command , human edit the generated image until the desired result is achieved . In this process , the artist becomes a kind of conductor , guiding the machine & rsquo ; s & ldquo ; creative & rdquo ; efforts.London-based Israeli photographer Ori Gersht demonstrates how AI can expand the expressive possibility of traditional medium in his project & ldquo ; Fields & amp ; Visions & amp ; ( Another World ) . & rdquo ; When processing his own photograph , the artist invite the neural network to reinterpret and literally & ldquo ; build upon & rdquo ; the original image & ndash ; now , they balance on the edge of photography and digital painting . & ldquo ; The combination of the precise trace of the optical lens in harmony with the computerized interpretation of artificial intelligence capture a shift in our concept of reality , a these photograph are no longer a faithful depiction of the physical subject matter , & rdquo ; comment Gersht.With this experiment , the artist transforms the very nature of photography , leading the viewer into a space of imagination.The ethical ramification of AI artOf course , it & rsquo ; s not so straightforward . In Israel , a around the world , there is an extensive public discussion surrounding generative art . It & rsquo ; s questionable whether it can be considered genuine art if a substantial portion of the work is done by a machine rather than a human.While diversity of approach and freedom of expression are hallmark of Israeli art & ndash ; just a they are of it society a a whole & ndash ; a majority of Israeli artist continue to work successfully with traditional fine art materials.Guy Yanai , an Israeli painter well-established on the international art scene , told The Jerusalem Post that he doe not use AI tool in his art . At the same time , he note that every industrial revolution ha a beneficial impact on the evolution of art , pushing the boundary of creative exploration and opening up new dimension of creativity.Experts also point out that generative art challenge the established understanding of the creative process and the very concept of an artwork . & ldquo ; I view generative art a a new method that may complement other contemporary a well a traditional practice , & rdquo ; Irena Gordon , chief curator of The Petah Tikva Museum said . & ldquo ; While it is exciting a a starting point , in the end it is up to the artist to use it to create good and meaningful art . & rdquo ; The integration of AI into the artistic sphere raise a number of important ethical and legal questions.Who is the author of a work created by an algorithm ? How do we assess the authenticity and value of such art ? Particularly heated discussion revolve around copyright for generative content and privacy issue when algorithm process personal data . Israel & rsquo ; s recently adopted & ldquo ; Responsible Innovation & rdquo ; policy for AI regulation , aimed at finding a balance between technological progress , ethical norm , and public interest , is intended to serve a a guide for the integration of AI , including in the creative industry . & ldquo ; The revolutionary impact of AI technology is yielding constant improvement in the quality of life for Israel & rsquo ; s citizen in countless field . However , along with the numerous benefit , there are also many risk . We must ensure that the human remains at the center of AI development , & rdquo ; said Innovation , Science and Technology Minister Ofir Akunis.However , it would be incorrect to claim that AI ha completely and suddenly taken over art in Israel . Rather , it ha complemented the extensive list of tool in the arsenal of contemporary artists.Digital art in Israel encompasses a wide range of technology , demonstrating the openness of local artist to innovation and experimentation , from 3D modeling , VR , and AR to generative graphic , animation , and more . These medium often intersect and overlap in the practice of artist , creating complex artistic statement in the language of contemporary techno-culture.This is the language in which Ruth Patir , representing Israel at this year & rsquo ; s Venice Biennale , also express herself . Her project & ldquo ; ( M ) otherland & rdquo ; masterfully combine documentary narrative with advanced computer-generated imagery ( CGI ) technology . In her work , the artist us 3D animation to convey her idea to a digital-age audience in a language most understandable to them . & ldquo ; For me , creating work that expand the vocabulary of the digital asset ha become something I wa really eager to fight for , & rdquo ; Patir said , noting , & ldquo ; My practice doesn & rsquo ; t focus on technology , it is only a facade of whatever is the contemporary moment we are living . & rdquo ; Creative experiment with technology are also resonating in the local art market . Galleries and collector , primarily of the younger generation , are showing increasing interest in new media.The first auction sale of NFT work by Israeli artist took place in 2022 at Tiroche auction in Herzliya , with lot selling for record amount for this segment , reaching the upper estimate . Sales of digital art on the secondary market indicate the successful integration of this genre into the commercial context.Leading cultural institution in Israel are gradually including generative art along with other digital art in their exhibition and educational program . However , it should be noted that these are still only tentative attempt , and truly large-scale exhibition project exploring the theme of AI are still ahead for Israelis.It is equally crucial to discus the challenge . Vladimir Opredelenov , a leading expert on digitalization for creative industry , warned The Jerusalem Post about the risk of falling behind technological progress : & ldquo ; Cultural institution need to change their mindset and implement innovative solution to avoid finding themselves in a kind of & lsquo ; blackout . & rsquo ; If they do not become part of the global digital ecosystem , they risk losing relevance and audience in the era of intelligent machine . Museums must actively study and apply AI technology in their work & ndash ; from curating and research to collection management and visitor engagement . & rdquo ; Moreover , the integration of AI into artistic practice requires art professional to continually improve their digital literacy and master new technological tools.To effectively leverage the capability of AI for creativity , analysis , curating , and audience engagement , employee of museum , gallery , and other cultural institution need to actively develop digital competency , and stay up-to-date with the latest technology trends.AI also open up previously unseen opportunity , particularly in the realm of preserving historical memory and cultural heritage . Algorithms can efficiently analyze vast amount of digitized archival data , systematize it , extract valuable information , and even aid in reconstructing lost artifacts.At Yad Vashem Museum , AI technology are used to process million of document , identify Holocaust victim , and create installation that immerse visitor in the context of historical event . & ldquo ; AI is not just another technological trend , it is a fundamental shift that will affect every aspect of our life , & rdquo ; Leading world expert in AI and co-founder of Navan Ilan Twig said . & ldquo ; This technology ha already firmly entered our life and will only develop further . It is important for the art community to embrace these change and learn to harness the potential of AI in the most productive way . & rdquo ;
title: when art meet ai : israel 's journey into generative art

Body Text: CNN hired a photojournalist who just three day before posted video and photo of himself inside Israel during the Hamas massacre , including with an Israeli tank and a room of bloody , dead bodies.Gaza photojournalist Hassan Eslaiah crossed into Israel on October 7 to document the Hamas massacre of more than 1,200 Israelis . His photo from the scene appeared on several international news outlet , including The Associated Press , the Jerusalem-based watchdog HonestReporting revealed last week . & nbsp ; CNN had also hired Eslaiah.The watchdog & rsquo ; s story sparked a series of question and international outcry , ultimately leading to his being let go from the two institution . & nbsp ; However , CNN said in a statement last week that their working relationship with the freelancer began after the October 7 terrorist attack on Israel , on October 10 . It also noted that despite it decision to stop working with Eslaiah , it did not have & ldquo ; any reason to doubt the journalistic accuracy of the work he ha done for u , & rdquo ; a reported by Ynet and confirmed by The Jerusalem Post . & nbsp ; The Post confirmed that Eslaiah wa not fired for his work on the 7th but for a separate but related concern.It wa unclear if CNN knew about Eslaiah & rsquo ; s post on Telegram before offering him work . & nbsp ; CNN told the Post it will not be commenting further on the matter.Crossing the line : Did a photojournalist support the massacre of Israelis ? The issue go beyond issue of accuracy or bias but is more about the line that get crossed when a photojournalist appears to act with delight in response to witnessing the killing of civilian , while working for a major news outlet.HonestReporting showed a screenshot of a now-removed post of the photojournalist on X standing in front of the Israeli tank without a press vest or helmet . The tweet read , & ldquo ; Live from inside the Gaza Strip settlement . & rdquo ; A similar image still appears on his Telegram page.HonestReporting also published a separate image from well before the massacre showing Eslaiah buddying up with Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar.However , by scrolling through Eslaiah & rsquo ; s personal Telegram channel , the Post ha found that Eslaiah posted much more than a tank on the 7th , including item that indicate that not only did he likely know about the planned massacre before it began at around 6:30 a.m . , but that he supported the death of the innocent Israelis he watched being murdered.Eslaiah & rsquo ; s first post on October 7 wa at 5:59 a.m . : & ldquo ; We wake up to the great gift of God , & rdquo ; he posted , according to a translation by ChatGPT . & ldquo ; The spirit ha returned , and our blessing have increased . & rdquo ; Within half an hour , he is posting about the rocket being launched at Israel and the sound of the Iron Dome intercepting them over Khan Yunis . Then , between 6:55 a.m . and 8:30 a.m . , he post multiple variation : & ldquo ; To follow the latest news moment by moment , follow me on my medium platform . & rdquo ; At 8:29 a.m . , he appears & ldquo ; live from inside the settlement near the Gaza Strip & rdquo ; with a picture of a burning tank in the background.At 8:36 a.m . , after witnessing nearly 10 minute of the massacre , he post image from the scene with a verse from the Koran : & ldquo ; And on that day , the believer will rejoice in the victory of Allah & rdquo ; and the hashtag & ldquo ; # AqsaFlood . & rdquo ; At 9:25 a.m . , the most gruesome of post is revealed : a video with his watermark : & ldquo ; Filmed by Hassan Eslaiah & rdquo ; in the center , depicting a room full of dead , bloody body . & nbsp ; This particular video doe not appear to have been published anywhere else . In the background , you hear a calm voice that sound like his from other video , and is spoken in his Arabic dialect , stating the following : & ldquo ; [ Animal ] carcass , carcass . God is great . This is the path to Jerusalem . & rdquo ; There is another video at 9:49 a.m . of his standing in front of burning Jewish home a terrorist run by . And a final video one minute later of his leaving Israel on the back of someone & rsquo ; s motorbike . & nbsp ; Is this the kind of photojournalist that major news outlet should be hiring ? What kind of vetting process should be required before hiring someone in a foreign country ? Perhaps these are the question that all international outlet should now be asking themselves .
title: crossing the line of integrity with a hamas-praising photojournalist - analysis

Body Text: Hanan Savyon and Guy Amir , the duo behind the TV series Asfur and the megahit Israeli movie Maktub and Forgiveness , are back on the small screen with Bros , Netflix & rsquo ; s first original Hebrew-language series , which recycles the Jerusalemite schlubby bromance shtick that ha worked for them all these years.If you liked their earlier work , you & rsquo ; ll have fun with this , and if you didn & rsquo ; t , well , you & rsquo ; re probably not their target audience anyway . For once , there are English subtitle available , which will make it easier for many English-speakers in Israel to give it a try . & nbsp ; It won & rsquo ; t shock anyone to hear that they play two friend who run a bar in the Mahaneh Yehuda market called Pin-Younis , with Savyon a the hard-partying Pini , whose wife can & rsquo ; t get pregnant ( which a doctor suggests is a problem caused by Pini & rsquo ; s drug use ) , and Amir a Niso , his BFF and business partner , whose girlfriend , Rotem ( Yael Sztulman ) , work at the bar.The main plot is about how they head to Krakow to support their favorite soccer team & ndash ; Beitar Jerusalem , a you might have guessed & ndash ; a it competes against a Polish team . Subplots include a possible cancer diagnosis , Niso & rsquo ; s problem with Rotem , and a group of Tel Aviv hipster who plan to open a rival establishment and then try to buy their bar . & nbsp ; Their Poland adventure take up several episode and allows them to delve a bit into the little-known history of how Mizrahim were victim in the Holocaust.The Poland episode also feature all kind of action , including when they get chased by a group of neo-Nazis and even more dire predicament . Like a lot of Israeli comedy , the series mix sentimental and melodramatic storyline with the slapstick . & nbsp ; One thought that occurred to me watching it is that while most Beitar fan are just fan , there is a racist element to the team & rsquo ; s fan base that you wouldn & rsquo ; t guess at from it portrayal here . The series doesn & rsquo ; t make it clear that the character distance themselves from the kind of fan who have actually unfurled & ldquo ; Forever Pure & rdquo ; banner at the team & rsquo ; s match & ndash ; & ldquo ; Forever Pure & rdquo ; is the title of an excellent documentary about these fan & ndash ; to show their opposition to the team hiring Arab player . These fan have resorted to violence to show their opposition to having Arabs and Muslims of all nationality join the team . & nbsp ; But the heart of the series is Pini and Niso & rsquo ; s friendship , and Savyon and Amir , who have been working together for decade , really project the closeness of longtime friend and , like so many comic actor , rise to the occasion when there is an emotional moment . Their self-deprecating likability lift this series above it often formulaic script , and if you stick with it , it will be because you enjoy spending time in their company . & nbsp ; What else is on Israeli TV ? IT & rsquo ; S GOOD news for fan of vintage American sitcom that Yes ha just started a new channel called Classic Comedies , which is available on Channel 29 . It run around the clock , and it offer comedy series from the & rsquo ; 70 to the & rsquo ; 90 . It feature All in the Family , which many consider the greatest sitcom of all time , which wa about the unrepentant racist Archie Bunker.This series wa created by television great Norman Lear , and wa more or less the first time that a network television comedy dealt with political issue for laugh , but with a serious agenda . Lear wa a liberal , and while the pugnacious hero , Bunker , charmed some , his conviction were proved wrong in episode after episode , although the series also made fun of his liberal son-in-law ( played by Rob Reiner , the son of Carl Reiner , who is now a movie director ) and his daughter ( Sally Struthers ) . Other sitcom on the channel include Mad About You , with Paul Reiser and Helen Hunt ( who went on to win a Best Actress Oscar for As Good As It Gets ) , Cheers ( considered one of the best ensemble cast of all time ) , Happy Days ( the Fonz ! ) , Who & rsquo ; s the Boss ? and The Love Boat.If Yes programmer are reading this , I & rsquo ; d like to request that they add The Mary Tyler Moore Show and Taxi , two series created by James L . Brooks that I would be very happy to see at 2 a.m . when I can & rsquo ; t sleep.ONE OF the big issue in the Hollywood writer strike wa the use of AI to write screenplay , because the Hollywood scribe feared they would be replaced . But when you watch a lot of the rom-coms and light entertainment on Netflix and other platform these day , it & rsquo ; s hard to believe that they weren & rsquo ; t written by robot , and not especially well-programmed robots.That doesn & rsquo ; t mean you won & rsquo ; t enjoy aspect of them ; the cast and location are always great-looking . But to say that there are no surprise would be an understatement . & nbsp ; A case in point is the new Spanish movie on Netflix , Love , Divided . It & rsquo ; s about a nerdy but gorgeous app designer who work out of his apartment , which share a paper-thin wall with the apartment that a recently dumped , awkward but gorgeous pianist move into . He ha a deadline to get the app ready and must work all the time , while she is practicing for a special audition.If you & rsquo ; ve seen a movie or two , you could easily write a script right now that would be almost identical to the actual film.LOOKING FOR something a little more interesting , I found I & rsquo ; ll See You in My Dreams , a movie that recently joined the Netflix lineup and which star Blythe Danner ( who is probably best known these day for being Gwyneth Paltrow & rsquo ; s mother , but who ha had a very interesting career of her own ) a Carol , a lonely widow who step back into the dating pool after many year alone . While it might sound like a typical rom-com , it & rsquo ; s much more thoughtful and even a bit downbeat.Carol , a retired singer and teacher and the mother of an adult daughter who life far away , wake up every morning , water her plant , exercise , see her girlfriend ( a great group played by Rhea Perlman , Mary Kay Place , and June Squibb ) , and play golf , but she feel something is missing in her life ; and after her beloved dog dy , she begin dating.Sam Elliott , who played the wise old cowboy in The Big Lebowski , is her love interest , and his character is similarly adrift.But the story isn & rsquo ; t all straight line and big laugh , ending with a clinch . One element that set it apart is a storyline where she befriends her pool cleaner , a young man who aspires to write song and feel stuck , and to whom she can open up in a way she can & rsquo ; t with her old friends.The pool cleaner is played by Martin Starr , whom you may know a Gilfoyle , the Satan-worshiping programmer in Silicon Valley . While I loved him in that series , I actually didn & rsquo ; t recognize him here , and without his strange Gilfoyle hairstyle , he is a handsome leading man type , with an edge . & nbsp ; While I watched this movie , I started out envying the character because they were living their life in a world that wa so peaceful , without war or terrorism or the thousand of other thing that make life in Israel challenging . But by the end I realized that , to quote a line from the Norwegian movie 1001 Grams , & ldquo ; Life & rsquo ; s heaviest burden is having nothing to carry . & rdquo ; MUCH IS coming up soon in May , including a number of movie and series to mark Holocaust Remembrance Day , notably the series The Tattooist of Auschwitz , which star Harvey Keitel in an adaptation of the book of the same name.There will be much more programming devoted to marking this day , including documentary , series , and feature film , a well a movie devoted to Remembrance Day for the Fallen of Israel & rsquo ; s Wars and Independence Day , which will be filled with deeper sorrow this year , since the loss of October 7 and the subsequent war .

Body Text: The Israel National Team will get back to action with a pair of soccer friendly against Hungary on Saturday and Belarus on Tuesday a brand-new head coach Ran Ben Shimon will get his first taste of leading the blue-and-white.Following a number of disappointing campaign under the leadership of Alon Hazan and Yossi Benayoun , the Israel Football Association decided to make a change and it brought in a battle-tested head coach , both in Israel and abroad , who also ha international soccer experience on his resume.The 53-year-old Ben Shimon grew up a a player in the Maccabi Petah Tikva youth system , where he featured between 1987-1995 . But it wa with Hapoel Haifa where the defender starred and captained the Carmel Reds to the 1999 league championship . The Petah Tikva native also played for the Israel National Team , making 34 appearance , before moving into coaching where he began to earn his stripe in the Maccabi Tel Aviv youth department in 2003.His first full time head coaching job wa with Kiryat Shmona , where he helped the team earn promotion from the Leumit League and then finished in third place in Premier Leauge action to earn a place in UEFA Cup play.After a very short stint with Maccabi Tel Aviv in 2008 it wa back to Kiryat Shmona for a trio of season where he won a pair of Toto Cups . Most notable a well a the shocking 2011-2012 League championship with K8 that became an international story of success for a small team finding a way to finish atop the table against club with budget much higher than the northerners.The next season , Ben Shimon went abroad to lead AEK Larnaca in Cyprus and then returned back to Israel to head up Hapoel Tel Aviv , Maccabi Petah Tikva and Beitar Jerusalem before taking over the Cyprus National Team post where he plied his trade between 2017-2020.Ashdod for three season and then another stop back at Larnaca wa on tap before being appointed a the head coach of the Israel National Team.Ahead of the two upcoming match , which for Hungary will be a tune-up for the UEFA European Championship , Ben Shimon wa unveiled a the new bench bos and spoke about his vision for the & nbsp ; blue-and-white a he begin to mold the squad to his liking . ' Israel National Team is a mission ' & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The Israel National Team is not just another stop for me & ndash ; it & rsquo ; s a mission , and I will go into every working day treating it a the most important day . & ldquo ; Being a national team player is how one conduct himself off and on the field , both when we are together a a team and when we are not . Every time we are together is of great importance to me . Every game will be treated the same , no more or no less important . & nbsp ; This is an opportunity for everyone who is around the team to ask what they can do differently . We are in a complex period of time and I will try my utmost to connect this team to the people of Israel . & rdquo ; Ben Shimon spoke about Barak Bachar , who had been a leading candidate for the position but decided to head back to Maccabi Haifa after a short and disappointing run with Red Star Belgrade . & ldquo ; Coaches who were deserving of this position were in competition for it and I don & rsquo ; t feel second to anyone , no matter what is written and what people may say . I wa also a candidate in other campaign , I feel very secure in my place . & ldquo ; Every place that I & rsquo ; ve been in my life there wa also a clash between my head and my heart and I went with my gut feeling . This is the right place for me to be . I believe in my ability to do different thing than what wa done in the past . I believe in this generation of player and I have arrived at the right stage in my life to coach the Israel National Team , which is a big challenge . I will have to bring all the experience and what I have gained in life into the challenge that I am entering into today with great faith . & rdquo ; Ben Shimon will lead the team in the upcoming Nations League campaign , where the opponent will be European heavyweight France , Italy and Belgium . & ldquo ; I am not going to deny that the main goal is Euro 2028 , but we will have a competitive team in every game . Each game will give u a little more a to what we can do and accomplish . & ldquo ; I & rsquo ; m not going to pas up these two year . I & rsquo ; m going to work very hard to produce a DNA of winner and I need to create a team that will connect with the people in this campaign . We will not give up any game . That & rsquo ; s the beauty of sport & ndash ; you don & rsquo ; t know what the outcome will be at the end . We will come into these game with complete faith that we can win . & rdquo ; Ben Shimon added that he is still working to put together his group of assistant . & ldquo ; I believe that in the next week or so the balance of the staff will be appointed and if we only rely on the time we get together for game our philosophy won & rsquo ; t work . We have to work on a daily basis , work hard and convince the player that this is what it take to advance to a big tournament . & ldquo ; In order to achieve different result , we must change . My predecessor did good thing and we need to learn from that . I am a big believer in seeing what team similar to ours have done and those that have broken glass ceiling . I am coming into this with complete faith in both the local product and the Israeli player . & rdquo ; The new coach also spoke about what type of player that he will want to include in his squad a well a how he will work with them to get the best out of the squad . & ldquo ; I will have to shape the nature of my work in front of the player . I prefer player with European experience , but the team is open to everyone . & rdquo ; Last campaign saw the ugly saga of Eran Zahavi & rsquo ; s hotel room assignment , which caused a stir at the time . & ldquo ; Everyone come in with their own agenda , & rdquo ; Ben Shimon said . & ldquo ; We & rsquo ; ll sit down and decide how we want thing to look . I don & rsquo ; t think it & rsquo ; s too complicated , we need to create an environment for the player to succeed . I have a personal connection with each player . I have a wonderful relationship with Eran and I also spoke with [ Miguel ] Vitor . I believe that everything will be & nbsp ; considered individually , but there is no doubt that the team is going through a process . & rdquo ; Ben Shimon also commented on the path he took to become the head coach . & ldquo ; When I wa a player , I didn & rsquo ; t think I would become a coach . All the station I went through come back to me . While I am an emotional person , I am less concerned with the past and I am not very nostalgic . All this is nice , but from here on it is a matter of seeing what we can do to succeed . & rdquo ;

Body Text: The non-profit Momentum brought 130 Jewish mother to visit Israel in a trip designed to help them understand the gravity of Hamas & rsquo ; s October 7 attack , help them connect to their Jewish value and to the state , the organization announced on Tuesday.Momentum which work with the Ministry of Diaspora Affairs and Combating Antisemitism , ha collectively transported more than 200 participant in three different solidarity trip , before this one , since October 7.The current cohort of woman hailed from North , Central and South America from country including : the United States , Canada , Columbia , Chile , Panama , Argentina , Mexico , Uruguay and Israel.What did the mother do on the trip ? While the trip still maintains the goal of connecting participant to Judaism and Israel , in the wake of October 7 , Momentum ha placed a greater emphasis on volunteerism and hearing first-hand account from soldier , evacuee and October 7 massacre survivors.Participants met with the family of the hostage in Tel Aviv & rsquo ; s Kikar HaChatufim ( Hostages Square ) and volunteered at a farm . The group also made chocolate for evacuated families.Additionally , the woman prepared meal for IDF soldier , and visited Sderot and kibbutz on Israel & rsquo ; s southern border , where they witnessed what remains of the October 7 massacre . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The mother on this trip saw Israel & rsquo ; s story from their own eye and heard them from their own ear and now it 's the time to act , & rdquo ; said Momentum Founding Director Lori Palatnik . & ldquo ; We hope every participant take the call of & lsquo ; Hineni & rsquo ; - to show up - and they each go back to their home to show up for their Israeli sister who have suffered so much . It is our hope that they come out of this experience forever changed . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; `` The purpose of the mission is to provide opportunity for woman in the Diaspora to meaningfully contribute to Israeli society while they & rsquo ; re here and identify with their struggle . After hearing from family of hostage , soldier , farmer and Israeli mother we hope our participant will emerge from this experience with a new sense of understanding about what Israelis are going through right now . And , collectively , when the Diaspora and Israel come together , we can demonstrate the power of unity , & rdquo ; Palatnik added.Trip participant Erica Markovitz , from Detroit , said , & ldquo ; I had two friend at the Nova Festival . One of them is still a hostage . I & rsquo ; m here in Israel to bear witness and send a message home and to keep their story alive . & rdquo ;
title: jewish mother fly to israel to offer support in the wake of october 7

Body Text: Can the US offer financial assistance to the Palestinians even while the Palestinian Authority pay monthly stipend to terrorist and their family ? & nbsp ; The question wa raised by reporter and pundit on Wednesday when the US announced it planned to restore humanitarian and security assistance to the Palestinians , a part of an overall financial package of $ 290 million . & nbsp ; Former US president Donald Trump cut all funding to the Palestinians , which had soared close to $ 600 million annually under the Obama administration . & nbsp ; Trump also put in place legislation to hold the PA financially accountable for terror activity and to halt it practice of terror stipend , known a & ldquo ; pay-for-slay . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; A reporter referenced that legislation when quizzing US State Department spokesman Ned Price on how the Biden administration could legally restore funding . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; US law & ndash ; there & rsquo ; s several of them & ndash ; say that the US can not provide money to the Palestinian Authority , & rdquo ; the reporter stated . & nbsp ; Price assured him that the funding wa & ldquo ; absolutely consistent with relevant US law . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Here are five thing to know about US funding to Palestinians and PA terror payment : & nbsp ; PA & rsquo ; s pay-for-slay The Palestinian Authority provides monthly stipend to the family of terrorist who are killed while engaging in act of terrorism , and to those jailed for terrorist act or on suspicion of terrorist activity . & nbsp ; It is estimated that the PA spends at least NIS 500 million annually on these stipend , with higher payment going to those whose crime were more severe and who have longer jail sentence . & nbsp ; Proponents of & ldquo ; pay-for-slay & rdquo ; brand the payment a a kind of social welfare system , particularly in light of Israel & rsquo ; s practice of administrative detention in which security prisoner can be held without charge . & nbsp ; Opponents have argued that if this were the case , payment would be based on need rather than the severity of the crime . & nbsp ; Taylor Force Act US military veteran Taylor Force wa stabbed to death in March 2016 , while in Israel for a business program , near the beach in Tel Aviv by a Palestinian . Two year later the US Congress passed legislation prohibiting direct assistance to the PA , to prevent terror payment based on US fund going to anyone associated with Force & rsquo ; s death . & nbsp ; The Biden administration intends to uphold that legislation , including not paying PA loan . & nbsp ; The Anti-Terror Clarification Act The anti-terror clarification act of 2018 allowed the Palestinian Authority to be financially liable should it be found guilty in US court of supporting terror activity . The legislation wa broadly written so that even humanitarian assistance to non-governmental Palestinian organization , peace-building funding or scholarship funding put the PA in a position of liability . & nbsp ; The PA notified the US in 2019 that it would not accept any funding , including humanitarian assistance , over fear of judicial liability . Subsequent Congressional legislation amended the ATCA to allow financial assistance to the Palestinian people , but leaving intact judicial liability issue for direct funding to the PA and the Palestine Liberation Organization . & nbsp ; PA Security Forces The US-trained Palestinian security force , which cooperate with the IDF , are considered an essential pillar of stability in the West Bank . Funding for those force , which had amounted to $ 60 million annually , wa exempt under the Taylor Force Act . & nbsp ; Joel Braunold , managing director of the S . Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace , said that the Taylor Force Act wa specifically intended to target the Economic Support Funds account that drew on & ldquo ; bilateral economic assistance and humanitarian traditional program in the West Bank and Gaza . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; But it wa not intended to & ldquo ; affect security assistance that come from the International Narcotics and Law Enforcement account ( INLE ) , not covered by Taylor Force requirement . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Funding for the security force , however , wa impacted by the ATCT , a problem corrected by amendment to that legislation . The Biden administration ha now resumed funding to the PA security force . & nbsp ; UNRWA The majority of US funding to the Palestinians had always gone through the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian refugee , amounting to an annual grant of over $ 350 million . The US wa the single largest donor to UNRWA . & nbsp ; The Trump administration & rsquo ; s decision in 2018 to cut funding to UNRWA wa not based on prohibition in the ATCT or the Taylor Force Act . There wa no legal impediment to continued US funding to UNRWA , which service 5.7 million Palestinian refugee in east Jerusalem , Gaza , the West Bank , Lebanon , Jordan and Syria . & nbsp ; The Trump administration made a policy decision not to support the organization because it believed that Palestinians could be better served by other organization . It agreed with Israel that UNRWA & rsquo ; s definition of who is a Palestinian refugee wa problematic , and that the organization wa inefficient and promoted incitement against Israel . & nbsp ; The Biden administration ha now made a policy decision to support UNRWA , with an initial grant of $ 150 million .

Body Text: Israel should not re-occupy the Gaza Strip , and should make sure Palestinians still rule the area , Commanders for Israel & rsquo ; s Security ( CIS ) and other former top defense official said in it recommendation for how Israel should handle Gaza post-toppling Hamas.In contrast , several official familiar with government deliberation on the issue are far more circumspect about sharing their view , and about whether a serious strategy can be framed , before the outcome of the ground invasion ( which continues to be delayed ) becomes clearer.According to the senior former security official , & ldquo ; The war must end decisively for Israel , in a manner which will restore Israel & rsquo ; s standing and enhance deterrence . Towards this end , diplomatic , economic and other tool of statecraft should be pursued alongside the military campaign . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; Israel ha no intention of occupying the Gaza Strip and will not reassume responsibility for it . The Gaza Strip must be ruled by a Palestinian government with the assistance of international entity and a direct connection to the Palestinian government in the West Bank , & rdquo ; said CIS.Further , CIS said , & ldquo ; Israel should relinquish control of the territory captured during the operation a quickly a possible and should not repeat the scenario of becoming mired in the Lebanese quagmire . This imperative doe not include territory captured for the purpose of widening the buffer zone . & rdquo ; Questions about this new Palestinian regime in GazaCIS & rsquo ; s strategy paper is one of the most detailed to date on the issue by top official , though it still leaf many open question : What form will a new Palestinian regime in Gaza take ? How much will the Palestinian Authority dominate this regime versus local representative from Gaza ? Given Hamas & rsquo ; s success at eliminating organized internal opposition , how will Gaza have local representative if none of the class of Hamas , ruler for the last 15 year , will be allowed in the new regime ? & nbsp ; Also : Why will this new Palestinian government , with whatever unidentified international assistance , succeed in keeping Hamas down where the PA , UNFIL , and other international peacekeeping group have failed in the past to keep down determined local violent group ? Finally , CIS said to avoid the Israeli model of the early 1980s of interfering with who ran Lebanon , but suggested an unidentified larger security zone . This larger security zone idea is another large piece of what kept Israel mired deep in the & ldquo ; Lebanese quagmire & rdquo ; for almost another 20 years.A top former intelligence official separate from this group gave a wider number of potential choice of what could happen to Gaza post Hamas . & ldquo ; We need to take apart Hamas , and any future ruler of Gaza can not bring back the military power . All of Oslo wa based on the paradigm of demilitarization . We dropped this requirement for Hamas . We need to hand off Gaza to Egypt , or the Palestinian Authority , Jordan , or the UAE , & rdquo ; said the former top intelligence official.However , he added , & ldquo ; Maybe no one will want to take it . & rdquo ; Despite this dilemma , he stated , & ldquo ; that even in the worst case , it would take year for some other bad actor to achieve the militarization level of Hamas . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; Hamas had 15 year for it military buildup . And it is not just that we did not disrupt their militarization . [ Prime Minister Benjamin ] Netanyahu even helped Hamas with funding and material . The material were for building , but they were used for making rocket and tunnel . It doe not matter who rule Gaza , we can not let them rebuild their military power . & rdquo ; This official wa possibly being the most blatantly honest of all , recognizing that there may be no perfect solution that can prevent Hamas from at some point regaining control of Gaza.However , he recognized that even if Hamas returned in the worst case scenario , this & nbsp ; would take time , and he wa pointing out that that time itself and extra time afterward to rebuild military power , would give a much longer break from large round of fighting with Gaza.Former national security council chief from 2017-2021 Meir Ben Shabbat said using overwhelming force against Hamas to defeat it quickly and comprehensively is the only thing Israel should be thinking about at this stage . & ldquo ; Israel is exempt from worrying what will happen in Gaza after the war . It must overthrow Hamas and destroy it military capability , and let the chip fall where they may , & rdquo ; said Ben Shabbat , who now also head Misgav : The Institute for National Security and Zionist Strategy.Ben Shabbat appears to be concerned that the invasion itself continues to be delayed and to look more surgical and less aggressive than Netanyahu and other official & rsquo ; public statement would suggest.Regarding the multiple official familiar with government debate on the issue , one noted that Israel may not have a dominant role in deciding who to hand Gaza to , even if it militarily defeat the Gaza group.In other word , once Israel refuse to hold on to Gaza itself , and asks for international help , Jerusalem may be stuck with arrangement sponsored by the UN , the US , or some other mix of powers.Others implied that the invasion itself wa so large , and the guerilla war afterward so unclear and vague , that it wa nearly impossible to plan post-war issue until the shape of the war itself eventually becomes clearer . & nbsp ;

Body Text: Palestinians on Thursday expressed anger over report that British Prime Minister Liz Truss wa studying relocating her country & rsquo ; s embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.Some Palestinians described the move a & ldquo ; a new Balfour Declaration & rdquo ; and said it prof Britain & rsquo ; s bias in favor of Israel.A Palestinian Authority official said the Palestinian leadership ha not received an official statement from the British government regarding the relocation of the embassy.The official warned that such & ldquo ; dangerous & rdquo ; move would have a negative impact on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.Moving the British embassy to JerusalemThe official pointed out that the report about moving the British Embassy to Jerusalem surfaced shortly after a meeting between PA President Mahmoud Abbas and Truss , who are both in New York to attend the annual United Nations General Assembly session . & ldquo ; If Britain want to play any role in the region , it must avoid taking any decision that only cause harm and aggravates tension , & rdquo ; the official told The Jerusalem Post.Sabri Saidam , a former PA cabinet minister and senior member of the ruling Fatah faction headed by Abbas , also rejected any decision to move the British Embassy to Jerusalem.Referring to the transfer of the US Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem just over year ago , Saidam told the PA & rsquo ; s Voice of Palestine radio station , & ldquo ; Britain is not America , and it ha historical obligation toward the Palestinian people . Body Text: A Hezbollah missile hit an IAF fighter jet . In response , the entire air force is scrambled to participate in a broad offensive against Lebanon , including attack against infrastructure such a bridge , power plant and airport spanning 24 hour . That scenario wa the focus of an IDF exercise that began on Sunday morning and ended on Tuesday at noon . & nbsp ; During the drill , the IAF proved it ability to strike at 3,000 Hezbollah target within a 24-hour period . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We practiced defending Israel & rsquo ; s sky against cruise missile and operating our active [ aerial ] defense system against the rocket that they will want to use to target air force base and densely populated area , & rdquo ; a senior IAF officer said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We practiced attacking high-value target in quantity in a way we never did before , & rdquo ; the officer added . & ldquo ; It wa 24 hour with more than 3,000 target attacked , causing severe damage to the operation of the enemy . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Despite the limitation imposed by the coronavirus crisis , about 85 % of IAF personnel participated in the exercise , which involved all branch , including technician , ammunition officer and reservist , who were called up to participate . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; One of the main task simulated wa achieving air superiority over Lebanon . This wa achieved by destroying all element that could threaten Israeli aircraft , including antiaircraft launcher , especially in southern Lebanon and Beirut , where Hezbollah ha it headquarters . & nbsp ; Two week ago , Hezbollah tried to shoot down an IAF drone over Lebanon . The surface-to-air missile missed , and the drone continued it reconnaissance mission , the IDF said at the time . & nbsp ; While the drill focused on Hezbollah and Lebanon , the IAF considers the North a a single front and understands that Hezbollah also operates in Syria and that Iran is present throughout what is referred to a the & ldquo ; Shi & rsquo ; ite Crescent , & rdquo ; spanning Iran , Iraq , Syria and Lebanon , the senior officer said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We look even further east , but we operate there only in response to [ incident ] , & rdquo ; he said . & nbsp ; Lt . - Col . S . , commander of the 201st Squadron that fly the F-16I and participated in the drill , told The Jerusalem Post his unit practiced a wide range of mission , including collecting intelligence and using many type of munition in attacking multiple target . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; This drill demonstrated a response to a mistake the other side made , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; It show the enemy what the air force will do in response to an attack on a fighter jet . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; During the 60 hour of the exercise , the entire staff of the squadron , including pilot and technician , practiced loading and unloading different type of munition onto and off of their fighter jet , all of which participated in the drill , S . said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We & rsquo ; re talking here about lifting munition weighing ton . . . We basically did everything we will do in a war , except actually flying to the operational area , and dropping the bomb , & rdquo ; he said . & nbsp ; Another aspect of the exercise wa getting the participant into the mood of the drill and hoping that reservist , who are considered a vital element in the air force , drop their day-to-day life and attend . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; On Sunday morning we got the call that the drill is starting , & rdquo ; S . said . & ldquo ; It caught u by surprise . We changed all our plan and started operating in war mode . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; People who planned to be with their loved one on Valentine & rsquo ; s Day had to cancel the plan , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; Our reservist who planned on going to work on Sunday and Monday had to call their boss or their colleague and tell them they couldn & rsquo ; t come . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; But above all , it wa a mental exercise , & rdquo ; S . said . & ldquo ; Just after the lockdown and the uncertainty , people understood that this is what they have to do , and they attended the drill . & rdquo ;
title: in message to hezbollah , iaf practice striking 3,000 target in 24 hour

Body Text: I like museum at night & ndash ; there is just something about seeing the art after most people have gone home . & nbsp ; I had just gone to the first opening at the Israel Museum after the coronavirus pandemic had more or less calmed down , and it wa so relaxing to walk through the empty corridor and look out the glass window at the Valley of the Cross . The exhibit wa a large , realistic painting called The Bureaucrat by Matan Ben Cnaan . It show a group of people in a field in Israel looking pleadingly at a man with a clipboard . The artist said he copied it & ndash ; the grouping , the face , the tense body language & ndash ; from a photo of prisoner arriving on the platform at Auschwitz.There wa a panel at the event , and they had an interesting commentary about it . They seemed to have thought a bit about the same idea the painting had raised for me : What would I have done if I had lived during the Holocaust ? How would I have protected my son Oren , who is in his 20 and ha autism ? & nbsp ; The audience listened intently a they [ the panel member ] spoke . It wa such a Jerusalem evening , with those old couple I see at all kind of exhibition and event . I used to hate and envy them , especially when I would overhear them talking about their adult child who were finishing the army and going to medical school or opening hi-tech business and getting married and having child . I don & rsquo ; t hate them anymore . It & rsquo ; s harder to hate them when they & rsquo ; re wearing corona mask . They look scared and creepy and childlike all at once.But it & rsquo ; s not only that . I don & rsquo ; t hate them anymore because thing are different with Oren now . & nbsp ; When the opening wa over , I tried to head to the outdoor sculpture garden to wander for a few minute in the cool air , but it wa blocked off . Oren used to like going to the museum and walking in that garden before we slipped into our routine of the zoo every Saturday afternoon . & nbsp ; THE LAST time I remember taking him to the museum wa during the summer he turned 18 , one of our hardest time . My mother , who had become too demented to live on her own in New York , had moved in with u . I couldn & rsquo ; t work a much a I had been because I wa taking care of her part of the time , and to write at all , I had to hire someone to look after her & ndash ; in addition to the student I hired to help me take care of Oren in the evening , when he often had tantrum . & nbsp ; So my income wa down , my expense were up , and my mother & rsquo ; s pension and saving were stuck in America and I had no one to help me get them out . The customer service employee on the phone line would hear the desperation in my voice and put me in the automatic scammer category , denying me access to every account she had . & nbsp ; My ex-husband had always said he would help care for my mother when the time came , but now he wa long gone . My mother , angry that I had whisked her away from her beloved New York , wa sitting on the couch all day , criticizing me , a mother do . I had to do all my work and any exercising in my bedroom . & nbsp ; We had just gone through a war with Gaza that had included missile fired at Jerusalem . It had thrown Oren & rsquo ; s school schedule out of whack ; now it wa the end of the summer and he wa home for 14 indescribably long day . When his repetitive question began to bother my mother , she would start yelling at him . I could not leave them alone in the living room , even to go to the bathroom . He didn & rsquo ; t react right away but later in the day , he would have violent tantrum , usually when I told him it wa time for him to stop playing on the computer . & nbsp ; But that wa n't the worst of itBUT THAT wasn & rsquo ; t the worst of it . The worst of it wa that I had stopped sleeping . & nbsp ; All right , that & rsquo ; s an exaggeration . I slept a little , but never more than four hour a night and usually much less . I had a sleeping-pill prescription at one point , but my doctor said it wa too much , I needed to stop , and he wouldn & rsquo ; t renew it . & nbsp ; He didn & rsquo ; t understand , though . My father had been bipolar , and I knew how it wa when someone stopped sleeping & ndash ; the sloppiness and the craziness that came out . I could feel myself heading that way . & nbsp ; The day we went to the Israel Museum back then , my mother wa home watching tennis with my younger son , Ben . It wa okay to leave them together , and I hoped my mother would never lose it with him the way she did with Oren . Ben wa affected by Oren & rsquo ; s tantrum more than any of u , I felt . Oren wa my son ; a his mother , I had signed on for this , for better or worse . But Ben had never asked for any of this , and a Oren & rsquo ; s outburst had gotten worse , Ben had gotten more and more withdrawn and rarely came out of his room . & nbsp ; Oren and I walked through the sculpture garden that summer day and stopped outside the child & rsquo ; s wing . The guard are real tough ass there , and Oren & rsquo ; s loud voice and jumping would instantly get him thrown out of any other part of the museum . He climbed the structure outside that kid were allowed to climb , a kind of pyramid that he lowered himself down into until only his long foot were visible.Being upside down like that seemed to calm him , and he wa quiet a we walked into the child & rsquo ; s wing , where a film about city wa showing , called Dies Irae . The room where it wa playing wa cool and empty , and we sat down . I had to Google dy irae to find out that it mean & ldquo ; day of rage . & rdquo ; The film showed rapidly shifting cityscape , and Oren and I were both transfixed . & nbsp ; I had brought a book with me to read during any kid & rsquo ; movie we might see there . It cheer me even now to remember that I wa actually reading a book then . How could I ever have found the time and energy ? & nbsp ; But it wa the perfect book for me right then : The Financial Lives of the Poets by Jess Walter . It wa a novel about an unemployed journalist who made disastrous real estate and career decision and briefly tried to deal weed to help him out of the mess he wa in , while coping with a cheating wife and a live-in , senile father . A different story from mine , but we shared a few thing & ndash ; including insomnia . & nbsp ; AT ONE point in the story , the hero read an article about chronic insomnia which said that it cause & ldquo ; & lsquo ; a steep decline in neural activity which can eventually lead to severe hallucination , delirium , mania , even psychotic break & ndash ; then death & ndash ; & rsquo ; Then death ? Wait . Just like that ? Shit . . . A few day without sleep and you go from slurred speech and bad decision to . . . death ? Well , that hardly seems fair . It feel like they left out a few step . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; I had seen the psychotic break of my own father and I knew I wa slipping , slipping . God , I shouldn & rsquo ; t have been driving at that time . It & rsquo ; s funny that they can test your alcohol level but not the fact that you haven & rsquo ; t had a good night & rsquo ; s sleep in month . & ldquo ; Empire State Building , & rdquo ; said Oren a an image of New York flashed on the screen . He had lived in New York until he wa four and wa still crazy about the subway and big building , which he looked at on YouTube video . I had not been able to bring him back for a visit in year , his behavior being too erratic , but his love for the city wa strong . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The Chrysler Building , & rdquo ; he added a moment later . & nbsp ; A few month earlier , when my friend & rsquo ; kid in the US were graduating from high school and my Israeli friend & rsquo ; kid were joining the army , Oren & rsquo ; s father and I had gone to family court to become his legal guardian . That & rsquo ; s what you will eventually have to do when you have a special-needs kid after he turn 18.The school sent home the initial paperwork , and a government representative came to the school to do back-to-back interview with parent and the kid & ndash ; just a formality . Eventually , we had to go to the court building without Oren and do some final paperwork . A few week later , the document showing we were now his guardian arrived in the mail . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The Statue of Liberty , & rdquo ; Oren said , and my mind reeled with gratitude to the filmmaker and curator & ndash ; that they had come up with something that Oren found absorbing . & nbsp ; The day before we visited the museum , The New York Times had run a magazine story on what they claimed were the nearly 10 % of people diagnosed with autism who & ldquo ; lose their diagnosis & rdquo ; and become completely mainstreamed , usually a a result of a kind of behavioral therapy that had left Oren in worse shape than before he started it . People kept emailing this article to me . & nbsp ; I have forgotten almost everything about the Dies Irae film , but it must have been a masterpiece because it made me forget about my mother and all of my other problem & ndash ; for a long a 20 second at a time . At the end of the film , a quote from the Requiem Mass appeared on screen , and I scrawled it down on the back page of The Financial Lives of the Poets : Remember that I am the cause of your journey ; Do not lose me on that day.The most relaxing place in IsraelWE WALKED out of the child & rsquo ; s wing . Oren asked to go home , but I couldn & rsquo ; t face the nightly routine yet , with all the possibility for tantrum and outburst from my mother , so I suggested walking a little more in the sculpture garden and , to my surprise , he agreed . & nbsp ; It can be the most relaxing place in Israel . Wherever you turn , there is another cluster of tree and another sculpture , and it seems a if you will never come to the end of it . We saw a small white entrance to a boxy structure . I assumed it would be filled with the kind of heavy abstract modern sculpture that I don & rsquo ; t have patience for . But we walked in anyway . & nbsp ; It wa a small white marble room , ringed with bench . There wa a square opening at the top , and when I looked up at it , I wa blinded by the glare of the sun high in the sky . Oren walked across the empty space , sat down on the bench , and tilted his head back . I followed and sat down next to him a he put his foot on the bench and stretched out his long leg . I glanced around to see if there wa a sign forbidding this & ndash ; we had been kicked out of so many other spot around the museum before . But there wa nothing.I followed his gaze upward and saw that from the side we were on , the square framed a perfectly blue piece of sky , dotted with white wisp . This description doesn & rsquo ; t do justice to the purity of the image . It wa a brilliant exhibit , and there wa no way you could look at it without being entranced by the beauty of the sky . I glanced at Oren lying there , so sweet and relaxed , and I stretched out myself , my head next to his , looking into that patch of blue & ndash ; and we drifted off to sleep . & nbsp ; We were suddenly awakened by a large and stern guard . I sat up instantly , feeling startled but unusually rested . The problem wasn & rsquo ; t that we had our leg on the bench ; it wa that the museum wa closing . & nbsp ; Oren understood and wa ready to leave . & nbsp ; We walked slowly along the gravel path with the other straggler . & nbsp ; As I looked at Oren walking alongside the reflecting pool just outside the exit , the sun glittered on the water and I saw that I had not lost him & ndash ; and that I would never lose him . & nbsp ; 
title: ‘ dy irae ’ - a short story

Body Text: Defense Minister Yoav Gallant voted against his party , coalition , and the revival of an old haredi draft bill late Monday night , which wa approved by the majority of the Knesset despite his rebellion.Gallant wa applauded but immediately left the Knesset chamber after his vote , which led to a final tally of 63-57 to implement the Rule of Continuity procedure for the January 2022 security service law amendment to integrate yeshiva students.Otzma Yehudit MK Almog Cohen , who had retreated from threat that he would not vote with the coalition , shook Gallant & rsquo ; s hand and gave him a look of sympathy a the minister departed.Cohen & rsquo ; s vote in favor of the continuance of the bill came a opposition MKs and leader had urged coalition member to follow Gallant & rsquo ; s lead.In accordance with the procedure , which allows for the advancement of a bill that had been previously been approved in plenum reading , but abandoned by the Knesset & rsquo ; s dissolution , the legislative remnant from the previous Israeli government will be transferred to the Foreign Affairs and Security Committee for preparation for further plenum readings.Opposition leader Yair Lapid slammed the vote that had dragged on into the late hour of the night a a one of the most & ldquo ; despicable & rdquo ; moment of the Knesset & ndash ; it had allegedly failed to stand by it value , in favor of politics . & ldquo ; The biggest sin is this government that dare to speak on behalf of [ IDF ] fighter , & rdquo ; said Lapid . & ldquo ; Today the IDF announced that it need 15 battalion . Where are we going to get them if this government encourages order refusal and draft dodging ? At least don & rsquo ; t talk about your commitment to the fighter and then come here and pas law on order refusal and draft dodging . Today the Knesset stand before more than 500 soldier who were killed , in front all the people who did 180 day of reserve duty & ndash ; and the coalition will say we don & rsquo ; t care about you , you don & rsquo ; t interest u . & rdquo ; Ultra-Orthodox draft evasionYisrael Beytenu leader Avigdor Liberman attacked the refusal by ultra-Orthodox leadership to embrace military service . & ldquo ; I have never understood why a Jew is not allowed to be a combat soldier . Where doe this appear in the source ? I have found no trace of military service being contrary to Judaism . All the great Jewish leader were all warrior , & rdquo ; said Liberman . & ldquo ; You do not care at all about the Torah , there is nothing Jewish about this . All this to me is how this draft dodging is anti-Jewish and anti-Zionist . We lost a full brigade & ndash ; killed , injured . The security situation requires an increase in the manpower of the IDF . Evasion of everything , military or civilian service & ndash ; this is the most anti-Jewish thing . & rdquo ; Security Committee Chairman MK Yuli Edelstein said that a Israel faced complex challenge , it wa part of the political leadership & rsquo ; s job to provide an accurate response to the security need of the nation.This is a historical turning point for the people of Israel . It is necessary and we have no other choice . We all need a big , efficient and strong IDF and a big , efficient and strong IDF need u all , & rdquo ; said Edelstein . & ldquo ; We will do this in a clean , matter-of-fact manner and with the full cooperation of all actor . & rdquo ; The security service law amendment to integrate yeshiva student would raise the age of exemption to 22 after two year , and again to 23 a year later . Ultra-orthodox youth would be offered alternative enlistment route with the national emergency and rescue service , or a shortened three month or three week service . This would circumvent combat role , which require several more month of training for qualification.The bill also introduced escalating consequence for religious school that did not comply with enlistment quota and regulation , with a 20 % decrease in government funding that would grow with consecutive year of violations.The law went through first reading during Lapid & rsquo ; s tenure in a shared administration with then-alternate prime minister Naftali Bennett , but opposition member argued that the October 7 massacre had changed the Israeli paradigm and the legislation wa obsolete.Coalition member also changed their position on the legislation , with MKs like Degel HaTorah leader Moshe Gafni arguing in the Budget Committee on Sunday that the opposition only sought to topple the government after the withdrawal of the National Unity party from the wartime emergency government and the coalition faced a March High Court interim order over military exemption for ultra-orthodox men in the wake of the April legislation deadline and a July 2023 draft law expiration . & nbsp ;

Body Text: A group of Israeli illustrator created a virtual exhibit and webinar in memory of the child lost in both Gaza and Israel during Israel 's war against Hamas . The exhibit and webinar were initially created in 2021 after Operation Guardian of the Walls . & nbsp ; The gallery wa initiated by the Parents Circle-Families Forum ( PCFF ) and is hosted through the American Friends of the Parents Circle , which work to educate the American public about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict . & nbsp ; The exhibit is intended to draw focus on the child living through war and to commemorate the innocent who lost their lives.Remembering the child amid the Israel-Hamas war & nbsp ; The illustration used in the film were taken from the 2021 exhibit , in memory of 68 Israeli and Palestinian child who lost their life in the war that year . & nbsp ; `` Every illustration is in memory of a different child , `` said Yuval Rahamim , co-CEO of the PCFF.The video created is not intended to take a stance on the war , such a a ceasefire or hostage release . Instead , it is intended to shed light on the complexity of the situation and to remind people , from all side , of the innocent child who are drawn into the conflict against their will . & nbsp ; Driven to extreme '' In wartime , we are driven to extreme . We view thing a either black or white , but when doing so , we may easily forget to hold onto humanity , `` said Rahamim . `` Children remind u of our duty to remain humane because they are innocent . They are victim of war . We must ask ourselves if we should be justifying act that are harming child for the sake of war . `` The video exhibit wa created to mark International Children 's Day on November 20.Video for International Children 's Day by the Israeli Palestinian Bereaved Families for Peace ( CREDIT : Parents Circle-Families Forum ) . It express the thought of both Palestinian and Israeli child who were participant in the 2023 joint PCFF summer camp that aim to bring the two group together . & nbsp ; `` The artwork [ made by adult artist ] & nbsp ; illustrate the impact of the war on the young soul , `` said Robi Damelin , spokesperson and director of international relation for the PCFF . `` This is the call to save all child and to spare them from the horror of the war , `` Damelin concluded .

Body Text: Gaza 's Health Ministry accused Israel on Thursday of delaying the entry of several X-ray machine needed to treat patient in the blockaded Palestinian territory.The ministry , run by the Gaza Strip 's ruling terrorist group Hamas , said request in the past 14 month for eight different type of X-ray machine and spare part to repair existing equipment had been rejected or delayed.Dozens of other X-ray machine were allowed into the impoverished Strip during the same period.Israel , which together with Egypt maintains a blockade around Gaza citing security concern , say it is worried about militant group commandeering such machine for military purposes.Palestinian Health Ministry director Medhat Abbas said the equipment wa funded by international relief and medical institution on behalf of hospital in Gaza . `` Holding back the entry of that equipment caused a delay in providing medical service to thousand of patient , `` Abbas told Reuters.Conflicting accountsResponding to his remark , Israel 's military-run Coordinator of Government Activities in the Territories ( COGAT ) & nbsp ; accused Hamas and other militant group of `` systematically and cynically taking advantage of humanitarian and civilian shipment of equipment and good for terrorist purpose . `` Requests for such equipment , COGAT told Reuters , are examined on a case-by-case basis.Abbas said Israeli assertion about the medical equipment having dual us were a lie.At Gaza City 's Shifa hospital , Nalat Zeino , 51 , said she had been waiting 45 day to have an X-ray done for her kidney . Doctors blamed the delay on the withholding of equipment . `` As if the pain I am feeling wa n't enough - waiting ha been another form of torture , `` the mother of four told Reuters outside the X-ray unit.Hamas , deemed a terrorist group by Israel and much of the West , took control of Gaza in 2006 , a year after Israel withdrew soldier and settlers.The ensuing blockade limiting the number of good crossing in and out ha crippled Gaza 's economy and health care system , which suffers from a chronic shortage of hospital bed and medical equipment .
