Body Text: & nbsp ; Former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu oversaw some of the most virulent instance of diplomatic warfare against Israel since the & ldquo ; Zionism equal racism & rdquo ; battle at the United Nations in the last century . & nbsp ; The Israeli-Palestinian and the larger Israeli-Arab conflict have long fueled attempt to turn the Jewish state into a pariah nation . & nbsp ; The stake were raised , however , because of the 2012 vote in the UN General Assembly that upgraded the status of the Palestinians to that of a non-member state . The Palestinian Authority & rsquo ; s newfound status a a de facto UN state gave it a more expansive toolbox by which to pursue Israel and force it to execute a civilian and military withdrawal to the pre-1967 line . & nbsp ; At issue , however , wa not just Israel & rsquo ; s hold on the West Bank , east Jerusalem and the Golan Heights . The initiative also took aim at Israel & rsquo ; s Jewish identity , Jewish tie to it holy site , and it right to self-defense . & nbsp ; Netanyahu offset some of that impact by linking some of the attack with antisemitism and anti-Israel bias . He wa more effective than past premier in enlisting American support and in securing a circle of European , African and Asian ally . Issues of Palestinian incitement and support for terror also gained prominence during his tenure . & nbsp ; Here is a list of 12 victory and loss during his 12-year prime ministerial reign that began in March 2009 and ended this week . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Losses & nbsp ; 1 ) ICC open war crime probe against Israel & nbsp ; Israelis were not in danger of war crime suit at the ICC when Netanyahu entered office . & nbsp ; The accession of the PA to the Rome Statute in 2015 changed that , and allowed the PA to request a war crime probe into Israeli action in the West Bank , Gaza and east Jerusalem . & nbsp ; The ICC ruled this year that it had jurisdiction to hear war crime case connected with that territory , and ha opened a probe . While it is examining the possibility of war crime case against Israelis and Palestinians , it is presumed that the focus will be on potential Israeli war crime . & nbsp ; Should the ICC conclude that a probe could be conducted , then individual Israelis , most likely it leader , could find themselves facing war crime charge . & nbsp ; 2 ) UNHRC creates permanent probe against Israel & nbsp ; The UNHRC during Netanyahu & rsquo ; s tenure launched at least six fact-finding mission against Israel in an attempt to prove it had committed and continued to commit war crime and serious human right violation . & nbsp ; The most infamous wa the initial probe headed by and named for South African jurist Richard Goldstone . & nbsp ; The Goldstone mission and two others explored potential Israeli war crime during the three Gaza war . One of the fact-finding mission probed alleged human right abuse connected to West Bank settlement . The mission on the Hamas-led March of Return led to the creation of a database of IDF soldier who potentially executed war crime against the Palestinian participant . & nbsp ; This year the UNHRC created a permanent probe into potential Israeli human right abuse , both within sovereign Israel and in the West Bank and Gaza , starting from April 13 , 2021 . Israel is the only country under permanent investigation for war crime . & nbsp ; Separately it published a blacklist of company doing business with Israeli entity located over the pre-1967 line . It & rsquo ; s the only country against whom such a blacklist ha been published . & nbsp ; In 2018 it also began issuing an annual call for an arm embargo against Israel . & nbsp ; 3 ) UNESCO register Tomb of the Patriarchs to Palestine & nbsp ; UNESCO became the first UN body to recognize Palestine a a state , in 2011 . PA membership at UNESCO allowed the registration of three site onto it World Heritage List : the Church of the Nativity , the Battir terrace and the Tomb of the Patriarchs . The registration focused primarily on the period when the Tomb wa under Mamluk control in 1250 and through the Ottoman Empire period , rather than on the ancient and Biblical period when it wa in Jewish hand . & nbsp ; Israel withdrew from UNESCO in 2018 to protest it anti-Israel bias , after halting it annual payment to the organization in 2011 and losing it voting right two year later . & nbsp ; 4 ) EU product labeling & nbsp ; The European Union published guideline in 2015 on how to place consumer label on product from east Jerusalem , the West Bank and Gaza , to clarify that they were not produced in Israel . & nbsp ; The guideline were voluntary . Four year later , however , the EU Court of Justice ruled that all Israeli product produced over the pre-1967 line must be marked with such consumer label . & nbsp ; 5 ) UN launch apartheid investigation & nbsp ; & nbsp ; The UN Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination this year ceded to a request by the Palestinian Authority to investigate whether Israel had committed act of apartheid . It would mark the first such UN investigation into such a charge based on the definition set out in the Rome Statute . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Victories & nbsp ; 1 ) Abraham Accords put a damper on BDS & nbsp ; The Abraham Accords , which normalized tie between Israel and four Arab country , took some of the wind out of the sail of the Boycott , Divestment and Sanctions movement . The willingness of Arab country to do business with Israel made it more difficult for BDS to argue that other country should boycott it . & nbsp ; 2 ) ICC Mavi Marmara war crime probe nixed & nbsp ; The International Criminal Court chief prosecutor rejected a request to probe Israel for war crime relating to the IDF raid in 2010 against the Gaza-bound flotilla ship Mavi Marmara . The IDF forcibly boarded the ship a it attempted to break Israel & rsquo ; s maritime blockade of Gaza . During the raid , 10 Turkish activist aboard the ship were killed . & nbsp ; 3 ) Only one UNSC anti-Israel resolution passed & nbsp ; The UN Security Council condemned Israel only once during Netanyahu & rsquo ; s tenure , which is a record in the institution & rsquo ; s treatment of Israel . It wa the direct result of Netanyahu & rsquo ; s ability to secure opposition to such resolution from former US president Barack Obama and Donald Trump . The only exception wa in 2016 , in the final week of the Obama administration , when the UNSC approved Resolution 2334 that condemned Israeli settlement activity and rejected Israeli sovereignty over any part of east Jerusalem , including the Western Wall . & nbsp ; 4 ) Partial victory on the Jerusalem resolution & nbsp ; The PA pushed for the UN to ignore Jewish tie to the Temple Mount by referencing that site and the Western Wall solely by their Muslim name of Al-Haram Al-Sharif and the Buraq Plaza . With the support of Arab state , it began to insert Muslim-only reference in resolution on Jerusalem passed by the UNESCO Executive Board at each of it bi-annual meeting . Those text also disavowed Jewish sovereignty over Jerusalem . & nbsp ; The Jerusalem resolution were neutralized at UNESCO through a compromise in which the controversial element of the text were placed in an annex . The PA ha been more successful with a similar drive at the General Assembly , where it ha an automatic majority of support . & nbsp ; 5 ) Agenda Item 7 boycott & nbsp ; Netanyahu made no headway in swaying the UN Human Rights Council to rescind it mandate that the 47-member body discusses alleged Israeli human right abuse against the Palestinians at every one of it session under Agenda Item 7 . & nbsp ; But it successfully swayed European country that the existence of such a mandate against only one country wa an example of anti-Israel bias . As a result , most of the European country boycott Agenda Item 7 session , which take place three time a year . & nbsp ; 6 ) Spotlight on Pay-for-Slay & nbsp ; Netanyahu made significant inroad in persuading European and Western country , particularly the United States , to take the Palestinian Authority to task for providing monthly stipend to Palestinian terrorist and their relative . Israel ha dubbed the practice & ldquo ; pay-for-slay . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The US took a strong stand on the issue , with Congress passing the Taylor Force Act that prohibits direct economic assistance to the PA until it halt the payment . & nbsp ; 7 ) Condemnation of UNRWA incitement & nbsp ; Netanyahu also succeeded in generating awareness of UNRWA & rsquo ; s failure to ensure that it textbook did not include inciting material against Jews and Israel . & nbsp ; The Biden administration ha promised to link future funding to UNRWA to it adherence to a zero-tolerance policy for material that promotes hate and antisemitism against Jews and Israel . & nbsp ; The EU Parliament this year also condemned any use by UNRWA of such material .
title: netanyahu ’ s diplomatic warfare with the palestinian : 12 high and low

Body Text: Israel and US official have discussed expelling thousand of lower-level Hamas terrorist from the Gaza Strip a a possible option to shorten the war between Israel and Hamas , The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday.The proposal rose a part of discussion concerning how Gaza will be run when the war end and how to prevent a resurgence of Hamas or similar groups.One proposal which ha been developed by the IDF 's think tank which wa shown to The Wall Street Journal would involve the creation of `` Hamas-free safe zone `` that would be ruled by a new Gaza-based authority backed by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.The option to expel Hamas terrorist and their family from the Strip aim to provide the terrorist with an exit strategy and make it easier to rebuild Gaza after the war.The proposal seemingly would not include higher-up Hamas leader such a Yahya Sinwar or Mohammed Deif . Israeli official have said that the two , and other Hamas leader located both in the Gaza Strip and abroad , are `` dead men walking . `` The proposal wa compared to the 1982 deal which had then Palestinian Liberation Organization head Yasser Arafat and about 11,000 Palestinian terrorist leave Lebanon for Tunisia after a two-month siege of Beirut.Unclear if Hamas terrorist would accept option to leave GazaA senior Israeli official told The Wall Street Journal that it is not clear that Hamas terrorist would accept the option to leave Gaza if it wa offered . & ldquo ; I don & rsquo ; t see them a rational a the PLO wa , & rdquo ; said the official . & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s a more religious , jihadistic organization connected to the idea of Iran . & rdquo ; The official added that at the moment there is no `` practical discussion `` about expelling Hamas terrorist , although that option may become available if there is no other choice.Another proposal being examined by the IDF is the creation of a `` Gaza Restoration Authority `` backed by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates that would be tasked with rebuilding a Hamas-free Gaza .

Body Text: The retreat of the United States from the world stage could doom the Abraham Accords , former US ambassador to Israel David Friedman told The Jerusalem Post Annual Conference & nbsp ; on Tuesday , in a warning to the Biden administration . & ldquo ; This won & rsquo ; t work if America retreat from the world stage and fails to project it value in the region , & rdquo ; said Friedman a he spoke with the paper & rsquo ; s senior contributing editor and diplomatic correspondent Lahav Harkov at Jerusalem & rsquo ; s Museum of Tolerance.He spoke of the deal brokered by the former Trump administration under whose rubric & nbsp ; Israel normalized tie with four Arab country : the United Arab Emirates , Bahrain , Morocco and Sudan.Watch the Jerusalem Post 10th Annual Conference video & gt ; & gt ; As a Trump administration envoy in the region , Friedman wa a part of the process from it infancy . On Monday , he launched the Friedman Center for Peace throughStrength to help continue to advance the accord . He ha just completed a documentary on the process and is authoring a book on the initiative.The accord , he said , were possible because they were backed by a strong US that guided and encourages tie between Arab nation and Israel , offering political , economic and security support.Friedman never mentioned the US President Joe Biden & rsquo ; s withdrawal of US force from Afghanistan , but he appeared to reference it when he said that the Biden administration need to convince Arab state that it can be depended on a a strong regional ally.Countries that signed the Abraham Accords and those that could join the deal are asking , & ldquo ; Is America going to be a reliable partner going into the future ? All these country depend on a strong America , & rdquo ; Friedman said.He also spoke to the Biden administration & rsquo ; s attempt to revive the 2015 Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action . The plan , otherwise known a the Iran nuclear deal , wasdesigned to limit Iran & rsquo ; s nuclear capacity and wa signed between Tehran and six world powers.The former Trump administration exited the deal and the Biden administration ha sought to revive it , but third-party talk held in Vienna have stalled.In the interim , Iran ha advanced toward the production of a nuclear weapon , a move that diplomat and pundit have speculated could soon render the idea of reviving the JCPOA irrelevant.Friedman said the Biden administration had to be on only one of two path ; it could halt Iran & rsquo ; s nuclear program through maximum sanction and covert action , or it could engage in talk with regard to a new deal that would replace the JCPOA.But this gray area , in which there wa an absence of diplomacy and maximum pressure , wa not applied and wa unsustainable . He also cautioned the Biden administration against lifting sanction just for the option of continuing talk to revive the 2015 Iran deal.It doe not make sense , he said , & ldquo ; to let up on sanction , reduce the pressure and beg for a diplomatic outcome . & rdquo ; Watch the Jerusalem Post 10th Annual Conference video & gt ; & gt ;

The official said they were seeking to obtain the vaccine from various company , with the help of the World Health Organization . & nbsp ; Last week , however , a senior PA official told & nbsp ; The Jerusalem Post & nbsp ; & nbsp ; that the Palestinians were examining the possibility of asking Israel for vaccine . & nbsp ; But a PLO official said last weekend that they have not asked Israel for the vaccine . & nbsp ; The ministry denied a report by Kan , the Israeli Broadcasting Corporation , which said that Israel had secretly & nbsp ; sent dozen of dos & nbsp ; of vaccine to the Palestinians . The ministry said that Israeli & ldquo ; non-governmental & rdquo ; organization had offered to send 20 dos of vaccine to the Palestinians a an & ldquo ; experiment . & rdquo ; The offer wa turned down , the ministry added , without elaborating . & nbsp ; Meanwhile , the PA Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement that Israel , a an & ldquo ; occupying power , & rdquo ; wa obliged to provide vaccine to the Palestinians . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Expatriates affirms the duty of Israel , the occupying power , to provide vaccine against the coronavirus to the Palestinian people , at a time when it provides these vaccine to it own citizen , & rdquo ; the statement read . & nbsp ; It warned that if Israel ignores it & ldquo ; duty , & rdquo ; this would be regarded a & ldquo ; racial discrimination against the Palestinian people and a denial of their right to healthcare . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The ministry claimed that Israel wa & ldquo ; trying to absolve itself of it duty a an occupying power , and fully blame the Palestinian government . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Noting that the PA wa making an effort to secure vaccine from various source , the ministry said that this doe not & ldquo ; exempt Israel from it responsibility towards the Palestinian people in providing them with vaccine & rdquo ; in accordance with international law and convention .

Body Text: Daoud Zubeidi , the brother of Palestinian prisoner Zakaria Zubeidi who temporarily escaped from Gilboa Prison last year , died on Sunday from wound sustained during armed clash with Israeli force in Burkin on Friday.He wa shot in the abdomen after force from the YAMAM counterterrorism unit , Border Police and Sayeret Golani entered the village near Jenin to arrest wanted Palestinian Islamic Jihad ( PIJ ) member Mahmoud Al-Debai on Friday morning.During the operation , which lasted close to four hour , clash with gunman injured 13 Palestinians , including two seriously and five moderately.One of the seriously wounded Palestinian gunman wa identified a Zubeidi . He wa transferred to the Ibn Sina hospital in Jenin for medical care and then to Rambam Medical Center in Haifa , following a request from the Palestinians when his condition deteriorated.The hospital confirmed his death . Israel is reportedly withholding his body . & nbsp ; Following attack in which Palestinians are killed by Israeli security force , their body are regularly taken to Israel . Though body are sometimes retired to their family at a later date to be buried , Israel ha also withheld body in order to be used a part of future negotiation and a a deterrent against terror attack . & nbsp ; The Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigades in Jenin had warned on Saturday that & ldquo ; any harm to the life of the wounded Daoud Al-Zubeidi will open the fire of hell in the face of the Zionist enemy and herd of criminal settler . & rdquo ; Zubeidi & rsquo ; s brother Zakaria escaped from Gilboa Prison along with three other security prisoner in September . He wa once considered a & ldquo ; symbol of the Intifada , & rdquo ; but renounced militancy over a decade ago and wa awarded clemency by Israel after he agreed to give up arms.He had been arrested by the Shin Bet ( Israel Security Agency ) in 2019 following intelligence that he wa planning a serious attack in the West Bank and for two shooting attack against Israeli bus in the West Bank near Beit El and Psagot.During the clash in which Zubeidi wa injured , YAMAM counterterrorism officer Sgt . - Maj . Noam Raz wa shot and critically wounded . He wa evacuated to Rambam hospital by helicopter where he succumbed to his wounds.A senior IDF officer told journalist that said he wa shot in the back a force were leaving the village under fire . & ldquo ; I & rsquo ; ve been through everything over the past 20 year , but there were thousand of bullet fired towards u and our vehicle this morning , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; It wa indescribable . & rdquo ; Raz wa buried on Sunday morning on Mount Herzl with hundred of mourner in attendance.Security force have been on high alert across the country a Israeli Arabs and Palestinians mark Nakba Day & ndash ; the 74th anniversary of what the Arab world refer to a & ldquo ; the catastrophe & rdquo ; following the founding in 1948 of the State of Israel.Tensions are already high following a spate of deadly terrorist attack that have killed 19 people in Israel .
title: brother of palestinian security prisoner injured in jenin clash succumbs to wound

Body Text: & lsquo ; I wanted to express the very bizarre and extreme reality of these trip , what it & rsquo ; s really like to be there at that age , & rdquo ; said Asaf Saban , the writer/director of Delegation , a new feature film that opened on Thursday and look at teen on a high-school class trip to Poland , where they visit death camp & ndash ; a quintessentially Israeli rite of passage.Saban knew that making a dramatic film about the reality of such trip , rather than the ideal , would not be easy . But he ha created a thoughtful , compelling film , well-written and well acted , that illuminates the complexity of one of these trip in the & rsquo ; 90 . & nbsp ; It neither sentimentalizes the character & rsquo ; emotion nor condemns the teen for just being teen . He did that through creating several quirky , relatable character , among them Frisch ( Yoav Bavly , ) a sensitive guy , who ha a crush on Nitzan ( Naomi Harari , ) an ostensibly relaxed , confident girl.But Nitzan is more troubled than she seems , and the trip brings out strange emotion in her , which cause her to take an action on one of the concentration camp tour that is very human but obviously wrong . Ido ( Leib Levin ) is a brash extrovert focused on usual teen concern like girl and drinking , and doesn & rsquo ; t suddenly become an altruist in Poland.Delegation spotlight how there is some manipulation built into these trip , a the teen have group discussion in which they are encouraged to show emotion , the more intense the better . The difficulty created by this are illustrated by the character of Yosef ( Ezra Dagan , in a heartrending performance , ) and Frisch & rsquo ; s grandfather . He is a survivor who accompanies the class . & nbsp ; As the grandfather begin telling his personal story to the group , he speaks charmingly and engagingly about his life and experience a a child before his family wa deported . But it & rsquo ; s rambling , contains a great deal of personal detail , and isn & rsquo ; t what the group leader ( Alma Dishy ) want to hear . She is portrayed not a a villain but a a cog in a system designed to elicit a particular set of reaction : tear at the horror and pride in the State of Israel . & nbsp ; In one of the film & rsquo ; s most moving scene , she take the survivor aside and he admits that he know he hasn & rsquo ; t been saying what the student need to hear . & ldquo ; I get it . You want me to get to the action more quickly , & rdquo ; he say . As the film go on , he is overwhelmed by emotion and can & rsquo ; t & ldquo ; get to the action . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Prize winningIt 's not surprising that Saban & rsquo ; s complex , multi-layered script won the Anat Pirchi Best Screenplay Award at the Jerusalem Film Festival last year , or that his cast took the Best Ensemble Award there . And it & rsquo ; s particularly heartening that the film received recognition in Poland , where it won a special award at the Warsaw Film Festival . & nbsp ; The film wa inspired by Saban & rsquo ; s own experience on such a trip year ago . & ldquo ; It wa the first time I wa abroad without my parent . That & rsquo ; s an important detail , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; There is something festive about being abroad . I remember the excitement and my wish , and I think this is characteristic of young people that age , regardless , whether they are Israeli or not , whether it is a Holocaust trip or not , to experience something great . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The reality for me is that I remember the trip in fragment , and I remember feeling that I didn & rsquo ; t respond in the way I wa meant to . I don & rsquo ; t remember much about the historical site . I have many meaningless memory of small moment . I think this is what characterizes u a human being , the gap between the expectation and what we really take away from the experience . & rdquo ; He said he wasn & rsquo ; t interested in debating whether the trip are worthwhile or questioning the motivation of the student who take them . & ldquo ; Before you place a lot of political and sociological interpretation on them , the reality of these trip is that they are a very extreme and weird experience . & ldquo ; As weird a they are , these trip are the ultimate normative experience for Israeli teen . It & rsquo ; s a dissonance that is fascinating for me , because it say a lot . I wanted to look at it and give more weight to the subtext . People go into this territory with a lot of expectation and preconceived opinion that are all expressed with an exclamation point . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; For me , it wa very important to speak quietly , with sensitivity and to direct the viewer & rsquo ; s glance to the nuance and ask question , and not necessarily give answer . I wanted to replace the exclamation point with question mark . & rdquo ; He always kept in mind the importance of the reality of the Holocaust and to treat it with respect , not to exploit it for drama . & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s something that I a a filmmaker am very sensitive to , & rdquo ; he said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s an ethical question . How do you create a drama in such place [ where the Holocaust took place ] ? You can manipulate the viewer emotionally , by using imagery and using the Holocaust a a drama in the background to elicit emotion , in way that are too easy . And the dilemma I felt a a filmmaker mirror what the student go through there . & rdquo ; Saban made a point of creating & ldquo ; very typical character , who are dealing with small , ordinary problem . My challenge wa to shift the attention to the detail and dynamic among these character in the present , when in the background you have the greatest drama , not just in Jewish history , but in the history of humanity . & rdquo ; Speaking about the character of the grandfather who is not encouraged to express his story fully and in depth , he said , & ldquo ; I think he want to succeed . He want to perform his role in the way that is expected of him . He ha the will to do it , but not the ability . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Saban said that the toughest task for him wa to put aside his perspective a an adult and recapture the feeling of what it wa like to be in Poland and at the death camp at age 17 . & nbsp ; But with Yosef , he allowed himself to look at the experience with the eye of a more mature person . & ldquo ; There is a similarity between how I wanted to tell the story of the student in the film and how Yosef want to tell his story . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; When a sheepish Yosef admits to the teacher that he know he isn & rsquo ; t getting to & ldquo ; the action & rdquo ; & ndash ; the horror & ndash ; quickly enough and will try to do better , that sentence express something that Saban wa also grappling with . & ldquo ; I & rsquo ; m also saying to the viewer , you come to this with expectation , but maybe you won & rsquo ; t get the action in the place you expect , at the volume that you & rsquo ; re expecting to hear . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; With the character of Yosef , he is the storyteller , but he isn & rsquo ; t the storyteller you expect . The fact that he fails and can & rsquo ; t finish his task in the way that is expected of him & ndash ; that is the deepest and truest proof of his authenticity , of the authenticity of his experience and his feeling . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I think that & rsquo ; s life . People like Anne Frank and Etty Hillesum succeeded in expressing their humanity in the context of their personal experience , and that & rsquo ; s what creates the drama of their story . That & rsquo ; s why you remember them . & rdquo ;
title: israeli director tackle film about a class trip to poland

Body Text: ( JTA ) - The musician Jonny Greenwood wa pushing back on critic who said he should abandon a plan to tour with an Israeli collaborator because of the Israel-Hamas war.Greenwood and Dudu Tassa , an Israeli rock star from a prominent Mizrahi musical family , were scheduled to perform together on the European festival circuit this summer , a year after they released a joint record that featured singer from across the Middle East . Some of the date were rescheduled after the pair canceled show in the immediate wake of Hamas & rsquo ; October 7 attack on Israel.The performance are drawing criticism amid widespread anti-Israel sentiment in the art and in Europe , and Greenwood ha faced call to cancel.In a statement posted to social medium on Tuesday , he said he would do no such thing - and said that call to silence Israeli artist are counterproductive . & ldquo ; Others choose to believe this kind of project is unjustifiable and are urging the silence of this - or any - artistic effort made by Israeli Jews , & rdquo ; Greenwood wrote . & ldquo ; But I can & rsquo ; t join that call : The silencing of Israeli film makers/musicians/dancers when their work tour abroad - especially when it & rsquo ; s at the urging of their fellow western filmmakers/musicians/artists - feel unprogressive to me , not least because these people that are invariably the most progressive member of any society . & rdquo ; Greenwood & rsquo ; s relationship to Israel is long . He is married to Israeli visual artist Sharona Katan , who ha said the family identifies a Jewish , and recorded guitar on album by Tassa and fellow Israeli Shye Ben Tzur before making the album with Tassa . Both artist opened for Radiohead on some tour date in 2017.Music unites against boycottsTassa is the grandson of Daoud Al-Kuwaity , one of the most famous Iraqi composer of the 20th century who emigrated to Israel in 1951 . In his statement , Greenwood note that the song of Al-Kuwaity and his brother Saleh & ldquo ; are still staple of Arab-wide radio station - though sadly their heritage a Jews is never mentioned . & rdquo ; Radiohead , which won several Grammy Awards and sold million of record since the 1990s , have been the target of the boycott , divestment and sanction movement against Israel , especially in the lead-up to their 2017 concert in Tel Aviv . In response , lead singer Thom Yorke called BDS protester & ldquo ; offensive & rdquo ; and & ldquo ; patronizing , & rdquo ; adding , & ldquo ; The person who know most about these thing is Jonny . & rdquo ; In an Instagram post this week , Tassa called Greenwood & ldquo ; an amazing person who is always willing to take risk for peace and justice & rdquo ; and a dear friend . & ldquo ; Our desire and choice a musician from different background ( he is an English rocker and I am a Jewish-Israeli who absorbed root of Arab culture ) have always been and will continue to be , to strive to understand the & lsquo ; other , & rsquo ; to get to know him and to introduce him to u through the language of music - completely the opposite of fostering a one-sided discourse of boycott and threat , & rdquo ; Tassa wrote . & ldquo ; The truth is that the boycotters and condemners do not promote anything - just more hatred , & rdquo ; he added . & ldquo ; I hope and wish that together our performance will unite and connect people from different background and be part of a small step towards a better future . & rdquo ; Greenwood did not explicitly mention the war , the Palestinians or Gaza in his statement , angering some of his critic . But he acknowledged that his planned performance with Tassa come at a difficult time . & ldquo ; No art is a & lsquo ; important & rsquo ; a stopping all the death and suffering around u . How can it be ? But doing nothing seems a worse option , & rdquo ; he wrote . & ldquo ; And silencing Israeli artist for being born Jewish in Israel doesn & rsquo ; t seem like any way to reach an understanding between the two side of this apparently endless conflict . & rdquo ;
title: radiohead ’ s jonny greenwood reject call to cancel tour with israeli musician dudu tassa

Body Text: Palestinian detainee held in Israeli prison under administrative detention have decided to go on an & ldquo ; open-ended & rdquo ; hunger strike in the next few day , a committee representing the inmate announced over the weekend.The committee called on the detainee who are planning to join the hunger strike to start & ldquo ; writing their will . & rdquo ; Palestinian source say more than 1,000 detainee are currently being held in Israeli prison under administrative detention , a procedure that allows the security force to hold suspect on the basis of classified information without charging them or bringing them to trial.Most of the administrative detainee are former security prisoner who spent time in Israeli prison for security-related offense and terrorism , the source noted . & nbsp ; Previous hunger strike & nbsp ; Last year , dozen of administrative detainee went on a 19-day hunger strike in protest of the policy of administrative detention . It did not set a date for the start of the hunger strike . & nbsp ; In response to the death of Adnan , 44 , Palestinian terror group in the Gaza Strip last week fired more than 100 rocket at Israel before an unofficial ceasefire wa announced with the help of Egypt , Qatar and the United Nations . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We have become certain beyond doubt that the occupation and the Shin Bet ( Israel & rsquo ; s Internal Security Agency ) can & rsquo ; t provide positive result on the level of the administrative detention file unless they come under real pressure , & rdquo ; the committee said.It pointed out that effort to solve the issue of administrative detention began two year ago with hunger strike and boycott of Israeli courts.According to the committee , the administrative detainee & rsquo ; decision to declare a hunger strike wa taken after & ldquo ; round-the-clock consultation and coordination & rdquo ; with representative of the Palestinian faction in the West Bank and Gaza Strip . & ldquo ; We are facing a historic moment and we must take advantage of it , & rdquo ; the committee said.A leader of the Palestinian security prisoner held in Israeli jail wa quoted on Saturday a saying that a large number of inmate belonging to Hamas and other Palestinian faction would take part in the hunger strike.The unnamed leader , who wa quoted by the Hamas-affiliated Palestine Information Center , said the detainee who are planning to take part in the hunger strike were on a & ldquo ; suicide & rdquo ; mission . & ldquo ; The decision to go on hunger strike wa taken after the martyrdom of Sheikh Khader Adnan , & rdquo ; he said.Zaher Jabareen , a member of the Hamas political bureau , said the Palestinians and their & ldquo ; Shlomo Karhi announced on Sunday the proposal of a new regulation that will protect the elderly from exploitation and fraud by blocking incoming call from abroad that are aimed at stealing money.This phenomenon ha already affected thousand of consumer and caused severe economic damage to many of them . This is what we did with surprise charge for call abroad , excessive fee on standing order , the failure to give pensioner discount at the postal bank , and also here in the issue of exploitation . `` Increase in attempted telephone fraud since start of warAccording to report by the Communications Ministry , since the start of the war , there ha been a sharp increase in telephone fraud attempt , mainly targeting the elderly population , especially among Russian-speaking immigrant . & nbsp ; These activity can target both commercial and public entity by utilizing their phone number a identifier , making call to subscriber appear on their phone screen a originating from legitimate sources.The impostor aim to steal personal and credit information from the victim or persuade them to make various financial transfer under false pretense . & nbsp ; Typically , this scheme unfolds when the impostor allege that the victim 's bank account or credit card have been compromised . They then insist that the victim withdraw their fund and transfer them , ostensibly to secure police account or coerce them into divulging password and sensitive information.Alongside the police , the Communications Ministry is working to prevent the display & nbsp ; of false number on cellular devices.Following an increase in scam attempt , which primarily affect the elderly population , and in continuation of prevention activity carried out by relevant authority , the Communications Ministry published on Sunday a draft amendment to regulation in which provision are considered to mitigate the phenomenon of impersonation of law enforcement agency and company using their phone number . & nbsp ; The draft regulation under consideration include a provision stating that an international service provider must block call originating from outside Israel if the caller 's number is an Israeli landline.Additionally , it stipulates that a mobile phone service provider should block call from outside the State of Israel if the caller 's number is a mobile phone , except for it roaming customers.Further , a service provider will not allow it subscriber to use number that are not allocated for their use.Following the necessary preparation period of several month , the change to this draft regulation are expected to take effect during the coming year to ensure comprehensive protection for the public .

Body Text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu & rsquo ; s decision to dissolve Israel & rsquo ; s war cabinet raise several question about the management of the war against Hamas from now on.The war cabinet , which wa also known a the & ldquo ; small cabinet , & rdquo ; wa authorized to make day-to-day decision regarding the war while bringing broader policy decision to the larger , statutory security cabinet.In response to a query by The Jerusalem Post , a spokesperson for the Prime Minister & rsquo ; s Office said that the security cabinet will now be convened at a higher frequency . In addition , Netanyahu will hold ad-hoc & ldquo ; security consultation & rdquo ; on specific matter when necessary.The spokesperson did not answer a number of follow-up question , including what the division of responsibility will be between the security cabinet and these & ldquo ; consultation . & rdquo ; Furthermore , the spokesperson did not address the statutory status of these consultation , such a whether they will be transcribed in an official protocol like the now-defunct war cabinet did . They also did not specify who would participate in these consultations.The deliberation will likely serve two purpose : The first will be to avoid having to convene the security cabinet over minor decision , and the second will be to keep sensitive information away from the far Right Ministers Itamar Ben-Gvir and Bezalel Smotrich.Both Ben-Gvir and Smotrich , who are both member of the security cabinet but were not appointed to the war cabinet , repeatedly criticized the latter since it founding for policy that they believed were not aggressive enough . In addition , many leak emerged from the security cabinet during the month of the war , with Ben-Gvir believed to be the source of many of these.Ben-Gvir , Smotrich 's threat were feltThis led the prime minister to avoid including them in certain decision or revealing specific information . For example , according to Ben-Gvir , Netanyahu refused to show him a draft of Israel & rsquo ; s latest proposal for a ceasefire and hostage deal with Hamas.Still , according to MKs Benny Gantz and Gadi Eisenkot of the National Unity Party , who , until recently , were member of the war cabinet , the presence of Ben-Gvir & rsquo ; s and Smotrich & rsquo ; s threat to leave the government over what they deemed were unacceptable concession to Hamas , wa felt tangibly in the room . Gantz and Eisenkot said that at one point , Netanyahu limited the mandate given to Israel & rsquo ; s negotiating team without updating them due to pressure from Smotrich.Both Ben-Gvir and Smotrich demanded to be part of the war cabinet once Gantz and Eisenkot left the government last week.However , instead of conceding to their request , Netanyahu opted to dissolve the war cabinet completely . Nevertheless , it is clear that Ben-Gvir and Smotrich will now enjoy even more influence over security decision given that the security cabinet will convene more frequently.In interview with foreign medium in recent month , Netanyahu repeatedly distanced himself from incendiary comment made by Ben-Gvir and Smotrich and member of their party , such a calling for a & ldquo ; voluntary emigration & rdquo ; of Gaza & rsquo ; s population or building Israeli settlement in the Gaza Strip.Indeed , the prime minister repeatedly argued that all minister were free to voice their opinion a they saw fit but that the decision and policy were decided on only in the war cabinet . With the war cabinet now gone , the prime minister will likely find it more difficult to make this argument.Perhaps more significantly , Israel made the same argument in the case made against it in both the International Court of Justice and the International Criminal Court at the Hague . Body Text: The High Court of Justice on Thursday night issued it sensational decision endorsing a universal IDF draft , including the ultra-Orthodox ( haredi ) population , bringing to a theoretical end week of squabbling and disagreements.From April 1 , although in reality deferring most enforcement of the ruling until August 9 , the decision largely accepted the recommendation of the Attorney-General & rsquo ; s Office on invoking a legal universal draft across Israel.As of Monday , some institution or class within institution will already have their fund frozen , but on a larger scale , the freeze won & rsquo ; t take effect until August 9.The High Court & rsquo ; s decision could also potentially destabilize Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu & rsquo ; s government if it two haredi party , United Torah Judaism and Shas , decide to exit the government.Shas chairman MK Aryeh Deri lambasted the decision in a written statement . & ldquo ; Shas will continue to fight for yeshiva student & rsquo ; right to persevere in Torah and will consider it next step , & rdquo ; Deri added.The Degel Hatorah faction in the United Torah Judaism party expressed outrage at the decision , warning that they would not let it pas without a response . & ldquo ; s decision should be applauded a it theoretically brings to some form of closure an issue that ha rankled Israeli society for many year . The landmark ruling reflects a principled stance towards ensuring that all citizen contribute to the defense of the nation , while also providing a transition period for adjustment to be made.High Court signal to Israel that no one is exempt from dutyIt sends a clear message that no individual or group should be exempt from their civic duty based on religious or cultural ground . By endorsing a universal draft , the court ha taken a bold step towards fostering a sense of unity and shared sacrifice among all sector of Israeli society , at a time when the country need it most . Demographically , the question of haredi enlistment will become even more urgent a the ultra-Orthodox become the dominant population in the country.While there are many more stop along the journey of universal enlistment in Israel & rsquo ; s military , the government , the judiciary , and those who are willing to serve , many of whom are religious themselves and Torah student , can not let themselves be held to ransom by one sector of society that refuse to contribute to the ongoing survival of the country.Israel , unlike many country around the world , desperately requires it military to survive . The country & rsquo ; s very existence depends upon it army , and the ongoing Israel-Hamas War prof how necessary it is.Netanyahu ha managed to survive in power despite a tumultuous period , beginning last year with continuous protest against the government 's planned judicial reform , an act that wa halted when Hamas terrorist crossed the border on October 7 . He ha since been dealing with the ongoing military operation in Gaza.It would be ironic if Bibi & rsquo ; s bedfellow in government , the ultra-Orthodox party , were to do what the judicial protest nor the war against Hamas have done and bring the government toppling.The court & rsquo ; s ruling should serve a a catalyst for meaningful dialogue and engagement on the issue of military service instead of pathetic threat of emigration and political discord . Body Text: Americans tend to view Israel more positively than the Palestinians in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict , though view toward both side have modestly become more positive in recent year , according to a recent Pew Research Center survey.A favorable opinion toward Israelis among the US public went from 64 % to 67 % between 2019 and 2022 . In 2019 , 41 % of Americans viewed the Israeli government under Benjamin Netanyahu favorably , and 51 % viewed it negatively.Favorable opinion of Palestinian government have jumped from 19 % in 2019 to 28 % in 2022 . However , the majority of Americans ( 63 % ) still hold unfavorable view toward the Palestinian government despite an improvement from a negative 71 % in 2019.Overall , just 18 % view both government favorably , compared with 29 % who view just the Israeli government favorably , 10 % just the Palestinian government , and 33 % who view both unfavorably.Demographic divideThe number change when accounting for age and political affiliation . Older Americans and those who lean toward the Republican Party tend to view Israelis more positively than younger Americans and those inclined towards the Democrats.Among the under 30 , 56 % view Israelis favorably compared with 78 % who are 65 and older.While 46 % aged 50 + view Palestinians favorably , 61 % under 30 do.Republicans seem to hold Israelis in much higher regard , both a people ( 78 % ) and a government ( 66 % ) than Palestinian people ( 37 % ) and government ( 18 % ) . Democrats , however , tend to incline slightly toward the Palestinians.Around 60 % view Israelis positively and 64 % view Palestinians positively . & nbsp ; On the Israeli and Palestinian government , the number are 34 % and 37 % , respectively.Close to half of all Democrats and Democrat-leaning independent view both Israelis and Palestinians positively.Solving the Israeli-Palestinian conflictWhile American view toward Israel and the Palestinians have warmed since 2019 , the best possible outcome to the conflict itself remains a stumbling block.While 35 % support a two-state solution backed by US diplomacy , 27 % back a one-state solution , though 16 % seem to prefer a government that consists of both Israelis and Palestinians , 10 % prefer one headed by an Israeli government , and 2 % say they want a Palestinian-headed government.Still , 37 % say they are unsure what they want , and 1 % have nothing to say.Here , too , older Americans tend to back a two-state solution , while younger adult are more likely to say they aren & rsquo ; t sure.Evangelical angleOverall , white evangelical Protestants at 28 % are more likely than other Christians to back a one-state solution headed by an Israeli government , while only 6 % of Catholics , non-Evangelical white Protestants and Black Protestants support that solution.White Evangelicals bring religious motif to their views.Fully 70 % of white Evangelicals believe that God gave the Land of Israel to the Jews , compared with 32 % of US Jews who answered a similar question in a 2020 survey.In addition , 86 % of white Evangelicals have favorable view of Israelis while 37 % view Palestinians favorably.Among atheist , agnostic or other irreligious Americans , Israelis and Palestinians tend to be viewed identically positive at 58 % and 59 % respectively.BDSDespite the media-savvy nature of the BDS movement , relatively few Americans even know about it , and fewer support it.According to Pew , 84 % have heard & ldquo ; not much & rdquo ; or & ldquo ; nothing at all & rdquo ; about BDS . Just 5 % have heard something about it and support it , with 2 % strongly supporting it.Interestingly , more Republicans and Republican-leaning independent have heard of BDS than Democrats and Democrat-leaning independent who are more likely to support it .

Vincent and the Grenadines , and Vietnam . Body Text: Around the Gaza Strip , the morning of the second day of Operation Shield and Arrow began quietly . Communities were told to either go to shelter or remain close by . Frantzman ) Inside Gaza , loud boom indicated that Israel wa responding . The radio continued to say where the siren were sounding and to encourage people to go to their shelter . Trucks continued to go back and forth from industrial area , and civilian continued to drive on the most essential roads.I drove over to the industrial area south of Ashkelon , where several road stretch into the distance , toward the sea , the Rutenberg Power Station and Zikim Beach . The name of the operation fade with time & ndash ; Pillar of Defense , Defensive Edge , Black Belt , Guardian of the Walls , Breaking Dawn . Body Text: Garfield , that lazy , lasagna-loving cat , is back , in The Garfield Movie , which opened throughout Israel this week , and this ferociously selfish feline may be just the character we need to spend a couple of hour with right now.The movie , which did not have advance screening prior to press time , is the latest screen portrayal of the surly pet.Those who like to take their child to English-language movie rather than dubbed version of animated movie are in luck , because this is being released in theater in two version , one dubbed into Hebrew and one in English with Hebrew title , probably because Garfield movie tend to appeal to adult a well a kids.There & rsquo ; s something liberating and almost politically incorrect about seeing a character a gluttonous , lazy , and bossy a Garfield . Other than James Bond when he & rsquo ; s not on a mission , what character get to do what he want to do all day , every day ? Right , only Garfield.This time , sadly , Bill Murray , who voiced the cantankerous cat in the 2004 Garfield movie and in 2006 & rsquo ; s Garfield : A Tail of Two Kitties , is not around . Murray & rsquo ; s vaguely hostile hipster persona wa perfect for the character . This time , Chris Pratt voice a slightly less cynical , slightly more energetic-sounding Garfield.The new film is all animated , unlike the previous two , in which Garfield wa animated and digitally inserted into live-action scenes.The plotWe learn how Jon Arbuckle ( Nicholas Hoult , who made his big-screen debut over 20 year ago , playing the teen who befriends Hugh Grant in About a Boy ) first met his very prideful pet . Jon wa having a slice of pizza in a restaurant when he saw Garfield , then a kitten , looking pitiful outside . Jon invited him in , and Garfield consumed the pizza and everything not nailed down.This film feature the usual Garfield antic , but then get into a plot that tell the story of how Garfield get back in touch with his father , a scruffy alley cat named Vic , voiced by Samuel L . Jackson , of Pulp Fiction and so many other movie . & ldquo ; I & rsquo ; m mixed up with some bad cat , and I need your help , & rdquo ; say Vic.Garfield reply , & ldquo ; I haven & rsquo ; t seen you for year , and when I do , you pull me into a life of crime . & rdquo ; Vic asks if he ha ever jumped a train , to which Garfield responds , & ldquo ; I & rsquo ; ve never jumped . & rdquo ; Vic is being blackmailed by his former associate , Jinx ( Hannah Waddington of Ted Lasso ) , and he want to pay her to leave him alone so he can concentrate on his next heist : a large-scale robbery of Lactose Farms , after which he promise they will be set for life.Liz , Jon & rsquo ; s sometime girlfriend and Garfield & rsquo ; s veterinarian , is played by Dev Joshi . Ving Rhames ( who played Jackson & rsquo ; s gangster bos in Pulp Fiction ) and Cecily Strong of SNL portray character who get mixed up in the heist , while rapper Snoop Dog voice a character called Snoop Cat.If you & rsquo ; d like to see the older version of Garfield , you can watch The Garfield Show , a series from about 15 year ago , on Netflix . The two Bill Murray movie are available on Disney + and Apple TV + . Garfield started out a a comic strip , created by Jim Davis , that wa published in an Indiana newspaper in the late & rsquo ; 70 and wa originally called Jon.Raised on an Indiana farm with 25 cat , Davis later worked in advertising and created the comic strip , thinking at first that reader would connect to story of the nebbishy Jon , but everyone loved Garfield so much that he quickly had to change the name and the focus of the comic , admitting that Garfield had turned out to be his bos . Soon , the cartoon wa syndicated in thousand of newspaper and now is also available online at Garfield.com / . And there look to be enough of that here to keep them amused .

Body Text: For Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas , the event of the past week in Jerusalem have been both a blessing and a curse.On the one hand , he managed to get Israel into trouble with many country by portraying it a the & ldquo ; aggressor . & rdquo ; On the other hand , what happened at al-Aqsa Mosque compound ( Temple Mount ) ha emboldened his rival in Hamas and other extremist group , showing that they have more influence and support in Jerusalem than the PA or Jordan.The violence that erupted at the Temple Mount last Friday brought the Israeli-Palestinian conflict back to the center of the world & rsquo ; s attention , which ha been almost entirely focused on the Russian invasion of Ukraine since February . The visit of the Jews are portrayed by Palestinian and Jordanian official and medium outlet a violent incursion by extremist settler under the protection of the Israel Police.Yet , the allegation failed to achieve their goal , a the reaction of most Arabs and Muslims have remained limited to lip service.Scenes of Palestinians burning flag and photo of Arab leader engaged in normalization with Israel managed to enrage many Arabs , especially those residing in the Gulf state . Those Arabs were further enraged when they saw Palestinians curse and harass Emirati and Bahraini visitor to the Temple Mount.The Abraham Accords , which were signed between Israel and a number of Arab country , a well a the apparent rapprochement between Israel and Saudi Arabia , left the Palestinians with the impression that the Arabs and Muslims do not really care about Israel & rsquo ; s ostensible scheme to change the status quo at the Temple Mount by allocating time and space for Jewish prayer there.That & rsquo ; s why Palestinian official in Ramallah were pleased this week to see the United Arab Emirates , Bahrain and Saudi Arabia condemn & ldquo ; the Israel Police & rsquo ; s storming of al-Aqsa Mosque . & rdquo ; These official , however , are aware that the UAE and Bahrain are not going to take drastic measure , such a recalling their ambassador from Israel.By contrast , the PA leadership appears to be content with the crisis that erupted this week between Israel and Jordan in the aftermath of the violence at the Temple Mount.Since the beginning of the tension at the holy site , the PA and Jordan have been holding intensive discussion on & ldquo ; defending & rdquo ; al-Aqsa Mosque and & ldquo ; thwarting & rdquo ; Israel & rsquo ; s alleged attempt to alter the status quo . The feeling in Ramallah is that the Jordanians are the only one who are siding with the Palestinians . & ldquo ; The State of Palestine commended the courageous Jordanian stance expressed by King Abdullah of Jordan and the Jordanian government , parliament and people in defending Jerusalem and the Christian and Islamic holy site , & rdquo ; the PA said in a statement issued by it foreign ministry . & ldquo ; The State of Palestine and it people highly appreciate the diplomatic activity led by King Abdullah to expose the Israeli aggression on al-Aqsa Mosque . & rdquo ; THE PA and Jordan , nonetheless , have good reason to be worried about the event of the past week . The violence that erupted at the Temple Mount ha shown that Ramallah and Amman have little influence , if any , over the young men and woman who clashed with the Israeli security forces.The Jordanian-controlled Wakf Islamic religious trust , which is responsible for administering the Islamic holy site in Jerusalem , failed to stop dozen of rioter from entering the mosque with stone and firework . The Wakf ha dozen of security guard stationed at the Temple Mount , but they did not intervene to stop the rioter and thug from sneaking into the mosque.Similarly , the PA , which ha it own supporter and representative at the Temple Mount , did not do anything to stop the rioter from storming into al-Aqsa Mosque with a large cache of stone and other objects.On the eve of Ramadan , some Israeli and US official approached the PA and Jordan and asked them to work toward preventing an outbreak of violence in Jerusalem , particularly the Temple Mount.But instead of appealing for calm , Ramallah and Amman ramped up their rhetorical attack on Israel , warning that allowing Jews to enter the Temple Mount would ignite & ldquo ; religious war & rdquo ; and plunge the entire region into a fresh cycle of violence.The PA and Jordan do not feel comfortable admitting that supporter of Hamas and other extremist group are the one who call the shot at the Temple Mount . It & rsquo ; s easier for Ramallah and Amman to hold Israel solely responsible for the violence than denounce the rioter who desecrated al-Aqsa Mosque . In fact , the PA and Jordan seem to have scored a diplomatic and propaganda achievement by convincing many in the international community that it wa Israel that planned and initiated the violence.While the violence seems to have served Abbas & rsquo ; s goal of shifting the blame toward Israel , he nevertheless appears worried that he wa excluded from the first stage of the mediation effort to restore calm.Instead of talking to Abbas , the Egyptians , Qataris and the United Nations chose to negotiate with Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh , who is based in Qatar.According to Palestinian source , Abbas wa & ldquo ; furious & rdquo ; for being sidelined by the mediator , mainly because this allows Hamas to score more point with the Palestinian public and gain more legitimacy in the international arena.Abdullah , for his part , is worried that the violence at the Temple Mount and the rising tension with Israel could cost the Hashemites their status a custodian of the Islamic and Christian holy site in Jerusalem . He is well aware that Palestinian teenager hurling stone at Israeli police officer have more influence than his Wakf in Jerusalem . But that doe not mean that the monarch is prepared to walk away from the city.In recent year , report have surfaced that Israel may allow Saudi Arabia and other Arab and Islamic country to replace the Hashemites a the sole custodian of the holy site . The report are said to have angered Abdullah , who ha since been making a huge effort to reassert the royal family & rsquo ; s role in tending the Islamic and Christian holy site in Jerusalem . He doe not seem to be worried if Hamas present itself a the & ldquo ; defender & rdquo ; of Jerusalem , a long a that doe not affect the Hashemites & rsquo ; status a & ldquo ; custodian & rdquo ; of the holy sites.Like Abbas , Abdullah is also worried about the increasing role Hamas and other Islamist group are playing at the Temple Mount.Videos and photo featuring rioter wrapped in Hamas flag and chanting slogan in support of Hamas arch-terrorist Mohammed Deif over the past week have undoubtedly left Abdullah perturbed . Still , he doe not seem to be worried if Hamas present itself a the & ldquo ; defender & rdquo ; of Jerusalem , a long a that doe not affect the Hashemites & rsquo ; status a & ldquo ; custodian & rdquo ; of the holy sites.In Ramallah , PA official were also unhappy to see the Hamas supporter leading the riots.THERE & rsquo ; S NO doubt that the inflammatory statement that came from Ramallah and Amman before and during the event of the past week served the interest of Hamas and other extremist in orchestrating the riot at the Temple Mount.Abbas and Abdullah would have been happy to see the rioter raise their photo ; instead , they got Hamas banner and flag , and were forced to watch and hear Palestinians calling on the Gaza-based terrorist group to fire rocket at Israel.Now , it appears that Abbas and Abdullah are desperately trying to extinguish the very fire they helped ignite , not out of concern for Israel & rsquo ; s security , but out of fear of being totally removed from the holy site.But because they don & rsquo ; t dare to speak out against the young men and woman who have turned al-Aqsa Mosque into a battlefield and spoiled the Ramadan celebration and prayer for hundred of thousand of Muslim worshipper , the current strategy of the PA and Jordan is to get the international community to exert pressure on Israel to halt Jewish & ldquo ; provocation . & rdquo ; Even if the situation doe calm down after Ramadan end ( a expected ) , it & rsquo ; s evident that the status quo ha indeed shifted at the Temple Mount.But it & rsquo ; s not Israel that ha changed the status quo ; rather , it & rsquo ; s the shabab ( youth ) and Hamas who have managed to create a new reality in which they are now the & ldquo ; custodian & rdquo ; and & ldquo ; defender & rdquo ; of al-Aqsa Mosque . & bull ;

Body Text: Hamas , through a senior official , stated it readiness to enter a cease-fire of five year or more with Israel and transition into a political entity if an independent Palestinian state is established along pre-1967 border . Khatib further explained the internal dynamic within Hamas : `` The statement can also reflect dissent and the debate within Hamas . Different leader have different view , but it could also be a tactic , considering the imminent threat of the Israeli army to enter Rafah . `` & nbsp ; He added that while the promise to dissolve the military wing and pursue a sovereign state wa notable , `` Hamas being willing to put it gun down isn & rsquo ; t something you hear every day . Body Text: Hamas and a number of Palestinian armed group vowed on Monday to avenge the death of five gunman killed by Israeli security force during a raid on Aqbat Jaber Refugee Camp , located on the outskirt of Jericho.The five , identified by Hamas a Malek Lafi , 22 , Ra & rsquo ; fat Oweidat , 21 , Ibrahim Oweidat , 27 , Thaer Oweidat , 28 , and Adham Oweidat , 22 , belonged to the group & rsquo ; s armed wing , Izaddin al-Qassam.Palestinian source said the gunman operated in the camp under the name of a group called Aqbat Jaber Camp Battalion.A new armed Palestinian gunman group ha formed in JerichoThe new group , the first of it kind in the Jericho area , is seen by the source a part of an attempt to imitate similar militia that have been operating in the northern West Bank over the past year : Jenin Battalion , Nablus Battalion and Balata Refugee Camp Battalion , a well a the Lions & rsquo ; Den and Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigades.While these group consist mostly of member of Palestinian Islamic Jihad ( PIJ ) and the ruling Fatah faction headed by Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas , the slain Aqbat Jaber cell member all belonged to Hamas.Two of the gunman were involved in a shooting attack on January 28 against an Israeli-owned caf & eacute ; at Almog junction , located only a few kilometer away from Aqbat Jaber Refugee Camp . No one wa hurt.Since the attack , the IDF ha imposed strict security measure in the Jericho area , a move that badly hurt the local economy , which relies mainly on local tourism.The camp is located across the street from the Oasis Casino , the first gambling facility in the West Bank . The casino ha been shut since the start of the Second Intifada more than 20 year ago . Some of the camp resident previously worked in the casino and a nearby hotel.Last year , unconfirmed report claimed that Israel and the Palestinians were discussing the possibility of allowing the casino to reopen . The report revived hope in Aqbat Jaber camp in particular and Jericho in general that the local economy would be strengthened once the gambler , most of whom were Israeli citizen , returned to the casino.Despite the closure of the casino , Jericho ha over the past few year witnessed an unprecedented boom in local tourism a dozen of luxurious villa have popped up in and around the city . In addition , many foreign tourist have returned to the city in recent years.The villa , owned by Arab Israelis and resident of east Jerusalem , are offered for rent on a daily , weekly and monthly basis . Most of the client are Palestinian family from east Jerusalem and the West Bank , a well a Arab Israelis . & ldquo ; The street of Jericho were empty after the shooting operation [ at the Almog junction ] , & rdquo ; said a resident of east Jerusalem who owns two villa in Jericho . & ldquo ; Many people couldn & rsquo ; t go to Jericho because of the Israeli checkpoint . People rent the villa for private event , including birthday party and wedding . & rdquo ; He and other Palestinians who own business in Jericho expressed fear that the phenomenon of armed group and anarchy would spread from Jenin and Nablus to their city . They revealed that some activist from Jenin and Nablus moved to Jericho over the past year.Jericho : Once a `` sleepy town `` with stability despite violence in the West BankOnce described a a & ldquo ; sleepy town , & rdquo ; the situation in Jericho ha been generally stable over the past year , despite the significant upsurge of violence in the northern West Bank . The calm allowed many Arab investor from Israel and the West Bank to purchase relatively cheap land and build villa a vacation home for themselves and to put on the booming short-term rental market.The call by Hamas and other Palestinian group for avenging the killing of the five Aqbat Jaber militant indicates that the security situation in the Jericho area could further deteriorate in the coming day and weeks.In a statement published shortly after the armed clash in the camp , Hamas praised the & ldquo ; heroic resistance fighter & rdquo ; and said that the & ldquo ; confrontation with the enemy confirms once again that our people are on the path of resistance and liberation and won & rsquo ; t be intimidated by the crime of the occupation . & rdquo ; The Aqbat Baber Camp Battalion also pledged to retaliate for the killing of it men , although it remains unclear whether the group ha more member operating in the camp and other area of Jericho . What is certain , however , is that the Hamas member operated inside a camp located only a few hundred meter away from the main headquarters of the PA security force in the city . It is also located not far from the notorious Jericho Prison , where the Palestinian security force often hold Palestinians suspected of being affiliated with Hamas and PIJ.The PA leadership , which recently decided to halt security coordination with Israel in response to the killing of nine Palestinians , mostly gunman , during a similar Israeli security operation in Jenin Refugee Camp , on Monday condemned the & ldquo ; new crime & rdquo ; in Aqbat Jaber camp . In a statement issued by Abbas & rsquo ; s office , the PA accused the Israeli government of continuing it & ldquo ; crime & rdquo ; against the Palestinians.Hours before the incident in Aqbat Jaber camp , Abbas chaired a meeting of the commander of the Palestinian security force and discussed with them the ongoing tension and violence , especially in the West Bank.At the meeting , Abbas reportedly reaffirmed the Palestinian leadership & rsquo ; s decision to end the security coordination with Israel . In the same breath , he also instructed the Palestinian security service & ldquo ; to assume their role in preserving the rule of law , public security and civil peace . & rdquo ; This wa not the first time in recent month that Abbas ha issued such instruction to his security forces.Yet , despite the instruction , the PA security force have failed to take significant action against armed group and gunman in Jenin and Nablus , who continue to operate freely in area under his control and carry out attack against Israeli soldier and civilian . And there & rsquo ; s no reason whatsoever to think that these security force will now take meaningful measure to stop Jericho from joining Jenin and Nablus a terror hub in the West Bank .

Peled is an officer with rich , professional , and sharp experience . He is a fighter for the country and an administrator who will move the police forward . This is the opportunity to deeply thank the current chief Shabtai , to whom the state owes forty year of service and fighting for the people of Israel . `` About a month ago , a I recall , the Meron disaster investigation concluded that Shabtai bear personal responsibility for the disaster , `` Ben-Gvir continued . `` The finding of the report determined that in Shabtai 's case , would have led it to recommend the termination of his position , but considering the current circumstance ( Israel-Hamas war ) , It leaf the government to determine the correct date for the end of his position . `` Jerusalem Post Staff contributed to this report .
title: ' new sheriff in town , ' ben-gvir announces candidate to replace chief of police

My only interest in it existence is if it operates within existing agreement & hellip ; and take care of it citizen and thwart and act against terror and work in conjunction with the Israeli security force , then the PA is an authority with which one can have a in-depth relationship , & rdquo ; Smotrich said.The withholding of tax fee wa part of a series of sanction Israel imposed on the PA to protest it successful initiative through the International Court of Justice , which will now issue an advisory opinion on the legality of Israel & rsquo ; s & ldquo ; occupation . & rdquo ; Israel suspends Palestinian Foreign Minister Riyad al-Maliki 's travel passIsrael suspended on Sunday a pas easing Palestinian Authority Foreign Minister Riyad al-Maliki & rsquo ; s travel in the West Bank a part of the sanction it leveled against the PA late last week to protest it push for an International Court of Justice advisory opinion against the Jewish state . & ldquo ; The foreign minister will continue his job and his diplomatic activity with or without the card , & rdquo ; Maliki & rsquo ; s aid Ahmed Al-Deek told Reuters.Maliki & rsquo ; s & ldquo ; VIP & rdquo ; travel card wa confiscated by border staff a he crossed from Jordan into the West Bank via the Allenby Crossing , his office said . The Defense Ministry confirmed the suspension of Maliki & rsquo ; s VIP pass.Retaliatory measure taken by Israel against PalestiniansIn an interview with Voice of Palestine Radio , Maliki said his office had written to government around the world asking that to condemn the Israeli sanctions.Israel confiscated Maliki & rsquo ; s VIP card in 2021 after he returned from a meeting of the ICC . It wa not immediately clear why the card had been confiscated and when it will be restored.Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu discussed the sanction at the start of his weekly government meeting , explaining that they were in response to & ldquo ; a radical anti-Israel decision at the UN . & rdquo ; He said that & ldquo ; these step include sanction against senior Palestinian official , the offsetting of terrorist fund and the freezing of Palestinian construction project in Area C , which contravene the explicit commitment that the PA ha taken upon itself . & ldquo ; We have established a different government with a different policy , and everyone will see this , & rdquo ; Netanyahu said.On Sunday , Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich ordered Tax Authority Director Eran Ya & rsquo ; akov to transfer NIS 138.8 million from tax fee it had collected on behalf of the PA to Israeli victim of Palestinian terror . & ldquo ; Today we are correcting an injustice , & rdquo ; Smotrich said . & ldquo ; This is an important day for morality , justice and the war on terror , & rdquo ; particularly given the PA & rsquo ; s policy of paying monthly stipend to terrorist and their family , he said . & ldquo ; There is no greater justice than offsetting the authority & rsquo ; s fund that support terrorism and transferring them to the family of the victim of terrorism , & rdquo ; Smotrich said . & ldquo ; There is no comfort here for the family of the murdered , but there is justice here .
