Body Text: An 80-year-old Palestinian-American who died in IDF custody two week ago most likely suffered a heart attack caused by the stress he experienced during his detainment , Jiljilya Mayor Fuad Qattum said Sunday . Palestinian official and relative said the body of Omar Abdalmajeed As & rsquo ; ad wa found in the Palestinian town of Jiljilya , near Ramallah , in the early hour of January 12 with a plastic zip tie around one wrist . The Biden administration ha sought & ldquo ; clarification & rdquo ; from Israel about As & rsquo ; ad & rsquo ; s death , US State Department spokesman Ned Price said last week . & ldquo ; We are still waiting for the autopsy report , & rdquo ; Qattum said . & ldquo ; Today I talked to the prosecutor , and he told me that it take time to prepare such report . It & rsquo ; s likely he died from a heart attack a a result of the stress he wa in . But we want to wait for the official report to see what caused the death . & rdquo ; As & rsquo ; ad wa detained while soldier carried out an overnight operation in the village , the IDF said . He wa alive when the soldier released him , and the Military Police ha opened a probe into the matter , it added . & ldquo ; The Military Police Criminal Investigation Division is reviewing the incident , at the end of which the finding will be transferred to the Military General Advocate Corps , & rdquo ; the IDF said in a statement at the time . The Military Police ha launched an investigation into the incident , but it is unlikely that charge will be brought against the soldier and officer who participated in the operation , Ynet reported Sunday . The soldier were from the Netzah Yehuda Battalion , which is part of the Kfir Brigade . Three soldier and two officer were questioned by police under warning , the report said . The soldier said they had detained As & rsquo ; ad since he wa driving in a car that appeared suspicious , and they wanted to rule out that he wa carrying arm . They detained As & rsquo ; ad and moved him to a nearby abandoned home to be questioned . As & rsquo ; ad resisted and claimed he wa not a terrorist , Ynet reported . The soldier allegedly then forcefully moved him into the abandoned home , tied his hand and covered his mouth . He then appeared & ldquo ; woozy , & rdquo ; according to the soldier , and they believed he had fallen asleep . They did not call for medical assistance and eventually left the home after untying As & rsquo ; ad , the report said . As & rsquo ; ad wa a former Milwaukee , Wisconsin , resident who had lived in the United States for decade and returned to the West Bank 10 year ago , according to his brother . As & rsquo ; ad & rsquo ; s family delayed the funeral until Thursday to allow a postmortem . Islam Abu Zaher , a local doctor who said he had tried to resuscitate As & rsquo ; ad but found no pulse , said there were no obvious sign of injury and that the cause of death wa unclear .
title: idf question soldier , officer over death of palestinian-american

Body Text: There wa something about the story of the murder of a mother and two daughter during the Passover holiday last year that imprinted itself on the consciousness of the nation and catapulted Rabbi Leo Dee , the grieving husband and father , to international prominence.On April 7 , 2023 , Lucy Dee and her daughter Maia , 20 , and Rina , 15 , were driving to Tiberias over Hol Hamoed , the intermediate day of the week-long festival . Their vehicle wa rammed off the road by terrorist gunman , who shot all three woman . Maia and Rina were killed on the scene , and Lucy passed away from her wound two day later.In a private ceremony exactly one year later , Rabbi Leo Dee and his daughter Keren and Tali and son Yehuda ( now 19 , 18 and 15 year old ) dedicated a new social hall in their community of Efrat in Lucy ’ s memory.Later that evening , a standing-room-only crowd of 700 , plus 2,400 who watched the ceremony online , gathered in the newly dedicated Shirat Lucy ( Lucy ’ s Song ) Hall above the Mishkan Tziporah synagogue in Efrat to remember the three woman and to draw inspiration from their lives.Rabbi Leo Dee speaksAfter thanking the attendee for “ the abundance of love , help , positive wish , and kindness from everyone this year , ” Rabbi Dee called these collective act of kindness “ our greatest nechama [ comfort ] . ” In his talk , Rabbi Dee highlighted what he identified a “ some of the thousand of project that have been set off during this year in their memory by friend , family , and people we have never met before ! ” He spoke about the Torah scroll written in Lucy ’ s memory , “ with every one of the 300,000 letter written by different schoolchildren , soldier , and others from around the world … . This sefer Torah is the essence of Lucy ’ s quest to get every Jew to feel part of our greater story and to shine their light in the world . ” In a widely publicized follow-up story to the murder , seven people received one of Lucy ’ s organ . In the audience that night wa Rina Lital , the recipient of Lucy Dee ’ s heart . While relating all the way that Rina ’ s life ha begun to mirror Lucy ’ s since the transplant , Rabbi Dee said , “ The head of organ donation at Beilinson [ Hospital , Rabin Medical Center , Petah Tikvah ] recently announced on national radio that the 30 % increase in organ donor in Israel is directly connected to Lucy ’ s story . ” Continuing the theme of saving life , Rabbi Dee said that “ group of extremely generous Swiss and American donor , who had never met any of u , dedicated a number of ambulance in [ Lucy ’ s ] memory and in the memory of Rina and Maia . They have saved numerous life since then . ” Dressed in matching white T-shirts , the student and faculty of Efrat ’ s Orot Yehuda , where Lucy wa a much-loved English teacher , recorded a haunting video of song of encouragement and faith dedicated to Lucy ’ s memory . The five-minute video garnered more than 43,000 view in it first four days.In Maia ’ s memory , ten of thousand of Jews around the world are learning and discussing a teaching from Pirkei Avot ( Ethics of the Fathers ) at their Shabbat table each week . The project started 18 month ago , when the Dees hosted two of Maia ’ s friend from London . On that Shabbat , they learned one mishna from Pirkei Avot at each meal . In Maia ’ s memory , those friend expanded the project to the extent that Rabbi Dee commented , “ I can not travel anywhere today without people coming up to me and saying , ‘ I am learning your Pirkei Avot . ’ ” He also talked about a project that Maia initiated during her National Service in a high school in Yeroham . She provided snack to encourage girl to study the weekly Torah portion during their morning break . Maia named the project “ Nish Nosh Parsh ” and , according to Rabbi Dee , the project “ ha now been rolled out to hundred of ulpanot across Israel in her memory . ” Rabbi Dee shared that Rina ’ s friendly and adventurous nature ha been memorialized in “ a trip to Masada for hundred of teen from around the country before Pesach . They are planning to build a spring for [ Rina ] in Hamra over the summer . “ Rina , if there wa a girl in your year feeling lonely , you were the one with your arm around her , and you were the one who would start a new ball game to include her , ” her father said . “ To remember your kindness , your friend have built a special space in the school at Kiryat Arba to bring everyone together during break time and for Mincha [ afternoon prayer ] ( which you inspired everyone to daven ) , and they have dedicated a new chug of basketball , to which everyone is invited and will keep everyone fit . ” Future plan include a new youth house for Ezra in the Tamar neighborhood of Efrat in memory of Rina , who wa instrumental in helping to establish the Tamar branch.Speaking directly to his wife and daughter , Dee concluded his summary of memorial project with the word , “ Lucy , Maia , and Rina – you will never be forgotten . Everything I am doing is dedicated to one of you , and so many project continue in your merit . ” The rabbi peppered his evening ’ s talk with the question , “ Mi kamocha , Yisrael ? ” ( Who is like you , Israel ? ) , highlighting the many way that he ha been inspired by the Jewish people ’ s response to his family ’ s tragedy . He concluded with seven lesson he ha drawn from the past year.These were his exact word : There ’ s no benefit to being sad . I believe that the purpose of mourning is to get to a point where you can remember your loved one with a smile ; otherwise , we ’ ll never want to think about them at all . The challenge is figuring out how to do it . With the help of all these project and more , Am Yisrael [ the Nation of Israel ] ha been the greatest help.There ’ s nothing like the Jewish people . From the shiva [ week-long mourning period ] onwards , we have felt that we did not lose three member of our family of seven , but three from our family of 14 million.Tzaddikim [ righteous people ] live forever : They never die . Rashaim [ evil people ] never live , even when they are alive . This also applies to nation . The Jewish people from all past generation are still living through their contribution to our life today . Our enemy have contributed nothing but destruction and are forgettable even while they live.I ’ m grateful for the 30 year I knew Lucy , the 20 year I knew Maia , and the 15 year I knew Rina . Your impact on this world is immeasurable . What you have achieved in half a lifetime , or quarter of a lifetime , is more than most of u could achieve in 10 lifetime . It ’ s a challenge to always think of the good time , but that ’ s what ’ s needed.The best treatment for destruction is to build . The first mitzvah of the Shulchan Aruch [ Code of Jewish Law ] is to jump out of bed in the morning like a lion . This mean : You must have something to jump out of bed for . Every Jew must have at least one passion he or she is working on at any time , and that ’ s what get you up in the morning . If you are struggling to get out of bed , find your passion . Friday morning , planting fruit tree in Efrat wa fulfilling the biblical mitzvah of Yishuv Ha ’ Aretz , settling the land . We will continue to build , we will continue to plant.There ’ s no youth like our Jewish youth . They have get up and go , they build , they invent , and they are the bravest generation in our history . I am proud of every one of them . They are the or le ’ goy [ light unto the nation ] . At the shiva , some 17-year-old boy from the community asked if they could build a viewpoint [ lookout ] in Efrat in memory of the girl , and I apparently agreed . Nine month later , they showed me what they had achieved – and the Mitzpeh HaDegel [ Flag Outlook ] would be a victory for a professional landscape company , let alone a group of 17-year-old boy who raised the fund themselves and taught themselves how to build pergola and plant tree from YouTube videos.Finally , I learned that what matter is not my emunah in Hashem , my faith in God , but rather Hashem ’ s faith in me . Every morning I say “ Modeh Ani … Rabah Emunatecha ” Thank you , Hashem , for Your faith in me . We can appreciate the infinite miracle in our life – the friend , the family , Am Yisrael , Eretz Yisrael [ the Land of Israel ] – but if Hashem agreed for u to wake up this morning , He ha a purpose for u . Our job is not to question Him but to find that purpose . Today there are hundred of thousand of Jews in Israel fighting for our people and for freedom in the world – fulfilling their purpose , and million of others are supporting them.The daughter speakGathered together for strength and support , the three remaining Dee child ascended the platform , where both daughter spoke about their mother and sister . At the evening event , Keren and Tali , who are fully bilingual , spoke in Hebrew ; at the memorial ceremony at the cemetery in Kfar Etzion the next morning , they delivered their comment in English.Keren revealed the truth about living post-trauma by contrasting her daily reality with what she described a “ the beautiful image I built for myself from the outside . ” “ At night , every thought and feeling that come to mind keep switching to difficult thing . I am flooded with memory ; tossing and turning over and over and unable to sleep . At about five , I get out of bed in despair and decide to spend the remaining time ‘ til morning on my phone . ” She then recounted what her day would be like if her mother and sister were still alive , including a poignant image of finding her mother in the kitchen baking “ some indulgent chocolate banana muffin that we could take with u ; and reminding u , of course , that it ’ s important to put on sunscreen so we don ’ t have wrinkle and to drink a lot because it ’ s hot today . ” Keren mused about the “ Orphan ’ s Kaddish ” she find in her prayerbook and how she realized , with a start , that this memorial prayer now refers to her . She concluded with a thought she learned from her father that she said “ help me continue . ” “ What if our life wa supposed to look like this ? What if God predestined an allotted time for them to be with u ? For 18 year ? And then we were meant to go on alone ? ” she asked . “ And then I ask myself , if I had the option and I knew that my life would look like this from the beginning , would I take it or give it up ? “ Everything in life that made me who I am today , I learned from them , ” Keren said . “ Mummy : If it ’ s doing hessed [ act of kindness ] , giving , caring , cooking like crazy , forgiving , being a listening ear but always remembering that there is something more to aspire to and to move forward , then that ’ s what she ’ ll do . “ Maia : Demanding what you deserved , dressing in style , giving good advice , putting effort into what is important to you , loving the Torah , and always listening to others . “ Rina : Loving this country , being righteous with complete faith that this is the way , being humble , loving and believing that everyone ha something special of their own . “ In short , of course I would choose life ! “ Mummy , Maia , and Rina , I believe that you are still by my side in every dilemma I have , every new beginning , in every frustration and in every achievement . Thank you for being with me during the most beautiful 18 year of my life , and now I must move on : not by replacing you , or forgetting you , but with you by my side and above . ” TALI , the younger Dee sister , spoke about all the time , place , and circumstance when she miss her mother and sisters.In a heartrending admission , Tali shared that “ I don ’ t have a mother ’ s voice in my life . There is no one to wake me up in the morning and push me out of bed . Everyone want to make it easy for me , they tell me to [ have ] compassion on myself – but I often just need your demanding voice . I miss your hug . There is nothing in the world that can replace it . And no human being can fill that place . Someone who will take me with my temper , to whom I can show all my hard side – and no matter what , you will always love me . ” Moving from the personal to the national , she said , “ And during this year , our nation ha also turned upside down . After the attack [ on October 7 ] , I thought a lot about the difference between soldier who knowingly put themselves at risk , and my family , who just wanted to go on holiday . “ But I understood that we chose to live here in this country . And we were always aware of the danger present in this choice . The home front and the battle front are close to each other in our country , ” Tali said . “ Many people are now experiencing what I experienced and I want to tell them it get easier , but I ’ m not sure I can say that . There are day when I really manage to be happy . But there is no pill that can cure the pain ; there is no pill that fix everything . “ … I ’ m not the same person after everything that happened to me . This story is such a central part of my identity that you can ’ t really know me without it . I ’ ve grown up . I have a broader perspective . Things I cried about a year ago are not the thing I cry about now , ” she said . “ In many way , this is what is happening to our nation . We went through something huge : terrible . And we can ’ t go back to being what we were before . We sacrificed too much for this . We need to grow up . Our prayer should increase . ” Tali concluded her remark by speaking of how her mother and sister still influence her . “ Thanks to Rina , I now pay much more attention to the people around me : say hello to everyone , even the girl I ’ m less friendly with . To be a better friend , to reduce my ego ; to have a simple joy . “ Thanks to Maia , when I ’ m in midrasha I try harder and invest more , and I ’ m not ashamed to ask question . “ Thanks to Mummy , I try to be more flexible . “ Some day it ’ s harder to feel it , but sometimes I feel like I have three angel of my own , ” she revealed . “ I feel protected . ” A close friend speaksIn a raw and deeply personal speech delivered at the cemetery , Lucy ’ s close friend Danja Keesing related an amusing story about how her friend convinced her to wake up in time to take an exercise class together early Sunday morning . “ Sunday morning , I liked you least of all , I have to admit . Actually , I didn ’ t like you at all . No one is perky on Sunday morning after Shabbos … besides Lucy . ” Lucy ’ s enthusiasm eventually won Keesing over . “ That is your essence , Lucy : believing in others – maybe even many time more than you ever believed in yourself . ” Later she declared , “ You loved so , so hard ; tried so , so hard . Had so many love and care goal a a wife and a mother that sometimes I thought to myself , ‘ What is the intensity ? What is the rush ? Breathe . Take less to heart . Don ’ t work so hard . Don ’ t try so hard . ’ “ Now I know that your soul knew that what others do in 70 , 80 , or 90 year , you had to do in less than 50 . ” The evening memorial program also featured a siyum ( conclusion celebration ) on Mishna made by Maia ’ s friend , and word of Torah in Hebrew from Rabbanit Yemima Mizrachi . The evening ended with a group sing-along , filled with song about Moshiach ( Messiah ) and redemption led by Shlomo Katz , who is a musician and rabbi of Shirat David in Efrat .  The writer is a freelance journalist and expert on the non-Jewish awakening to Torah happening in our day . She is the editor of Ten From The Nations and Lighting Up The Nations .
title: the inspiring dee family : one year after a terror attack killed maia , rina , lucy

Body Text: Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas announced on Thursday night that the Palestinian election have been postponed until Israel allows the vote to take place in Jerusalem . & nbsp ; Abbas made the announcement after a meeting of leader of Palestinian faction in Ramallah . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We have decided to postpone the parliamentary election until we ensure the participation of the people of Jerusalem , & rdquo ; Abbas said in a statement . & ldquo ; The election must be held in all the Palestinian territory , including Jerusalem . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; He said that he will work toward forming a Palestinian national unity government that would & ldquo ; abide by international resolution and reinforce the PLO . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Earlier in the night , Abbas announced that Israel ha informed the Palestinian Authority that it will not allow the Palestinians to hold election in Jerusalem . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; There will be no election without Jerusalem , & rdquo ; Abbas said in opening remark during a meeting of leader of several Palestinian faction in Ramallah . & nbsp ; The meeting wa called amid report that Abbas wa set to announce the postponement of the election indefinitely because of Israel & rsquo ; s reported refusal to allow the vote to take place in Jerusalem . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; He said that the US , European Union and some Arab country also informed the Palestinians of Israel & rsquo ; s refusal to allow the election to take place in Jerusalem . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Today , we received a message from Israel , the US and some Arab country about Israel & rsquo ; s opposition to holding the election in Jerusalem , & rdquo ; Abbas said . & ldquo ; The message we received said that Israel can @ @ @ t make a decision because there is no government in Israel . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Scoffing at the purported Israeli response , Abbas said : & ldquo ; But there is a government in Israel that is making decision to build thousand of settlement . Who issued the order to the [ Israel ] police to stand with the settler in killing the people of Jerusalem ? Where did these decision came from ? Africa ? We won & rsquo ; t allow anyone to fool u . This is nonsense . Where is [ Prime Minister Benjamin ] Netanyahu ? Netanyahu , may God prolong his life , is still the prime minister . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Abbas said that the Palestinians are ready to hold the election once Israel agrees to allow the vote to take place in Jerusalem . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We want the election to take place in Jerusalem , and not in Abu Dis , & rdquo ; he said , referring to a West Bank village south of Jerusalem . & ldquo ; For u , the election are not a tactic or a game . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Abbas said that the EU made a big effort to exert pressure on Israel to allow the election to take place in Jerusalem , but to no avail . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; When we announced the election , the Europeans told u that they support u and are ready to help u achieve our goal , & rdquo ; he noted . & ldquo ; I told the Europeans that that Israel will not agree to hold the election in Jerusalem . They told me that they will talk to the Israelis about this . We also asked the Americans where are they , but we didn & rsquo ; t hear from them . We waited and didn & rsquo ; t receive a response . We also sent our foreign minister to Europe to tell them we are running out of time . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; According to Abbas , the head of the EU told him that they were & ldquo ; frustrated & rdquo ; by Israel & rsquo ; s refusal to respond to the request to hold the election in Jerusalem . & nbsp ; Abbas accused Israel of & ldquo ; beating & rdquo ; Palestinian candidate in Jerusalem and preventing election gathering . & nbsp ; He went on to praise the resident of east Jerusalem for protesting Israeli security restriction in the city in the past three week . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I want to praise the great stance of our people in Jerusalem and the Arab people who stood with u regarding the event in Jerusalem in the past few week , & rdquo ; Abbas said . & ldquo ; There is a great people in Jerusalem capable of saying no to the occupation . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; He accused the Israeli government of supporting Jewish extremist who chanted & quot ; Death to the Arabs & quot ; during a recent demonstration near the Old City of Jerusalem . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Referring to the removal of the police barricade from Damascus Gate & ndash ; which reportedly triggered the clash in the city & ndash ; Abbas said : & ldquo ; Jerusalem belongs to u ; our brother managed to remove the barricade that prevented them from moving and working in the city . They launched a peaceful , popular resistance . This is the only way to confront this aggression on our people . Jerusalem is the eternal capital of Palestine . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Earlier this week , Foreign Ministry political adviser Alon Bar told European ambassador that Israel wa not interfering with the scheduled Palestinian election . & ldquo ; Israel will not prevent the election in the Palestinian Authority from happening , & rdquo ; Bar said . The Palestinian election are an internal Palestinian matter , and Israel will not intervene , he added . & nbsp ; Hamas official said they did not participate in the meeting of the faction leader because they received an invitation only at the last minute . & ldquo ; Hamas & rsquo ; s position is clear : we reject the postponement of the election and we will not provide a cover for such a decision , & rdquo ; said Mohammed Subha , a spokesperson for the Hamas electoral list & ldquo ; Jerusalem is Our Destiny . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Subha warned that postponement of the election would have a negative impact on effort to end the rivalry between Hamas and Fatah . He also hinted that the move could trigger widespread protest in the West Bank and Gaza Strip . & nbsp ; Hours before the meeting , thousand of Palestinians demonstrated in the Gaza Strip to voice opposition to the cancellation of the election . & nbsp ; Some of the protest were organized by supporter of exiled Fatah leader Mohammed Dahlan , an archrival of Abbas . Dahlan loyalist have formed an electoral list called Al-Mustaqbal ( Future ) to contest the parliamentary election . & nbsp ; Nayrouz Qarmout , a spokeswoman for Al-Mustaqbal , pointed out that 25 electoral list running in the parliamentary election were opposed to the cancellation of the vote . & ldquo ; No one ha the right to postpone the election , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; Only those who are afraid of the result don & rsquo ; t want election . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Qarmout and other Palestinians predicted that the cancellation of the election would intensify the dispute between Fatah and Hamas . & nbsp ; In a joint statement , the electoral list warned that the cancellation of the election would be a & ldquo ; constitutional crime . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The cancellation of the election is a new and big catastrophe for the Palestinians , & rdquo ; said Abdel Hakim Awad , a senior official with Dahlan & rsquo ; s Democratic Reform Current movement . & ldquo ; It will have dire effect and serious consequence on the Palestinian people . The election are a light at the end of the tunnel in order to unify the Palestinian people and end the division [ between the West Bank and Gaza Strip ] . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The decision to hold the election wa part of an agreement reached between Fatah , Hamas and 12 other Palestinian faction . & nbsp ; The agreement , reached under the auspex of Egypt , called for boosting public freedom in the West Bank and Gaza Strip , including the immediate release of detainee held by the PA and Hamas and non-interference by the Palestinian security force in the electoral process . & nbsp ; The agreement wa reached after month of negotiation , which began in July 2020 between Fatah and Hamas leader in Turkey , Qatar and Egypt . & nbsp ; In accordance with the agreement , Abbas issued a decree on January 15 for holding the first general election since 2006 , when Hamas won the parliamentary vote . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The Palestinian people in Jerusalem and all constituency of the nation are invited to general , free and direct election to elect member of the Palestinian Legislative Council ( PLC ) on May 22 , 2021 and President of the State of Palestine on July 31 , 2021 , & rdquo ; Abbas said in the decree . & nbsp ; According to the decree , the PLC election shall be considered the first stage for the election of the Palestinian National Council ( PNC ) , the PLO & rsquo ; s legislative body . The formation of the PNC shall be completed on August 31 , 2021 . & nbsp ; The Palestinian Central Elections Commission said that 36 electoral list submitted their nomination application for the PLC election , including 29 independent list and seven from political party . The number of candidate nominated for the 132-member PLC reached 1,391 , including 405 woman .
title: abbas : palestinian election postponed after israel block jerusalem vote

Body Text: & nbsp ; On April 7 , 2011 , a new era began for Israel & rsquo ; s air and missile defense force & ndash ; when the Iron Dome missile defense system completed it first successful operational interception against a short-range threat originating from the Gaza Strip . & nbsp ; Now , one decade later , it is time to analyze the decision-making process behind the system & rsquo ; s development , some lesson learned from a decade of operation , and the prospect for further advancement and adaptation over the next decade , including potential future connection with laser solution . & nbsp ; Iron Dome & rsquo ; s unrivaled success on the battlefield & ndash ; which ha even made it , in many people & rsquo ; s eye , the most important Israeli innovation in the country & rsquo ; s 70 year of existence & ndash ; ha produced countless article , interview , book and television program on the path to develop the system and it progress over the year . & nbsp ; For the sake of history , those who made the decision and developed the system , and for the purpose of drawing effective lesson for the future , it is essential that the record be set straight , and that the factual truth , albeit subjective , be known , a it primarily appears in the State Comptroller & rsquo ; s report 59A . & nbsp ; Deciding to develop Iron Dome & nbsp ; In 1996 , Israel and the United States agreed to collaborate on Project THEL ( Tactical High-Energy Laser ) , mistakenly dubbed Nautilus ( America & rsquo ; s earlier adventure in this technological field ) . From the start , the project wa developed a a technological demonstrator . In 2001 , a series of test wa completed proving a laser beam can intercept a threat , but concluded that a chemical laser-based interception system wa not suitable for operational deployment in Israel . Low operational preparedness ( technological reliability ) , complex logistics ( size , availability , repair and transfer from site to site ) and environmental concern were only a few of the many significant reason why . & nbsp ; Israel and the US decided to plan another system , smaller and more portable , named MTHEL ( Mobile THEL ) . From this decision , it can be understood that the cessation of the THEL program wa not in any way caused by Israel & rsquo ; s exit from Lebanon , a some have argued . & nbsp ; From 2001 to 2005 , Israel and it American counterpart worked on the new collaboration but decided to discontinue it in 2005 while still in the planning stage , a per advice from the Defense Ministry & rsquo ; s Directorate of Defense Research and Development ( DDR & amp ; D ) director Shmuel Keren and assessment shared by numerous expert . It wa believed this project would not lead to an operational weapon system given that there wa no foreseeable future for a chemical laser-based system . It wa clear that any future laser-based interception system would be based on a solid-state laser , but such technology would not be available for & ndash ; what proved to be optimistic & ndash ; at least another decade . & nbsp ; In the end , by 2005 , after roughly nine year of work and $ 600 million ( mostly funded by the US ) , the outcome wa a technological demonstrator , impossible to duplicate or be used operationally on an American test field . Over the year , a series of interception test wa conducted on the system with an actual success rate of less than 50 % ( based on American official data ) . & nbsp ; Additionally , a detailed on-paper plan wa designed for a small mobile system , MTHE . The idea , later dubbed SKYGUARD , wa not yet created . SKYGUARD & rsquo ; s status can also be deduced from a Northrop Grumman ( NG ) proposal submitted to DDR & amp ; D down the road . The proposal required higher development cost than all of Iron Dome & rsquo ; s development from zero . Statements contending that the THEL system could have been brought to Israel and operationalized , or that the MTHEL/SKYGUARD system wa ready for production in 2005 were simply not factually accurate nor based in reality . This remains the case today , 15 year later . & nbsp ; In 2004 & ndash ; facing elevated threat , especially in southern Israel & ndash ; an interagency team wa set up to draft solution for defensive system against short-range threat . This team , led by R & amp ; D unit director Daniel Gold , issued a call for proposal and tested dozen of potential solution . Eventually , at the end of 2005 , the team recommended developing a system based on Rafael & rsquo ; s proposal ( with change ) & ndash ; and it wa named & ldquo ; Iron Dome . & rdquo ; The proposal wa approved by DDR & amp ; D director Keren and a relatively small budget wa allocated , out of the department & rsquo ; s overall budget , and a partnership with Rafael that financially support part of the R & amp ; D effort . & nbsp ; In 2006 , in light of the changing threat landscape & ndash ; with the Second Lebanon War and rocket launched into Israel serving a significant catalyst & ndash ; and inquiry by NG and other defense industry , Keren presented the proposed concept to then-defense minister Amir Peretz , recommending Iron Dome . Peretz adopted the suggestion and even called for expedited development . However , there still wa not a significant budget allocated to the project , & nbsp ; In October 2006 , after additional significant pressure , Keren appointed a professional committee led by his deputy Jacob Nagel , to test which solution would best protect Israel from short-range missile threat . The committee included dozen of internal and external expert in the field of missile , laser , operational research and doctrine . Lt . - Col . Shachar Shohat & ndash ; who later achieved the rank of brigadier-general and served a commander of the Air Defense Forces & ndash ; served a the Air Force representative on the committee . & nbsp ; For three month , the Nagel Committee worked intensely to test all potential Israeli and international solution . Finally , in December , the committee presented it finding and recommendation to Keren , to Defense Ministry director-general Gabi Ashkenazi and to Peretz , and they approved it . In February 2007 , these recommendation were presented to prime minister Ehud Olmert , who authorized them . & nbsp ; Israel & rsquo ; s state comptroller noted , & ldquo ; DDR & amp ; D , through the work of the Nagel Committee , conducted an orderly process for testing alternative , and presented the alternative to different party and noted the clear advantage with the Iron Dome system . Each of the party & ndash ; the director-general , minister of defense , and prime minister & ndash ; approved DDR & amp ; D & rsquo ; s conclusion . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Peretz declared that the Iron Dome concept wa proven , but would require additional external funding . Olmert explained that Iron Dome & rsquo ; s development wa unavoidable and directed the Defense Ministry to approach the Finance Ministry to allocate the needed budget . By June 2007 the project still had not received a substantial budget , and progressed with DDR & amp ; D and Rafael R & amp ; D budget , increased by several dozen of million of shekel from Peretz and acting director-general Yehiel Horev from the defense budget . & nbsp ; The Nagel Committee did not include the THEL system a a potential solution , given previous assessment casting doubt on it operational potential or relevance , and the inability to be duplicated . SKYGUARD , NG & rsquo ; s solution , wa examined in detail . During the process , NG & rsquo ; s VP met with the DDR & amp ; D director and thanked him & ndash ; in writing and in person & ndash ; for the opportunity to present the proposal to the committee . & nbsp ; In 2007 , upon taking office and facing lingering tension , defense minister Ehud Barak convened yet another hearing , calling for a re-presentation of the Nagel Committee finding and recommendation on each of the proposed solution , including another external presentation of the SKYGUARD system . Barak then ratified these recommendation , declared development of Iron Dome a essential , and allocated the needed budget out of the Defense Ministry budget . & nbsp ; Following this approval , final negotiation were conducted with Rafael , the project wa submitted to the government , and it wa officially approved . In December 2007 , Rafael signed a contract with the Israeli government for the development and equipping of the first two Iron Dome battery . & nbsp ; From this point , development of the project wa expedited by Rafael , ELTA and M-Prest under a DDR & amp ; D project team , led by then-Lt . - Col . Chicco with the close guidance of R & amp ; D director Gold . & nbsp ; Simultaneously , an unprecedented lobbying campaign for SKYGUARD kicked off , drafting senior retired military officer , academic and medium figure . This campaign led to serious incitement , with personal attack lobbed at director-general Pinhas Buchris , DDR & amp ; D director Keren and his deputy Nagel , who were dubbed the & ldquo ; high-priests of Iron Dome & rdquo ; by the campaign . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; The lobby & rsquo ; s effort included drafting PR expert , distributing marketing brochure , pushing defamation both online and in newspaper , and planning an approach to key US figure in an effort to harm the State of Israel . This wa revealed in article by Channel 11 & rsquo ; s Ayala Hasson and Channel 10 & rsquo ; s Raviv Drucker . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Buchris , Keren and Nagel were at the forefront of defending the decision to develop Iron Dome , while Gold and his team were working on developing the system with the industry . They held dozen of meeting with the leader of Israel & rsquo ; s northern and southern community , minister , MKs , member of the Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee , and member of the press and academia . Upon reviewing the factual data and decision-making process , almost every one of these individual understood that they had been fed nothing but misinformation , and withdrew their support of the lobbying campaign . & nbsp ; As part of his effort to defend the project , Buchris ( with Nagel ) traveled a part of a professional delegation to the US to see the THEL system in New Mexico . They met with representative from NG and with relevant member of the US military who explained that the decision to stop development of the project wa reached in consultation with Israel . Buchris returned to Israel more convinced than ever that the THEL system wa not relevant , and they were completely in support of the decision-making process . & nbsp ; In 2008 , Barak met with US secretary of defense Robert Gates , and they discussed way the US could support Israel in it attempt to protect the home front from high-trajectory missile . This wa largely motivated by America & rsquo ; s desire to prevent Israel from entering a war with Gaza . As a result of these meeting , a joint committee led by DDR & amp ; D & rsquo ; s Nagel and US Gen . Robin Rand wa formed to once again test each of the possible solution ( Iron Dome , SKYGUARD , Vulcan Planks and other proposed laser system ) . Again the conclusion wa reached that only Iron Dome could sufficiently supply the defense needed for Israel & rsquo ; s home front , while providing it leader the freedom to act a needed . & nbsp ; The Nagel-Rand committee again determined that the SKYGUARD system , still only on paper , wa not a suitable solution & ndash ; either for Israel or the US . As part of this committee , a delegation of US missile , radar , command and control , and laser expert arrived in Israel , conducted in-depth discussion and visited both DDR & amp ; D and the Israeli defense industry . While the first visit started with marked skepticism surrounding the feasibility of developing the system , it ended with admiration for the system , but with expectation that the project would not be completed on time or within budget . Yet one year later during a subsequent visit , the delegation wa enthralled by the pace of Iron Dome & rsquo ; s development and advancement in solving technical problem . They released a professional report , optimistic on the project & rsquo ; s success and keeping to the projected schedule and budget . & nbsp ; The Nagel-Rand Committee recommendation were presented to and subsequently approved by Keren , Buchris and Barak . They were then presented to relevant American stakeholder and resulted in then-president Barack Obama allocating $ 205 million in special assistance to the program . A central element of the committee & rsquo ; s proposal insisted that assistance be limited to equipping the Iron Dome system in an effort to prevent any future potential export restriction on the system and ensure development remained & ldquo ; blue and white & rdquo ; in it entirety . & nbsp ; In the decade following that decision , the US significantly increased it financial contribution to equipping additional Iron Dome system and launcher . Included in the 2016 Memorandum of Understanding between the US and Israel , pushed by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Obama ( which entered into force in fiscal year 2019 ) , a new , special section wa added allocating $ 500 million annually to ballistic missile defense , with the equipping of Iron Dome component being an important component thereof . & nbsp ; The past decade & ndash ; analysis and lesson learned & nbsp ; Today , the Iron Dome missile defense system is highly regarded in professional , political , military and civilian circle both in Israel and abroad , and ha received numerous prize and praise for it groundbreaking military innovation and success in saving life . The term & ldquo ; Iron Dome & rdquo ; ha become ingrained in the Hebrew lexicon , synonymous with incredible success . & nbsp ; Despite it operational and technological success , those initial naysayer were not quick to mute themselves or their criticism . At the tactical level , Iron Dome & rsquo ; s operational capability were called into question , while at the strategic level , concern were raised that the damage outweighed any benefit , especially given the negative impact on the national-level decision-making process and international legitimization . & nbsp ; They claimed that Iron Dome , with the passage of time , had become a burden rather than an asset and a double-edged sword . An academic research project conducted at the National Security College , guided by one of the author of this article , analyzed Iron Dome & rsquo ; s impact on the Israeli National Security Strategy & ndash ; economically , militarily , socially and politically . After a decade of operational experience and more than 2,500 successful interception , the research conclusively find that the Iron Dome system is a first-class asset and clear barrier breaker , not remotely resembling a double-edged sword . Iron Dome often change the decision-making process of Israel & rsquo ; s political echelon , and our enemy & rsquo ; method and tactic . & nbsp ; Iron Dome is a key element of Israel & rsquo ; s multi-layered defense array , developed to protect the home front from incoming missile threat . While Iron Dome protects against short-range threat , the David & rsquo ; s Sling system defends against mid-tier threat , and the Arrow system defend against upper-tier threat . & nbsp ; The US Army , facing many threat similar to Israel , decided to procure two Iron Dome battery a an interim solution while deciding what the most appropriate enduring solution would be for it need . Simultaneously , the US Marines also expressed interest in the system and have conducted several successful test in America . & nbsp ; The continued collaboration between Israel and the US in the development and equipping of Iron Dome contributes to strengthening the strategic and technological collaboration between the two country and their defense of their respective civilian and service member . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; AS WE celebrate 10 year since Iron Dome & rsquo ; s first interception , we are reminded of the importance of recalling the overall goal that led decision-makers to develop this system : & bull ; Life and limb : Save life above all else , almost at any cost . & bull ; Strategic asset : Protect strategic facility , military facility and national infrastructure . & bull ; Economic defense : Reduce the amount of direct and indirect economic damage ( cost of property , human casualty and injury ) and prevent interference with the economy and national gross production . & nbsp ; & bull ; Strategic flexibility : Provide additional option to political decision-makers by reducing the risk posed by incoming rocket . & bull ; Ability to act : Increase the military & rsquo ; s freedom to act via the ability to carry out offensive operation free from the fear of retaliatory rocket attack . & bull ; Confidence : Raise the national morale and spirit , decrease the psychological impact on the population caused by image of damage and destruction , especially in the age of social medium . & nbsp ; IN-DEPTH ANALYSIS of relevant event of the past decade lead to determination of success on several level , such a : & bull ; Economic perspective : A review of the past decade & rsquo ; s economic data prof beyond all doubt that Iron Dome certainly stand up to the economic test . This is further supported with the realization that the comparison can not be between the cost of the interceptor and the cost of a missile , but rather the total cost of a launch compared to the direct and indirect economic consequence resulting from incoming enemy missile scoring direct hit . & bull ; Societal Perspective : Iron Dome , a an effective defense system , significantly contributes to Israel & rsquo ; s sense of community and national pride . It contributes to Israel & rsquo ; s degree of resilience by reducing overall level of fear and anxiety , creating a unified home front with all it civilian feeling protected . In the battle over public opinion , the system also contributes to Israel & rsquo ; s story of success over the enemy and improves overall morale both during and after period of combat . However , it is also important to note that the system & rsquo ; s past success creates a danger of an illusion of security to civilian . To prevent such negative surprise , it is essential that our leader set reasonable expectation for citizen . Outlook for the next decade & nbsp ; Over the past decade , Iron Dome provided unprecedented superiority . During the next decade , we can expect enemy will respond with technological effort of their own . All sign suggest they have already started , and thus there is no time to waste . Testing , improvement and adaptation of Iron Dome are constantly required a a way to ensure it maintains it legendary superiority . This is an endless battle in the fight between the threat and the interceptor . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Without getting into specific , it is clear that every system ha limitation and vulnerability . However , if we do not put forth every effort to further it innovation and renewal , our adversary will detract from Iron Dome & rsquo ; s effectiveness and superiority . There is no indefinitely hermetic defensive solution . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; We can not rest on our laurel . We must consistently test the enemy & rsquo ; advancement and threat trend , and adapt our system to achieve optimal effective defense , in order to maintain relevance on the future battlefield . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; ONE KEY area of interest is laser-based solution . & nbsp ; During the Iron Dome decision-making process and continuously ever since , baseless allegation have been made related to the performance of laser-based system versus kinetic interception-based system using missile . & nbsp ; Each solution ha advantage and disadvantage that are important to raise and understand . Understanding the pro and con of a laser-based system is especially important today , given the great progress recently made in Israel in technology development . & nbsp ; It is critical to correct some of the factually incorrect argument in favor of transitioning to a laser-based system : & bull ; & ldquo ; A laser-based interception system will prevent disruption to daily life , a it is an almost perfect and hermetic system . & rdquo ; Hermetic system do not exist , and it is clear that with any system , daily routine will be disrupted . In any case , the performance of the missile-based system seems to be better than those based on laser . & bull ; & ldquo ; Laser system will better handle barrage attack . & rdquo ; Actually , the opposite is true and this is one of the most compelling disadvantage to a laser-based system , since such a system & rsquo ; s primary role would be to handle a series of threat . Statements alleging & ldquo ; interception at the speed of light & rdquo ; are misleading . While the beam can reach it target at the speed of light and notably faster than a missile , it must remain on each target for several second to destroy it ( how long can not be revealed ) and largely depends on the threat variant , the strength of the beam and it distance from the target . The laser-based system would be quite limited in it ability to counter attack salvo ( unless it could be built with multiple beam , meaning another system , which would substantially increase the overall cost ) . In multi-purpose missile-based system , the missile are launched independently , are operated simultaneously by the system and operate instantaneously on the target to counter incoming threat . & bull ; & ldquo ; Laser system don & rsquo ; t require adaptation for new threat . & rdquo ; Laser-based system are not robust , and each threat need to be programmed for separately . & nbsp ; ON FEBRUARY 8 , 2020 , the Defense Ministry announced a groundbreaking technological achievement in the development of the solid-state laser . The depth and gravity of this achievement are noteworthy , a is it potential for strengthening Israel & rsquo ; s low tactical defensive layer capability . The correct and planned use of this new technology add to the interception capability in a newer , cheaper way , based on an understanding of it limitation . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; While this is a major advancement that allows for a demonstration of the system & rsquo ; s battlefield capability , the full operational range of the system is still several year and hundred of million of shekel of development away . There is no doubt that the addition of a laser interceptor , alongside the classic Iron Dome interceptor , will improve overall performance and will also be beneficial to Israel & rsquo ; s partner , including the US . & nbsp ; IN SUMMARY , after a decade of operational work of the Iron Dome system , it can be said that we must tip our hat to all those who have worked on this project over the past 15 year , the decision-making stage , development of the system , it integration and it transition into successful operationalization and use , through continuous improvement along the way . & nbsp ; That being said , Iron Dome is not yet complete , and it will likely continue for many year to come . Our enemy are learning the system all the time and without question they never cease to try to surprise u . The role of all those involved is to always be one step ahead of them . Brig . - Gen . & nbsp ; ( re ) & nbsp ; Prof . & nbsp ; Jacob & nbsp ; Nagel & nbsp ; is & nbsp ; a & nbsp ; senior & nbsp ; fellow & nbsp ; at & nbsp ; the & nbsp ; Foundation & nbsp ; for & nbsp ; the & nbsp ; Defense & nbsp ; of & nbsp ; Democracies & nbsp ; ( FDD ) & nbsp ; and a visiting professor in the aeronautics and space faculty at & nbsp ; the & nbsp ; Technion . & nbsp ; Nagel & nbsp ; served & nbsp ; a & nbsp ; acting & nbsp ; national & nbsp ; security & nbsp ; adviser & nbsp ; and & nbsp ; head & nbsp ; of & nbsp ; the & nbsp ; national & nbsp ; security & nbsp ; council & nbsp ; under & nbsp ; Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu , serving a head of the committee that recommended the development of Iron Dome.Brig . - Gen . ( re ) Shachar Shohat is executive vice president of Rafael Advanced Defense Systems , previously serving a head of the Air Force & rsquo ; s Aerial Defense Unit . Shohat served a the Air Force representative on the Nagel committee .
title: iron dome developer set the record straight on it evolution

Body Text: The World Court of Justice unanimously ordered Israel , accused by South Africa of genocide in Gaza , to take all necessary and effective action to ensure basic food supply to the enclave 's Palestinian population and halt the spreading of famine.Judges at the World Court , also known a the International Court of Justice , said the Palestinians in Gaza face worsening condition and famine and starvation were spreading . `` The court observes that Palestinians in Gaza are no longer facing only a risk of famine . . . but that famine is setting in , `` the judge said in their order . South Africa requested the new measure a part of it ongoing case that accuses Israel of state-led genocide in Gaza.There wa no immediate comment from Israel 's Foreign Ministry on the ruling . Israel ha said it wa making effort to expand access for humanitarian aid to Gaza overland , through airdrop and by ship to the enclave 's Mediterranean coast.Spokesperson Matthew Miller said on Thursday afternoon that the State Department will review the ICJ order before reacting . `` But a a general proposition , of course , increasing humanitarian assistance to Gaza is something that we support and something that we have urged Israel to help facilitate , `` Miller said.However , Miller wa clear in saying that the US doe not believe a genocide ha taken place or that it 's an appropriate or constructive term to use in this instance.In January , the International Court of Justice ( ICJ ) , also known a the World Court , ordered Israel to refrain from any act that could fall under the Genocide Convention and to ensure it troop commit no genocidal act against Palestinians after South Africa accused Israel of state-led genocide in Gaza.Ireland said on Wednesday it would intervene in South Africa 's genocide case against Israel . Foreign Minister Micheal Martin announced the move.Martin did not say what form the intervention would take or outline any argument or proposal Ireland plan to put forward.Israel and it Western ally described the allegation a baseless . Those may include Hapoel Jerusalem & rsquo ; s Randolph , Hapoel Holon big man Justin Smith along with Hapoel Tel Aviv & rsquo ; s center Jaylen Hoard , to name a few.The upcoming campaign will be complex and challenging without a doubt , but the most important thing for Maccabi will be to be able to adapt on the fly and adjust a it did this season . & ldquo ; There are a lot of question mark . Body Text: CONTROVERSY OVER the awarding of the Israel Prize ha not yet subsided . Attorney Batya Kahana Dror recently filed an urgent petition to the High Court of Justice seeking to prevent Sephardi Chief Rabbi Yitzhak Yosef from receiving the Israel Prize for Torah Literature , which wa announced in March . Kahana Dror & rsquo ; s complaint ha nothing to do with Torah literature , but with Yosef & rsquo ; s remark on the haredi draft , which have been interpreted a encouraging draft-dodging by ultra-Orthodox young men considered eligible for army service . The Movement for Quality Government filed a similar complaint in March , calling for the rabbi & rsquo ; s removal from the Great Rabbinical Court of Appeals in a letter to Uri Shoham , the Israeli judiciary & rsquo ; s ombudsman.The letter accused Yosef of overstepping his role by supporting the attempt to prevent the enactment of legislation that would force ultra-Orthodox youth to perform military service . Yosef wa reported to have said that if there is a change from the status quo whereby exemption from military service will no longer be valid , ultra-Orthodox youth will leave the country in drove . As a public servant who receives his salary from the state , Yosef spoke out of turn , and what he said wa a form of incitement . He ha since stated that he wa misunderstood , but to no avail . There have been call for his ouster and for the retraction of the award . There have also been demonstration against him.As ha happened in the past , the question arises a to whether a person should be judged only for achievement in the category in which he or she ha been named a an Israel Prize winner or whether the awarding of the prize should also be based on that person & rsquo ; s behavior and political and religious view and affiliations.Empty seat on Passover at the Great Synagogue ■ ONE OF the most demoralizing thing that could happen during a pilgrim festival , such a Passover , is to attend service at the majestic Jerusalem Great Synagogue and see that most of the seat are empty.There could be several reason for this.One is that people slept in after the Seder , having gone to bed at midnight or later . Another is that , due to numerous flight cancellation , many of the thousand of evacuee transferred to Jerusalem after October 7 have returned to their home , leaving no tourist to replace them . Yet another is the police warning following the terrorist attack in Jerusalem just ahead of the holiday ; fear may have kept some people at home.But , a always , the inspiring Great Synagogue choir , with it wide vocal range that accompanied Cantor Tzvi Weiss and wa conducted by Elli Jaffe , wa top-notch , even though it & rsquo ; s somewhat disconcerting that Weiss sings in the Ashkenazi pronunciation of Hebrew . Latecomers began to file in after the Bible reading , more so in the men & rsquo ; s section than in the woman & rsquo ; s , but there were still far too many empty seat in both.In nearby France Square , a long , symbolic Seder table had been set with artistically folded yellow paper napkin on each plate , empty wine bottle , and dead flower . Each chair had a large photograph of a hostage , affixed with his or her name , sending a powerful message . The symbolic high chair at the head of the table , which bore the portrait of Kfir Bibas , the youngest of the hostage , wa especially poignant . & nbsp ; The fact that the high chair wa at the head of the table wa reminiscent of the prophet Isaiah & rsquo ; s vision , which , in addition to including the wolf dwelling with the lamb and the leopard with the young goat and the lion , spoke of a small child who would lead them . & nbsp ; Though each and every hostage is equally important , none ha captured a much sympathy a Kfir Bibas , whose first birthday on January 18 wa spent in captivity in Gaza.The venue for the symbolic Seder wa appropriate in that there are synagogue within the distance of a kilometer in all direction , representing most stream of Judaism . Prayers and special psalm for the hostage have been incorporated into synagogue services.Hamas 's hostage video ■ THE VIDEO of Hersh Goldberg-Polin that wa released by Hamas last week and the timing of the release may possibly be attributed to two factor . One is that he is a dual national , holding American and Israeli citizenship , and the other is that his mother , Rachel Goldberg-Polin , wa included in Time Magazine & rsquo ; s list of the 100 most influential people . Goldberg-Polin ha been extremely active in the campaign by hostage family for the return of their loved one to Israel.Unfortunately , because the date of the video is unknown , no one know the true state of Hersh & rsquo ; s health . But what matter is that , hopefully , he & rsquo ; s alive , and unlike so many other parent who have no idea whether their son and daughter are alive , the Goldberg-Polins have at least received a sign , and they can play the video over and over again . It is so terribly important for hostage family to keep getting the word out , not just because they want more people to understand what ha happened and to imagine what it would be like if one of their loved one were captured by Hamas , but because Gilad Shalit had been heartened during his captivity by hearing on the radio that his family and the Israel government had not given up on him . His captor had allowed him to listen to the radio from time to time , which is why the message of relative of the hostage are rebroadcast several time a day , and the message always includes all the hostage , assuring them that the effort for their release are ongoing without let-up.Meanwhile , news of the release of the video , which wa the first sign of life that Hersh Goldberg Polin & rsquo ; s family have received since October 7 , prompted a spontaneous demonstration near the prime minister & rsquo ; s residence in Jerusalem with a demand to resume negotiation for the return of the hostage . The number of demonstrator quickly swelled into the hundred , necessitating police intervention . Police pushed the crowd back into France Square , where the noise level wa much louder than at demonstration last year.Tribute to the Dayan family ■ THE FINAL resting place of member of the famed Dayan family , whose contribution to the nation have been military , political , literary , and dramatic , includes Assi Dayan , the celebrated actor and filmmaker , who died on May 1 , 2014 , and his cousin Yehonatan Geffen , the author , poet , songwriter , journalist , satirist , and playwright who died on April 19 , 2023.Because Nahalal wa home to so many well-known personality , the cemetery , like the Trumpeldor Cemetery in Tel Aviv , is embedded in the nature of a tourist site , where the name on the tombstone are linked to the evolving history of the state.Writing in Maariv , the sister publication of The Jerusalem Post , journalist Lior Dayan , in paying tribute to his father Assi , who unfortunately wa a drug addict , observes that so often , when a parent dy , his or her child say they regret that there are so many thing they never got around to telling them . But that wa not the case with him and his father , Lior wrote . They told each other everything , candidly and without secret . At the start of the lengthy article , he mention how the tour guide & rsquo ; s anecdote about the Dayan family captivate the tourist group that visit the cemetery . On a recent visit to his father & rsquo ; s grave , he overheard a boy , standing with his mother , asking in relation to Assi , & ldquo ; So , what did he do ? & rdquo ; & ldquo ; He did a lot , & rdquo ; she replied . & ldquo ; A lot of good or a lot of bad ? & rdquo ; he persisted . & ldquo ; A lot of good for the public ; a lot of bad for himself , & rdquo ; she answered.In Lior & rsquo ; s opinion , this wa the most succinct and definitive summing up of who his father was.Aliza Bloch 's new book ■ POLITICAL LEADERS who lose to their opponent quickly learn that there is life beyond the corridor of power . Aliza Bloch , the immediate past mayor of Beit Shemesh , despite an intensely busy schedule during her period in office , nonetheless found time to prepare her new book , Bridges of Light , which she launched this month in the presence of Minister without Portfolio Chili Troper and several past and present politician , including member of the Beit Shemesh Municipal Council , a well a other well-known figures.ANZAC Day in Israel ■ ANZAC DAY , which commemorates the ill-fated dawn landing in Gallipoli by Australian and New Zealand troop on April 25 , 1915 , ha for many year been a day of remembrance for all the Australian and New Zealand soldier who died in the line of duty . In Israel , the ANZAC Day service is traditionally held at the Commonwealth War Graves Cemetery in Jerusalem at a reasonable hour of the morning , though one of the recent Australian ambassador insisted on a dawn service . It is usually hosted by the Australian ambassador and attended by military attach & eacute ; s & ndash ; and , occasionally , by ambassador of the Allied Forces that fought in the First World War & ndash ; a well a by representative of the Turkish and German embassy . This year , due to the current security situation and the Passover holiday , the service wa shorter than in past year , and instead of being held in Jerusalem , it took place at the Ramleh War Cemetery on Thursday of last week at the reasonable hour of 9.30 a.m . Kudos to Australian Ambassador Ralph King for refraining from a dawn service.greerfc @ gmail.com

Body Text: & nbsp ; Palestinian armed group have called for mass protest a the High Court is scheduled on Monday to issue a ruling on an appeal against the eviction of Palestinian family from their home in the east Jerusalem neighborhood of Sheikh Jarrah . & nbsp ; Lower court had ruled that several home in Sheikh Jarrah , known in Hebrew a Shimon HaTzadik , were owned by Jews before 1948 . Sources close to Bennet said that they did not expect the court to order the government to enforce any eviction order or to impose a deadline . & nbsp ; A statement issued by several Palestinian armed group on Sunday called on the Palestinians in the West Bank and Jerusalem to & ldquo ; ignite the flame of resistance under the foot of the Zionist occupier . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The occupation & rsquo ; s aggression against our people in Jerusalem and Sheikh Jarrah is increasing , & rdquo ; the statement read . & ldquo ; In addition , the aggression against the family threatened with displacement continues . The crime of the occupation have not stopped . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Voicing & ldquo ; full solidarity & rdquo ; with the Palestinians in Jerusalem and the West Bank , the terror group said that they will defend them a they did during the & ldquo ; Sword of Jerusalem & rdquo ; battle , the name Hamas us to describe it 11-day war with Israel last May . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The resistance group that defended the people of Jerusalem and the West Bank will not fail them , & rdquo ; the group added . & ldquo ; We call on our people in the West Bank and Jerusalem to continue to ignite the flame of resistance at all point of contact with the Zionist occupier , and to ignite the occupied land under the foot of the Zionist usurper . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Mohammed Hamadeh , a spokesperson for Hamas , warned Israel against & ldquo ; playing with fire & rdquo ; regarding the possible eviction of the Sheikh Jarrah family . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The Palestinian people , who refuse to give up and surrender , will continue to resist all attempt by the occupier [ to evict the family ] , & rdquo ; Hamadeh said . & ldquo ; We are ready to respond to the aggression of the occupation . What the resistance group did not allow in the past , they will not allow today or tomorrow . The occupation must learn the lesson and stop tampering with the Jerusalem neighborhood . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The Hamas official accused Israel of planning to & ldquo ; Judaize & rdquo ; Jerusalem and expel the Palestinians from the city . & nbsp ; Fatah activist in east Jerusalem also called for protest on Monday in solidarity with the Sheikh Jarrah family . & nbsp ; On the eve of the court ruling , Palestinian Authority Minister of Jerusalem Affairs , Fadi al-Hidmi , warned that any decision to evict the Palestinian family & ldquo ; would bring matter back to square one . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The case of the Sheikh Jarrah family ha reached & ldquo ; a critical and dangerous situation that requires urgent intervention by the international community , to prevent matter from returning to square one , & rdquo ; Hidmi cautioned . & nbsp ; He accused the Israeli government of presenting the case a a dispute over real estate and claimed that what is happening in Sheikh Jarrah is & ldquo ; a political issue par excellence . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The Israeli government & rsquo ; s attempt to show that this is a legal dispute over real estate & ldquo ; will not deceive anyone , & rdquo ; Hidmi said . & ldquo ; The whole world know that the issue is political , and that what is happening is an attempt to replace the original owner of the land with settler . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The PA official said that the Palestinians do not trust the Israeli court which , he claimed , & ldquo ; serve a an executive tool & rdquo ; that work for the benefit of the Israeli government and settler . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The international community , especially the US , the European Union and the United Nations , must be firm in rejecting the displacement plan , & rdquo ; Hidmi continued . & ldquo ; We do not rely on the Israeli court , and we believe that only firm and decisive international intervention can force the Israeli government to reverse it decision . Body Text: The coalition & rsquo ; s bloc is down to 48 mandate should there be election now , according to a poll conducted for Maariv by Lazar Research . This is against the backdrop of the northern border tension , the continued IDF operation in Rafah , and tension in the government on the haredi draft and rabbi bills.The opposition bloc rose to 62 mandate , without two Arab-led party , which would allow it , should it stay united , to formulate a coalition without being dependent on the Islamic Ra & rsquo ; am Party.The poll , led by Dr . Menachem Lazar , show the left-wing Meretz Party rising above the electoral threshold with four mandate while the Religious Zionist Party , led by led by Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich , remains below the threshold , with only 2.7 % support.The National Unity Party , led by former emergency government minister-without-portfolio Benny Gantz , dropped by one mandate from the previous poll and stand at 23 mandates.The poll , conducted in partnership with Panel4All , found that Likud is one step below National Unity with 22 mandate & ndash ; one more than the previous poll & ndash ; while Yesh Atid went from 15 to 16 mandate , Yisrael Beytenu stayed at a steady 14 , a did Shas with 10.For several week , the far-Right Otzma Yehudit Party ha been polling at nine mandate , United Torah Judaism at seven ; the Labor Party at five ; and Hadash-Ta & rsquo ; al and Ra & rsquo ; am , both at five.Who should be the next prime minister of Israel ? Of those polled , 42 % believe that Benny Gantz is the most suitable candidate for prime minister , while 35 % support Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu . The remaining 23 % are still undecided.Among right-wing voter , 2 % favor Gantz , and 90 % favor Netanyahu ; among center-left voter , 84 % are for Gantz and 3 % are for Netanyahu ; and among Arab party voter , 47 % are for Gantz and 0 % are for Netanyahu.The poll wa conducted on Wednesday among 510 respondent , constituting a representative sample of the adult population in Israel , Jews and Arabs alike.The maximum sampling error is 4.4 % .
