Body Text: After more than 30 year in office a mayor of Ma & rsquo ; aleh Adumim , Benny Kashriel wa psyching himself up to move to Rome a Israel & rsquo ; s next ambassador to Italy.In recent year , Kashriel had been offered several opportunity to get out of local politics and into the Knesset . But he wasn & rsquo ; t interested . Ma & rsquo ; aleh Adumim wa the love of his life , and he wa happy to stay there and devote all his energy to it development.But Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and former foreign minister Eli Cohen had other plan for him , and persuaded him to enter the diplomatic corp . As a loyal Likudnik , Kashriel could refuse for only so long.But there & rsquo ; s one major obstacle by way of geography . Ma & rsquo ; aleh Adumim is located in the West Bank . That hasn & rsquo ; t deterred some leftist from living there , but it is a red rag to Italy , which decline to accept a West Bank & ldquo ; settler & rdquo ; a an ambassador in Rome.Even though he wa not due to take up the appointment till well into the summer , at this stage of the game Kashriel can not go back to being mayor , even though there are plenty of resident of Ma & rsquo ; aleh Adumim who would like to see him in that position.Hungary wa mentioned a a possible alternative , but the next ambassador to Hungary ha been approved both by Jerusalem and Budapest.The ideal situation would be for Israel to establish diplomatic relation with another country , and to accord Kashriel the honor of being Israel & rsquo ; s first ambassador there . But given Israel & rsquo ; s loss of popularity over event in Gaza , it & rsquo ; s unlikely for a new diplomatic relationship to materialize in the foreseeable future.Quickly forgotten & nbsp ; ■ ONE OF the sad thing about public figure is that once they resign or retire , they are quickly forgotten.A case in point is Moshe Mizrahi , who in the course of a long career served a director-general of both the office of the president and the prime minister , and met score of local and foreign dignitary while safeguarding the interest of five prime minister and two president . Mizrahi & rsquo ; s successor began to capture the interest of the medium , and Mizrahi wa all but forgotten , except by veteran journalist and by leading figure of his generation.Like many people who have led exciting and meaningful life , and who have made significant contribution to the history of their respective nation , Mizrahi decided to write a memoir , which he launched at the Peres Center for Peace and Innovation , where speaker included retired Supreme Court justice Elyakim Rubinstein , MK Avigdor Liberman , who ha known Mizrahi for some 30 year , Matan Vilna & rsquo ; i , a former deputy chief of staff of the IDF , politician , and diplomat , and Efrat Duvdevani , the director-general of the Peres Center.All four spoke of Mizrahi & rsquo ; s strong sense of patriotism , his dedication , and his important contribution to the nation and it security.Mizrahi also took a copy of his book to the President & rsquo ; s Residence and personally presented to President Isaac Herzog , who , a the son and nephew of several of the nation & rsquo ; s dignitary , wa familiar with episode and people mentioned in the book , and enjoyed reading about them a he skimmed through it.Abducted Holocaust historian named honoree of the 2024 Jan Karski Eagle Award & nbsp ; ■ The Jan Karski Society ha named abducted Holocaust historian Alex Dancyg a the honoree of the Jan Karski Eagle Award for 2024.In May 2000 , only two month before his death , Karski established the award to be presented to people who have distinguished themselves by defending human right , speaking out against aggression and on behalf of the integrity of ethnic and religious group and sovereign nations.A Polish soldier , member of the Resistance during the Second World War , diplomat , academic , and author , Karski wa captured by the Gestapo and tortured . He wa smuggled out of prison , and , in an attempt to stop the Holocaust , traveled to Britain and the United States , to tell Allied leader of what the Nazis had done to Poland and how they were exterminating the Jews of Europe.He migrated to the US after the war , but his heart remained in Poland , where he wa always held in high esteem , a he wa in Israel , where he wa named Righteous Among the Nations and wa awarded honorary citizenship.Warsaw-born Dancyg , who wa associated with Yad Vashem , and who led many group to Poland and facilitated dialogue between Polish and Israeli youth , wa abducted by Hamas from his home at Kibbutz Nir Oz and taken to Gaza . Both Poland and Israel mounted campaign for his return.Dancyg wa mentioned by President Andrzej Duda at the traditional Hanukkah candle-lighting ceremony at the Presidential Palace in Warsaw.Speaking in the presence of Poland & rsquo ; s Chief Rabbi Michael Schudrich and Israeli Ambassador Yacov Livne , Duda noted that the Hanukkah candle-lighting tradition had been inaugurated by president Lech Kaczynski on December 18 , 2006 , and had taken place annually ever since.Duda said he is glad that after the Holocaust and other tragedy , citizen of Poland had over the past 30 year experienced the restoration of Jewish tradition and Jewish culture.Dancyg is not the first member of the Jewish faith to be considered deserving of the Jan Karski award . Others have included anti-Communist dissident Adam Michnik , former director of the Anti-Defamation League Abe Foxman , former president and prime minister Shimon Peres , and author , philosopher and Holocaust survivor Eli Wiesel.Canceling the Israel Prize category ■ IT & rsquo ; S AMAZING the extent to which Education Minister Yoav Kisch manages to get himself into hot water . Up until now he ha managed to extricate himself , but it will take a lot more effort this time , with his decision to cancel the Israel Prize award in a year in which Israel most definitely need a morale booster.But worse than the cancellation itself is the reason for it & ndash ; the fact that the Science Prize wa to be awarded to Eyal Waldman , one of the most outspoken critic of Netanyahu and the planned judicial reform.Initially , Kisch wanted to simply cancel the category . But then he declared that because Israel is at war , it would be inappropriate to hold the Israel Prize award ceremony this year.Why ? So many other event that are traditionally held on Independence Day will be held a usual . Look how many event are being held around the country for International Women & rsquo ; s Day.Aside from that , if Kisch wanted to cancel or postpone the Israel Prize award ceremony , why did he not do so month ago ? Why wait till the adjudicating committee & rsquo ; s choice of Waldman wa made public ? Why humiliate a bereaved father whose daughter Danielle and her boyfriend were murdered by Hamas ? Previous Israel Prize scandal ■ SOMETHING AS honorable a the Israel Prize should not be marred by scandal . Unfortunately , the current episode is not the first or even the second.In 1992 , Emile Habibi , an Arab politician who wa also a gifted writer , wa awarded the Israel Prize for Arabic literature.Arab nationalist pressured him not to accept it , but Habibi , who two year earlier had been awarded the Al Quds Prize for literature , argued that his being awarded the Israel Prize signified official recognition of a national culture , adding that a dialogue over prize wa preferable to arguing over stone and bullets.There were many Jews who also objected to Habibi receiving the Israel Prize , so much so that right-wing die-hard Yuval Neeman , who had received the Israel Prize for physic in 1969 , returned it in 1992 to emphasize his displeasure.There wa also a scandal the following year , in 1993 , when Yeshayahu Leibowitz , a controversial , outspoken Orthodox philosopher and scientist , wa selected to receive the Israel Prize . Leibowitz had urged Israeli soldier to refuse order that would in any way be harmful to peaceful Palestinians . Yitzhak Rabin , who wa then prime minister , declared that he would not attend the ceremony if Leibowitz wa to receive the prize.Unwilling to fan the flame of controversy on the most important national day of the year , Leibowitz declined to accept the prize.The year 2021 wa an uncomfortable one for Yoav Gallant , who wa then education minister , with two Israel Prize scandal on his hands.One of the people selected for the prize wa Yehuda Meshi-Zahav , a haredi and former anti-Zionist activist who founded ZAKA and changed his attitude to the extent of sending his son to the army.But after it wa announced that Gallant had informed him of his selection for the Israel Prize , story began to surface about year of sexual abuse that Meshi-Zahav had inflicted on both religious and secular women.As police began their investigation , Meshi-Zahav decided to forgo the prize and also resigned from ZAKA . He subsequently tried to commit suicide , but wa rescued by one of his son . However , he remained in a coma for more than a year before he died.In 2021 , Prof . Oded Goldreich of the Weizmann Institute of Science wa also selected to be awarded the Israel Prize . His category wa mathematics . But Gallant refused to accept the recommendation of the jury , alleging that Goldreich supported the Boycott , Divestment and Sanctions movement.Goldreich denied the allegation , stating that all he had done wa to add his signature to those on a petition calling on the EU to halt it funding to Ariel University , which is located in the West Bank.The jury petitioned the High Court of Justice on Goldreich & rsquo ; s behalf , and fellow Prof . David Harel , who wa among the Israel Prize winner in 2004 , offered to share his prize with Goldreich.Yifat Shasha-Biton , who had succeeded Gallant a education minister , agreed with his decision on Goldreich . But a month later , Avichai Mandelblit , who wa then the attorney-general , told the High Court that in his opinion the prize should be awarded to Goldreich.In March 2022 , the court ruled that the prize should be awarded to Goldreich , who eventually received the prize in a private ceremony at the Education Ministry , and announced that he would donate the prize money of NIS 75,000 to five human right organization , including Breaking the Silence.Netanyahu would earn brownie point if he made a public statement to the effect that the Israel Prize is awarded on merit in a certain field , and that it should in no way be influenced by political considerations.He should add that even though he and Waldman are at complete odds politically , he recognizes Waldman & rsquo ; s contribution to technology , and will be pleased to congratulate him on that issue at the Israel Prize ceremony.Israeli professor awarded world & rsquo ; s most prestigious prize for brain research ■ AS PRIZES go , the medium are , of course , focused on the Israel Prize , and in paying so much attention , some medium outlet may overlook the fact that an Israeli ha been awarded the world & rsquo ; s most prestigious prize for brain research.Prof . Haim Sompolinsky , a physicist and neuroscience researcher at the Edmond and Lily Safra Center for Neuroscience at the Hebrew University and professor at the Center for Brain Science at Harvard University , is the first Israeli scientist to receive The Brain Prize , which is awarded by the Lundbeck Foundation to pioneer in the field of neuroscience . He share the & euro ; 1.3 million prize with Prof . Larry Abbott of Columbia University and Prof . Terrence Sejnowski of the Salk Institute.Sompolinsky is widely acclaimed for his groundbreaking work in theoretical and computational neuroscience , particularly in the study of neural circuit dynamic in the brain . His research ha significantly contributed to the understanding of how neural circuit process and encode information , map the external world , and participate in learning and memory . Through a combination of theoretical and computational approach , his work ha elucidated key computational principle underlying brain function.The Brain Prize , initiated in 2011 and awarded annually by the Lundbeck Foundation , is considered the most prestigious award in neuroscience . It recognizes researcher whose work ha advanced the field , from fundamental research to clinical application . Sompolinsky & rsquo ; s research not only deepens the knowledge of the brain & rsquo ; s inner working but also hold promise for application in brain-inspired artificial intelligence.In congratulating Sompolinsky , Hebrew University President Prof . Asher Cohen stated : & ldquo ; Prof . Sompolinsky & rsquo ; s Brain Prize triumph is a testament to his pioneering contribution in computational neuroscience , unraveling neural circuit dynamic and laying the foundation for insight into information processing . His groundbreaking work inspires artificial intelligence , blending experimentation and theory to illuminate fundamental computational principle in brain function . & ldquo ; This recognition not only honor his exceptional achievement but serf a a beacon guiding u toward further revelation at the intersection of neuroscience and computation . & rdquo ; Sompolinsky and his two colleague will receive the 2024 Brain Prize at a ceremony in Copenhagen in June.Brain Prize recipient were previously presented with their award by the crown prince of Denmark , who is now king . It is not yet known whether he will continue to do so in his role a monarch.Sompolinsky is the son of the late Prof . David Sompolinsky , who wa born in Denmark , and whose personal history wa one that pointed not only to academic success but also to heroism . Together with friend from the Danish underground , he saved hundred of Danish Jews from Nazi persecution in October 1943 by smuggling them on fishing boat to a safe haven in Sweden.Shai Piron call on haredi to enlist ■ FORMER EDUCATION minister Shai Piron , who is religious and studied in several yeshivot before , during , and after his service in the IDF , ha lost friend , colleague , and student in the war against Hamas . He ha called on haredi to enlist & ldquo ; because we need you . & rdquo ; Haredim have been extremely active in numerous civilian operation on behalf of soldier and evacuee . If they could take time out from Torah study , simply to do good , why not to defend ? Then again , some haredi men who have enlisted , because they understood the meaning of mutual responsibility , have been disappointed by not being called to fight after a year & rsquo ; s intensive training . One of them , in conversation on KAN Reshet Bet with Liat Regev , told her that he had not been called up , and did not know why , and he knew of other haredi young men who had voluntarily enlisted , spent a year in training , and were still sitting at home , waiting for a call-up.What is the point of this if the defense establishment doesn & rsquo ; t want to have haredi on the battlefield ? If it doe want them , why not call them up when they & rsquo ; re willing to fight and put their life on the line ? Haredim who sign up display special courage , because there is so much pressure on them from their family and their community not to do so . ■ ON ANOTHER , more personal issue , Piron is a pleased a punch . His daughter Or Piron Zomer campaigned to head the Oranit Council & ndash ; and triumphed . She is one of the very few female council head in Israel . ■ MOST OF the many International Women & rsquo ; s Day event are simply a mean of acknowledging the success of woman achiever in a variety of profession and entrepreneurial activity & ndash ; both social and business.Factory 54 , which specializes in high-class fashion and carry merchandise with the label of the world & rsquo ; s best-known designer , went one better on Tuesday , in that the event that it hosted at it store in the Ramat Aviv Mall wa for the benefit of the next generation.Held in conjunction with , and on behalf of , Babies for Life , an organization that rescue and adopts hungry infant during the first year of their life , and help single mother and family suffering from economic distress , the event featured noted broadcaster Dana Weiss and veteran singer Rita talking about everything and anything . The two celebs represent woman & rsquo ; s voice , and among the subject they discussed wa woman & rsquo ; s voice during the present war.The occasion also gave people who like to mingle with celebs the opportunity to do so . There were quite a few celebs on hand , in addition to the two who were conducting the conversation.Exchanging view on implication of genocide case ■ ISRAEL & rsquo ; S IMMEDIATE past attorney-general , Mandelblit , is currently in New York with Amit Becher , the president of the Israel Bar Association , to join UJA lawyer in a panel discussion in which they will exchange view on implication of the genocide accusation against Israel at the International Court of Justice and the future of judicial reform in Israel . The big question is whether the outcome in either case will affect Israel & rsquo ; s diplomatic status.Embassies celebrate independence day amid war & nbsp ; ■ BEARING IN mind the security situation , some embassy have canceled their traditional Independence Day reception , while others have thought up different way in which to celebrate.The Hungarian Embassy , for instance , will celebrate the anniversary of the 1848-49 Hungarian Revolution and War of Independence with an online screening of Gabor Herendi & rsquo ; s blockbuster movie Kincsem ( My Precious ) , which wa the name of the famous Hungarian thoroughbred racehorse with the longest undefeated record in history , winning all of her 54 race . The movie is a period drama love story set in 19th-century Hungary.The link to the film and the required password can be acquired from the Hungarian Embassy at the email address rsvp.tlv @ mfa.gov.hu / . Registration by March 13 is essential . The link and password will be sent to the email address that would-be viewer have indicated , just before the start of the screening , which is scheduled for 5 p.m . on Thursday , March 14 . When registering please state how many viewer there will be.Following the screening the movie will be available for an additional 24 hour to people who had other commitment on the above mentioned date to see it.Estonia set the trend ■ IT WAS published recently in this column that the Estonian Embassy wanted to celebrate it Independence Day with both fun and good deed . Estonian Ambassador Veikko Kala may have started a trend among some of his colleague . The idea wa that all the guest would congregate at the Cooking Studio in Tel Aviv , and under the supervision of professional chef would prepare kosher meal for evacuee , thereby adding to Israel & rsquo ; s national resilience.Many of the invitee loved the idea , and some 120 showed up & ndash ; approximately half of them diplomat and half Israelis , a well a friend who were neither diplomat nor Israelis . Altogether , there were more than the embassy expected.Each participant received the gift of an Estonian apron with the embassy logo and the slogan & ldquo ; Estonia cook with you . & rdquo ; During approximately one and a half hour , they prepared salmon , beef stew , roast chicken , beef patty , and tofu , served with rice , potato , and green bean . Anyone hoping for a taste of Estonian cuisine wa disappointed , but it wa such a fun evening that no one minded the Israeli fare that wa served afterward with wine.Guests who had minimal kitchen experience quickly learned to chop , slice , cook , and pack.Generally , when one talk of stirring the pot , it mean causing tension , but in this case Gil Haskel , chief of State Protocol , wa literally stirring the pot a he shared a work counter with Croatian Ambassador Vesela Korac and the deputy head of mission of Portugal and Italy.Some 300 meal were prepared , and because the date coincided with the second anniversary of the Russian invasion of Ukraine , recipient included Israeli evacuee and Ukrainian refugee who are being sheltered in Israel for the duration of the war in their homeland.An extra bonus for the guest wa that many were working side by side with people they had not previously known , and were thus able to make new friend with ease.After all their work , they were rewarded with a mouthwatering supper washed down with excellent wine.greerfc @ gmail.com

Body Text: Two separate incident that took place in the West Bank over the past few day underlined the discrepancy between the Palestinian Authority & rsquo ; s rhetoric in public and it action on the ground . & ldquo ; The Palestinian Authority is a real Jekyll and Hyde , & rdquo ; a Ramallah-based Western diplomat remarked this week with reference to the inconsistency . & ldquo ; The Palestinian Authority & rsquo ; s rhetoric towards Israel is bad , but it action on the ground , especially the security coordination with the Israeli security authority , are good . & rdquo ; The diplomat & rsquo ; s remark is shared by many Palestinians who are familiar with the inner working of the PA . In the first incident , two Israeli woman in their 40 were spotted by Palestinians late at night driving their car alone inside al-Ama & rsquo ; ri refugee camp at the entrance to Ramallah and it twin city , El-Bireh . The camp is considered a stronghold of Palestinian militant belonging to various group , including those opposed to PA President Mahmoud Abbas and his ruling Fatah faction . The PA security force are often reluctant to enter al-Ama & rsquo ; ri to avoid friction with the group . In this case , however , a soon a the PA security force were informed about the presence of the Israeli woman in the camp , they rushed to the scene and safely escorted them out and handed them over to the IDF . The second incident took place in the PA-controlled part of Hebron , a city traditionally known a a stronghold of Islamist group , particularly Hamas and Hizb ut-Tahrir ( Party of Liberation ) . A bus carrying IDF soldier that accidentally entered Hebron wa safely escorted by PA security force out of the city . No one wa hurt and minimal damage wa caused to the bus a a result of rock-throwing by a small number of Palestinians . The two incident could have ended in a tragic way , were it not for the intervention of the PA security force . Had any of the woman or soldier been harmed , this would have resulted in a serious deterioration in the security situation on the ground and renewed tension between the new Israeli government headed by Prime Minister Naftali Bennett and the PA . Such an escalation would also have dealt a severe blow to the Biden administration & rsquo ; s effort to rebuild confidence between Israel and the Palestinians with the hope of reviving the stalled peace process . The Biden administration ha endorsed a policy that seek to bolster the standing of the PA a a way of countering the rising popularity of Hamas . The Americans want the Israeli government to follow suit by engaging with PA official and refraining from unilateral move , including the eviction of Arab family from their home in the east Jerusalem neighborhood of Sheikh Jarrah . Indeed , Bennett & rsquo ; s government and the PA leadership appear to be moving toward some form of rapprochement . In addition to the continuing security coordination , Israeli and PA minister recently met for the first time in several year . Moreover , the government ha agreed to increase the number of permit for Palestinians who wish to work in Israel , and , according to Palestinian source , senior PA official whose VIP card were confiscated by the previous government of Benjamin Netanyahu have gotten them back . Some Palestinians maintain that the security coordination between the PA security force and the IDF never stopped , not even when Abbas and other Palestinian institution claimed that they had suspended all tie with Israel , including in the security field . The incident in Ramallah and Hebron were not the first of their kind . Several case involving Israeli ( Jewish ) citizen who were seen by the Palestinians inside Area A of the West Bank have been returned safely to Israel , thanks to the effort of the PA security force . Entry into this area , which is controlled exclusively by the PA , is forbidden to all Israeli citizen . Israel , however , doe not stop Arab-Israelis from entering Area A . Most of the case involving Israelis caught in Area A are not publicized , probably in order to avoid embarrassing the PA . Each time Palestinians learn that the PA security force & ldquo ; rescued & rdquo ; Israeli citizen caught in Area A , they accuse the Palestinian leadership of & ldquo ; collaboration & rdquo ; and serving a & ldquo ; subcontractor & rdquo ; for the Israeli security establishment . But the security coordination is not a one-way relationship benefiting Israel alone . Abbas wa quoted a few year ago a telling a group of Israelis who visited him at the Mukata presidential compound in Ramallah that security coordination [ with Israel ] is & ldquo ; sacred . & rdquo ; Although Abbas did not elaborate , it & rsquo ; s obvious that the Palestinians , too , enjoy the fruit of this coordination . First , the PA and Israel have a common enemy in the West Bank & ndash ; Hamas . Abbas is well aware that without Israel & rsquo ; s security presence in the West Bank , Hamas and another Iranian-backed proxy , Palestinian Islamic Jihad , would pose a direct threat to the PA . Second , the security coordination ensures the continued flow of fund to the PA from the Americans , Europeans and other international party . In a bid to further curry favor with the Western donor , including the Biden administration , Abbas and senior PA official have recently indicated their readiness to return to the negotiating table with Israel under the auspex of the Quartet member & ndash ; US , European Union , United Nations , and Russia . PA official who are talking about their dissatisfaction with the Bennett government are actually sending a message to the Biden administration that it need to get more involved in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict . YET WHILE Palestinian security officer are & ldquo ; rescuing & rdquo ; Israelis who accidentally enter Area A , and a the security coordination appears to be continuing in full force and effect , the rhetoric of the PA and Fatah toward Israel remains a toxic a ever . This is precisely why many Palestinians and Israelis are confused about the real intention of the PA leadership . On the one hand , the PA is telling Palestinians that it want to prosecute Israelis for & ldquo ; war crime & rdquo ; and & ldquo ; ethnic cleansing & rdquo ; before international forum , including the International Criminal Court . The PA is also telling Palestinians that there is no difference between the Bennett government and the Netanyahu government , especially regarding the policy of settlement construction and the & ldquo ; Judaization & rdquo ; of Jerusalem . On the other hand , this is the same PA that is allowing it minister and security official to hold meeting with their Israeli counterpart . Similarly , many in Israel still can not figure out whether the PA is an ally or an enemy . The PA & rsquo ; s deed and rhetoric suggest that it is both an ally and an enemy . It is an ally when it come to working with the IDF in maintaining security and stability in the West Bank . It is an enemy when it come to the fiery rhetoric of PA official and medium outlet . & ldquo ; The Palestinian Authority ha always excelled in sending conflicting message to both the Palestinians and the Israelis , & rdquo ; remarked a veteran Palestinian journalist from Ramallah . & ldquo ; The Palestinians have long become used to the duplicity of the Palestinian leadership . & rdquo ; The PA & rsquo ; s action on the ground may be good for Israel in the short term . These action place the PA on the side of the good guy in the war on terrorism . In the long run , however , the anti-Israel rhetoric emerging from Ramallah is further radicalizing Palestinians . The PA , in other word , is driving more Palestinians into the welcoming arm of it own rival , Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad . The apparent rapprochement between the PA and the Israeli government and the Biden administration & rsquo ; s policy of & ldquo ; strengthening & rdquo ; the PA are critical for the continued survival of Abbas and his cohort . But this approach come with a cost . The closer Abbas move toward Israel and the US , the more he loses point with the Palestinian street . The Bennett government and the Biden administration may help the 85-year-old Abbas hold on to power , but there & rsquo ; s nothing the Israelis and Americans can do to help him regain the confidence of his people . Abbas & rsquo ; s decision to cancel the parliamentary election , which wa supposed to take place on May 22 , and the recent unprecedented massive security crackdown on Palestinian political activist , journalist and social medium user have severely undermined the credibility of the PA leadership . At this stage , it & rsquo ; s clear that the widespread discontent with the Ramallah-based leadership doe not pose an imminent threat to the PA . The PA security force remain loyal to Abbas , and the number of people willing to take to the street to demand & ldquo ; regime change & rdquo ; is declining every week . If and when the peace talk with Israel resume , Abbas is sure to face a radical reaction from the Palestinians . Under the current circumstance , the likelihood of marketing any agreement with Israel to the Palestinian public is zero . This statistical nonstarter is the direct result of the PA & rsquo ; s decades-long demonization of Israel , which remains one of the major obstacle to moving forward with any peace process .

Body Text: Just over a year ago , Stav Levi met Idan Shtivi , 28 , while she wa working for a brief period at Ijo & amp ; Babet , a wine bar on Tel Aviv & rsquo ; s Dizengoff Street . The chance meeting , a growing rarity in the age of online dating , sparked a deep love that ha grown over a relatively short time . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; One of the thing that defines Idan is his heart . He is quiet , but so profound and strong , & rdquo ; Levi say , smiling wanly , if only for an instant , a she enters the fourth week without him a her rock and partner . Idan is still missing , presumed to be held captive in the Gaza Strip a the deadly war that ha consumed Levi & rsquo ; s life wage on.Together , they camped and hiked throughout Israel , sharing a mutual love for nature and the environment & ndash ; a defining passion that led Idan to pursue a career in environmental science at Reichman University & rsquo ; s School of Sustainability , where he began his second year recently . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Idan is driven to make an impact in the world , with a desire to promote green energy and environmental conservation . He ha this connection to the earth , & rdquo ; explains his older brother , Omri , 30 , gazing across the crystal blue water of the Mediterranean Sea from his mother & rsquo ; s apartment in Tel Aviv . & nbsp ; Idan life for the water , and wa about to sign a new lease with Levi on October 9 in the seaside community of Ein Hayam . After three minute , Idan resurfaced , catching a huge fish and [ sporting ] a big smile . He is the kind of person who will always surprise you . He & rsquo ; s a survivor , and this is what help u to believe . & rdquo ; Maintaining his composure , Omri hold on to the belief that his brother & rsquo ; s survival instinct will soon return him to his family . & nbsp ; To his family and many friend , Idan is the anchor that imparts a sense of confidence , a reassuring presence to everyone around him that everything will always be okay . Idan & rsquo ; s family hold on to that feeling , trusting that Idan will persevere against all odds and return to them . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Growing up , Idan always made me feel secure , and I could always depend on him for everything . Whenever I am struggling , he is always there beside me , & rdquo ; say his sister , Hila , 24 , detailing to the extent that Idan would stay with her at night when she wa scared or had trouble sleeping , until she would fall asleep . & ldquo ; He & rsquo ; s this person who make you feel that you can do anything . Anything that need to be done , fixed , taken care of , that & rsquo ; s Idan . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Idan wa asked to photograph at Supernova music festivalAN AMATEUR photographer , Idan wa asked at the last minute by friend to take picture during the yoga and music workshop they were leading the next morning at the Supernova music festival near Kibbutz Re & rsquo ; im in the western Negev . Idan made sure to join his family for Shabbat dinner on October 6 before waking up at 5 a.m . to drive down to help capture the beauty of the peaceful gathering in the warm glow of the desert sun . This wa the last time his family saw him before the celebration of music and nature would become the epicenter of the most tragic event of their life . & ldquo ; Idan had only just arrived [ at the festival ] when I called him at 6:48 a.m . and he told me that rocket had started to go off . It wa just the rocket at this point . It wa only a matter of minute before gunshot were fired , & rdquo ; Levi recall a she sits at Idan & rsquo ; s mother & rsquo ; s kitchen table with Omri and Hila , recounting the haunting event that they continue to replay in their head . & nbsp ; Idan & rsquo ; s survival instinct quickly kicked in , calmly explaining to his girlfriend that they were packing up and getting ready to head home with the two friend he had traveled with . Just a they were about to leave , Idan saw another friend who wa wounded and took responsibility to drive his car , along with another girl , making sure to help everyone escape safely . & ldquo ; They were one of the first car to get out before anyone understood the extent of the real situation , at around 7:15 , & rdquo ; Omri elaborates , detailing every aspect of his brother & rsquo ; s attempted escape . & ldquo ; They had made it onto the main road before seeing it had been blocked by Hamas terrorist in stolen police car . He crossed over into the southbound lane , and only made it approximately 4 km . before it appeared that Hamas opened fire somewhere near the junction at Kissufim . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Without any photographic evidence , witness account , or Israeli intelligence to confirm if Idan is alive , Omri , Hila , and Levi face an ongoing nightmare that grows with each passing day . Desperate for answer , and plagued by uncertainty , Omri had to piece together the event that unfolded himself , tracking his brother & rsquo ; s location from his phone , looking through photograph of the carnage that took place , and eventually traveling himself to Idan & rsquo ; s last known location after a week without any information on his brother & rsquo ; s whereabouts . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; It wa absolute hell , and just to see it wa traumatic , & rdquo ; he recall . & ldquo ; Burnt car filled with bullet hole , the festival site wa destroyed & hellip ; I wa there for hour [ searching ] , but I quickly understood that the area wa enormous ; it would take thousand of people to search . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The car that Idan had driven wa bloodstained and filled with bullet hole , near a tree off the side of the road , leading Omri to understand that the terrorist continued to shoot at Idan and the two friend he had helped escape , before being forced to veer off the road . s goal , and one of the goal of the intervention center , is to provide people with tool to promote their independence and involvement in the community , and they work based on the belief that everyone deserves to be included in society.The child treated at these center go through a daily schedule that is very similar to what child their age experience in other framework , but in addition to their preschool day , they receive a wide variety of treatment , including occupational , speech , and physical therapy.From the outbreak of the war , it took around two week until Elwyn wa able to overcome the chaos of the beginning and to get organized , said Strul . & ldquo ; after the war & rsquo ; s outbreak , she said.Strul noted how important her organization & rsquo ; s ability to work independently wa , because it meant that Elwyn did not have to & ldquo ; wait for the Welfare and Social Affairs Ministry or the Home Front Command , who first needed to handle thing that were bigger than intervention center . & rdquo ; The mother & ldquo ; wa evacuated and had just received a diagnosis that her child is autistic . Before she came to u , she didn & rsquo ; t know what to do , & rdquo ; Strul said , explaining that the mother wa forced to leave her home right after receiving her child & rsquo ; s diagnosis and had no idea what framework wa appropriate for , or accessible to , her child during the war.To make matter more complicated , this mother & rsquo ; s husband wa called to reserve duty and wa unreachable in Gaza . She then she found out she wa pregnant with her second child . & ldquo ; You have to understand that the evacuee have a very difficult experience because they have been uprooted from their home , & rdquo ; said Strul , explaining that thing are especially hard when you & ldquo ; uproot a child with a disability from their home . & rdquo ; Strul shared that she marveled at the difficulty of the situation , asking herself how she could help someone handling so much chaos . & ldquo ; She [ the mother ] really fell apart , & rdquo ; described Strul.Along with her team , Strul helped the mother to find an appropriate framework , and providing this help gave Strul the chance to take action , which , in turn , helped her handle her own experience . It & ldquo ; made me sharper and kept me from sinking in the sadness and terrible grief we are all dealing with , & rdquo ; she explained.Personally helping this woman & ldquo ; took me to a place of & lsquo ; okay , I have a job to do , and I need to lead the team and help the family , and have some routine , & rsquo ; & rdquo ; she said , adding that this story made her stronger.ANOTHER ELEMENT that made thing emotionally difficult for many employee and intervention center family wa the mixed Arab-Jewish nature of many of Elwyn & rsquo ; s team , said Strul.This proximity at work & ldquo ; brought up the conflict that exists in the country , & rdquo ; she said . It wa hard to avoid sensitive topic , at a time when tension and emotion were so high.There were & ldquo ; parent whose child were in preschool with Arab staff , & rdquo ; which brought up fear for some of them , described Strul , adding that & ldquo ; this also impacted Arab employee who encountered Jewish parent who were uncomfortable with them . & rdquo ; Strul handled these feeling with open communication . & ldquo ; You have to give these feeling space , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; If you pretend these feeling don & rsquo ; t exist , they will come out in the end . So , first of all , we decided that we were going to give them space and talk about them on a local level . & ldquo ; If we saw that there were problem or conflict , feeling that sometimes aren & rsquo ; t apparent on the surface but are under the surface , we addressed them , & rdquo ; she said.IN ADDITION to the emotional turmoil of helping the family from their center , Elwyn & rsquo ; s staff had to contend with numerous logistical hurdles.Some of the center did not have appropriate shelter and needed to be totally relocated to space with adequate protection . Some center were too close to conflict zone , and needed to be totally evacuated.The organization offered a variety of solution , depending on the stage of the war and the unique need it presented . & ldquo ; We offered service from afar , using video . An occupational therapist would show parent how to help with their child & rsquo ; s treatment at home , & rdquo ; said Strul , who added that the organization recruited numerous volunteer to help provide these services.The organization also prepped the center & rsquo ; s shelter and drilled taking the child into the shelter in the appropriate time frame . Elwyn staff created special activity for the child to do while they were in shelter , to try to make the time pas more calmly.Caring for these family in the chaos of the war wa an incredible challenge , but no less of a challenge wa the job of caring for the early intervention center staff , Strul explained . & ldquo ; The son of one of our worker wa murdered at the [ Super ] nova music festival , & rdquo ; Strul recounted . & ldquo ; It wa a shock , encountering that on a personal level , when one of your worker loses her 21-year-old son . She wa totally broken , & rdquo ; said Strul , who added that handling this loss of someone who is a daily part of her life caused her to break down a well . & ldquo ; We accompanied her for the whole shiva [ mourning period ] and we were with her and came to visit her , & rdquo ; Strul said , adding that they also provided space for the staff to process the loss together.Many of Strul & rsquo ; s staff were also evacuated from their home in the North . & ldquo ; There wa a lot of thought put into what happens with those worker , how can we help them so they will come back to a sort of schedule , & rdquo ; Strul explained . & ldquo ; I don & rsquo ; t think there wa a single worker who did not get the care they needed , & rdquo ; she said.Looking forward , Strul feel prepared to handle whatever the continuation of the war , or possible escalation in the north , might throw their way.There is a feeling that the war is present . & ldquo ; There could be a siren today , & rdquo ; said Strul , & ldquo ; but it doesn & rsquo ; t occupy u daily . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; What is important is that , in an emergency , the staff know what to do with each child , where to take them , where the safe area is for each structure , who the Home Front Command contact is , what is in the shelter , what equipment , & rdquo ; she explained.Unexpected event will always be present , but Strul isn & rsquo ; t worried . When asked why , her answer is simple : & ldquo ; Because we are prepared for it . & rdquo ;
title: child disability organization face challenge during the war

Body Text: The Zimin Institute ha been at the forefront of scientific philanthropy for over six year , supporting research at university worldwide , including Tel Aviv University ( TAU ) . Its mission is to harness contemporary scientific insight to address humanity & rsquo ; s challenge , bridging the gap between theory and practicscienal application . An integral part of this process is the & ldquo ; Scope of Research , & rdquo ; where once a year , a scientific committee and an international committee both work to identify study that have the potential to create real change in the world , and for collaboration with other research team from around the world . In addition , the institute & rsquo ; s biannual international conference brings together leading academic , professional , and investor from around the world to create scientific partnership and develop breakthrough discoveries.Headed by Prof . David Mendlovic , the Zimin Institute at TAU is among the pioneering & ldquo ; Zimin Institutes for a Better World , & rdquo ; established by the Zimin Foundation . Driven by the vision of the late Dr . Dimitri Zimin , an engineer , entrepreneur , and philanthropist , these institute aim to integrate engineering research with medical and healthcare technology , aligning seamlessly with TAU & rsquo ; s multidisciplinary ethos . The institute take pride in funding numerous groundbreaking study , many of which are already making tangible impact in the healthcare industry , thus realizing Dr . Zimin & rsquo ; s vision of fostering positive change.A recent success story involves Zimin & rsquo ; s investment in early detection technology for fetal malformation and developmental disorder . Building on groundbreaking research in fetal electrocardiogram ( FECGs ) at TAU , this investment ha yielded promising result . FECG , the prevailing method for detecting developmental difference and fetal distress , is currently limited by it reliance on invasive technique or noisy maternal signal . In a breakthrough study , researcher Dr . Dan Raviv and Dr . Shai Tejman-Yarden propose a novel approach to extract FECGs from joint maternal-fetal data using deep learning model . Their method , personalized and self-supervised for each patient , demonstrates real-time extraction of high-quality maternal and fetal ECGs , offering a significant advancement in fetal monitoring accuracy.In the study , researcher Dr . Dan Raviv from the School of Electrical Engineering at TAU and Dr . Shai Tejman-Yarden from Sheba Hospital propose a new approach to extracting the FECG from the joint maternal-fetal data , which come attached to the common ECG sample from at least two source . They then train a Deep Learning model to separate the two in real-time . Because this is a difficult task , the researcher created a personalized and self-supervised network for patient . This method train individually on the data of each patient ( mother and fetus ) and can extract the maternal and fetal ECG in real-time and with high quality . Based on preliminary result using real-world data , the researcher demonstrate that the hypothesis and solution are applicable and feasible.Another medical project funded by the Zimin Institute that is already in it advanced stage is the TENG ( Triboelectric nanogenerator ) sensor , which can restore the sense of touch to people who have lost this sense due to injury , illness , chemotherapy , and more . The sensor is durable , small , and modular and operates using an independent energy source to restore tactile sensitivity without the need for an external energy source , and can be easily and safely implanted under the skin in a variety of place . Today there are million of people in the world who have lost their sense of touch , and there is currently no approved clinical solution capable of restoring their sensation . Through the unique support that the Zimin Institute offered to the team of researcher , led by Prof . Ben Maoz from the Department of Biomedical Engineering at TAU , a start-up company called Teng-Able wa established , and their sensor is currently in the clinical trial phase . & nbsp ;
title: the zimin institute at tau : promoting scientific solution for humankind ’ s challenge

Body Text: Israel ha remained officially silent regarding report that a team of Mossad agent were captured during a botched operation to kidnap a Hamas operative in Malaysia.On Tuesday , the first image of the group of 11 suspect & mdash ; 10 men and one woman & mdash ; were published a they were brought to the court where they were charged . & nbsp ; Sebelas individu termasuk seorang wanita didakwa di Mahkamah Majistret Kuala Lumpur atas pertuduhan menculik seorang lelaki warga Palestin bagi mendapatkan maklumat berkaitan perisian yang digunakan untuk menggodam telefon bimbit . 📹 Diana Barka | Bernama pic.twitter.com/VlECq54rHn & mdash ; BERNAMA ( @ bernamadotcom ) October 14 , 2022 '' The Israelis wanted to know about his experience in computer application development , Hamas ' strength in developing software , member of the Al-Qassam Brigade that he knew and their strength . `` Malaysian New Straits Times source & nbsp ; The botched Mossad operationThe abduction-style capture of the Gazan man , whose tie to Hamas were allegedly subject to a Mossad investigation , occurred in Kuala Lumpur on September 28 , according to local press.Malaysian mercenary allegedly operating on behalf of the Mossad drove up to two Palestinian national , who were reportedly computer programming expert . They dragged one into the vehicle & ndash ; warning the other to stay away & ndash ; and drove him to a secretive location , where he wa tied up and forced to answer question via a video call with Israeli agent , the Malaysian New Straits Times & nbsp ; reported . `` The Israelis wanted to know about his experience in computer application development , Hamas ' strength in developing software , member of the Al-Qassam Brigade that he knew and their strength , `` a source told the paper.Malaysian security force freed the Palestinian man and arrested the alleged Mossad operative 24 hour later , a the second alleged victim lodged a report at a Kuala Lumpur police station about 40 minute after the abduction.Malaysia and HamasOn Tuesday , Malaysian Home Minister Datuk Seri Hamzah Zainudin said the government would take action if the report were true . `` We should look into matter [ allegation ] like this , then we will announce [ further action ] , `` he said according to the Straits Times report.In 2020 , a Gazan imam wa sentenced to a year in jail for smuggling fund from Malaysian charity to Hamas , and in 2018 a Hamas-affiliated Palestinian engineer from the Gaza Strip wa shot dead in Kuala Lumpur in what many suspected wa a Mossad assassination .

Body Text: The French movie The Sixth Child , which opened in Israeli theater on Thursday , brings to mind the famous line from Jean Renoir & rsquo ; s The Rules of the Game : & ldquo ; The awful thing about life is this : everyone ha their reason . & rdquo ; The Sixth Child , directed by Leopold Legrand , is an intricately constructed tragedy about two couple who choose to make an awful but understandable decision , and they all have their reason . What & rsquo ; s brilliant about it is that , a heartrending a this story is , there are no obvious villain & ndash ; other than a heartless economy and an unfeeling adoption bureaucracy & ndash ; and no easy answers.As I watched the movie , my loyalty kept shifting among the character , and I wasn & rsquo ; t always sure where it wa going & ndash ; one of the highest compliment I can give any movie.What is The Sixth Child about ? The movie start out showing the tough life of Franck ( Damien Bonnard , who can currently be seen in Poor Things ) and Meriem ( Judith Chemla , who starred in the Israeli film The End of Love ) , a Roma couple struggling to make end meet a they raise five child in a trailer park , which they have chosen because it is near good schools.Franck is a scrap metal dealer , and when his partner pick a fight , he , too , get in trouble with the law . Julien ( Benjamin Lavernhe , who recently appeared in Jeanne du Barry and who wa also in The Sense of Wonder ) , the lawyer Meriem hire to get him out of the jam , is understanding and make a payment plan . To thank him , Franck insists that Julien and his wife , Anna ( Sara Giraudeau , one of the star of The Bureau ) , who is also a lawyer , stop by for a beer.Anna isn & rsquo ; t interested at first but then is charmed by their child , and it turn out that she can & rsquo ; t have any of her own . They have tried IVF several time and it failed , and psychologist have given her damning report when they have tried to adopt , essentially saying she want a baby too badly.A little while later , when Franck come to Julien & rsquo ; s office unannounced , Julien think it is because he need more help with his case . But it & rsquo ; s not that : Meriem is pregnant with what will be their sixth child . They are devout Catholics and an abortion is out of the question , but they are already packed like sardine into their trailer . Franck desperately need money for a new van to replace the one that wa damaged in an accident ; without it , he can & rsquo ; t support the family . So he proposes an unholy deal : their baby in exchange for money to buy a new van.Julien quickly shuts him down : This would be human trafficking and highly illegal . But when he tell Anna about the incident , she is desperate to go for it . They float the idea of a legal deal : an open adoption , where they would raise the child , but Franck and Meriem would still be the parent and would be in the child & rsquo ; s life . But Meriem can & rsquo ; t bear this idea . She would much prefer to give the baby to this couple and walk away.At this point , Julien is desperate to shut down the whole idea because he know that to pay the couple for their baby would be wrong , legally and morally . But Anna can & rsquo ; t let go of this dream of raising this baby , and Meriem and Franck have decided they will give the baby up for adoption in any case , since they are in such dire financial strait . Anna & rsquo ; s determination over this baby drive a wedge between her and her husband . Meanwhile , Meriem is despondent about the idea of giving up this baby but know she can not give another child a good life.THE STORY play out like a Greek tragedy , in which each character follows his own destiny , no matter how much sorrow it will bring . You wish for a happy ending for all of them , knowing it isn & rsquo ; t possible.At first I thought that the two lawyer would be portrayed a vile , predatory rich people , but the movie go in a different direction . They are portrayed a deserving of compassion because of their infertility , and if the film is anyone & rsquo ; s story , it & rsquo ; s Anna & rsquo ; s.While it & rsquo ; s clear that capitalism and anti-Roma racism have put Franck and Meriem into an impossible situation , they have a warm , loving family , which Anna and Julien don & rsquo ; t have . There is no explanation given for the fact that they can & rsquo ; t have child , but it is devastating for Anna and , to a lesser extent , for Julien.The four actor work well together , and all give good performance , but the standout is Giraudeau a Anna . It is she who drive the action and can & rsquo ; t give up , willing to sacrifice her upper-class life to become a mother.There have been many movie about parent who fight over child , such a several film based on the Baby M and similar case , and many fall into clich & eacute ; s.The Sixth Child avoids these pitfall , although toward the end , some of the resolution feel too neat . But it & rsquo ; s still a movie where you identify with everyone . You keep turning over their option in your mind , and will likely think about the character and the story long after the movie end .
title: ' the sixth child ' : a tragic french story of parenthood , poverty - review

Body Text: Education Minister Yoav Kisch announced Thursday that the Israel Prize ceremony will be held during the country 's 76th Independence Day , the first of such following the October 7 massacre in the city of Sderot . & nbsp ; Following the outbreak of the Israel-Hamas war , Kisch decided to hold the annual Israel Prize this year a a sign of revival , civil heroism , and mutual guarantee . Special recognition will be given to Israeli citizen who demonstrated extraordinary bravery and contributed to the revival of the state following the outbreak of war . & nbsp ; This year , in addition to the three award celebrating Israeli revival , two-lifetime achievement award , and nine award in other professional category will be given . & nbsp ; Confirmation of Netanyahu critic & nbsp ; The education minister announced six additional winner . The announcement also provided the first confirmation of Eyal Waldman , an Israeli tech businessman , who criticized Prime Minister Netanyahu over the judicial reform policy passed by the government . Kisch reportedly requested that the committee that voted on the prize not give the prize to Waldman . & nbsp ; The ceremony also come after Kisch 's initial demand to cancel the ceremony , which resulted in Israel 's High Court requesting the government to provide justification for the cancellation . & nbsp ; The winner include the following : The Israel Prize in Psychology Research is awarded to Prof . Gershon Ben Shahar.The Israel Prize in Life Sciences Research is awarded to Prof . Hagai Bergman.The Israel Prize for Entrepreneurship and Technological Innovation is awarded to Mr . Eyal Waldman.The Israel Prize in Torah Literature and Hebrew Law is awarded to Rishon Lezion , the Chief Rabbi of Israel , Rabbi Yitzhak Yosef.The Israel Prize for Research in Mathematics , Computer Science , and Computer Engineering is awarded to Prof . Vitali Milman.The Israel Prize for Economic Research and Statistics Research is awarded to Prof . Yaakov Ritov.Kisch noted in his statement that `` this year , we will hold the Israel Prize ceremony with the heroic resident of the city of Sderot . The State of Israel is at war , and we cherish our soldier at the front , we remember our hostage brother and sister , and we praise the heroism and spirit that ha pulsated in the nation since the dawn of history . `` `` The Israel Prize is an award for Israeli excellence , and the honor of the winner is the honor of the State of Israel . Unfortunately , in my announcement today , there were no woman honoree , only men . The discretion in this matter is in the hand of the company and member of the various committee , and I hope that they will choose deserving woman in the following category . `` `` The hour is the hour of war ; the order of the hour is unity , and together , Israeli excellence will face every challenge and defeat every enemy , `` Kisch said . & nbsp ;
title: israel prize winner announced , among them netanyahu critic eyal waldman

Body Text: Egypt , Qatar , the United Nations and other international party are making significant effort to prevent & nbsp ; another military confrontation & nbsp ; between Israel and the Palestinian faction in the Gaza Strip . On Friday , Israel announced for the first time in 18 month that it will allow merchant and businessmen from the Gaza Strip to enter through the Erez crossing . The announcement came after the relative calm on the Gaza-Israel border during which no balloon or incendiary device were launched toward Israel . Hamas source said that the mediation effort were being made due to Israel & rsquo ; s insistence on linking reconstruction of the Gaza Strip to a prisoner exchange . Hamas ha been holding the body of IDF soldier Oron Shaul and Hadar Goldin since 2014 , and is holding Israeli citizen Avner Mengistu and Hisham al-Sayed , who entered the Gaza Strip on their own in 2014 and 2015 respectively . The source told the Palestinian daily Al-Quds that mediator from Egypt , Qatar , the UN and the European Union are working to avoid another flare-up of hostility between the Gaza-based faction and Israel . Several faction warned over the weekend that failure to move forward with reconstruction would lead to another military confrontation with Israel . According to the source , the faction met in recent day and discussed setting an ultimatum to Israel in the event that there is no breakthrough in the reconstruction issue , a well a the easing of restriction imposed on the Gaza Strip . & ldquo ; The coming day will be decisive in this regard , and the resistance faction will not accept anything less than the fulfillment of their demand , & rdquo ; the source said . & ldquo ; The mediator asked Hamas and the other faction to give them more time to achieve a breakthrough on these issue , including a possible prisoner exchange and a long-term truce with Israel . & rdquo ; In addition to merchant , all Gazan good can now enter Israel for the first time since the end of May & rsquo ; s 11-day Gaza war , the Coordinator of Government Activities in the Territories ( COGAT ) Maj . - Gen . Ghassan Alian announced . The list of item that can enter Gaza from Israel at Kerem Shalom & rsquo ; s commercial crossing also expanded to include item used for transportation and communication . Equipment and good for Gaza & rsquo ; s humanitarian infrastructure , such a for the water and sewage system , can also enter . Senior Hamas official & nbsp ; Osama & nbsp ; Hamdan & nbsp ; said on Saturday that Egypt wa continuing it effort to prevent another military confrontation with Israel . Hamdan warned that the Gaza faction would not wait too long for a solution regarding the easing of the restriction and the reconstruction of the house destroyed during the 11-day war in May . The faction are also demanding a solution to the issue of the Qatari cash grant to the Strip . They accused the Palestinian Authority of hindering reconstruction and the delivery of the Qatari financial aid to more than 100,000 family . Earlier this month , a Palestinian official said that the PA and Qatar had reached an agreement on the transfer of the fund through the Palestinian Monetary Fund but Palestinian bank are refusing to cooperate for fear that they could be exposed to lawsuit on the ground of supporting and funding terrorism . Azzam al-Ahmed , a senior member of the Fatah Central Committee , claimed that Israel , and not the PA , wa responsible for the delay of the delivery of the Qatari fund , & ldquo ; The Palestinian government signed an agreement in order to coordinate the disbursement of the fund in the Gaza Strip , which were previously transferred through the Israeli Mossad , & rdquo ; Ahmed said in a radio interview . He claimed that Israel rejected the agreement , & ldquo ; because of it desire to take over the task of delivering the Qatari grant fund . & rdquo ; Contacts are underway between the Palestinian Authority , Qatar and Egypt to resolve the issue , Ahmed added . He denied charge that the PA wa obstructing the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip . He stressed that reconstruction will only take place through the PA government headed by Prime Minister Mohammed Shtayyeh . Ahmed said that there will be no reconstruction of the Gaza Strip until the split between the West Bank and Gaza Strip end . & ldquo ; There will be no reconstruction without achieving unity and ending the division , & rdquo ; he emphasized . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; The head of the Palestinian General Federation of Trade Unions in the Gaza Strip , Sami al-Amsi , accused the PA of obstructing the transfer of the Qatari fund . He also accused the PA of imposing a siege and sanction on the resident of the Gaza Strip . & ldquo ; The Palestinian Authority is dragging it foot , because it want to increase the pressure on people in the Gaza Strip and impose more sanction on them , & rdquo ; Amsi said . & ldquo ; The Palestinian Authority is punishing the son of Fatah before Hamas . & rdquo ; Commenting on Israel & rsquo ; s decision to allow the entry of Palestinian merchant and businessmen from the Gaza Strip into Israel , Amsi said the move came because of Israel & rsquo ; s & ldquo ; fear of the response of the Palestinian resistance faction . & rdquo ; Israel , he added , & ldquo ; is an enemy that only understands the language of force . & rdquo ; Tovah Lazaroff contributed to this report .
title: mediator in bid to avert hamas-israel face-off

Body Text: Tambour , the largest paint and building material company in Israel , unveiled it new color collection , the Balance collection , which draw inspiration from the space around u and express the effect of color in the various space on our feelings.Tambour also revealed the finding of a survey according to which 90 % of Israelis feel positive emotion after painting their house , and it launched an online service of paint sample that consumer can order for their home to help with the decision on choosing the color for their house.On the occasion of the launch of the new collection ahead of Passover , Tambour conducted an in-depth survey that examined the feeling Israelis are experiencing after six month of war , whether Israelis spend more time at home compared to the period before the war , what action they are doing more to relax and to take a break from the situation , how the security situation affected their consumption habit and how many of them intend to paint the house for the holidays.The wisdom of balance '' We live in an era of far-reaching change that are happening at a dizzying pace . Some of them encourage u to move forward even more strongly , and some of them invite u to stop and rethink the way we live and the space where we spend our time . We want these space to transform our quality of life , for good & ndash ; have them give expression to the nature that surround u , plant , tree , soil , air , and water , and may they allow u to rest and recharge with renewed strength and inspire u , `` say Niva Yehiav Alon , Head of Design at Tambour.Tambour 's Balance collection combine the beneficial property and inspiration we draw from nature and our immediate environment , and the psychology of color and it ability to influence the mood and general feeling in the space where we are . The collection present 5 group of shade , each of which ha a different effect on our feeling : starting with feeling of calmness and peace , through feeling of renewal , relaxation , and stability , and up to a feeling of enchantment , which make our heart skip a beat.Tambour chose to describe the story of each shade group in the title and keywords and let the color convey the feelings.Calm : freedom | boundless space | quiet release | infinityRelaxation : walking barefoot and feeling the ground under your foot | a place of refuge | Mother Earth | a place for comfort | tendernessStability : certainty | a sense of belonging | stable ground | connect to the root | depth | meaningRegeneration : regeneration | refreshment | to be recharged | to grow | to reach new heights.Excitement : to feel your breath taken away in front of a spectacular sunset | admire a full moon | to hear the whistling of the wind in the heart of the desert
title: tambour launch a new color collection : balance

Body Text: MK Meir Cohen from Yesh Atid , former welfare and social service minister , wa interviewed recently by Anat Davidov and Udi Segal on 103FM radio about the war in Gaza , about the departure of New Hope chairman Gideon Sa'ar from the coalition with Benny Gantz Gantz , and on whether Yesh Atid would join the current coalition . He also criticized the conduct of the government and the Knesset by stating , `` There are debate here that you ca n't believe someone would raise during a war , `` and said of the family of the abductees , `` I see that it ha become routine . `` Regarding the hostage deal taking shape , Cohen said that he `` see the family , their story becomes routine . This is the great danger that we are in the overall picture of another thing called captive , and the world continues a usual . I sincerely hope that this will not happen , and we are doing everything we can to prevent it . `` When asked if he wa afraid that the hostage would never be released , he answered , `` Yes . I do n't know if the government will give them up , but the government 's conduct and the lack of determination among some of the people I talk to lead u to the perception that there is not enough determination . Where there is not enough determination , that a state abandon 134 hostage & mdash ; that 's [ moral ] bankruptcy . `` He reveals that `` There is looting of the state budget . It 's unbelievable that someone think that in the great distress we are in , they can pas such a budget . `` He added , `` We , a Yesh Atid , say that all we need to invest everything in order to return the hostage . Everything must be done to bring them back , and if we have to pay a heavy price , we should . `` Further into the interview , Cohen wa asked if the prime minister and his government could afford to stall the return of the hostage . Cohen answered , `` I do n't know . We are talking to them and making our voice heard . I hear determination from one side , even within the family of the hostage . We keep saying we wo n't end the effort . Our people probably die in Gaza every week . `` The factor that influence Netanyahu 's major political decision & nbsp ; Cohen also stated , `` I am realizing that Gantz and Eisenkot do not have a significant influence on the government , `` and said regarding Sa'ar , `` I think that what Gideon did wa his decision but he should not have done it . It is his sole right to ask to be a cabinet member . What is worrying is that I think that the prime minister will accept him into the cabinet , but he will also bring Smotrich and Ben-Gvir along with him . `` Since we are witnessing the crazy circus , the lighting of bonfire in our district by the security minister , I am very afraid of how the reduced cabinet will look . I realize that both Gantz and Eisenkot no longer have a significant influence on the conduct of the government , and I call on them to leave . Up until now , they are an oxygen balloon for Netanyahu and the failed government . `` When asked if there wa an option for them to join the current coalition , Cohen said , `` We are no longer talking about entering the government . We were the first to want a government , but we warned against very radical and messianic element . Even two month ago , we approached the prime minister and said , ' Any deal you offer , we will back it up . ' Regarding Israel 's political reputation , Cohen stated , `` I hear the voice in the Knesset a if we are in our own utopian world . To be clear , the Americans , the English , and the Germans are not telling u not to enter Rafah , they are not telling u not to continue with the elimination of Hamas , but they are asking what will happen after the operation . Netanyahu is not ready to answer that . If we want positive international attention and legitimacy , let 's have a dialogue , not fight with the Americans . The prime minister suggests they are against u and only he know how to stand up to them . It is unnecessary and it put u at risk `` .
title: israeli lawmaker call on gantz , eisenkot to leave the ' failed gov't '

Body Text: It quickly became apparent to Ofir Amir , one of the founder and producer of the Supernova music festival , that survivor of the brutal Hamas attack , which left hundred of festival goer dead or wounded , needed help.And so , Amir and other festival producer founded the nonprofit Tribe of Nova Foundation , in order to help survivor of the festival with their rehabilitation and return to life after the attack.The foundation also work to memorialize those who were killed at the party and to share their story with the world.Nearly 380 festival participant and police were murdered on October 7 at the trance festival held in southern Israel near Kibbutz Re & rsquo ; im . Countless participant were wounded , and some were taken hostage to Gaza.Shortly after the outbreak of the attack , which began with massive barrage of rocket from Gaza , police told the people at the festival to evacuate . Amir recalled staying a while after the evacuation order to make sure that party-goers were getting out safely.He described his hellish experience that morning , touching on the chaos caused by the Hamas attack , from which party-goers struggled to escape , a terrorist came at them from multiple direction and security force were overrun.Around 8 a.m . , Amir saw emergency service bring a body into the festival site , and that is when the reality of the situation hit him , he said.After failing to escape in a car crammed with seven people , Amir lay in a field for hour , waiting for help . He wa shot , hit in both of his leg . Some of the 20 people hiding near him kept coming to check on him , risking themselves each time.In that field , Amir & rsquo ; s friend , who had also been shot , succumbed to his wound . Amir wa able to help him call his mother to say goodbye.One of the thing that kept Amir going , surviving those long hour waiting for rescue , wa thinking of his wife waiting for him at home , nine month pregnant . Amir & rsquo ; s daughter wa born four week later.Heroes on the production staffAmir shared story of the heroism of other member of the festival & rsquo ; s production staff.Just after the attack , one of the producer posted on social medium , asking for those hiding around the party site to share their location with him so that emergency service and civilian rescuer could come and help them.He wa inundated with thousand of message , and wa able to save more than 300 survivor of the party who were hiding in the area around the party , Amir shared . He came back every day for the rest of the week following the massacre , at first rescuing survivor , many of whom were wounded , and then locating body , said Amir.There are around 3,600 survivor , according to the foundation , which is still working to locate anyone who wa at the party that day . The foundation is in touch daily with survivor and their family , in an attempt to help them with issue that the state doe not provide enough support on . It also advocate for the family in various Knesset and government forums.BAR , WHO survived the attack , is active in the community that the foundation offer to those who were at the festival . The 28-year-old Tel Aviv resident came to the event a a production assistant . She ha been connected to trance music for year , and that is how she became involved in the Nova festival , she said.A healing communityBar found the Nova healing community soon after October 7 . & ldquo ; A few day after the party , I got a message from one the producer , offering u to come to a campus set up for people who were at the party where they could be taken care of , & rdquo ; she remembered . & ldquo ; It wa during a time when I really didn & rsquo ; t want to leave my house . I didn & rsquo ; t want to leave my bed , & rdquo ; she said.She saw there wa a concert at the campus and told a friend , who sent another friend who had been at the Supernova festival to bring Bar to the event . & ldquo ; He literally pulled me out of bed so that we would go , & rdquo ; she remembered.At the campus , she found a setup that offered a break from how difficult thing were , with performance , workshop , food , and drink for those who had been at the party . & ldquo ; I wouldn & rsquo ; t have eaten anything if I wasn & rsquo ; t there , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; I wasn & rsquo ; t able to prepare food for myself , and didn & rsquo ; t want to eat anything , & rdquo ; she said , remembering how challenging the week following the party were . But at the campus , where there wa food for the survivor and she wa with her friend , she found herself able to eat.For month she came to the campus whenever she could , she said , explaining that she wa not working , and wa not capable of thinking about working at that time . & ldquo ; The fact that I wa able to leave my bed wa an added bonus ; the fact that I wa able to drive alone wa an added bonus . The fact that I wa outside my house after dark wa a miracle , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; It wa unbelievable that I wa able to do those thing . & rdquo ; Various therapy on offerTHE VARIETY of treatment offered at the campus gave Bar the chance to find thing that made her feel better . & ldquo ; They gave u all the option of therapy and said , & lsquo ; Come try them out , & rsquo ; & rdquo ; she remembered.The atmosphere at the campus wa difficult in the day and week just after October 7 , but still made Bar feel much better . & ldquo ; At first I saw friend that I hadn & rsquo ; t seen since the party , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; We would cry and hug and couldn & rsquo ; t believe we were there together . & rdquo ; Bar talked about the benefit of the workshop offered at the campus . & ldquo ; It take you out of your thought . Something that hold me back a lot is thought , & rdquo ; she explained . & ldquo ; What happened to me , how did this happen to me , to my friend ? & ndash ; All kind of unpleasant thought that come with the post-traumatic reaction . & rdquo ; When you do activity and workshop , you don & rsquo ; t think of anything , she explained . & ldquo ; You can disconnect for a minute and take this moment with your friend and music . & rdquo ; Community and being surrounded by people who understand is also a major part of her process , Bar shared . & ldquo ; Through conversation we have , I realize that we feel the same , & rdquo ; she said , explaining the comfort in the community of those who survived the festival . & ldquo ; It make the situation normal . You realized that it isn & rsquo ; t only you , & rdquo ; she added . & ldquo ; We understand each other . The community is really strong in that sense . . . . We are over 3,000 survivor . We understand that we are together in this , even if it is hard or bad . & rdquo ; They encourage each other , reminding one another that a bad day will be followed by a better one.Bar expressed gratitude for the foundation & rsquo ; s help with bureaucracy . & ldquo ; They brought social worker and National Insurance Institute representative , & rdquo ; making the institution that could help her get what she is entitled to accessible , she said.Some authority offered some benefit which the foundation helped survivor access , but generally Bar said that no authority took upon itself to take care of the survivors.The government wa MIA , survivor say & ldquo ; The Nova nonprofit ha taken it on themselves to help u , and that is something no one else in the country did & ndash ; I & rsquo ; m talking about government authority . No governmental organization took it on themselves and said that they want to help u , & rdquo ; said Bar . & ldquo ; There is help for anything , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; From the biggest to the smallest thing , there is someone there for u . & rdquo ; The Nova nonprofit & ldquo ; deserves huge thanks , and I hope this keep going and people understand how important this is , and that whoever is able to donates to them , because it really , really help u , & rdquo ; she said.Along with the activity described by Bar , the foundation also develops program for the community of survivor , run by the community , such a a mentorship program . & ldquo ; The best healing come from survivor helping each other , & rdquo ; explained the foundation.The foundation ha a number of initiative planned for the future , including founding a center for the community . The center would be a home to activity for the community of survivor a well a a memorial for the victim of the attack.The foundation also plan to lead , in coordination with Keren Kayemeth LeIsrael-Jewish National Fund , a cleanup of the Re & rsquo ; im site , the place where the massacre took place . & ldquo ; The Re & rsquo ; im site is the place where our loved one had their final moment , & rdquo ; said the foundation , explaining that they want to & ldquo ; build a campus for family and friend with easy access , and clean up the way the area look . & rdquo ;
