Israel , he said , & ldquo ; must stop and retreat from it step , a it is the only party that bear full responsibility . & rdquo ; The Hamas leadership told the mediator that it message wa clear , which is to & ldquo ; strengthen the position of the Palestinian people in Jerusalem and at al-Aqsa Mosque , and the steadfastness of family threatened with expulsion from their home in Sheikh Jarrah , & rdquo ; Abu Marzouk added . The Hamas official wa later quoted by Palestinian news website a saying that the Europeans have also contacted his group to explore the possibility of reaching a ceasefire with Israel . & ldquo ; The Europeans contacted u and asked u to stop firing short-range missile [ at Israel ] or else they will not participate in the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip , & rdquo ; Abu Marzouk said . & ldquo ; I told them we will stop our short-range missile and use long-range missile . & rdquo ; Abu Marzouk did not provide detail about the identity of the Europeans who reportedly contacted Hamas . It said that Issa and & ldquo ; a group of his brother , the leader and mujahedin ( warrior ) were martyred during the occupation & rsquo ; s aggression . & rdquo ; Abu Hamza , a spokesperson for PIJ & rsquo ; s military wing , al-Quds Brigades , said on Wednesday that the Gaza-based terror group will & ldquo ; continue the jihad and will not retreat , regardless of the price and sacrifice . & rdquo ; He said that his group fired 100 missile toward Tel Aviv at 5:00 a.m . & ldquo ; We were able to respond to the continuation of the aggression and the targeting of civilian and mujahedin , & rdquo ; Abu Hamza said in a statement . Body Text: President Biden spoke with the `` big four `` leader on a call Sunday to discus Iran 's unprecedented attack against Israel , according to White House pool report . & nbsp ; On the call , Biden discussed the urgent need to pas the national supplemental a soon a possible on a call Sunday , Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer ( D-NY ) , Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell ( R-KY ) , Speaker of the House Mike Johnson ( R-LA ) , and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries ( D-NY ) . The only aid package for Israel that will get to President Joe Biden 's desk is the Senate-passed supplemental bill which includes military aid for Ukraine , Taiwan and Israel and also humanitarian aid for Gaza , Ranking member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee Sen . Gregory Meeks ( D-NY ) said Sunday morning on MSNBC . & nbsp ; Meeks reiterated Biden 's stance that US defensive support for Israel is `` ironclad . `` On Saturday night a US force intercepted Iranian missile and UAVs targeting Israel , House Republican leader Rep . Steve Scalise ( LA ) said this week 's legislative schedule will be changed to bring forward legislation to support Israel . & nbsp ; Details of this coming week 's legislative change have yet to be announced a of Sunday morning . & nbsp ; In early November , the Republican-led House passed a plan to provide $ 14.3 billion in aid to Israel and cut funding to the ternal Revenue Service.But because it combined aid for Israel with a cut to the Internal Revenue Service and left out aid for Ukraine , President Joe Biden promised a veto and Senator Chuck Schumer , majority leader of the Democratic-controlled Senate , said he would not bring it up for a vote.Senate supplemental billIn February , the Democratic-led Senate passed it supplemental bill which would give $ 60.06 billion in aid for Ukraine , $ 14.1 billion to Israel , $ 2.44 billion for operation in the Red Sea and almost $ 4.82 for partner in the Indo-Pacific to deter aggression by China . & nbsp ; The Senate bill would also provide $ 9.15 billion in humanitarian assistance for civilian in Gaza , the West Bank , Ukraine and other population in conflict zone around the globe . & nbsp ; `` The Administration strongly encourages both chamber of the Congress to reject this political ploy and instead quickly send the bipartisan Emergency National Security Supplemental Appropriations Act to the President & rsquo ; s desk , `` the White House Office of Management and Budget said in a statement in February . & nbsp ; Former President Donald Trump is the leading Republican voice opposed to sending additional funding to Ukraine . Republican House Speaker Mike Johnson , a close Trump ally , declined to allow a House vote on the Senate supplemental bill for month . Johnson met with Trump on Friday in Florida , fueling speculation about whether Trump will clear a vote on Biden 's national security spending request . & nbsp ; However , not every Republican is siding with Trump . & nbsp ; McCaul on Ukraine and IsraelIn an interview Sunday morning on CBS ' Face the Nation , House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Michael McCaul ( R-TX ) said he will be speaking with Johnson on Sunday night about the dire situation in Ukraine . & nbsp ; McCaul said an option for Israel 's response to Saturday night 's attack would be to take out the facility where Iranian drone or rocket come from , and also destroy the manufacturing facility that build them . & nbsp ; Not just for Israel 's sake , McCaul said , but also for Ukraine because the rocket and drone are being bought by Russia and are used to kill Ukrainians . & nbsp ; What happened in Israel on Saturday night happens in Ukraine every night , McCaul said . & nbsp ; McCaul told CBS ' Margaret Brennan that he need to educate his House colleague on how Israel , Ukraine and the Indo-Pacific are all tied together . & nbsp ; `` Iran is selling this stuff to Russia . Guess who 's buying Iran 's energy ? China , `` McCaul said , which is happening because the Biden administration lifted sanction on Iran and helped fund their terror operation , he added . & nbsp ; McCaul said he 's an `` eternal optimist `` and is doing his part . He said in World War II the US did n't choose it enemy , it went after Japan , Italy and Germany all together . & nbsp ; `` We just ca n't pick and say Iran is bad , Russia is okay and China is bad . They 're all in this together , `` McCaul said , `` And it 's very clear to those of u in the intelligence national security community . ``
title: biden urge house to approve israel , ukraine aid after month of stalling senate-passed bill

Body Text: There are a worrying number of video about the Israel-Palestinian conflict that have been published on TikTok in recent day , often garnering hundred of thousand if not million of view , over 100,000 like and more than 10,000 share . But in the film , the TikToker accuses Israel of trying to burn down al-Aqsa Mosque . & nbsp ; The video can be broken down into three category : news , propaganda and political declaration . & nbsp ; Some of the clip simply show the situation in Gaza from the Palestinian point of view , such a building collapsing or the population panicking a Israel carry out airstrikes . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We don & rsquo ; t really see a lot of this on Israeli TV and Western channel , & rdquo ; Weimann said . & ldquo ; They get it out using TikTok and social medium . & rdquo ; Take a recent video by Shahed ( @ shahed.kudsi ) : & ldquo ; This world is sick , & rdquo ; she say . & ldquo ; May Allah protect them . & rdquo ; Then , she show scene in east Jerusalem of the protest and riot on the Temple Mount . Over the picture it say , & ldquo ; In occupied East Jerusalem , Israeli occupation force attacked Palestinians who had gathered to break their fast , throwing a stun grenade into a crowd of men , woman and child . & rdquo ; @ shahed.kudsi Ya rab protect them ❤ ️ keep them in your prayer everyone # freepalestine # palestine # arab ♬ another love - eh & nbsp ; The video got 147,000 like . Another short clip selects a narrow view of an Israeli soldier dragging a Palestinian on the ground during a recent confrontation . The use of compelling music sensationalizes the episode . The video got 158,000 like and close to 13,000 share . @ palestiniansisterrrr This is near Shiekh Jarrah neighborhood in Jerusalem capital of Palestine # palestine # palestinian # israel # israeli # عرب # عربي # فلسطيني ♬ another love - eh The propaganda reel can be divided into two category : those produced by Palestinians in Arabic and those produced in English by Arabs or Muslims living in the United States or other English-speaking country . & ldquo ; Some of them are song for Palestine , Sheikh Jarrah or Gaza & ndash ; made in the West and getting more than a million view , & rdquo ; Weimann noted . He said that because the video are & ldquo ; made in TikTok-style , they are very attractive . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; In a video titled & ldquo ; What is currently going on in Palestine ? & rdquo ; that had 51,500 share , TikToker Solana ( @ solanathagreenfairy ) explains : & ldquo ; One of the holiest site in Islam , Al-Aqsa Mosque , is on fire . Israeli force have shot Palestinians , thrown stun grenade all over the mosque and sprayed tear gas . There is a video currently circulating with hundred of Israeli settler singing and dancing and celebrating these horrendous attack , & rdquo ; she say . & ldquo ; In addition to this , since last October , Israeli settler have been stealing and moving into Palestinians & rsquo ; home in Sheikh Jarrah , & rdquo ; Solana say . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; And since early this month , the situation ha severely escalated . Far right-wing Zionists were marching through the street chanting death to Arabs . As well a the military assaulting woman and child and forcibly raiding home . & rdquo ; She call on the public to & ldquo ; share informative resource to spread awareness and donate and sign petition when you can . & rdquo ; @ solanathagreenfairy a brief explanation but please help in any way you can ! ! ! # foryou # savesheikhjarrah # viral ♬ original sound - solana & nbsp ; TikToker Kamelia ( @ bnr.kamelia ) , who appears to be French , jig to a popular song while she spit on the Israeli flag and say she prefers s * * t over Israel . & nbsp ; @ bnr.kamelia # # collage avec @ yael_deri1 # # palestine # # freepalestine ♬ Jalebi Baby - Tesher & nbsp ; Her video got 313,000 like . The political declaration video use TikTok to take viewer to other site where they can learn more or take action . One of Kamelia & rsquo ; s video , for example , informs watcher of how they can participate in local march for Palestine . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; These video are not just video , & rdquo ; Weimann said . & ldquo ; They have political message in the video ; and in the comment , they link to other place to expand the exposure . & rdquo ; TikTok ha 1.2 billion active user . Half of them are in China , and half from around the world , & ndash ; many of them young people , including under the age of 13 , despite the community rule . & ldquo ; Many young people get their information from social medium , & rdquo ; Weimann warned . & ldquo ; If they are exposed to the interpretation of the news through TikTok , that should make u worried . & rdquo ; TikTok is owned by a Chinese company and ha proved insensitive to public pressure to regulate the site . Body Text: Kuwaiti Public Works Minister Dr . Rana Abdullah Al-Fares issued an order on Saturday banning the entry of commercial vessel loaded with good to and from Israel into Kuwaiti territorial water , according to Kuwaiti newspaper Al Anba . The order prohibits entry permit being requested for ship carrying good to or from Israel , even if good being carried from Israel are being brought to another country outside of Kuwait . Under Kuwaiti law , individual and company can not conclude agreement with organization or person living in Israel and can not deal financially or commercially with person who have an interest in Israel , even if they live outside Israel . It is also illegal to import , exchange or possess any Israeli good , commodity or product , whether received directly or indirectly . Products also can not include any material from Israeli product . Hamas issued a statement welcoming the decision on Saturday , calling on other country to & ldquo ; follow the same approach & rdquo ; and restrict Israeli trade and maritime traffic . When the Abraham Accords were signed last year , Kuwait & ndash ; a staunch opponent of Israel & ndash ; insisted that it would & ldquo ; be the last & rdquo ; to normalize relation with Israel . On Wednesday , Kuwait & rsquo ; s permanent ambassador to the UN , Talal Al-Fassam , reiterated Kuwait & rsquo ; s support for the Palestinians , and condemned a recent visit by Israeli President Isaac Herzog to the Tomb of the Patriarchs in Hebron , saying it provoked the sentiment of Muslims worldwide , according to the Palestinian WAFA news agency . In May , the Kuwaiti parliament passed a bill that would restrict any form of contact with Israel . Any expression of sympathy with Israel would also be outlawed .
title: kuwait ban entry of ship carrying good to and from israel

Body Text: On Wednesday , Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and leader of the haredi party failed to come up with a new compromise on the controversial issue of the haredi exemption from IDF service that would enjoy legal backing from Attorney-General Gali Baharav-Miara.The attempt at a new compromise were aimed at convincing the Supreme Court & ndash ; ahead of a midnight deadline & ndash ; to give the government a few more month to have the plan pas into law . The attorney-general is the government & rsquo ; s legal representative in the Supreme Court , and she requested that the court give her until 2:00 p.m . on Thursday to file the government 's official response.According to Israeli medium outlet , a leaked draft of the response revealed that Baharav-Miara intends to claim that the state is no longer authorized to avoid recruiting yeshiva student , and should begin the process of drafting them from April 1 onwards . Regarding state funding to yeshivot , the A-G is expected to request that the funding cease but not immediately , so a to give the yeshivot time to adapt to the change.The government & rsquo ; s proposal ha been viewed a too weak because the haredi have refused to commit to specific quota number of draftee per year or to any financial or criminal sanction for those who do not comply . Baharav-Miara said that without some minimal number and sanction , it would be hopeless for her to try to defend the bill before the High Court of Justice.It wa expected that the government would ask for an additional postponement , given the inability to reach a deal to keep the government intact , with some report suggesting a request for an additional 10 day . It wa unlikely that the High Court would give the government much of a postponement , if any , and in the past , the High Court ha often only granted a shorter extension than whatever the government had requested to keep up the pressure.The court could also just let the issue play out at the hearing scheduled for Thursday and demand answer from the government throughout that hearing . In the most extreme case , the court could order an immediate universal draft until the government put in place an alternative.Fuchs blame attorney-general 's officeCabinet Secretary Yossi Fuchs wrote a letter to government minister on Wednesday in which he blamed the Attorney-General & rsquo ; s Office for the government & rsquo ; s inability to pas a decision on time . Fuchs argued that the A-G & rsquo ; s office initially refused to support the decision for what it described a a & ldquo ; procedural & rdquo ; reason , namely that the decision did not include an opinion by the defense ministry . On March 24 , however , the A-G & rsquo ; s office again refused on the same ground , saying that the lack of a defense ministry opinion served a a & ldquo ; legal impediment . & rdquo ; Fuchs argued in the letter that the A-G & rsquo ; s office contradicted itself and had not made it clear in advance that the defense ministry opinion wa legally obligatory . He added that the reason the defense ministry opinion wa unattainable wa because Defense Minister Yoav Gallant wa not participating in the procedure . & ldquo ; The door to the vault of government approval ha been locked by the Attorney General & rsquo ; s Office and there is no key since , from a technical standpoint , it is impossible to receive the professional underpinnings from the defense ministry , & rdquo ; Fuchs wrote . & ldquo ; Until this moment , the Attorney General & rsquo ; s Office ha not pointed out any core problem or problem whatsoever in the government & rsquo ; s decision and ha not raised a & lsquo ; black flag & rsquo ; over it , & rdquo ; Fuchs accused.Gallant refuted the claim that his ministry had not cooperated , saying in a written statement soon after Fuchs & rsquo ; s letter wa published that the allegation were & ldquo ; biased and false . & rdquo ; According to Gallant , & ldquo ; every request that wa received regarding cooperation with the professional echelon in the defense ministry or a piece of data regarding the conscription law wa approved and will continue to be approved . & rdquo ; However , the defense minister repeated a prior pledge that he would only support a bill that wa supported by & ldquo ; the entire & rdquo ; emergency government , which includes Minister-without-Portolio Benny Gantz , head of the National Unity Party.Opposition leader MK Yair Lapid said in response to Fuchs & rsquo ; s letter , & ldquo ; The government & rsquo ; s wonderful ability to evade any responsibility is impressive , and tonight , who is to blame that there is no conscription law ? The attorney general ? You got it wrong : The blame is on those who are attempting to whitewash draft-dodging and discriminate between group based on blood . & rdquo ; A source from United Torah Judaism expressed the party & rsquo ; s frustration with the prime minister . & ldquo ; He [ Netanyahu ] signed an agreement . We wanted to pas [ a new conscription bill ] before the government & rsquo ; s formation ; he delayed . We agreed [ to pas the bill ] before the budget [ passed on May 23 ] ; he delayed . If he want a government , he must ensure that yeshiva student can study Torah , & rdquo ; the source told The Jerusalem Post in a text message.Gantz also threatened earlier this week to leave the government if an unsatisfactory conscription bill pass into law.In term of viable alternative and compromise that the government could adopt , there is a spectrum of idea that other party have presented , and there could also be variation on those proposals.The closest way to a compromise would be some variation on Gantz & rsquo ; s proposal of all haredi having to do national service , with a more symbolic number serving in the IDF.This would not truly address all of the IDF service inequality that have angered the public for decade , but it would at least show the majority of the population that the haredi were ready to contribute to the national destiny in a physical and quantifiable way . ( Haredim claim they care for the spiritual sustenance of the nation ) . Also , if more Israelis from other sector were being pulled out of necessary job , the haredi stepping in with national service would cover some of that gap.Advocates of the Gantz compromise say it would temper some economic impact and start a social transformation within the haredi community by connecting and contributing more to the nation.In practice , IDF source have said they can not integrate all of the draft-eligible haredi and that it would probably take year to do so , if at all doable . They explained that there are too many social and educational issue to work through to take in haredi in anything other than gradual number . & nbsp ; Above a certain volume , it is not even clear that the IDF want to spend the amount of resource necessary to integrate so many Haredim at once.The lack of an agreement about how to solve the crisis is part of what ha continued to allow the consistent rejectionist haredi position to prevail over the last several month , not to mention for decade before October 7 . & nbsp ;
title: israeli gov't in crisis a netanyahu , haredi party fail to reach idf draft deal

Body Text: The Auschwitz Memorial International Council ha issued a heartfelt plea for the urgent and unconditional release of all hostage caught in the midst of the escalating conflict in Gaza , emphasizing the paramount importance of ending their suffering . `` The International Auschwitz Council , represented by the Prime Minister of the Republic of Poland , acknowledges with the deepest pain and sorrow the suffering of innocent Victims & ndash ; tortured , raped , taken hostage , and murdered by Hamas terrorist , `` stated the Auschwitz Memorial International Council . `` We wish to express our unwavering solidarity with Israelis and Jews worldwide , `` the council emphasized.The council , including Deputy Chairman Dani Dayan , Chairman of the Yad Vashem Institute , and Deputy Chairman Albert Stankowski , Director of the Warsaw Ghetto Museum , affirmed , `` Threatened in it existence , the State of Israel ha the right to self-defense in accordance with international law and the principle of humanitarianism . The existence of a free , sovereign , and democratic Jewish State is one of the pillar of world peace . `` Only result in more widespread suffering '' The unimaginable hatred and violence perpetrated by terrorist only result in extensive and more widespread suffering & ndash ; affecting also the civilian population of Gaza , whom Hamas exploit a human shield , `` warned the council . `` An essential first step to halt the horrifying spiral of death and war is the immediate and unconditional release of all hostage , a demand we make with all our might , `` the Auschwitz Memorial International Council concluded.The council also includes member such a Colette Avital , Israeli diplomat and politician ; Michael Berenbaum , Director of the Sigi Ziering Institute ; Sara Bloomfield , Director of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum ; Piotr Cywiński , Director of the Auschwitz-Birkenau Memorial and Museum ; Ronald Lauder , Chairman of the World Jewish Congress ; and Marian Turski , Chairman of the International Auschwitz Committee , among others . These distinguished individual play vital role in Holocaust remembrance and education .

Body Text: Security source estimate that Hamas leader Mohammed Deif and Yahya Sinwar were aware of the close surveillance by the Israeli intelligence community and used covert method to communicate message . `` No one understood this , not Aman ( Military Intelligence ) , not the Shin Bet , nor the Mossad , `` admitted a security official . `` Otherwise , they would n't have left the border unguarded , with no basic response from the ground or air . `` Deif and Sinwar , under surveillance by Israeli intelligence , operated to convey message covertly , security source believe . According to assessment , Hamas conducted a meticulous preparation for an incursion on October 7 , described by a senior security system official a `` a perfect deception exercise . `` An Israeli security official explained the tactic used by the Hamas military commander for message transmission . `` It 's likely that the confidential detail , instruction , and overall sentiment were reserved for face-to-face conversation or other mean , `` he admitted . `` In retrospect , the intelligence community did n't grasp this . Body Text: Deep underground , dozen of meter beneath the surface , in a classified location in the Negev lie a unique facility storing large quantity of fuel for emergency , N12 reported on Wednesday.According to N12 's report , the underground fuel cache 's goal is to provide continuous operational energy for Israel even during war and in the most challenging scenario imaginable . It is one of the largest fuel tank in Israel and is located in a unique facility in the entire Middle East.Moshe Kaltzyn , CEO of the Energy Infrastructure Directorate : `` We are distributing fuel to every corner of the country . We can provide fuel immediately , in a process that take only a few hour . We have million of liter here , enough for the long term . You can be confident with the quantity we have here . `` According to the National Emergency Authority 's attribution scenario , during an expected war in Israel , up to 48 hour of blackout , covering 60 % of the country 's territory , are anticipated.Energy backup systemEstimates suggest that during combat in the northern arena , Israel 's gas facility will be shut down , and electricity supply will switch to operate on the basis of fuel and coal . The vast amount of fuel in the reservoir is expected to suffice for an extended emergency period.Israel 's backup system includes storage capability above and below ground throughout the country . When needed , fuel will be distributed to all energy consumer in the country - power station , Ben Gurion Airport , and fuel stations.If fuel import to Israel are completely halted during a war or extreme scenario , the electricity supply will need to be managed with these existing reserve - undoubtedly a challenging task . `` This fuel here can last u for many year . The temperature throughout the year is 22 degree , which effectively preserve the shelf life of the fuel , `` explains Moshe Elimelech , facility manager.Energy Minister Eli Cohen : `` We have energy reserve underground and above ground , including gas , coal , and various fuel , and we are working to provide a responseben gu a needed . The rumor of long week or month of power outage are baseless , and the likelihood of that happening is remote . ``
title: israel hide energy reserve in secret location in negev desert

Body Text: El Al reportedly humiliated an Israeli-Bedouin police officer while he wa on an Israel advocacy mission to the United Kingdom , according to Israeli media.Sgt . - Maj . Ramo Salman Huzeil , an investigator at the Segev Shalom police station , reluctantly became famous on October 7.He wa assigned to security at the Nova Music festival in the morning shift , arrived at the scene eight minute before 6:30 am , then became a hero who took the initiative , organized an escape vehicle , and , while under fire , made dozen of round of the site of the festival massacre , saving hundred of people , whom he moved to safety , only to return , again and again , saving more and more people.In the day that followed , the medium wanted to interview him , and his story grabbed headline in Israel and worldwide.Following his heroism and the publicity he received , he wa sent to London about two week ago a part of an awareness campaign for the State of Israel to gather support for the call to release the hostages.The initiative wa part of the & ldquo ; Israel is & rdquo ; Association , which ha set itself the goal of & ldquo ; creating high-quality , genuine , and universal meeting & rdquo ; between Israelis and young people worldwide.Israel advocacy campaignHuzeil , whose career in the Israel Police made him an even more fitting ambassador for the country , wa very proud of his role.However , according to him , his elation upon returning from this mission wa cut short by hostility when he received what he claimed wa a humiliating security check before boarding El Al flight 326 at it connection at the Paris airport . & ldquo ; Is this the thanks I get ? & rdquo ; he asked.Not worthy of respect ? & ldquo ; I returned from a mission in which I represented the State of Israel , our country . We met with the Jewish community in England , high-ranking , wealthy people ; we met with lord and member of parliament ; and in the end , I went through an experience that made me feel second class after they checked me a if I were a criminal , a if I am not worthy of respect . & rdquo ; As Huzeil , 38 year old and father of three , tell his story , his voice break and tear choke him . & ldquo ; I am an investigator in the Israel Police . This appears in their system , and I also showed them my ID when they asked , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; They put me through an illogical examination and asked unnecessary and intrusive question , which made me feel like I wa under investigation like I wa guilty of something . It could be that the examiner wanted to embarrass or lower my value and dignity : I have no other way to explain it . I left there feeling terrible , and when I retell it , it brings me back to those moment , and I experience it again . & rdquo ; Huzeil said the investigator & ldquo ; also refused to identify herself , but she wanted to know how many child I have , what their name are , if I have another passport ( I have a Swiss one , I showed her ) , how long I have known the woman in the delegation that I flew back with , where I wa , what I did , etc . & ldquo ; I told her that she wa talking to a police officer and not a regular citizen , `` he said . `` She didn & rsquo ; t care at all and asked if my big bag had a lock or not ; I wa already annoyed by her disdain and also by her treatment of me in a humiliating manner . If this is how they treat a police officer and investigator who wa at the Nova Festival and saved hundred of human life , I don & rsquo ; t know if there is anything left to say . & ldquo ; The fact is that the two girl who were with me did not go through the same experience and were released to board the plane very quickly , & rdquo ; Huzeil said . & ldquo ; Only I wa asked disgusting question . I & rsquo ; m a police officer , and they interrogated me more than an ordinary citizen . It wa a humiliating and unnecessary experience . & rdquo ; In response , El Al stated that , & ldquo ; First of all , we are very sorry for the passenger & rsquo ; s feeling . The security screening procedure for passenger is based on security reason only , in accordance with the guideline of the authorized body and the professional aviation security procedure . & ldquo ; We would like to emphasize that during the conversation held by the security representative at the airport with the passenger , no special finding or problem came up , and they always made sure to treat the passenger with respect and courtesy , `` the airline said . & ldquo ; The Israeli aviation security establishment and El Al are full of appreciation and gratitude for the action of Mr . Huzeil in the event of October 7 and for his ongoing contribution to the security of the country . El Al see itself a the airline of the entire Israeli society and will continue to be so in the future a well . & rdquo ;
title: el al humiliates bedouin cop , who rescued dozen on oct . 7 , while he 's advocating for israel

Body Text: Against the background of the protest against the Netanyahu government , which are intensifying a the war continues , on Sunday evening , Brig . - Gen Amir Haskel , one of the leader of the protest against the government , spoke with Ben Caspit and Prof . Body Text: Not long ago , Walter Bingham celebrated his 100th birthday , but a he phrase it , he ha entered his 101st year of life.I first met Walter in Jerusalem when I wa working at a radio station , where he wa featured on it Aliyah Show . A long-time experienced broadcaster , he wa subsequently offered his own show , Walter & rsquo ; s World . I wa the sound engineer and frequently joined Walter for live broadcast and to cover news events.Walter quickly adapted to the new , ever-changing technology , and his hand-held digital recorder and microphone became his constant companion . We went backstage to interview performer at music festival , and politician at rallies.With his outgoing personality and relaxed style , Walter wa always able to get guest to open up.Today , he record and edits two program covering current event , a well a human interest story : Walter & rsquo ; s World on Israel National Radio ; and The Walter Bingham File on Israel News Talk Radio.Despite his age , he often join the international medium to cover event at dangerous locations.Walter also spends time commemorating the memory of the Holocaust through frequent speaking engagement . Last May , he spent a week in the Berlin area talking to schoolchildren about his youth in Germany and the rise of Nazism.In October , he wa hosted by the March of the Living organization , which promotes Holocaust education , for a special reenactment of the Kindertransport , which saved up to 10,000 child from the Nazis . He traveled with one of three other kinder from Israel to several location in Germany , and then to Holland and England , reenacting their journey in 1939 . That wa how Walter survived the war ; he wa sent to England on the Kindertransport , where he grew up without his parents.Throughout the journey , they were interviewed and filmed for a documentary , which captured touching moments.When the ferry left the port of Hoek Van Holland , emotion welled up a Walter remembered waving goodbye to Europe and awaiting freedom in England , a he did 84 year ago.I had the opportunity to interview Walter about the experience for my podcast , Jewish History Moment.Kindertransport Refugee Walter Bingham Returns to Germany by Ben BreskyWalter Bingham describes the Kindertransport reenactment , modern German attitude to Jews post-Holocaust and his travel to Europe during the Israel-Gaza war.Kindertransport Refugee Walter Bingham Returns to Germany by Ben BreskyWalter Bingham describes the Kindertransport reenactment , modern German attitude to Jews post-Holocaust and his travel to Europe during the Israel-Gaza war.Read on SubstackGermans then v todayWalter explained that he had previously returned to Germany in 1988 , but the attitude were different . & ldquo ; I wa invited by the municipality , who were very nice , but the population didn & rsquo ; t seem to care about u . Nobody smiled , nobody waved , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; This time it wa different . We were approached by local in Germany . You couldn & rsquo ; t miss u because we had two cameraman , a sound man , and lighting . The Germans were friendly , interested , and very happy to see u . The atmosphere wa so much different . & rdquo ; Walter & rsquo ; s trip to Germany coincided with the Oct . 7 attack in Israel , and he commented on how the president of Germany traveled to Israel in a display of support.Walter explained that 1988 wa too soon after World War II . & ldquo ; That generation were the child and grandchild of those who voted for Hitler . They were still indoctrinated , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; It take several generation to take the poison out of their system , although there is still an element of neo-Nazis in Germany . & rdquo ; In February 2024 , March of the Living hosted Walter to again speak in London for three major event . This month , he went to the Auschwitz-Birkenau Memorial in Poland with March of the Living for Holocaust Remembrance Day , where he recited Kaddish at the end of the commemoration.The Nazi daggerWhen Walter speaks about his wartime experience to group , he ha a visual presentation with picture , photo , and chart that explain antisemitism and the Nazi era.Among the item he pass around to the audience is an authentic Hitler Youth dagger with a swastika . The blade is inscribed with the word & ldquo ; Blood and honor & rdquo ; in German . & ldquo ; For me it meant Jewish blood , & rdquo ; Walter explained , & ldquo ; because after school , I saw my fellow pupil marching in Hitler Youth uniform singing & lsquo ; When Jewish blood spurt from the knife , everything go much better . & rsquo ; & rdquo ; British ArmyAfter arriving in England with the Kindertransport , he spent several year on a religious kibbutz training camp in Wales.Walter then went to London and joined the British Army . In June 1944 , he landed on the beach of Normandy . For his extraordinary action , he wa awarded the Military Medal for bravery in the field by King George VI . He also received France & rsquo ; s highest honor , the L & eacute ; gion d & rsquo ; honneur.As a fluent German speaker , he wa eventually transferred to London to train a a document specialist and counter-intelligence operative . On VE Day ( May 8 , 1945 ) , he wa sent to Hamburg , where he wa given an office in the former Nazi party headquarters of the greater Hamburg area.Among the numerous interview he conducted wa one with Nazi foreign minister Joachim von Ribbentrop , who denied all knowledge of the Holocaust , although he oversaw all anti-Jewish activity in Nazi-occupied Europe . He wa the first of the senior Nazi leader to be executed after the Nuremberg war crime trials.After the war , Walter made a life for himself in England . Following his BA , he obtained a post-graduate degree in political philosophy from the University of London . That helped him to take up a career in radio journalism.Modeling careerTo supplement his income , Walter grew a beard and wa in demand a an actor and advertising model . He wa Santa Claus at Herrods , England & rsquo ; s premier department store , and for several year in London & rsquo ; s Selfridges department store.In documentary , he played Charles Darwin , a well a other interesting part . Advertisements with his photo could be seen in poster on London bus and underground stations.I wa even filmed with Walter . A Jerusalem-based musician wa shooting a music video for Purim and asked for volunteer . When Walter and I showed up , they were especially glad to see him and promptly gave him the role of Mordechai.Today Walter , who made aliyah in 2004 at age 80 , ha become a known name in Israel among the English-speaking community , journalist , and the many diplomat he ha interviewed . President Isaac Herzog visited him on his birthday.Among his many honor , he hold two Guinness World Records : a the oldest working journalist in the world , and the oldest active radio show host.Plans for the futureAs a pilot , Walter once flew his airplane solo from England to Israel . One of his most emotional moment wa circling low over Jerusalem , with tear running down his cheek . For his 95th birthday , he went skydiving and is planning another jump within the next several months.His birthday cake this year bore the word & ldquo ; Until 180 & rdquo ; instead of the usual wish & ldquo ; Until 120 & rdquo ; because a Walter say , there is still much more work to be done . ■ & lsquo ; Kaddish & rsquo ; in BirkenauWalter Bingham participated in the 2024 commemoration of Holocaust Remembrance Day in Poland and recited mourner & rsquo ; Kaddish in front of 7,000 participants.The commemoration included 55 Holocaust survivor , several of whom were also survivor of the Oct . 7 Hamas attack in Israel . & ldquo ; It wa very emotional , & rdquo ; Bingham told In Jerusalem.The event , organized by March of the Living , begin at the Auschwitz concentration camp , with student and others marching to the ruin of the Birkenau camp . A series of speech and prayer took place near where the Birkenau gas chamber were located.Among the participant were Rabbi Yisrael Meir Lau , a survivor and former chief rabbi of Israel ; popular Israeli singer Noa Kirel , who sang & ldquo ; Eli Eli & rdquo ; ; and IDF Chief Cantor Shai Abramson , who recited the El Maleh Rachamim ( Prayer of Mercy ) . Bingham noted that March of the Living had distributed blue jacket and Israeli flag to participant , giving the impression of a sea of blue a they marched.Many of the participant pledged to pay homage to the survivor and made a commitment to transmit the history and lesson of the Holocaust to the next generation .
title: 100-year-old friend : talking with walter bingham , the world 's oldest journalist

Body Text: Incoming prime minister Naftali Bennett will be sworn in on Sunday in the shadow of last month & rsquo ; s Gaza war , domestic Jewish-Arab unrest and amid the threat of renewed IDF-Hamas hostility , particularly over Jerusalem . & nbsp ; The sequence of event that are likely to unfold in the coming week , let alone the coming month , would be a test under fire for any prime minister , but will present a unique challenge for this particular government because of it unorthodox composition . & nbsp ; The new coalition headed by Bennett of the right-wing Yamina Party and incoming foreign minister Yair Lapid of the centrist Yesh Atid Party also includes left-wing party and the Arab Islamist Ra & rsquo ; am Party . & nbsp ; It & rsquo ; s a coalition that ha an unprecedented ideological range and many of the decision that it make are likely to involve principled compromise by one or more of it member . & nbsp ; The Israeli-Palestinian conflict is the most contentious and divisive arena for this coalition and issue relating to it are expected to be one of it weakest link . & nbsp ; It & rsquo ; s precisely here , on the Israeli-Palestinian front , the new coalition will be tested , both within it first week and it first month in these four way . & nbsp ; 1 . Evyatar outpost evacuation & nbsp ; Defense Minister Benny Gantz , who will retain his role in the new coalition , is poised to evacuate the West Bank outpost on Monday , less than 24 hour after the government is sworn in . The outpost wa built last month in the aftermath of a Palestinian terror attack at the West Bank Tapuah junction , in which Yehuda Guetta , 19 , wa killed . It wa erected on a spot that settler had first attempted to settle in 2013 in the aftermath of a Tapuah junction terror attack in which Evyatar Borovsky , 31 , wa killed . & nbsp ; The reconstruction of the outpost named in Evyatar & rsquo ; s memory wa largely ignored by the IDF . Within a month & rsquo ; s time , close to 50 family had moved onto the site . & nbsp ; Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu & rsquo ; s plea to Gantz to allow the community to remain wa ignored , so only direct intervention by Bennett can prevent it evacuation . & nbsp ; Should Bennett intervene , he would likely anger the left-wing flank of his coalition , a well a some of it centrist member , such a Gantz , who head the Blue and White Party . & nbsp ; Such an evacuation , however , risk inflaming the West Bank and setting off a chain of violent event . Past outpost evacuation were often followed by violent retaliatory attack by right-wing Jewish extremist against Palestinians . This would come at a time when Hamas is already attempting to inflame the West Bank . & nbsp ; 2 . The Flag March & nbsp ; Police on Friday approved a parade route for a right-wing Flag March set for Tuesday , just one day after the anticipated West Bank outpost evacuation . & nbsp ; The annual event is typically associated with Jerusalem Day event that mark the celebration of the city & rsquo ; s unification in the aftermath of the Six Day War , in which Israel captured the eastern part of the city from Jordan and subsequently annexed it . & nbsp ; During Jerusalem Day last month , however , marcher were prohibited from following their traditional route through the Old City & rsquo ; s Damascus Gate and the Muslim Quarter , and were instead expected to head through the Jaffa Gate . Hamas fired seven rocket at Jerusalem during the march , thereby officially bringing it to a halt . This month , march organizer had sought to hold the march along it original route and in the end brokered a compromise with the police by which they would dance with flag by the Damascus Gate that open into the Muslim Quarter . & nbsp ; The area in front of the gate ha been one of the city flashpoint for Israeli-Palestinian violence . Police closure of the area briefly a a place of Palestinian gathering in April during the Muslim holiday of Ramadan wa one of the initial spark that led to May & rsquo ; s violent outbreak . & nbsp ; An Israeli flag dance by the Damascus Gate , which for the Right is an important symbol of sovereignty over the city , is similarly expected to ignite renewed Palestinian violence . & nbsp ; 3 . Palestinian eviction in Jerusalem & nbsp ; There are four existing land issue in Jerusalem that could lead to the eviction of thousand of Palestinians from their home in three east Jerusalem neighborhood . & nbsp ; The one that captured both medium attention and that of Hamas last month wa the fate of some 28 family in the Sheikh Jarrah neighborhood . The High Court of Justice ha yet to decide whether to weigh in on the matter or to allow for the eviction to move forward . No date ha been set for it decision . & nbsp ; But date do exist for additional case . The attorney-general is expected by the end of June to issue an opinion on a land case in Silwan & rsquo ; s Batan al-Hawa that could impact at least 700 Palestinians . & nbsp ; Another land case regarding al-Bustan in Silwan that could impact more than 1,000 Palestinians ha been delayed until August . Some 13 family , however , could be in danger of losing their home , irrespective of that ruling , because they fall under the dictate of the Kaminitz Law , which block them from seeking any additional legal recourse . & nbsp ; One such Palestinian family wa already given a notice last week that he ha 21 day to destroy half his home , otherwise the municipality would move to knock down that portion of his abode . It & rsquo ; s a demotion that could equally spark violence and the pending eviction that neighborhood have been under intentional scrutiny . & nbsp ; Lastly , the issue of pending eviction in the Walaja neighborhood of east Jerusalem is also due back in court on June 21 . & nbsp ; The Right ha viewed each of the case a land issue . The one in al-Bustan and Walaja involve municipal plan for park . The case in Sheikh Jarrah and Batan al-Hawa involving property dispute between Palestinians and Jews . & nbsp ; But they are seen within the larger context of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and placed within the prism of the battle for sovereignty in Jerusalem , with the Left and the Palestinians believing that the eviction are an attempt by the city to seize control of Palestinian neighborhood for Jewish project and resident . & nbsp ; The neighborhood battle have sparked tension and violence , with the European Union and the US weighing in on behalf of the Palestinians . Hamas ha also threatened violence a a result , and the issue of Sheikh Jarrah , in particular , wa one of the spark that led to May & rsquo ; s violence . & nbsp ; 4 . Gaza & nbsp ; The IDF-Hamas 11-day war ended on May 21 , but it & rsquo ; s unclear if the calm is a lull in the war or the end of this round of violence . Hamas ha already renewed it threat of more rocket fire with regard to the Flag March and there exists a real chance it could make good on it threat . & nbsp ; Bennett and Lapid & rsquo ; s coalition could be in the position in it first week of deciding whether and how to retaliate should that happen . It would mark the first time that Israel would have a coalition with divergent view on how to handle Hamas rocket . & nbsp ; When Netanyahu became prime minister in 2009 , Hamas had been in charge of Gaza for less than two year , having ousted Fatah in a bloody coup in 2007 . The initial Gaza policy and the first Gaza war occurred under former prime minister Ehud Olmert & rsquo ; s watch . & nbsp ; The bulk of the Gaza policy , however & ndash ; including the 2012 and 2014 war , a well a the border restriction on good & ndash ; ha been set by Netanyahu . It wa one of the area of consensus within his government . The disagreement that existed centered around the question of whether Israel had been hash enough , rather than too lenient . & nbsp ; Bennett , who often criticized Netanyahu for not doing enough on Gaza , particularly with respect to the tunnel threat , will now have to decide how harsh a response he would authorize . & nbsp ; Even without violence , other question must immediately be answered , particularly with regard to what type of good can enter Gaza and what mechanism can be put in place to ensure that Hamas can not divert material for military use . & nbsp ; The term of the calm between the IDF and Hamas that is now in place have yet to be set . Egypt is mediating indirect talk . It is still attempting to finalize those detail while at the same time attempting to create a permanent ceasefire that could include the return of the remains of two IDF soldier and the release of two Israeli citizen held by Hamas . & nbsp ; All these issue must now be dealt with by the Bennett government , with the possibility that the failure to find a satisfactory response could lead to renewed violence . & nbsp ; Egypt ha also chosen this time to become more involved in Gaza , a move that could potentially lower the possibility of renewed Hamas rocket fire , but which may lead to tension point with Israel .

Body Text: 86 Holocaust survivor who were evacuated from their home from both southern and northern Israel following the outbreak of the Israel-Hamas war have passed away , the Welfare and Social Affairs Ministry announced on Thursday ahead of Holocaust Remembrance Day next week.According to the ministry , 52 Holocaust survivor died from the city of Ashkelon , 12 survivor from Sderot , and 11 survivor from other settlement in the south . In addition , 11 Holocaust survivor died from the evacuated northern settlement of Shomrat , Metula , Kibbutz Dan , Shlomi , and Kibbutz Yir & rsquo ; on.The data show that some of the 238 Holocaust survivor who were evacuated to hotel returned to their home or moved to other place . In the city of Ashkelon , 122 Holocaust survivor left hotel , while in Sderot , 33 Holocaust survivor left . Most of the Holocaust survivor who were evacuated from the north , on the other hand , remained in the evacuation center , like much of the other resident . From Kiryat Shmona , for example , only two Holocaust survivor left the hotel , a well a two from Metula and seven from Shlomi.About 2,500 Holocaust survivor experienced the difficult event of October 7 . About 2,000 Holocaust survivor were forced to abandon their home and evacuate to a safe area a a result.In the meantime , the ministry note an increase in the number of Holocaust survivor who are assisted by welfare service . According to the data , this applies to 42 % of Holocaust survivor in Israel . As of 2024 , the office provides service to approximately 48,610 survivor , compared to 45,300 last year . 22,893 of the Holocaust survivor receive service from various framework of the Welfare and Social Affairs Ministry , mainly through support community . 1,710 survivor receive assistance through the social payment system , receiving mainly material and financial assistance . 5,110 receive service from the Friendship Fund in cooperation with the Welfare and Social Affairs Ministry.In addition , more than 1,000 Holocaust survivor are assisted by a remote welfare program and a connected program - program to alleviate loneliness and strengthen intergenerational tie through two-way digital communication technology system for remote contact and physical meeting , which aim to improve the quality of life of Holocaust survivor in the community in term of reducing loneliness and a sense of belonging , promoting a healthy lifestyle , and promoting digital literacy.Israeli government and ministry seek to alleviate difficulty for survivorsThe Welfare and Social Affairs Ministry added designated standard for the care and assistance of Holocaust survivor in local authority , alongside the expansion of community service to all senior citizen in the State of Israel and various programs.Welfare and Social Affairs Minister Ya & rsquo ; akov Margi said : `` This year , more than ever , we have an obligation a a ministry , a a society , and a a community to embrace Holocaust survivor , many of whom experienced the event of the terrible massacre on October 7 and brought back to them difficult memory of the terrible Holocaust . `` `` At a time when the State of Israel is fighting for it right to exist and when terrible antisemitic event and demonstration take place every day in city and campus around the world , the generation of Holocaust survivor are our light and moral compass and the beacon of faith in our righteousness . The people , many of whom have experienced the horror of both time , are testimony to the rise of Israel and the strength and resilience of the Jewish people , `` he concluded . & nbsp ; Director General of the Welfare and Social Affairs Ministry , Yinon Aharoni , said : `` Aid and support for Holocaust survivor is at the heart of the ministry 's activity , and we are constantly working to diversify and expand the program and service for this population . The goal is to personally reach every survivor , and to lay out before them all the right and service they deserve . Our debt a a country and citizen to the survivor of the Holocaust is enormous , and we must work every day to make sure that they will live a good life with good health and a supportive and wide social network a possible , and this so that they will not lack anything . ``
title: of the 2,500 holocaust survivor who experienced the october 7 massacre , 86 have died

Body Text: Fifty-five year after the 1967 war , the status of the West Bank ( aka Judea and Samaria ) and of it Palestinian Arabs resident remains unclear , temporary and officially disputed.Because the war & rsquo ; s outcome wa unexpected , Israel & rsquo ; s government at the time did not have a ready framework for the future . In the best of Jewish tradition , minister and pundit spent week , month and then year debating the issue , waiting in vain for the Palestinians to respond substantively . & nbsp ; For more story released for the 55th anniversary of the Six Day War , click here.In this vacuum , some Israeli group created fact on the ground that evolved into settlement and city on ancient Jewish biblical site , while the army established position that , in some instance , became town . The result wa chaotic , with no strategic or political coherence . Unlike almost every other country , Israel doe not have clear border and operates two parallel legal system & ndash ; one for pre-1967 Israel , and another for the resident of the post - & rsquo ; 67 territory.Another unplanned result is the gradual morphing of the land from the Mediterranean to the Jordan River into a single political entity , in which the Palestinian and Jewish population of approximately the same size are locked into wave of terrorism and response.For the Palestinians , the 55-year status quo keep alive the illusion of moving the clock back to 1947 , abetted by massive international support for a unique and mythical & ldquo ; refugee & rdquo ; status . The image of a single state in which half or more of the population is Palestinian , and where Jews ( Zionists ) eventually disappear like the Crusaders , is far more appealing than a & ldquo ; two-state solution , & rdquo ; which would acknowledge the legitimacy of Jewish sovereignty , regardless of borders.While many Israelis have become accustomed to the stalemate , for outsider & ndash ; including many Jews & ndash ; Israel is presented by the NGO industry in cartoon-like portrait of colonial settler , apartheidists and serial killer of journalist , accompanied by the slogan and myth of international law . When Al Jazeera reporter Shireen Abu Akleh wa killed in Jenin , Israel wa automatically accused of & ldquo ; cold-blooded murder , & rdquo ; ignoring the absence of evidence . In part , this demonization reflects hostility to Jewish empowerment & ndash ; in other word , antisemitism & ndash ; regardless of border , and reinforced by NGO propaganda campaign . The post-1967 image , however inaccurate and unfair , make this easier.In parallel , after more than five decade , ten of thousand of family living outside the 1949 & ldquo ; Green Line & rdquo ; face outbreak of chaos and uncertainty . Disputes over land ownership lead to year of legal proceeding and unpredictable court decision . This absurd situation is unimaginable for people living a few kilometer away , on the other side , in & ldquo ; sovereign & rdquo ; Israel.None of these observation are new & ndash ; indeed , they should be obvious . Not obvious at all is what can be done in 2022 to replace the status quo with a better and realistic framework , if one can be found . The search for alternative that avoid the drift and end the chaos is critical for the future of Israel and Zionism.The goal here is not to propose another imaginary peace plan & ndash ; there are plenty of these gathering dust on physical and virtual diplomatic and academic shelf . Rather , my objective is to contribute to a renewed Israeli debate on option and alternative to the status quo , based on where we are now , in June 2022 . The hope is that through a substantive discussion anchored in political realism , Israel can move beyond the trap of continuing chaos leading to a single non-Zionist state.Diplomatic Dead Ends : 1967-2022Before considering alternative , a brief summary of previous effort is worthwhile , at least to avoid some of the illusion and mistakes.Immediately after the 1967 war , euphoric Israelis , who feared the worst just a few day before , were suddenly able to enter Jerusalem & rsquo ; s Old City and visit the ancient biblical site that had been previously closed to Jews . A return to the narrow armistice line ( drawn in green on map ) that had prevailed since 1949 wa , and remains , unthinkable.Unlike Egypt and Syria , there wa no international border in the West Bank to serve a a basis for negotiation & ndash ; Jordan & rsquo ; s Arab Legion had occupied this territory for almost 20 year , including eastern Jerusalem , and allowed fedayeen to launch murderous raid into Israel . Going back to the previous situation wa a non-starter & ndash ; the question wa , and remains , what should replace it ? In addition to holding Jerusalem , official agreed that the Jordan River would remain a Israel & rsquo ; s eastern border , with a buffer and access zone in the Jordan Valley . But from here , the view diverged . Foreign Minister Yigal Allon presented a plan in which small area such a Gush Etzion ( from which Jews were expelled in 1948 ) would be incorporated . But most of the West Bank would revert to Jordan , noting that : & ldquo ; From a demographic standpoint , a Jewish majority will be kept/maintained , which would allow Israel to exist a a democratic Jewish state , based on the principle of the Zionist vision . & rdquo ; In contrast , minister-without-portfolio Menachem Begin adamantly rejected foreign sovereignty over any part of the Land of Israel , including Judea and Samaria & ndash ; the biblical term that were also used during the British Mandate . However , while agreeing with Allon on demography and Zionism , he rejected annexation , even a prime minister a decade later . Begin & rsquo ; s alternative wa autonomy for the & ldquo ; Arab population in the Land of Israel , & rdquo ; including control of education , finance , service and other sector & ndash ; everything except security and foreign policy.Neither Allon & rsquo ; s nor Begin & rsquo ; s proposal went beyond the debating stage , primarily because the Palestinians were only interested in turning the clock back to 1947 & ndash ; in other word , the elimination of Israel . Nothing caused them to abandon the & ldquo ; all-or-nothing & rdquo ; approach and consider pragmatic compromise , such a a & ldquo ; two-state solution & rdquo ; or a federation with Jordan.IN THE POLICY vacuum , the Israeli presence in these area gradually and chaotically increased . Periodically , another attempt at change would start & ndash ; for example , in 1987 , then-foreign minister Shimon Peres negotiated secretly with Jordan & rsquo ; s King Hussein in London & ndash ; but this wa another dead end.The Oslo Accords , signed in 1993 and accompanied by a White House extravaganza , marked the most sustained effort , including the creation of the Palestinian Authority , which governs more than 90 % of the Palestinian population . To Israelis , Oslo wa presented a embodying the & ldquo ; land for peace & rdquo ; formula , leading to a permanent status agreement and presumably two state within five year . The term & ldquo ; end of conflict & rdquo ; wa used frequently , and the demographic threat to Zionism seemed to be averted.But to Palestinians , PLO leader Yasser Arafat marketed Oslo a a short-term tactical measure , to be renounced once the benefit had been realized . The massive UNRWA & ldquo ; refugee & rdquo ; support system remained intact , and the incitement and terrorist attack continued and even increased in the form of mass terror directed , or at least approved of , by Arafat . Israelis recognized that on the other side , nothing had changed . And Israel & rsquo ; s improved relation with the so-called & ldquo ; international community & rdquo ; evaporated quickly when the IDF moved to counter Arafat & rsquo ; s war.The next effort to end the stalemate took place in 2005 , when prime minister Ariel Sharon unilaterally & ldquo ; disengaged & rdquo ; from Gaza and from two small civilian location ( & ldquo ; settlement & rdquo ; ) in Samaria . Two year later , the Hamas terrorist organization took control of Gaza , followed by the acquisition of thousand of rocket and missile , and the construction of massive terror tunnel . Sharon became incapacitated in 2006 , Israel failed to destroy the nascent Hamas war machine and discussion of further unilateral withdrawal from the West Bank came to a halt , particularly with the election of Benjamin Netanyahu in 2009.But Netanyahu also understood the difficulty inherent in an infinite stalemate , leading him to support the initiative for unilateral annexation ( & ldquo ; extension of sovereignty & rdquo ; ) . Details were not revealed and no official map were made public , but the discourse focused on incorporating the major settlement and the strategic area of Area C ( including the Jordan Valley ) . However , the effort became mired in Israeli electoral politics a well a strong international opposition , and in 2020 , it wa officially halted in the context of the Abraham Accords.As this brief history demonstrates , after 55 year , the temporary status quo , with all of it weakness , continues . At the same time , the default option of a single political entity between the Mediterranean and the Jordan River , with roughly equal population and the implication for Zionism , also remains & ndash ; and a noted , is the Palestinian & rsquo ; s favorite . These problem will not disappear , and a Israelis , we have the obligation of continuing to look for better options.A Strategy of Political RealismWith this dismal history , it is not surprising that many Israelis have given up . The long drift and it implication are not included in the election platform of any of the main party , and that is precisely the problem . It play into those who are not exactly supporter of Zionism and see the evolution of a one-state framework a the best path to their objectives.To move forward by learning from the failure , a new strategy is long overdue , anchored in political realism and concrete Israeli interest , a distinct from hope , faith or ideology . Realism requires the careful analysis of the relative potential cost and benefit of different option , including continuing the status quo , based on security ( military capability , defensible border ) ; Zionism and demography ( a viable Jewish majority ) ; and the perception of Israel from the outside ( public diplomacy and image ) . On this basis , and unlike Oslo and the other experiment , I suggest starting from the end point & ndash ; Israel & rsquo ; s urgent need to determine our border . Once we examine , debate and then decide on the area we need to hold and where Israel & rsquo ; s and Zionism & rsquo ; s interest are best served by exiting , the path necessary to reach this outcome can be considered.Beyond maintaining the integrity of Jerusalem , particularly the Old City and it sacred site , the core pragmatic requirement is to maximize security and minimize control over and responsibility for the Palestinian population . In Israel today , about 80 % identify a Jewish a compared to 20 % Arabs . Among the world & rsquo ; s other nation-states based on a dominant ethnic , religious or linguistic group ( a distinct from inherently multi-cultural country ) , a minority of 20 % is already considered quite high , particularly when that minority ha recidivist claim . Borders that would reduce the Jewish majority to 60 % , for example , would add significant strain to the Zionist Jewish Hebrew-speaking core.In examining other basic element , there is already wide agreement on the need for full control of the strategic Jordan Valley and the main access corridor to defend it . Similarly , the settlement bloc adjacent to the pre-1967 Green Line and within the separation barrier are readily incorporated into Israel , without including a large Palestinian population . There are also a few exception & ndash ; sizable settlement located in non-contiguous area , such a Ariel and Beit El . But with population of 20,000 and 7,000 , respectively , abandoning them is politically unrealistic.THE REMAINING issue concern the future of Area C & ndash ; which , under the Oslo accord , remains , at least in theory , under full Israeli control . Extending from Jerusalem east to the Jordan River , and north along the Jordan Valley , this land is important strategically , and ha a small Palestinian population . & nbsp ; However , in the absence of a coherent policy , the Palestinians and their European support team are busy creating their own settlement & ndash ; precisely in order to disrupt Israeli requirement . The Palestinian & ldquo ; village & rdquo ; that have been created in key location like Khan al-Ahmar and Masafer Yatta , including fictitious backstories to persuade outsider of their authenticity , are attempt to foreclose the option of retaining this territory . The more time that pass before deciding which part of Area C should become part of Israel , the more difficult this process will become.The final dimension concern perception . For some Israelis and Diaspora Jews , the most painful aspect of the post-1967 status quo is the image of the Jewish state a an occupier , portrayed a brutally denying the Palestinians their own state . This is the basis for campus Boycott , Divestment and Sanctions resolution and other denunciation of Zionism.The question is whether demonization would decrease significantly if the status quo wa replaced with declared border , particularly if these were recognized by the United States and at least some European country . Would the Jews who have become hostile to and alienated from Israel because of the 55-year & ldquo ; occupation & rdquo ; move to a more positive relationship with Israel ? On these question , the evidence is unclear . The image of Palestinian weakness and victimization , in contrast to Israeli power , will not change regardless of any move in the West Bank , and Israel will still be blamed . However , there is reason to expect that among those not committed to the Palestinian cause and anti-Zionism , the demarcation of border would reduce the hostility . Nevertheless , based on a realistic assessment , the potential change in perception of Israel based on the setting of clear border and an end to the temporary post-1967 & ldquo ; occupation & rdquo ; should not be considered a deciding factor.In summary , while the result are far from certain & ndash ; and changing the status quo after 55 year will be difficult to accomplish , particularly in the face of intense ideological opposition & ndash ; the greater danger to Israel and Zionism come from continued drift and chaos . & nbsp ; The longer we allow the illusion of temporary arrangement to fester , the more difficult it will be to deal with the result . ■ The writer is emeritus professor of political science at Bar-Ilan University and president of NGO Monitor . His latest book , Menachem Begin and the Israel-Egypt Peace Process : Between Ideology and Political Realism , wa published by Indiana University Press .
title: 1967 to 2022 : ending 55 year of ‘ temporary ’ drift and chaos

Body Text: The sixth installment of the American Jewish Committee 's Arabic-language video series `` About the Jews `` wa released on Tuesday . `` About the Jews `` is a YouTube video series released by AJC on their Arabic-language platform and aim to challenge stereotype and misconception within the Arab world about the State of Israel and the Jewish people . The newest video in the series , `` Is Israel Only for Jews ? , `` focus on highlighting the coexistence of religious and ethnic group in Israel , while challenging several notion regarding the daily life of an Arab-Israeli . The video acknowledges inequality and outstanding social challenge within Israel , a well a the democratic tool all citizen of Israel possess to address them . `` As the Arab world display greater openness to Israel , it is important that perception of the Jewish state reflect it remarkable pluralism and diversity , `` said AJC CEO David Harris . `` Israel is , at once , the homeland of the Jewish people and a thriving democracy that is home to more than 1.8 million Arab citizen , all of whom enjoy equal right and freedom , `` added Harris . AJC 's video series , most watched in country such a Egypt , Saudi Arabia , Morocco , Tunisia , Jordan and the United Arab Emirates , also touched on other delicate subject , such a the Jewish connection to Jerusalem , the Holocaust and the history of Muslim-Jewish relation . `` The barrier to peace between Israel and the Palestinians are political , not religious or ethnic , `` said Harris . `` We hope this new film will help promote Arab-Israeli peace by upending stereotype about Israel and fostering greater understanding of the Jewish state throughout the Arab world . `` You can watch the English version of `` Is Israel Only for Jews ? `` by AJC below :

Body Text: Palestinian Islamic Jihad ( PIJ ) prisoner have suspended their hunger strike after reaching an agreement with Israeli authority , PIJ official said on Friday . & ldquo ; The prisoner decided to suspend the hunger strike after they scored victory against the administration of the occupation prison authority , & rdquo ; said PIJ official Tareq Ezaddin . The detail of the agreement between the prisoner and the Israel Prison Service will be announced in the coming hour , Ezaddin said . & ldquo ; The victory is a turning point in the confrontation with the [ Israeli ] jailer , & rdquo ; he added . A statement issued by the leadership of the PIJ prisoner held in Israeli prison confirmed that the hunger strike , which began nine day ago , ha ended . Sheikh Khader Adnan , a senior PIJ official in the northern West Bank , & ldquo ; congratulated & rdquo ; the family of the prisoner of PIJ for ending the hunger strike . He did not provide detail about the alleged agreement with the Israeli authority . Some 250 PIJ inmate went on hunger strike nine day ago in protest of restriction imposed on them following the escape of six prisoner from Gilboa Prison last month . & nbsp ; Five of the escapee belong to PIJ , while the sixth , Zakariya Zbeidi , is a member of the ruling Fatah faction headed by Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas . Body Text: Ministers to the right and left of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu issued dueling threat on Tuesday to leave the government over the possibly impending decision of whether or not to move forward with a deal with Hamas to release some of the hostage being held in Gaza.The statement came after US official said on Monday that new progress had been made in negotiation for a & lsquo ; humanitarian & rsquo ; deal to release between 20 to 40 hostage , in which Israel reportedly would suspend it plan to enter Rafah , the last major Hamas stronghold that the IDF ha yet to attack , a well a enable Gazans to return to Gaza City and release hundred of Palestinian prisoners.The far-right flank of Israel & rsquo ; s government , Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich , and National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir pressed Netanyahu to shun the deal and move forward with an invasion of Rafah and threatened to leave the government if the prime minister decided otherwise.In a video statement following a closed-door meeting with Netanyahu on Tuesday afternoon , Ben-Gvir said that the prime minister had promised that Israel would invade Rafah , that the war would not end , and that there will not be a & ldquo ; reckless & rdquo ; deal.He added that he believed that Netanyahu & ldquo ; understands what the consequence are if these thing do not happen , & rdquo ; hinting that he would leave the government if such a deal wa made.Smotrich , in a press conference , demanded that Netanyahu not wave a & ldquo ; white flag & rdquo ; of surrender by agreeing to the Egyptian-brokered deal . He said that Israel wa facing a fork in the road with & ldquo ; no middle & rdquo ; , in which it needed to choose between & ldquo ; decisive victory & rdquo ; and & ldquo ; defeat in the war and humiliation , & rdquo ; and said that he wa willing to pay a & ldquo ; political price & rdquo ; if Netanyahu decided to move forward with the deal . He added that the government did not have a & ldquo ; right to exist & rdquo ; if it went through with the hostage deal a it stood.Gadi Eisenkot responded & nbsp ; In response to both minister , National Unity Minister-without-portfolio Gadi Eisenkot issued a rare statement warning that he would not be a partner in a government that make decision based on & ldquo ; political consideration & rdquo ; . & ldquo ; The cabinet defined the goal of the war six month ago , & rdquo ; Eisenkot said in a written statement that he also posted on Facebook . & ldquo ; In the past day , two cabinet member have been using political threat to commit extortion . This is a serious phenomenon that harm Israel & rsquo ; s national security . I will only be a partner in a government that make decision based on the national interest of the State of Israel , and not on political consideration . & rdquo ; During a meeting earlier on Tuesday with forum of hostage family and family of fallen soldier who are affiliated with the right and support invading Rafah , Netanyahu pledged that Israel would invade the city with or without a deal . & ldquo ; The idea that we will halt the war before achieving all of it goal is out of the question . We will enter Rafah and we will eliminate the Hamas battalion there & ndash ; with or without a deal , in order to achieve the total victory , & rdquo ; Netanyahu said.According to the press statement of the Prime Minister & rsquo ; s Office , & ldquo ; The prime minister listened to their call to continue achieving the goal of the war and to withstand the international pressure . & rdquo ; The two forum that met with the prime minister were the Hope Forum , which includes family of hostage , and the Heroism Forum , which includes family of fallen soldier . Both are affiliated with the right and have largely called to increase military pressure in Gaza . These are separate from the larger Hostage and Missing Families Forum , which ha taken an increasingly critical stand against the government.Opposition leader MK Yair Lapid said in response to Ben-Gvir , & ldquo ; The state of Israel ha become hostage to people who are crazy and irresponsible . This can not continue . A minister with a criminal record stand in the prime minister & rsquo ; s office and threatens the prime minister about the consequence if he doe not do a he is told . Ben-Gvir is saying to the whole world and the whole region that Netanyahu is weak and working for him . It is unbelievable that he wa not fired on the spot . & rdquo ; The coalition currently includes 72 Knesset member . Ben-Gvir and Smotrich together have 14 seat , and without them the coalition will be left with 58 Knesset member , and will no longer have a majority in the 120-member Knesset . & nbsp ;
title: eisenkot , far-right minister threaten government over hostage deal

Body Text: The last week ha been an anatomy of a spiraling brawl between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and US President Joe Biden.First , there wa the & ldquo ; hot mic & rdquo ; moment last week in which Biden , in an incident that many thought wa scripted , wa heard telling politician that he wanted to have a & ldquo ; come to Jesus meeting & rdquo ; with Netanyahu.That wa followed by Biden & rsquo ; s attack on Netanyahu on Sunday , when during an interview with MSNBC he said the Israeli Prime Minister & ldquo ; is hurting Israel more than helping Israel . . . it is contrary to what Israel stand for , and I think it & rsquo ; s a big mistake . & rdquo ; On Monday a US Intelligence Assessment report speculated that Netanyahu could be overthrown .
