Political symbol like this are strictly prohibited for artist performing or competing in the show , but Saade 's keffiya , a scarf associated with the Palestinian cause , almost matched his black-and-white shirt , so it could have passed for part of his outfit . However , Eurovision chose not to post video of him on social medium . He is one of more than one thousand musician from Sweden who published a joint statement in January of this year calling for Israel to be kicked out of the competition , and artist from other country have also requested this . However , no artist agreed to boycott the competition despite these call . 🇧 🇪 Mustii ha `` Peace `` written on his shoulder # Eurovision # Belguim pic.twitter.com/aRsknEORy2 & mdash ; Eurovision Insider ( @ escinsiders ) May 9 , 2024Belgium 's representative , Mustii , had the word `` peace `` written on his arm during his performance at the semi-final.The Flemish Broadcasting Authority in Belgium opened the Eurovision broadcast on Thursday night with a protest slide against Israel that said , `` We condemn Israel 's violation of human right , which also harm the freedom of the press . Ceasefire now . `` The Finnish singer , K & auml ; & auml ; rij & auml ; , danced with Golan a camera rolled . The video wa posted to social medium by KAN and other place , but he later posted a disclaimer to Instagram that said , `` I happened to meet Israel 's Eurovision representative today , and a video wa filmed of u . It wa then posted on social medium without my permission . Despite my request for it removal , it ha not been taken down . I would like to clarify and emphasize that the video is not a political statement or an endorsement of any kind . `` Israel ha won Eurovision four time , most recently in 2018 with `` Toy , `` sung by Netta Barzilai . Last year , Noa Kirel performed `` Unicorn `` and came in third . But no matter where she place in the Final , Golan ha already won heart around the world with her grace under pressure.Netanyahu wish Golan luck ahead of performancePrime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu wished Golan luck in her performance in a video released on Thursday ahead of the show . & nbsp ; In his statement , Netanyahu said , `` Eden , I want to wish you success , but you have already succeeded . You not only face Eurovision in a proud and impressive way , but you successfully face a wave of antisemitism while standing and representing the State of Israel with respect . `` Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu wish Israel 's Eurovision contestant , Eden Golan , luck in the contest . Netanyahu referred to Golan facing booing from the crowd during her rehearsal in Malm & ouml ; , telling her that Israel stood firmly behind her and supported her in her endeavors.Jerusalem Post Staff contributed to this report .
title: eurovision 2024 : israel 's eden golan advance to eurovision final

Body Text: The French Navy 's Languedoc frigate intercepted two drone fired from a Houthi-controlled area in Yemen which were heading straight toward it on Saturday , the General Staff of the French Armed Forces said on Saturday night.The two drone were launched from near Al Hudaydah , a port city controlled by the Iran-backed Houthis , before they were intercepted about 110 km . from the coast , according to the navy . The first drone wa launched at the vessel at about 10:30 p.m . Israel time , and the second wa launched at 12:30 a.m.The Languedoc ha been deployed in the Indian Ocean Maritime Zone since August and recently accompanied the US Navy 's USS Dwight D . Eisenhower aircraft carried through the Strait of Hormuz into the Persian Gulf . & nbsp ; Earlier on Saturday , the spokesman for the Houthi 's military force , Yahya Sare ' e , threatened to attack any ship heading toward Israel , no matter which country the vessel belongs to . `` In order to ensure the safety of maritime navigation , we warn all ship and company against dealing with Israeli port , `` said Sare ' e.Houthis escalate attack on maritime traffic in the Red Sea , Gulf of AdenIn recent week , the Houthis have escalated their attack on civilian and military vessel in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden.On Wednesday , the movement said that it launched ballistic missile toward Eilat , with the IDF saying it intercepted a missile over the Red Sea . Additionally , the US Navy said it shot down a drone that wa launched from a Houthi-controlled area of Yemen.A few day earlier , three commercial vessel came under attack in the southern Red Sea , with the Houthis saying they had conducted drone and missile attack against two Israeli vessel . The IDF later said that the two ship were not connected to Israel.US Central Command ( CENTCOM ) said at the time that four attack had been conducted against three separate commercial vessel in the southern Red Sea . The three vessel are connected to 14 different countries.According to CENTCOM , the Arleigh-Burke Class destroyer USS Carney responded to distress call issued by the ship and provided assistance . While responding to the call , the destroyer shot down a drone launched from Houthi controlled area . Although the drone wa headed toward the Carney , it specific target is not clear . No damage wa caused to the US vessel and no injury were reported . `` These attack represent a direct threat to international commerce and maritime security , `` said CENTCOM at the time . `` They have jeopardized the life of international crew representing multiple country around the world . `` We also have every reason to believe that these attack , while launched by the Houthis in Yemen , are fully enabled by Iran , `` & nbsp ; it said . `` The United States will consider all appropriate response in full coordination with it international ally and partner . ``
title: french navy intercept two drone fired from houthi area in yemen

Body Text: Contrary to most report , Salim Joubran , who died on March 15 , wa not the first Israeli-Arab Supreme Court justice when he wa appointed in 2003.Technically , that distinction go to Abdel Rahman Zuabi , who received a temporary appointment a a Supreme Court justice in 1999.However , Zuabi served for only nine months.Joubran served from 2003 to 2017 and finished with the rank of deputy chief justice , a well a being the first Israeli-Arab to chair the Central Elections Commission.In that sense , he wa the father of the idea that a minimum of one seat should be an Israeli-Arab.Since then , his seat wa filled by two other Israeli-Arabs . First George Karra , for a short term ; and now by Khaled Kabub.In that regard , Joubran convinced the Jews of Israel that the court & rsquo ; s identity must somewhat reflect the country & rsquo ; s multi-religious nature , and convinced the Arabs of Israel that partnering with Israeli society can be worth it and have real results.Not everything wa perfect . There wa an incident in 2012 when Joubran came under attack by many in the political sphere when he stood for the singing of & ldquo ; Hatikvah & rdquo ; during a state ceremony , but he clearly did not sing the words.Ultimately , Joubran weathered the storm , with many mainstream political and judicial official pointing out that a long a he stood and conveyed respect , that neither he , nor Israeli-Arab soldier , could be expected to sing about Jewish longing to return to their homeland.Orthodox former deputy chief justice Elyakim Rubinstein wa one of those who publicly came to Joubran & rsquo ; s defense at the time , and he eulogized Joubran last week a one of his close friend in the court.Most of the time , though , Joubran managed to stay out of and above politics.He represented Israel around the world and served a one of it brightest light in embodying Israeli multicultural coexistence.Whenever critic tried to tear Israel down a discriminating against Arabs , the example of Joubran could be rolled out a a stark contrast to that narrative.Joubran wa involved in a myriad of historic decisions.He wa on the panel of three justice who rejected the appeal of former president Moshe Katsav , sending him to prison for seven year for rape and sexual abuse.Likewise , he wa on the bench of five justice who rejected part of the appeal of former prime minister Ehud Olmert , sending him to jail for two plus year on various charge of public corruption.Ever the independent thinker , Joubran wa the one dissenting vote on the Olmert panel when four justice tossed out the largest conviction for Olmert having allegedly requested that a middle man give NIS 500,000 to the former prime minister & rsquo ; s brother , Yossi Olmert . Had they listened to Joubran , Olmert would have spent many more year in prison.Regarding equality issue , he wa a consistent and unabashedly liberal voice whether for Jews or for Arabs . He wrote soaring opinion about justice and fairness that even his conservative critic sometimes respected more than they respected quieter closet activist , who often ruled liberally but tried to frame themselves in technical non-activist terms.In his final case & ndash ; a 2017 ruling on same-sex couple & rsquo ; surrogacy right & ndash ; Joubran said that he found it difficult to come to term with a situation in which single people and same-sex couple were blocked from fulfilling their dream to become parent through surrogacy agreements.He said he could not see the justice of giving preference to heterosexual parent over same-sex parent , though the court a a whole deferred the issue for six month to give the Knesset time to resolve legislation on the issue which it wa already considering.In addition , Joubran advocated religious freedom and pluralism for Jews , often banging head with the haredi rabbinic establishment.Regarding Israeli-Arab equality , he dissented in a major 2014 razor-thin 5-4 Supreme Court decision which kept a law in place that allowed & ldquo ; acceptance committee & rdquo ; to vet and reject candidate using vague criterion for around 434 yishuvim ( village ) in the Negev and the Galilee.That law replaced an earlier law previously struck down by the Supreme Court which explicitly permitted discrimination against Israeli-Arabs in those villages.However , Joubran and three other dissenting justice said that the new law would be used to achieve the same outcome and impact a the old law of discriminating against Israeli-Arabs , and possibly sometimes against haredi or other minority group . This wa even if , at face value , the new law did not explicitly discriminate.The new brand of moderate-formalist activist allied with a growing group of conservative to keep the law , but unapologetic liberal like Joubran could not stand a law which would likely cause inequality , even if there were technical reason to avoid or delay striking the law until it played out more in the real world.In 2016 , in the High Court & rsquo ; s 4-1 decision , Joubran got to vote in the majority against justice Noam Sohlberg , invalidating a 10-year price freeze and cap on legal liability rule that wa part of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu & rsquo ; s natural gas policy.Joubran also voted 3-2 in the majority against Sohlberg and then-justice Esther Hayut to suspend the policy for a year while the government would adjust the price and liability issues.But in that same series of ruling , the Supreme Court affirmed virtually all of the many other aspect of the policy by a 4-1 majority , with only Joubran dissenting.This included empowering Netanyahu to override and circumvent objection of the antitrust authority on the ground of national security.This wa huge.The prime minister , acting a his own economy minister , could override the antitrust authority on a question of economics using national security a a reason.Joubran had no problem switching back to being in the minority on that issue to check what he regarded a executive power overreach.Critics would say that Joubran harmed the country & rsquo ; s economic development and imposed his own world view in place of the representative of the voter , Netanyahu.But Joubran viewed the court a the last line of defense of those in society who were weaker ; and if that meant protecting the antitrust authority in a way that slowed down economic development , he wa at peace with that . Unlike other liberal justice , he wa willing to say it out loud.I met Joubran a number of time at conference and Supreme Court ceremony , and I saw him in action countless time on the bench.There were some on the bench who struck me a having been promoted up through the rank but basically remaining the same a they had always been , simply at a higher rung within the judiciary.Joubran seemed to hold himself differently and think in term of his place and the court & rsquo ; s place in history , and trying to find the right side of history to be on without getting dragged down into the technicality of the moment.Once again , conservative would not like many of his ruling but would honor his honesty and the sense that he wa a true believer and not just playing the politics of his sector of society.I also found him to be kind and a gentleman , with a lightness in an old-fashioned way that is hard to capture in the social medium punchy age of 2024.A graduate of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem , Joubran practiced private law from 1970 until 1982 before leaving to accept an appointment to the Haifa Magistrate & rsquo ; s Court . In 1993 , he wa appointed to the Haifa District Court , and wa then promoted to the Supreme Court in 2003.At his retirement , he preached stronger commitment to coexistence and to integration of Israel & rsquo ; s Arab minority.In an age of unbridled partisanship and personal ambition , Joubran & rsquo ; s voice of being respectful , honest , and genuinely committed to the State of Israel , though his background could have given him every excuse to take an opposite path , will be missed .
title: meet former deputy chief justice salim joubran : the embodiment of coexistence

Body Text: Minister-without-Portfolio Benny Gantz resigned on Sunday from the emergency government in a move that will not collapse the coalition but that leaf Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu more dependent on his far Right partner . & ldquo ; Netanyahu is preventing u from moving forward to a real victory , & rdquo ; said Gantz in a press conference designed for the prime-time news hour . & ldquo ; And so today , we are leaving the emergency government with a heavy heart & ndash ; but with our whole heart . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; Fateful , strategic decision are met with hesitance and procrastination due to political consideration , & rdquo ; Gantz added in criticism of the current government & rsquo ; s recent behavior . He called for election to be held in the fall , urging Netanyahu to set an agreed-upon date for them to occur.The departure of his National Unity Party , which had entered the government at the start of the war purely due to the emergency nature of the government , is set to impact the small war cabinet of which he and the number two in his party , former IDF chief-of-staff Lt . - Gen . Gadi Eisenkot , were members.Gantz call for electionsThe war will continue for year , said Gantz , telling Israelis that he & ldquo ; will not promise [ them ] a quick and easy victory . You deserve more than empty promise . But Israel should and must achieve real victory . & rdquo ; Their departure come a Netanyahu ha given a nod to a three-phase hostage deal , which Gantz support but which coalition faction Otzma Yehudit and the Religious Zionist Party oppose . Both of these party , notably , make up 14 out of the 64 seat that the coalition is comprised of.Gantz expressed his support for the hostage deal presented by US President Joe Biden while urging Netanyahu to stand behind it . I & ldquo ; demand that the prime minister show the necessary courage to stand behind it and do everything to move it forward , & rdquo ; he stated.In an apology to the family of the hostage , Gantz said , & ldquo ; We did a lot & ndash ; but we failed the test . We have not managed to bring many of the hostage home . The responsibility is mine a well . & rdquo ; He also called for the formation of a national probe to & ldquo ; examine the failure from within and protect from hypocritical attack from without . & rdquo ; Gantz praised Defense Minister Yoav Gallant , calling him a brave and determined leader , and telling him that now is the time not only to say what is right , but & ldquo ; to do what is right . & rdquo ; Netanyahu responded to the announcement saying , & ldquo ; Israel is in an existential war on several front . Benny , now is not the time to abandon the fight , it is the time to combine force . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; Citizens of Israel , we will keep fighting until victory and until the achievement of all of the goal of the war , first of which is to free all of our hostage and to eliminate Hamas , & rdquo ; Netanyahu proclaimed . & ldquo ; My door will stay open to any Zionist party that is willing to share the burden and help bring victory over our enemy and ensure the safety of our citizen , & rdquo ; he stressed . Further , Eisenkot addressed Netanyahu in his resignation letter , which wa submitted on Sunday . & ldquo ; Despite my many effort , alongside my colleague & rsquo ; , the cabinet led by you ha , for a while , avoided making real decision that are needed to achieve the goal of the war and improve Israel & rsquo ; s strategic stance , & rdquo ; he said.National Security Minister and Otzma Yehudit head Itamar Ben-Gvir immediately demanded to be added to the war cabinet . & ldquo ; It is time to make brave decision , to get real deterrence , and to bring security to the South , the North , and all of Israel , & rdquo ; he said.Finance Minister and & nbsp ; Religious Zionist Party leader Bezalel Smotrich criticized the move , saying that it wa the wrong one to make in the midst of war . & ldquo ; Benny , when you began to share the burden eight month ago , you did a brave and correct thing , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; Understanding the importance [ of the need of the hour and ] despite [ our ] difference , I agreed to step aside and be left out of managing the war . Since then , I have backed up a number of decision that I really do not agree with simply because unity is vital to victory , & rdquo ; Smotrich added.He went on to call on all Zionist party head to join a unity government & ldquo ; until victory . & rdquo ; Opposition leader Yair Lapid praised the decision saying , & ldquo ; Benny Gantz and Gadi Eisenkot & rsquo ; s decision to leave the government is both justified and important . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s time to replace this extremist and failing government with a government that will restore security for the people of Israel , bring the hostage home , rebuild the economy , and restore Israel & rsquo ; s international standing , & rdquo ; he said.Gantz had announced on May 18 that his party would leave the government on June 8 if Netanyahu did not adopt six objective : Returning the hostage ; demolishing Hamas and demilitarizing the Gaza Strip ; providing a governing alternative in Gaza ; returning resident of the North to their home by September 1 and rehabilitating the western Negev ; promoting normalization with Saudi Arabia ; and adopting an outline for standardized national service , in which all Israelis will serve their country.National Unity go on the offensiveMembers of Gantz & rsquo ; s party took step last week to oppose the government . MK Orit Farkash-Hacohen put forward a bill to form a national committee of inquiry on the event leading up to and during Oct . 7 and on what ha transpired since.In addition , MK Pnina Tamano-Shata put forward a bill to disperse the Knesset , which would lead to an election.Eliav Breuer and Jerusalem Post Staff contributed to this report .
title: benny gantz resigns from wartime government

Body Text: The Palestinian Authority 's General Security Service ( GIS ) ha apparently admitted to using American money earmarked for security to pay the family of terrorist from Jenin , according to a Palestinian Media Watch report.According to the report , on April 4 , 2024 , PA news agency WAFA published that the GIS in Jenin had given a grant to `` the family of the Martyrs and the prisoner from the service & rsquo ; s rank in the district . `` The GIS gave grant to around 36 family from among the `` martyr and prisoner . `` The vast majority of those identified a `` martyr `` or `` prisoner `` were member of the GIS who had committed act of terror , according to the PMW.The grant wa given at the direction of PA General Intelligence Chief Majed Faraj , who emphasized a core principle of Mahmoud Abbas : `` If we are left with one penny , it will be paid to the family of the Martyrs and the prisoner . `` Taylor Force ActThe US had all but ceased providing fund for the PA after the implementation of the 2017 Taylor Force Act , which blocked all funding for the PA general budget.The act wa named for Taylor Force , an American citizen killed in a terror attack in 2016 , where the attacker 's family received money from the PA 's pay-for-slay program.The exception to this wa the funding of the PA 's security sector , which received around $ 45 million in 2022 , according to the State Department 's website.The PMW say that this money wa then used to not only provide fund for terrorist and their family but also to train PA security force , many of whom end up involved in terrorism , according to PA statement in 2023.The PMW charge that US fund are now being used to directly fund and train terrorist in the West Bank .
title: american money ear-marked for pa security used to pay family of terrorist from jenin - report

Body Text: Pope Francis on Sunday said it wa `` painful `` to see that the truce between Israel and Hamas had been broken , and voiced hope that all party involved can reach a new ceasefire `` a soon a possible . `` A seven-day pause in the fighting between Israeli force and Hamas terrorist , which had allowed the exchange of Israeli hostage and Palestinian prisoner , collapsed on Friday . On Sunday , Israel stepped up it bombing campaign.More than 15,400 Palestinians have been killed a of Sunday , according to Hamas official , in the conflict that broke out after a Hamas attack on southern Israel on Oct . 7 in which 1,200 Israelis were killed and more than 200 taken hostage . `` It is painful that the truce ha been broken . This mean death , destruction and misery , `` Francis said - his word read out by an aide because of the pope 's frail health - during his Sunday Angelus message and prayer . `` Many hostage have been freed but many are still in Gaza . We think of them , of their family , who had seen a light , a hope of embracing their loved one again . `` `` In Gaza there is a lot of suffering , there is a lack of basic necessity , `` Francis said . `` I hope that all those involved can reach a new agreement for a ceasefire a soon a possible , `` he added , and find `` solution other than weapon . `` Recovering from an illness & nbsp ; The pope is limiting his public speaking and his appearance because he is recovering from a lung inflammation that forced him , among other thing , to cancel a trip to Dubai this weekend for the COP28 UN climate summit . `` Dear brother and sister , good morning . Today a well I will not be able to read everything . I am getting better , but my voice is still ( not good ) , `` Francis said at the start of the Angelus.Screens were placed in St Peter 's Square so that the faithful , who normally listen to the pope speaking from a window overlooking the square , could follow his message.At the end , they greeted him with chant of `` Viva il papa ! `` ( Long live the pope ) . & nbsp ;
title: pope deplores end of israeli-hamas truce , call for new ceasefire

Body Text: Alternate Prime Minister Benny Gantz ( Blue and White ) said he hoped to speak soon with Palestinians even though he did not believe that it wa possible at this time to finalize a peace deal with the Palestinian Authority . & ldquo ; I hope I can meet with the Palestinians in the near future , & rdquo ; said Gantz who is also the defense minister . There ha not been a meeting between an Israeli defense minister and or prime minister in year . Talks between Israel and the PA broke down in 2014 and have never been revived . But Gantz hinted at the possibility of a meeting with the Palestinians when he spoke Thursday night at a special virtual Zoom gathering for Jews who live in Latin America to mark the eighth day of Hanukkah , which wa sponsored by both the Jewish Agency and the Strategic Affairs Ministry . It wa important to advance normalization with the Palestinians , Gantz said , even if , & ldquo ; it is very hard at this stage to arrive at a final status agreement . & rdquo ; Gantz clarified his position on a number of issue relating to the conflict , noting that he did & ldquo ; We will not withdraw to the pre-1967 line . & rdquo ; With respect to Jerusalem he quoted from the Psalms , stating that Israel would not give up on the idea of & ldquo ; Jerusalem , a city that is knitted together . & rdquo ; In the West Bank , he said , it is important to build only on state land and not to build settler home on private Palestinian land . In response to a question about the continued leadership of PA President Mahmoud Abbas , Gantz said that there wa not a replacement for him currently . Gantz lauded Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu & rsquo ; s leadership with respect to the ratification of two normalization deal with the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain a well a the declaration of three additional deal with Sudan , Morocco and Bhutan . It is important to continue to work with Netanyahu to continue to advance these deal and to expand this circle to include normalization deal with other country , such a Saudi Arabia . It is also important to normalize tie with the PA , he said , noting that relation between the Palestinians and Israel had improved . Security tie between Israel and the PA have resumed and the PA ha agreed to accept tax revenue Israel had collected on it behalf . He spoke warmly about both US President Donald Trump and US President-elect Joe Biden , noting that US Israel tie were strong no matter what administration wa in Washington . Among the participant were Jewish Agency chairman Issac Herzog , along with Diaspora Affairs Minister Omer Yankelevitch and Minister in the Defense Ministry Michael Biton , both from the Blue and White Party .

Body Text: The Israel-based NGO International Legal Forum ( ILF ) ha called on UNICEF to investigate allegation of Palestinian child being trained a child soldier in Gaza , following & nbsp ; a report by & nbsp ; The Jerusalem Post . & nbsp ; The NGO , which is a network of over 3,000 lawyer and activist in over 40 nation worldwide , stated that they have & quot ; grave concern & quot ; following report that the Gaza-based Palestinian terrorist group Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad ( PIJ ) were training and recruiting child . Arsen Ostrovsky , director of ILF , told The Post that UNICEF @ @ @ s ongoing failure to act on this issue is an & nbsp ; & quot ; unconscionable dereliction of duty in it central mission to protect and defend child @ @ @ s right . & quot ; & nbsp ; As reported by the & nbsp ; Post , Hamas announced in late June it annual summer camp , where it train child to take up arm . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; According to & nbsp ; Post & nbsp ; analyst Seth J . Frantzman , the terrorist group say the youth need to be ready to make & ldquo ; sacrifice , & rdquo ; which appears to be the language used to describe recruiting them to be killed . The speech by Hamas member said the camp include religious indoctrination and & ldquo ; security & rdquo ; training . & nbsp ; An English video wa released by Hamas with an explanation that it intended to & quot ; prepare the youth , & quot ; calling the summer camp & quot ; training camp & quot ; that were named after the & quot ; Sword of al-Quds ( Sword of Jerusalem ) . & quot ; This is the term they used to refer to the & nbsp ; 11-day Hamas-Israel conflict in May , dubbed by the IDF a Operation Guardian of the Walls . & nbsp ; As reported by & nbsp ; Post & nbsp ; correspondent Khaled Abu Toameh , around 50,000 child had registered . & nbsp ; The & nbsp ; Meir Amit Intelligence Terrorism Information Center & nbsp ; published a report that at least one Palestinian child killed in Gaza during the conflict wa a member of Hamas . This is especially notable , a an entire front-page story in & nbsp ; The New York Times & nbsp ; with photo of each child killed in Gaza during the conflict drew significant attention . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; UNICEF , the UN agency responsible for humanitarian and developmental aid for child , ha stated that recruiting child soldier violates international humanitarian law . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Thousands of child are recruited and used in armed conflict across the world . Often referred to a & lsquo ; child soldier , & rsquo ; these boy and girl suffer extensive form of exploitation and abuse that are not fully captured by that term , & rdquo ; UNICEF @ @ @ s website state . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Warring party use child not only a fighter but a scout , cook , porter , guard , messenger and more . Many , especially girl , are also subjected to gender-based violence , & quot ; it said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Children become part of an armed force or group for various reason , & quot ; the website explained . & quot ; Some are abducted , threatened , coerced or manipulated by armed actor . Others are driven by poverty , compelled to generate income for their family . Still others associate themselves for survival or to protect their community . No matter their involvement , the recruitment and use of child by armed force is a grave violation of child right and international humanitarian law . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The ILF released a statement including a selection of picture from the training camp showing child receiving & quot ; military terror training & quot ; by PIJ and Hamas . & nbsp ; & quot ; Hamas and PIJ are committing a war crime under customary and treaty international law a appears in the Rome Statute ( Article 2 ( b ) ( xxvi ) and Optional Protocol to the Convention on the Rights of the Child regarding the involvement of child in armed conflict , inter alia , & quot ; the statement read . & nbsp ; The citing of the Rome Statute is notable , a it is under this jurisdiction that the International Criminal Court ( ICC ) ha launched a war crime probe into both Israel and Hamas for their 2014 conflict , Operation Protective Edge . & nbsp ; According to International Legal Forum advocate Russell Shalev , & quot ; As an organization committed to protecting and defending child right , it is incumbent upon UNICEF to act immediately and without reservation to prevent the continuation of such unconscionable atrocity and abuse of child in Gaza , a well a to hold Palestinian terror group Hamas and PIJ , accountable for these heinous crime . & quot ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Seth J . Frantzman contributed to this report .

Body Text: Not many Israeli performer can understand the pressure and glare being hoisted upon them at the Eurovision Song Contest . This year , Israel & rsquo ; s representative , Eden Golan , ha the additional burden of being the focus of protest and boycott call over the Gaza war.One performer who ha been there had some prescient advice for the 20-year-old Golan , who performed in the semi-finals of the competition late Thursday night . & ldquo ; Embrace and cherish the moment , & rdquo ; said iconic singer Gali Atari , who represented Israel at Eurovision in 1979 a part of Milk and Honey and won with the legendary & ldquo ; Hallelujah . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; She should try and savor this pivotal moment in her life . She stand at the outset of her professional journey , poised to grace this immensely significant international stage a the representative of the State of Israel . I have unwavering confidence in her , and I trust her to represent Israel with utmost dignity , & rdquo ; Atari said.Wednesday night , a Golan belted out her entry & ldquo ; Hurricane , & rdquo ; during the dress rehearsal , the tension that pervaded the street of Malm & ouml ; , Sweden , seeped into the concert hall , casting a shadow over the atmosphere a disgruntled spectator booed and , in some case , stormed out in protest.Tension in Malm & ouml ; & ldquo ; In any other year , Eden Golan and & lsquo ; Hurricane & rsquo ; would stand a good chance of reaching the top , & rdquo ; Atari told The Jerusalem Post from Mount Herzl , where the recording of her part in the upcoming torch-lighting ceremony for Independence Day wa just taped . & ldquo ; Nevertheless , let & rsquo ; s remain optimistic . Let & rsquo ; s hope and trust that the judge across different nation will prioritize genuine musical evaluation over political distraction , & rdquo ; she said.Under ordinary circumstance , going onstage at Eurovision can be a daunting experience , the 1979 winner recalled . & ldquo ; Yes , there is tension , there & rsquo ; s some anxiety before going on stage . And this year , with the boo , the violent protest & ndash ; it & rsquo ; s all very frightening , but Eden handle it very well . & rdquo ; Atari wa very impressed by Golan & rsquo ; s poise . & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s hard to believe she & rsquo ; s only 20 . . . and already she is such a diva , such a fantastic performer , & rdquo ; say Atari . & ldquo ; She know how to command the stage , she know how to stand & ndash ; so regal on stage . Body Text: Colombian President Gustavo Petro ha ordered the opening of an embassy in the Palestinian city of Ramallah , Foreign Minister Luis Gilberto Murillo told journalist on Wednesday . `` President Petro ha given the order that we open the Colombian embassy in Ramallah , the representation of Colombia in Ramallah , that is the next step we are going to take , `` Murillo said.Murillo added he belief more country will soon begin backing the recognition of a Palestinian state before the United Nations , effort Colombia ha already supported.At the beginning of this month , Petro , who had already recalled the Colombian ambassador from Tel Aviv , said he would break diplomatic relation with Israel over it action in Gaza . The embassy wa closed on May 3.Petro ha heavily criticized Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and ha requested to join South Africa 's case accusing Israel of genocide at the International Court of Justice.Israeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz accused Petro of being `` antisemitic and full of hate `` following Colombia 's decision to cut tie with the Middle Eastern country , saying the move wa a reward for Hamas.Ramallah , in the West Bank , serf a the administrative capital of the Palestinian Authority.On May 10 , the United Nations General Assembly overwhelmingly backed a Palestinian bid to become a full UN member by recognizing it a qualified to join and recommended the UN Security Council `` reconsider the matter favorably . `` Israel-Hamas warIsrael ha been rooting out Hamas in Gaza over a brutal rampage by Hamas militant in Israel on Oct . 7 in which 1,200 people were killed and more than 250 taken hostage . Nearly 36,000 Palestinians have been killed in the war , according to the Gaza health ministry.Israel 's response ha drawn heavy international criticism , with aid access into southern Gaza disrupted since it stepped up military operation in Rafah , a move that the UN say ha forced 900,000 people to flee and ha raised tension with neighboring Egypt.Colombia wa not the first Latin American country to cut tie with Israel.Bolivia broke with relation with Israel at the end of October last year while several other country in Latin America , including Chile and Honduras , have recalled their ambassador .

Body Text: Internationally acclaimed and Grammy Award-winning violinist Gil Shaham will join the Israeli Philharmonic Orchestra under the baton of Karen Kamensek , herself a Grammy Award-winning artist , for a performance of Anton & iacute ; n Dvor & aacute ; k & rsquo ; s Violin Concerto in a series of show from June 16-23.The 53-year-old Shaham grew up in Israel and left at a young age for an international career a one of the world & rsquo ; s leading soloist . On stage , with his gaunt almost haggard feature and eye fixed on the violin , he seems like a Mephistophelean figure , conjoined with the violin a it abides and subjugates itself to his technique . & nbsp ; Just before arriving in Israel for the first time since the Gaza war began , the New York-based Shaham told The Jerusalem Post that he wa eager to visit the country . & ldquo ; Look , these are tragic time . It & rsquo ; s just an ocean of suffering and tragedy , an ocean of pain . And I do feel that music ha a way to bring solace to people . I think music is very life-affirming and brings people together , & rdquo ; he said , appearing uneasy discussing the political situation . & ldquo ; You know , there wa one time when we performed with Zubin Mehta and the Israeli Philharmonic at the BBC Proms , and a we were playing , there were loud protest coming from outside , and even louder counter-protests . I looked at Zubin , and he sort of looked at me and said , & lsquo ; Just keep playing , just keep making music . & rsquo ; I thought that wa a good statement on many level . & rdquo ; According to Shaham , Dvor & aacute ; k & rsquo ; s Violin Concerto is one of his masterpiece . & ldquo ; I wa thinking a little bit about Beethoven and the great work of the past . Many of them were written during brutal , terrible time . The Dvor & aacute ; k Violin Concerto ha a very Beethovenian narrative . When you take a piece that start in the minor mode but at the end arrives in the major , it really offer hope , you know . And it & rsquo ; s so uplifting in that way . And I think that & rsquo ; s also true for the piece we will be playing , & rdquo ; he said.A perfect fitHaving performed with the IPO since the 1980s under Mehta , Shaham ha had a perfect seat to see it development over the year . & ldquo ; I think they are playing better than ever before . There are so many star musician there , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s interesting for me because nowadays , I feel I & rsquo ; m probably one of the older people on stage . There are some brilliant young musician , and I feel lucky that they still include me and still want to play with me . & rdquo ; He added that he had performed with the IPO & rsquo ; s Lahav Shani several time . & ldquo ; We & rsquo ; ve had several opportunity to play a handful of different concerto . I also got to play with him in his pianist role . I & rsquo ; m a big fan of his and the orchestra , & rdquo ; said Shaham.Shaham and the IPO will also be performing Bedrich Smetana Vlatava ( Moldau ) , Dvor & aacute ; k & rsquo ; s Slavonic dance , and Richard Strauss & rsquo ; s Four Symphonic Interludes from his 1924 comic Opera Intermezzo .
title: gil shaham to perform dvorák with israeli philharmonic orchestra

Body Text: National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir 's announcement on Monday regarding his choice of Israel & rsquo ; s next police chief , Avshalom Peled , served not just a a general announcement , but also a a warning to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that he could act to topple the government if Israel agrees to concession in a hostage deal that Ben-Gvir opposes.Ben-Gvir 's announcement wa not brought for approval to minister Benny Gantz 's National Unity party , which responded on Monday evening that it expected Netanyahu to respect a coalition agreement giving it veto power over major appointments.The fact that Ben-Gvir made the announcement without taking Gantz into account plant the excuse to leave the government if Gantz applies his veto . This connects directly to a threat from Ben-Gvir earlier on Monday , in a post on X , that if Netanyahu end Israel 's war against Hamas without an extensive attack on Hamas in Rafah , he will & ldquo ; cease to have a mandate to serve a prime minister . & rdquo ; In other word , the timing of the police chief appointment wasn & rsquo ; t a coincidence , but a reminder of Ben-Gvir & rsquo ; s leverage over Netanyahu . In order to dissolve the 120-member Knesset and force an election , 61 MKs must support it dissolution . The departure of Ben-Gvir & rsquo ; s six seat in itself is not enough to bring down the 72 seat governing coalition , but it will give Gantz the power to bring down the government in the near future by leaving with his eight seats.Ben-Gvir is hovering around the 10-seat mark in most poll , and he thus stand to gain from an election . But in order not to receive blame for the rise of a possible centrist government , he need to be able to explain to his voter why he decided to leave . Inaction on Rafah coupled with an inability to move forward with his choice of commissioner would serve a an adequate reason.Unilaterally announcing Peled a his choice for police chief may be a relatively empty threat , a it first must receive the approval of Israel & rsquo ; s Advisory Committee on Senior Civil Service Appointments . This committee usually approves the candidate brought before it , but in Peled & rsquo ; s case , it may not.Peled engaged in illegal quid-pro-quoThe Police Investigations Department recommended in 2015 that he not be promoted after a recording revealed that he engaged in a seemingly illegal quid-pro-quo with a local authority leader . Peled wasn & rsquo ; t indicted after the recording wa disqualified a evidence due to privacy-related infraction . Then-police chief Roni Alsheich ignored the recommendation and promoted Peled , but the advisory committee may not.Still , Ben-Gvir & rsquo ; s announcement and National Unity & rsquo ; s subsequent response that it expected Netanyahu to respect it veto power , if it chooses to use it , upped the pressure on the prime minister to appease Ben-Gvir by other mean to keep the national security minister on board.The move wa typical of Ben-Gvir , who , on a number of occasion , ha threatened to leave the government unless he receives certain concession . For example , Ben-Gvir threatened to jump ship when Netanyahu wa about to announce a freeze on the judicial reform just over a year ago , following mass protest and strike . Netanyahu convinced him to stay despite the freeze by agreeing to a government decision to begin the process of forming a National Guard , which wa a major policy goal for Ben-Gvir.This time around , Ben-Gvir may condition remaining in the government after a hostage deal on a commitment from Netanyahu to push through Peled & rsquo ; s appointment regardless of the National Unity veto . If Peled & rsquo ; s candidacy is struck down , Ben-Gvir will likely demand something else.For most of 2023 , Ben-Gvir wa considered a loose cannon and the largest potential threat to Netanyahu & rsquo ; s government . But with haredi party taking over in recent month a the major political threat due to the issue of haredi national service , Ben-Gvir made his presence felt and reminded the prime minister that he must be taken into account a well . & nbsp ;
title: ben-gvir 's police chief announcement is a veiled political threat - analysis

Body Text: Simcha Rothman , the chair of the Knesset 's Constitution , Law and Justice Committee , and member of Knesset from the Religious Zionist Party , spoke in a Holocaust ceremony at Columbia University in New York . `` We are standing on Holocaust Memorial Day at Columbia University , and the antisemitism is on the rise here and in many place around the world , `` said Rothman.He spoke to listener about the ongoing demonstration at American college , stressing the importance of separating protest from hate speech.Jews are facing severe threat in the diaspora '' In a demonstration where people simply want to convey a message , this this is freedom of speech , this is legitimately possible . What we see here on campus is not a demonstration ; what we see here is support for terrorism and antisemitism , `` he added.In recent week , dozen of campus across the US have faced occupation and aggressive protest by activist in a bid to force the adoption of anti-Israel policy since the original April 17 Columbia University tent settlement . Many graduation ceremony and exam season have been disrupted , and there have been incident of violence and antisemitism towards Jewish and Israeli student and staff.Rothman addressed this by questioning why protest , under the guise of being critical of Israel , choose to discriminate against or harass Jewish student . Why would you block a lecturer from entering the university if he look Jewish ? & rdquo ; He spoke to the existential threat facing the State of Israel , which he say is fighting & ldquo ; not only to protect the safety of our citizen , but also to preserve the life of Jews around the world & rdquo ; . Body Text: The IDF Widows and Orphans ( IDFWO ) organization announced on International Widows Day , Sunday , that 260 Gaza war widow have joined the organization since October 7.More than 520 orphaned child are being supported by IDFWO and 31 of the widow are pregnant.IDFWO is an Israeli non-profit which offer support to the spouse and child of fallen soldier . Body Text: Israel raised eight billion dollar in bond sale , setting a record with the highest-ever demand for an Israeli international bond offering , the Finance Ministry & rsquo ; s Accountant General & rsquo ; s office announced on Wednesday . Demand for the offering , launched on Tuesday , reached $ 38 billion , and some 400 investor from 36 country participated , the ministry added.The bond were sold a part of the Finance Ministry & rsquo ; s strategy to fund the government & rsquo ; s activity a the Israel-Hamas war continues to impact Israel & rsquo ; s economy.Selling bond allows Israel to raise money to cover current budgetary need by essentially borrowing money from those who buy the bond . A government bond represents a debt owed by the government to the person who buy the bond . The government must repay that debt in the specified time frame and interest to the buyer . Thirty-year , ten-year , and five-year bond were sold in the issuing.The bond offering result showed that Israel would pay 135 basis point over comparable 5-year US Treasuries , 145 basis point over 10-year Treasuries , and 175 basis point over US 30-year bond . This mean that Israel will pay higher interest rate than comparable US bond issued over a similar time frame.Smotrich and Rothenberg celebrate change in bond salesRothenberg and Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich celebrated the record-breaking debt issuance , pointing to the high demand a an important expression of foreign investor & rsquo ; faith in Israeli market . This expression follows a tumultuous time for Israel & rsquo ; s economy , a government bond have underperformed the most widely-followed global emerging market bond index by just over ten percentage point over the last six month , along with Moody & rsquo ; s cut Israel & rsquo ; s credit rating last month.Moody & rsquo ; s downgraded Israel & rsquo ; s credit rating to & ldquo ; A2 & rdquo ; from & ldquo ; A1 & rdquo ; in early February , citing material political and fiscal risk for the country due to it war with Hamas . & ldquo ; While fighting in Gaza may diminish in intensity or pause , there is currently no agreement to end the hostility durably and no agreement on a longer-term plan that would fully restore and eventually strengthen security for Israel , & rdquo ; Moody & rsquo ; s said at the time.This lower credit rating is an indication of a higher risk of investing in Israeli security . This risk impact the interest paid for Israeli bond . A higher-risk investment pay a higher interest to compensate investor for this risk.According to Accountant General Yali Rothenberg , the majority of similar bond offering will be on local market , such a in shekel bond sale . These offering may also impact inflation in Israel . When Israelis buy bond , it reduces the amount of money in circulation in the Israeli economy and so may slow inflation.Israel & rsquo ; s inflation wa above the target rate when the war began , but currently , Inflation is moderated and stand at 2.6 % , & rdquo ; said Bank of Israel Governor Amir Yaron on Tuesday . & ldquo ; Expectations for inflation for the coming year have risen slightly . Uncertainty still prevails regarding the effect of the war on inflation process , & rdquo ; he added .
title: how record-breaking bond offering is part of israel ’ s strategy to fund gov ’ t

Body Text: Police on Sunday arrested Muna al-Kurd , 23 , a prominent activist from the east Jerusalem neighborhood of Sheikh Jarrah , on suspicion of & ldquo ; participating in disturbing the peace and in riot . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Her twin brother , Mohammad , wa also arrested on the same charge . They didn & rsquo ; t even allow her to brush her teeth . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The police officer searched the home of his son , Mohammad , who wa not present at the time his sister wa taken into custody . The brother later handed himself over to the police . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The police think that the arrest will silence our people and stop the campaign [ against the Sheikh Jarrah eviction ] , & rdquo ; Nabil al-Kurd said . & ldquo ; But the people and the shabab [ youth ] of Jerusalem will not be silenced . They will continue to talk about the Palestinian cause and how Israel stole our land . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Muna al-Kurd wa arrested one day after she wa seen filming the detention of Al-Jazeera Arabic reporter Givara Budeiri by the police at Sheikh Jarrah . Budeiri wa released a few hour later . & nbsp ; It wa not clear whether Muna al-Kurd & rsquo ; s arrest wa connected to the incident involving Budeiri . & nbsp ; Several Palestinian activist gathered outside the Shalem police station in east Jerusalem to protest against the arrest of the Kurd sibling . They also chanted slogan in support of al-Aqsa Mosque . & nbsp ; The arrest of Muna and Mohammad al-Kurd would not deter the Palestinians from continuing the campaign to resist the planned eviction , said Ahmed Mansour , a friend of the Kurd family . & nbsp ; The eviction order were issued earlier this year by the Jerusalem District Court . At the request of the attorney-general , the Supreme Court last month delayed until further notice a session to look into the case . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Muna and Mohammad are the symbol of the Palestinian struggle in Jerusalem , & rdquo ; Mansour said , adding that he and his friend would continue to hold daily protest at Sheikh Jarrah & ldquo ; to prevent Jewish settler from taking our home . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The Palestinian Authority & rsquo ; s ruling Fatah faction and Hamas condemned the arrest of the Kurd sibling and called for their immediate release . & nbsp ; The arrest are a & ldquo ; crime that reflects the mentality of ethnic cleansing and apartheid , & rdquo ; Fatah spokesman Osama Qawassmeh said . & nbsp ; The arrest of Muna and her brother & ldquo ; reflect the ugly face of the state of occupation and it breach of international law , & rdquo ; said Abdel Latif al-Qanou , a spokesman for Hamas in the Gaza Strip .

Two YAMAM officer were lightly injured by Palestinian fire during the raid in Jenin.The Hamas terrorist movement warned that the response to the death `` will not be long in coming . `` Islamic Jihad spokesman Tariq Selmi stated that `` the bill of reckoning with the occupation will not be closed , and it continuous aggression and violation place before the resistance it duty and responsibility in defending the Palestinian people . `` Fatah spokesman Munther al-Hayek responded to the death a well , stating `` the new assassination crime in Jenin and all terrorist practice to resolve the conflict will not succeed . Blood follows blood , and history is a witness to the people 's victory . `` Nabil Abu Rudeineh , a spokesman for Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas , called the clash and recent violence `` an all-out Israeli war against the Palestinian people . `` Operation Break the Wave15 Palestinians were arrested by Israeli force overnight throughout the West Bank a part of Operation Break the Wave , including in Silat ad-Dhahr , al-Yamun and Sebastia , among other locations.National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir congratulated Israeli force on the operation in Jaba , stating `` I congratulate the YAMAS ( Border Police undercover unit ) officer and all the security force , for the exact operation and the elimination of the abominable terrorist who opened fire at our soldier , in an attempt to hurt them and murder our heroic soldier . `` `` Every terrorist who would try to hurt u must know that his blood is on his head and we will bring him to account . I urge the public to continue to show high vigilance , especially during this period , `` added Ben-Gvir.Later on Thursday , four Palestinian fisherman were injured by rubber bullet fired by the Israeli Navy towards them off the coast of the northern Gaza Strip.On Wednesday , IDF Chief of Staff Herzi Halevi met with the head of settlement and regional council in the West Bank to conduct a situation assessment and update them on the IDF 's operation in the area.The settlement leader expressed appreciation for the IDF 's effort to thwart terrorism and raised a number of issue that need handling in the West Bank , including the distribution of firearm among Palestinians , the need for accelerated work on road and infrastructure and stone and Molotov cocktail throwing.The head of the Gush Etzion Regional Council Shlomo Neeman stated after the meeting `` Regular discourse and full cooperation between IDF officer and authority are part of our routine . `` Ne'eman thanked Halevi for the conversation and wished him success in his new role a chief of staff . `` The citizen of the State of Israel are entitled to travel safely on every road in Judea and Samaria , `` added Ne'eman . `` There is no difference between a stone-thrower or a terrorist who carry out a shooting , both have one goal - to hurt the people and the state and kick u out of here . Only the heavy hand of the security force against each danger will return deterrence and quiet to the area . `` IDF Chief of Staff Herzi Halevi held a review of the recent violence in the West Bank with the commander of the IDF 's Central Command on Wednesday.Halevi praised the soldier under Central Command for the complex operation they carried out in recent week . `` These complex operation send a clear message to terrorist , that we will get to every terrorist and capture or hit every terrorist , wherever they are , `` said Halevi.The chief of staff additionally reviewed the riot that took place last week in Huwara , in which hundred of Israeli settler torched dozen of home and vehicle and shot and killed a Palestinian citizen after two Israelis were murdered in a terrorist attack in the town.The commander at the meeting noted that the pogrom in Huwara wa `` a very serious incident that should have been prevented , `` noting that the violence wa unusual in it scope and intensity . The commander noted that lesson were learned concerning improvement needed for cooperation between the IDF , Border Police , Israel Police and Shin Bet and that improvement are needed in the security force ' ability to rapidly redeploy in developing situation . `` This is a serious incident that occurred on our watch - and should not have happened , `` said the chief of staff . `` The chain of command correctly decided the order of priority between the various task , but erred in the allocation of force and control of the event . The expectation from every regular and reservist soldier is to act in a professional and ethical manner and to prevent act like these , a we trained him and in accordance with the value ​ ​ of the IDF . `` `` We will draw the necessary lesson and learn them to prevent similar incident in the future , `` added Halevi .

Body Text: Richard Gere is starring in an English-language remake of Longing by Israeli director Savi Gabizon , set to hit US theater on June 7.Gere ha visited Israel several time and starred in the 2016 movie Norman , by Israeli director Joseph Cedar , in which he played a conman who befriended an Israeli prime minister . The movie wa filmed in filmed in the US and Israel . The Longing remake is set in the US , however , and is being remade by Gabizon himself – an unusual move , because generally , when Israeli director sell a film for a remake , a different director is brought in . Longing , which won the BNL Audience Award at the Venice Film Festival , tell the story of a man whose old girlfriend look him up and is shocked to learn that he fathered a child with her , and that child grew up and then died tragically . Diane Kruger star opposite Gere a the mother of his child . Gabizon , one of Israel ’ s most popular movie director , made his first film , Shuroo , in 1991 , which he followed up with the hit Lovesick on Nana Street in 1995 . His next film , Nina ’ s Tragedies , wa the first Israeli film to compete in the Best Narrative Feature section at the Sundance Film Festival .
title: richard gere star in ' longing , ' a remake of an israeli film

Body Text: Outside the window of the rectangular corrugated tin shig ( traditionally a tent used for hospitality , which in many place ha been replaced by a structure ) , a wind heavy with desert heat blow slightly and in the not-too-far distance , a young camel of the same color stand motionless and almost imperceptible in the tiny unrecognized Bedouin village of al-Bat.Here the al-Qaran family & ndash ; now totaling some 20 family & ndash ; ha lived their traditional life since 1952.Sofas and armchair line one side of the shig & ndash ; used to receive guest & ndash ; and on the other side red , orange , black , and blue striped rug and pillow bring color to the space.Saed , one of the al-Qaran brother , offer coffee from a long-handled copper finjan , his movement slow and measured , his dark eye unable to disguise the pain he feel . Even in his state of mourning , the Bedouin ritual of hospitality is paramount . & nbsp ; Just two week ago , on the first day of the war , he and his brother were sitting in a similar shig with their child , on this little hilltop 4.5 km . north of the Bedouin town of Kuseife , some 65 km . from Gaza , when suddenly they heard a missile fly overhead and land in their animal pen . One of the brother went out to check on the penned animal , while another went to check on the camel . Saed wa just coming into the shig with the coffee finjan in his hand when a second missile landed in front of him , on the tin shig where the child were sitting . The flimsy shig wa flattened a if it were literally a tin-can , burying the five boy underneath the rubble . & nbsp ; It took the brother 15 minute to dig them out with their bare hand & ndash ; they didn & rsquo ; t have any tool to use & ndash ; and another 20 minute to get them to Soroka Medical Center in Beersheba . Four of the boy & ndash ; brother Malek al-Qaran , 14 , and Jawad al-Qaran , 15 , and cousin Amin Akal al-Qaran , 16 , and Mohammad D & rsquo ; ib al-Qaran , 12 & ndash ; were already dead by the time they got there . Another cousin , Taleb Mahmoud al-Qaran , 35 , wa seriously wounded but survived and is being treated in a hospital in the center of the country.Ibrahim , the father of two of the boy killed in the missile attack , walk in silently , his head wrapped loosely with a scarf . There is nothing to say , and the two men sit silently a one , and then another cousin come to sit on the rug , and Saed serf them coffee.The corrugated tin panel that used to make up the shig where the boy died lie flat in a pile next to a new shig which ha been quickly built to replace it . & nbsp ; Here , in this isolated place in the desert , their little village is one of some 35 unrecognized Bedouin village dotting the Negev desert . Despite numerous request to the government from the resident , they have no air raid siren , nor are they allowed to build a safe room or communal bomb shelter , so the boy had no chance . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We have everything we need here , & rdquo ; Saed , who served in the IDF , said . & ldquo ; We just need bomb shelter . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; So far , no temporary bomb shelter have been set up for the unrecognized village , although at the entrance of the village the Islamic Movement brought two large cement pipe and placed cement slab on either side & ndash ; a if that would protect anyone . According to Saed , the Dead Sea Works potash plant put together a & ldquo ; shelter & rdquo ; with huge industrialized-size bag of dirt but no roof covering . Neither shelter affords protection worth the effort of trying to reach it during a rocket attack.Some 400,000 Bedouin live in Israel in an area ranging from Beersheba to Arad . This includes 100,000 in the 35 unrecognized village , such a al-Bat , which have no electricity , running water , paved road , or school infrastructure ; and 300,000 in seven established town . Thus the Negev Bedouin represent the most vulnerable socioeconomic group in Israel . & nbsp ; According to the Association for Civil Rights in Israel , at one point there were 46 unrecognized Bedouin village . Following the state & rsquo ; s recognition of 11 of them , 35 village in the Negev still remain unrecognized , with some still in the same location since before the creation of the State of Israel , and others in their current location following Israel & rsquo ; s transfer of the resident there during the period of military rule . & nbsp ; Since the Hamas terrorist attack on October 7 , at least 26 Bedouin citizen of Israel have been killed & ndash ; 19 by Hamas terrorist in the kibbutz where they were working early on that Saturday morning , and seven by Hamas missile . Osama Abu Asa , a Bedouin guard at the Supernova concert , wa killed a he attempted to protect some of the young people hiding in a bomb shelter , believing that Hamas would not kill him because he wa a Muslim . Abed Alrahman Ataf Alzeadna , 26 , from Rahat , wa among those killed by Hamas terrorist on Zikim Beach ; and four of his relative , who were with him , are still missingTaken hostageSix Bedouin who were working in the Holit dairy were kidnapped , including four member of the Ziadna family : father Yosef , 53 ; son Hamza , 22 , and Belal , 19 ; and daughter Aisha , 17 . & nbsp ; In addition , said Jamal Al-Kirnawi , a Bedouin social worker and director of New Dawn & ndash ; a Rahat-based Bedouin-Jewish coexistence NGO that provides programming for at-risk Bedouin youth & ndash ; several Bedouin soldier have been taken hostage , although how many ha not been made official . & nbsp ; If the attack had taken place on Sunday , there would have been many more Bedouin victim , a many are agriculture worker at the kibbutz , he added . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Bedouins are really suffering , & rdquo ; Al-Kirnawi , 44 , said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We were all shocked by what happened on October 7 . No one knew what wa going on . We thought it wa rocket attack like we are used to , and that soon there would be an army response . We were not expecting anything like this . The society ha been in shock & ndash ; especially the Bedouin who worked in the kibbutz . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We feel very sorry for this loss and pain . The rocket and Hamas did not differentiate between Jews and Bedouin . & rdquo ; He lost 20 close Jewish friend from the kibbutz in the terrorist attack and said he is still living in mourning , a he ha spent the week since the attack going from funeral to funeral and shiva to shiva . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; If on a daily basis we a Bedouins live in a complex reality , imagine the reality of uncertain chaos that we are living in now , & rdquo ; he said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The war make it much worse in the complexity of the society & ndash ; how to handle this tragic crisis . No one is able to understand this biggest tragedy that ha happened . We feel the suffering of the family , and we can & rsquo ; t contain all the story of loss . We are not in a normal situation and are processing this loss . & rdquo ; The economy of Bedouin town ha shut down since October 7 , and the many Bedouins who worked in the kibbutz have lost their employment . But for Al-Kirnawi , the most difficult thing is that a a traditional society , many people in his community are suffering from anxiety and trauma ; but , in addition to municipal social welfare service being shut down and the government in general not functioning , the whole concept of counseling is still not widely accepted in Bedouin society , especially in the more traditional sector . & ldquo ; People are suffering , whether they speak about it or not , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; But in general , Bedouin society take what is happening on the outside and keep it inside , without interpreting how that affect them [ on the inside ] . & rdquo ; He added : & ldquo ; The concept of therapy is very hard , and usually people come to therapy when they are overwhelmed . So we need to be proactive before people get so overwhelmed that they need major intervention . & rdquo ; Trauma training for Bedouin mental health workersNew Dawn ha begun special trauma training for educator and mental health worker within the Bedouin community , who pay several visit to the family directly affected by the war reaching out with mental health tool to help them cope with the loss , trauma , and anxiety they are feeling , he said . & nbsp ; Initially , they have trained seven men and woman who have gone to attend to the most vulnerable in five village , and there are plan for further training session . & ldquo ; We can & rsquo ; t wait for [ government office ] . We , a a civil society , are much more powerful [ than the government ] , & rdquo ; he said.Manar Abu Gosh , 25 , a resident of Rahat and social worker and volunteer at New Dawn who ha gone through the training , ha begun visiting resident of the unrecognized village . The child are scared , and many of the parent are in shock and not able to function normally , she said . A missile fell near one of the village while she wa there , she noted . & ldquo ; We heard the sound of the missile , but we didn & rsquo ; t know where to run . The child were terrified , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; They are in a panic . & rdquo ; The men , who worked largely in agriculture , are now unemployed , and the child can & rsquo ; t participate in the remote video class because they have no Internet service nor tablet , Abu Gosh said . & ldquo ; They are , after all , citizen who want to live in peace and quiet , & rdquo ; she said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The men do not want to talk about how they are feeling , but the woman and child come and speak about their worry and fear . Honestly , I came home and cried . It wa the first time I wa ever in an unrecognized village . I wa shocked by what is happening to them . They are in a terrible situation . But I will continue to go to speak with them . It is not easy for any of u . & rdquo ; President Isaac Herzog visited the Bedouin Situation Room in Rahat on October 26 , where Jewish and Arab Israelis are working together to provide care package for the most needy of the area & rsquo ; s resident , and met with community leader and family of the missing and murdered of the community , including representative of the Ziadna family . & ldquo ; We will continue to live together , and it is important for me to tell the entire Arab society in Israel how much I appreciate the responsibility shown across the community in these difficult day , & rdquo ; he told them on October 26 . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We deeply share in their grief . I came to offer my sympathy to the family , and we will meet with them again . We came to offer strength to the local authority and to hear what is important to them . We came to tell everyone : We will continue to live together and continue to live in peace . & ldquo ; What we saw on October 7 doe not represent Islam . Islam is a religion of respect , sensitivity , brotherhood , and love . & rdquo ; Quiet vigil for four family membersA few day before the president & rsquo ; s visit , in the Ziadna neighborhood of Rahat & ndash ; a conglomeration of tin hut and small garden outside of Rahat & ndash ; the uncle , brother , and nephew of Yosef Ziadna , kidnapped along with his three child , sit on white plastic chair in a large circle in a vigil outside a home . The young men all sport beard and are powerfully built , but in their eye are broken spirit , waiting to hear about their loved one . At the time of the visit , all four & ndash ; including daughter Aisha , who wear the traditional Muslim hijab & ndash ; were presumed to be held hostage in Gaza.Yosef & rsquo ; s brother Salem had also been at the Holit dairy on October 7 with his four young child a every Saturday , taking the youngster on a & ldquo ; fun day & rdquo ; to see the cow . He describes how for 12 harrowing hour he evaded the terrorist by hiding and darting through the dairy with his four terrified child , carrying the two the littlest one in his arm . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I heard shooting all the time . My child were so scared , they kept very quiet . Twice they captured u but I wa able to escape , but sadly Yosef and his child were captured , & rdquo ; he said . Though an uncle is hesitant about speaking to the press , Salem said he want the story of his escape to be published in a many medium outlet a possible , in the rare possibility that perhaps Yosef or his child will see it and then know that he and his child are safe . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; He is probably worried about u , too . I want to let him know that we are safe and got out . & rdquo ; Bedouin rescuer save 70 at SupernovaOn that Black Saturday morning , a reveler from the Supernova dance festival were frantically trying to escape from the onslaught of the Hamas attack , Hamed Alkarnawi and his family member Rafi , Ismail , and Dahish & ndash ; all of Rahat & ndash ; rushed to the scene with their truck when their cousin Hisham , who worked in the dining room of Kibbutz Be & rsquo ; eri , called them to tell them he and kibbutz member Aya Meidan & ndash ; who had gone out for a bike ride in the early morning & ndash ; were surrounded by Hamas terrorist . & nbsp ; The rescuer have declined medium interview , but in a powerful video produced by Have You Seen the Horizon Lately ? & ndash ; an initiative promoting Jewish-Arab partnership & ndash ; Meidan and the Alkarnawis recounted the daring rescue they undertook . Under fire , they first rescued some 40 young people from the Supernova party whom they encountered on their way to Be & rsquo ; eri hiding from the Hamas terrorist , and then made their way to rescue Hisham and Aya.Minivan driver Yosef El Zaidneh , 47 , also of the unrecognized neighborhood of Ziadna , who risked his life to save people from the party , ha become an unlikely medium hero after one of the people he rescued praised him and posted his phone number on social medium to bring him more costumer . & nbsp ; El Zaidneh described himself a a & ldquo ; regular person , & rdquo ; who never served in the army , just someone who go out every morning to work and come home in the evening to his wife and children.That Saturday at 1 a.m . , he took a regular customer and eight friend from Omer to the Supernova dance party near Kibbutz Re & rsquo ; im with instruction to return to pick them up later , at 1 p.m . But shortly after 6 a.m . , his phone began to ring incessantly and when his customer , Amit , told him there wa a red alert of missile , he told him he would be there in 20 minute . But a he approached the junction to Kibbutz Sa & rsquo ; ad , he saw car coming toward him and people motioning him to go back . & ldquo ; It is the first time in my life I have been afraid , & rdquo ; he said , but he continued through the gunfire and wa able to rescue 30 young Israelis a he packed twice the number of passenger allowed into his minivan . He knew the terrain near the kibbutz well and made his way through the field to safety , forging a way for other car to follow him . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; There wa not one soldier there ; I saw wounded police . I knew if we went on the road to Re & rsquo ; im , they would kill u . & rdquo ; When they eventually reached a roadblock manned by Israeli police , they were directed to Kibbutz Tze & rsquo ; elim . Sadly , his cousin , Abed al-Rahman Alnasarah , 50 , also a minivan driver , wa killed by the terrorist a he attempted to reach the party to rescue Israelis there.Since that morning El Zaidneh , the father of seven child , ha not been able to sleep , and the horrific scene of death and destruction keep replaying in his head . & nbsp ; He spends the night chain smoking and drinking coffee , sitting outside on the swing in his fenced-in yard in front of his corrugated tin hut , praying for the morning to come . He saw thing people should never have to see , he said . He ha received threatening phone call originating in Gaza from people claiming to be from Hamas who say they will find him because he rescued Israelis . He ha reported the call to the police , and his phone is under surveillance for any more threatening call that come in , he said . He ha been going to daily therapy session to help deal with the trauma . & nbsp ; El Zaidneh ha also received many phone call from people who want to donate money to him or give him present , he said , but he is not interested in any of that and often doe not even answer his phone anymore unless he recognizes the number . He did not do what he did for any sort of recognition , he said . & ldquo ; I had the chance to turn around . But above all , I am a human being , and I am an Israeli and I knew there were Israeli citizen [ in danger ] . If I can help , why not ? That is how our parent raised u . To do good if we can , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; I hope after this , the mayor of Omer & ndash ; who doe not like u & ndash ; and the State of Israel will appreciate the Bedouin and stop destroying our house and see that we are a part of this country . & ldquo ; We are not Hamas . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I hope that the country will now think about u ; help the Bedouin develop in education , in culture . Maybe we won & rsquo ; t be 100 % equal , but at least 70 % equal . & rdquo ;  Video of the Supernova rescue : x.com/Horizon_lately/status/1720905755371405633 ? t=KCzVUClfm7Y2_bsM2V13rA & amp ; s=08
