Body Text: Israel will forever be grateful to US President Joe Biden for the support that he showed the battered country in the day immediately following the October 7 massacre.Israel will forever be grateful for the way he stood by the country in it darkest hour , how he warned Iran and it proxy Hezbollah not to take advantage of the situation and fully open other front against Israel , and how he sent US aircraft carrier strike force to the region to back up those warning . And , indeed , Iran and Hezbollah were deterred.Israel will forever be grateful for the way Biden immediately launched an arm airlift to the country , making good on his promise to ensure that Israel ha the wherewithal to defend itself.The country will also long remember the way he came here 11 day after Hamas & rsquo ; s attack , the first US president to visit Israel in time of war , and relieved the country & rsquo ; s stunning feeling of isolation by demonstrating genuine sympathy and empathy.Many , frankly , were surprised by the Democratic president & rsquo ; s unequivocal , unstinting support . In the day and week immediately following October 7 , Biden did the right thing by Israel.Hamas welcomed the resolution that the US allowed to passOn Monday , by instructing the US not to veto Security Council Resolution 2728 calling for an immediate ceasefire for Ramadan that will lead to a & ldquo ; lasting sustainable & rdquo ; ceasefire but not making that contingent on the Security Council & rsquo ; s call in the same resolution for Hamas & ndash ; which it ha yet to condemn for October 7 & ndash ; to release all the hostage , he did the wrong thing by Israel.It did not take long for the consequence of this action to be felt.Just hour after Hamas welcomed the resolution ( imagine the UN Security Council passing a resolution that ISIS or al-Qaeda , Hamas & rsquo ; s twin , would welcome ) , the terrorist organization turned down the term painstakingly hammered out in week of negotiation for a ceasefire and hostage release deal.The refusal of the Security Council to even once & ndash ; either through a resolution or in a statement put out by it president & ndash ; condemn Hamas for it October 7 atrocity is staggering . Especially considering that the council know how to condemn terrorism when Israel is not on the receiving end.For example , on March 22 , one day after a terrorist attack in Moscow killed some 140 people , the council issued a statement condemning & ldquo ; in the strongest term the heinous and cowardly terrorist attack . & rdquo ; The council swiftly issued a similar statement on Wednesday , within 24 hour of when a suicide bomber in Pakistan killed five Chinese worker and their Pakistani driver.Yet it & rsquo ; s now 174 day since terrorist murdered 1,200 people in Israel , kidnapped more than 240 hostage , raped woman , burned baby , mutilated body , set fire to entire community , and no similar statement from the Security Council ha yet been issued.And some still wonder why Israelis are cynical of world opinion and not particularly moved by Security Council actions.It is clear why Hamas rejected the hostage dealJust a it wa clear why Hamas would welcome Monday & rsquo ; s Security Council resolution , it is also equally clear why it rejected the hostage deal on the table.Hamas welcomed the resolution despite it call for an immediate release of all the hostage , because it know that the world will focus on the first part of the first clause in the nonbinding resolution & ndash ; pressing Israel hard to stop the fighting & ndash ; and pay less attention to the second part of that same clause : a call for Hamas to release all the hostages.Why will the world not press the second part of that clause ? Because it know full well that Hamas operates way outside the bound of civil society and that the terrorist organization is not going to heed any such call.It wa also clear following the resolution that Hamas would stiffen it condition on a hostage deal , sensing that if it just hold out longer , international pressure will force Israel to stop the war , enabling the terrorist group to survive to fight & ndash ; meaning to murder , rape , and mutilate & ndash ; another day . Security Council Resolution 2728 undoubtedly strengthened Hamas & rsquo ; s feeling that the international community would & ldquo ; deliver & rdquo ; Israel.Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu & rsquo ; s office put out a statement saying a much on Tuesday . & ldquo ; Hamas & rsquo ; s stance clearly demonstrates it utter disinterest in a negotiated deal and attests to the damage done by the UN Security Council & rsquo ; s resolution . & rdquo ; While there is a tendency among many pundit and most opposition politician to reject anything Netanyahu say and to reflexively place the blame on Netanyahu rather than Biden whenever the two are at odds , in this case , that reflex is misplaced.Put aside whether , a a result of the US failure to veto the resolution , it wa wise for Netanyahu to cancel Strategic Affairs Minister Ron Dermer and National Security Council head Tzachi Hanegbi & rsquo ; s trip to Washington this week to consult on how to pursue the war in Rafah ( it wasn & rsquo ; t ) , and whether move such a these have political motivation ( they do ) . Nevertheless , Netanyahu is not always to blame in these confrontation with America , nor is Biden always free of fault.Do n't assume that another PM would have better relation with the USOn Tuesday , one leading columnist wrote in Yediot Aharonot : & ldquo ; Do we need anything more than what is happening in our relation with America to understand the abyss the prime minister is leading u into ? What else need to happen to understand that every additional day he sits in his chair , our international situation deteriorates , and the crisis with our biggest and only friend & ndash ; our arm supplier & ndash ; get worse ? & rdquo ; The columnist assumes that were someone else sitting in the prime minister & rsquo ; s chair right now , with the war in Gaza in it sixth month and picture of Palestinians suffering flooding the traditional and social medium in the West , Israel & rsquo ; s situation in the world would be any better.But that is an erroneous assumption.Had even Yesh Atid & rsquo ; s Yair Lapid been prime minister when October 7 happened , it is hard to believe that the country & rsquo ; s policy toward Hamas and the IDF & rsquo ; s way of prosecuting the war would be that significantly different from what they are now . While perhaps there would be more of an emphasis on the & ldquo ; day after & rdquo ; and a more receptive ear to international plea for more humanitarian aid into Gaza , Israel would have the same war aim it ha now of destroying Hamas & rsquo ; s capabilities.That aim & ndash ; unfortunately , because of the way Hamas ha chosen to fight & ndash ; will lead to a high number of Palestinian civilian casualty and much Palestinian suffering , regardless of who is sitting in the Prime Minister & rsquo ; s Office . And it is those casualty and that suffering that , more than anything , are driving the wedge between Jerusalem and Washington.If you doubt this , look back to the day of the Naftali Bennett and Lapid tag-team government and think whether Israel & rsquo ; s position among the progressive Democrats in the US wa that much better than it is under Netanyahu . It wasn & rsquo ; t , because the anti-Israel progressive and & ldquo ; social justice activist & rdquo ; who are all impacting Biden & rsquo ; s policy right now during an election year are opposed not only to Netanyahu but to Israel itself , regardless of who lead the country.In their mind , Israel is an instrument of white supremacy and imperialism , and regardless of the identity of the prime minister or composition of his government , the Jewish state would still be an illegitimate , racist , colonialist enterprise in their eyes.US official were quoted a saying that Netanyahu & rsquo ; s decision not to send Dermer and Hanegbi to Washington for consultation wa motivated by political consideration . And they are probably right . Being seen a willing to stand up to US pressure play well politically with Netanyahu & rsquo ; s base.But there is something disingenuous in this criticism of Netanyahu for letting political consideration influence his policy . Are not political consideration now also heavily influencing Biden & rsquo ; s policy in this crisis ? Last month , the US vetoed a similar resolution at the Security Council calling for an immediate ceasefire . Why did it not do the same thing now ? What changed in the interim ? Several thing changed . Among them is that the casualty figure in Gaza continue to rise , and another is that Biden is getting pounded by progressive Democrats and Arab Americans for his support of Israel.Biden & rsquo ; s tone and the tone of his administration have changed markedly in the last two month , and that ha to do with Arab Americans voting & ndash ; or not voting & ndash ; in Michigan and with progressive unenthused by the Biden campaign , harshly critical of his Israel policy , and threatening either to vote for a third party candidate or stay at home on Election Day , November 5.Both Biden and Netanyahu are political animal , and both are using their disagreement for their own political purpose . But to say this is all Netanyahu & rsquo ; s fault , and that Israel & rsquo ; s position in the world and in Washington would be sterling even amid a war such a this if someone else were calling the shot in Jerusalem , is unrealistic.This doesn & rsquo ; t mean that Netanyahu & rsquo ; s handling of the relationship with the US during the war ha been flawless . It most definitely ha not.For example , Netanyahu could have played Monday & rsquo ; s Security Council resolution completely differently & ndash ; accept a two-week ceasefire for the duration of Ramadan to win favor with the Biden administration and the world , and then resume fighting at the end of the Muslim holy month if Hamas did not release the hostage . At that point , Israel could say that it fulfilled the resolution , but Hamas did not & ndash ; placing the onus on the terrorist organization.Netanyahu could have done thing differently , but not all the tension in the relationship can be dumped on his doorstep . Netanyahu & ndash ; with all his fault & ndash ; is not always wrong , nor is Biden & ndash ; with all the support he ha given Israel since October 7 & ndash ; always right , a various opposition leader and leading voice in the medium lamenting the current tension in the relationship would have one believe.Monday & rsquo ; s Security Council resolution is a case in point .

Body Text: The tension and clash in Jerusalem , particularly the video from Friday night showing Israeli police in al-Aqsa Mosque , have led to the first condemnation of Israel from the country & rsquo ; s new Gulf partner . & nbsp ; Bahrain condemned Israeli force for the & ldquo ; attack on worshiper at al-Aqsa Mosque . & rdquo ; The UAE ha called on Israel to de-escalate tension in Jerusalem and Sheikh Jarrah . & nbsp ; Bahrain also ha been concerned about the eviction of Palestinians from Sheikh Jarrah . It doesn & rsquo ; t want the peace process or stability in the region undermined , and it want provocation to stop . It want tension reduced a Ramadan concludes after a difficult month of clash . & nbsp ; The statement came a Saudi Arabia said it & ldquo ; reject Israel & rsquo ; s plan and measure to evict dozen of Palestinians from their home in Jerusalem and impose Israeli sovereignty over them . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The triumvirate of Saudi Arabia , Bahrain and the UAE is important because it is largely accepted that Riyadh gave the green light to Manama and Abu Dhabi to make peace last year . The Emirates went first , for various reason , even though Bahrain had long considered a peace deal and wa pushing coexistence for year . & nbsp ; The UAE made the first unprecedented flight with humanitarian aid during COVID-19 in the spring of 2020 . Then it ambassador to Washington , Yousef al-Otaiba , wrote an op-ed in Yediot Aharonot . Peace followed soon after a Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu backed down from & ldquo ; annexation & rdquo ; of the West Bank . & nbsp ; However , the peace deal , which moved quickly in August and September , hit some hurdle . There were question about F-35 sale , and US president Donald Trump lost the election in the US . This took the wind out of the sail of Saudi Arabia & rsquo ; s consideration and of several other country that might have jumped on the peace wagon . & nbsp ; There were consideration about reconciliation after year in which country had a transactional relationship with the Trump administration . Under Trump , Washington had signaled that human right were not an issue . There wa no pressure on Israel regarding Palestinian issue . On the contrary , there wa a & ldquo ; peace to prosperity & rdquo ; plan . & nbsp ; The plan wa unveiled on January 27 , 2020 , but aspect of it had been pushed in 2019 . The US Embassy had been moved in 2018 . Palestinians lost funding and were sidelined . The Jordanian king even went to Turkey for a meeting , and he had hoped Trump would reconsider the embassy move . & nbsp ; BY 2020 , thing were moving in favor of the peace deal , with key work from Jared Kushner and Avi Berkowitz . But calculation have changed in 2021 . & nbsp ; Human-rights group have made a new push to condemn Israel for & ldquo ; apartheid . & rdquo ; There have been call on the Biden administration to pressure Israel . Former CIA director John Brennan and others have led the push , along with critical voice in Congress . & nbsp ; Meanwhile , Netanyahu sought to fly to the UAE for a quick trip to show off the new relation while in the midst of an election campaign . Having twice canceled the trip during the pandemic , he had to cancel again on March 11 , claiming Jordan had prevented a stopover . Embarrassment followed a voice in the UAE expressed concern that they were being embroiled in Israeli politics . & nbsp ; Then came the Jerusalem tension . Failed attempt at Palestinian election and the beginning of Ramadan coincided with Israel & rsquo ; s election on March 23 . Ramadan began on April 21 , and with it came clash . & nbsp ; Nevertheless , the positive relation with the Gulf have continued . UAE Ambassador to Israel Mohamed Al Khaja penned an op-ed at Yediot about his first month in Israel . & nbsp ; However , the scene at al-Aqsa Mosque last Friday were the kind that cause tension in the region . Iran , Hezbollah and Hamas had slammed Israel in the day leading up to the clash . Turkey and Qatar were preparing statement to slam Israel . The US wa expressing concern and demanding de-escalation . European country were following the tension closely . & nbsp ; Instead of listening and trying to reduce the clash , Israeli security force waded into them . Whether that wa due to political uncertainty in Israel , with Netanyahu & rsquo ; s rival gaining in influence , or other issue wa not clear . & nbsp ; The security cabinet met for the first time in month on April 18 . A new crisis after shooting attack in the West Bank ha led Israel to bolster force . Hamas ha fired rocket and threatens more . Israel is holding a large drill preparing for a multifront conflict . & nbsp ; COULD GULF tie be strained by this convergence of trouble ? So far , the statement are what wa to be expected : concern and some mild condemnation ; a desire for stability and for Israel to listen . The question is whether Israel will listen . & nbsp ; Israel & rsquo ; s relatively cold official relation with Jordan and Egypt , combined with good security relation that largely go unnoticed , are the opposite of the positive tie and human-to-human connection with the Gulf that saw Israelis flock to the region to take part in conference and discus business deal . & nbsp ; However , voice in the UAE cautioned Israel about expecting too much and moving too fast . They certainly were wary of being used for a two-hour photo op by Netanyahu before an election . & nbsp ; Some Israeli right-wing voice in Israel , accustomed to slamming Arab state and never listening to regional voice , have paid lip service to peace with the Gulf . But they still show little interest in listening or taking to heart the need to reduce tension in Jerusalem . & nbsp ; Outside of the statement and Jerusalem clash , Israel and it peace partner in the Gulf have much to work on regarding wider issue , such a regional strategy and tie with Greece . There are new deal and initiative moving forward . & nbsp ; There is coexistence . However , the Jerusalem tension are the kind that require sensitive handling and showing respect for the concern of others , a type of language that Jerusalem ha not often used in recent year . & nbsp ; With a new administration in the White House , electoral uncertainty in Israel , and Iran , Turkey , Hamas and Hezbollah chomping at the bit for a showdown with the Jewish state , many challenge are in the air , of which the Gulf & rsquo ; s concern about Jerusalem are just one .

Body Text: Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas on Monday called on Canada and the international community to & ldquo ; stop Israeli aggression that violate international law . & rdquo ; He made the appeal during a meeting in Ramallah with Canadian Foreign Minister Marc Garneau . & nbsp ; Garneau & rsquo ; s visit to Ramallah came a Abbas continues to face widespread criticism over the death of anti-corruption activist Nizar Banat , who wa reportedly beaten to death by PA security officer in Hebron on June 24 . & nbsp ; In the past week , thousand of Palestinians have taken to the street to demand Abbas @ @ @ s removal from office . It called on the PA to take immediate step to ensure that freedom of assembly and expression are respected and protected . & nbsp ; Abbas told Garneau that the Palestinians are prepared to return to the political process with Israel & ldquo ; to end the occupation and achieve comprehensive peace , in accordance with international resolution , under the auspex of the Quartet & rdquo ; member & ndash ; the US , Russia , the United Nations and the European Union . & nbsp ; Abbas stressed the importance of having a political horizon and giving hope to the Palestinians , according to the PA & rsquo ; s official news agency WAFA . & nbsp ; It said that Abbas emphasized the need to expedite the process of rebuilding the Gaza Strip and providing aid to the Palestinians . & nbsp ; request to hold the election in Jerusalem . & nbsp ; WAFA quoted Garneau a saying that Canada wa opposed to the & ldquo ; expulsion of Palestinian resident from their home in east Jerusalem and the importance of respecting religious site , & rdquo ; a well a it rejection of settlement . & nbsp ; Garneau also expressed Canada & rsquo ; s keenness to establish peace in the region , it commitment to achieving peace based on the principle of the two-state solution , establishing security and stability and continuing to provide relief and assistance to UNRWA , the agency said . & nbsp ; Body Text: The decision by the Defense Ministry to designate six Palestinian NGOs a arm of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine terrorist organization quickly developed into an international storm , with the US , the UN and the EU raising objection and questioning the validity of the move . & nbsp ; On Monday , European Union Representative to the Palestinians Sven K & uuml ; hn Von Burgsdorff visited the six Palestinian NGOs Defense Minister Benny Gantz had targeted . On Wednesday , representative of 25 Israeli nongovernmental group paid a solidarity visit to the Al-Haq office in Ramallah to voice their opposition to the designation . Two divergent narrative emerged in the wake of the decision . In one reality resides Gantz , the Defense Ministry and pro-Israel NGOs , subscribed to the reality that long-ignored terrorist activity cynically cloaked in the guise of human right ha finally been unmasked . The other narrative considers the six NGOs to be human right organization and considers the designation to be a draconian attack on Palestinian civil society . & nbsp ; On one side , you have Prof . Gerald M . Steinberg , president and founder of NGO Monitor , who say : & ldquo ; There & rsquo ; s no justification for not considering or ignoring or overlooking the terrorist connection . These are not trivial . People & ndash ; Israelis & ndash ; have been killed . & rdquo ; On the other side , there & rsquo ; s Samer Sinijlawi , chairman of the Jerusalem Development Fund and Fatah activist from Jerusalem , who say : & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s just a blind war against all voice that are criticizing the occupation and the abuse of the human right of the Palestinians . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Which reality is true ? Is Israel trying to suppress Palestinian civil society , or is it a legitimate grievance against terrorist organization ? After reviewing the importance of the NGOs and their terrorism connection , where one fall seems to be a matter of priority . PFLP affiliation The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine is a Marxist military group recognized a a terrorist group by most of the Western world . & nbsp ; Israel claim that Addameer , Al-Haq , Bisan Center , Defense for Children International & ndash ; Palestine ( DCI-P ) , Union of Agricultural Work Committees ( UAWC ) and the Union of Palestinian Women & rsquo ; s Committees ( UPWC ) are part of a PFLP terrorist network that recruit , provides legitimacy to operative , and serf a a leadership wing for the PFLP . They & rsquo ; ve been accused of funneling funding to terrorism through forgery , laundering , and the awarding of stipend to the family of terrorist . & nbsp ; The government hasn & rsquo ; t provided much information to prove it allegation . But little ha been done to dispute them other than to note the group & rsquo ; status a human right NGOs . This leaf everyone else to make sense of the diverging reality . The NGOs have rejected the claim , but group like NGO Monitor assert that there is enough open source documentation to prove that the only thing under attack is terrorism . Al-Haq Established in 1979 and based in Ramallah , Al-Haq is an award-winning NGO with connection with dozen of international human right bodes , which describes itself a a human right NGO that & ldquo ; document violation of the individual and collective right of Palestinians . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Al-Haq wa the first NGO that drew Steinberg & rsquo ; s suspicion of PFLP connection , & ldquo ; and in many way is the most significant , of the one that were recently designated a terrorist organization , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; Al-Haq is headed by Shawan Jabarin , who sat in Israeli jail for a while , wa convicted of being an activist member of the PFLP , & rdquo ; said Steinberg . & ldquo ; The court ruled that he is a human right worker by day and a terrorist official by night . & rdquo ; According to NGO Monitor , in 2018 , Visa , Mastercard , and American Express shut down online donation to Al-Haq due to PFLP tie . Al-Haq asserted in a statement that the & ldquo ; baseless allegation & rdquo ; seek & ldquo ; to delegitimize , oppress , silence & rdquo ; Palestinian NGOs . It argued that the decision is not based on security concern , but come due to & ldquo ; the opening of an International Criminal Court investigation . & rdquo ; Sinijlawi find it suspicious that & ldquo ; these organization are leading the procedure in the ICC , where Gantz himself is the main target because he ha been the chief of staff in 2014 . & rdquo ; DCI-P Founded in 1991 , DCI-P is a Palestinian child right organization that provides legal support to Palestinian minor in the Israeli and military court system . & ldquo ; We reject the recent designation a another unjust action by Israeli authority to criminalize and eliminate our lawful human right and child protection work , & rdquo ; said Khaled Quzmar , general director of Defense for Children International & ndash ; Palestine . & ldquo ; When year of delegitimization and disinformation campaign against u have failed to silence our work , Israeli authority now choose to escalate repressive tactic by labeling civil society organization a terrorist . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; We & rsquo ; ve identified five or six different people at different level of the organization that had been active in the PFLP , & rdquo ; said Steinberg . & ldquo ; One in particular wa the coordinator of DCI-P & rsquo ; s Community Mobilization Unit , Hashem Abu Maria . & rdquo ; Abu Maria wa killed in a clash with the IDF in 2014 and , according to NGO Monitor , wa called & ldquo ; a leader & rdquo ; by PFLP . The designation is not the first time that DCI-P ha faced charge of terrorism . Citibank and Arab Bank PLC reportedly ceased providing service to DCI-P over PFLP link in 2018 . Addameer The Addameer Prisoner Support and Human Rights Association , established in 1991 , work and advocate for Palestinians in Israeli prison , & ldquo ; offer free legal aid to political prisoner , & rdquo ; and run social campaign . & ldquo ; They defend mostly PFLP , the people who are accused in the Israeli legal process , & rdquo ; Steinberg noted . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The designation represent an unprecedented & amp ; ominous attempt by the Israeli occupying authority to silence and criminalize Palestinian CSOs that challenge Israel & rsquo ; s prolonged military occupation , & rdquo ; Addameer tweeted . According to Steinberg , Addameer & ldquo ; have a number of staff member who are connected to PFLP . The founder , ( Abdul-Latif Ghait ) wa a member and activist . The former vice chairman . . . Khalida Jarrar . . . she is defined a the head of the PFLP operation in the West Bank . & rdquo ; NGO Monitor claim to have identified at least five other PFLP member in Addameer & rsquo ; s rank . Bisan Center The Bisan Center for Research and Development specializes in socioeconomic right and community engagement . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; It should be noted that Bisan Center for Research and Development is an independent , nonpartisan center that is not affiliated with any political entity , & rdquo ; Bisan said in a statement on it Facebook page . & ldquo ; This announcement [ of the terrorist designation ] come after concerted effort in the Israeli occupation & rsquo ; s attempt in a defamation campaign led by the Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs , & rdquo ; it continued . & ldquo ; The most recent [ Bisan ] executive director . . . wa sentenced for 12 month for recruiting activist , & rdquo ; said Steinberg . & nbsp ; Ataraf Rimawi , identified by NGO Monitor a Bisan & rsquo ; s previous executive director , wa noted in a court ruling a a & ldquo ; PFLP member & rdquo ; who & ldquo ; posed a security threat . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; UPWC The UPWC is & ldquo ; a progressive mass feminist organization that wa established in 1980 , & rdquo ; according to it website . & ldquo ; And they have five individual that we & rsquo ; ve identified on the payroll a PFLP people , & rdquo ; said Steinberg . & ldquo ; One of the founder of the PFLP . . . wa the president of the UPWC . So again , the connection there is pretty strong between [ the UPWC and ] the PFLP . & rdquo ; Israel is not the first to identify UPWC a a PFLP arm . In 2015 , Fatah identified the UPWC a a PFLP affiliate , a did USAID in 1993 . UAWC Among the largest agricultural institution in Palestinian society , UAWC wa established in 1986 to promote Palestinian agricultural development . & ldquo ; They run agricultural project in Gaza and in the West Bank , & rdquo ; said Steinberg . & ldquo ; And that & rsquo ; s their excuse . That & rsquo ; s the justification for the large amount of funding . They get million from many different European country . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; UAWC reject and condemns Israel & rsquo ; s unsubstantiated allegation directed at UAWC and the other NGOs , which are politically motivated . It is telling that the Israeli government refuse to release any & lsquo ; evidence & rsquo ; substantiating these allegation , & rdquo ; the NGO told The Jerusalem Post . & ldquo ; We have identified seven [ PFLP-affiliated ] individual that have various position [ in UAWC ] , & rdquo ; said Steinberg . & ldquo ; A number of them have been sentenced in Israel , and , of course , Samir Arbid is standing trial ; he wa their accountant . & rdquo ; Arbid and Razak Farraj , another UAWC member , were arrested for their role in the 2019 terrorist attack that killed Rina Schnerb . & ldquo ; There are hundred of employee who have worked and continue to work at UAWC and thousand of volunteer , & rdquo ; said a UAWC representative . & ldquo ; UAWC , like any other organization , is not responsible for any individual action of any former and current employee . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; We should not forget that Arbid and Farraj have been exposed to horrifying torture to pressure them to give confession , & rdquo ; said the representative . As with UPWC , Fatah and USAID documented that UAWC is a PFLP affiliate . NGO Monitor ha further noted that due to Arbid & rsquo ; s and Farraj & rsquo ; s affiliation , the Netherlands suspended funding to the organization . & nbsp ; The UAWC representative asserted that the funding wa suspended only because of & ldquo ; NGO Monitor & rsquo ; s large incitement campaign against UAWC . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The representative dismissed the USAID designation , saying that the USAID & ldquo ; report [ in which UAWC wa designated a PFLP affiliate ] wa published before the arrival of the Palestinian Authority , and it is a report that talk about the beginning of UAWC and it work , which wa all voluntary . & rdquo ; A few bad egg ? The main evidence for proponent of the designation doesn & rsquo ; t come from the government , but from NGO investigation showing overlap of PFLP member within civil society . & nbsp ; Sinijlawi argues that there are a few flaw in perceiving NGOs a terrorist organization based on a few individual . The NGO could be unaware it ha terrorist in it rank . & ldquo ; I don & rsquo ; t think that , by law , any NGO need to get a security clearance for any person to get employed . If somebody submits the CV and he & rsquo ; s qualified for a job , he get it . & rdquo ; Even if the NGOs were aware , while some country do not differentiate between military and political wing , these NGOs may have . & ldquo ; There could be a military wing inside the Popular Front , but it doe not mean that every student activist . . . is involved in a certain type of violence or military action . & rdquo ; While some of the NGOs may have had violent actor , & ldquo ; it doe not mean that this organization is totally involved into terrorism , & rdquo ; said Sinijlawi . & ldquo ; To blame the whole people because of someone related directly or indirectly to these NGOs . . . it & rsquo ; s a trick that anybody will buy . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s not just that they & rsquo ; re member . . . it & rsquo ; s high-level staff , & rdquo ; said Steinberg , dismissing that it & rsquo ; s a few bad egg & ndash ; & ldquo ; in some case , the head of the organization , the people who control the money . & rdquo ; Besides the pattern of NGO employee being PFLP operative , Steinberg noted , PFLP/NGO activist often hold multiple position in different NGOs , including in umbrella organization . & ldquo ; There & rsquo ; s a broader framework called PNGO , Palestinian NGO umbrella Organization . These organization are all member of the PNGO , and the head of the PNGO generally ha been a PFLP official . & rdquo ; NGO or terrorism ? & ldquo ; What doe anybody mean by Palestinian & lsquo ; civil society , & rsquo ; particularly when these organization are very clearly part of a network which is not just terrorist , but it & rsquo ; s also part of the PLO structure ? & rdquo ; Steinberg asks . & ldquo ; What make these organization civil society ? & rdquo ; The NGOs & ldquo ; are very important for Palestinians , & rdquo ; said Sinijlawi . The designation is tantamount to & ldquo ; shutting down the democratic dynamic inside Palestinian society . & rdquo ; On it part , PFLP ha not disputed it connection to the NGOs . & nbsp ; PFLP political bureau & rsquo ; s Kayed al-Ghoul ha said that Palestinians are & ldquo ; proud of the affiliation of any of their son with any national faction that resists the occupation , including the & rdquo ; PFLP . The negative reaction to the terrorism designation show how important these organization are to Palestinians and their ally . & nbsp ; Years of terrorist activity in the midst of Palestinian NGOs show that when it come to terrorist in their rank , the prevailing sentiment in the response from the international community , Palestinian activist , and international body is that you need to break a few bad egg to make an omelet . The two reality may not be so irreconcilable . The NGOs and the terrorist group are interconnected , and while Palestinian civil society may be under attack & ndash ; that may also be legitimate . & bull ;

Body Text: One recipe for a successful military operation is to clearly define goal beforehand , accomplish them , and then end the operation before expanding those goal and risking getting bogged down.As of Tuesday evening , Operation Home and Garden & ndash ; based on these criterion & ndash ; can be considered successful.The stated goal wa to target the terrorist infrastructure in Jenin and degrade the terrorist & rsquo ; capabilities.The IDF successfully knocked out terrorist command center , uncovered weapon lab and arm stockpile , killed nearly a dozen terrorist , and apprehended 10 time that number . It also signaled that it wa ready to end the operation swiftly.The success of the campaignThe campaign seemed successful at an operational and tactical level : well planned and effectively executed , with no IDF fatality a of Tuesday evening and minimal harm to non-combatants.Prevention need to be the next goalBut what come next ? What happens the day after the troop leave Jenin ? This question can be divided into two part : operational and strategic.Operationally , once the IDF leaf Jenin , it must prevent the terrorist from rebuilding the infrastructure there and posing a threat to the country . It must prevent them from building workshop for producing roadside bomb and lab for manufacturing primitive rocket . & nbsp ; The IDF also need to prevent the Jenin refugee camp from again becoming a sanctuary for terrorist carrying out attack on the road in Judea and Samaria.The relatively small number of terrorist killed or apprehended in this operation & ndash ; the IDF ha identified an additional 350 armed terrorist gunman in the city beyond the 120 arrested & ndash ; indicates that they evaded the IDF soldier . They hid but did not vanish , and once the IDF leaf they are likely to be even more motivated to carry out attacks.To prevent the terrorist from launching attack or rebuilding the terrorist infrastructure , the IDF will need to go back into Jenin again and again . This can not be a one-time operation because it effectiveness would rapidly diminish.In a perfect world , or at least in a world run according to agreement reached under the Oslo Accords , the Palestinian Authority security apparatus would be doing this job . But because the PA security apparatus is not fulfilling it responsibility , & nbsp ; the IDF ha to operate in it place . This mean the IDF will need to go into Jenin more frequently to keep the terrorist from having freedom of movement and action.After the IDF withdraws from Jenin , the security force must brace for retaliatory attack of the kind carried out by a lone terrorist in Tel Aviv on Tuesday afternoon.Additionally , they must be prepared for Jewish revenge attack in response to these terror attack . Such action , like the rampage by Jewish extremist in Palestinian town following the murder outside of Eli two week ago and in Huwara earlier this year , are not only morally reprehensible and wrong but also sap international legitimacy for the type of military action taken by Israel in Jenin , and which may become more frequent.As Israel take action to prevent the buildup of terrorist network in the West Bank , encouraged and supported by Iran , Hamas , and Hezbollah , it must also be ready to strike at target in Gaza and Lebanon if terrorist organization there launch rocket toward Israel in a show of solidarity with Jenin . That the recent fighting did not spread to other front this time doe not guarantee the same outcome if similar action are taken in the future.Israel need to define strategic goalsAll that is on the tactical and operational level.On a strategic level , Israel need to define it goal . While the IDF spokesman clarified Operation Home and Garden & rsquo ; s goal over the last few day , emphasizing that the aim wa to target the terrorist infrastructure without occupying and remaining in Jenin , a similar diplomatic goal wa not articulated.The IDF want to degrade the terrorist organization & rsquo ; s capability in Jenin , but what happens afterward ? What is Israel & rsquo ; s vision for Jenin ? Does it want the Palestinian Authority to regain control of the city ? If so , what political , diplomatic , or financial incentive is it willing to give the Palestinian Authority to motivate it to reassert it control ? In addition , Israel must determine how far it is willing to go and what action it is prepared to take to weaken Hamas , which is the Palestinian Authority & rsquo ; s main rival.During a Knesset Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee meeting last month , Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that while Israel want to eliminate the Palestinian aspiration for statehood , it & ldquo ; need & rdquo ; the Palestinian Authority and can not & ldquo ; allow it to collapse . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; We are prepared to help it financially . We have an interest in the Palestinian Authority continuing to work , & rdquo ; he said.Following the Jenin operation , Netanyahu must define what exactly that mean and outline the step he is willing to take to strengthen the PA so it will have incentive to regain security control in area like Jenin.When Naftali Bennett wa prime minister in 2021 , he spoke of & ldquo ; shrinking the conflict & rdquo ; with the Palestinians . This meant increasing Palestinian sovereignty through building a network of roadblock-free road controlled by the Palestinians , expanding Palestinian housing and infrastructure , implementing measure to boost the Palestinian economy , and decreasing Israel & rsquo ; s footprint in Palestinian-controlled areas.Although this fell far short of the Palestinian aspiration for statehood , it wa something.So far , the Netanyahu government ha not held out any diplomatic horizon for the Palestinians , and instead ha approved thousand of new housing unit in the settlement and green-lighted an expedited planning process for more.This reflects internal division within the government . While Netanyahu speaks of not wanting to bring about the collapse of the Palestinian Authority or annexing the West Bank , other voice & ndash ; such a those of Bezalel Smotrich & ndash ; advocate the opposite.Following the event in Jenin , Netanyahu need to decide what the government want . If the aim is to collaborate with the Palestinian Authority , action should be taken to strengthen it and weaken it enemy . But if the goal is to undermine the Palestinian Authority , Israel should begin preparing to fill the void created when the PA collapse . This week & rsquo ; s action in Jenin offer a glimpse of what may await throughout Judea and Samaria if this is the chosen course . & nbsp ;

Body Text: The tragic death of veteran Al Jazeera reporter Shireen Abu Akleh in Jenin on Wednesday morning came a Palestinian Authority Prime Minister Mohammad Shtayyeh wa visiting Brussels , where he attended a meeting of the Ad Hoc Liaison Committee , a body whose primary function is to coordinate the delivery of international aid to the Palestinians.Established in 1993 , the AHLC ha been meeting at least twice a year under the chairmanship of Norway.This year & rsquo ; s meeting came amid report that some of the Western donor country were refusing to provide additional financial aid to the PA unless it implement major reform , especially in the field of education . The proposed reform basically call for change in the Palestinian school textbook , which are written by PA professional whose salary are directly funded by the European Union.Shtayyeh went to the meeting with the hope of convincing the donor that the PA wa serious about implementing large-scale reform not only in the education sector , but in other field , too.And a in previous meeting , Shtayyeh used the platform to launch a scathing attack on Israel , accusing it of engaging in a & ldquo ; systematic destruction of the two-state solution by allowing settler to invade the Aqsa Mosque , preventing Palestinians from entering Jerusalem , in addition to field execution and arrest . & rdquo ; Referring to the severe financial crisis in the PA , the PA premier said that the Palestinians have started recovering from the coronavirus pandemic crisis , and that the Gross Domestic Product rose about 7 % in 2021 . & ldquo ; The Palestinian economy suffers from a defect in it structure , & rdquo ; Shtayyeh told the donor . & ldquo ; It is a besieged economy that doe not control it resource or capability , and it exists in an exceptional situation imposed by the reality of the occupation and it procedure . & rdquo ; He revealed that the rate of unemployment decreased in the last quarter of 2021 to 13 % , after having reached 18 % in 2019 . This , Shtayyeh said , wa due to new job opportunity in the West Bank and work in Israel.A report submitted to the AHLC by the Quartet , which consists of the US , EU , United Nations and Russia , noted that the PA continues to face a dire financial situation resulting from diminished economic growth , a marked decline in donor funding and Israeli deduction from clearance revenue ( in response to payment made by the PA to family of Palestinians involved in terrorist attack against Israelis ) . In 2021 , the PA & rsquo ; s deficit reached $ 757 million & ndash ; approximately 4.4 % of GDP & ndash ; despite GDP growth of 6 % , an increase in gross local revenue of $ 1.5 billion and a decrease in government expenditure . During the same year , deduction by Israel from clearance revenue reached $ 282m . , representing 37 % of the budgetary deficit . & ldquo ; Projections for 2022 by the PA portray a similarly grim fiscal situation , & rdquo ; according to the Quartet report . & ldquo ; Despite projecting 3 % growth in GDP and 8 % in gross revenue , the PA & rsquo ; s fiscal deficit is expected to reach $ 558m . Addressing that gap will require structural change , internal fiscal reform , improved economic growth , and the resolution of a number of long-discussed but still outstanding Israeli-Palestinian fiscal file . & rdquo ; Shtayyeh presented to the donor a plan that includes 21 step for reform related to administrative , financial , security , social and economic issue . & ldquo ; Whatever reform we make , they alone are not sufficient to address the imbalance in the Palestinian economic structure , because it is under occupation , & rdquo ; he argued . & ldquo ; Therefore , Israel must take measure on it part , and the support of donor country must continue to enable u to continue fulfilling our obligation . & rdquo ; Shtayyeh did not refer to the issue of anti-Israel incitement . But the plan he presented to the donor country argued that , a part of the reform process , the PA will work toward promoting and protecting the Palestinian national narrative and culture . & ldquo ; Information about Palestine is being deliberately distorted by the Israeli occupying authority , and , a part of this process , Palestinian folklore , heritage and archaeological artifact are being stolen , & rdquo ; the plan stated . & ldquo ; A battle is being waged over the narrative dominating the conflict . It is important that our national culture , grounded on the Palestinian identity , should be consolidated and protected . & rdquo ; THE NEWS OF Abu Akleh & rsquo ; s death came a Shtayyeh wa meeting with Roberta Metsola , president of the European Parliament , and other EU official on the sideline of the AHLC meeting.The widespread condemnation of the incident have since been used by Shtayyeh and other Palestinian official to garner additional support for the Palestinians & rsquo ; case , promote the Palestinian narrative , and shift the blame onto Israel . The ultimate goal : to ramp up the narrative according to which the Palestinians are the & ldquo ; victim of the Israeli occupation . & rdquo ; In a statement from Brussels , Shtayyeh wrote that & ldquo ; Shireen wa killed by the Israeli occupation while documenting their horrific crime against our people . & rdquo ; He later urged the senior EU official to pressure Israel & ldquo ; to stop all it unilateral measure and violation against our people and to allow the holding of election in occupied Jerusalem . & rdquo ; It & rsquo ; s not clear at this stage whether Shtayyeh wa successful in persuading the donor country to resume or increase their financial aid to the Palestinians . The killing of Abu Akleh may significantly contribute to the Palestinians & rsquo ; diplomatic and medium warfare against Israel , but it will not necessarily bring more money into the coffer of the PA.The Europeans and other Western donor have , at least in the past few year , been exerting heavy pressure on the PA to end the incitement and tone down it rhetoric against Israel.For now , it & rsquo ; s evident that the pressure ha proven to be ineffective.In fact , it seems that matter have been going in the opposite direction . The voice and message emanating from Ramallah and the Hamas-ruled Gaza Strip have become even more toxic , a evidenced before and during Ramadan.Allegations that Jewish settler are & ldquo ; storming & rdquo ; and & ldquo ; desecrating & rdquo ; the Aqsa Mosque during their tour of the Temple Mount are sounded almost every day in the West Bank and Gaza Strip . Senior PA and Hamas official don & rsquo ; t miss an opportunity to accuse Israel of planning to & ldquo ; commit crime & rdquo ; against one of Islam & rsquo ; s holiest site , Jerusalem , and the Palestinian people.Against this backdrop , terrorist attack were carried out in Beersheba , Bnei Brak , Tel Aviv , Elad and Jerusalem . The attack , which resulted in the death of 19 people , are said to be connected , directly and indirectly , to the tension at the Temple Mount and Jerusalem.Yet , just a the tension and violence appeared to be fading away , the incident involving the popular Al Jazeera journalist took Israel and the Palestinians back to square one . The PA , Hamas and other Palestinian faction and party are now using the tragedy to further whip up anti-Israel sentiment among the Palestinians.The protest against the killing of Abu Akleh are likely to continue in the coming day and week . The protest , which coincide with the first anniversary of the Israel-Hamas war , could escalate during the Palestinians & rsquo ; annual commemoration of Nakba Day on May 15 in protest against the establishment of Israel.The PA is now hoping to turn the tragedy of the reporter into a new version of the incident involving Mohammed al-Durrah , the 12-year-old boy who wa killed in the Gaza Strip in 2000 after being caught in a crossfire between the IDF and Palestinian security forces.The main goal is to increase the international pressure on Israel to halt all it practice in Jerusalem and the West Bank , including construction in the settlement and security measure at the Temple Mount.The PA & rsquo ; s effort are directed mainly toward the US and the EU.PA President Mahmoud Abbas want the Biden administration to & ldquo ; end it silence & rdquo ; and increase it involvement in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.He want the Biden administration to exert crushing pressure on the Israeli government to stop all IDF & ldquo ; incursion & rdquo ; into Palestinian city and village . He also want the Biden administration to fulfill all it promise to the Palestinians , especially the commitment to the reopening of the US Consulate in Jerusalem.On the other hand , Abbas and his official want the EU and other Western donor to unconditionally resume their financial aid to the PA.Meanwhile , there & rsquo ; s growing concern in Ramallah over the rising influence and popularity of Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad in the West Bank . While it & rsquo ; s true that the IDF crackdown on Hamas and PIJ member serf the interest of Abbas , it nevertheless underscore the weakness and alleged collaboration of the PA with Israel . Body Text: The Supreme Court on Thursday dismissed the petition filed by human right organization on behalf of the parent of Iyad al-Halak , who wa killed by an Israeli police officer four year ago in Jerusalem & rsquo ; s Old CityThe petition wa against the decision of the Police Investigation Department and the State Attorney & rsquo ; s Office not to appeal the Jerusalem District Court & rsquo ; s ruling that acquitted the Border Police officer who killed Halak in May 2020.According to the investigation , Halak , 32 , wa walking to the special need school where he both worked and studied . He kept running and eventually went into a nearby shed , where another officer opened fire and wounded him . Following the ruling , Adalah and the Meezan Organization for Human Rights ( Nazareth ) filed a petition on behalf of Halak & rsquo ; s parent , claiming that the decision wa extremely unreasonable and warranted Supreme Court review . & nbsp ; Setting a new precedentThe petition argued that the court & rsquo ; s ruling set new legal norm , and failing to challenge them would have significant legal consequences.According to the petition , the decision effectively lower the threshold for the justifiable use of lethal force by police officer , which could virtually eliminate all criminal accountability in case where Palestinians are killed by law enforcement.In addition , the petition argued that the judgment unreasonably expands the parameter of self-defense in criminal law , relying solely on the officer & rsquo ; s subjective perception of danger.The Supreme Court reviewed the argument and rejected the need for an appeal . Justices David Mintz , Khaled Kabub , and Ruth Ronnen handed down the judgment unanimously.Most case in the Supreme Court are overseen by three of the 15 sitting justice , with only major case receiving the full attention of the court.The Supreme Court said that there wa no basis for judicial interference and that it would only do so in highly exceptional and exceedingly rare cases.The court rejected argument that the Police or the State Attorney & rsquo ; s Office had been influenced by outside factor . title: supreme court upholds decision not to appeal acquittal of officer who killed iyad al-hallak
