Body Text: The Tiv Ta & rsquo ; am supermarket chain will continue it price reduction strategy that began about three year ago , lowering the price in the fruit and vegetable department in preparation for the Passover holiday.This is a 30 % discount rate for the vegetable and fruit product , and thus it will be comparable to the price of the best-selling vegetable and fruit that make up the basic basket to the price of Shufersal Deal ( Sunday-Wednesday ) and Shufersal Basket Online ( Thursday-Saturday ) . Tiv Ta & rsquo ; am ha chosen to discount about 20 product that are the best seller in the department . The price update will begin this week in the major branch and on the website www.tivtaam.co.il . & nbsp ; The move will be accompanied by a festive campaign that will cost about half a million shekel under the slogan : `` Cutting the price of the fruit and vegetable , the same quality at a new price . `` & nbsp ; Haggai Shalom , CEO and owner of the Tiv Ta & rsquo ; am Group : `` This is a continuation of the price control process that we started in the network about four year ago , in which we reduced the price of about 3,000 individual product from a variety of different department to Shufersal Deal price . `` The move that is now being made in preparation for Passover and at a time when the cost of living is worrying everyone come to strengthen the viability of everyday shopping and of course holiday shopping . The price reduction is carried out while taking care and maintaining the advantage that characterize the chain : quality , shopping experience , wide international culinary variety , service , and more . `` Shalom also added that : `` The price update is valid in the large chain store . In the urban store , we will continue to be competitive , high quality , diverse , and better than the competitor . ``
title: tiv ta ’ am to lower price before passover

Body Text: Ever since the shocking , deadly attack by the Hamas terrorist group on southern Israel on October 7 , civilian across the religious and political spectrum have been volunteering to help the war effort , eager to do whatever they can to support IDF soldier preparing to fight the brutal enemy . & nbsp ; Last week saw the largest call-up of military reserve in Israel & rsquo ; s history & ndash ; close to 400,000 & ndash ; in response to the brutal massacre of 1,300 Israelis , not to mention the wounded and the roughly 200 hostage taken to Gaza , including baby and Holocaust survivors.Israelis in the center of the country are concerned about their fellow citizen fleeing not only the South but also the North , where they were advised to evacuate in anticipation of a war with Hezbollah . & nbsp ; So much help is needed for so many cause , such a hot meal and warm clothing for the soldier , housing for displaced person , help for working mother of small child who remain home from school , and more . And ordinary citizen have risen to the occasion , searching for any way they could contribute to the war effort.The Kovacs familyAmong them is Chava Kovacs , a mother of seven child ranging in age from six to 14 . Residents of the ultra-Orthodox settlement of Tel Zion in Judea and Samaria , she and her husband have been hosting a family of eight from the southern city of Ashdod since the beginning of the current war ; the eldest child is eight and a half year old ; the youngest is two months.The Kovacs family made aliyah from Calgary in 2006 and speak English among themselves . Chava wa born in Poland and raised in the western Canadian city ; her husband , Hillel , grew up in Florida . & ldquo ; When we signed up to host a family , there wa an option to specify haredi/religious / secular , etc . We checked the & lsquo ; It doesn & rsquo ; t matter , send anyone & rsquo ; button , & rdquo ; Chava told the Magazine . & ldquo ; Our guest are a Sephardi haredi family . They don & rsquo ; t speak any English . We can manage in Hebrew but prefer English , & rdquo ; she said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We & rsquo ; re different in some way . They & rsquo ; re a kollel family ( meaning the husband study Torah during the day ) ; my husband work . We & rsquo ; re a little more relaxed about what we allow our kid to see on medium . We allow wholesome content , even if it & rsquo ; s secular . & rdquo ; Nevertheless , & ldquo ; they are very nice , sweet people , and very appreciative , & rdquo ; Chava continued . & ldquo ; They are thankful for the opportunity to get away from all the siren and for being able to go outside freely rather than being trapped in the house . They don & rsquo ; t seem traumatized or shocked . But yes , being constantly awakened by siren when you have young child is unbearable . & rdquo ; THE ADJUSTMENT , she said , ha not been too difficult . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Their kid are younger than mine , so there & rsquo ; s more cry than before ; but otherwise , it & rsquo ; s great to help someone . And my kid have new friend to play with , which is so important , since school ha been canceled . My kid really enjoy showing the Ashdod kid around all our park . My eldest took them to the petting zoo on our yishuv the other day . It gave him something fun to do . & rdquo ; Even though Chava and Hillel are immigrant , their child are & ldquo ; typical Israeli kid who grew up here . They understand English but are most comfortable speaking Hebrew & rdquo ; & ndash ; which help in this case . & ldquo ; Eliyahu , the father of the Ashdod child , now ha the opportunity to learn with his hevruta ( study partner ) by phone . He & rsquo ; s around some of the time . Baruch Hashem ( thank God ) , we have a big apartment with five bedroom , so everyone ha a little space , & rdquo ; she explained.How doe she manage to feed so many people ? & ldquo ; I & rsquo ; m just making more food and serving simple meal like pita and falafel or meatball with mashed potato and veggie . Their child are young , but still I definitely feel some pressure making sure we have enough food . Basically , I just put out a bunch of container on the table , and everyone take what they want . & ldquo ; We have a small Crockpot , so I borrowed a big one from a friend , & rdquo ; she added.Several charitable organization have publicized their willingness to help family in various central location that are hosting others from more volatile area . Chava said she ha been getting some help from a hessed ( kindness ) kitchen in their community that help new mother , people in hospital , and others during challenging times.The Magazine asked if the Ashdod mother ha been helping with the preparation . & ldquo ; She helped cut potato today , but really , she ha a new baby and a few small child , so I & rsquo ; m happy to let her relax a bit . She said she & rsquo ; s helping me tomorrow with the Shabbat cooking , & rdquo ; Chava replied during the interview last Thursday . & ldquo ; She & rsquo ; s really sweet and want to help . & rdquo ; AS FOR keeping the child busy , the family received permission from the community center to use the local Gymboree at no cost & ldquo ; any time they feel like it . & rdquo ; If closed , they can take the key . & ldquo ; I & rsquo ; m usually not a person who ha house guest , aside from nephew or my friend & rsquo ; s son who are here studying for the year , & rdquo ; Chava said . & ldquo ; My house look & lsquo ; lived in , & rsquo ; and our Shabbat meal aren & rsquo ; t so fancy . My kid chatter a lot at the table . But this family that we & rsquo ; re hosting , because they & rsquo ; re used to it , are just so happy to be here . I & rsquo ; m not bothered that they see that my sink is always full of dish . & ldquo ; I wish I could be a Henny Machlis , & rdquo ; she said of the late rebbetzen who wa famous for her remarkable charitable work and hospitality and would host 200 people every week on Shabbat . & ldquo ; But this is finally my chance to get a little closer to her example . & rdquo ; Chava hope that this experience will serve a an example to her child a well . & ldquo ; I & rsquo ; m hoping that my kid will look back on the war with some happy memory of having guest with cute little child rather than being miserable about the situation , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s a good distraction to have other people to think about and something tangible to do to help . & rdquo ; As for residing in the West Bank , & ldquo ; We & rsquo ; re fortunate to live here , a much a we & rsquo ; re so close to Ramallah . We very rarely have siren and missile , & rdquo ; she said , adding that & ldquo ; with their bad aim , & rdquo ; the Hamas terrorist would be more likely to hit a surrounding Palestinian village than the Jewish settlement . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I think our Ashdod family is happy , & rdquo ; she concluded . & ldquo ; Tel Zion is a nice community . They don & rsquo ; t care that our apartment isn & rsquo ; t 100 % clean or that it & rsquo ; s a little run down . They & rsquo ; re getting a little peace in the middle of wartime . & rdquo ; The Jerusalem Post and OneFamily are working together to help support the victim of the Hamas massacre and the soldier of Israel who have been drafted to ensure that it never happens again . & nbsp ; Become a partner in this project by donating to OneFamily & gt ; & gt ;
title: haredi family of 9 host family of 8 fleeing hamas attack

Body Text: Thailand will resume sending agricultural worker to Israel this week after an eight-month hiatus , the Thai labor ministry said on Monday , with a target of having more than 10,000 of it citizen working in the country by year-end.Around 30,000 Thai laborer had been working in the agriculture sector , comprising one of the largest migrant worker group in Israel , before the conflict broke out last October.Caught in the fighting when Palestinian Hamas gunman attacked Israel on Oct . 7 , 39 Thais were killed and another 32 were taken hostage , according to the Thai government.Israel to ensure safety of workersSix of them are believed to remain in captivity . `` The government asked for the cooperation of the Israeli government to help emphasize to employer to take care of the safety of Thai worker , `` the labor ministry said in a statement.The first batch of around 100 worker will fly out from the capital Bangkok on Tuesday , followed by another group in early July.Many Thais , particularly from the rural northeast region , have sought employment in Israel drawn by higher wage and an opportunity to work their way out of ballooning debt , a gnawing issue for million in Southeast Asia 's second-largest economy .
title: thailand to send farm worker to israel for first time since hamas attack

Body Text: WHAT & rsquo ; S IN a name ? Does changing the name change the purpose ? Not really . It & rsquo ; s merely a pacifying ploy to placate objector . We could see that this week with the Jerusalem parade , which while still in the planning stage , started out a the Adloyada , which signifies lot of joy and merriment . When objection were raised by family of the hostage and their supporter , the event wa not canceled , but the name wa changed to United Purim.Although it wa a muted affair compared to the annual parade during the intermediate day of Sukkot , it still attracted a large number of spectator and participants.According to municipal estimate , the attendance figure wa in the realm of 30,000 . But there were also protester waving placard with sign that registered displeasure at a festive event being held while no agreement had yet been reached on the return of the hostages.In interview last week , when the holding of the parade wa still a strongly contested issue , Jerusalem Mayor Moshe Lion said that it wa a way to bring happiness to the many evacuee child who were being hosted in Jerusalem . On the actual day of the parade , he said that it wa not a celebration but a continuation of tradition , adding that Israel & rsquo ; s enemy & ldquo ; will not stop u . & rdquo ; While the frustration of the hostage & rsquo ; family is understandable , they should remember that in Jewish tradition , the Sabbath and Jewish holy day take precedence over grief and mourning , and the week-long shiva mourning period is suspended.As a rabbinically declared holy day , Purim may have less sanctity or stricture than Passover , Rosh Hashanah , Yom Kippur , or Simchat Torah , but it is the only festival where the Jewish people are commanded to enjoy themselves , eat a sumptuous meal & ndash ; and indulge in alcoholic beverage until they lose the ability to discern what is happening around them ( Ad lo yada ) . Moshe Lion a guest of honor ■ TWO DAYS prior to the parade , Lion and his wife , Stavit , were guest of honor at the Hazvi Yisrael Synagogue in Talbiyeh . Although Lion did not lead the service or read from the Torah a he ha done during past visit , he did give a mini sermon . It wa one of the rare occasion in which congregant heard two sermon instead of one.Referencing the Torah portion that begin with the word & ldquo ; zachor & rdquo ; ( remember ) , Lion spoke briefly on the importance of remembrance , then launched into his favorite subject : the revolution that ha overtaken Jerusalem , and the huge construction boom throughout the city.Indeed , tall tower are now looming in almost every neighborhood , but the mayor should be aware that the foundation of all these tower are well below ground , and in digging them real estate developer are causing damage to the surrounding area . Walking to the synagogue from his home in Rehavia , Lion must have surely noticed all the pothole and crack in the road and the pavement , which are a blight on Israel & rsquo ; s capital . That situation will only get worse a more car , motorbike , scooter , and bicycle traverse the streets.Lack of adequate parking facility cause increasing number of vehicle to park on the pavement , forcing pedestrian to step out into the road . Moreover , electric scooter and two-wheeled vehicle , in addition to parking on the pavement , are also riding there & ndash ; sometimes at extraordinary speed & ndash ; causing frightening hazard to pedestrian . Is there no one on the city council who care ? Israel Prize news ■ OVER THE year , there ha been no shortage of faculty member of the Hebrew University among Israel Prize laureate , but this year there were special circumstance in the choice of Cochav Elkayam-Levy , a legal expert from HU & rsquo ; s Davis Institute for International Relations , being named among the recipient . She is being recognized for her tireless work to raise awareness about and acknowledgment of the crime against humanity committed by Hamas on and following Oct . 7 against Israeli woman , child , men , and families.Elkayam-Levy established the Civil Commission on Oct . 7 Crimes by Hamas against Women and Children , which aim at giving voice to the victim and their family , raise awareness about the concerning development in war crime against woman , child , men , and family on and after the massacre , and raise support for this cause . Her award is in the field of Solidarity ( Ahdut Hadadit ) , which is a new Israel Prize category.Any prize for an HU faculty member is , by extension , a prize for the university itself . HU President Prof . Asher Cohen said : & ldquo ; The Hebrew University take immense pride in the profound impact Dr . Cochav Elkayam-Levy ha had on raising awareness and acknowledgment of the atrocity committed against Israeli woman , child , men , and family on and following Oct . 7 . Her relentless dedication ha served a a powerful catalyst for justice and remembrance , inspiring u all to confront adversity with courage and compassion . & ldquo ; We congratulate [ her ] on being awarded the Israel Prize , the state & rsquo ; s highest honor , in a testament to her unwavering commitment to shedding light on one of the darkest chapter of our shared humanity . & rdquo ; Education Minister Yoav Kisch , in praising Elkayam-Levy & rsquo ; s work in the international arena , said that her commitment to exposing the atrocity of Hamas & ldquo ; is a crucial pillar in our ongoing struggle for justice and in our effort to confront the perpetrator . & rdquo ; He said that her work is deeply valued by the people of Israel , who owe her their heartfelt gratitude.greerfc @ gmail.com
title: grapevine : on parade

Body Text: Palestinian faction in the Gaza Strip have threatened to implement a gradual escalation against Israel if their demand are not met concerning reconstruction and the blockade on the Strip , complaining that Egypt is deliberately delaying the reconstruction process , according to Arabic medium . Sources from the faction told the Hezbollah-affiliated Al-Mayadeen on Monday that the Egyptians did not respond to a position paper presented by Hamas recently , claiming that Egypt is deliberately delaying the reconstruction process in the coastal enclave . The source warned that Hamas and the other faction in Gaza have set a deadline for the end of this year and would begin a gradual escalation starting next week . The source added that Egypt refused the entry of a large Hamas delegation which wa scheduled to visit Cairo at the end of November . A `` leading source `` in Hamas told Al-Jazeera on Monday that the movement is studying option for an escalation with Israel , also expressing `` strong dissatisfaction `` with Egypt 's behavior , saying that it ha been reluctant in implementing it promise to Gaza . The source , pointing to what they called Israeli attack on al-Aqsa Mosque and the tightening of measure against Palestinian prisoner , warned that this would `` explode the situation . `` The Hamas source also claimed that Egypt ha been preventing thousand of people from leaving the Gaza Strip without reason . `` Egypt 's behavior is considered an abandonment of it commitment to compel Israel in return for the resistance 's commitment to the truce , `` the source told Al-Jazeera . On Tuesday , Hamas member Suhail al-Hindi told the Palestinian al-Ayyam news that the faction could no longer accept the tightening of the blockade on Gaza and the prevention of reconstruction , warning that they would not remain silent for long . Unlike the Al-Jazeera and Al-Mayadeen report , al-Hindi told al-Ayyam that Egypt had made great effort a a mediator to resolve the various issue . The Hamas official stressed that the faction would `` have their say `` in the coming day . Additionally on Tuesday , Palestinian medium reported that the faction in Gaza had warned against Israel 's procrastination in lifting the siege on Gaza , calling on mediator to assume their responsibility `` before it is too late . `` The report indicated that the `` gradual escalation `` would likely begin with measure referred to a `` popular resistance , `` usually referring to incendiary and explosive balloon , a well a riot and demonstration along the Gaza border . The situation between Gaza and Israel ha remained relatively calm since Operation Guardian of the Walls in May , except for a spike in clash which took place in August . Despite the claim that Egypt is holding up reconstruction effort , it signed agreement with Qatar to supply fuel and basic building material to the Gaza Strip in November . The expression of disappointment with Egypt come two week after Palestinian Islamic Jihad Secretary-General Ziyad al-Nakhlah attacked Hamas for accepting and facilitating economic aid approved by Israel , saying the aid provided by Egypt to Gaza wa an attempt by Israel to `` tame Gaza `` with economic incentive . `` The resistance should not play the role of an agent in facilitating the work of citizen within the Israeli entity , `` stressed the PIJ leader in an interview with Al-Mayadeen . `` Israel want to turn the West Bank and Gaza into warehouse for worker , and this is something we do not accept . `` Israel considers Gaza a time bomb that it want to dismantle , and the new facility come within this framework , `` he said . `` Everyone in the region is betting that the resistance will become afraid for privilege and facility and will not enter into a war . `` Delegations from both Hamas and the PIJ held talk with Egypt 's Intelligence Minister Maj . - Gen . Abbas Kamel in Cairo in October , discussing effort to reach an extended ceasefire and prisoner swap . Mixed report from the past few month have claimed both that significant progress wa made on these two issue and that little to no progress had been made .
title: gaza faction threaten escalation , lash out at egypt over reconstruction delay

Body Text: Israeli security force will be given a & ldquo ; free hand & rdquo ; to conduct any operational activity , Prime Minister Naftali Bennett said following another day of Palestinian rioting in Jerusalem & rsquo ; s Old City and on the Temple Mount.Israel & rsquo ; s main goal is to provide security to all Israeli citizen , the prime minister added following a situational assessment held with Defense Minister Benny Gantz , Foreign Minister Yair Lapid , Public Security Minister Omer Bar Lev , IDF Chief of Staff Lt . - Gen . Aviv Kohavi , Israel Police Chief Kobi Shabtai , Shin Bet ( Israel Security Agency ) Director Ronen Bar and other security establishment officials.Despite every effort by Israel to enable freedom of worship to Palestinians during the month of Ramadan , security force will continue to act against rioter who try to disrupt public order , Bennett said.Clashes broke out on the Temple Mount between Israeli security force and Arab worshiper on Sunday morning a Jewish visitor entered the site on the first intermediate day of Passover and hundred of Arab youth began gathering stone and blocking pathways.Rocket siren sounded in Nahal Oz on Sunday afternoon , with local resident reporting hearing an explosion . Despite the report from local , the IDF announced that the siren were a false alarm.Early on Sunday morning , Palestinian medium reported that Israeli police had set up checkpoint at the entrance to the Old City of Jerusalem and the Temple Mount , only allowing worshiper through after checking their ID cards.Shortly before Jewish visitor began entering the site on Sunday , Israel Police entered the complex , pushing Arab visitor toward the Dome of the Rock and al-Aqsa Mosque . Video shared by Al-Qastal , a Palestinian news site focusing on Jerusalem , showed security force closing gate and closing the door of the Dome of the Rock and prayer hall at the site after pushing worshiper inside.Israel Police issued a statement saying they entered the site after hundred of Arab youth began gathering stone and blocking pathway in an attempt to disturb the peace . & ldquo ; Hundreds of law-breaking young people disturbed the peace in the Temple Mount area and inside the mosque during violent riot , which have nothing to do with the sanctity of the holiday and the holy place . These violent outlaw are the one who defile and desecrate the holy place and try to harm innocent civilian and security force , & rdquo ; the statement said . & ldquo ; Unfortunately , on social medium false information and misinformation is disseminated in relation to event , while throwing sand in the eye of the public in an attempt to incite and agitate , & rdquo ; it added . & ldquo ; These false publication , some of which have no grip on reality , try to create improper legitimacy for throwing stone and firing firework inside a house of prayer and at policeman and civilian and misrepresenting the holy place and especially the Temple Mount . & rdquo ; There were 19 Arabs injured in the clash , with five transferred to hospital , according to the Jerusalem Red Crescent.تغطية صحفية : `` نداءات استغاثة عبر سماعات المسجد الأقصى إثر استمرار اعتداءات قوات الاحتـــلال على المصلين ومحاصرتهم `` pic.twitter.com/Ux7ft8z9ne & mdash ; AlQastal القسطل ( @ AlQastalps ) April 17 , 2022Video shared from the scene showed Arabs calling on Palestinians in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank to support them , alongside chant in support of Hamas saying , & ldquo ; With our soul and blood , we will redeem you , Oh , Aqsa . & rdquo ; Jewish worshiper walking in Jerusalem & rsquo ; s Old City were attacked by Arab assailant on Sunday morning . Video showed the assailant hitting at least one Jewish victim on the head . Although the worshiper did not require medical treatment , two suspect were arrested in connection with the incident.A total of 728 Jews visited the Temple Mount on Sunday morning , according to the Temple Mount Administration . The compound will be open to Jewish visitor from 7 a.m . to 10:30 a.m . throughout the intermediate day of Passover , including Thursday.Jewish visitor are not allowed to bring religious item with them or to pray on the Temple Mount , according to police regulation , although quiet , subtle prayer without bowing ha seemingly been permitted by police in recent years.Amid the unrest on the Temple Mount , Palestinian rioter threw stone at a number of public bus near the Old City , damaging window and lightly injuring a number of commuters.Nine suspect were arrested during the unrest on the mount and in the Old City , four of whom were involved in throwing stone at buses.Al-Aqsa tension shake coalitionMeanwhile , the Islamic Movement & rsquo ; s Shura Council decided on Sunday evening that Ra & rsquo ; am would suspend it membership in the Knesset and coalition in protest against the situation at al-Aqsa . The party called on the Joint List to do the same until a solution is reached about al-Aqsa , adding that it wa ready to take a decision for the collective resignation of the Arab party from the Knesset.Ra & rsquo ; am MK Waleed Taha had told Channel 13 on Sunday afternoon , & ldquo ; I would expect the government to behave differently toward the Jews who came up to provoke at al-Aqsa Mosque , but it allowed several hundred fascist to do so . The price will probably be the dissolution of the coalition . & rdquo ; The decision and warning from Taha came after MK Mazen Ghanaim warned Bennett in a letter on Friday that he would pull out of the coalition if police activity on the Temple Mount did not cease.The office of Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas called on Palestinians to arrive at al-Aqsa Mosque in order to & ldquo ; defend it . & rdquo ; He warned that the action of Israeli security force were a & ldquo ; dangerous escalation , the repercussion of which are to be borne by the Israeli government alone . & rdquo ; JORDAN & rsquo ; S KING Abdullah II stressed on Sunday afternoon the need for Israel to respect the & ldquo ; historical and legal status-quo at al-Aqsa Mosque/al-Haram al-Sharif and cease all illegal and provocative measure that violate it and could push toward further escalation . & rdquo ; The Jordanian monarch directed his government to continue regional and international effort and communication to & ldquo ; stop Israeli escalation . & rdquo ; Amid the tension , Otzma Yehudit head Itamar Ben-Gvir warned on Sunday that he had sent a message to the commander of the Jerusalem Police District saying that if police were not given a free hand to act against rioter , he would establish a bureau at the Damascus Gate . Last year and earlier this year , Ben-Gvir established a bureau in the Sheikh Jarrah/Shimon Hatzadik neighborhood of east Jerusalem amid tension there.Rabbi of the Western Wall and Holy Sites Rabbi Shmuel Rabinowitz condemned the violence on Sunday , saying , & ldquo ; [ I ] strongly condemn the severe attack and calamity this morning against innocent Jews on their way to the morning prayer of the intermediary day at the Western Wall . This is an act of terrorism on the path of peace in a city that sanctifies freedom of religion , and anyone who desire should be allowed to pray in peace and security . & rdquo ; On Saturday night , Arabs put up a banner on the Temple Mount/Haram al-Sharif reading & ldquo ; Hamas call on you for a general mobilization and to push out the herd of settler who are threatening to storm al-Aqsa . & rdquo ; Israeli force entered the complex later in the night to remove the banner and arrested a person there.Clashes broke out between Arabs and Israeli security force in front of the Jerusalem Magistrate & rsquo ; s Court on Saturday night a well , after Palestinian medium reported that Israeli authority had decided not to release some of those detained during the riot at al-Aqsa on Friday . Joint List MK Ahmed Tibi wa present at the scene.Early on Sunday morning , video wa shared on Palestinian medium showing group of detainee in multiple location being released , although at least some remained in custody , according to the reports.Hamas official Khaled Mashal stated on Saturday night that the movement had told the Qatari foreign minister it wa demanding that sacrifice not be brought by Jews at the site , that Israeli force not & ldquo ; storm & rdquo ; Jenin and that those arrested at al-Aqsa on Friday be released.Mashal added that the foreign minister had told Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh that Israel wa not interested in an escalation , and that Hamas had responded that it wa also not interested in a step-up in violence but that it & ldquo ; had it responsibility and the escalation in Jerusalem must be stopped . & rdquo ; Arabs clash with Israeli force in Nazareth and the West BankIn Nazareth , Arab-Israelis clashed with police during a demonstration about Friday & rsquo ; s clash at al-Aqsa . At least 20 arrest were reported by Palestinian medium . Video from the scene showed rioter burning large fire in the middle of a street in the city.A Palestinian wa shot by Israeli force near Tulkarm on Saturday night and five others were arrested at the scene , according to Palestinian reports.Clashes broke out in Beit Iksa , northwest of Jerusalem , with Israeli force firing tear gas to disperse rioter , according to Palestinian report .
title: israeli force given ' free hand ' a clash break out on temple mount

Body Text: Energy Minister Yuval Steinitz , an observer on the security cabinet , called for the IDF to temporarily take over Gaza for a few week in order to disarm Hamas , in an interview with Ynet on Wednesday . & nbsp ; & quot ; We will have no escape one day from a temporary takeover of Gaza , which ha heavy price , & quot ; said Steinitz to Ynet . & quot ; This day did not come for all sort of reason . I think this day will come , if not now , then in the coming year . & quot ; & nbsp ; & quot ; No one will disarm Hamas unless we do it by force , & quot ; added Steinitz . & quot ; This idea of taking over Gaza to completely dismantle terrorist organization ha heavy cost . That is why I understand the people who think differently from me and who object to the idea of one day doing a ground invasion and the collapse of the Hamas regime . & quot ; & nbsp ; Steinitz added that Israel should declare a unilateral ceasefire without an agreement with Hamas , saying that the terrorist group wouldn @ @ @ t follow any agreement in any case . & nbsp ; Concerning how long he belief the operation will continue , Steinitz stressed that he wouldn @ @ @ t make a statement on the matter a the & quot ; last thing that I want to do is provide the other side with a schedule . & quot ; & nbsp ; The statement come amid report in Israeli and international medium claiming that Israel and Hamas were nearing an agreement on a ceasefire that would begin on Thursday . & nbsp ; Hamas official Izzat Reshiq tweeted on Tuesday night that the report of a ceasefire were not true and that no agreement had been reached , adding that & quot ; the effort and discussion of the mediator are serious and continuous , and the demand of our people are clear and known . & quot ; & nbsp ; During a briefing for ambassador in Israel on Wednesday , Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stressed that Israeli is & quot ; not standing with a stopwatch , but rather is concerned with meeting goal . & quot ; & nbsp ; Community Affairs Minister and security cabinet member Tzachi Hanegbi told KAN Reshet Bet radio on Wednesday that & quot ; Israel is not engaged with a ceasefire , but in firing . The IDF ha many other goal and mission & mdash ; for many day and week . & quot ; Regional Cooperation Minister Ofir Akunis told Army Radio that the operation is continuing and that there is & quot ; nothing related to a ceasefire . & quot ; & nbsp ; A person involved in the ceasefire talk told Army Radio on Wednesday that there are currently no negotiation on a truce and that Egyptian effort to reach a ceasefire are ongoing . A senior official in Jerusalem said on Tuesday that while the IDF ha had major success in striking Hamas , it ha many more target it want to hit . Since the beginning of the fighting , close to 3,500 rocket have been fired from the Gaza Strip toward Israel , with some 500 falling short and landing inside the coastal enclave . Body Text: A month before the Gaza war , thing were going well for Israel . The Abraham Accords were going strong and a vaccination campaign had made Israel an envy during the pandemic . A new US administration wa keen to increase the US role around the world and support human right . That might mean no more chaotic policy , like the flip-flop of the Syria withdrawal in 2018-2019 . & nbsp ; On May 22 , after the recent Gaza war , the Palestinian Authority mufti wa expelled from al-Aqsa for not supporting Hamas . Hamas wa riding a wave of popular support , claiming it had defeated Israel . Protests in many country had targeted Jews and article slamming Israel were being printed in newspaper worldwide . Anti-Israel activist sensed the tide had turned : Israel could be eliminated a a & ldquo ; settler-colonial state . & rdquo ; Iran agreed . & nbsp ; How did it come to this ? ISRAEL HAD largely kept Hamas isolated and ossified in Gaza since the 2014 war . Cut off from many supply by Egypt , it had few friend . It had tried to expand that dwindling support abroad in 2019 and 2020 through visit to Turkey , Malaysia , Qatar and Iran . However , Israel & rsquo ; s new relationship in the Gulf appeared to show that Israel wa now accepted in the region and a new alliance with Greece and Cyprus could promise new energy deal . Turkey , concerned about the incoming presidency of Joe Biden , wa talking reconciliation across the region after being empowered by the Trump administration . The US wa & ldquo ; back , & rdquo ; Biden said . & nbsp ; When the Biden administration came into office it wa after an unprecedented era of uncertainty in the US , with COVID and the former US President refusing to concede . The Middle East wa not a priority . Israel had close cooperation with US Central Command and good relation with the US regarding it desire to protect it interest . It wa able to act against Iranian entrenchment in Syria . There wa no big push for peace . There wasn & rsquo ; t even a new US ambassador in Jerusalem . But a slow drumbeat wa beginning . In preparation for the incoming Biden administration , the human right group B & rsquo ; Tselem released a report on Israel apartheid . By April 27 , Human Rights Watch would follow suit . On April 29 , the Palestinian Authority postponed it election , fearing a Hamas victory . Israel had held election on March 31 and continued to be divided . It wa the fourth election in two year . Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu did little to form a coalition . A ray of hope wa the rise of Ra & rsquo ; am and it head Mansour Abbas . He looked willing to join an opposition coalition after breaking from the Joint List . By May 5 , President Reuven Rivlin had tasked Yair Lapid with forming a government after Netanyahu failed once again to create a coalition . MEANWHILE , tension were growing in Jerusalem . Ramadan had begun and with , it there were clash with Israeli police at Damascus Gate . After attack on Orthodox Jews there wa a right-wing rally on April 22 and several were wounded . A dispute in east Jerusalem @ @ @ s Sheikh Jarrah neighborhood began to get some international and Palestinian attention . Hamas vowed to defend Al-Aqsa . On Quds ( Jerusalem ) Day , May 7 , Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Khamenei said Israel wa a terrorist state . Iran & rsquo ; s IRGC head Hossein Salami also slammed the Jewish state and predicted that it could suffer a tactical defeat or be blockaded at sea . Hamas and Hezbollah made similar statement . Hamas warned Israel that it would respond to Jerusalem clash and on May 10 , to coincide with Israel & rsquo ; s Jerusalem Day march , fired rocket at Jerusalem . Israel , with Lapid and Naftali Bennett seeking to form a coalition to replace Netanyahu , began airstrikes on Gaza . By May 12 , Bennett had ended discussion on a new government . Riots across Israel in Arab and mixed town created a crisis . Border Police were rushed to Lod . Attacks and lynching began on both side from Bat Yam to Umm al-Fahm , Rahat , Jaffa and other place . There had been clash in Jaffa since April 20 . Now thing took a turn for the worse . Israel called up almost 10,000 reservist , and sent Golani and 7th Armored soldier to the border of Gaza . It rushed support to the West Bank where shooting attack and clash grew . The attack had begun with Palestinian terror cell targeting the Tapuah junction in early May . Another shooting attack took place on May 7 , near a post at Salem in the West Bank . Israel said the shooter were planning a worse attack . & nbsp ; WHEN ISRAEL retaliated on May 10 , Hamas put into action a plan to use thousand of rocket to pound Ashkelon , Ashdod and Tel Aviv , a well a Israeli airport and population center . It used drone and planned to use unmanned submarine . It sent anti-tank guided missile ( ATGM ) team to the border to strike at Israeli vehicle . This wa a sophisticated , planned operation , in which up to 140 Hamas rocket would be fired at once in massive barrage . Hamas had perfected this over the year with various rocket attack at sea , practicing for this scenario . It also showed off new long-range rocket with a range of up to 250 km . , targeting Eilat and perhaps Dimona a well . It knew that a Syrian S-200 had been fired that triggered alert near Dimona on April 22 . & nbsp ; With Iranian support , there were attack in the North a well . On May 13 , rocket were fired into the sea from Lebanon and protester laid siege to Israel @ @ @ s border with it northern neighbor on May 18 . It may have come from Iraq . Rockets fired on May 19 even flew near Kiryat Yam , near Haifa . This wa a serious incident . It followed the April 27 downing of a Hezbollah drone . & nbsp ; Now Hamas and Fatah activist are battling over Al-Aqsa , a clash showed on May 23 , and Hamas is saying that it war ha harmed the Abraham Accords . & nbsp ; It & rsquo ; s not clear whether Hamas knew it plan would work or the degree to which Iran advised Hamas on this strategy . It is also not clear if the benefit to Hamas and Iran wa merely a lucky turn of event for them and that timing dictated the need to go to war but the result were far from certain . Clearly , Hamas didn & rsquo ; t have much to lose . Israel , on the other hand , ha much to lose and it had diminishing return from it year of sunk cost in Gaza . Iran and Hezbollah wanted to test Israel & rsquo ; s defense . It increasingly appears Israel walked into a trap in Gaza . It wa a trap partially of Israel & rsquo ; s own making due to not having a new government and having strategic planning concentrated in Netanyahu & rsquo ; s office without check and balance and broader security cabinet discussion . & nbsp ;

Body Text: In the best of time , the eerie transition from Remembrance Day & ndash ; the sad music , the half-mast flag , the national mourning & ndash ; into the jubilation of Independence Day is jarring . This year , the first since October 7 changed Israel forever , it wa unfathomable.No firework , no raucous party in the park with the country & rsquo ; s top talent belting out the hit , and no kid attacking each other with string spray.According to most report , the street were generally extremely quiet for Independence Day , a many of the populace preferred to stay close to home and hunker down with their family and friend for more intimate commemorations.Dueling ceremony touted the country & rsquo ; s irrefutable achievement and it citizen & rsquo ; bravery ( the official state-sponsored event ) on the one hand , and on the other hand , spotlighted the hostage held in Gaza by Hamas and the inability to celebrate amid a bloody war that ha seen thousand of soldier killed or wounded ( the alternative grassroots event ) . The different reality Israel encountersLooking on a split screen , one could ask which wa the real Israel at 76 ? They both reflect a reality of where the country is at this most precarious moment in it short life . The only conclusion that can be drawn is that they & rsquo ; re both accurate and reflect the pain , uncertainty , and sadness that exemplified this year & rsquo ; s Remembrance and Independence Days , a well a the pride in the accomplishment of the world & rsquo ; s only Jewish state.We & rsquo ; re a broken , damaged country , filled with question about it government and institution that enabled October 7 to take place or why it did not succeed in the last seven month of the war to defeat Hamas or bring the more than 130 hostage or their remains back home.Yet , taking a step back , it & rsquo ; s undeniable that Israel 's last 76 year are a huge success story & ndash ; a triumph of human spirit unmatched in recent history.That doesn & rsquo ; t help fill the agonizing void and anguish the country felt this week , however . The 24 hour of Remembrance Day , filled with heart-wrenching story of the oh-so-fresh death of so many people who were so full of life and had so much to offer , wa too much to bear.But , bear it we do - because there & rsquo ; s no alternative . This year & rsquo ; s Independence Day , rather than a celebration , wa more like a reminder that yes , no matter how bleak thing may seem right now , we & rsquo ; re still here and what we & rsquo ; ve built and cherish is still worth fighting for.Every day in Israel is Remembrance and Independence Day . We can never forget the sacrifice made by so many to establish the country and bring it to the great height it achieved in it first 76 year . At the same time , we can never take it independence for granted.Rather than the usual over-the-top merriment , the last 24 hour offered a bear hug to people desperately in need of it . We & rsquo ; re a long way from starting a healing process & ndash ; one that will take year to complete , if ever.That will only begin once the hostage are freed , Hamas is rendered not to be a formidable threat to Israel & rsquo ; s security any longer , our soldier stop dying in the Gaza battlefield , and the resident of the North feel safe enough to return to their home . And , of course , all of that is bracketed by the prime minister and the head of the country & rsquo ; s security apparatus resigning for their role in not preventing October 7.Until that time , Israelis need to ask themselves : Is what unifies u more powerful than what separate u ? If the answer is yes , then there & rsquo ; s hope that Israel & rsquo ; s 77th Independence Day will be more joyous than the one that just sunk under the exhaustion of war and sorrow . & nbsp ;

In 2020 , the United States imposed sanction on an ICC prosecutor.The Kremlin said on Tuesday it wa very curious that the United States appeared ready to use sanction against the ICC . `` In general , the situation is more than curious in term of the U.S . attitude and willingness to use sanction method even against the ICC , `` Kremlin Spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters.In March last year , the ICC issued warrant for the arrest of President Vladimir Putin on war crime charges.Russia say the warrant against Putin is a meaningless attempt by the West to soil Russia 's reputation and denies war crime in Ukraine . Every person who support Hamas support continuing a level of threat against u that doe not allow progress . Therefore , addressing the security danger & ndash ; which is a real danger for u , and not paranoia & ndash ; is the key . We will be working on this with all our partner , but we need some time . Let & rsquo ; s focus first on a real solution for Gaza . & rdquo ; He would conclude with a broader message that will resonate around the world : & ldquo ; Palestinian and Arab friend , and also enemy : We want peace , but we will not roll over . The Jewish people are in Israel to stay . Work with u and you will find a supporter and a champion . The past seven month have offered a glimpse of the hell that awaits u if the radical prevail . Let & rsquo ; s instead ensure that this never occurs again . & rdquo ; The prime minister will have not committed to anything that Israel should not itself desire & ndash ; but the deck will have been completely reshuffled . Even if Hamas reject all the option , among serious people in the world there will be clarity at last , and Israel would have international legitimacy to press on . This is good , because there is no great advantage in dwelling alone.I know & ndash ; the prime minister who doe this can not be Netanyahu . It really doe appear that basically nothing drive him but a lust for power and the most vulgar of political calculation . That & rsquo ; s why Israel need a new election with urgency . But I would love to be proved wrong.The writer is the former chief editor of The Associated Press in Europe , Africa and the Middle East , the former chairman of the Foreign Press Association in Jerusalem , and the author of two book about Israel . Body Text: & nbsp ; Even with over 3.1 million Twitter follower and a popular weekly television show , British-American late-night television comedian & nbsp ; John Oliver doe not run the world . Thank God . & nbsp ; Because if he did , or if he even ran a small country , Israel would be facing a humongous challenge on the international stage . & nbsp ; Oliver delivered a vicious 10-minute attack on Israel on his Last Week Tonight show on Sunday that wa a brutally unfair a it wa void of any context . To sum up his simplistic argument : Israel is hitting Hamas much harder than Hamas is hitting Israel , more Palestinians are dying than Jews , so Israel is wrong , immoral and guilty of war crime . & nbsp ; That & rsquo ; s the equivalent of saying that because an estimated 500,000 German civilian were killed in World War II , a opposed to & ldquo ; only & rdquo ; 67,000 British civilian , the Nazis were right in that war , and Britain wa wrong . & nbsp ; And Oliver is not alone . Other late-night comedian , such a Trevor Noah , have jumped into the fray with their pearl of geopolitical wisdom , a have various entertainer and celebrity . & nbsp ; What all that doe , in a world where social medium amplifies these voice well beyond what they deserve , is to create a sense among many Israelis that nobody understands u , that everyone is against u . And while the Olivers and Noahs are opinion influencers who have an oversized impact on a younger demographic that often get it view of the world from those type of TV show , the world & rsquo ; s government & ndash ; most importantly that of the US & ndash ; are not internalizing their drivel . At least not yet . & nbsp ; As the second full week of Operation Guardian of the Walls is nearing completion , it would be a mistake to look at Oliver & rsquo ; s and Noah & rsquo ; s rant , or the tweet of radical progressive US congresswoman Rashida Tlaib and Ilhan Omar , or listen to the anti-Israel and often antisemitic chant at protest around the globe , and see that a representative of where Israel stand today in the world . & nbsp ; Those rant are bad , those tweet are infuriating , those chant are pernicious , but when it come to the world & rsquo ; s reaction to Israel & rsquo ; s campaign against Hamas & ndash ; meaning the reaction of government to Israel & rsquo ; s action & ndash ; Israel & rsquo ; s situation vis-a-vis the government of the world is better this time than it wa during any of the previous round of violence with Hamas in Gaza . & nbsp ; US President Joe Biden and many other leader around the world have given Israel the & ldquo ; critical time we needed & rdquo ; to carry out this operation , former National Security Council head Yaakov Amidror said . & nbsp ; Biden , who ha come under pressure from within his own party , primarily from the progressive wing , to take a more active role and demand an immediate ceasefire , said on Wednesday during a call with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that he supported a ceasefire . Twenty-four hour later , in another call with Netanyahu , he said he & ldquo ; expected to see a significant de-escalation today on the path to a ceasefire . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; This wa after nine day of giving unstinting support to Israel for it right to defend itself , and blocking three different UN Security Council statement calling for an immediate halt to the fighting without mentioning Hamas or the rocket from Gaza . & nbsp ; Some have characterized Biden & rsquo ; s call that he expects a de-escalation a US pressure , others that it portends an imminent crisis in tie between the two leader and the two country . Amidror caution against hyperbole . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I don & rsquo ; t think there is pressure , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; I think that what the Americans are saying is that they want to see a ceasefire . But that is not pressure . They understand the need for Israel to complete the operation , they understand we are talking about a terrorist organization that crossed all redlines , opened fire on Israeli city . Therefore the administration gave u time . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I MAKE no pretense of understanding how America work , & rdquo ; said Amidror , a fellow at the Jerusalem Institute for Strategy and Security . & ldquo ; I look at what they have done , and what they have done up until now is to give u the time we needed . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Amidror said he wa not surprised by this , since the leadership in the Democratic Party & ndash ; & ldquo ; contrary to the perception here & rdquo ; & ndash ; still maintains & ldquo ; check and balance over the radical progressive element within the party that sometimes contains antisemitic element . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; What is ironic about Biden & rsquo ; s support is that it ha disappointed some on the Right , because it disrupts their narrative that Biden is a reincarnation of Barack Obama who will squeeze Israel at the first opportunity , and at the same time ha also disappointed some on the Left who would like to see much less support for Israel . & nbsp ; There are also Israeli domestic agenda at work among those who want to characterize Biden & rsquo ; s comment a & ldquo ; pressure . & rdquo ; Those politically opposed to Netanyahu would like to cast him now in the role a someone on a collision course with Biden and his administration , while the prime minister & rsquo ; s supporter are keen on painting a picture of perfect harmony between the two men who have known each other for nearly 40 year . & nbsp ; But there are objective standard against which to judge pressure to withdraw . Here & rsquo ; s one : In April 2002 , just nine day into Israel & rsquo ; s Operation Protective Shield aimed at crushing the terrorist infrastructure in the West Bank that wa responsible for hundred of death during the Second Intifada , president George W . Bush called on prime minister Ariel Sharon to withdraw IDF troop immediately from the Palestinian city they had moved into . & nbsp ; At a press conference in Crawford , Texas , Bush said , & ldquo ; My word to Israel are the same today a they were a couple of day ago : Withdraw without delay . & rdquo ; He added that he expected Israel to & ldquo ; heed my advice . & rdquo ; Sharon didn & rsquo ; t , the military campaign went on for another month , and US-Israel tie survived . & nbsp ; Biden & rsquo ; s expectation of de-escalation and support for a ceasefire doe not come near that Bush standard of rhetorical pressure . & nbsp ; AVIV SHIRON , a recently retired diplomat who previously served stint a Israel & rsquo ; s ambassador to the Netherlands , Austria and Switzerland , said that in comparison with other round of violence in Gaza in the past , & ldquo ; the international pressure this time is less significant and massive . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We have seen the new US president give full support to Israel & rsquo ; s right to defend itself , and did not demand an immediate ceasefire . Now he is calling for a ceasefire , but we are 11 day into the operation & ndash ; that is very significant . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Also inside the European Union , which is always more critical , there were more country this time that supported Israel & rsquo ; s right to defend itself , and did not demand a ceasefire . & rdquo ; He also pointed out that Israeli flag were flown atop government building in Germany , Austria , the Czech Republic and Slovenia a a sign of solidarity . & nbsp ; Shiron attributed this primarily to the fewer civilian casualty in Gaza than in the past . & ldquo ; The collateral damage is less , and we are seeing fewer picture of dead and injured and child , even though there are always civilian casualty . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The number of casualty in Gaza is less because the IDF and the air force have learned lesson from the past , and a a result pressure coming from various government is less , & rdquo ; he said . & nbsp ; Shiron maintained that anti-Israel protest on the street of London , Paris , Berlin and Washington always accompany this type of conflict , and that there is little difference in them this time around . As they continue , there will be more pressure on various government to speak out and take a stand , but & ldquo ; all in all thing are better than in previous time . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Hamas took advantage of existing tension in Jerusalem a it pretense for launching attack , and started the current campaign by firing at Jerusalem & ndash ; an act that succeeded in both playing on and building up passion of Muslims around the world , including among Israeli-Arabs , something Hamas certainly deems a & ldquo ; success . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; At the same time , however , Shiron said that firing on Jerusalem hurt Hamas in capital around the world . & ldquo ; When you fire on Jerusalem , a opposed to Sderot , it is perceived differently in the world . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Amidror , who agreed with Shiron that Europe ha largely given more support for Israel than in the past and allowed it to carry out it operation according to it own timeline , said there were three main reason for this degree of understanding among many world government . & nbsp ; First , he said , wa Israeli restraint over incident from Gaza in the week before Hamas fired rocket toward Jerusalem on May 10 . Second , is that it is clear to the government around the world who started the conflagration . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; And the third thing is that they are shooting at civilian target , while everyone understands we are shooting at military one , & rdquo ; Amidror said . & ldquo ; Sometimes we err and civilian are killed , but our intent & ndash ; and the direction of our fire & ndash ; is toward military target , while they are shooting at civilian from among civilian . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Amidror said that even those critical of recent Israeli action in Jerusalem , such a effort to evict four family from Sheikh Jarrah and police activity during Ramadan at the Damascus Gate , understand that there are huge gap between the claim of Israeli error in this matter and the response . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; There is disproportionality between the claim against u , and the reaction . For the sake of argument , let & rsquo ; s say that they were right , that our behavior could have been gentler in Jerusalem . Does that justify rocket on Jerusalem and Tel Aviv ? There is tremendous disproportionality . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; But that disproportionality & ldquo ; play into our hand , & rdquo ; Amidror said , a & ldquo ; reasonable people understand that a terrorist organization took advantage of the situation to fire on civilian . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; While Amidror maintained that the reaction of much of the world overall ha not been overly bad , including Russia , China is an exception . There the overseas channel of state broadcaster CCTV aired a report shot-full with antisemitic trope . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; . . . . Some people believe that US pro-Israeli policy is traceable to the influence of wealthy Jews in the US and the Jewish lobby on US foreign policy-makers , & rdquo ; said host Zheng Junfeng , asking his audience whether US support for Israel wa truly based on shared value . & ldquo ; Jews dominate finance and Internet sector . So do they have the powerful lobby some say ? Possible . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Amidror took umbrage . & ldquo ; There is a big difference between being for a ceasefire and antisemitic claim , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; As someone who very much value the relationship with China , it pain me to see antisemitic claim in China compete with the antisemitic argument of [ Turkish President Recep Tayyip ] Erdogan . This is beneath China . & rdquo ;

Body Text: Two rocket were fired at Israel from the Gaza Strip , one week apart from each other . While the IDF shrugged off the first , blaming it on bad weather , it & rsquo ; s now clear . It wa not a mistake . It wa a message . Hamas is under pressure , and it & rsquo ; s getting worse . The coronavirus pandemic is wreaking havoc in the blockaded enclave , and Hamas & ndash ; which is in no mood for conflict with Israel & ndash ; tends to send message in the form of incendiary balloon or rocket when it is under pressure and need aid . Though the group wa able to effectively deal with the deadly virus during the first wave , the blockaded coastal enclave is suffering from a harsh second wave of the coronavirus , with more than 5,517 total case and 65 death , the majority since September . The Strip & rsquo ; s weak healthcare infrastructure , with fewer than 3,000 bed , is unable to cope with all the sick , and is also seeing a record number of daily new case & ndash ; on Saturday alone the Health Ministry said there were 891 new case . Fathi Abu Warda , adviser to the Palestinian health minister in Gaza , wa quoted by Wafa news agency a saying on Sunday that there wa an & ldquo ; unprecedented hike & rdquo ; in the number of case and that the European Hospital in Khan Yunis in the south of the Gaza Strip ha reached it limit in receiving coronavirus case . Thanks to the international aid Israel ha let into the Strip , Hamas ha been able to increase it testing capability from 200 a day during the first wave to 3,500 a day , and the number of ventilator ha risen to 160 . Abu Warda also said two truckloads of & ldquo ; urgent medical aid , & rdquo ; including respirator and medication for those with chronic illness , will enter the Strip in the coming day . But it & rsquo ; s still not enough . In addition to the coronavirus crisis , the economy is still a disaster & ndash ; with the unemployment rate in Gaza close to 50 % , with those who are employed earning close to nothing . The average monthly income ha fallen from $ 244 to $ 29 since March . Israel & rsquo ; s defense establishment and Southern Command have warned several time that there is a direct link between a worsening economy and rocket fire or incendiary balloon . Hamas is also becoming further isolated , including from the Palestinian Authority , which recently resumed security cooperation with Israel following the victory of US President-elect Joe Biden . Following the resumption of security tie , Palestinian security force in the West Bank are expected to renew their arrest of Hamas operative in the territory . The normalization of tie between Israel and Gulf state ha also placed a strain on Hamas . And that , the IDF fear , will lead to closer tie with Israel & rsquo ; s enemy on it northern border & ndash ; Hezbollah . Already following the deal with the United Arab Emirates , Ismail Haniyeh , who head Hamas & rsquo ; s political bureau , met with Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah in Beirut . There have been more than a dozen round of violent clash between the IDF and terror group since 2018 , with thousand of rocket fired toward Israel and thousand of Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad target struck by the Israel Air Force in retaliation . But all of them ended without any tangible solution , leading the IDF to change it concept toward a new approach , called & ldquo ; Southern Wind , & rdquo ; which would use higher-quality intelligence and firepower to shorten the length of an operation . A new concept is all fine and dandy , but when push come to shove and a large-scale military operation take place , neither side will end up a a winner . You just have to look at the recent history of the military operation in the Gaza Strip where nothing changed , except that both side experienced more death and destruction . So why did the IDF echo Hamas & rsquo ; s lightning excuse when two rocket were fired toward central Israel ? Neither side want a large-scale military operation , and the IDF belief that Yahya Sinwar , Hamas & rsquo ; s leader in the Strip , a well a the head of it military wing , Mohammed Deif , still prefer to follow the status quo and avoid confrontation with the IDF . The rocket fired by Hamas are a message sent by Sinwar , a message that ha been received and understood by Israel before . The pressure is rising and something need to be done before the situation explodes . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ;

Body Text: The armed wing of Hamas , Izz al-Din al-Qassam Brigades , published on Tuesday a dog tag it claimed it member snatched from an IDF soldier during the 2014 Operation Protective Edge with Israel.The group did not provide further detail about the dog tag , which carried the name of the Givati Brigade . & ldquo ; We won & rsquo ; t talk much about this tag ; the command of the enemy & rsquo ; s army know well who this tag belongs to , & rdquo ; the group said . & nbsp ; The publication of the dog tag came on the ninth anniversary of the abduction of IDF soldier Hadar Goldin during the operation . Body Text: & nbsp ; Delegates to the 16th Socialist International were milling about the Montechoro Hotel & rsquo ; s lobby in Albufeira , a sleepy resort town off of Portugal & rsquo ; s Algarve coast , when a gunman nailed five bullet into Palestinian cardiologist Isam Sartawi & rsquo ; s chest and head . & nbsp ; The assassin vanished under a hail of police bullet . His target , the first PLO leader to advocate recognition of Israel , and also to openly hold talk with Israelis , wa soon pronounced dead , along with his message . & nbsp ; Sartawi & rsquo ; s Israeli interlocutor came from the thick Left , people like Maj . - Gen . ( re . ) Matti Peled and former Labor Party secretary-general Arieh Eliav , but when shot he wa but one wall away from Shimon Peres , who would become prime minister the following year . & nbsp ; Rumors of a planned meeting between the two were probably unfounded , but to the assailant & ndash ; the Abu-Nidal terrorist group & ndash ; that didn & rsquo ; t matter ; Sartawi spoke peace , and that made him anathema and his death foretold . & nbsp ; It wa part of a pattern , one that neither began nor ended on that sorry day in April 1983 , and in fact lace Israel & rsquo ; s history almost from it birth to these very day of awe ; day which make many assume fatalistically that peace-killers will always defeat the peacemaker . Well they haven & rsquo ; t , and they won & rsquo ; t . & nbsp ; THE FIRST of the peacemaker to fall in the line of duty wa Jordan & rsquo ; s King Abdullah , who wa shot in 1951 at the Mosque of Omar & rsquo ; s entrance after holding secret talk with David Ben-Gurion & rsquo ; s emissary . & nbsp ; Two year before Sartawi & rsquo ; s murder , Anwar Sadat wa mowed down by four Islamist gunman who emerged from a truck during a military parade and emptied their Kalashnikovs at the presidential podium killing , besides Sadat , another 10 men . The young peace treaty with Israel , though only part of a broader Islamist agenda , wa a key element in the squad & rsquo ; s motivation . & nbsp ; The following year Lebanese president-elect Bashir Gemayel , who had been dialoguing with Israel for a while and wa widely expected to make peace with Menachem Begin , wa blown up along with 26 others during a political meeting in Beirut . The assassin , widely believed to have been activated by Syrian agent , cited the alliance with Israel a the cause of his act . & nbsp ; The common denominator among all these assault is the belief that Arab-Jewish peace , no matter how limited or embryonic , is an abomination that must be nipped in the bud . & nbsp ; Now this history is once again at play ; not in Hamas & rsquo ; s quest to fight & ndash ; that & rsquo ; s a given that need no pretext & ndash ; but in it timing . Hamas could have started this round of violence long before or well after this month . What made it press the trigger wa Israel & rsquo ; s first-ever Arab-Jewish coalition agreement , which wa but several day away from being signed . & nbsp ; The extraordinary Bennett-Abbas-Lapid government wa set to inspire a great Arab-Jewish reconciliation , a prospect that from the viewpoint of Hamas wa intolerable . Like Sartawi & rsquo ; s evolving dialogue and like Gemayel & rsquo ; s burgeoning peace & ndash ; it had to be preempted . Hence the rush , scope , and total abandonment of measure with which Hamas unleashed it wrath . & nbsp ; Time will tell to what extent the fighting & rsquo ; s spillover to Israel & rsquo ; s mixed town wa micromanaged by Hamas operative . However , it is clear already now that the rampage in Lod , Acre and Jaffa served Hamas well , and that whether or not they were conducted from Gaza they were clearly incited from there . & nbsp ; Worse , in term of it immediate aim the ploy worked . The breathtaking move Naftali Bennett had already introduced with the inspiring statement that & ldquo ; a broad government is not a default , it & rsquo ; s an aim , & rdquo ; wa summarily shelved . & nbsp ; Like that peace with Lebanon & rsquo ; s elected president which Israel wa already touching and smelling only to see him and his gospel murdered , the great reconciliation that Bennett and Mansour Abbas seemed ready to launch wa trampled , overnight , by thug who lynched pedestrian , shattered storefront , and torched synagogue . & nbsp ; The question this plunge from utopia to dystopia raise is therefore this : Can peace survive it murder ? & nbsp ; STRATEGIC SURPRISES are good at what they announce & ndash ; surprise & ndash ; but their planner often fail to plan for what their surprise uncork . & nbsp ; Hitler & rsquo ; s invasion of the Soviet Union , Japan & rsquo ; s attack on Pearl Harbor and Egypt & rsquo ; s crossing of the Suez Canal were stunning . All three , however , were ultimately defeated . Hamas & rsquo ; s strategic surprise is headed the same way . & nbsp ; The Germans disparaged the Russians & rsquo ; industrial ability , the Japanese underestimated America & rsquo ; s fighting spirit , the Egyptians didn & rsquo ; t calculate Israeli improvisation , and Hamas doesn & rsquo ; t understand what the sight of a torched synagogue doe to a Jew , any Jew , even a leftist , an agnostic or a convert . & nbsp ; On this front the counterattack is already underway , with hundred of arrest that will be followed by harsh indictment that will produce lengthy jail term . & nbsp ; Equally swift will be the physical restoration that the peace-murderers & rsquo ; carnage demand . It will take month , but every ruined synagogue , hotel , restaurant and shop will be repaired , a will all the vandalized park , playground , plaza and bus stop , not to mention ransacked police station . & nbsp ; Much more difficult will be the rehabilitation of the surprise attack & rsquo ; s big target : communal relation that were built over generation . & nbsp ; Yes , the struggle ahead of u is daunting , the civic version of defending Stalingrad and wresting Iwo Jima , but like those battle , it will end in evil & rsquo ; s defeat . & nbsp ; Anwar Sadat wa murdered , but the peace he struck survived him , and life to this day . & nbsp ; Mansour Abbas & rsquo ; s emergence in an Israeli coalition ha apparently been derailed , but he still showed up at the burnt Beit Yisrael Synagogue and , with Lod Mayor Yair Revivo ( Likud ) alongside him , denounced the arson a anti-Islamic and vowed to participate in it reconstruction . & nbsp ; Yes , the Arab-Jewish coalition which Middle Israelis crave , the situation begs , and nearly half the Arab electorate endorsed & ndash ; is dead . Body Text: Hamas ha been dealt a heavy blow after severely miscalculating the Israeli response to it rocket attack , analyst believe . Hamas and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad have so far lobbed nearly 4,000 rocket from Gaza into Israeli territory in less than two week . Israel & rsquo ; s Iron Dome missile defense system ha successfully managed to intercept the majority of these in midair . & nbsp ; Nevertheless , 12 Israelis have been killed and hundred more injured . & nbsp ; On the Palestinian side , some 219 people have been killed in the ongoing flare-up , according to Gaza & rsquo ; s health ministry . Of those , Israel ha said that at least 150 were combatant . & nbsp ; According to Dr . Harel Chorev , an expert on Palestinian affair and head of the Network Analysis Desk at Tel Aviv University & rsquo ; s Moshe Dayan Center , Hamas ha suffered significant loss during this round of fighting . & ldquo ; Hamas lost in every strategic calculation : Many of their tunnel in the Strip are destroyed and their maritime force are also paralyzed , & rdquo ; Chorev told The Media Line . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Since the damage is very high , this will be a lesson that Hamas will take into account . Unlike in 2014 [ during ] Operation Protective Edge , they were not ready . & rdquo ; Israel pummelled a network of underground tunnel in the Palestinian enclave that were being used to hide rocket and launcher . IDF spokesperson Brig . Gen . Hadai Zilberman on Wednesday said that Israeli Air Force plane had targeted 15 km ( roughly 9 mile ) of tunnel , dropping 122 bomb on the southern Gaza Strip overnight on Tuesday . & nbsp ; When Hamas initially began launching rocket into Israel last week , they mistakenly believed that the fighting would only last a day or two , Chorev said . & ldquo ; It will be very hard for them to recover their underground infrastructure , & rdquo ; he stated . & ldquo ; They thought that it would be inconvenient for [ Israeli Prime Minister Binyamin ] Netanyahu to attack now , which is quite the opposite . It wa quite good for him , politically . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Hamas & rsquo ; ongoing strategy , he added , relies on a combination of guerrilla tactic and more traditional military weaponry like rocket and mortar . While Israel ha been mostly successful at countering the group & rsquo ; s rocket and ha efficiently targeted fighter in Gaza without needing to send in ground force , Hamas ha also notched a few surprising victory of it own . Namely , in helping to stoke the division between Arab and Jewish Israelis across Israel . The rioting and unrest recently seen in several town and city , Chorev argued , & ldquo ; is the main asset of Hamas and they are totally surprised by it and trying to inflame [ the situation ] more and more . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The Islamist group , which run the Gaza Strip , ha also managed to score a few point in other key strategic area , including undermining the Palestinian Authority , which recently called off general election in the West Bank . In addition , they succeeded in putting the international spotlight on the Palestinian issue . In term of firepower , Hamas ha also advanced , according to a former Israeli counterterrorism chief . & ldquo ; Naturally , when the pace of [ rocket launch ] is greater and the warhead is larger , then the damage is more significant , & rdquo ; Brig . Gen . ( Res ) Nitzan Nuriel , a fellow at the International Institute for Counter-Terrorism at the Interdisciplinary Center in Herzliya , told The Media Line . & nbsp ; Nuriel , a former director of Israel & rsquo ; s Counter-Terrorism Bureau , pointed to Hamas recently devising a system that can launch multiple rocket at a time . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Their missile capability & ndash ; from the size to the range and the warhead dimension & ndash ; in all of these area Hamas ha improved , & rdquo ; Nuriel said . & ldquo ; They & rsquo ; ve improved thanks to Iranian know-how a well a through experimentation . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Many of the material the group us to manufacture their weapon come through the Rafah Border Crossing , located between Egypt and the Gaza Strip . Some of these are standard construction material , like pipe . & ldquo ; The Egyptian system is not a hermetically sealed a our [ blockade ] is , so I am guessing that Hamas is managing to smuggle in material through the Rafah crossing , & rdquo ; Nuriel said . & ldquo ; Ten percent of the pipe entering the Strip are turned into rocket or else the metal is melted down in order to be recast into a relevant shape . & rdquo ; Daniel Sonnenfeld contributed to this report .
title: hamas dealt heavy blow , ‘ surprised ’ by israeli response , analyst say

They preach Jewish supremacy and work to deepen the occupation . They seek to widen the divide and sow hatred between the Palestinian and Israeli people . & rdquo ; Yusra Mahfouz from Nablus , whose son wa killed by a stray bullet in 2000 , said : & ldquo ; In the first day after I lost my son , I felt the need to take revenge , until one day people from the Parents-Circle Families Forum came to u . Body Text: Chen Peiper , born in the Netherlands , is an esteemed Israeli jewelry designer and teacher , and over the last two decade ha been a glass sculptor .
