Just a we were about to begin our trip , some people told u there wa a war in Israel . Then , we wanted to make aliyah even faster.The war didn & rsquo ; t stop you from this move ? No , when you want to live in a country , a war is not a reason to go away . You stay here ; you don & rsquo ; t leave the country because of a war.And why did you want to make aliyah in the first place ? My husband is Israeli , born in Tel Aviv . He ha lived in Holland for 10 year , and we met at the Academy of Art . We could have stayed in Holland , but it wa clear to u that we could not live in both country , and we decided that we wanted to live in Israel . & nbsp ; Following this decision , you arrived in the middle of the Yom Kippur War . . . It happened like that . We moved in with Gidi & rsquo ; s , my husband & rsquo ; s , parent in Ramat Hasharon , which made thing much easier . & nbsp ; How wa Israel back then ? How do you remember Israel during the Yom Kippur War ? Cities without men . Tel Aviv , Hod Hasharon , completely without men . For a few month , it wa like that . Life wa quieter . There wa nobody on the street . It wa a real war for u in the center of Israel . Now during the war people continue their life , shop are open , and people are sitting at coffee shop ; back then , the street were empty . But also the street looked different . Now everything is modern ; in 1973 there were cloud of sand on the road of Ramat Hasharon.And how different wa the society of Israel back then in comparison to today & rsquo ; s ? It & rsquo ; s hard for me to say . I jumped into the group of Gidi & rsquo ; s friend . They all were in the army and all talked about the army , so it wa difficult . And they were shy to speak in English to me at that time.But in general , you could have visited a friend or a neighbor anytime . Now you must call or text to set up a visit . [ Back then , ] the door to the apartment were always open . & nbsp ; From what you are saying , it sound like people were closer to each other . As we speak , I & rsquo ; ve just realized that you and the State of Israel are almost the same age . Since 1973 , the very young state of 25 year and you , almost 27 year old , a peer you grew up together.I have never thought of this , but this is true , yes . [ She laugh . ] And after the Yom Kippur War , how do you recall Israel ? We all worked very hard . We wanted to build something , and we felt we did . & nbsp ; Do you mean your life or also Israel ? Also Israel . & nbsp ; So after the war , you started to work in your profession , a a jewelry designer ? Yes , at home . People have come especially to me . I looked at how a person behaved and what he [ or she ] liked , and based on that I wa designing . & nbsp ; Before shifting to glass sculpture ( which is your main focus right now ) , for 40 year you were creating jewelry , showing it at professional exhibition in the Netherlands , Israel , and the US , and you were also teaching how to design . & nbsp ; Yes , I taught design at a technology center for jewelry in Tel Aviv ( 1985-1995 ) , and in 1993 at a special program for Bedouin girl and young woman who were making traditional Bedouin jewelry but wanted to learn about other approach ; and ( in the year 1990-2000 ) at Beit Berl art college in Ramat Hasharon , where I wa head of the jewelry department . & nbsp ; So you had an established professional position , and suddenly in 2002 you went to Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design to study glass design . What triggered that ? I wa looking , for a long time , for something else . I hoped that if I had another material , it would be more interesting for me and more creative.My husband , who ha been always very supportive of me , saw in a newspaper that there wa an opening of a new department of glass , a a second degree , at Bezalel . I applied and got accepted.It wa two year of hard work , but it wa very interesting to me to learn various technique of working with glass . It wa wonderful , in the middle of my life to start with a new material ! But I have never forgotten about my metal . The metal always help me to design the inside of the glass . It add the feeling . I have combined it with glass.What attracts you to glass ? It can be transparent and doesn & rsquo ; t have to . You can do everything with it , move it in all the direction you want to . Another thing , jewelry is also art , but when you create in gold it is [ displayed ] in a glass box ; people can & rsquo ; t touch it . And I like it when people can touch a sculpture . & nbsp ; It change the experience of the viewer . With your art you reflect on your personal experience , but also on group and social exposure , such a war , the issue of African refugee , or the pandemic . In 2022 , at the Venice Art Bienniale , you showed [ the installation ] Covitrum ( COVID and vitro , & lsquo ; glass & rsquo ; in Latin ) , a series of glass sculpture & ndash ; unrecognizable portrait , without distinction in gender or skin color . These face were covered with different mask worn during the pandemic.Yes , the only distinction wa that I made 13 adult and five child ( representing my five grandchild ) , together 18 . I chose this number because of it gematria ; the number 18 mean chai & ndash ; & lsquo ; life , & rsquo ; in Hebrew . & nbsp ; Why did you want to incorporate a number important in Judaism , in a way taking away from the universality of this project ? It wa very important to me because it is a very powerful number . Each head wa covered with a different mask . In these mask I put the story . A mask is a tool of pretense and protection , and it allows introspection . It give a space to reveal or hide the identity and feeling . One of them wa transparent , and I called it & lsquo ; Read my lip . & rsquo ; But there wa also the Israeli flag , the Venice flag , and a rainbow LGBTQ flag mask . & nbsp ; On view in Italy , there wa also your sculpture Refugees , dedicated to people who fled their country across the sea in inhuman condition . A huge unresolved issue of African emigrant often losing their life on the way to Europe wa expressed in your powerful sculpture.I wanted to show the color of the sky and the sea and , in between , human being . The sea wa their last refuge . They were mostly Black people , so I used the color black and red ( a blood ) . You can see that they are all on the boat , but one is outside & ndash ; didn & rsquo ; t make it . & nbsp ; You responded to this tragic reality with extreme sensitivity . Your latest sculpture are also very socially engaged . In December 2023 , at a group exhibition & lsquo ; The Colors of Camouflage , & rsquo ; at the Periscope Gallery in Tel Aviv , you presented two series of work : & lsquo ; Upside Down , & rsquo ; in camouflage military color , and & lsquo ; New Life , & rsquo ; with motif of Israeli flag in glass , flowing in different shape . In both case , you & rsquo ; ve connected a very smooth and elegant movement of glass attached to very simple and basic metal food can . What wa the idea behind this concept ? And did you make this series of sculpture before the war or during the current war ? I started before the war . During the war , my feeling about it were even stronger . I am very connected to my grandson , what they do.Do they serve in the army now ? Yes , three of them . I am very proud of them . & nbsp ; So the color came from your grandson ? Yes , although not directly . I wa worried , in general . The flag , at first , were connected to the last year & rsquo ; s demonstration in Israel . I wanted to show the sadness of thousand of people being with a flag during the protest . I wa concerned about what would be with this country and what wa going on . I am still , I am worried.What do think will be with Israel ? & nbsp ; The future will not be easy . But I think that we are very strong , and we have to be very strong . & nbsp ; We are talking after many month of war , and you are wearing a & lsquo ; Bring Them Home & rsquo ; necklace [ in solidarity with the hostage ] , and you are still saying that we are very strong ? This is a very scary and ugly fairy tale . But , of course , we are very strong ! Otherwise , we & ndash ; you and me & ndash ; would not be here today.So how do you see the future of Israel now , also with the new wave of antisemitism around the world ? When I listen to my daughter , Tamar and Dafna , they are worried . When I listen to my grandson , they are full of life and they believe that everything will be fine . & nbsp ; Why did you connect flag with simple can ? They are real can , reused . By adding a flag to them , there is something new , and maybe there will be something new in the region , not the same a it wa before.Whatever happens in Israel , I express it in my art , both my jewelry and glass sculpture . But the first reason why I used the can wa practical & ndash ; the metal [ material ] and it form . Then I realized that I could use different shape of can , which gave me new feelings.When I saw these sculpture at the exhibition , looking at the Israeli flag made of glass , I thought that this wa Zionist art . Is it okay to call your art Zionist ? I am very pleased to hear it ! Do you think there is a place for something like Zionist art , that the Israeli artist will want to go in this direction ? This is interesting , what you are asking . When I look back at the exhibition ( and this is very important , to look back and check with yourself what you did ) , I ask myself if it wa only the obsession of flag . But it wasn & rsquo ; t . In every piece , I put my feeling inside . & nbsp ; How would you name these feeling ? New life . ■ On April 18 at 7 p.m . , at Beit Yad LaBanim cultural center , 2 Hamahteret Street , Ramat Hasharon , a group show will open which will include one of Peiper & rsquo ; s new work , View of Israel . & nbsp ; The artist & rsquo ; s website : chenpeiper2.wixsite.com/chen
title: the flag in focus : zionist art

Body Text: As tension escalated along the Gaza border with retaliatory airstrikes in response to a rocket fired on Monday evening , all 13-year-old Libi Kohn of Ein Hashlosha wanted wa for there to be calm , so her kibbutz youth group could hold it planned gathering in the evening . & ldquo ; I just mostly hope that this won & rsquo ; t develop into anything , and we can go on with our activity and I can meet with my friend , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; We asked our counselor whether it would be canceled , and he said he didn & rsquo ; t know yet . So we are waiting . I want the Passover vacation to be like it should be where I can enjoy it with friend . & rdquo ; The rocket fired from Gaza followed tension in Jerusalem , a dozen of Palestinian rioter were injured and hundred arrested following violent clash with police on the Temple Mount.The sound of siren ha been so much a part of Kohn & rsquo ; s life that she didn & rsquo ; t know if she could really use the word & ldquo ; fear & rdquo ; to describe how she felt when she heard the red alert phone application beep , when a rocket wa launched at her kibbutz just a she wa sitting down to dinner with her family at her grandparent & rsquo ; home at around 8:30 p.m . & ldquo ; We heard the red alert for Kissufim , and at first didn & rsquo ; t understand what wa happening , & rdquo ; said Kohn . & ldquo ; Then we heard a loud boom and ran to the bomb shelter in the house . & rdquo ; The whole family had gathered for dinner , 16 people altogether . & ldquo ; We let my grandmother go in first so she could sit down , and then we the grandchild went in . & rdquo ; The rocket wa intercepted by the Iron Dome missile-defense system . There were no report of injuries.After the all-clear , they returned to the dinner table . At night they closed the metal window on the bomb shelter , which is also Libi & rsquo ; s bedroom , and made sure there wa a clear path to the room in case the family needed to reach it in the middle of the night . & ldquo ; I want the government to create a situation where we don & rsquo ; t have to pay for the situation every Passover , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; We want the government to make u feel safe so we don & rsquo ; t have to pack a suitcase all the time and run . I don & rsquo ; t know how they should do that , but the nation voted for them and it is time that they do that . & rdquo ; There are no magical solution to the situation , said Libi & rsquo ; s mother , Meirav , 49 , who wa born in Ein Hashlosha . & ldquo ; You never know when or where it will come , but we understand that with everything that is happening in Jerusalem , we will end up paying the price , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; When the security situation heat up , it will end up reaching Gaza . & rdquo ; FOR THE most part , the Kohns enjoy a quality of life that make up for the occasional missile they have to contend with . & ldquo ; I am sure this is where I want my kid to grow up , even if sometimes we have these & rdquo ; attack , said Meirav.But the government should reach a comprehensive solution once and for all , she said , even if that mean an initial military operation to get both side to the negotiating table.Almost 4,400 rocket were fired at Israel from Gaza in May & rsquo ; s 11-day war , Operation Guardians of the Wall , in which 256 Palestinians and 13 Israelis were killed . In 2014 , Operation Protective Edge lasted six week and some 2,100 Palestinians were killed , including 1,462 civilian . Sixty-six Israeli soldier and seven Israeli citizen were also killed . Operation Pillar of Defense in 2012 left 167 Palestinians , including 87 civilian , and two Israeli soldier and four civilian dead , according to B & rsquo ; Tselem . & ldquo ; It is obviously a very challenging situation for all the government , also for the last government , & rdquo ; Meirav said . & ldquo ; Before we reach a solution we need a serious military operation , but at the same time , if we keep doing the same thing all the time , nothing will change . I do expect the government to be ready after the next war for the day after , and to come with clear goal and to sit and talk and come to an agreement for the last time & ndash ; not to just come , reach a ceasefire agreement , and then go home . & rdquo ; Sirens were also activated on Sunday afternoon in Nahal Oz . The IDF later said they were false alarms.However , 67-year-old Adele Raemer , who ha lived on Kibbutz Nirim since 1975 , said Israeli resident living along the Gaza border know there is no such thing a a false alarm . & ldquo ; A false alarm mean something wa shot at u from Gaza and didn & rsquo ; t reach the border , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; So two day ago after the & lsquo ; false alarm , & rsquo ; we knew something could happen . We have been getting rocket since 2006 . This is not something anybody get used to but is something you learn to live with . Everyone is aware and ready . We know how to sense an escalation . & rdquo ; With Ramadan coinciding with Passover , and with Israeli Independence Day and Yom Hazikaron coming up , it can become a & ldquo ; prime time for terror , & rdquo ; she said.However , Raemer noted , most Gaza resident do not want an escalation now with an increase of work permit being issued by Israel and Egypt , sending expert to help them rebuild the infrastructure destroyed in last year & rsquo ; s war . & ldquo ; That is something they don & rsquo ; t want to lose , & rdquo ; she said.And while Islamic Jihad ha been held responsible for the latest rocket attack , it is Hamas that control Gaza and need to be accountable . & ldquo ; We are the strong one here , and I would really prefer that we don & rsquo ; t do thing that can be seen a inflammatory , & rdquo ; Raemer said . & ldquo ; I understand we want to say this is our land , and people have the right of freedom of expression , but we have to take responsibility for our action . & rdquo ; Raemer mentioned the planned flag march by the Im Tirzu NGO . & ldquo ; Going out on a march just to beat our chest can have an effect on the rest of our country , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; I hope people will keep their head on straight and not do something that will be inflammatory . & rdquo ;
title: for israeli living by gaza , life amid tension is 99 % heaven , 1 % hell

Body Text: In a statement on Monday , Jerusalem Chief Rabbi Shlomo Moshe Amar called on the public not to publicly celebrate Mimouna due to the war.Mimouna is a holiday celebrated the day after the end of the Passover holiday and originates with North African Jews ; this year , it will be celebrated on April 30.The holiday quickly spread to other group in Israel and is now celebrated across different heritage groups.Celebrations often take the shape of open house party with a wide variety of food ; guest are expected to go from house to house , celebrating with each household , although this is less common in modern times.Politicians quickly picked up on this and began attending and publicizing their attendance at Mimouna parties.Rabbi Amar previously served a the Israeli Sephardi Chief Rabbi from 2003 to 2013 , and shortly after finishing his term , became Chief Rabbi of Jerusalem in 2014 . `` Since we are already past the holiday , it is not appropriate for u to celebrate in public with drum and dancing when so many of our brother are hostage and wounded , `` he said in the message . `` We will dedicate this night to strengthening ourselves by studying book of faith and security . We will thank the Holy One , blessed be He , for all His grace , and ask for a speedy future redemption of the people of Israel . `` A break with traditionRabbi Amar used to hold a public Mimouna event every year with rabbi and public figure , but this year , he canceled it.A Walla report published on Sunday indicates that the top leadership of the country , who have traditionally been guest of honor at the celebration of their activist and supporter throughout the country , are not expected to participate this year . & nbsp ; Speaker of the Knesset Amir Ohana , last year even held an open Mimouna event in the Knesset building for the first time , but this year doe not intend to celebrate publicly.The head of the opposition , Yair Lapid , the National Unity Party head , Benny Gantz , a well a the Yisrael Beytenu head , Avigdor Lieberman , are also not expected to celebrate this year . `` What is there to celebrate these day ? `` wa the common response to the inquiry .
title: jerusalem chief rabbi shlomo amar call for mimouna to be canceled this year due to the war

Body Text: Palestinian official on Tuesday expressed hope that a new Israeli general election will not disrupt Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas & rsquo ; s initiative to convene an international conference for peace in the Middle East early next year . The official , who were responding to news about the possibility that Israel may be headed toward it fourth election in March 2021 , also expressed hope that the vote would result in an end to the era of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu . In October , Abbas sent a letter to United Nations Secretary-General Ant & oacute ; nio Guterres , urging him to hold pressing consultation in coordination with the Middle East Quartet ( US , UN , Russia and European Union ) and the UN Security Council on convening an international conference & ldquo ; with full power and with the participation of all concerned party . & rdquo ; The Palestinians believe the prospect of holding the proposed conference have grown after the victory of US President-elect Joe Biden in the US presidential election . & ldquo ; The purpose of the international conference is to revive the two-state solution after Netanyahu and [ outgoing US President Donald ] Trump did everything to destroy that option , & rdquo ; a Palestinian official told The Jerusalem Post . & ldquo ; We are confident that once Trump is out of the White House , we will go back to the two-state solution . We also hope that Israeli voter , when they go to cast their ballot , would understand that Netanyahu and his government are harming Israeli interest by rejecting the two-state solution . & rdquo ; However , the official said the Palestinians were concerned that new election in Israel would delay or divert attention from Abbas & rsquo ; s plan to hold an international peace conference . & ldquo ; If Netanyahu win again , we expect the Biden administration and the international conference to take real and serious measure to compel Israel to adhere to international resolution pertaining to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict , especially Security Council Resolution 2334 , which call for an end to Israeli settlement activity , & rdquo ; the official said . While the Palestinians do not meddle in the internal affair of Israel , another Palestinian official told the Post , they nevertheless would & ldquo ; like to see Israelis vote for candidate who believe in a genuine peace process with the Palestinian people . & rdquo ; The past four year of the Trump administration & ldquo ; have been very bad for the Palestinians and the peace process , & rdquo ; the official said . & ldquo ; We hope Israeli voter would be a clever a the Americans who said no to four more year of the Trump administration . & rdquo ; He , too , expressed concern that new election in Israel would & ldquo ; hinder & rdquo ; Abbas & rsquo ; s international conference idea . & ldquo ; The election will undoubtedly delay our effort to hold the conference , but this will only be a temporary postponement , & rdquo ; the official said . & ldquo ; We are optimistic that a Biden administration will endorse the international conference initiative , even if Netanyahu is reelected . & rdquo ; On Tuesday , Abbas won the backing of Russian President Vladimir Putin for the proposed international parley . Moscow support holding an international peace conference and achieving peace and stability in the region on the basis of UN resolution and international law , Putin reportedly told Abbas during a phone conversation , according to a statement published by WAFA , the PA & rsquo ; s official news agency .
title: palestinian hope new election will ‘ end netanyahu era ’

Body Text: Thousands of right-wing activist marched Tuesday to Homesh to stake their claim to the remote West Bank hilltop that Israel abandoned 17-years ago , despite heavy criticism from the Left for stoking tension with the Palestinians . `` We came to commit to settling all area of the Land of Israel , `` said MK Bezalel Smotrich.Those at the march demanded that the government authorize the Homesh yeshiva , which is illegally located on the hilltop and to rebuild the Homesh settlement that wa destroyed in 2005 after the Gaza pullout.Smotrich , who head the Religious Zionist Party , is among those politician who want to see an all right-wing government replace the existing coalition made up of party on the Right , Center , and Left of the political map , including the Israeli-Arab party Ra'am . & nbsp ; `` I have no expectation from this government that ha surrendered to Islam , `` said Smotrich.A march make it way by the West Bank settlement of Homesh ( Credit : Samaria Regional Council ) The Homesh march sparked clash at the entryway to the Burqa and Bazaria village in northern Samaria , in which score of Palestinians were injured , including 11 with rubber bullet , according to the Palestinian news agency WAFA.Settlers and the Right have been braced for the IDF to evacuate the yeshiva.Samaria Regional Council head Yossi Dagan said that `` the thousand who came here today , did so to give a message to the government . Do n't touch Homesh . `` & nbsp ; The IDF `` must stop with the eviction and the checkpoint , `` he said adding that the `` nation is with Homesh `` and pledged `` we will rebuild it `` along with the settlement of Sa-Nur which wa also destroyed in 2005 . `` A government that abandon both the Negev and Homesh will be replaced with a government worthy of the people of Israel - a full right-wing government , `` Dagan said.MK Idit Silman ( Yamina ) who sparked a political crisis when she resigned from the coalition earlier this month , also participated in the march.Other participant in the march included relative of terror victim from Homesh , including yeshiva student Yehuda Dimentman , 25 , who wa killed by a Palestinian gunman in December , and & nbsp ; Shalom `` Shuli `` Har-Melekh , 25.A resident of the former Homesh settlement , Har-Melekh wa killed by a Palestinian gunman in a drive-by-shooting near Ramallah in 2003 .
title: israeli march to west bank 's homesh , amid tension with palestinian

Body Text: A European Commissioner on Monday said EU humanitarian aid to Palestinians will continue , after another commissioner said another type of aid wa being reviewed and suspended a a result of Hamas ' attack on Israel.Crisis Management Commissioner Janez Lenarcic said he `` most strongly `` condemned the attack but `` it is imperative to protect civilian . `` `` EU humanitarian aid to # Palestinians in need will continue a long a needed , `` he said on social media.His announcement came after Oliver Varhelyi , the European Commissioner for Neighbourhood and Enlargement , said the Commission wa putting it entire portfolio of development aid for Palestinians under review and suspending payments.A brief pause in fundingThe European Commission said on Monday it wa putting all it development aid to Palestinians , worth 691 million euro ( $ 729 million ) , under review and immediately suspending all payment following Hamas ' attack on Israel . `` The scale of terror and brutality against Israel and it people is a turning point , `` Oliver Varhelyi , the European Commissioner for Neighbourhood and Enlargement , said in a post on social medium . `` There can be no business a usual . `` Hamas militant killed 700 Israelis and abducted dozen in the deadliest such incursion since the Yom Kippur war 50 year ago , prompting Israel to retaliate with it heaviest ever bombardment of Gaza , which ha killed more than 400 people.New budget proposal on holdVarhelyi said all new budget proposal for Palestinian aid were also postponed until further notice . `` The foundation for peace , tolerance and co-existence must now be addressed , `` he said . `` Incitement to hatred , violence and glorification of terror have poisoned the mind of too many , `` he added . `` We need action and we need it now . `` Earlier on Monday , Austria said it wa suspending aid worth ten of million of euro to Palestinians in response to the attack on Israel to ensure fund were not flowing into the wrong hand , while Germany wa reviewing it support . ( $ 1 = 0.9483 euro )
title: eu funding aid to palestinian to continue

Body Text: Egypt continued mediating a ceasefire between Israel and Palestinian Islamic Jihad to end Operation Shield and Arrow on Wednesday , even a the latter continued a barrage of rocket towards Israeli city in the south and Tel Aviv area . & ldquo ; The campaign still isn & rsquo ; t over , & rdquo ; Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said in a statement to the medium . & ldquo ; We say to the terrorist and those who sent them : We see you everywhere ; you can & rsquo ; t hide . & rdquo ; However , a senior diplomatic source said that Israel is & ldquo ; ready for a ceasefire ; we did what we needed to do & rdquo ; in Gaza . & ldquo ; A ceasefire will be judged only by action and not by word , & rdquo ; another senior diplomatic source said.Following over 100 IDF strike and over 300 rocket attack mostly from Palestinian Islamic Jihad of Gaza earlier Wednesday , Egypt reached out to Israel to say PIJ want a ceasefire , The Jerusalem Post confirmed from multiple sources.Further , top IDF official have recommended accepting a ceasefire in light of major perceived accomplishment of the current operation & ndash ; though publicly the IDF said it doe not comment on such issues.However , a late a 8:00 p.m . , Islamic Jihad and the IDF had each unleashed another significant round of attack against one another.Foreign Minister Eli Cohen confirmed to KAN News that a ceasefire proposal wa sent by Egypt and is under consideration by the defense establishment.The senior diplomatic source said that Egypt is the central player in ceasefire talk , despite report in Arab medium that Qatar and the UN were involved.Rocket barrage launched at southern , central IsraelAccording to unconfirmed Palestinians report , 21 Palestinians have been killed , with no indication yet from Israel about their identity a combatant or civilians.Netanyahu said that no Israelis died during Operation Shield and Arrow , though there have been report of a number of injuries.Earlier , around 12:30 p.m . , the IDF initiated a widespread preemptive strike on a variety of Islamic Jihad rocket position , including some concealed from the public eye , after seeing intelligence sign that the terror group wa getting ready for a broad round of rocket attack on Israel.At 11:45 a.m . , the IDF carried out it first attack of Wednesday on an Islamic Jihad crew that wa getting ready to fire rocket near the southern Gaza city of Khan Yunis.This incident came after a similar incident on Tuesday early evening.After these incident and along with other intelligence sign , IDF chief spokesman Brig . Gen . Daniel Hagri said that the IDF decided instead of only selectively attacking rocket crew on their way to their rocket firing position , to preemptively attack a variety of concealed rocket position that intelligence had previously found.At that point , Hagari said that the IDF & rsquo ; s rationale wa that it wa better to put the Jihad organization back on it heel again , rather than trying to track dozen of rocket crew once they are already out near their positions.Around 1:00 p.m . on Wednesday , the IDF & rsquo ; s analysis of why Islamic Jihad delayed striking back related to shock that the group wa going through from a surprise attack overnight between Monday and Tuesday eliminating three of it top leader and 10 key military position , followed by the IDF successfully thwarting it initial attempt to strike back , said Hagari.For example , the IDF & rsquo ; s attack on an anti-tank missile crew on Tuesday evening thwarted an initial move to use one of it more advanced weapon against Israel , a opposed to many of it rocket , which are less precise.Hagari rejected any conception that Islamic Jihad wa successfully using psychological warfare against Israel by rolling out it counter strike slowly.Rather , the IDF & rsquo ; s view would be that it ha been consistent about keeping Islamic Jihad on it heel , but without getting drawn into a longer fight or a larger fight with Hamas.IDF chief-of-staff Lt . Gen . Herzi Halevi visited the South early Wednesday afternoon to personally ensure that Israel 's missile defense and other defense element remain on the highest level of alert.If Hamas had joined in in a serious way , the conflict could have been extended longer than the multiple round Israel ha had with Islamic Jihad which have all ended in less than 72 hours.But Hamas mostly stayed out of the fight , despite some of it public statement that it would join in.The IDF said on Wednesday that the David Sling missile defense system had also been used to shoot down a mid-range rocket fired at Tel Aviv.David 's Sling & nbsp ; In 2018 , David 's Sling wa used against two missile being fired from Syria , but it ha not been used operationally since then.Moreover , the IDF wanted to emphasize that this wa the first time David 's Sling wa used in defense of Tel Aviv.It wa only used on Wednesday a an opportunity to test it status in a situation where there were fallback alternatives.Along with the Iron Dome against short-range rocket and the Arrow defense system against long range missile , David 's Sling is the middle element of Israel 's missile defense .
title: ceasefire talk ongoing a over 500 gaza rocket shot at israel

Body Text: Israel is today a polarized society , but special event like Holocaust Remembrance Day ease this division due to , in part , an increase in feeling of sadness and underscore the pivotal role of memorial day in temporarily reducing societal division and safeguarding cohesion.These were the finding of a new study by researcher at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem ( HU ) led by doctoral student Tamar Gur and colleague , under the guidance of psychology Prof . Eran Halperin . It delved into the emotional dynamic surrounding this day marked on Monday this year that detected a substantial decline in & ldquo ; affective polarization during the commemoration . & rdquo ; They published their paper in the journal Political Psychology under the title & ldquo ; A group that grief together stay together : Examining the impact of Holocaust Memorial Day in Israel on affective polarization . & rdquo ; Affective polarization is defined a the tendency to dislike , distrust , and maintain hostile attitude toward supporter of other political party or ideology . In it extreme form , affective polarization may pose a severe threat to these group & rsquo ; cohesion , functionality , and existence.Relation between memorial day and unityThe association between memorial day and national unity ha long been recognized . In poignant speech delivered during these commemoration , there & rsquo ; s always a powerful call for unity , underscoring a common identity and shared commitment to the memory of a collective history . Against the backdrop of polarization that ha beset Israel since January 2023 & ndash ; characterized by growing divide among group with identical national identity & ndash ; the need to strengthen these bond of common identity is vital , the researcher said.Research ha shown that the Jewish public is very involved in and moved by Holocaust Remembrance Day : In one survey , 93 % of them reported standing at attention in honor of the fallen during the commemorative siren.The study examined the effect of memorial day on emotional response and their potential role in mitigating affective polarization . Affective polarization , defined a the tendency to harbor negative attitude and hostility towards supporter of opposing political ideology , pose a grave threat to societal cohesion and functionality.The study wa based on extensive survey of participant , gauging their feeling and attitude before , during , and after the day of remembrance . The result showed that the prevalent sadness associated with the day significantly decrease polarization of mood and feeling that often manifest a distrust or hostility towards those with differing political or ideological view . & ldquo ; Out of the great crisis we grew , became stronger , and established a glorious country , and we should not take this for granted , & rdquo ; said Rosa Bloch , a speaker at a Holocaust Remembrance Day event three year ago . & ldquo ; As a woman who love people , I will add and say that I call for unity of the nation . & lsquo ; Love your neighbor a yourself & rsquo ; is a principle that should be with u every day , every hour , because our strength is in our unity . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; Memorial day serve a a reminder of our shared humanity and collective responsibility towards preserving the memory of our past , & rdquo ; Gur commented . & ldquo ; Our finding underscore the pivotal role of sadness in temporarily reducing affective polarization and safeguarding societal cohesion . & rdquo ; They said that despite it limitation , this research hold far-reaching implication . & ldquo ; Sadness , though often deemed an unpleasant emotion , offer substantial personal and group advantage in specific context . Memorial day exemplify how national group can harness the power of sadness to bolster cohesion and preserve group integrity . & rdquo ; This profound impact on societal cohesion underscore the importance of collective memory in healing national wound and building a resilient community , the team concluded . & ldquo ; It highlight how remembrance and shared grief can serve a powerful catalyst for social solidarity , promoting a more harmonious coexistence among various social group . & rdquo ; & nbsp ;
title: remembrance day bring israeli together in their grief , even if only temporarily

Body Text: Statistics have shown that only 13 percent of ultra-Orthodox youth of conscription age neither study nor work , 39 percent only work , and 19 study and work . Finally , only 29 percent meet the requirement of Torah study . This is according to a report by a team commissioned by the Defense Ministry to examine the integration of ultra-Orthodox youth into the IDF.The team wa appointed by Defense Minister Yoav Gallant and headed by former commander of the Israel Air Force , Maj . - Gen . ( re . ) Eliezer Shkedi , with the goal of examining the possibility of integrating and raising the number of ultra-Orthodox recruit to the IDF.The Israel-Hamas war led to an increase of ultra-Orthodox drafting to the IDF . A significant jump in the number of recruit wa registered in the last recruitment cycle in May , where 250 ultra-Orthodox enlisted a combat soldier in the Paratrooper , Givati , and Netzah Yehuda infantry brigade , and for the first time , in the Border Police ( Magav ) . Another hundred enlisted a combat support soldier . Following the ongoing war in Gaza and tension along the northern border , and in light of additional security challenge such a the West Bank , the Iranian threat , the Syrian front , and distant front in Iraq and Yemen , the IDF need a massive increase in manpower in the IDF.The team , led by Maj . - Gen . Shkedi , compiled a report with 15 section to be implemented to increase the number of recruit . `` We got the impression that there is a desire among the ultra-Orthodox to contribute . There is a profound change in attitude . There is tremendous potential to advance the issue of recruiting the ultra-Orthodox population to enlist in various recruitment route for the IDF , `` said Shkedi.Among the section that promote the scope of recruitment is the opening of all system in the IDF for the benefit of recruiting ultra-Orthodox in all branch and unit . `` Our motto must be ' We want you , we need you , and we respect you , ' `` Shkedi stated . He further elaborated , `` We decided on a maximum number of position for all age . We do not want to send the ultra-Orthodox recruit straight to the military rabbinate . We need to create an open grade . And we will do everything to not change their lifestyle . `` Report offer solution and adjustment for ultra-Orthodox enlistment & nbsp ; One of the section in the report deal with the fact that action must be taken to make military service accessible to ultra-Orthodox youth , among other thing , by opening short-term preparatory program of between two week and a month . Two such preparatory school have already been opened with the Jewish Agency and there is a plan to open dozen of similar preparatory programs.It wa also decided to change the screening at the recruiting office and adjust it for the ultra-Orthodox , such a adjusting the aptitude and other test that many in this group are not technologically sufficient to conduct . Another aspect is to ensure that these aptitude and placement test are not administered by female soldier , a well a making various adjustment on bases.Another section deal with the construction of service track for combat support , with an emphasis on unit such a Intelligence , Air Force , and the Navy . It wa also decided to make information accessible on the internet to learn about all the track that stand before them in the IDF . At the same time , there wa a recommendation to establish a special directorate in the Defense Ministry for the issue of encouraging the recruitment of the ultra-Orthodox population into the IDF , a well a appointing a special adviser to the IDF Chief of Staff for ultra-Orthodox affair , similar to the adviser for woman and gender affairs.Defense Minister Yoav Gallant , in response to the report , stated , `` Thank you to Maj . - Gen . Eliezer Shkedi , for important and groundbreaking action on expanding the rank of the IDF and strengthening Israel 's security . Together with the dedicated team and in cooperation with the Chief of Staff and the Director General of the Defense Ministry , we brought good news to the people of Israel and in particular to member of the ultra-Orthodox sector - the possibility to enlist in any unit in the IDF and preserve their way of life . & rdquo ; `` Already in December 2023 , the team began it work , in order to bring about a significant recruitment of ultra-Orthodox , starting with the upcoming recruitment cycle . This is good news for the Israeli public - the security establishment will continue to support any effort that will lead to the expansion of it rank . In the day when the IDF is fighting in seven arena , near and far , in order to maintain Israel 's security and deal with it need , we must make sure that everyone who is needed can join , this is a real operational need and a necessary and vital action . `` `` Thanks to the team member for purposeful and efficient work , I am confident that the thousand of ultra-Orthodox who seek to serve in the IDF will receive adequate treatment in accordance with their lifestyle and will be able to contribute their part to the security of the country . The entire security system and the IDF in particular will study the report and it recommendation in depth , and will shortly formulate a comprehensive work plan to implement the conclusion , `` Gallant 's statement concluded .
title: defense ministry-commissioned team draw up report on increasing haredi draft

Body Text: Israelis today have shiny biometric passport , but those from the nascent Jewish state in the 1950s were hand-written and issued well before computer existed ; they were also marked in French : & ldquo ; Valid to any country except Germany . & rdquo ; Israelis who wanted to visit Germany had to file a request . That condition wa then deleted by an official drawing a line through the words.After the Reparations Agreement wa signed between Israel and West Germany in 1952 , the passport became valid for travel to all countries.The history of travel document in IsraelWhat about travel document for those living in Mandatory Palestine before and after May 14 , 1948 ? Beginning almost a century ago , Jews and Arabs who lived in the land were able to acquire a Palestine passport issued by Britain . These were valid for two year only , and the text wa written in Hebrew and French.The first Mandatory Palestine passport wa issued in 1925 to Pinhas Rutenberg ( 1879 & ndash ; 1942 ) , a Russian Jewish engineer who went on to build the mandate & rsquo ; s First Jordan Hydro-Electric Power House aka Rutenberg Power Station or Naharayim Power Station at the confluence of the Jordan and Yarmuk Rivers . This dammed hydroelectric power station operated from 1932-1948 in Jordan ( then , Imarat Sharq al-Urdun , the Emirate of Transjordan , a British protectorate from 1921-1946 ) , supplying power to Mandatory Palestine.When the British Mandate of Palestine ended on May 15 , 1948 , the State of Israel began issuing travel document with an initial validity of two year & ndash ; and printed and filled out in Hebrew and French & ndash ; until the Knesset passed the Israeli nationality law in 1952 . & nbsp ; Thereafter , the first Israeli passport issued wa in the name of Golda Meir , who at the time worked for the Jewish Agency and wa soon to become Israel & rsquo ; s ambassador to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics ( USSR ) , aka the Soviet Union . 
title: before biometrics : israel 's earliest passport and travel document

Body Text: & nbsp ; Israel 's Holocaust commemoration this year have a searing significance for six elderly survivor now deeply scarred by the Hamas attack of Oct . 7 that sparked the ongoing Gaza war.The killing and kidnapping spree by Palestinian infiltrator on a Jewish holiday morning shook the sense of security of Israelis - not least , those who had witnessed the state emerge a a safe haven after the Nazi genocide.For Bellha Haim , 86 , the upheaval is especially profound.Her grandson Yotam - like her , a resident of a village near the Gaza border - wa taken hostage by Hamas and managed to escape , only to be accidentally shot dead by Israeli soldiers.The trauma drove Haim to return to her native Poland , which she had fled with her family a a child during World War Two , and where she will , on Monday , take part of the `` March of the Living `` at the site of the Auschwitz death camp.The annual ceremony is timed to coincide with Israel 's Holocaust Remembrance Day.A cohort of university president and chancellor from America and Canada will participate in the 2024 International March of the Living . The event will be headed up by former US Secretary of Education Dr . John King , now the Chancellor of SUNY , and Yeshiva University President Rabbi Dr . Ari Berman.Dr . King lead a system of 64 college and university in New York State , the largest comprehensive system of public higher education in the United States.The trip will come to a close after Holocaust Remembrance Day , during which participant join Holocaust survivor on a solemn march from Auschwitz to Birkenau to commemorate the Nazi horror . `` I never went back , and I wa n't convinced to go back , `` Haim said during a meeting with other survivor ahead of the trip . `` But this time , when they told me that they were connecting the Holocaust and what I call the ' Holocaust of October 7 ' - because then in the Holocaust we ( Jews ) were not a united people , we did n't have a country , and suddenly this pride of mine that ha been broken , my pride in my people and my country that wa shattered in front of my eye - I said , ' This time I will break my oath , and I will go out . ' `` As a teenager , Yotam had taken part in the annual Auschwitz vigil , and Haim said she saw the event a a chance for communion with him and other victim of the Hamas attack . `` I will go out in the name of Yotam , who marched there when he wa in high school , and I will go out there to shout out the cry of the slain , of the baby , of all my good friend that I will never meet again , & rdquo ; she said.Yelling in Arabic and gunfireAmong those joining her will be 90-year-old Daniel Louz , whose hometown , Kibbutz Beeri , lost a tenth of it resident to the Palestinian terrorists.In some way , he said , that ordeal wa worse for him than the European war , when he escaped Nazi round-ups in his native France , although half his family perished in Poland.After he awoke to the sound of Arabic yelling and gunfire , `` I wa constantly busy with surviving and figuring out what to do , `` Louz said . `` In France , a a child , I suffered all kind of post-traumas that I & rsquo ; ve learned to cope with . But in Beeri , it wa the first time that I felt the fear of death . `` A neighboring house wa riddled with bullet . Louz 's wa untouched . He say he imagined the soul of the six million Holocaust victim steering Hamas away from him . `` They probably wanted me to be here to tell this story , `` he said , weeping.Other Holocaust survivor participating in the March of the Living include Smil Bercu Sacagiu , 87 , whose home wa hit by a rocket from Gaza , and Jacqueline Gliksman , 81 , whose home wa torched by a Palestinian infiltrator . `` What wa left , and luckily the terrorist didn & rsquo ; t see it , is my grandchild , `` she said , referring to gold figurine on a necklace she wa wearing . `` That 's the only thing I have left . `` Before he wa seized , Haim 's grandson left a text message : `` They & rsquo ; re burning down my house . I smell gas . I 'm scared . `` She said that it reminded her of a Holocaust-era song in Yiddish , invoking century of pogrom , with the refrain `` fire , Jews , fire . `` A veteran campaigner for peace with the Palestinians , Haim said she would no longer pursue that activism . `` I 'm not able to , `` she said . `` Now what interest me is only my people . & rdquo ; Jerusalem Post Staff contributed to this report . & nbsp ;
title: hamas killing spree haunt holocaust survivor participating in ' march of the living '

Body Text: An IDF soldier wa murdered in a Palestinian shooting attack near Kedumim in the northern West Bank on Thursday , with the terrorist also later killed.The soldier wa identified a IDF Staff-Sergeant Shilo Yosef Amir , a 22 year old from Meirav in northern Israel and a soldier in Sayeret Givati.Hamas 's al-Qassam Brigades declared responsibility for the attack , saying that it wa conducted a a response to the recent Israeli operation in Jenin and the tearing up of the Quran in Urif.The al-Qassam Brigades added that the attack aimed `` to tell the criminal Zionist Minister [ Finance Minister Betzalel ] Smotrich that al-Qassam almost knocked on your door . `` Smotrich life in Kdumim.Around 3:45 p.m . , security force connected to Kedumim identified a suspicious white van that wa driving in circle around the outskirt of the yishuv.The suspicious movement of the vehicle led those security force to send out a mix of a civilian security official and a group of four IDF soldier to converge on and approach the van.IDF Brig . Gen . Avi Blut said that the heightened awareness of the Yishuv 's security complement both in detecting the van and in keeping all of the gate to the Yishuv closed , may have saved significant civilian life since it meant the terrorist could not penetrate the Yishuv or achieve any surprise.The civilian security official arrived at the vehicle first and initiated a request for the driver to produce identification.The driver continued to act suspiciously but did not yet open fire.How the attack unfoldedVery shortly after , the four IDF soldier arrived and started to approach the terrorist.At a certain point during their approach , the terrorist opened fire , mortally wounding the commander of the four IDF soldier , who wa hit with one deadly bullet.Magen David Adom initially indicated that the soldier wa severely wounded after the IDF confirmed report of the attack , but later confirmed his death.Though the terrorist also fired in the direction of the civilian security official , he wa not injured.There were conflicting report about potential other incident in the area a the terrorist attacker initially escaped on foot , fleeing toward the Jiat junction.The remaining three IDF soldier pursued him and managed to bring him down with gunfire.Additional soldier arrived on the scene shortly after and ensured that he wa neutralized . & nbsp ; Blut said that the IDF ha identified the terrorist , but will only release his identity later , after determining whether he wa a lone wolf attacker or whether he wa directed to carry out the attack by a terror group.The IDF ha already determined that no other attacker wa involved in the incident and that the terrorist did not come from Jenin.Blut said that once the terrorist 's identity is publicized , the IDF will also initiate process related to his family and potentially demolish his house.This is a developing story .
title: idf soldier murdered in terror shooting near west bank settlement of kedumim

Body Text: International Criminal Court Prosecutor Fatou Bensouda on Wednesday threatened both Israel and Hamas with new possible war crime allegation relating to the ongoing conflict . & nbsp ; In a series of tweet , Bensouda wrote , & ldquo ; I note with great concern the escalation of violence in the West Bank , including East Jerusalem , a well a in and around Gaza , and the possible commission of crime under the # RomeStatute . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Further , she wrote , & ldquo ; I echo the call from the international community for calm , restraint & amp ; a stop to the violence . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Next , she said , & ldquo ; I recall that my Office & rsquo ; s investigation will cover all side and all the fact and evidence relevant to an assessment of whether there is individual criminal responsibility under the Statute . My Office will continue to monitor development on the ground and will factor any matter that fall within it jurisdiction . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; In February and March , the ICC Pre-Trial Chamber and Bensouda herself each made decision pushing forward with a full criminal probe of Israel & rsquo ; s and Hamas & rsquo ; s conduct . & nbsp ; Regarding Israel , Bensouda wa already probing the 2014 Gaza war , the 2018 Gaza border conflict and the settlement enterprise . & nbsp ; With regard to Hamas , she wa probing the 2014 and 2018 conflict . & nbsp ; However , once an ICC probe is launched , it is open-ended and can add new event into the investigation a they occur . & nbsp ; Bensouda & rsquo ; s tweet on Wednesday were a reminder to Israel and Hamas that for the first time ever , the current major conflict is taking place in the middle of an already ongoing full ICC criminal probe . & nbsp ; Back in 2014 , there wa no ICC process in place , and the former prosecutor , Luis Moreno-Ocampo , had rejected jurisdiction over & ldquo ; Palestine & rdquo ; in early 2012 . & nbsp ; However , by late 2012 , the & ldquo ; State of Palestine & rdquo ; received a heightened nation , nonmember state status from the UN General Assembly . & nbsp ; In early 2015 , the Palestinian Authority used this new status to request a probe of Israel , and Bensouda spent the next five year carrying out a preliminary review of the issue . & nbsp ; Between December 2019 and February of this year , the issue wa litigated before the ICC Pre-Trial Chamber , which eventually endorsed Bensouda & rsquo ; s moving to the next stage , the full criminal probe . & nbsp ; Previously , Bensouda issued warning to Israel over the 2018 Gaza border conflict and over a plan to evict the resident of Khan al-Ahmar . & nbsp ; Israel indefinitely postponed the eviction of Khan al-Ahmar resident , and the IDF acknowledged that it altered some of it tactic during the 2018 conflict . & nbsp ; But neither of those situation came anywhere near the magnitude of the current conflict , which could expose Israel on a much greater level . & nbsp ; Israel reject ICC jurisdiction on a variety of ground , ranging from rejecting the idea of Palestine being a state , the IDF & rsquo ; s self-investigating mechanism superseding any ICC probe , the fact that Israel never ratified the Rome Statute , and the idea that building house in the disputed West Bank can not be a war crime , and is an issue for peace negotiation . & nbsp ; Bensouda step down next month and will be replaced by Karim Khan , who Israel hope may be more sympathetic to it view , but who to date is an unknown variable .
title: icc threatens new war crime allegation against israel , hamas

Body Text: Not many people alive today have done a much for human freedom and the Jewish people a ha Natan Sharansky . Sharansky , born in Donetsk , Ukraine , wa the spokesman for the human right movement , a prisoner of Zion , and a leader of the struggle for the right of Soviet Jews to emigrate to Israel . After applying to `` make aliyah , `` Sharansky wa arrested on charge of treason and espionage . He wa convicted in a Soviet court and served nine year in the Gulag . Following massive public campaign by the State of Israel , world Jewry and leader of the free world , Sharansky wa released in 1986 , and emigrated to Israel , on the very day of his release.In his first year in Israel , Sharansky founded the Zionist Forum to aid Soviet immigrant in their absorption into Israeli society , and , in the 1990s , he founded the Israel Ba'aliyah party to represent the interest of Russian olim . He served in four successive government , a a minister , and a deputy prime minister.From 2009 to 2018 , he served a chairperson of the Jewish Agency , and upon his retirement , received the Israel Prize for promoting aliya and the ingathering of the exile . Sharansky also received the Congressional Medal of Honor in 1986 and the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2006 . He is the only living non-American citizen who is the recipient of these two highest American awards.Clearly , there is almost nothing in the Jewish world and in Israel that Sharansky ha not been involved with , in one way or another , in the course of his life . At this challenging time , it seemed appropriate to discus current event with Sharansky.These are difficult time for u , a a people , a a country , a a society . How have you felt since October 7 ? `` Of course , there wa a huge failure here of our intelligence , our army , and our politician . We were deeply invested in incorrect concept . For me , it all started back with Oslo . I said then , that the idea of our bringing a dictator to the Palestinians who would make peace with u & mdash ; because we would make him a dictator by giving him a lot of money & mdash ; did not make sense . It 's just the reverse : the dictator would need u a enemy , and therefore would not make peace with u . `` It continued even with the withdrawal ( from the Gaza Strip , A.W . ) . The idea wa that we would be here , and they would be there , and we could control them that way . As ( Prime Minister ) Arik Sharon explained to me , if they turned militant and tried something , we would go in . I resigned from the government at that time , because of the disengagement . `` `` We have become a united society '' Sharansky belief it wa the spirit of Oslo that caused Israel 's leadership , at all level , to act incorrectly , and led to the failure of October 7 . On the other hand , `` This event wa a reminder of how good it is that we have the State of Israel . There is a poet who wrote that the proximity of Israeli Memorial Day and Holocaust Day help u understand the price of the world with a state and without a state . When we were in the Soviet Union and there wa a surge of antisemitism , could we could fight , go to court ? No ! We just had to get by , take refuge in mathematics and physic , perhaps they 'd leave u alone . Even after 100,000 people were killed ( in pogrom ) , there wa nothing to be done but to run away to America . `` Now , we 're fighting , `` Sharansky declares proudly . `` We have transformed from a most divided society into a united society . We are all sitting in one tank , and our appreciation for the State of Israel ha been renewed . And a much a we called the young generation a TikTok one , it turn out this generation is giving u a lesson in true Zionism , in such a noble , such a brave way . So , good thing are happening . I am optimistic about the future of the State of Israel , but far less optimistic about what is happening in America and Europe . `` Sharansky try to explain what he think is happening nowadays in the West , both in the Jewish context and the wider one . `` The Jews feel they are part of the liberal world , and the liberal world think the progressive are their partner . For year , I wrote about the fact that the real crisis in the United States is not between Republicans and Democrats , but between liberal and progressive . I said that one day , the liberal would realize they were not partner . `` In his various role , Sharansky met with many Jews in the West . `` I asked Jews at university , in the most elite place , if any of the organization they had developed relationship with , befriended over the year , expressed any sympathy after October 7 . I 'm not asking for anything more , just sympathy . They looked and looked , and found one right-leaning organization at Yale that participated in mourning . That 's it . This mean that all the organization on the progressive left see the terrible thing that happened on October 7 a part of a legitimate struggle . This is a big change ; antisemitism came out in a big way . `` Sharansky say in the past he had theory about how to prove a connection between antisemitism and anti-Zionism . `` Today we no longer need a theory , we do n't need to show anything , it 's in everyday life . I hope that the new generation of American Jews will go out in public and fight over this it . `` You said you were encouraged by the unity here , but there is a repeat of the tension we saw before October 7 , is n't there ? `` There is a comeback , but a group of politician and a group of journalist are behind it . The mass are not with them today , unlike what happened until October 7 when half the country thought the other half wa trying to steal their democracy and the other half thought they were trying to steal their Judaism . Today , the people feel that it is important for everyone that there is a Jewish state , and also a free country , and you can see this with almost every bereaved family of a fallen soldier . Also , we see that , in the moment of truth , suddenly , the real and deep thing that unite u still exist . They are n't lost . `` Marxism is backI spoke not long ago with a researcher named Izabella Tabarovsky who belief that the anti-Zionist rhetoric and progressive left activity stem from the Soviet attitude towards Zionism and Israel . Do you agree with this analysis ? `` Yes , of course . I think Izabella is right . There is a large group of people who left he Soviet Union who understand much better than most Americans what exactly happened in America . The whole post-modern ideology that divide the world into oppressed and oppressor is neo-Marxism in it most primitive form . In the study of critical race theory & mdash ; which have become the Koran of the progressive & mdash ; if you replace race with class , you get the ideology of the Bolsheviks in the Soviet Union . There , too , the whole war is between one good side and one bad side , between the proletariat and the capitalist . The capitalist are always wrong and should not be given freedom of speech & mdash ; aside from those who are considered politically correct . And the capitalist world should be destroyed completely , and a just world will be built on this . It is very sad that Marxism ha come back after such a huge failure . It ha come back via the academy because it could not come back through politics . It is always like that , the bad idea always come from the academy . `` When did I first realize that this is what had happened ? `` Sharansky asks , and immediately answer : `` Twenty year ago , I wa touring university in America , and I told Arik Sharon , who wa then prime minister , that this wa where the most important struggle for Israel 's future wa taking place . I saw there for the first time that student were afraid to say what they thought because it would not be good for their career . And a soon that start , it start taking u towards Soviet life . `` How do you overcome this madness ? `` Liberal student , first of all Jewish student , should enter the arena , stand up , and take a strong position . A position that say we are Jews , we are Zionists , Zionism is part of our identity , and the United States , according to it principle , must protect u . It is already starting ; 500 student in Columbia issued a very firm letter , and every day more student are joining , and I believe it will reach more university . In addition , there are now investigation into how Qatar give ten of billion of dollar to university . This must be investigated . `` Correspondence with NavalnyIn February of this year , American journalist Bari Weiss revealed that during April 2023 , Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny , who wa apparently killed in prison , corresponded with Sharansky . Navalny had written to Sharansky , saying he had read `` Fear No Evil , `` Sharansky 's account of his year of struggle against communist rule . In the letter , he also quoted from the Bible : `` That which hath been is that which shall be , `` and said , among other thing , that he `` continues to believe we will fix it , and that one day in Russia there will be what ha not been . `` How did your relationship with Navalny come about ? `` About a year and a half ago , I suddenly received a letter from Navalny through his lawyer . `` A physical letter ? `` A handwritten letter that wa photocopied and sent to my email . `` And what did he say ? `` He said , we did n't know each other , but he wa writing to me a a reader to a writer , because he had read my book and wa amazed at how much the situation had gone back to what it wa when I wa in the Gulag . During my year in prison , I spent 450 day in isolation , Navalny wa already almost 300 day in isolation . It is clear from his letter that he is a free man , and of course I wrote that I admired him and his struggle . It wa clear this wa a very strong man , that he wa optimistic , not because of what wa happening with him , but that he wa optimistic about the victory of his struggle . We had an exchange of letter , and we had a good feeling towards one another `` . What wa in his last letter to you ? `` In the last letter , right before he entered the isolation cell again , he wrote to me : ' I received a letter from you , and I do n't know when I will be able to write to you again , so I 'm simply writing to you . ' What wa interesting is that he ended the letter with the word ' Next year in Jerusalem ' in Russian letter & mdash ; the last word in my book . As if he wanted to join the optimism of Jewish history . `` You are one of the personage most identified with the word `` freedom . `` What is freedom to you ? `` Freedom is when you can do and say thing you believe in . In this respect , in prison I wa much freer than those who interrogated me . During the interrogation , I really liked to tell anti-Soviet joke about Brezhnev . The guard were almost bursting but could not laugh because of the consequence . And I would say to them , ' Well , you want to tell me that I 'm in prison ? You 're in prison & mdash ; you can not laugh . ' For me , freedom is very much related to identity , because we found the strength to fight for our identity only when we became a free people , and vice versa . `` The fact that the West itself ha lost it identity is connected to everything we see now . And here Israel ha a special role . We are part of the free world , yet still insist on maintaining our identity a a Jewish state . `` How did you feel about the judicial overhaul , the conduct of the government , and all the demonstration ? `` I thought both side were wrong . There wa no reason for Netanyahu , who came to power for a four-year term , to try in two month to introduce a law that change thing so significantly . I agreed with most of the element of the reform except for a few thing , but they wanted to do everything immediately . It wa a huge mistake . Let 's say that in the first week Bibi did n't understand that [ Minister of Justice Yariv ] Levin wa rushing something , okay , but after ten week you can already understand it wa a mistake . `` On the other hand , the demonstration shouting to the whole world that this is the end of democracy , that this is a dictatorship , that this is the end of woman 's freedom & mdash ; I think that 's irresponsible . Once one of the organizer of the demonstration asked me , ' Why do n't you come to our demonstration ? ' I asked , ' Why do you shout that this is the end of democracy ? ' He told me , ' Without it , we would n't be able to bring along so many people . ' That 's cynical . `` Too many year in powerSharansky ha known Benjamin Netanyahu since he wa a diplomat . Asked his opinion about Netanyahu and his performance these day , he reply that `` Bibi is a great politician , a great leader . It 's not by chance that he ha been at the head of this country for so long . When I wa in the government , I saw how he fought to liberalize the economy . Thanks to him & mdash ; and I wa there & mdash ; there 's the Taglit-Birthright project , not to mention the fact that he wa first in the world to understand the Iranian threat . And when he wa Prime Minister and Minister of Finance , he began advancing the sanction . He also took office after the Oslo Accords , when there were many commitment in place , and he managed to moderate them . `` Following this praise , Sharansky come to his problem with Netanyahu : `` I think it 's not good when a politician stay in power for too long . ' He asked , ' Are you telling me that ? ' and I said , ' Yes , you too . ' When you 're in a post like that for a long time , you begin to feel that the best thing for the country would be for you to stay in power & mdash ; and then that becomes the goal . And there is no doubt that he ha also contributed to the divisiveness here . The fact that he started using the word ' leftist ' a word describing an enemy is very bad . `` He should have finished up , and prepared a new generation to replace him , but he felt that there wa no-one who could replace him to save the country , and thought ' I need to stay in power ' . title: sharansky : in prison i wa freer than my interrogator

Body Text: In the midst of horror , story of heroism emerge . Linoy Al-Ezra , a resident of Hatzor HaGlilit and a senior Magen David Adom medic , started her shift on the fateful morning of the deadly Hamas terrorist attack in the south of the country . In a heart-wrenching conversation , she spoke with nine-year-old Michael , a resident of a Kfar Aza , who informed her that his parent had been shot and were unresponsive.Michael wa only nine year old , his sister age 6 '' In an attempt to assess if there wa any hope of saving them , I asked him where they had been shot . From his description , it became evident that there wa no chance of saving them , `` she recall , sharing in the pain . `` Michael remained composed and performed admirably , telling me that he wa with his six-year-old sister named Alma . `` Al-Ezra went on to describe how she guided them to safety , saying , `` I advised them to go to the shelter and lock the door securely . He initially hesitated but then complied . I inquired if there wa a closet inside the shelter , and he confirmed it presence . I instructed them to enter the closet , remain quiet , and not come out until the brave soldier arrived to rescue them . `` In a recent meeting with their aunt and grandmother , Al-Ezra shared their story of bravery . For many hour , these two young soul remained hidden in a closet , maintaining their silence , ultimately ensuring their survival.The Jerusalem Post and OneFamily are working together to help support the victim of the Hamas massacre and the soldier of Israel who have been drafted to ensure that it never happens again.Become a partner in this project by donating to OneFamily & gt ; & gt ;

Body Text: Israel 's cabinet on Sunday voted unanimously to shut down the Qatari news outlet Al Jazeera 's operation in Israel , nearly six month after first announcing it intention to do so due to security concern related to the Israel-Hamas war.The decision , which requires recertification every 45 day , includes shutting down Al Jazeera broadcast in Arabic and English ; shutting down Al Jazeera 's office in Israel ; seizing equipment used for it broadcast ; and limiting access to it websites.Communications Minister Shlomo Karhi signed an executive order soon after the vote passed , and it thus came into effect immediately.Videos on Sunday afternoon showed law enforcement official arriving at Al Jazeera 's Jerusalem office in the Ambassador Hotel . HOT , one of Israel 's major television service provider , announced that it had shut down Al Jazeera 's broadcast . Another provider , YES , ran the following message on the blacked-out channel , `` In accordance with the government decision , the Al Jazeera station 's broadcast have been stopped in Israel . `` In a joint statement following the vote , Netanyahu said that `` Al Jazeera correspondent have harmed the security of Israel and incited against IDF soldier . The time ha come to eject Hamas 's mouthpiece from our country . `` Karhi added , `` We will take immediate action against those who use freedom of the press to harm the security of Israel and IDF soldier , and incite to terrorism in time of war . There will be no freedom of expression for Hamas 's mouthpiece in Israel . `` Al Jazeera condemned the decision , calling it a `` criminal action . `` `` Israel 's suppression of free press to cover up it crime by killing and arresting journalist ha not deterred u from performing our duty , `` it said.Decision go against Mossad chief 's positionIsrael 's National Security Cabinet wa scheduled to hold the vote already on Thursday , but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu delayed it due to concern that the vote would not pas . According to a spokesperson for Minister-without-portfolio MK Benny Gantz 's National Unity party , this wa because Mossad chief David Barnea requested that the government delay it for a few day , so a to avoid possible negative diplomatic ramification relating to Qatar , a mediator between Israel and Hamas in negotiation for a deal to free Israeli hostage . The decision required approval from either the government 's National Security Cabinet ( NSC ) or the general cabinet , and Netanyahu chose to move forward on Sunday in the general cabinet.National Unity 's three minister were not present at the meeting and did not take part in the vote . The party said in a statement that it minister `` support closing Al Jazeera 's broadcast and even announced that they would support it closure in the recent ( national security ) cabinet meeting . `` However , `` Bringing the topic forward this morning for a vote in the government meeting , is a correct decision but with terrible timing , that could undermine effort to exhaust the ( hostage deal ) negotiation , and stem from political consideration , `` the party said.Karhi countered by accusing the centrist National Unity of acting like a `` fifth column `` within the government . According to Karhi , the decision received `` unequivocal validation `` by all security official . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; The decision wa based on a law that Israel 's Knesset ( parliament ) passed on April 2 , which expires on July 31 . The legislation will therefore need to be extended if the government wish to extend the banning of Al Jazeera beyond that date . The law itself is also facing a constitutional challenge in the High Court of Justice by the Association for Civil Rights in Israel ( ACRI ) based on it violation of free speech , and the state ha until May 15 to file it preliminary response to the court.The government passed emergency executive measure at the start of the war that would have enabled it to shut down Al Jazeera temporarily . These were in effect from October 21 until January 20 . However , the government refrained from implementing these measure during that period , reportedly due to possible negative diplomatic ramification relating to Qatar.The legislation that passed in April wa aimed at giving the cabinet firmer legal footing to move against Al Jazeera . In it decision on Sunday , the cabinet explained that it had classified opinion from the Shin Bet on April 9 deeming Al Jazeera a national security threat . The IDF and Mossad also provided classified opinion supporting limiting Al Jazeera 's broadcast in Israel.According to the law , the decision must be brought before a regional chief justice or deputy chief justice within 24 hour , who then have three day to decide whether or not to change the decision or limit the length of the ban.In it petition to the High Court of Justice against the law , argued that it unnecessarily limited free speech and wa thus unconstitutional . ACRI said that while there wa no arguing the fact that Al Jazeera ran a `` pro-Palestinian `` narrative , this wa not a sufficient reason to shut down the network . In addition , the network provides content from Arab state and includes Israeli Arab perspective that have been quoted numerously on mainstream Israeli medium , indicating that it content wa viewed a important , ACRI added . The NGO acknowledged that Al-Jazeera had included content that incited against Israel . Still , the severity of this incitement wa no worse than incitement against Palestinians on mainstream Israeli website , ACRI argued.ACRI filed a request on Thursday that the court issue a temporary order barring the government from deciding to shut down Al Jazeera until the case is heard . The court denied the request , and said it would consider a temporary order after receiving the state 's preliminary position .

Body Text: United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said on Wednesday that the number of civilian killed in the Gaza Strip show that there is something `` clearly wrong `` with Israel 's military operation against Hamas Palestinian terrorist . `` There are violation by Hamas when they have human shield . But when one look at the number of civilian that were killed with the military operation , there is something that is clearly wrong , `` Guterres told Reuters NEXT.Israel ha vowed to wipe out Hamas , which rule the Gaza Strip , after the terrorist killed 1,400 people and took more than 240 hostage in an Oct . 7 attack . Israel ha struck Gaza from the air , imposed a siege and launched a ground invasion.The number of Palestinians killedHamas official have claimed 10,569 people have now been killed , 40 % of them child . `` It is also important to make Israel understand that it is against the interest of Israel to see every day the terrible image of the dramatic humanitarian need of the Palestinian people , `` Guterres said . `` That doe n't help Israel in relation to the global public opinion . `` Guterres compared the number of child being killed in Gaza with the toll in conflict around the world that he report on annually . `` Every year , the highest number of killing of child by any of the actor in all the conflict that we witness is the maximum in the hundred , `` Guterres said . `` We have in a few day in Gaza thousand and thousand of child killed , which mean there is also something clearly wrong in the way military operation are being done , `` he said.The UN report on child and armed conflict includes a list intended to shame party to conflict in the hope of pushing them to implement measure to protect child . It ha long been controversial , with diplomat saying Israel exerted pressure in recent year in a bid to stay off the list.The next report is due mid-next year.The United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights said on Wednesday that war crime had been committed by both Israel and Hamas in the conflict that erupted just over a month ago . `` The atrocity perpetrated by Palestinian armed group on 7 October were heinous , they were war crime - a is the continued holding of hostage , `` Volker Turk said at the Rafah crossing in Egypt on the border with Gaza . `` The collective punishment by Israel of Palestinian civilian is also a war crime , a is unlawful forcible evacuation of civilian , `` he added .
