Body Text: Berlin Blues , an excellent series that recently became available on Yes , is about an Israeli couple , a musician and a writer , who move with their daughter to Berlin.It examines the drama caused by their being foreigner in a place that offer a stimulating artistic environment but is shadowed by the tragic history of the Holocaust . It also show , very convincingly and sympathetically , how dormant problem in a couple & rsquo ; s relationship can be stirred up by such a move.It wa created by real-life married couple Itamar Rotschild , a musician , and Dana Idisis , the writer of such series and movie a On the Spectrum and Here We Are , who moved to Berlin with their daughter a couple of year ago . They stayed for about a year , then returned to Israel . & nbsp ; Rotschild himself play Yonah , the musician husband in the series . Shira Naor portrays Talya , his wife , a woman who ha published a novel based on the story of her mentally ill brother , and Idisis ha a brother on the autism spectrum , who wa part of the inspiration for some of her recent work . & nbsp ; Given all these similarity , Rotschild , speaking from his backyard in a recent interview , wasn & rsquo ; t exactly surprised when I asked how closely the series wa based on their actual life . & nbsp ; To what extent is the TV series based on real life ? & ldquo ; Let & rsquo ; s talk about the similarity . We moved to Berlin because I wanted the experience of living abroad for a few year . For Dana , it wa after the first season of On the Spectrum and we flew there and lived there for a year and a half , with our daughter . We have two daughter now but then we had only one . For me it wa nice there , I found myself there , I felt good . & rdquo ; So many young Israeli couple spend at least a couple of year abroad that it & rsquo ; s practically a rite of passage , but there haven & rsquo ; t been many fictional portrayal of this phenomenon . Berlin , with it low cost of living and thriving art scene , ha become a destination for thousand of young Israelis . Rotschild and Idisis thought of that when they lived there , although Rotschild emphasized that despite the superficial parallel , it wa not their story . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We knew the feeling of being in Berlin and feeling foreign , but we created the story , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; It can be complicated in so many way to live in a foreign country . There are lot of little thing that you know how they are done at home , but in this new place , everything is different , and you have a feeling of being an outsider . & rdquo ; That feeling put Yonah and Talya & rsquo ; s marriage under a strain : & ldquo ; There were all kind of problem before in their marriage , but they were kind of hidden , but here , in Berlin , everything is amplified . You are still you , but the new setting brings out thing that were more under control before . & rdquo ; When Talya return to Israel for a single episode , she is confronted by tough reality of the life she left behind there , notably that there are frequent missile attack from Gaza during her visit & ndash ; a disclaimer note that the episode wa filmed before October 7 & ndash ; and that her brother and her parent are in denial about the severity of his mental illness . & nbsp ; In a particularly harrowing scene , he insists on returning to work at his job at the Ramat Gan Safari after he ha been fired , and when Talya try to take him home , he jump out of the car near several hippopotamus . & ldquo ; You see that so much is hard for her in Israel , too , how complicated it is for her there . & rdquo ; THE RELATIONSHIP of Israelis to Germany is also complicated in all kind of way and Berlin Blues deal with that head-on . When Yonah & rsquo ; s mother ( Liora Rivlin ) come for a visit , she can barely contain her anger at her son for choosing to live in the country that persecuted her parent . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Lots of people are & lsquo ; anti [ German ] , & rsquo ; because of their parent , people don & rsquo ; t want to buy German good , wouldn & rsquo ; t want to buy a German car . I even know people my from my generation who won & rsquo ; t go to Germany . . . Yonah & rsquo ; s mother ha a real issue that is connected to the trauma of what so many Jews went through there , and I think that we tried to show what & rsquo ; s behind it , and she isn & rsquo ; t just & lsquo ; anti , & rsquo ; but you see at the end , with her monologue in German , that she ha a real connection to the country because of her parent , she isn & rsquo ; t just & lsquo ; anti . & rsquo ; & rdquo ; Another way that the series differs from his own life , Rotschild said , is that , & ldquo ; My music and the music in the series are two different thing . & rdquo ; Rotschild is a guitarist and pianist who writes and performs in a folk-rock style . He ha released a number of album and is at work now on a new one , while Yonah is an oboist who get a position with a Berlin orchestra . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I wa never in an orchestra . We thought about what would keep Yonah in Berlin , so that it make the conflict between him and Talya , who want to go home , stronger , and we thought of having him be an oboe player . The oboe is an instrument that maybe one or two people in orchestra can play full-time in Israel , but it & rsquo ; s hard to make a living at it here . But in Europe , you can make a living at it , there are a lot of orchestra there . & rdquo ; Rotschild had never played the oboe and learned enough to look convincing handling the instrument on screen . & ldquo ; I had a very good teacher , Shani Shachar , and she taught me how to play it and hold it and how to blow in it and how to clean it and how to get a sound from it . It & rsquo ; s a very difficult instrument just to get a sound out of & ndash ; and I & rsquo ; m not talking about a beautiful sound , just any sound at all . & ldquo ; We did a lot of research to get into the world of classical musician , to check how it sound , how it feel , what it & rsquo ; s like , because it wasn & rsquo ; t a world we knew . It & rsquo ; s music that I like , but it isn & rsquo ; t music , or a world , that I really know . & rdquo ; Rotschild said that the director of the series , Ram Nehari , who worked with them for two year , & ldquo ; helped to make the series what is today , he directed it beautifully and also worked on the script . He had a big influence on how well it turned out . & rdquo ; Rotschild & rsquo ; s most important role prior to Berlin Blues wa also a a musician , in the series , The Echo of Your Voice . Rotschild played a struggling artist who is the son of an Arik Einstein-like , all-time great performer , just a the Rotschild character & rsquo ; s own son becomes a rising star . In an unusual achievement , the three lead actor , Rotschild , Shaul Luria , and Orr Amrami Brockman , shared the award for Best Actor at the prestigious Series Mania competition in France . & nbsp ; But when asked whether he intends to continue acting , Rotschild said , & ldquo ; Acting is fun for me . It & rsquo ; s a kind of vacation , like taking a vacation from myself . & rdquo ; Despite his success a an actor , he said , & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s not my profession . It seems to me that people who are professional actor have to take part that are not what they really like , that are not that good , because that & rsquo ; s what they do . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I & rsquo ; m not there . I only do thing I like . So if someone brings me a part that I can connect to , I & rsquo ; ll do it gladly , it & rsquo ; s fun when you feel that you can express yourself through it . But I & rsquo ; m not an actor . I & rsquo ; m a musician who sometimes act . & ldquo ;
title: new tv series ‘ berlin blue ’ brings berlin to life

Body Text: The continued reality that 90 % of adult haredi ( ultra-Orthodox ) male are exempt from national service ha no moral , halachic , or security justification . This wa true before October 7 and ha become a critical issue since . Having formed part of the debate during the period of legal reform before the war , it is now a burning public issue.There are many people responsible for the fact that the haredi community ha been exempted for the 76 year since the creation of the State of Israel , starting with David Ben-Gurion and including pretty much every government since.But in the very real-world crisis in which Israel find itself , the issue ha crystallized due to the huge sacrifice made by conscripted and reserve soldier since October 7 and the army & rsquo ; s need for more combat force . With the immediate and long-term requirement for battle-trained soldier going up , the haredi leadership is doubling down on it rhetoric.Currently , the only thing standing between real change in government policy and the untenable status quo is the political need of the prime minister , backed by the religious Zionist party in the government . It is time for the moral mass on the political and religious right to call their leader out and demand a change of course . The fact that any change will take time to have an impact only increase the urgency for action.The country need more soldier , in particular combat soldier . In order to achieve this , the army is demanding that conscripted soldier extend their service and that those in reserve be called upon for extended period of service for the foreseeable future . There is a limited number of population that can provide additional pool for recruitment , namely , female soldier ( whose number in combat role is on the rise ) and haredi men.The government is in a bind . Public opinion is now strongly and emotively against any extension of the blanket exemption for over 60,000 haredi yeshiva student , and on the other hand , the government is politically beholden to the haredi party , which a yet remain firm in their resistance.The law allowing for the haredi exemption actually expired in June 2023 , and now there are several case before the Supreme Court calling for two measure a a result . One is to force the Defense Ministry & rsquo ; s hand and start calling up haredi men , and the second is to halt any financial support for the yeshivot , with student now legally required to enlist . Both outcome are political causus belli for the haredi parties.Raising the age of exemptionIn an attempt to stave off these sanction , the government is mulling a decision that will , among other thing , increase the age of exemption to 34 . This mean that any haredi not performing national service will not be legally allowed to work until they are 34 . Currently , the age is 26 . This will turn the clock back to 2010.Dr . Gilad Malach of the Israel Democracy Institute is an expert on government policy on conscription and haredi . He note that , in contrast to what is now being claimed by the government , not only will this not increase the number of haredi joining the IDF but it may cause the opposite . According to Malach , all the data show just the opposite . & ldquo ; History and experience have shown u that it will also have a negative impact on the quality and quantity of the haredi participation in the employment market . The later haredi seek training or employment , the less likely they will be able to train for highly skilled work , & rdquo ; he says.Alternatively , reducing the age of exemption cause more haredi to seek employment at a younger age , with the ability to skill up in order to exploit the opportunity . Instead of raising the age , Malach and all the expert would prefer that the government reduce it.Yoav Gradus , director-general of the Budget Department in Israel & rsquo ; s Ministry of Finance , issued a letter to the defense minister on Sunday , following the publication of the proposed government decision . Reports in the press stressed that the decision wa being driven without the normal professional input from relevant government ministry , which only increase the sense that the decision is purely political , without any real prospect of a positive impact on either increased participation in the army or the economy.In the letter , he is quite specific : & ldquo ; From an economic point of view , the condition connecting the non-conscription of men and their non-integration into the labor market led , a mentioned , to the creation of employment pattern that produce long-term damage to the entire economy . & rdquo ; Shaked reflects on decade of failureIn a stunning and unusually candid moment from an Israeli politician , former minister of justice Ayelet Shaked , who wa closely involved in the conscription law passed in 2014 , admitted that all her hope for the law and the process it wa meant to create have failed . & ldquo ; At the time we passed the law , the annual haredi cohort of boy numbered 8,000 , and 1,200 were conscripted . After 10 year , we didn & rsquo ; t reach ( our target of ) 6,000 . Indeed , the cohort ha grown to 12,000 , and the number of conscript is 1,800 , & rdquo ; she told a recent conference at Tel Aviv University . In the meantime , the army & rsquo ; s need have grown dramatically . & nbsp ; No magic bulletThere are no easy fix to this entrenched problem . Nobody expects or belief that mass of haredi will join the IDF immediately , no matter what policy is employed by the government . However , the need to shift course is now . At the very least , the government ha to begin the process.For this to happen , one of two thing will have to occur . Either the Likud and the Religious Zionist Party will have to force the issue with the haredi party or there will have to be election with the ball dropping into the lap of the next government . Urgency demand that this happens under the auspex of the current government . Politics determines that this is an unlikely outcome.For the first to happen , Netanyahu and Smotrich will have to switch course , the risk being that the haredi party will bolt the coalition and the government will fall . On the other hand , Gantz , Eisenkot , and perhaps Defense Minister Gallant can force their hand by either demanding a different policy or delivering an ultimatum to leave the government . Of course , election will delay the process.One way or another , there will soon be irresistible public pressure for change . This will have to include reduced government budget supporting yeshiva for haredi who do not serve and increasing budget for haredi institution and program that encourage national service , whether military or civilian . The government must support school teaching core study and social responsibility and reduce budget to school that are not preparing their student to make a full contribution to Israeli society . & nbsp ; Nobody want to see Haredim stop being loyal to their religious identity , but most Israelis are in no mood to see the status quo extended.The writer , a founding partner of Goldrock Capital , is the founder of The Institute for Jewish and Zionist Research . He is a former chair of Gesher , World Bnei Akiva , and the Coalition for Haredi Employment .
title: haredi draft issue ha made no progress , but it must - opinion

Body Text: Israel & rsquo ; s High Court of Justice on Tuesday held a significant hearing in a petition put forth by several organization against a law passed by the coalition in late December 2022 that expanded the authority of the soon-to-be , now-National Security Minister , MK Itamar Ben-Gvir.The case reached it climax after a series of procedural stage and wa heard in front of an expanded bench of nine High Court justices.It wa passed in the Knesset on December 27 , two day before the current government wa sworn in , after Ben-Gvir set it a a precondition for his joining the coalition.The law wa an amendment to Israel & rsquo ; s Police Law ( also known a the Police Ordinance ) . It anchored the police & rsquo ; s subordination to the government , a well a allowing for the national security minister to set policy and general principles.Further , it enabled the minister to set policy regarding investigation after consulting with the attorney-general , the police commissioner , and the officer responsible for investigations.The leading petitioner , the Movement for Quality Government in Israel ( MQG ) , argued at the hearing that Ben-Gvir & rsquo ; s conduct since taking office proved that the law wa dangerous , a it de facto enabled the minister to intervene in operational matter , including in the treatment of individual protesting against the government.MQG chairman Adv . Eliad Shraga said to reporter outside of the courtroom , & ldquo ; We have seen everything that we have warned against come true in the last year and a half . We have seen the minister meddling in the policy regarding investigation ; we have seen the minister meddling in operative law enforcement policy ; we have seen the minister meddling in appointment policy ; and we have seen the minister running the police . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; This is an abnormal situation where the police are effectively a militia at the service of the minister . We live in a democratic country , and so we insist that the amendment to the Police Ordinance be repealed & mdash ; that the Israel Police be an institution of the state , subject only to the rule of law , & rdquo ; Shraga punctuated.Other petitioner included Yesh Atid MKs Yoav Segalovitz and Mickey Levy , both of whom served in senior role at the police in the past ; the Labor Party ; the Association for Civil Rights in Israel ( ACRI ) ; and the High Follow-Up Committee for Arab Citizens of Israel.Adv . Aner Hellman of the Attorney-General Office & rsquo ; s High Court of Justice division argued during the hearing that the part of the law regarding investigation needed to be struck down a unconstitutional since it did not include provision to protect citizen from violation of human rights.Hellman added that the part of the law giving the minister the ability to set policy should also be struck down unless the court clarifies what exactly qualifies a & ldquo ; policy . & rdquo ; According to Hellman , & ldquo ; policy & rdquo ; must be defined in advance and can not be set during a specific addition . Moreover , the legality of these policy decision must first be deemed legal by the ministry & rsquo ; s legal adviser.A lawyer for Ben-Gvir , Adv . Nadav Haetzni , argued in response that the fact that Ben-Gvir ha made controversial policy decision since taking office doe not mean that the law itself is unconstitutional . According to Haetzni , the minister should have the right to set general policy , and if the minister gave specific operational order , these could be challenged in a separate process in the High Court.In reference to this , Hellman and others argued that illegal operational directive given by Ben-Gvir could not always be appealed in real time and that the potential for human right violation wa serious enough to render the law unconstitutional . The law should especially clarify that the police , and not the minister , were responsible for making decision in real-time regarding protest against the government.Ben-Gvir attended part of debateBen-Gvir attended part of the debate and at one point even interrupted his attorney , saying that he would not agree to be a & ldquo ; plant , & rdquo ; i.e . , a passive observer of the police & rsquo ; s action . This continued a claim made by Ben-Gvir on Tuesday that outgoing Israel Police Commissioner Yaakov Shabtai and the Attorney General & rsquo ; s Office were colluding against him to prevent him from applying his policies.Indeed , the hearing came during an ugly public spat between Shabtai and Ben-Gvir . Shabtai complained to the attorney-general in recent week that , on numerous occasion , the national security minister had illegally bypassed him and spoken directly to lower-ranking police officers.Ben-Gvir , in turn , accused Shabtai of not functioning properly since the result of the Mount Meron tragedy report were made public in March.The report found several official , including Shabtai , former public security minister Amir Ohana , and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu , personally responsible for the catastrophe in which 45 haredi were crushed to death during a mass Lag Ba & rsquo ; omer event at the grave of Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai in 2021.Shabtai himself attended the hearing and wished to speak , but the judge denied his request . Shabtai instead spoke to reporter outside . & ldquo ; I came here today out of a deep concern for the future of the Israel Police a a professional , apolitical & rdquo ; member of the police , without any specific agenda , Shabtai said . & ldquo ; I did not come here against some minister or other . I came simply to present our position about the significance and consequence of this law . Expanding the authority [ of the minister ] could affect democracy in the State of Israel , & rdquo ; he emphasized .
title: high court begin hearing on ben-gvir law , police chief expected to oppose

Body Text: A month after Operation Guardian of the Walls , the IDF continues to struggle to maintain calm in the West Bank . With Israel & rsquo ; s attention focused on the Gaza Strip , the flame of violence in the West Bank are at risk of exploding . & nbsp ; According to data released by the Shin Bet ( Israel Security Agency ) , there were 592 attack in the West Bank and another 178 in Jerusalem in the month of May , compared to a total of 104 in April ( 80 in the West Bank and 24 in Jerusalem ) . The May attack included 401 firebombings , 33 pipe bomb , 87 arson attack , 47 small-arm fire , two grenade attack , one vehicular attack and others . & nbsp ; One Israeli civilian , Yehuda Guetta , wa also killed in a shooting attack at the Tapuah junction in early May by 44-year-old Muntasir Shalabi . & nbsp ; Most of the attack that took place were not carried out by group but by lone wolf . Those kind of attack , the IDF ha admitted , are much more challenging to thwart than attack planned by group . If you don & rsquo ; t have an organization , you don & rsquo ; t have the signature of the preparation of the specific attack . & nbsp ; Despite the challenge , the great majority of attack have been thwarted by security force . But the high number of thwarted attack also indicate that the flame of violence are growing in the West Bank . & nbsp ; While there have been significantly fewer vehicular attack a well a stabbings and shooting attack against IDF soldier , they remain a major threat , especially toward driver on the road shared by both Palestinians and Israelis . & nbsp ; According to the IDF , shooting or vehicular ramming attack are more likely to be carried out by young men , and child are behind many case of stone throwing . & nbsp ; Along with the high number of attack against Israeli target , a report by Ynet news found that 34 Palestinians were killed over the past month , & ldquo ; more than during any month in the past 10 year . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Comparing the past month to the height of the wave of knife and vehicular-ramming attack that took place in 2015-2016 , an average of 26 Palestinians were killed every month . & nbsp ; SO WHAT & rsquo ; S happening ? & nbsp ; With the cancellation of the May Palestinian election in late April , the public ha lost all faith in their leader who they say have abandoned the cause a long time ago . Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas , they say , ha remained silent about the beating of protester and worshiper by Israel . & nbsp ; The reestablishment of the illegal settlement of Evyatar ha led to repeated violent clash between Israeli security force and local Palestinians . Four Palestinian teenager have been killed in recent week . & nbsp ; Like on the Gaza border , Palestinian youth have been taking part in night disturbance with loud riot and setting fire to tire . In one video uploaded to YouTube , demonstrator chant & ldquo ; Greeting from the steadfast village of Beita to the steadfast city in Gaza . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Evyatar wa reestablished by settler in April on land that historically belonged to the Palestinian village of Beita , Kabalan and Yatma . Residents have been barred from the land for decade by the Israeli military for security reason . & nbsp ; The IDF ha made it clear that the outpost will be demolished , with the IDF & rsquo ; s Central Command writing that & ldquo ; the Evyatar outpost wa established illegally , and everything wa done in complete violation of the law . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; But , even when it will be demolished , local aren & rsquo ; t holding their breath . They know that another illegal settlement will likely be built on another hill . & nbsp ; And while the fighting between Israel and the terrorist group in the Gaza Strip ended , the initial reason behind Hamas & rsquo ; s rocket fire remains : clash on the Temple Mount . Last week nine Palestinians were wounded by sponge-tipped bullet and stun grenade used by Israeli police when they clashed at the holy site . & nbsp ; While rocket are not raining down on Israel , incendiary balloon have caused dozen of fire to rage across southern Israel . & nbsp ; Hamas ha repeatedly warned that it would once again fire rocket into Israel and restart hostility over development in Jerusalem . Terrorist group on Tuesday warned that if Israel doe not allow humanitarian relief into the blockaded enclave , they will once again resort to violence . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We warn the Israeli enemy and it ally of delaying the lifting of the siege . The enemy will not succeed with it extortion policy , and we will not sit back a our people are pushed over , & rdquo ; the group said in a statement quoted by Israeli medium . & nbsp ; Hamas leader Yayha Sinwar , who met with Tor Wennesland , the UN special coordinator for the Middle East peace process , said Monday that the talk failed , and accused Israel of extortion , urging Palestinians to resist . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; It wa a bad meeting , & rdquo ; Sinwar said . It wa not positive at all , and we clarified to the [ United Nations ] delegation that we would hold a meeting of Islamic and national faction in Gaza to decide our next step . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; So while the world watch a southern Israel burn from balloon launched from Gaza , the flame are growing just a deadly in the West Bank . Israel need to get both fire under control before it & rsquo ; s too late .
title: shin bet report dramatic increase in west bank attack on israeli

Body Text: Against the backdrop of the ongoing 46th day of the war against Hamas , the question arises of how the terrorist organization perceives the large-scale ground operation carried out by the IDF in the Gaza Strip.In a conversation with Yinon Magal and Barak Seri on 103FM , Zvi Yehezkeli , the head of the Arab Desk at Channel 13 , commented on the mindset of Hamas since the outbreak of the conflict.What were they thinking when they committed the horrific massacre on October 7 ? `` Killing Jews is Yahya Sinwar 's strongest instinct . We are currently in the midst of a military operation , with the army actively engaged , showcasing an incredible fighting spirit . `` Now , let 's discus the future . As long a there is a political entity in the Gaza Strip , you will always have Hamas . You can not eradicate Hamas ; it 's deeply engrained in the Palestinian identity , more so than Fatah or anything else . If the situation in the north Gaza Strip were to replicate itself in the south Gaza Strip & ndash ; with refugee seeking protection elsewhere and finding host country & ndash ; leaving the Gaza Strip without Hamas and a large population will be impossible . `` It 's either Hamas or the people . Eventually , whoever governs the Gaza Strip will never accept your existence . No Palestinians , in any form , neither the Palestinian Authority nor a reformed Authority , will acknowledge your presence . `` What do you propose for the day after ? `` What ha happened in Gaza can also happen in the West Bank . We have a zero-sum game with the Palestinians , and if we fail to realize this , it will consume u . Even in Judea and Samaria , my friend , it 's just a matter of time . `` Just ask the resident of settlement ; they know this is coming their way . Palestinians passing by the fence warn u , ' We will do to you what they did to you in Gaza . ' I receive call from Haredi individual living in Beitar Illit , telling me , ' The Arabs are coming , and Gaza is a precursor . ' `` Understand that something ha fundamentally changed regarding Palestinian existence . They have achieved what Nasrallah did in 2000 ; they managed to enter , kill , and massacre , and we did nothing . `` Does witnessing the ongoing event in Gaza not make them think twice ? `` Their concern is not for the resident . Yahya Sinwar doe n't care that two million people have become refugee . It simply doe n't matter to him . He belief it is a noble cause , something greater than himself , and it would be a miscalculation if he doe n't pursue it . `` Hence , even if you push it towards the West Bank , even if it 's true that Abu Mazen doe n't incite them for jihad , the public will . Is Jenin no longer like Gaza ? Is Nablus no longer like Gaza ? These are small place that have embraced jihad . Jihad hold greater significance for them than anything else , even if it brings them down and backfire . `` Yehezkeli also said , `` Gaza , before the massacre , wa in a state of development . They built infrastructure and thriving building . Yet , they are willing to destroy all of it , reducing it to rubble , just to fight you . They know that eventually , you will feel remorse over their situation and leave . `` There 's an Arabic saying , ' If you want your stock to rise , deal with a Jew . They will always take care of you . ' The mercy of the Jews is something Arabs praise & ndash ; their compassion . They know we wo n't turn the table ; they know we are merciful . A soldier said to me , ' Jews kill to survive , while Arabs live to kill . ' That 's the difference . `` `` Every day the token fall to u , we are in the Middle East . This war is not a month or two , I think something strategic ha happened here , the State of Israel is about to go through a huge process for the next few year . You will not stop seeing soldier here in reserve and with weapon . `` This will not end friend , it will not end in Gaza , it will continue to Judea and Samaria . We have many more arena . What , do you think that Nasrallah ha finished his story ? `` he asked.Part of the argument for not launching a preemptive strike and a second front against Nasrallah and Hezbollah wa that `` we will dismantle Hamas `` so that those in the north will see what we are doing and not want to enter.Are you saying it make no impression on them ? `` If you end Gaza in a ' wow ' way , everyone will step back and say , ' Listen , the Jews did something that is beyond their nature , and that 's it . ' `` What is beyond nature ? `` What is beyond nature ? That no Palestinian refugee remain in the Gaza Strip . `` What ? Where will the two million go ? `` 200,000 to 10 country , what 's the problem ? Germany took in four million Syrian refugee , Europe took in another two million , Lebanon took in two million from Assad , Jordan took in Egypt . Those who protect the Palestinians all the time , what 's the problem if they take some Palestinians ? What 's the problem ? Why ca n't they ? `` You will not be able to establish your control and for the State of Israel to be safe , a long a you have an entity there that will always threaten you . Or you will once again build shield and protected room , etc . `` How is Dahlan ? Is he planning to return to Gaza ? `` I do n't know . He 's a star in Israel and among the Americans , but I think they do n't understand either . Everyone who took care of the Gaza Strip in recent year must hold themselves accountable . `` Assisted in the preparation of the article : Amitai Doak , 103fm

Body Text: Fifty-two Holocaust survivor have made aliyah throughout the past year , the Aliyah and Absorption Ministry revealed on Sunday on the eve of Holocaust Remembrance Day.Of the 52 , four made aliyah since October 7 , despite the country being at war.Russian aliyah saw a record 26 Holocaust survivor come to Israel throughout the past year , while 10 more came from Ukraine , five from France , four from the US , three from Germany , and a handful from Venezuela , Brazil , Italy , and Canada.Those who made aliyah following October 7 & nbsp ; The four Holocaust survivor who made aliyah on October 7 were from either Russia or the US.Since 1989 , 73,816 Holocaust survivor have arrived in Israel from around the world , according to Aliyah and Integration Minister Ofir Sofer . & ldquo ; We welcome the fact that precisely in these year , despite the difficulty and their age , they chose to come to our national home , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; I see their arrival in Israel a & lsquo ; closing a circle & rsquo ; and a victory for them and the Jewish people . & rdquo ; The aliyah of Holocaust survivor is no ordinary occurrence in the State of Israel , and the ministry handle such case accordingly . As such , Holocaust survivor who make aliyah , or immigrate to Israel , receive special support , including eligibility for a one-year advancement in the waiting list for public housing , financial grant , and assistance.Assistance given to Holocaust survivor who make aliyah & nbsp ; Sofer said that this year , when highlighting Holocaust Remembrance Day amid the Israel-Hamas war , there wa proof that & ldquo ; even 79 year after the end of the terrible Holocaust , there are many who wish to destroy u . & rdquo ; He continued , & ldquo ; During the commemoration of the memory of our brother and sister & ndash ; the six million who were murdered on European soil just for being Jews & ndash ; we remember what is incumbent upon u : To secure the future of the Jewish people , to protect our country , and to quickly return the hostage to their home . & rdquo ;

Body Text: The image coming from Israel of a massive fire south of Ashkelon , a bus blown up , fire near a gas station and also interception near the airport are a message to the region . & nbsp ; They appear to show an Israel that is more vulnerable than at any time in recent memory . One might have to reach back to 2009 or 2006 for this sense , but even then it wa regional . This ha serious ramification because Iran and Hezbollah may think that Israel is weaker than it is . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Images are important . The image of Israeli police in al-Aqsa Mosque helped to create an excuse for violence . There have been clash in Haifa , Lod , Ramle , Acre , Nazareth and other city in Israel . There have been clash in the South in Bedouin community and attack on a synagogue . People have been injured and several shot . This is a reminder of the era of the riot that set off the Second Intifada , which also swept Israel . It is a reminder of vulnerability . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; For the medium that are pro-Iran , the narrative is clear . Al-Mayadeen celebrates that Israel wa & ldquo ; astonished & rdquo ; by the huge volume of rocket fire . Pro-Iran commentator say Israel ha a failed leadership . Tehran & rsquo ; s leadership is saying Israel understands only force and that & ldquo ; resistance is the sole way & rdquo ; to confront the Jewish state . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Images showing celebration in Jerusalem and in Umm el-Fahm by Arab demonstrator are also being broadcast in the region . & nbsp ; This ha implication that are broader than whether Hamas ha achieved much with firing more than 700 rocket . It may be that the actual damage is not so large in comparison to what it could have been . However , the overall story is about image and narrative . & nbsp ; The narrative in Israel is to cast doubt on the leadership , question whether the prime minister ha empowered Hamas and whether Iron Dome is able to stop enough rocket . These question lead to what might happen in a conflict with Hezbollah . & nbsp ; The hesitancy of the government to strike back at Gaza also enables the focus to remain on the destruction wrought between Tel Aviv and Ashkelon .

Body Text: Relationships developed between Israel and Qatar to provide sufficient funding to Hamas and avoid an economic collapse and war in the Gaza Strip could be the engine for normalization between Jerusalem and Doha , The Jerusalem Post ha learned . Pressed that in November , Qatar rejected any imminent normalization with Israel , source told the Post confidently that this would likely change during the incoming Biden administration & rsquo ; s term . Further , they said that close coordination between Israel and Qatar to facilitate sufficient funding for Hamas to keep Gaza & rsquo ; s weak economy from collapsing will likely be the key to moving Doha to a normalization deal . Ironically , even a Hamas is committed to Israel & rsquo ; s destruction and periodically fire rocket at Israeli town and city , the strange dynamic with Gaza & rsquo ; s ruler could help bring a legitimacy coup for Israel with the state that run the influential Al Jazeera network . Qatar ha long been a focal point for many party in the Middle East and Doha ha been in a diplomatic and economic war with Saudi Arabia and other moderate Sunni Gulf country since June 2017 . In mid-December , Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas met with Qatari Emir , Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani , to try to convince him to host a peace conference in 2021 . The idea would be to move the conversation back from the Trump peace plan to the previous conventional Palestinian-Western plan for peace . Surrounding all these contact with Qatar is the fact that the US maintains close relation , including it key military base in the Middle East , in Qatar . The combination of a US connection along with Qatar & rsquo ; s ability to keep Hamas from starting a broad war , a occurred three time between 2009-2014 , wa part of what made Israel , through the Mossad , ready to deal with Doha on Gaza issue . This wa in spite of Jerusalem & rsquo ; s unhappiness with many of the more Islamist cause and group which Qatar support , including that it ha a strong relationship with Iran . With Israel & rsquo ; s approval , and often with Mossad Director Yossi Cohen & rsquo ; s personal involvement , Qatar ha periodically provided million of dollar in cash to Hamas to keep it economic situation stable so that it will not want war . When Hamas grew anxious that the payment would end in August , Cohen reportedly even took an especially active role to convince Doha to continue them , despite economic issue in Qatar related to the pandemic . When attacked by some on the Right that the Mossad and Israel are serving a a middle-man to fund Hamas , Cohen ha pushed back hard saying that the fund are humanitarian and that complex decision are preferable to war . Sources also indicated that there could be a breakthrough in unfreezing relation between Qatar and the Saudi-led Gulf state coalition a early a next week , while Trump is still in office . Statements by official on the possibility of Israeli-Qatari normalization have to date been mixed . In October , US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin visited Qatar but declined to tell the Israeli medium anything definitive about whether Qatar would be the next country to normalize tie with Israel or whether the US will sell it F-35 stealth jet . Also in October , Intelligence Minister Eli Cohen told Army Radio that to preserve it qualitative military edge , Israel will ask the US not to sell F-35 fighter jet to Qatar . & ldquo ; For u , our region still hasn & rsquo ; t become Switzerland . Israel is the most threatened country , not only in the Middle East , but in the whole world , and a such , we need to preserve our superiority , & rdquo ; he said . In mid-December , Rabbi Marc Schneier , an unofficial envoy for normalization with Gulf state , told the Post : & ldquo ; I won & rsquo ; t be content until I see Qataris , Saudis , Omanis and Kuwaitis join a well . Then , you will see a transformation . & rdquo ; Qatar is preparing for the World Cup , and Schneier think it is a natural fit for Israel . & ldquo ; Qataris are very excited about welcoming Israelis for the World Cup , & rdquo ; he said . Body Text: The family of a 21-year-old man who the Lebanese authority say wa killed by Israeli fire when he and a group of others tried to cross the border fence with Israel held his funeral on Saturday , a day after he died . The IDF identified a group of protester who left object near the border that they suspected were explosive device . Three suspect cut the border fence and crossed into Israel where they were joined by another four suspect ; they then started a fire inside Israeli territory , which spread to Lebanese territory . & ldquo ; The behavior of the suspect indicated that they were planning to commit a terror attack in Metulla , & rdquo ; the military said in a statement . During the event , the IDF shot one suspect identified by Hezbollah & rsquo ; s news outlet Al-Manar a Mohammad Tahhan in the leg . He wa identified by the IDF a a Hezbollah member . The incident took place during a protest on the Lebanese side to support Palestinians , amid a conflict between Israel and Hamas , the Islamist group which rule Gaza . And the event came a day after three rocket were fired from southern Lebanon , landing in the sea off of the northern coast of Israel . Hezbollah distanced itself from the rocket fire ; it is believed that a Palestinian group fired the rocket . Members of his family , dressed in black and wearing face mask to prevent the spread of the coronavirus , gathered around the coffin of Mohamed Tahan in his home town of Adloun , in southern Lebanon , to bid farewell , Reuters image showed . A large poster at the mourning ceremony wa emblazoned with his picture , alongside a symbol of the Iranian-backed Lebanese group Hezbollah , which is a staunch opponent of Israel . The poster carried the word : & quot ; On the way to Al-Quds ( Jerusalem ) . & quot ; Protesters gathered again on Lebanon side of border with Israel on Saturday , waving Palestinian and Hezbollah flag . UNIFIL , the UN peacekeeping force in Lebanon that monitor the boundary with Israel , said on Friday it had launched an immediate investigation into the incident . Anna Ahronheim contributed to this report .
title: funeral held of man lebanon say wa killed by israeli fire on border

Body Text: The Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs ( JCPA ) ha launched a new initiative titled `` Speaking Middle East , `` which is designed specifically for Israeli university student . This initiative provides a unique opportunity for young Israelis from various academic background to delve into the complexity of the Arab and Muslim world.The program target Israeli student , typically in their third year or beyond , who will have the chance to learn from a distinguished faculty that includes Israeli diplomat , journalist , security personnel , and even former government officials.Some of the program 's prominent figure include Jason Greenblatt , a previous US envoy to the Middle East , and Brig . Gen . Yossi Kuperwasser , who formerly headed the research division of the Israel Defense Forces ' Intelligence Corps.At the program 's inauguration , Israel 's Agriculture and Rural Development Minister , Avi Dichter , stressed the significance of looking beyond language acquisition . `` Beyond learning the Arabic language , it is essential to understand the Arab mindset , which differs from ours . The student of this new course will have a unique opportunity to do so with the expertise of top professional in the field . I applaud this amazing initiative , which will enable you to represent Israel honorably in the Arab world , `` he said.The JCPA created the program after recognizing a growing need for Israeli student to bridge the cultural divide with their Arab neighbor . This need became particularly evident after the outbreak of the current war when the center actively disseminated information to the international community . `` With the start of the war , the concept ha changed , and the Arabic language and culture have become important and even essential tool for every Israeli , especially those seeking to participate in Israel 's effort in the Middle East , `` said Middle East expert and Vice president of the JCPA Aviram Bellaishe . `` This is particularly necessary for analyzing threat and risk in order to understand ' Middle Eastern thinking , ' to build bridge with regional country and expand the historical Abraham Accords , `` he added . `` Speaking Middle East `` offer a comprehensive curriculum tailored towards Israeli student , which includes course in spoken Arabic , diplomacy , Islamic study , and international law.Workshops , field trip , and even a homestay experience with an Arab family are also incorporated . Upon completing their academic specialization , graduate will have the opportunity to join a regional leadership program.The program ha attracted over 40 Israeli student from across the country , representing diverse field such a Middle Eastern study , international relation , engineering , and computer science.Khaled Abu Toameh , a former Jerusalem Post Palestinian affair correspondent , course leader , and specialist in Arab society and communication , commented on the program 's unique approach for Israeli student . & nbsp ; `` Participants who join the program will meet and interact directly with Israeli diplomat , journalist , and commentator , a well a those from the Arab and Muslim world . At the end of the program , they will not only be able to speak Arabic fluently but also understand regional thinking . & rdquo ; What is the Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs ? The Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs specializes in policy , diplomacy , and communication . Since it inception in 1976 , the JCPA ha evolved from primarily focusing on regional security , strategy , and international law research.The center actively cultivates both overt and covert strategic partnership with key figure from Arab and Muslim nation and remains a pivotal force in combating BDS and global antisemitism
title: changing mindset : new program teach israeli student arabic language and culture

Body Text: The & ldquo ; Maslul Batuah & rdquo ; ( Safe Route ) operation , which set out to stem the tide of crime in Arab community , spanning joint effort of nine governmental office , ha recorded impressive stride since it initiation eight month ago.Last year , the violence in the sector exploded to a dramatic peak of 130 murder & ndash ; on average , a person wa murdered in Arab society every three day . Weapons seemed to flow freely in Arab town , in what to local felt like a lawless land , but since the Safe Route crackdown , the police say they have turned the tide and restored law and order.But are the operation & rsquo ; s effect really felt in Arab community a the police claim ? In the enforcement of the operation , mostly in the North , 3,871 suspect were arrested , thousand of weapon were seized , and 1,153 indictment were filed for weapon offense across Israel.Since the beginning of the year , the police have increased their activity against weapon crime in Arab community . In the past half-year ( January-June 2022 ) , the police across the country arrested 3,871 suspect for crime of armed robbery and shooting , and about 92 % of the suspect arrested were from the Arab community.Also , in the first half of 2022 , at the end of the police investigation , 1,153 indictment were filed against those accused of shooting and assault offense all over the country . About 88 % of the indictment filed for the offense of shooting and possession , trafficking and use of weapon were filed against defendant from Arab society.In addition , 31 illegal building were destroyed , a total of NIS 10 million wa confiscated , and , a part of the fight against road crime , over 8,000 traffic fine with a total value of over NIS 5m . were distributed . & ldquo ; Since the beginning of Operation Safe Route , the Israel Police ha recorded significant achievement in dealing with crime and violence in Arab community , in dealing with crime of extortion through threat and seizure of firearm held against the law . & rdquo ; Leon Hirsch & ldquo ; Since the beginning of Operation Safe Route , the Israel Police ha recorded significant achievement in dealing with crime and violence in Arab community , in dealing with crime of extortion through threat and seizure of firearm held against the law , & rdquo ; said Ch . - Supt . Leon Hirsch , head of the Operational Coordination Section in the Police Intelligence Division . & ldquo ; The Israel Police ha also recorded significant achievement in filing indictment for these crime which constitute a significant nuisance to the public in Arab community . Since the operation began , there ha been a much higher demand for police service , and we see this in the response we receive from the resident , & rdquo ; he added.Seizing weapon , arresting criminalsDuring this period in 2022 , ten of thousand of weapon , explosive , ammunition , grenade and other illegal item were seized in town of Arab community , including 770 handgun , and more than 100 submachine gun and 350 gun of different type , thousand of item of ammunition , a well a hundred of grenade , weapon part and explosive & ndash ; a significant increase when compared to the same time period in 2021.The operation ha been carried out so far in 19 locality , including Haifa , Umm el-Fahm , Nazareth and Rahat.After almost half of 2022 ha passed , data show that the extensive operation launched by the police to eradicate violence resulted in success & ndash ; at least partially : until June 5 , 31 people in the Arab community were murdered in Israel , including four woman , compared to 50 murdered in the first half of 2021 ( up to May 27 to be exact ) . In total , according to police data , since the beginning of the year , 42 people have been murdered throughout the country , of which , a mentioned , 31 were from Arab society . So far the police have solved only 12 murder case in the Arab sector this year . The police attribute this decrease in the number of murder in the sector to the operation.Murder on the riseDespite the effort police have put forward , some remain skeptical about the actual effect they have , a murder case in Arab society continue to rise , hitting 55 murder up until July , according to data from independent NGOs.WHILE POLICE action are at the forefront of the operation , it is much larger in scope when looked at from a broader lens . Efforts of the Finance Ministry and income tax official , for example , set out to combat money laundering and illegal loan , which in turn entangle many civilian . & ldquo ; Many Arab town in the North don & rsquo ; t even have a bank or any other mean of legally handling financial affair . Left out of option , they turn to organized criminal syndicate , & rdquo ; Ola Najami-Yousef & ldquo ; Many Arab town in the North don & rsquo ; t even have a bank or any other mean of legally handling financial affair . Left out of option , they turn to organized criminal syndicate , & rdquo ; Ola Najami-Yousef , vice president of the Abraham Initiative NGO , which track crime in Arab community , told the Magazine in an interview.The issue , she explained , is much larger than a simple lack of policing . The Arab community have long faced neglect from all governmental office , from finance to education . Residents are often left to their own device , something that leaf a large vacuum for criminal to fill.Arabs were viewed a a security threat themselvesBefore Safe Route wa initiated , Arabs were viewed a a & ldquo ; security threat themselves . Even though a lot of these issue were well known to the government , nothing wa done , until now . & ldquo ; The way Arab society is viewed and discussed ha changed ; we & rsquo ; re no longer social pariah , and a wide range of effort is now being undertaken to give Arab community what they rightfully deserve a Israeli citizen , & rdquo ; she said.THE PROBLEM with crime in the community often stemmed from this larger perspective that painted Arabs a a collective threat.Even if a plain citizen got entangled with criminal element on account of a lack of service , he had no one to turn to when thing turned sour , a situation that not only left an opening for crime on it own but also severely hurt the community & rsquo ; trust in the police , further increasing the reign of criminals.In town like Nazareth , where Najami-Yousef life , you could hardly notice police presence , and town like Jisr e-Zarka didn & rsquo ; t even have a functional police station , even though the building for it existed.Now , police are making effort to increase their presence , understanding that the lack of trust from local severely impact how well they could combat crime effectively.The change is certainly being felt.Jasser & rsquo ; s police station , which had been vacant until now , is fully staffed , and town like Rahat and Nazareth are seeing more patrol car on the street . Najami-Yousef , a resident of Nazareth herself , even stated that & ldquo ; you could even hear less gunfire in Nazareth these day . & rdquo ; To further the bond with the community , the Abraham Initiative ha organized meeting between teen and police officer from local station . The change , Najami-Yousef said , is slowly starting to take effect.But when looking at the still high murder rate which claimed the life of 11 Arabs in the last month , one could question the effectiveness of this change . & ldquo ; These thing take time , & rdquo ; Najami-Yousef explained . & ldquo ; It may take up to five year until we would see a practical change in murder . & rdquo ; Najami-Yousef even theorized that the latest chain of murder could be a direct response to police effort , with criminal organization feeling the pressure and , in turn , attempting to clean house.Police official claimed , on the other hand , that the operation ha attained significant achievement , and that the decrease in the number of murder is felt & ldquo ; everywhere & rdquo ; in the Arab sector.One of the reason for this , according to them , is that budget are now being diverted to combating violence in the sector , making it possible to strengthen the force stationed in the Arab community and also recruit Arabs directly to the police . & ldquo ; In the last five year , 800 Muslims have been recruited to the Israel Police . Today the police can react quickly when case of violence occur , & rdquo ; a police official said . & ldquo ; Along with the continuation of enforcement and it deepening , in order to deal with the phenomenon and completely deter it , a multisystemic treatment and a deep-rooted change beyond police enforcement are needed , & rdquo ; said Ch . - Supt . Hirsch . & ldquo ; The Israel Police will continue the determined fight in Arab society and everywhere else , all in order to maintain public peace and security . & rdquo ; ■
title: have israel 's police helped stem the tide of arab sector crime ?

Body Text: Rachel Goldberg , whose 23-year old son Hersh Polin Goldberg wa taken hostage from the Nova music festival on October 7 , invoked Cain and Abel a well a the Holocaust in a fiery speech at the Israel rally last Tuesday in Washington , DC , advocating for more activism on behalf of the hostages.Goldberg , who emigrated from Virginia to Israel with her family when Hersh wa eight , ha been one of the most vocal family member of hostage to speak out on the international stage on behalf of the hostage ' plight . A couple of week after the massacre , she wa the focus of a 35-minute podcast episode of The New York Times ' `` The Daily , `` in which she recounted in detail the event of the day , what they knew about her son 's condition , and story of unity and love among the family member of the kidnapped and dead & mdash ; who through their shared circumstance have become a community of their own.Posters of Hersh & mdash ; larger and more distinct than the typical `` kidnapped `` sign featuring different hostage & mdash ; have been displayed in many place throughout Israel and the world . & nbsp ; `` Right now , how we are living is hard to describe to you , `` Goldberg told the crowd of nearly 300,000 at the National Mall in Washington last Tuesday . `` We hostage family have lived the last 39 day in slow motion torment . For 38 night none of u have slept the real sleep of ' the before . ' We all have third-degree burn on our soul . Our heart are bruised and seeping with misery . `` But the real soul suffering are those of the hostage , `` she continued . `` And they want to ask everyone in the world & mdash ; all the screamer , the indifferent , the expert , the academic , the knowledgeable , the passive , the perfectly outraged , the righteous , the indignant , the hater , the leader , the lover & mdash ; every single one of u : Why ? Why is the world accepting that 240 human being from almost 30 country have been stolen and buried alive ? `` These child of God ranged in age from nine month to 87 year . They are Christians , Muslims , Jews , Buddhists and Hindu . Why are they being left underground in the dirt ? `` she asked . `` Abigail Mor Idan is three year old ; she watched her parent get murdered in front of her and wa then kidnapped , and she would like me to ask the world , why are you letting her stay in the dark in her trauma , buried in the Earth 's crust ? `` she asked . `` And Joshua Mollel , who is a Tanzanian African graduate student studying agribusiness , would like for me to ask you why somehow his life actually doe n't matter . When he wa asked why he risked so much to do this , he answered : `` at least I will know when I die and stand before God , He will not ask me what he asked Cain in the Bible : ' Where were you when your brother 's blood cried out from the ground ? ' `` What the world need to start thinking about today is , ' what will your excuse be ? ' ``
title: ' what will your excuse be ? ' : gaza hostage 's mother urge world to help

Body Text: Palestinian security prisoner held in Israeli jail are planning a series of measure this week to protest the alleged failure of the Israel Prisons Service ( IPS ) to improve their conditions.The move could escalate tension between Palestinians and Israel , especially in the wake of call by several Palestinian group to hold rally in support of the prisoners.What are the claim made by the Palestinians ? The restriction include , among other thing , solitary confinement and the transfer of dozen of inmate to other prisons.The prisoner then announced a series of protest against the restriction and threatened to go on a hunger strike.Last March , however , they agreed to suspend their protest after reportedly receiving a promise from the IPS to ease the restrictions.On Sunday , the Palestinian Prisoners Club , a group that support the security prisoner , said the inmate would resume their protest on Monday.It said they would refuse to leave their cell for routine security check & ldquo ; a a step of disobedience against the prison administration law . & rdquo ; What 's next for the Palestinian prisoner ? The next stage of the protest will begin in two week when the prisoner are expected to go on an open-ended hunger strike.More than 1,000 prisoner are scheduled to participate in the hunger strike , the group claimed.Palestinian source said the prisoner who are planning to participate in the protest belong to all the Palestinian faction , including Hamas , Palestinian Islamic Jihad and the ruling Fatah faction headed by Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas.The source said the prisoner formed an & ldquo ; emergency national committee & rdquo ; after the IPS imposed a number of sanction on them in response to the Gilboa Prison jailbreak , during which six inmate escaped through a tunnel they dug inside their cell . All the fugitive were later captured by Israeli authorities.Since then , the prisoner claim , the IPS ha been moving many of them every few week to different prison a part of punitive and preemptive measure designed to prevent another escape.The Palestinian Prisoners Club called on Palestinians to support the prisoner in their struggle against the restriction imposed by the IPS.The planned protest come a three security prisoner are continuing their hunger strike in Israeli jails.One of them , Khalil Awawdeh , 40 , ha been refusing food for nearly six month .
