Body Text: Lines of freshly planted tree . Israeli flag , each at a different height on a stick above where a tree will one day grow , fly in the wind . It & rsquo ; s been six month since the Nova festival massacre took place here.On each flag is printed the name of one of the victim who wa killed here , or in the nearby forest and field , during the massacre . Meanwhile , the sound of artillery can be heard in the distance . By this late point in the day , the military had already announced that it wa rotating force out of Gaza.A sense of change , noted by the passage of half a year , can be felt here . Time continues to pas , and each day end , but there is no closure for the family , who are left in limbo while Hamas continues to hold 134 hostages.On Sunday morning , family of the Nova victim gathered at the site . They talked of the feeling of abandonment they experienced , especially from the government ; they talked of pain , of getting treatment for that pain . They spoke about how this massacre could have been prevented , and how difficult it is to return to life.Right then wa when the news broke that a mourner & rsquo ; s wreath wa sent to the family of 19-year-old hostage Liri Albag , blaming the government for the lack of a deal . The Shin Bet ( Israel Security Agency ) later said it suspected Iranian force were behind it . It wa a if the news hammered home just how deeply wrong it is that this is still the situation six month later.How can it be that six month into the war the hostage are held just across the border from where I am standing ? Gaza is not very large , so wherever you stand along the border , you are always a few mile from the coast and not far from Rafah . There are 134 people across the border ; IDF unit are being withdrawn . Israeli citizen were promised that & ldquo ; there won & rsquo ; t be any more Hamas & rdquo ; when the war wa over , and that military pressure would lead to the release of the hostage . From the border , it is obvious that neither ha come to pass.For me , Sunday wa a return to a border I & rsquo ; ve been to many time since October 7 , a well a before the war a well . Back in 2005 , before the Disengagement from Gaza , I visited Netzer Hazani , a settlement in Gaza near Khan Yunis.Border region became a target for HamasAfterward , this border region became a target for Hamas ; rocket rained down on Sderot . This a place where there were many war : in 2009 , 2012 , 2014 , and briefly in 2021 ; it always carried danger . At Kibbutz Nirim , a resident told of threat dating back to the 1970s . There wa always a threat from Gaza , but there were also time of peace and effort at coexistence.The sense on Sunday , at Nova , is that all that is broken . The festival ground today are made up of various memorial , like the new section of tree that will grow and an area of photo of the victim , staked in the ground so that each victim ha their area.Besides the few monument , such a some bench and individual make-shift memorial people have left , or graffiti on a concrete bunker , much remains a it would have been before the festival . There are tree with no undergrowth ; there is a dirt road running down Route 232 , which run parallel to the border . It wa on this dirt road , from the festival ground to the main road , where car would have been stacked up on October 7 after the festival organizer stopped the music and told everyone to run and hide.I look around among the tree and think about the thousand of people fleeing ; their desperation and confusion . The area is familiar to me from the many video that came out that morning ; the bathroom where people hid , the bar where people were massacred , the field that people tried to drive through and flee through , the rescuer & ndash ; like the Davidians & ndash ; who came and saved people.Six month later , this conjures up the ghost of the past , the spirit that roam this forest now . Nearby Kibbutz Mefalsim had almost 1,000 resident on October 7 . Like Kfar Aza , it wa a place people wanted to live . The resident in many of these community say that these kibbutz were 95 % heaven and 5 % hell & ndash ; before October 7.Today , many of them are empty and lack resident & ndash ; proud , peace-loving people who were evacuated . At Mefalsim , there is a sign supporting the & ldquo ; Kaplan & rdquo ; protester , the anti-Netanyahu camp . These kibbutz are proud of their heritage . In a small building housing the archive of Mefalsim , there is a photo of the bolt-action rifle acquired by the Jewish state via Czechoslovakia in 1948 that helped defend Israel.On October 7 , the member of the security team , using modern rifle , defended this community successfully from the terrorist . In many case , the terrorist assigned group of 30-40 men to attack each border community . When they didn & rsquo ; t succeed in some place , there wa no second wave . When they did succeed , such a breaking into Kfar Aza , wave of men came from Gaza to loot and murder.In Sderot , terrorist shot upon entry , firing bullet at the street , targeting the police station in a battle that went on for hour into the night . The building eventually burned down . Residents had to hide indoors for several day amidst fear that infiltrator were still inside . Eventually , the city of 30,000 wa evacuated . Six month later , it recovered a lot : many resident returned , and there were even traffic jam downtown . But the sign of war remain & ndash ; soldier stand at the city entrance , checking cars.In Ofakim , around 30 minute away from Gaza by car , one particular neighborhood saw an intense gunfight ; more than two dozen people were killed in different incident . In total , around 50 resident of the city were killed , some in a bus for retiree that wa traveling to the Dead Sea from Ofakim through Sderot . The bus wa attacked , and the people were killed . Police officer in Ofakim were killed a well . In one neighborhood , the terrorist attacked several home . Residents helped defend the city and eventually , the terrorist were hunted down.Back on the border with Nirim , the small , 240-person community , it is quiet , but eerily so , like a ghost town . The kibbutz minimarket ha been reopened , and the customer are mostly soldier who come over from unit stationed nearby . Several green parrot inhabit a tree , apparently escaped pet . Other former pet are wandering around , including a cat that wouldn & rsquo ; t stop following me . Wild dog had infiltrated from Gaza on October 7 , following the marauding looters.In contrast to Sderot and Nova , field of memory , Nirim is almost deserted , the burned home on one side of the kibbutz unchanged since October 7 , cleared on October 10 and 11 of bodies.In the background , like a whisper , ring concern about what come next in Gaza , with the IDF decision to pull out Battalion 98 , though the military remains steadfast in it goal , holding a a stark symbol of a lack of strategy , a symbol that haunt these roads.I drive back along the 232 , the same road the terrorist would have driven on ; it is quiet today . Six month ago , this wa a road of death . No matter how much the field are full of green today , and the orchard of orange are pregnant with fruit , this place will always hold the massacre it witnessed . & nbsp ;
title: reporter 's notebook : the gaza border , six month after oct . 7

Body Text: A majority of Israelis would like to see Prime Minister Naftali Bennett reignite the Israeli-Palestinian peace process by meeting with PA president Mahmoud Abbas , according to a December poll by the Geneva Initiative . Amongst 504 responder , 51 % would support a potential meeting between the prime minister and Abbas , while 39 % would oppose such a meeting . Interestingly , 40 % of Bennett 's right-wing party Yamina 's voter also support a Bennett-Abbas meeting . & nbsp ; In addition , 43 % of responder noted that a move towards peace with the Palestinians would broaden support for the Bennett-Lapid government among Israelis . In contrast , 37 % said it would decrease support . If a meeting between Abbas and Bennett wa to happen , the prime minister would not be the first in the current government to meet the PA president . In August , Defense Minister Benny Gantz held a rare meeting with Abbas in Ramallah . Unsurprisingly , a large share of voter affiliated with more left-leaning party , such a Labor , Yesh Atid and Gantz 's Blue and White , stated they would support the government if such a move wa made . Responders were also asked about the handling of terrorist organization Hamas , the Palestinian public and Donald Trump 's comment on Netanyahu . Almost half of responder ( 49 % ) stated they support a transparent , open approach to a dialog with Hamas , while 40 % stated they oppose any dialog . & nbsp ; Out of the responder who support talk , 57 % of responder stated that dialog with Hamas would be beneficial to gain insight on the Palestinian public , while 43 % disagreed with that statement . Lastly , two-thirds of responder ( 67 % ) stated they agree that opposition head Benjamin Netanyahu `` never wanted to make peace , `` a stated by former US president Trump . The poll wa ordered by Geneva Initiative , an Israeli NGO dedicated to solving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict , and conducted by Mano Geva 's market research company Midgam .
title: majority want return to israeli-palestinian peace process - poll

Body Text: Israel Police are investigating the cause of death of a woman in her 50 whose body wa found early Monday morning in the & nbsp ; Reihan Forest in the northern West Bank . The police and Shin Bet ( Israel Security Agency ) are reportedly evaluating whether the murder might have been a terrorist attack . & quot ; We wake up to a difficult and painful event in the northern Shomron , & quot ; said MK & nbsp ; Betzalel Smotrich upon hearing the news . & quot ; We send our condolence to the family of the 14th murdered woman [ this year ] and ask to embrace and strengthen the resident of Tal Menashe and the entire Shomron community . & quot ; The security force will , with God @ @ @ s help , get their hand on the perpetrator of this terrible attack and bring them justice , & quot ; the MK concluded . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; The woman , Esther Hurgan , wa a resident of Tel Menashe , a town near the forest . Her body wa found on the side of the road in the forest , marked by sign of violence , including to her head . Her family reported her missing on Sunday . She leaf behind her husband , Benyamin , and six child . Her youngest child celebrated his bar mitzvah just three month ago . IDF soldier were called to the scene alongside police after the body wa found . The Samaria Regional Council referred to the incident a a terrorist attack , adding that Hurgan wa found overnight with & quot ; her head crushed . & quot ; & nbsp ; & quot ; A dear woman so full of kindness , go out in the afternoon in the center of the State of Israel to exercise a minute away from her home , and is murdered by vile people in such a cruel way , & quot ; said the head of the Samaria Regional Council , Yossi Dagan . & quot ; I ask @ @ @ what barbarian , like in the Middle Ages , what cruelty to hack the face of a 52-year-old woman with a rock in cold-blood ? What evil are we facing ? @ @ @ & quot ; He added : & quot ; I want to say clearly to these barbarian from the Palestinian Authority in front of the whole world : you will never break u . The settlement in Samaria will flourish and grow and build together with the whole State of Israel , because you in the barbaric Palestinian Authority chose death and we chose life . You act like barbarian from the Middle Ages & ndash ; and we are in 2020 and the people of Israel will win . & quot ; & quot ; The late Esther Hurgan wa brutally murdered when she went for a run near her home , & quot ; said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in response to the incident . & quot ; The security force will get their hand on the killer a soon a possible and we will bring him to justice . I would like to send my deepest condolence to the family . & quot ; & quot ; I send my deepest sympathy to the Horgan family on the horrific murder of Esther , of blessed memory , & quot ; said Alternate Prime Minister Benny Gantz in response to the incident . & quot ; Israel & rsquo ; s security force are working to find the despicable murderer and take him promptly into custody . We will never accept a reality in which human life becomes dispensable . & quot ; President Reuven Rivlin commented on the murder , saying : & quot ; This is a hard , heart-breaking morning with news of the cruel murder of Esther Hurgan , who left her house yesterday and did not return . A full life of wonderful work & ndash ; of home and family , of creativity and care & ndash ; ha been cut short by a beast in human guise . I have full faith that our security force will get to the despicable murder and that justice will be done . I embrace Esther @ @ @ s family , her child and their father . We are with you in this time of such deep grief . & quot ; & quot ; Esther went out yesterday a she wa used to , to walk in nature , which she loved so much here around the settlement , & quot ; said Benyamin , Esther @ @ @ s husband . & quot ; No adventurous deed , a walking trail like every normal place in the country & ndash ; and she did not return . It doe not suit her , so full of life and light and love for everyone , and all this is cut off in an instant . Who can do such a thing ? & quot ; & nbsp ; & quot ; We should all be here in the settlement in the regional council , all the people of Israel , and give the appropriate Zionist answer to act of destruction and killing with more light , more life , more construction , more creation , and more action on the ground for our child and all the people of Israel , & quot ; he stressed . & nbsp ; & quot ; Esther raised a family for glory , loved her grandchild and now they will have no mother , no grandmother , & quot ; the bereaved husband said . & quot ; Esther will be missed by all of u , the family and everyone who knew her . Before I knew what wa going on , I got message from all sort of people how much she touched them and how much she did . We see the great success of the family and of the community in general , and that is largely due to her . & quot ; & quot ; We start the morning with the sad news of the brutal murder of Esther Hurgan , a mother of six , last night in Samaria . It can not be that a woman go for a run and doe not return home , & quot ; said Jerusalem Affairs Minister Rafi Peretz . & quot ; I trust the security and police force to lay hand on the perpetrator of this heinous crime , and I send my condolence to the grieving family . & quot ; & quot ; The murder of Esther Hurgan , a mother of six , is heartbreaking . Such cruelty and evil , & quot ; said opposition leader Yair Lapid . & quot ; I send condolence to the family and am sure that the security force will catch the heinous killer . & quot ; & quot ; My heart weeps over the murder of the late Esther Hurgan , a mother of six from Samaria & ndash ; all she did wa go for a run near her home , & quot ; said Yisrael Beytenu leader Avigdor Liberman . & quot ; I send my condolence to the family and hope that the IDF and the security force will reach those responsible for the murder soon . & quot ;
title: woman @ @ @ s body found in west bank forest , police investigating terror attack

Body Text: Winner of the prestigious Rechter Prize for Young Architects , Daniel Zarhy ( 43 ) hail from a prestigious lineage of architect . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I am , in fact , the fourth generation in my family to pursue architecture , & rdquo ; he shared in an interview with The Jerusalem Post , shortly after clinching the esteemed Rechter Prize for young architects.Zarhy won the prize for designing the Faculty of Engineering at the Tel Aviv University . The judge & rsquo ; reasoning stated that & ldquo ; The project harness innovative engineering thinking , brilliantly intertwining technological and ecological perspective , and fostering a genuinely distinctive architectural outcome . By creatively reinterpreting the modernist context of the campus structure in a contemporary light , Zarhy & rsquo ; s project reflects current global trend . The exceptional level of design and execution showcased by the project stand out prominently , deserving commendation within the Israeli context . & rdquo ; Zarhy explained with pride , & ldquo ; My great-grandfather wa Ze & rsquo ; ev Rechter . He met my grandfather , Moshe Zarhy , when they studied together at the Technion . Moshe married Rechter & rsquo ; s sister , and they established a firm that later split and wa continued by my father . & rdquo ; Zarhy graduated with honor from Tel Aviv University & rsquo ; s School of Architecture . In 2012 , after working for renowned office such a OMA & ndash ; Rem Koolhaas in Rotterdam and Herzog & amp ; De Meuron in Basel , he founded Studio PEZ together with Pedro Pe & ntilde ; a.The studio ha won numerous international competition , among them : The Jerusalem Courthouse , Ideas competition for a New Opera House in Busan , S . Korea , Broadcom & rsquo ; s R & amp ; D Center at Tel Aviv University , and most recently the campus for Bern & rsquo ; s University of Applied Science ( in collaboration with Wulf Architetken ) . Zarhy said that working abroad ha influenced his work tremendously . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I am influenced both by my family & rsquo ; s heritage & ndash ; I practically had architecture streaming in my vein since childhood & ndash ; and my work experiance , which gave me new and different perspective . When you work in a big international firm with people who hail from around the globe , and everyone brings their point of view , it open your mind , you get new idea . & rdquo ; Zarhy and Pe & ntilde ; a established STUDIOPEZ International Architecture Studio in 2012 & ndash ; now based in Basel , Switzerland , and Tel-Aviv & ndash ; a a continuation of their ongoing collaboration while working at Herzog & amp ; De Meuron . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We started off working together in our spare time on two project and won both . We thought this wa it & ndash ; we made it . But the reality wa different , both project never got completed but our partnership survived and flourished , & rdquo ; Zarhy said.Duo begin journeyObserving the world & rsquo ; s rapid pace outstripping architecture & rsquo ; s ability to keep up , the duo began their venture by plunging into the depth . They successfully took on complex , large-scale project and paved their way to solving major architectural challenge . Prioritizing simplicity over complexity , their goal in each project is to craft adaptable and people-centered space , fostering long-term benefit for community and city . & nbsp ; Since it establishment , PEZ ha been able to showcase this philosophy in a significant number of successful project and competition awards.The building for which Zarhy received the prize house both R & amp ; D Center for a worldwide leading semiconductor company and the Tel Aviv University Engineering Faculty . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The building combine the engineering faculty with the semi-conductors & rsquo ; research . Excluding the University Gallery , which wa built 35 year ago , this is the first building on campus that wa built with the idea of opening to the city . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; This is part of the changed attitude of the university . The campus perimeter , which for year wa made up almost exclusively of car parking , will change to be made of building that will be open to the urban surroundings a well a the campus , & rdquo ; Zarhy explained.Challenging the enclosed campus paradigm of the university , the building connects the city and the campus creating a meeting point for academia and industry . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; This is the first building in many year that rise from this level and connects the street outside the campus , to the university campus itself , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; You can enter the building , and the University & rsquo ; s campus from the street that encircles the university , while on the other side of the ground floor - the street floor visually continues , forming a patio , or an enclosed four-meter deep shaded courtyard which is open to the cafeteria . & ldquo ; It is a new model of a research building & ndash ; simple and efficient on one hand , and iconic on the other , & rdquo ; Zarhy said.This building is , at the same time , both iconic by it merit , and simple by design . When looking for simplicity you sometimes come across the best idea , new idea , & rdquo ; said Zarhy proudly , stressing that his architectural vision is & ldquo ; to make a statement but to keep it simple & rdquo ; . & ldquo ; Winning this prize wa extremely important for u , & rdquo ; Zarhy concluded .
title: tau faculty of engineering zarhy and studio pez win rechter prize for young architect

Body Text: MK Benny Gantz 's political future remained stable while Netanyahu 's leadership remained in doubt : An election poll conducted by Maariv and political pollster Dr . Menachem Lazar uncovered what the political landscape would look like had election been held today . & nbsp ; The National Unity Party , led by MK Benny Gantz , continued to weaken despite it boost following the outbreak of the Israel-Hamas war and Gantz 's entry into the government . National Unity would see a decrease of two mandate ( decreasing to 33 from the last poll 's 35 seat ) . At the same time , the Likud Party , headed by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu , slowly recovered two more seat to be positioned at 19 mandate . & nbsp ; MK Gideon Sa'ar , who left National Unity and quit the coalition in mid-March to form his own party , New Hope & mdash ; The National Right , is predicted to rise above the electoral threshold with four mandate . & nbsp ; Sa'ar remains in , Smotrich outWhile Sa'ar is predicted to remain in the Knesset , others are less fortunate . Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich , who head the Religious Zionist Party , is expected to not pas the threshold with merely 2.9 % of the vote . & nbsp ; Other religious party expected to remain in the Knesset include United Torah Judaism , who could gain up to one more seat , and in general , most party remain unchanged in the Knesset 's seat distribution since the last poll . & nbsp ; Regarding potential coalition formation , the opposition and coalition are weakened by two mandate each due to Sa'ar 's incoming bloc of four seat , leading to a projected balance of 65 mandate for the current opposition and 46 mandate for the current coalition government . & nbsp ; Along with polling for the distribution of mandate in the Knesset , respondent were asked about leadership and who they deemed fit to lead Israel a prime minister . These result remained similar to last week 's , with 45 % of respondent supporting a Gantz premiership , while support for Netanyahu a prime minister decreased by four point , currently at 34 % . & nbsp ; Dr . Lazar is a political pollster , public opinion specialist , and CEO at Panels Politics , and conducted the electoral poll in cooperation with a panel of internet respondent using the site Panel4All.co.il . & nbsp ; The survey wa conducted between March 27 and 28 , 2024 , and wa answered by 503 respondent representative of the State of Israel 's population . Respondents included Israelis over 18 and Jews and Arabs . The margin of error in this survey stood at 4.4 % . & nbsp ;
title: gantz 's prospect remain stable while trust in netanyahu 's leadership decline - poll

Body Text: The US State Department ha informed the father of a World Vision official on trial for allegedly assisting Hamas that it is closely monitoring the case , according to an email obtained by The Jerusalem Post . Mohammad El Halabi , who claim the charge against him were made to delegitimize his humanitarian work , ha been detained for nearly five and a half year and ha been waiting for a verdict from the Beersheba District Court since closing argument concluded last July and October . His father , Khalil El Halabi , had sent a letter to the US government to request assistance to free his son or to at least hasten a verdict and a close to the unprecedentedly drawn-out proceeding . In the January 31 email being disclosed now for the first time , the US Embassy in Jerusalem responded to El Halibi , saying : & ldquo ; The United States is aware of your son & rsquo ; s case and ha also covered it in our annual Country Reports on Human Rights Practices . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; Officers at the Embassy have closely monitored his case and have previously been in touch with World Vision and Mohammad & rsquo ; s attorney to learn more about his detention and court case , & rdquo ; it said . & ldquo ; We & rsquo ; ve also been in touch with the Israeli authority to express our concern over the impact his case ha had on the shrinking humanitarian space in Gaza , & rdquo ; it added . & ldquo ; We will continue to monitor the case closely and raise our concern with the appropriate official , & rdquo ; the US Embassy said . In parallel , Mohammad El Halabi & rsquo ; s lawyer , Maher Hana , is trying to get him freed from detention pending the verdict , given that he ha been in pre-verdict detention for so long . A hearing on the issue before the Supreme Court that had been scheduled for this coming Tuesday ha been postponed until February 15 . El Halabi ha vehemently denied the charge and accused the prosecution and the Shin Bet ( Israel Security Agency ) of manufacturing charge , coercing a confession to undermine humanitarian organization in Gaza and dragging out the case . To date , only the defendant ha been criticizing the prosecution , with the state refraining from responding publicly due to concern about revealing classified intelligence . El Halabi wa indicted in August 2016 for channeling $ 7.2 million a year to Hamas to buy weapon and build attack tunnel . The money wa to have been used by World Vision for food , humanitarian assistance and aid program for disabled child . Neither World Vision nor an Australian government audit found the wrongdoing allegedly uncovered by the Shin Bet . Meanwhile , Israel is trying to convince the International Criminal Court and country in Europe that it legal system is legitimate and fair to avoid war-crimes trial and combat charge of apartheid from Amnesty International and others . Closing argument for the prosecution started last spring , but like much of the case , they dragged out for unclear reason until October . Last March , the Justice Ministry indicated it would release key point of it closing argument to the public in response to some of the defendant & rsquo ; s allegation that his right had been abused . Ultimately , the ministry decided not to release any information and to postpone that issue at the court & rsquo ; s discretion a part of the verdict . Though the ministry claim the court postponed any disclosure , it usually is the prosecution that request gag order in the first place . Since last March , more allegation have emerged from El Halabi & rsquo ; s side . One is that he wa fooled by an undercover informant in detention into confirming detail that the informant kept pressuring El Halabi to confirm . According to the defense , El Halabi told law-enforcement official the confession wa coerced from the first moment they raised it with him . The original document recording the confession wa lost by the police . The defense ha said the case should have been dismissed in light of the circumstance in which the confession wa given . The police record of what wa said is an inauthentic photocopy , raising question of a police cover-up , it said . In addition , the defense ha claimed that World Vision did not transfer any material to Gaza at some of the crossing point where the prosecution say El Halabi made illegal transfer to Hamas . Although these allegation are new to the public , the prosecution ha been aware of them and responded to them behind closed door throughout the trial , the Post ha learned . The prosecution & rsquo ; s response are classified at this stage , but the prosecution apparently acknowledges having used an undercover informant and would say this is a standard approved tactic and that no illegal pressure wa applied . Moreover , the prosecution would point out that the court had already rejected any allegation of a coerced confession earlier in the case and that the only question left for it to settle is how much weight to give the confession . Regarding the allegation of a lost document , it appears the prosecution would likely express regret and reject any conspiracy theory , adding that this is not the first case such an error occurred and that the defense ha not flagged any specific issue to invalidate the authenticity of the copy of the confession . Regarding the border crossing , the prosecution would respond that El Halabi wa a clever operator and sometimes used different organization or name to move material , while using World Vision a his main laundering tool . Last March , Khalil El Halabi told the Post Mohammad El Halabi had & ldquo ; brought conclusive evidence and testimony of the employee of the organization and internal and external international auditor , a well a contractor and even farmer , who all testified that there wa no diversion of any fund from the activity of the organization . & rdquo ; El Halabi said this show that allegation regarding his son misappropriating humanitarian fund for Hamas were unfounded . Further , he said , & ldquo ; At least three defense expert confirmed that the existing & lsquo ; evidence & rsquo ; is clearly unreliable and untrue & hellip ; based on limited preliminary examination only & hellip ; Due to the confidentiality imposed on me by the state , I am not allowed to comment on the nature of the evidence . & rdquo ; According to Khalil El Halabi , the defense ha called three expert witness , likely relating to finance or auditing , a well a employee of World Vision , contractor and farmer involved with how the NGO & rsquo ; s fund were spent . The defense also claim it did not see all of the evidence . The prosecution would say El Halabi used tactic such a falsifying documentation or concealing the use of certain fund using other entity to hide his use of World Vision a a financial laundering instrument , just a he did with physical transfer of mat & eacute ; riel for Hamas , the Post ha learned . Further , the prosecution ha said even though the public ha not seen the full evidence , the defense ha . Both side accuse the other of unconscionable delay relating to fighting over how the trial would take place , what evidence the defense would get to see and the possibility in the earlier year of reaching a plea deal .
title: u state dept . closely monitoring world vision case verdict

Body Text: A tribute to the great Japanese animation director Hayao Miyazaki is currently running at the Jerusalem and Tel Aviv Cinematheques and will continue throughout the Passover holiday and until the end of the month.Miyazaki & rsquo ; s unique work is imaginative and filled with beautiful imagery , but his story also have great emotional depth , usually from the point of view of child , that transport viewer into dreamlike world . & nbsp ; While some of these film are available on streaming service , it is much more intense and enjoyable to see them on the big screen.Most of his movie are suitable for child , although some feature nightmarish scenario that will be too intense for younger kids.The tribute feature his latest movie , The Boy and the Heron , about a boy drawn into a strange underworld in the aftermath of his mother & rsquo ; s death during World War II , and which I would not recommend for child under 10 . & nbsp ; But the movie , which won the Oscar this year for Best Animated Feature , is worth seeing for older child and adult , especially because Miyazaki , now in his 80 , ha said it will be his last film.His previous film , The Wind Rises , is about a boy who dream of becoming a pilot and instead ha a career a a flight engineer , will be shown in the tribute and is also more geared to adult viewers.Some of the movie that would be better for young child include Kiki & rsquo ; s Delivery Service , about a young witch who us her talent for riding a broomstick to make friend ; My Neighbor Totoro , the story of child who discover a world of enchanted forest creature after their mother is hospitalized ; and Ponyo , about a combination fish and girl who befriends a human child after she is washed ashore.Other Miyazaki masterpiece include Spirited Away , about a girl who is swept into a series of adventure after her parent are turned into pig on their way to a new home ; Princess Mononoke , about a boy who find himself in the middle of a war between the titular princess and forest creature ; and Howl & rsquo ; s Moving Castle , about a girl who is cursed and turned into an old woman at the base of a fantastic castle.For the full program , go to the website of the Jerusalem Cinematheque http : / / www.jer-cin.org.il / and the Tel Aviv Cinematheque cinema.co.il
title: cinematheques pay tribute to japanese animation master hayao miyazaki

Body Text: & nbsp ; Fakhri Abu Diab life in east Jerusalem , but everything he know about Israel & rsquo ; s capital is different from the one that his Jewish neighbor love . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Anyone who come to east Jerusalem know that it is not the same city and not the same language , & rdquo ; said Abu Diab , who is a spokesman for the Silwan neighborhood . & nbsp ; The barrier that once divided Jerusalem prior to 1967 ha long since been torn down . Fifty-four year have passed since Israel created a united capital when it wrested control of the eastern part of the city from Jordan during the Six Day War . & nbsp ; Next week , a Israel celebrates Jerusalem Day to mark that victory , few will remember where that barrier really stood , but the scar of the division still resonate in the city . & nbsp ; At issue are not just the cultural and linguistic difference between the Palestinian population that largely life in east Jerusalem and make up 39 % of the municipality & rsquo ; s 900,000 people . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Geopolitics play a role . Most of the international community support a divided Jerusalem , where the eastern part of the city would be the capital of a future Palestinian state . An additional complicating factor is the fact that most of the Palestinians have Jerusalem residency but lack Israeli citizenship . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; But over time , for many Jewish Israelis , the difference have almost begun to appear cosmetic . They walked around a city that easily look united and whose redivision seems unrealistic and unfeasible . & nbsp ; For Jerusalem & rsquo ; s Deputy Mayor Fleur Hassan-Nahoum the city & rsquo ; s unity is obvious . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Jerusalem is a city comprised of community . That is the essence of Jerusalem . It is a city of community , but it is a united city . What make it united ? You have one municipal authority taking care of all of it resident , & rdquo ; she said . & nbsp ; That authority is in charge of transport , health , education and public space , she added . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; That municipal authority , especially in the last few year , ha made it a point of being an inclusive authority , where everyone ha a voice , and where everyone can approach the mayor and the deputy mayor and can advocate for their community and receive resource for that community , & rdquo ; she said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; On a public level , what we have seen in the last five to 10 year is a city that is more integrated than it ha ever been . Ten year ago , you never had a young Arab student working in Fox , & rdquo ; Hassan-Nahoum said , adding that many of the shop throughout the city are staffed by Arab resident . & nbsp ; Today , public space is shared by Jewish and Arab resident of the city , including in coffee shop and gym . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Whether people admit it or not , whether the detractor can still point finger at the divided city & ndash ; in essence , in the day-to-day experience for most people , & rdquo ; the city is integrated physically , logistically and relationally , she said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I don & rsquo ; t think our work is finished , & rdquo ; she said , adding that more need to be done on issue of equity and job placement , particularly in the hi-tech industry , but that is true with respect to any community that ha been marginalized , she said . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; For many year the government of Israel , whether left or right , did not know what to do with the issue of east Jerusalem , Hassan-Nahoum said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The Left think one day it will be the capital of a Palestinian state , and the right wing is concerned with other issue , & rdquo ; she said . & nbsp ; Partially , she said , the problem lay with the Palestinians themselves . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We had a hostile community , with little leadership , manipulated by the Palestinian leadership in Ramallah . It wa difficult . I am not saying it wa all their fault , but I believe we are in a different place now . The Arabs in east Jerusalem are realizing that they are getting zero , nothing , from the Palestinian leadership , she said . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; She credited Jerusalem Mayor Moshe Lion and former Jerusalem Affairs minister Ze & rsquo ; ev Elkin , now a New Hope MK , for making stride in closing the equity gap between Jewish and Arab resident of the city , including the development of partnership with the local Arab leadership . & nbsp ; When riot broke out a few week ago , Lion , who is Sabbath observant , walked on Saturday to meet with community leader to seek a way to calm the situation , she said . & nbsp ; The city & rsquo ; s unity wa most clearly apparent , she said , during the COVID-19 pandemic , when everyone banded together to fight a common enemy . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; It wa beautiful . It wa a difficult time , but we came together a a city and that is the measure of how far we have come , & rdquo ; she said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The DNA of Jerusalem is one of diversity , & rdquo ; she said , a she explained that King David chose this space to build this city 3,000 year ago because it did not belong to any one tribe and thus it could be a place where everyone could gather together . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Our DNA is one of convergence , of east and west , of old and new , of past and future and heaven and earth . We will solve all of the conflict in our country and in our region from Jerusalem , & rdquo ; she said . & nbsp ; THE EXECUTIVE director of the left-wing NGO Ir Amim , Yudith Oppenheimer , said that , factually speaking , Israel annexed east Jerusalem in 1967 and since then it ha been managed by one municipality . & nbsp ; On the surface , & ldquo ; you can look at Jerusalem and say here is an urban space in which people can move from one place to another , so maybe this is a united city , & rdquo ; Oppenheimer said . & nbsp ; But & ldquo ; when you look deeper into the situation , you see that the city is actually divided in many aspect , and each one portrays a picture of two very unequal society , in which one control the other , & rdquo ; Oppenheimer added . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; One side ha all the resource and is very dedicated to expressing it hegemony , & rdquo ; and the other side lack those resource , she said . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; The issue , she said , start with the fact that most of the city & rsquo ; s Palestinian resident lack Israeli citizenship and have only residency right . Those right are conditional and can easily be removed , she explained , adding that this insecure status dominates many aspect of their life , she said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Everything is conditional . They may not leave the city ; they may lose their residency status . They can not build in the city , but they have to live in the city , or they lose all their entitlement to the city , & rdquo ; Oppenheimer said . & nbsp ; Palestinians have individual right in Jerusalem but not collective one , she said . & nbsp ; Oppenheimer dismissed claim that the Palestinians are to blame for this situation because they refused to take citizenship . & ldquo ; This is an urban legend , & rdquo ; she said . Palestinians were never offered collective citizenship , but rather the right to apply individually and that application is very complicated . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; It take year and many are denied , & rdquo ; she said . & nbsp ; Those who do not want citizenship should be offered permanent residency that can not be easily revoked , so that they can live their life more securely , she said . & nbsp ; The issue of inequity is the main issue , she said , and that issue is separate from the final political status of Jerusalem , which need to be negotiated between Israelis and Palestinians , she explained . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; So is the city united ? & rdquo ; she asked . It & rsquo ; s those who speak so highly of unity that seem to want it the least , she said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Do they really want for Jerusalem to be united in a meaningful way , in the full meaning of what it mean ? Because their action actually say the opposite , & rdquo ; she said . & nbsp ; Her organization , she said , support a two-state resolution to the conflict in which Jerusalem would be the capital of both an Israeli and a Palestinian state . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; But this doesn & rsquo ; t mean that the city ha to be physically divided , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; It is getting more and more difficult to divide the city . If you ask , the majority of the resident actually enjoy the diversity that the city offer and do not want to see the city divided again . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; There are creative way to create two capital without physically dividing the city , and the sustainability of a two-state solution depends on the capacity of Israelis and Palestinians to share the municipal public space in the fullest way possible , Oppenheimer said . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; The issue is not about dividing the city but about sharing it , she said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We are actually working very hard not for a vision of divided or united , but for a vision of shared city , & rdquo ; she said . & nbsp ; Abu Diab said it is clear to him that the city is divided . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The food is different , even the dream are different , & rdquo ; he said . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Here they [ Palestinians ] know they are living under occupation , & rdquo ; said Abu Diab who doe not consider himself unified with the Jewish resident of the city . & ldquo ; We think they are not living with u and that they want to live without u , & rdquo ; he added . & nbsp ; He ha never sought Israeli citizenship , nor doe he want it . He dream of being a citizen of a future Palestinian state in which east Jerusalem will be it capital . But this doesn & rsquo ; t mean he imago that a wall would divide the city , but , rather , that the city would be governed by two different entity , with it citizen walking freely between both . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Jerusalem belongs to everyone . It should be a city of love and peace and nonviolence . It should be an international city , but allow for everyone to be part of their own people , & rdquo ; he explained . & nbsp ; SARA HAETZNI-COHEN , who chair the right-wing NGO My Israel Movement , said that obviously Jerusalem is Israel & rsquo ; s united capital and , a such , all effort must be made to ensure that this is true in practice and not just a slogan . & nbsp ; To make that happen , she said , the issue of inequity between the eastern and western part of the city must be addressed and it must be the Right that lead that charge . & nbsp ; Failure to do that , she said , give an erroneous message that Israeli sovereignty in east Jerusalem is temporary . There is little reason to invest in neighborhood that will one day be given away . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Israel ha to make a statement of sovereignty by normalizing it treatment of those neighborhood , including offering Israeli citizenship to the Palestinians who seek it , she said . & nbsp ; Otherwise , Palestinians have the feeling they are temporary here , Haetzni-Cohen said . & nbsp ; From the start , Israel made a decision to apply sovereignty to the city , and now it should shore up that sovereignty , she said . & nbsp ; To not recognize this reality , she said , is to & ldquo ; put one & rsquo ; s head in the sand . & rdquo ;

Body Text: The Jerusalem District Attorney 's Office filed on Friday an indictment in the city 's district court against 32-year-old Ahmed Zahara , a resident of Jerusalem , for serving a an agent for Hezbollah . According to the indictment , approximately nine year ago Zahara contacted a released prisoner living in Lebanon and told him that he wa interested in contacting people from Hezbollah in order to work for them in Israel . He received encrypted software from the organization so that he could keep in touch with them . Zahara would sometimes travel to Ramallah , in order to contact his handler via the encrypted program in order to evade security force in Israel . He wa asked to perform various task , including providing update on the situation in Jerusalem and the West Bank and reporting on disturbance that occurred in Israel 's capital . In addition , the defendant initiated his own activity such a photographing a place with large satellite dish in order to send their location to Hezbollah . The operation ceased several year ago but resumed during the past year . During his honeymoon in Turkey , Zahara received money and , once again , an encrypted cellphone . Upon returning to Israel he contacted his handler and accepted additional task . He wa then wa arrested and his contact with Hezbollah wa cut off . Zahara wa indicted for contacting a foreign agent , passing on information to the enemy with the intent to harm state security and unlawfully exiting the country . The investigation wa conducted by the Shin Bet ( Israel Security Agency ) and by the Israel Police 's National Unit for the Investigation of International Crime , part of Lahav 433 .
title: 32-year-old man indicted for spying for hezbollah

Body Text: Last week saw an interesting discussion around China playing a possible role in peacemaking between Israel and the Palestinians . The Chinese said they would welcome visit by Palestinian officials.So how would China facilitate peace talk with Israel and the Palestinians ? SO HOW would China facilitate peace talk with Israel and the Palestinians ? Considering how China signed a 25-year deal with Iran recently , is it an impartial actor today ? The global shift that are taking place in the wake of COVID and Russia & rsquo ; s invasion of Ukraine may have changed thing so much that Beijing would find it to be an uphill struggle these days.Nevertheless , China appeared to have message discipline on this issue . It ha spoken to Israel and the Palestinians . Chinese President Xi Jinping appears serious . There are several way this could develop , and China could try to mediate more and play a larger role.This will put Israel in an awkward position . If Israel appears to not be interested , it could cause China to see Israel in a negative light and begin to invest more in tie with the Palestinians and Iran . Tehran ha interest here a well . Russia & rsquo ; s war accelerates process in international relation , which mean it accelerates China & rsquo ; s confrontation with the West.Despite France & rsquo ; s outreach , Beijing is indicating it support Moscow undermining the global rules-based international order . Beijing continues to make comment about the Baltic state that cause dismay in the West.On the other hand , a the Belt and Road Initiative may not be a important these day , because the world is more divided , and China & rsquo ; s soft , quiet and consistent approach to influence building in the region ha shifted , it & rsquo ; s not clear if the economic-stability model is even relevant.For instance , for many year , we were told that linking Russia & rsquo ; s economy to Europe would reduce the chance of war . In the end , this globalization neoliberal agenda failed because China and Russia have shown that despite economic link , they have become more nationalist , authoritarian and hostile to the West.Thus , democratic peace or Belt and Road have not come to fruition . Therefore , how will China & rsquo ; s talk of brokering peace deal come to fruition ? For China , the role of mediator is bolstered by it not having a major historic role in the region . On the other hand , it suffers from declining perception of neutrality in the region a it play a greater role here . That mean country all pour into China their hope and belief of what it might be to the region , and a with all diminishing return and feedback loop , it will inevitably come up short because you can & rsquo ; t be all thing to all people.The region ha a history of having expectation and then being angry when they aren & rsquo ; t met . Body Text: Elitzur Ramle captured the Israel woman & rsquo ; s basketball championship after defeating Harold Lev Jerusalem 84-60 , winning it third title in a row with a clean 3-0 sweep in the final . & nbsp ; Host Ramle came into Game 3 after just clipping the Reds 95-94 in Game 2 , and it wa clear from the get-go that the yellow-and-black had no interest in making a return trip to the capital for a fourth game . & nbsp ; Jessica Jackson , Jennie Simms , Tzlil Vaturi , and Eden Rotberg came out flying for Danny Gutt & rsquo ; s squad a the host took an insurmountable 44-23 halftime lead and never looked back to run away with the win . & nbsp ; Rotberg scored 19 point , Jackson added 17 point , and Simms checked in with a triple-double of 12 point , 11 rebound , and 10 assist In the win . We aim to do so by supporting innovative agricultural research and training the next generation across a broad range of agriculture , food , and nutrition-related topic through our fellowship program . & ldquo ; We are also looking into way we can accelerate innovation in agriculture by bringing together academic leader and industry expert . & rdquo ; Tel Aviv University celebrates 115th anniversary & nbsp ; ■ TEL AVIV , the Hill of Spring , is celebrating it 115th anniversary . Coincidentally , Meridor will celebrate his 77th birthday on April 25 , which this year fall during Passover.Also celebrating a milestone anniversary next year is Bar-Ilan University , which wa opened in 1955 , after it initiation in 1950 by the president of the Mizrachi movement in the US , Pinkhos Churgin.Tel Aviv University took somewhat longer to develop from an idea to a reality . Eventually , it wa founded in 1956 through the merger of the Tel Aviv School of Law and Economics , the Institute of Natural Sciences , and the Institute of Jewish Studies.Event for single in their 20 and 30 to be held at the Jerusalem Great Synagogue ■ FOR MANY new immigrant who are single , a well a student and volunteer from Zionist youth group spending a year or two in Israel , festival time such a Passover and Rosh Hashanah can be very sad and lonely because these are the two festival in which family get together more than at any other time . For reservation , Eisenberg can be contacted on WhatsApp at 917-945-7342.The story of Holocaust survivor Avraham Roet ■ THE ORGANIZERS of the Tel Aviv International Salon are already thinking ahead to Holocaust Remembrance Day on Sunday May 5 , when a ceremony will be held in English , and Dutch-born Holocaust survivor Avraham Roet , who also fought in the War of Independence , will present his amazing story . Suchard got in touch with her and , in the most objective manner that he could summon , explained the overall situation to her , resulting in her sending a pro-Israel post.If only it wa that easy in more influential quarters.Rewarding female reservist & nbsp ; ■ MOST ISRAELIS appreciate the sacrifice being made by reservist , especially female reservist who are the mother of young family . Body Text: Since the outbreak of war between Ukraine and Russia on February 24 , 2022 , a staggering 83,198 Olim from Russia have sought refuge in Israel , a reported by the Ministry of Aliyah and Integration . According to the Israel Central Bureau of Statistics , this influx is part of a broader pattern that ha seen approximately 1.3 million Russian speaker settle in Israel , making up 15 % of the nation 's population & mdash ; a demographic that includes those from other post-Soviet states.However , the transition to Israeli life ha not been seamless for many . Struggling with cultural and religious assimilation , these newcomer often experience profound isolation and loneliness . As their adjustment hurdle persist well into their second year , the urgency to address their integration challenge becomes increasingly apparent.For more story from The Media Line , go to themedialine.org.To gain insight into their situation , The Media Line recently spoke to Rabbi Binyamin Minich , a Russian `` war aliyah `` expert from the Daniel community in Jaffa who frequently interacts with new Israeli citizen from the post-Soviet region . `` Surely , repatriate from the post-Soviet space encounter difficulty integrating into Israel . Although everyone ha ' returned home , ' the immigrant crisis remains . People find it difficult from a financial point of view . First and foremost , everyone want to eat , not to pray . Then come the crisis of culture and language , `` admits Rabbi Minich . `` It 's impossible to be fully Israeli without being born here . And therefore , the crisis will always exist , `` he adds.The rabbi call the current weakness in integrating Russian repatriate a failure of the multicultural approach . `` People think that because there is a huge Russian-speaking diaspora here , they can settle without much effort . This is not the case . Despite Israel 's liberalism , there are cultural and religious code here , even among the most secular citizen , `` note Minich.Challenges Russian immigrant face in IsraelDasha Shkolnikova , a 28-year-old Russian immigrant , speaks about the difficulty many face while integrating into Israeli society . `` A fundamental mistake that many make is closing themselves off . Israel is not the right kind of country for that . You have to go out and socialize ; everything here is designed for you always to be outside . Nobody stay at home , and that 's the culture , `` say Shkolnikova . `` Many people from Russia left involuntarily , and in their mind , it 's ' I fled . ' They only communicate with Russians , & rdquo ; she add , & ldquo ; and it turn into a real Bat Yam ( an Israeli city popular among Russians ) , almost a ghetto . & rdquo ; Journalist Ilya Egorov echo that experience . `` I literally fled to Israel with just one suitcase because I wa on a business trip . Then I somehow managed to get the document transferred and repatriated . `` & nbsp ; `` I rented some apartment and just closed myself off on the balcony every day , opened Zoom , and communicated with my colleague and friend who remained in Russia . Honestly , apart from one business trip , I have n't even been to Jerusalem , `` admits Egorov.In addition , many immigrant from the post-Soviet space feel nostalgic for their country of origin . Russians may feel their identity and culture are being threatened . `` There 's a huge layer of Russian shop and event here , & rdquo ; say Shkolnikova . & ldquo ; You can find basically everything . But many thing feel unfamiliar here because it 's the East . For example , everyone here is very tactile , and for someone from the post-Soviet space , this is very unusual . `` `` I feel that this life & mdash ; a if it 's not mine , and mine stayed in Russia , & rdquo ; Egorov add . & ldquo ; I can beat my chest and shout , I 'm Jewish , I 'm Israeli , but I 'm only Israeli because I have a passport . `` At the same time , he want to learn the language and feel like an Israeli . Egorov admires the Israeli mentality and the resilience of people in the face of difficulty and war . `` Nowadays , I keenly feel antisemitism in the world , and I believe I have the right to say that it directly affect me too , `` he says.Rabbi Minich explains that the Jewish self-awareness of many repatriate change after moving to Israel , which make their integration harder . `` Perhaps in the country of origin , they felt like Jews , and no one objected to that , but in Israel , they are reminded that they are not by matrilineal descent , and therefore - ' not truly Jewish , ' `` say Minich.His word are confirmed by Polina Altzitser , a 25-year-old language teacher who wa repatriated to Israel from Russia in April 2022 due to the start of the war in Ukraine . `` Although I have Jewish root , no one in my family supported Jewish tradition at all , unfortunately . We did n't talk about it . I always knew my grandfather wa Jewish , but we never emphasized that , `` she explains . `` I see strong discrimination here against those who are n't Jews , according to halacha ( Biblical law in Judaism ) . It greatly upset and anger me . I do n't understand what the problem is . Why , for example , ca n't you get married without some certificate stating that your mother is Jewish ? I faced this when I started dating my boyfriend , and it 's been difficult for me , `` confesses Polina . `` It 's a secular but , at the same time , very religious country . When it come to family , tradition , and everything else , I clearly feel a lack of knowledge because my family is not entirely Jewish , & rdquo ; say Shkolnikova . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; You must get used to the tradition and understand them , & rdquo ; she add thoughtfully . & ldquo ; Living in a different world , you can not cut yourself off from it and continue to live a if you were in Russia . Why are you here if you do so ? `` Rabbi Minich share that besides being liberal , his community is also multilingual and multipolitical , where not only Jews of matrilineal descent but also child , grandchild , and spouse of Jews are welcomed . `` I believe less in the concept of Russian-speaking synagogue because , ultimately , I think it 's impossible to avoid the side effect of ghettoization . Therefore , my community is completely Israeli ; they speak six different language , `` Minich shares.Repatriates also emphasize the importance of language . `` I immediately enrolled in ulpan ( Hebrew language school ) ; I just knew it wa necessary . Language is the DNA of a people and culture . If you do n't have the language , assimilating will be much harder for you , `` say Shkolnikova.Ulpan is a big step but not always a complete solution . `` Ninety percent of my surroundings remain Russian-speaking , & rdquo ; say Alzitser . That 's why Hebrew is so difficult for me . The problem is that I still ca n't fully accept that I need the language . I ca n't say I 've completely abandoned my past and understanding of myself a Russian . & rdquo ; Minich belief that despite all the difficulty , those repatriate who stay in Israel will significantly contribute to the development of Israeli society . `` Israel is a complex country , and living here is n't easy . Those who are comfortable in Israel ultimately dedicate themselves to the country and make it better , `` he say . `` Immigration is always challenging . And the least we can do for those who have just arrived is to help them feel at home , `` Minich concludes .

Body Text: The UN Security Council must pressure Israel to halt the pending eviction of 3,000 Palestinians living in east Jerusalem including in & nbsp ; Sheikh Jarrah , Ir Amim executive-director Yehudith Oppenheimer urged in a special briefing she delivered to the 15-member body . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; It is therefore essential to hold the Israeli government accountable , and to urge it to prevent the large-scale displacement of these community , & rdquo ; said Oppenheimer , who head an Israeli left-wing NGO that focus almost exclusively on issue relating to east Jerusalem . & nbsp ; Oppenheimer spoke to the UNSC virtually from Jerusalem during it monthly meeting on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict . She briefly outlined issue relating to the 350,000 Palestinians who are resident of the city , but not citizen of the country . & nbsp ; Since 1967 , & ldquo ; Israeli authority have employed a system of discriminatory policy to weaken the Palestinian hold on the city , & rdquo ; Oppenheimer charged . & ldquo ; These policy have included : land confiscation , settlement [ Jewish ] building , denial of citizenship and political right , permanent residency revocation , insufficient service provision & nbsp ; and severe restriction on planning and building in east Jerusalem . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; But Oppenheimer focused specifically on the fate of four small community in east Jerusalem , where some 3,000 Palestinians are & nbsp ; in danger of losing their home ; Sheikh Jarrah , Batan al-Hawa , Bustan and Walaja . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I am speaking because these measure of Palestinian displacement have recently increased in scope and scale in an unprecedented manner , & rdquo ; Oppenheimer said . & nbsp ; At issue are four legal battle ; two involve city plan to build two national park and the others involve landlord-tenant dispute over land ownership and the legality of the home . & nbsp ; The most high-profile dispute ha been the fate of four family in the Sheikh Jarrah neighborhood , also known a the Shimon HaTzaddik neighborhood . & nbsp ; The four family have appealed to the High Court of Justice to overrule two lower court ruling , which determined that their home are owned by the Nahalat Shimon Company that want to develop the largely Palestinian neighborhood for Jewish housing . & nbsp ; The area had been a Jewish one prior to the 1948 War of Independence when the resident fled . In the aftermath of the war , Palestinians who fled sovereign Israel , including west Jerusalem , moved to that area . & nbsp ; Some 28 family were offered home there in exchange for relinquishing their refugee status . But the land , previously owned by two Jewish company , wa not registered in their name . & nbsp ; The High Court of Justice is expected to hold a hearing on the appeal on Monday . It had initially delayed the hearing to give Attorney-General Avichai Mandelblit time to determine if the government wanted to be a party to the case and to render an option . & nbsp ; Mandelblit told the court earlier this month that he saw no reason for the state to intervene , and threw the matter back to the court . & nbsp ; A source told The Jerusalem Post that Prime Minister Naftali Bennett would not order the eviction of the Sheikh Jarrah family . Police have the option to refuse eviction order that might cause a danger to security . & nbsp ; Hamas ha claimed that Sheikh Jarrah is one of the reason that it launched a salvo of rocket at Jerusalem and other town in May , which sparked an 11-day Gaza war . & nbsp ; Bennett & rsquo ; s opposition to the demolition is likely to delay the matter , possibly for a long time , but it could not ultimately subvert the legal process should the High Court rule against the family . & nbsp ; It is believed that the fate of the petition by the four family will determine the fate of the remaining 24 family in the neighborhood at risk of losing their home . & nbsp ; Ambassador to the US and the UN Gilad Erdan attacked Oppenheimer when he addressed the council , charging that she had brought & ldquo ; Hamas & rsquo ; s lie about Jerusalem to the Security Council . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; It & rsquo ; s a move , he said , which & ldquo ; strengthens the terrorist organization and weakens the Palestinian Authority , & rdquo ; and that it is an & ldquo ; absurd & rdquo ; and & ldquo ; dangerous & rdquo ; situation . & nbsp ; Erdan warned that the & ldquo ; Hamas narrative & rdquo ; put forward by Oppenheimer could be used to justify terror attack against Israel . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Today & rsquo ; s discussion might serve to increase Hamas & rsquo ; influence in Jerusalem and the Palestinian arena , & rdquo ; Erdan said . & nbsp ; He charged that Ir Amim had a & ldquo ; long history of spreading distorted claim regarding Israel & rsquo ; s legitimacy and presence in Jerusalem , while ignoring inconvenient fact . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Erdan claimed that more than & ldquo ; half of Jerusalem & rsquo ; s Arab resident would prefer Israeli citizenship to Palestinian citizenship . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Far from being displaced , Erdan said , & ldquo ; Jerusalem & rsquo ; s Arab population ha increased by over 400 % since Jerusalem wa reunited in 1967 . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; An Ir Amim briefing to the council , he said , is & ldquo ; a absurd a bringing a leader of the Yellow Vests protest to give an & lsquo ; objective & rsquo ; briefing on the French Government & rsquo ; s economic policy . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Neither the NGO nor the Security Council can undermine the & ldquo ; millennia-old connection between the Jewish People and it eternal capital of Jerusalem . & rdquo ; He added , & ldquo ; We will always keep that promise . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Despite & ldquo ; false claim to the contrary , we will never accept the delegitimization of our legal , historical and national right in Jerusalem , by the Security Council or any other international body , & rdquo ; Erdan said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Successive Israeli government had framed these case a standard property dispute , & rdquo ; Oppenheimer explained to the UNSC , but that in reality they were & ldquo ; systematic campaign & rdquo ; aimed at changing the demographic makeup of east Jerusalem . This is done by uprooting Palestinian family and supplanting them with Jewish enclave within larger Palestinian neighborhood , Oppenheimer said , adding that it & rsquo ; s a situation that creates friction and make normative communal neighborhood life difficult . & nbsp ; The situation is possible because of the discriminatory legal system that allows Jews to reclaim property lost a the result of the 1948 war , but forbids Palestinians from reclaiming property they lost in that war . & nbsp ; The & ldquo ; pretext for many of the demolition are the absence of building permit , which are nearly impossible to procure due to the absence of proper zoning plan that the Israeli authority have failed to advance , & rdquo ; Oppenheimer said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Many of the family facing eviction are Palestinian refugee who lost home in 1948 , and who now stand to be displaced for a second time , & rdquo ; she claimed . & nbsp ; Oppenheimer also highlighted the case of Batan al-Hawa in Silwan , noting that the court had asked Mandelblit to provide a response by August 29 . The request indicates & ldquo ; a possible understanding that these case have far-reaching political and moral ramification and therefore require & nbsp ; government involvement , & rdquo ; Oppenheimer said , adding that & ldquo ; the Israeli government is now being compelled to take an explicit position on these eviction proceeding . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; That is why international pressure is so important at this juncture , she said . & nbsp ;
title: pressure israel not to evict 3,000 palestinian , ir amim tell unsc

Body Text: & ldquo ; Palestinians renew threat to nix agreement with Israel , & rdquo ; read the headline to a story in Wednesday & rsquo ; s Jerusalem Post . According to the story by Khaled Abu Toameh , Palestinian official are threatening to rescind the Oslo Accords , cut off security cooperation and demand one democratic state & ndash ; instead of a two-state solution & ndash ; if Israel doe not recognize an independent Palestinian state with east Jerusalem a it capital along the pre-1967 line . In addition , the Palestinian leadership ha decided to dispatch envoy to several country urging them to pressure Israel , and Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas is planning a visit to Russia to get Moscow to do the same and press Israel into committing to a two-state solution . Maybe , in Moscow , an idea first broached in 2007 , a Russian-sponsored international conference on the Middle East , will be floated yet again . Abu Toameh & rsquo ; s story , with a slight change of the name of some of the official quoted inside , could have been written in 2005 , 2010 and 2015 . It is a if time ha stood still , a if the Palestinians have a set diplomatic menu from which they call in an order from time to time . Nothing ha changed . Not the threat to scrap Oslo , stop security cooperation with Israel or lobby the world to step up the pressure on the Jewish state . One staple on that menu that wa not mentioned this time , at least not yet , wa that Abbas would resign , something he ha threatened to do & ndash ; but ha failed to deliver on & ndash ; numerous time in the past . What is clear from these tired threat , and the same old pattern of action & ndash ; saying all signed agreement will be canceled , going to Moscow , threatening to revoke recognition of Israel & ndash ; is that the PA ha no idea what to do next diplomatically . The diplomatic process ha ground to a halt , the Americans & ndash ; realizing that it is not going anywhere right now & ndash ; have pushed it way down their list of priority , and the PA leadership ha no idea of how to further it aim . So it reverts to the default option : threat . THERE ARE two problem with that option , however . The first is that these threat have been issued so often in the past that they simply don & rsquo ; t move anybody . They are empty . And the second problem is that using these threat ha not worked . The PA leadership ha not moved any closer to it goal by threatening to break off agreement with Israel or get an international conference convened . Issuing these threat may serve a domestic political need to flex a muscle from time to time , to show the home audience that the leadership is doing something , but it is having exactly no impact on Israeli policy , and not doing much either in term of mobilizing international involvement . All these threat do is demonstrate that the Palestinian leadership is out of idea . Short of complaining that Israel is an apartheid state committing ethnic cleansing and trying to get the International Criminal Court to step in , it ha no fresh proposition to put forward . Not , mind you , that the Israeli government is bursting with them . But it is trying to put forth a more constructive approach , though others will argue that the recent announcement about a plan to advance construction of more than 3,000 home beyond the Green Line is anything but helpful . Even there , however , that announcement wa preceded by approval of some 1,300 unit for Palestinians in the West Bank , a well a the granting of legal status to some 4,000 Palestinians living there & ndash ; type of & ldquo ; constructive gesture & rdquo ; toward the Palestinians not seen in year . This is all part of an idea that ha taken hold in the Bennett government of & ldquo ; shrinking the conflict , & rdquo ; making life for the Palestinians easier , improving the economic condition in the West Bank , and promoting economic independence there , even while acknowledging that an overall peace settlement is nowhere in the offing . Prime Minister Naftali Bennett ha not taken this idea , developed by Micah Goodman & ndash ; who reportedly ha Bennett & rsquo ; s ear & ndash ; a far a Goodman would like , but it is still something . Goodman & rsquo ; s idea is for more than just an & ldquo ; economic peace , & rdquo ; but actually for Israel to give the Palestinians more area to control , a direction that Yair Lapid could conceivably follow if/when he becomes premier in August 2023 . Even if Bennett is not going a far a Goodman might like , he is still pushing something positive . The PA leadership , on the other hand , is just going back to the same slogan and the same method , vainly hoping that this time they will render a significantly different result . They won & rsquo ; t . Some new idea , new thinking , new approach are badly needed out of Ramallah . The PA need to come up with something better than the & ldquo ; same old , same old , & rdquo ; because that ha proven to be a path leading nowhere .
title: the palestinian ‘ same old , same old ’ is getting them nowhere - analysis

An additional squadron that operates the Eitan drone is located at the Tel Nof Base.In the past month , a new drone squadron , which operates the & ldquo ; Spark & rdquo ; drone , wa opened at the Hatzor Air Base.The drone array operates in cooperation with intelligence unit . Strikes are carried out with quality and precision to prevent bystander from being harmed.IDF drone strike Palestinian Islamic Jihad member in Gaza , August 17 , 2022 ( Credit : IDF Spokesperson 's Unit ) Zik Unit led drone coordination over GazaIn the day leading up to the recent operation in Gaza , the Zik Unit operated over the Gaza Strip and prepared for several operational scenario , explained IDF Chief Artillery Officer Neri Horowitz on Wednesday.Once it wa decided to launch a preemptive strike , the unit carried out a wide range of reconnaissance and attack mission , including targeted assassination of senior Islamic Jihad official , the destruction of rocket and mortar launcher and the assassination of rocket-launching squads.IDF drone unit operate during Operation Breaking Dawn , August 2022 ( Credit : IDF Spokesperson 's Unit ) The Zik Unit specializes in coordinating command between different force , exposing the enemy and strike . Horowitz added that the unit & ldquo ; ha been a significant force in many operation over the year and ha an extensive combat heritage , ha existed for over two decade and since it establishment ha been a model for a unique multi-armed partnership in the IDF . & rdquo ; The commander of the land drone unit in the Artillery Corps , Lt . - Col . & ldquo ; M . & rdquo ; added that & ldquo ; a a ground unit leading the coordination and mission in the current operation with the Gaza Division and the Southern Command , we are working 24/7 to ensure the safety of the resident of the surrounding area and the State of Israel . & rdquo ; When did the Israeli military censor allow information on IDF drone strike ? Body Text: A Palestinian woman carried out a stabbing attack at Gush Etzion junction on Highway 60 in the West Bank on Monday evening and wa shot by nearby IDF soldier , the IDF confirmed.A 36-year-old Israeli man suffered light-moderate injury in his upper body and arrived wa transported to Hadassah Ein Kerem Hospital in Jerusalem fully conscious and in stable condition . `` MDA medic and paramedic with the assistance of an IDF medical force are providing medical treatment and are transporting a 40-year-old man in light-moderate condition to Hadassah Ein Kerem Hospital , `` according to a Magen David Adom spokesperson.IDF soldier stopped the attackIDF soldier belonging to the Givati brigade witnessed the attack and shot the attacker . & nbsp ; The terrorist wa identified a 33-year-old Fatima Shahin , a resident of the Dahayshe refugee camp in the West Bank , according to Ynet.She wa hit in the leg and moderately injured , according to Hebrew media.The Gush Etzion junction , a central junction on Highway 60 lying between Jerusalem and Hebron , ha been the scene of numerous stabbing attack in recent years.This is a developing story .
