Body Text: The government , rabbi , and general public have been at their wit & rsquo ; end arguing about whether and how to encourage haredi ( ultra-Orthodox ) yeshiva student to join the Israel Defense Forces and/or get an academic education to be able to support their family and strengthen the economy.According to newly published research supported by the Edmond de Rothschild Foundation and published in the journal Learning , Culture , and Social Interaction , 93.8 % of haredi student at the Jerusalem College of Technology ( JCT ) described having a positive experience in volunteer programs.Haredi student & rsquo ; participation in volunteer program offered by their college can make other member of their community more inclined to enroll in higher education , the study reveals.The study , led by Dr . Zvika Orr , Prof . Edith Blit-Cohen , Maya Vardi , Bina Beieri , and Prof . Daphna Golan-Agnon , found that student volunteer from underrepresented minority group like Israel & rsquo ; s ultra-Orthodox sector can bridge the gap between academic institution and their community by serving a agent of societal change . & ldquo ; This is the first study to explore community engagement program involving haredi student , and it is our hope that the finding can serve a a template for analyzing student & rsquo ; community engagement among various minority group worldwide , & rdquo ; said Orr , a senior lecturer in the Selma Jelinek School of Nursing at JCT , who , along with Dr . Adi Finkelstein , is the co-founder and co-director of the college & rsquo ; s Lev Bakehila community engagement program.The paper examined response from questionnaire and in-depth qualitative interview with student enrolled at JCT , many of whom are first-generation student . A case study on JCT student contained within the report aimed to show how social engagement can impact minority and underrepresented group navigating the academic world.Student response were based on several volunteer program , including Perah , a volunteer framework in which college student serve a tutor to younger child and provide them with academic and emotional assistance ; Lev Bakehila , where student work to promote the right of people with disability affiliated with Jerusalem & rsquo ; s haredi community ; and the Payis Scholarships and Impact Program , in which student engage in volunteer work in a variety of field and organization , such a school , community center , hospital , and assisted-living facilities.Haredi student volunteer : experience is informative and enriching & ldquo ; Through their community engagement , haredi student act a agent of knowledge and change in their community . Although this process is wrought with challenge and dilemma , the haredi student volunteer described their experience a informative and enriching . This case study illuminates how community engagement can help underrepresented student cope with navigating their community and the academic world , & rdquo ; said Prof . Blit-Cohen of the Paul Baerwald School of Social Work and Social Welfare at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem ( HU ) . Responses from student participating in the study revealed that their community engagement experience helped them bridge the gap between the haredi and academic world . The author said that community engagement serf a a positive catalyst among the ultra-Orthodox because volunteering coincides with one of the basic religious and cultural value practiced in their community , where the prevailing discourse emphasizes charitable and benevolent endeavor , act of loving kindness , and compassion.Additionally , community engagement work helped them foster social change within their community . During their service , they were able to formulate a new perception of social phenomenon and offer this newly adopted perspective within their community . In the interview , those involved in a disability right project , for example , mentioned their sense of commitment to changing social perception about people with disability in their haredi community and beyond.Along with the many well-documented social and academic benefit associated with community engagement , volunteer service also reflects JCT & rsquo ; s institutional commitment not only to excellence on academic and religious level but also to fulfilling the college & rsquo ; s responsibility to make positive contribution to society.The study & rsquo ; s author chose to spotlight haredi student because they are often caught at the crossroad between their community and academia . According to the Central Bureau of Statistics ( CBS ) , in 2020 , only four percent of Israeli student were ultra-Orthodox , less than a third of their share in the college-aged population , and the dropout rate among haredi student is almost three time higher ( 23.9 % ) than the rate among non-haredi Jewish student ( 8.2 % ) . & ldquo ; Given our finding , we are calling for more inclusive community engagement program that reflect and further enhance the diversity in higher education , & rdquo ; Orr concluded . & ldquo ; It appears that the key solution for the optimal integration of haredi student in community engagement program should be understanding the unique need and cultural sensitivity of this community . & rdquo ;
title: community engagement motivates ultra-orthodox jewish men to pursue higher education - study

Body Text: United Nations Security Council member on Monday called for a restoration of calm a Israeli-Palestinian violence escalated in Jerusalem and the Gaza Strip . & nbsp ; The Security Council held a closed-door session on Monday to discus rising tension in east Jerusalem , particularly around the Temple Mount , also known a al-Haram al-Sharif . & nbsp ; The meeting wa held in New York just before Palestinians in Gaza launched rocket at Israel . & nbsp ; China , which hold the UNSC presidency this month , wa expected to issue a statement on it behalf later in the day . & nbsp ; After the meeting , Chinese Ambassador to the UN Zhang Jung tweeted : & ldquo ; Let & rsquo ; s work together for the de-escalation . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Vietnam & rsquo ; s mission to the UN tweeted a summary of what it told the Security Council , saying it expressed & ldquo ; grave concern , & rdquo ; condemned & ldquo ; all act of violence [ and urged ] all party to exercise [ maximum ] restraint . & rdquo ; Hanoi also called on Israel to stop settlement activity and to halt & ldquo ; forced eviction & rdquo ; of Palestinians and & ldquo ; home demolition . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Diplomats said the briefing wa requested by two-thirds of the 15-member council & ndash ; Tunisia , Ireland , China , Estonia , France , Norway , Niger , St . Vincent and the Grenadines and Vietnam . & nbsp ; After the meeting , Norway & rsquo ; s mission to the UN tweeted it wa & ldquo ; critical that political , religious [ and ] other leader do all they can to de-escalate this volatile situation . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; All measure aimed at altering the demographic composition , character [ and ] status of the Palestinian Territory occupied since 1967 are illegal , & rdquo ; it added . & nbsp ; The Trump administration had been supportive of Israel at the UN and used it veto power at the Security Council to protect the Jewish state from censure . & nbsp ; US President Joe Biden ha promised to stand by Israel at the UN , but the Jerusalem and Gaza violence could test that resolve . & nbsp ; Reuters contributed to this report .
title: unsc member call for calm amid jerusalem , gaza violence flare-up

Body Text: Rocks were thrown at Israel Police and Border Police officer on the Temple Mount Tuesday night , the Israel Police Spokesperson announced . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Authorities have tried to disperse the protester , arresting one . & nbsp ; Police reportedly arrested eleven suspect for disorderly conduct and assaulting police officer on Tuesday afternoon during a protest against the recent escalation on Ben-Gurion Boulevard , near the University Junction in Beersheba . & nbsp ; One of the protester who wa arrested reportedly stabbed an 18-year-old during clash that broke out between Jews and Bedouin . A Jewish student at Ben-Gurion University of the Negev and activist in the Kumi Israel protest movement said she wa rescued by Border Police officer from being & quot ; lynched & quot ; by right-wing protester after arriving at the scene to document the protest , the movement said in a statement . & nbsp ; In her video , dozen of right-wing protester can be seen gathered around the activist , calling her a & quot ; whore for Arabs & quot ; and threatening to harm her a Border Police force who were at the scene protected her and escorted her from the scene back to her car . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; The activist said & quot ; I felt a real danger to my life . If I had not been surrounded by five Border policeman , I would not have left that protest alive ; there wa a guy who had already begun swinging his hand in my direction . & quot ; & nbsp ; Further video released by the activist revealed that a man had indeed tried to swing his fist at her before police moved him away and began escorting her to her car . & nbsp ; A witness at the scene told Kumi Israel that & quot ; Hundreds of demonstrator gathered around her and blocked her on both side of the road , cursing , shouting and threatening her , until a Border Police officer rescued her . & quot ; Israeli Police reported that a 42-year-old man wa stabbed at the Temple Mount compound on Tuesday evening and that the Red Crescent ha evacuated him to a hospital , where his death wa determined shortly thereafter . & nbsp ; Police added that officer who arrived at the scene have likely located the weapon used in the assault and that & quot ; action are being taken to locate those involved in the incident . & quot ; Police have determined that the background for the stabbing incident wa likely related to criminal matter , and wa not related to the protest at the Temple Mount compound . & nbsp ; Meanwhile , one Palestinians wa killed and another wounded while allegedly attempting a ramming attack at Tapuah Junction in Judea and Samaria on Tuesday evening , Zaka reported . It wa later discovered that the Palestinian men did not have weapon and we apparently not intending to harm soldier . & nbsp ; IDF soldier from the Givati Brigade reportedly shot toward the suspect , neutralizing them in the process . According to a statement , the volunteer firefighter spotted a Palestinian woman acting & quot ; suspiciously & quot ; near Huwara . When he approached her , the woman pulled out a knife and began running toward a bus station . He managed to subdue the woman , tackling her to the ground and calling in the authority . The incident come amid a massive upsurge of violent incident in the West Bank , including fire from burning tire and Molotov cocktail . & nbsp ; Israeli Arab protester in Haifa also engaged in disturbance , throwing rock and assaulting police officer . In addition , a restaurant in Acre and a car in the area were also burnt in protest . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Eight resident of Jisr az-Zarqa were also arrested early Wednesday on suspicion of throwing stone and burning tire , while in Wadi Ara , rioter threw stone , Molotov cocktail and firework at police , according to KAN news . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Jerusalem Post Staff contributed to this report . & nbsp ;

Body Text: Israel could consider a small tactical pause to the Gaza war for an hour or so , Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told David Muir of ABC & rsquo ; s World News Tonight program a he responded to the international pressure for a ceasefire . & ldquo ; As far a tactical little pause , an hour here , an hour there , we have had them before , & rdquo ; Netanyahu said . & ldquo ; We will check the circumstance in order to enable humanitarian good to come in or individual hostage to leave , & rdquo ; he stated on Tuesday.Earlier in the day he spoke with US President Joe Biden about the possibility of such a pause to the war which wa sparked on October 7 , when Hamas killed over 1,400 people in southern Israel and kidnapped over 240 others.According to the White House , & ldquo ; the two leader discussed the possibility of tactical pause to provide civilian with opportunity to safely depart from area of ongoing fighting . & rdquo ; Such pause , the White House said , would & ldquo ; ensure assistance is reaching civilian in need , and . . . enable potential hostage release . & rdquo ; Netanyahu : Ceasefire akin to surrenderIsrael ha insisted that any ceasefire must include the release of all the hostage , and that even then it could happen only with the understanding that the IDF still intends to pursue it military campaign to oust Hamas from Gaza.The United States ha backed Israel on that point , but the two side have differed on a mechanism for humanitarian pause , with Israel fearing that such a break in the fighting could become a de facto ceasefire . & ldquo ; A ceasefire would be a surrender to Hamas . It would be a victory for Hamas and you would no more have it than you would have a ceasefire after the al-Qaeda bombing of the World Trade Center & rdquo ; in New York in 2001 , Netanyahu told ABC . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; There will be no general ceasefire in Gaza without the release of our hostage , & rdquo ; he stressed.A ceasefire would hamper the & ldquo ; war effort & rdquo ; a well a effort to secure the release of the hostage , he said . & ldquo ; The only thing that work on these criminal in Hamas is the military pressure we are exerting , & rdquo ; Netanyahu said . & ldquo ; Until we started the ground operation there wa no pressure on them to release hostage . What we see is that the minute we started the ground action there wa pressure , `` he added.Netanyahu also appeared to indicate that Israel might have some intelligence on the location of the hostages.He also addressed the civilian cost of the campaign to Palestinians in Gaza , in light of the UN 's reporting that some 1.5 million of the 2.7 million people living in the coastal enclave have been displaced due to the war . Hamas ha asserted that over 10,000 people have been killed.Netanyahu said the number included at least several thousand Palestinian combatant . & ldquo ; Every civilian lost is a tragedy . We are fighting an enemy that is particularly brutal . They are using their civilian a human shield , & rdquo ; he said , referencing the fact that Hamas place it infrastructure in civilian area . & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s important to understand that there is no way to defeat terrorist & rdquo ; embedded in civilian area without incurring civilian casualty , he stated.Muir also asked Netanyahu if he took responsibility for the Israeli security failure that led to the October 7 attack . & ldquo ; The responsibility of the government is to protect the people and that clearly wa not met , `` Netanyahu said , but he added that the issue wa best addressed after the war.Netanyahu agreed with Muir that he needed to take responsibility but not while conducting a military campaign.When the war is over , he said , & ldquo ; tough question are going to be asked and I am going to be the among first to answer them . & rdquo ;
title: netanyahu : small tactical pause to gaza war possible

Body Text: Operation Guardian of the Walls wa not meant to overthrow Hamas , but to bring about deterrence by severely hitting the capability of the terrorist group in the Gaza Strip , IDF Chief of Staff Lt . - Gen . The Six Day War wa a sharp and smooth victory ; but shortly after , the War of Attrition began . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Deterrence is & ldquo ; an elusive concept subject to the cruel judgment of the time , & rdquo ; he continued , adding that it must be translated into & ldquo ; strategic and political achievement , and we have all said & ndash ; the prime minister , defense minister & ndash ; that whatever wa will not be , both in our reaction and our attitude toward Hamas . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The mainly air campaign saw hundred of target struck by the IDF in response to the over 4,000 rocket fired by the terrorist group . Hundreds of the target hit had been found , marked and hit in real-time , including missile launcher that were aimed at Tel Aviv and Jerusalem . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; During three day of Operation Guardian of the Walls , the Southern Command and the Gaza Division destroyed 70 multibarreled launcher . They destroyed a multibarreled launcher every hour , & rdquo ; the chief of staff said , adding that thanks to technique and capability developed during the fighting , & ldquo ; we were able to bring a new connection between the sensor and intelligence & rdquo ; and expose the multibarreled launcher . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We then set out to attack one after the other , & rdquo ; he said . & nbsp ; Other target destroyed included rocket launcher , rocket manufacturing , production and storage site , military intelligence office , drone , residence of commander , and Hamas & rsquo ; s naval commando unit , where Israel ha destroyed most of the group & rsquo ; s infrastructure and weaponry , including several autonomous GPS-guided submarine that can carry 30 kilogram of explosive . & nbsp ; The majority of attack that the group tried to carry out against Israel were also stopped and the majority of the rocket fired towards Israel were intercepted . & nbsp ; Hamas , Kohavi said , did not succeed in the way they wanted . & nbsp ; During the fighting & ldquo ; we attacked three time more every day , and with high-quality and accurate targeting , than in previous operation . This show the capability of the IDF that we will continue to develop , & rdquo ; he said . & nbsp ; But the capability of the IDF are not cheap , he said , and neither are the munition and other weapon that the military need . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; You can & rsquo ; t do what I said without money . Without a fixed and regulated budget . All over the world , the concept of an army is that it is going to be more expensive . An anti-tank missile is more expensive than 30 year ago , for many reason . Tanks are more expensive , F-35s are more expensive . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; And the Iron Dome , which the military say intercepted 90 % of rocket fired towards residential area , is not cheap either . title: idf chief kohavi : be modest with how long gaza deterrence will last

Body Text: A 5 % across-the-board budget cut for government ministry wa the main proposal in a series of budget cut laid out at a Finance Ministry meeting on the 2025 budget held Wednesday , Globes said source from the ministry told them.Other proposed cut included pay cut for senior manager in the public sector , postponed raise in the civil service , abolishing unnecessary ministry , and a NIS 2 to 4 billion cut in fund allocated to coalition party - all amounting to NIS 3.5 billion , according to Globes.While the total amount of cut that the ministry make in order to reduce Israel 's deficit is critical to the country 's economic recovery ; given Israel 's political and social climate , the composition of the cut that are made is also critical.Unequal treatmentFlat budget cut across the board for all ministry will likely have significant repercussion for all part of Israel 's society , which could cause widespread frustration if the public doe not think that serious cut to coalition fund , and fund for unnecessary ministry that prop the coalition up are being prioritized over cut that hurt the entire public.The recent controversy over the `` rabbi bill `` and the haredi draft law have highlighted deep discontentment in Israel 's society when it come to the treatment of different sector of society differently and the equal sharing of national burdens.The rabbi bill aim to give the government control over appointment of municipal and neighborhood rabbi , instead of the current system where the city appoint their rabbis.As pointed out in The Jerusalem Post 's editorial on Wednesday , this bill is widely viewed a an attempt by the coalition & rsquo ; s haredi party to appoint it member to position and gain influence over issue of religion and state.Highlighting the sense that this bill is seens a a coalition jobs-grab , Yesh Atid MK Yaron Levi summed up the inequality many felt this bill strengthened . & ldquo ; If the prime minister can approve 1,000 new rabbi , and not 1,000 psychologist , then this place is a piece of trash , `` he said.Public protest of the unequal sharing of the security burden ha also been coming to a head recently a the haredi draft law is advanced with no real solution in sight.The IDF say that they need more manpower , the ultra-Orthodox leadership ha not made concession that would allow for a bill that satisfies this need , and the public fury over this inequality grows with every day that the law is not amended and that more IDF soldier are killed in the Israel-Hamas war and in Israel 's northern conflict with Hezbollah.The 2025 budget may become just another instance of the government 's failing balancing act between coalition pressure and demand by the public to meet the need of the majority of Israelis.This would n't be entirely new . The current government ha already been criticized for how sectoral it allocation of fund ha been and for failing to address this and cut coalition fund when the war necessitated a rethinking of the 2024 budget . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We found in this budget , that to a much larger extent than in previous coalition agreement , coalition resource were very sectoral , & rdquo ; former Bank of Israel Governor Karnit Flug told The Jerusalem Post last month . & ldquo ; The fact that they didn & rsquo ; t cut coalition expenditure [ after the outbreak of the war ] that are very sectoral and are not based on professional work substantially undermines the trust in the government . This will make it much harder to come to the public and say & lsquo ; look , there is an additional burden that you will have to incur , & rsquo ; & rdquo ; explained Flug.The Israel-Hamas war ha brought the issue of the unequal burden on Israel 's different sector , long kicked down the road , to a head . Given this and the precarious situation of the coalition , Israel 's budget could potentially be the next crisis that could topple it , or bring the widespread public protest to new boiling points.Public trust in the government ha been stretched and challenged possibly beyond repair since the outbreak of the war , and also in the year prior during the advancement of the judicial overhaul.The budget is another opportunity for the government to try to show the public it is prioritizing the need of the many ; or for it to show that coalition demand are the top of it list of priority . & nbsp ;
title: is the 2025 budget israel 's next social powder keg ? - analysis

Body Text: A Syrian soldier wa injured in alleged Israeli airstrikes targeting site in the Damascus area on Monday night , according to Syrian state media.The Syrian Capital Voice news site reported that site in or near the Damascus International Airport were targeted in the strike . We are activating measure and will activate additional measure , both offensive and defensive , to deal with the murderer and also with their dispatcher , from near and far , `` said the prime minister.Recent strike in the Damascus areaThe strike in the Damascus area are the first alleged Israeli airstrikes reported in Syria since four Syrian soldier were killed in airstrikes near Damascus in early August.The strike in early August targeted site near Saidnayah and Mneen , north of Damascus , hitting warehouse belonging to the Syrian military used by Iran-backed militia , according to the Capital Voice.Those strike were the first such strike since late July when the Syrian Foreign Ministry accused Israel of attacking the country 's Internal Security Forces in al-Qahtaniah in the Quneitra Governorate along the border with the Golan Heights.That attack resulted in material damage and no injury , according to the Syrian Foreign Ministry . Body Text: Idan Damotov , the victim in the car crash with National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir that occurred on Friday , said that he is `` alright , a bit better `` and that he is `` now waiting for a CT scan `` after seriously injuring his knee in the crash . & nbsp ; Damotov , speaking on Tuesday to 103FM 's Udi Segal and Guy Peleg , said that it wa `` all a matter of second . `` According to Damotov , the crash , which landed Ben-Gvir in the hospital with light injury , happened quickly . `` I drove to the bank to deposit money . I entered the junction , driving with a green light and into an empty junction , and simply out of nowhere , Ben-Gvir 's convoy crashed into me from my left , swerving into my lane and causing the vehicle to crash into one another . `` `` I did n't plan on being hospitalized for five day ; that 's not what I want , `` he continued . `` I wa wearing a seatbelt , the airbags deployed , the car wa damaged beyond repair , the whole windshield wa shattered , it wa a mess . `` According to his lawyer , Rafat Asadi , Damotov is anxious . `` It is not every day that a person can be involved in such an accident with someone who sits at the top of the police pyramid , `` he said . `` This is not a normal incident . `` Dashcam footage of Itamar Ben-Gvir 's car crash , April 27 , 2024 . ( Credit : According to Section 27A of the Copyright Act ) Damotov said that Ben-Gvir called him when the minister wa released from the hospital . `` He asked how I wa , saw what wa going on with me , and that wa it , `` he said . I can not justify that just because he wa threatened give him the right to drive through a red light and risk the life of other people . There 's something to be said there , but you must still drive more carefully and take more responsibility for yourself . `` At the end of the day , there are other people around you , and you 're not the only person in the world , `` he concluded . `` I 'm here by miracle , I 'm hospitalized here , and I know that I am here by miracle alone , and I could have , heaven forbid , not been here . `` What happened in the car crash ? The car accident occurred on Friday while Ben-Gvir wa leaving the scene of a stabbing attack in Ramle that morning that left one eighteen-year-old woman in serious condition . & nbsp ; Ben-Gvir had been hospitalized for a couple of day . His daughter , who wa in the car during the crash , wa released Saturday . Body Text: Israel & rsquo ; s continued war-between-wars campaign ha led to a decrease in Iran smuggling weapon into Syria , according to IDF Chief of Staff Lt . - Gen . Aviv Kohavi . & ldquo ; The increase in the scope of operation over the past year ha led to a significant disruption of all smuggling route into various arena by our enemy , & rdquo ; he told reporter on Sunday , ahead of New Year & rsquo ; s Day . Israel ha repeatedly warned about Iran & rsquo ; s nuclear ambition a well a aspiration of regional hegemony . It ha admitted to hundred of airstrikes a part of it & ldquo ; war-between-wars & rdquo ; ( known a MABAM in Hebrew ) campaign to prevent the transfer of advanced weapon to Hezbollah in Lebanon and the entrenchment of it force in Syria , where they could easily act against Israel . In an attempt to halt Iran & rsquo ; s hostile regional activity , Israel ha increased it operation in Syria . The firing of antiaircraft missile by regime force ha also increased . The military belief Iran , Syria and Hezbollah are deterred from war with Israel , a they rarely retaliate against Israeli strike . When they do , they tend to target US base . The latest alleged Israeli strike on Tuesday morning targeted Latakia Port and destroyed an immeasurable amount of advanced and strategic weaponry . However , the strike have not been limited to Syria . Iran & rsquo ; s air , land and sea corridor did not function for 70 % of 2021 due to operation carried out a part of the MABAM . Kohavi said last year that the increase in operation , both overt and clandestine , had led to a slowdown of Iran & rsquo ; s entrenchment in Syria . & ldquo ; But we still have a long way to go to complete our goal in this arena , & rdquo ; he said . With the risk of regional war breaking out being low , and a Israel & rsquo ; s campaign against Iran in Syria is achieving satisfactory result , the MABAM will continue into the coming year , senior military officer have said . During a visit to the Ramat David Air Force Base along with IAF Commander Maj . - Gen . Amikam Norkin and OC Strategy and Third Circle Division Maj . - Gen . Tal Kalman , Defense Minister Benny Gantz called on the country in the region to stop Iran from harming their sovereignty . The IDF had a year with & ldquo ; significant operational action , & rdquo ; Gantz said , adding that the military ha dealt with threat on various front , & ldquo ; all of which are fueled by Iran , which is the greatest enemy to the citizen of Israel and the people of the Middle East . & ldquo ; The Iranian regime can not provide education or water to it citizen , but it continues to invest huge sum in it nuclear project and it proxy . Iran is undermining governance in Syria , Lebanon , Yemen and other country , and it seek to set the region on fire . I call on the country of the region to stop Iran from harming it sovereignty and resident . & rdquo ; Israel will not allow Iran to send balance-breaking weapon to it proxy to threaten Israeli citizen , he said . & ldquo ; The IDF will continue to operate everywhere & ndash ; in the air , on land and at sea & ndash ; to ensure the security of the State of Israel , & rdquo ; Gantz said . In addition to Israel & rsquo ; s policy of removing Iran from Syria , the regime of President Bashar Assad ha been working with the Russians in an attempt to expel all foreign force from Syria . After Assad regained control of 60 % of the country , the government ha been trying to reassert itself a sovereign and expel Iran and it proxy , including Hezbollah and other Shi & rsquo ; ite militia . As Assad work with Russia , Israel will continue to take advantage of the situation to push Iran out . While Israel & rsquo ; s strongest ally remains the United States , the IDF continues to work with Russia , a key influencer in the Middle East and especially in Syria , where it ha leverage over Assad . In addition to continuing the MABAM , the IDF is advancing plan for a military strike against Iran , to be prepared if or when the political echelon decides to carry out that strike against Tehran & rsquo ; s nuclear program . During a speech at the Institute for National Security Studies conference in Tel Aviv last year , Kohavi said he had ordered the military to begin preparing renewed plan for a strike on Iran & rsquo ; s nuclear program . & ldquo ; Iran can decide that it want to advance to a bomb , either covertly or in a provocative way , & rdquo ; Kohavi said . & ldquo ; In light of this basic analysis , I have ordered the IDF to prepare a number of operational plan in addition to the existing one . We are studying these plan , and we will develop them over the next year . The government , of course , will be the one to decide if they should be used . But these plan must be on the table , in existence and trained for . & rdquo ; With tension increasing over Iran & rsquo ; s nuclear program and regional hostility , both Israel and Iran have been threatening each other . Senior officer have said the military is capable of carrying out a strike . On Friday , at the end of five day of military drill , Iran fired 16 ballistic missile toward a target simulating Israel & rsquo ; s nuclear facility in Dimona . The IDF know that should a strike be ordered , the response would be a multifront war with Hamas , Hezbollah and other Iranian proxy , firing thousand of rocket , including precision missile , toward Israel and it strategic asset . To prepare for such a scenario , the IDF ha increased it intelligence-gathering capability for future operation , procuring additional weaponry , updating operational plan for all front , increased training exercise over the past year , and updated it target bank . Although the amount of precision weapon it ha is 10 time the number it had on the eve of the Second Lebanon War , the IDF is continuing to procure a large amount of precision and special munition . The NIS 58 billion defense budget set for the IDF in the coming year is expected to allow the military to focus on the threat posed by Iran across the region , with NIS 3.5b . designated for this . Intelligence and operational cooperation , along with joint exercise with foreign and regional country , are also helping Israel & rsquo ; s security and are of great significance , the military belief . A year after the signing of the Abraham Accords , which led to the normalization of relation with several Arab country , the potential for cooperation and the building of significant military manpower is already evident . The main threat to the country remain the rocket arsenal of Hamas and Hezbollah , Iran & rsquo ; s nuclear program , and potential nuclear weapon and infiltration force such a Hezbollah & rsquo ; s Radwan Unit . As tension with Lebanon and Syria remained high , 31 rocket were fired from Lebanon and another two long-range rocket were fired from Syria . In response to the rocket fired from Lebanon ( by Palestinians and Hezbollah ) , the IDF fired munition from fighter plane and some 200 artillery shell . The military also thwarted nine attempt to infiltrate from Lebanon and another two from Syria . It also confiscated 120 kilogram of drug and 75 weapon over the past year . Despite the ongoing tension , the IDF view the overall strategic-security situation a having improved compared with previous year .

Body Text: Since the signing of the Oslo Accords , the peace treaty between Israel and Jordan , and the Wye River Agreement in the 1990s , effort by politician and diplomat to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict have stalled . In the 21st century , according to Rabbi Ron Kronish , religious extremism , ultranationalist fanaticism , and intransigent leadership on both side , fueled by competing narrative about the past and the present , meant & ldquo ; a war process replaced the peace process . & rdquo ; According to Kronish , after then-opposition leader and Maj . - Gen . ( re . ) Ariel Sharon made a provocative visit to the Temple Mount , Palestinians launched a Second Intifada ; the Israeli government constructed what it called a & ldquo ; security fence , & rdquo ; which Palestinians blasted a an & ldquo ; apartheid wall & rdquo ; ; and , in 2005 prime minister Sharon ordered what turned out to be a disastrous withdrawal of Jewish settler and the IDF from the Gaza Strip.These development , Kronish state in his book Profiles in Peace , have made peacebuilders & ldquo ; the only game in town . & rdquo ; The initiative of the non-governmental organization they established , he belief , provide the last best hope to influence decision-makers to reverse course and make compromise to ensure a just and lasting resolution to what is now regarded a an intractable conflict.Can NGOs help decision-makers make peace ? Born in the US and educated at Brandeis University and Harvard & rsquo ; s Graduate School of Education , Kronish immigrated to Israel in 1979 , four month after Israel and Egypt signed a peace agreement . In 1982 , Kronish took to the street , joining protest declaring the Israeli army complicit in the massacre of Palestinians in the refugee camp of Sabra and Shatilla in Beirut . & nbsp ; From 1991-2014 , he served a the founder and director of the Interreligious Coordinating Council in Israel ( ICCI ) . A harsh critic of what he call the & ldquo ; militaristic , anti-Palestinian , pro-occupation & rdquo ; Likud Party , a well a PLO and Hamas terrorist , Kronish is the author of The Other Peace Process ( 2017 ) . In Profiles in Peace , Kronish review effort by politician to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict since the 1967 Six Day War and provides biographical sketch of six peacebuilders & ndash ; three Israelis and three Palestinian Arabs & ndash ; and four member of a younger generation of activist . & nbsp ; Despite & ldquo ; overwhelming obstacle and complex challenge , & rdquo ; Kronish claim , these men and woman have demonstrated that & ldquo ; enriching and energizing & rdquo ; relationship with perceived enemy can be forged , laying the foundation for a common future for Jews , Christians and Arabs.Peacebuilders operate on the assumption that dialogue on subject of mutual interest , undertaken in supportive setting , enhanced by precept of trauma healing and conflict resolution , can empower individual to bridge religious and ethnic difference . Hands of Peace , for example , brings Israeli and Palestinian teenager to the US for four successive summer . In 2018 , the Alliance for Middle East Peace created a Storyteller & rsquo ; s Project to enlist peacebuilding alumnus , including Israeli and Palestinian soldier , to share their experiences.Again and again ( Profiles in Peace , ala , is often repetitious ) , Kronish single out initiative to & ldquo ; get to know & lsquo ; the other & rsquo ; deeply , & rdquo ; and take seriously his or her religious and historical narrative , a central to peace work.Who are the activist ? KRONISH & rsquo ; S ACTIVISTS & ndash ; Huda Abuarquob , Mohammed Dajani Daoudi , Munib Younan , Michael Melchior , Galia Golan , and Hadassah Froman & ndash ; have certainly exhibited an abundance of courage , conviction , commitment , perseverance and resilience.It & rsquo ; s less clear , however , how effective their effort have been . Kronish doe not address study revealing that contact doe not increase religious or ethnic toleration in & ldquo ; weak relationship . & rdquo ; And that self-selection is a significant ( and therefore limiting ) factor in forging enduring relationship with perceived enemies.As Kronish and his peacebuilders acknowledge , moreover , the political context between Israel and the Palestinians ha made free and unfettered interreligious and intercultural dialogue difficult to arrange . When Dajani , a professor of American study and librarian at Al-Quds University , proposed taking 30 Palestinian student to Auschwitz and 30 student to a refugee camp in Bethlehem , a violent response to the trip led to his resignation and the cancellation of the project . & nbsp ; And neither Israeli nor Palestinian authority accepted the recommendation of Bishop Younan & rsquo ; s Council of Religious Institutions of the Holy Land to revise textbook in the schools.Most important , during the last two decade , peacebuilders & rsquo ; initiative have not had a significant impact on Israeli or Palestinian politician , or for that matter , on public opinion.And so , it should not be surprising that , along with frequent expression of hope , Kronish & rsquo ; s peacebuilders sometimes give voice to pessimism about the future . Given & ldquo ; the many force of violence and opposition to what we are doing , & rdquo ; Froman declares her intention , somehow , to & ldquo ; create a small oasis of peaceful coexistence & rdquo ; in her area of the West Bank . & nbsp ; Convinced that & ldquo ; civil strife may one day lead to the end of Israel , regardless of the occupation , & rdquo ; Golan find it & ldquo ; very difficult to be optimistic these day . & rdquo ; Although dialogue ha broadened his horizon , Tareq Saman , one of Kronish & rsquo ; s younger peacebuilders , ha concluded that & ldquo ; there is no solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict & hellip ; It look like one party will win and the other will lose . & rdquo ; Responding in his prison notebook to the rise of fascism in the 1930s , Marxist theorist Antonio Gramsci indicated he wa & ldquo ; far from feeling beaten . It seems to me that & hellip ; a man out to be deeply convinced that the source of his own moral force is himself & hellip ; never fall into those vulgar , banal mood , pessimism and optimism . My own state of mind synthesizes these two feeling and transcends them ; my mind is pessimistic , but my will is optimistic & hellip ; I imagine the worst that could happen in order to summon up my reason and willpower to overcome every obstacle . & rdquo ; In all likelihood , Kronish doe not endorse Gramsci & rsquo ; s pessimism of the intellect & ndash ; even if the considerable obstacle in Israel , the West Bank and Gaza make it seem reasonable to do so .  The writer is the Thomas and Dorothy Litwin Professor of American Studies at Cornell University.PROFILES IN PEACEBy Ron KronishL.E.A.R.H.N . Peacebuilding Publications215 page ; $ 22.95
title: ' profile in peace ' : how ngo peacebuilders became the ' only game in town ' - review

Body Text: The Likud & rsquo ; s response to the Meron report is indicative of the party & rsquo ; s tactic and strategy surrounding the question of responsibility , accountability , and blame for the October 7 Hamas massacre : Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is not to blame , and anyone who claim so ha partisan political motives.The response came from the party , not from the prime minister himself . Netanyahu & rsquo ; s medium team know how to put him in the limelight when they want to : they use video statement , picture , written statement , and often a mix of all of the above . In this case , a written statement from the Likud party , not the prime minister himself , show that the prime minister intends to keep himself a far away a possible from the report & rsquo ; s conclusions.The content of the response follows this theme . It begin , & ldquo ; The Meron disaster wa tragic , our heart are with the family of the victim . In practice , the government ha already implemented the required conclusion , and the last event at Meron wa held with a large crowd and without fault . The government will examine the need to implement additional operational lesson to prevent a repetition of a disaster such a this . & rdquo ; The statement then move on to accusation : & ldquo ; However , it is unfortunate that for the first time in history , the government led by Bennett and Lapid formed a committee of investigation against it predecessor in the political Right , and in which a central member wa a confidante of Lapid , Shlomo Yanai , who received an offer for a spot in the Yesh Atid Knesset list . This is a completely distinct political provocation . Lapid & rsquo ; s cynical and intentional attempt to turn the Meron disaster into a political tool will not succeed . & rdquo ; This response wa criticized by member of nearly all of the political party , including the Likud itself , a well a by a forum that represents the family of the victim , who called it & ldquo ; disgraceful . & rdquo ; It is worth noting that member of the National Commission of Inquiry were chosen by then-chief justice Esther Hayut , not by the Lapid-Bennett government . The Netanyahu government at the time of the disaster dragged it foot in forming the committee , and at first attempted to form a governmental or parliamentary committee , which would give it some power over the identity of the committee member , a well a reduce the impact of it conclusions.Furthermore , the Likud & rsquo ; s response did not mention that Yanai is a retired IDF Major General , a recipient of the IDF & rsquo ; s Medal of Distinguished Service , a former CEO of Teva Pharmaceutical Industries , and , according to Haaretz reporter Yossi Melman , wa Netanyahu & rsquo ; s choice to head the Mossad in 2010 ( which Yanai turned down ) . Nor did the response mention the other distinguished member of the commission & ndash ; former Supreme Court President Miriam Naor , who wa replaced by Tel Aviv District Court president Devorah Berliner , and Rabbi Mordechai Karelitz , former mayor of Bnei Brak.Instead of at least acknowledging the fact that Netanyahu wa found to bear personal responsibility for the disaster , the response attempt to discredit the member of the committee . Other than saying that the government will examine whether there are any more lesson to implement , the response doe not address any of the sweeping systemic failure that the committee found led to the disaster & ndash ; nor the fact that these failure were exacerbated during the decade before the disaster , during which Netanyahu wa prime minister.Likud responds similarly to October 7The response is indicative of how the Likud ha responded to the October 7 massacre . At least on two occasion , the Likud put out immediate response to reported intelligence failure leading up to the massacre , in which it said that Netanyahu wa not aware of the intelligence and that he wa not forewarned by IDF officials.The prime minister ha promised that there will be a committee of investigation , but it is not clear when such a committee will be formed . In addition , since the October 7 massacre , he mentioned the word & ldquo ; responsibility & rdquo ; in just one press conference & ndash ; and said that he wa & ldquo ; responsible for the future of the State of Israel , & rdquo ; which implied that he wa not responsible for event in the past.The government wa slammed with responsibility for the failure of October 7 , and at first , the word & ldquo ; responsibility & rdquo ; wa uttered by no one ; slowly , that changed . IDF Chief of Staff Lt . - Gen . Herzi Halevi said it first , followed by Defense Minister Yoav Gallant and Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich . Netanyahu still ha not.A direct line link the Likud & rsquo ; s response to the Meron report and it statement since the October 7 massacre : Netanyahu is not responsible , and whoever claim so ha political motif . This is likely to continue , and it is thus not clear how and when those who bear responsibility for the event of October 7 will be held accountable . & nbsp ;
title: likud 's response to the meron report is indicative of what 's to come - analysis

Body Text: As international actor debate the legitimacy of Israel & rsquo ; s operation in Gaza , the war on Israel & rsquo ; s northern front rage on . Deaths from the Israel-Hezbollah conflict are continuing to rise , and over 100,000 Israelis are still evacuated from their home in northern Israel , leading some to question the efficacy of the UN peacekeeper force meant to maintain security in southern Lebanon.After the Israeli army finished a military operation against the Palestine Liberation Organization ( PLO ) in Lebanon in 1978 , the UN established a temporary peacekeeping force known a the United Nations Interim Forces in Lebanon ( UNIFIL ) . The body wa meant to restore international peace and security and to assist Lebanon & rsquo ; s government and army in restoring control of the border with Israel.Israel & rsquo ; s 1978 invasion pushed the PLO north of the Litani River , about 18 mile from the border , in order to limit attack against Israel . Despite the establishment of UNIFIL a a peacekeeper force , Israel returned to Lebanon in 1982 . In 2006 , another conflict broke out between Israel and Hezbollah , a Lebanese Shiite group with tie to Iran.After 34 day of fighting between Hezbollah and Israel in 2006 , the UN brokered a cease-fire . Under the agreement , UN Security Council Resolution 1701 , Israel and Hezbollah agreed to cease hostility , and UNIFIL wa tasked with ensuring that no armed group other than itself and the Lebanese army operated south of the Litani River.Today , UNIFIL comprises more than 10,000 soldier from 49 nation . In addition to monitoring the border , the organization also provides humanitarian assistance to civilian affected by the exchange of fire in southern Lebanon.UNIFIL 's role pre-October 7 & ldquo ; Before Oct . 7 , we were able to guarantee the overall stability of the southern border for year , and this wa clearly a success , & rdquo ; Andrea Tenenti , spokesperson for the UNIFIL mission , told The Media Line . & ldquo ; We played an active role . In fact , we have helped the Lebanese army , starting from 2008 , to regain control of the southern part of the country . & rdquo ; Despite UNIFIL & rsquo ; s success , Hezbollah ha grown stronger in southern Lebanon since 2006 , especially in the town and village along the 75-mile-long demarcation line , leading some to criticize UNIFIL a ineffective . Since Oct . 7 , a constant clash between Hezbollah and Israel have plagued southern Lebanon and northern Israel , those criticism have grown louder . & ldquo ; The UNIFIL mission started with very weak point and ended up being more a cease-fire resolution than a peacekeeping one , & rdquo ; Hanin Ghaddar , a senior fellow at the Washington Institute , told The Media Line . She noted that the force mostly report violation . & ldquo ; They do not possess the tool and permission from the UN to confiscate weapon or even arrest those affiliated with & rdquo ; Hezbollah , she said.Tenenti characterized UNIFIL a & ldquo ; the only one who can mediate properly & rdquo ; amid the rising tension , noting that the group had arranged meeting between the Israeli and Lebanese armies.UNIFIL doe not only monitor the conflict between Hezbollah and Israel & mdash ; at time , it find itself caught up in that contact . & nbsp ; Among other incident , a car bomb killed six UNIFIL personnel in 2007 , and in October , two mortar shell of undetermined origin hit a UNIFIL base , injuring one peacekeeper . & ldquo ; Hezbollah target UNIFIL because they do not want another actor in the south , & rdquo ; Ghaddar explained . & ldquo ; It is never an accident when UNIFIL personnel is targeted because the militant group aim to send a message both to the country that serve in these force and to the UN : do not interfere with our activity in the southern part of the country . & rdquo ; Avraham Levine , a speaker at the northern Israel-based Alma Research and Education Center , told The Media Line that Hezbollah ha more control over UNIFIL than UNIFIL doe over Hezbollah . & ldquo ; There are area where UNIFIL personnel can not go to , and if they end up by mistake in Hezbollah & rsquo ; s territory , they are attacked on the spot , their vehicle are burnt , and sometimes they are even shot down , & rdquo ; he said.Levine also said that Hezbollah us UNIFIL base for it military purpose . & ldquo ; Both in 2006 and in further operation that Israel carried against Hezbollah , the militant used UNIFIL compound a shield for their operation in order to stop Israel & rsquo ; s counterattack against a UN base , & rdquo ; he said.One of the rocket launched at Israel by Hezbollah in December originated just 20 yard from a UNIFIL compound.Levine said that the Lebanese army & rsquo ; s lack of action to rein in Hezbollah relates to the Shia sympathy of many of the soldier a well a the interest in avoiding another Lebanese civil war.Describing both UNIFIL and the Lebanese army a ineffective deterrent to Hezbollah , he said that Israel may have to invade Lebanon once again . & ldquo ; We can not risk another Oct . 7 in the northern part of Israel since [ Hezbollah Secretary-General Hassan ] Nasrallah publicly claimed his goal to invade the Galilee . Even if this scenario is not pleasant for both side , we may need to stop Hezbollah by entering Lebanon a we did in the past , & rdquo ; he said.In the event that a full-scale war between Israel and Hezbollah doe break out , UNIFIL may be a target , Levine said . & ldquo ; Maybe this may push to reconsider it mission in the first place , & rdquo ; he speculated .

Body Text: Defense Secretary Austin will host Israeli Minister of Defense Yoav Gallant for a bilateral meeting at the Pentagon next Tuesday , Pentagon Press Secretary Sabrina Singh said Thursday . & nbsp ; Austin and Gallant will discus securing hostage release , the need for more humanitarian aid to reach Gaza , and Israel 's plan to invade Rafah . & nbsp ; Austin and Gallant 's meeting will be separate from the meeting in which a team of senior interagency Israeli official will meet with the White House , a President Joe Biden discussed on a call earlier with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu , Singh said . & nbsp ; Singh said Austin and Gallant 's meeting wa set up a few week ago . & nbsp ; `` Yesterday , Secretary Austin spoke with Minister of Defense Golan regarding the negotiation for the release of hostage and a temporary ceasefire . Secretary Austin also raised the need to consider alternative to a major ground operation and Rafa while reiterating the shared goal of defeating Hamas , `` Singh said . `` They also discus the need to do more to protect civilian and urgently increase the flow of aid into Gaza through land crossing . `` The meeting is another chance to discus the urgent need for humanitarian aid to flow into Gaza , which Singh said Austin press Gallant on every phone call . & nbsp ; Gaza pierA vehicle cargo ship containing material needed to construct the temporary humanitarian aid pier of Gaza departed from Newport News , Virginia today , the Pentagon said . & nbsp ; The ship is transporting component for the `` floating modular pier system , `` which will be delivered to the US Army 's seventh transportation brigade , which will construct the pier in the Mediterranean . The Pentagon indicated the pier is still on track to be built by mid-April . & nbsp ; The US military will coordinate the movement of humanitarian aid but will not distribute it once it reach Gaza . Body Text: With the arrival of Holocaust Remembrance Day , the International Fellowship of Christians and Jews ( IFCJ ) ha reaffirmed it support for the Holocaust survivor community through it Dignity and Fellowship Program , which support 17,000 of Israel & rsquo ; s poorest elderly over the age of 80 , including 8,500 Holocaust survivor , in 54 municipality across the country.The program is committed to providing Holocaust survivor with food every week for the rest of their life . Additionally , it enables survivor to engage in various social and practical services.Much-needed aid for Holocaust survivor & nbsp ; The support provided by the organization is vital , a a 2023 study that assessed the need of the survivor community by the Foundation for the Welfare of Holocaust Victims found that 22 % of those who require financial support were forced to give up necessity due to lack of fund , including the use of electrical or medical equipment , medical test , clothing , and other basic needs.97-year-old Merra Vinogradov , a Holocaust survivor who regularly receives food delivery from the IFCJ , explained how the Fellowship had helped her , providing her with essential need and more . & ldquo ; I don & rsquo ; t need much and have always managed with little . The food delivery from the Fellowship mean that I don & rsquo ; t have to worry about not having enough money for food . I can buy meat , fruit , and vegetable and don & rsquo ; t feel the lack of food like I did during my youth , & rdquo ; she explained.Dedicated to their mission & nbsp ; According to the organization , & ldquo ; supporting and caring for Holocaust survivor is at the very heart of the International Fellowship of Christians and Jews & rsquo ; 40-year mission . & ldquo ; Our responsibility , and the responsibility of our hundred of thousand of supporter around the world , is to care for this community , with dignity and respect , in every way possible while we still have the chance , & rdquo ; explained Yael Eckstein , President of the IFCJ.Eckstein then elaborated on her firm commitment to continue the organization & rsquo ; s work for a long a it can . & ldquo ; We will make sure that Holocaust survivor are not forgotten and are provided with at least their basic need until that tragic day when the last one leaf our world , & rdquo ; Eckstein concluded . & ldquo ; These are people who suffered the worst and experienced unspeakable sacrifice and loss , and we owe it to them to spread the message of & lsquo ; Never Again & rsquo ; through action in a way that honor their life . & rdquo ;

Body Text: Hamas ha `` more to lose `` than gain by involving itself in the recent round of rocket barrage toward Israel following the launch of the IDF 's Operation Shield and Arrow , military expert and former Coordinator of Government Activities in the Territories ( COGAT ) official Dr . Moshe Elad told 104.5FM on Tuesday . `` Now , they are looking up to the sky and searching [ for IDF aircraft ] because they have been complacent due to the assumption that Israel is supposedly holding it fire , `` Elad told Gadi Ness in reply to whether Israeli force will find themselves in another direct confrontation with the Palestinian terror group in control of the Strip.Hamas ' carefully considering ' response to Israeli strike '' The question is `` whether the Palestinian Resistance Factions , which includes Hamas and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad ( PIJ ) , will issue an order to attack Israel , Elad continued . `` That is a very interesting question and , in my opinion , an attack by Hamas is under careful consideration because they have more to lose . There are close to 20,000 Palestinian worker who leave the Gaza Strip for work every day , [ Hamas ] understands this will no longer be the case if it open fire . `` Elad also speculated on the possibility that Hamas unit stationed across southern Lebanon will open fire at Israel 's North . `` They established a sub-Hezbollah , all under the Lebanese terror organization 's watchful eye . The question is whether it allows the Hamas faction in Lebanon to launch rocket or will they have to wait for confirmation from Iran . `` This scenario is plausible , `` Elad told 104.5FM . `` Including an order from the Iranians to start firing at Israel from all theater , including Iran itself . This would be an all-out war , `` he said.Military expert : An all-out war between Iran and Israel is possibleElad further warned the IDF that it might have to operate in three-to-four theatre simultaneously . `` Yes , we will be prepared . [ We will be in big trouble ] if we had not come prepared for this scenario.According to Elad , Operation Shield and Arrow will force Israel to commit more of an effort in the long term to provide some ' air to breathe ' in the region , adding that he expects that by the end of the operation , the Middle East 's map will appear kind to Israel . `` If there is a multi-front war , the IDF will be able to handle it , `` the military expert concluded . `` But it will come at the expense of something else . ``

Body Text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu ha promised to allocate an additional NIS 14 million to advance work on a project & ndash ; dubbed & ldquo ; sovereignty & rdquo ; or & ldquo ; apartheid & rdquo ; road & ndash ; that would link the E1 section of the Ma & rsquo ; aleh Adumim settlement with Jerusalem . & ldquo ; This is a significant breakthrough in advancing the issue , & rdquo ; Ma & rsquo ; aleh Adumim Mayor Benny Kashriel said in a statement on the matter posted on the city & rsquo ; s website . The project , also called the & ldquo ; Fabric of Life & rdquo ; road , is considered essential for the development of E1 , where Israel is slated to build 3,412 home in a move that would vastly expand Ma & rsquo ; aleh Adumim , which is the third-largest settler city in the West Bank , after Modi & rsquo ; in Illit and Betar Illit . The E1 project ha been largely frozen for close to three decade because Palestinians and the international community consider it harmful to the feasibility of a contiguous future Palestinian state . The US , excluding the Trump administration , had also historically objected to the project . Israel ha argued that the issue of contiguity is best addressed by an efficient but separate road system , including this one , that would allow direct Palestinian traffic between Ramallah and Bethlehem that skirt the E1 bloc , while Israeli travel between Jerusalem and Ma & rsquo ; aleh Adumim would also be made easier . Critics of the project have accused Israel of & ldquo ; apartheid & rdquo ; for it promotion of a road that separate Israeli and Palestinian traffic . The municipal notice about the project stated that there would be & ldquo ; a separate road for Palestinians in the E1 area , & rdquo ; which would distinguish between Israeli and Palestinian traffic so that & ldquo ; Palestinian vehicle could pas without traveling through the Ma & rsquo ; aleh Adumim bloc , near the Jewish settlement . & rdquo ; It noted that & ldquo ; at the political level , the road would connect Jerusalem and Ma & rsquo ; aleh Adumim and allow Jewish settlement construction in the E1 area . & rdquo ; The municipality added that it would ease traffic congestion and eliminate the need for checkpoint . The road would then exit from Eizariya-Abu Dis to the tunnel under the a-Zaim checkpoint , and vehicle would travel on a separate road toward Hizma-Ramallah , the municipality said . Yamina party head Naftali Bennett had initially promoted the project in March when he served a the defense minister . Kashriel said he had campaigned and pushed Netanyahu to allocate more funding , a move that bore fruit only this week , with a conversation between Kashriel , Netanyahu , Transportation Minister Miri Regev and Finance Minister Israel Katz , both of the Likud Party . Prior to the meeting Kashriel sent Netanyahu a letter in which he accused him of dragging his foot on the issue , noting that he had promised to pave the road three year ago at a Likud faction meeting in the Knesset . Then it wa determined that the road would be paved in 2020 . Again in August , a pledge wa once more given with respect to the road , and yet , Kashriel noted in his letter , he wa still seeking fund for the project . After receiving another pledge from Netanyahu for fund this week , Kashriel thanked the prime minister , along with Regev and Katz , for the help . The left-wing group Peace Now charged on Wednesday that the project wa part of Netanyahu & rsquo ; s reelection campaign . & ldquo ; Netanyahu & rsquo ; s election campaign is costing Israel a very heavy price . Once again , he is using the election period to try to impress key Likud supporter by promoting a plan that could eliminate the possibility of a two-state solution . The planned road will allow Israel to cut the West Bank in two , build E1 and the separation barrier , and close the door on the possibility of developing a sustainable Palestinian state . & rdquo ; In the last year , Netanyahu allowed for plan for 3,412 settler home in E1 to be deposited .
