Body Text: The Border Police on Wednesday shot and killed a masked Palestinian in Shuafat , who had aimed a realistic-looking dummy gun at them , a he fled.A video showing some of the chaos surrounding police and IDF force preparing to demolish the house of terrorist Udai Tamimi in Shuafat , show several moment in the back and forth between the sides.At one point in the video , the now-deceased Palestinian is seen aiming his `` gun `` at Israeli force and then lowering it when a large car pass by in between the sides.Then at another point , the Palestinian is seen again aiming his `` gun `` at Israeli forces.While one can not see the action of the Israeli force in the video , at a certain point , the Palestinian turn around and start running away.After a few second of running , he also toss away the `` gun . `` A few second later in the video , he fall down dead.Police say they did n't know the gun wa fakeFrom the limited vantage point of the video , it is possible that : 1 ) he wa shot at only after he dropped the dummy gun and fled ; 2 ) while holding the gun he aimed at police but then managed to toss the gun and run another 30-40 foot before collapsing ; or that 3 ) the police started shooting at him while he held the gun but may have only hit him after he wa fleeing . The police said he wa hit while still aiming the gun at them.The police reported that they discovered the & ldquo ; gun & rdquo ; wa a dummy weapon only after the fact . At the same time , it wa unclear whether the killing wa justified . If he wa hit before he wa fleeing it wa certainly justified . If he wa hit after he dropped the `` weapon `` and fled , it get hairier.Rules of engagement in such situation do provide for firing at the leg of such a person who ha presented a threat in order to prevent their escape and arrest them.An initial response response from the police did not address the issue of the Palestinian dropping his weapon and fleeing , but did highlight that he had shown all of the open sign of presenting a threat . & nbsp ; The IDF declined to comment , saying that even though there were soldier in the area , the incident had been managed by the border police . & nbsp ; The police would have been in charge given that the incident wa taking place in east Jerusalem a opposed to the West Bank , where the IDF ha primacy.Tamimi wa killed in mid-October when he wa shot dead in a failed shooting attack at the entrance to Ma & rsquo ; aleh Adumim , south of the Israeli capital.He arrived at the entrance to the West Bank city and opened fire at nearby security personnel . According to United Hatzalah volunteer EMT Akiva Skolnick , the terrorist wa killed by returning fire from the guard . A grenade and knife were found on his person . `` Two highly experienced security guard that were at the checkpoint at the city entrance neutralized the terrorist immediately , with bravery and a lot of resourcefulness and without fear . `` The shooter wa responsible for the killing of 18-year-old Military Police officer Noa Lazar on October 8 when he opened fire at a checkpoint near the Jerusalem neighborhood of Shuafat . A 30-year-old security guard remains in intensive care , sedated and on a ventilator . A third person , a soldier , wa also injured . & nbsp ;
title: border police kill palestinian who aimed dummy gun at them a he fled

Body Text: That old joke wa wrong . The book of Jewish sporting achievement is in fact quite thick . . . and fascinating . & ldquo ; In many way , the development of Jewish sport reflects the reality of Jewish life over the past 120 year , & rdquo ; say Osnat Zur , director of the Iris Smith World Jewish Sports Museum in Ramat Gan & rsquo ; s Kfar Hamaccabiah campus.The innovative 21st-century museum , inaugurated during the 22nd Maccabiah in 2022 , depicts an under-recounted aspect of the development of Jewish identity and Zionism . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The museum in essence tell not only the story of Jewish sport but of the Jews in general in the 20th century , & rdquo ; say Zur . & ldquo ; We embark on a journey through time , see how the nationalist movement arose around the world , how the first Maccabiah offered a vision , through the disaster of the Holocaust & ndash ; from which it took decade for Jewish sport to recover & ndash ; the Munich massacre , and on to October 7 . & rdquo ; A visit to the interactive display , suitable for child and adult alike , put Jewish sporting achievement in perspective . The 1,500 square-meter museum , designed by Israeli company Breeze Creative , present the history and heritage of Jewish sport through more than 1,000 rare item , video , and exhibit . & nbsp ; The museum & rsquo ; s timeline begin in 1890 with the establishment of the first Jewish sport club in Constantinople , Turkey , built around a fencing team . Then Max Nordau & rsquo ; s famous & ldquo ; muscular Jew & rdquo ; speech at the second Zionist Conference in Basel , Switzerland , in 1898 sparked the birth of dozen of Jewish sport club throughout Europe , and Jewish sport flourished in the early part of the 20th century . & nbsp ; In term of achievement , the best wa Hakoah Vienna , champion of the Austrian national soccer league in 1924-25 and runner-up in 1921-22 . The soccer club & rsquo ; s parent association wa the largest sporting organization in the world in it time , numbering more than 5,000 member and offering a wide variety of sporting activity . & nbsp ; Jewish sport & ndash ; notably fencing and boxing & ndash ; prospered in Europe until Nazism reared it evil head . The museum & rsquo ; s display chart the rise in antisemitism in Europe , with Jewish athlete and team gradually banned from competing . The chronological section devoted to 1933-39 is titled & ldquo ; From Champions to Victims . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Hitler viewed the 1936 Berlin Olympic Games a a propaganda tool & ndash ; and the world agreed to his term , a one of the video display explains ( in your chosen language ) . Signs at entrance to the Olympic stadium pronounced & ldquo ; No entry for dog and Jews . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Then-world champion swimmer Judith Deutch refused to represent Austria , made aliyah instead , and passed away in 2004 after a meaningful life in Israel . It should be noted , however , that other Jews competed in the Olympic Games , and were forced to salute Hitler . & nbsp ; Hakoah Vienna could not survive the Anschluss of March 11-13 , 1938 , when Nazi Germany annexed neighboring Austria , and the club disbanded in 1941 , only to reestablish itself after World War II on a modest scale.Meanwhile , a more Jewish immigrant poured into pre-state Israel , the local sporting union Maccabi , Hapoel , and Beitar burgeoned , each with it own political affiliation and patron . & nbsp ; The Maccabiah is really one man & rsquo ; s idea . Yosef Yekutieli & ndash ; who later went on to establish the Israel Football Association and Israel Olympic Committee & ndash ; had the then-maverick vision of holding a & ldquo ; Jewish Olympics & rdquo ; in 1932 , and advertised the event by riding his motorcycle throughout Europe . Some 470 competitor turned up for the inaugural Games in Tel Aviv that year . For the second Maccabiah in 1935 , some 1,200 athlete competed in a specially erected stadium and swimming pool . Then came the war.The third Maccabiah in 1952 wa a small , sad event that became known a the & ldquo ; revival Maccabiah & rdquo ; & ndash ; an axiom to be repeated in the 2025 event . Since then , the quadrennial Games have increasingly attracted Jewish ( and some non-Jewish ) athlete by the thousand , earning the moniker & ldquo ; the second-largest sporting event in the world & rdquo ; ( in term of number of athlete competing ) after the Olympics . The Maccabiah is an event with a meaning beyond sport . Among the dignitary attending the last opening ceremony wa US President Joe Biden.Documenting the pastThe need for a museum documenting the rise , fall , and rise again of Jewish sport ha become more evident a more Jewish athlete have made their mark on the world stage . & nbsp ; Admittedly , Jews may not have left their mark the way they have , say , on the Nobel Prize , but the list of Jewish sport legend & ndash ; from the 18th-century father of scientific boxing Daniel Mendoza , through baseball legend Sandy Koufax to multiple gold medalist swimmer Mark Spitz & ndash ; is richer than generally perceived . & ldquo ; There had been more talk about establishing the museum over the past decade , & rdquo ; say Zur . & ldquo ; Then came a generous donation from Iris Smith that allowed the project to go ahead . & rdquo ; Orit Engelberg-Baram wa chosen a content curator , a committee of leading sportspeople and sport historian assembled . . . then the pandemic broke out , and everything stopped . & ldquo ; Ultimately , this actually worked for our good , & rdquo ; say Zur . & ldquo ; Maccabi & rsquo ; s outside activity came to a halt , suddenly freeing up time and resource for this project in a new building under construction on the site of the old museum . & rdquo ; ( The site at Kfar Maccabiah wa previously home to a charming , if somewhat aging , corner called The Pierre Gildesgame Maccabi Sports Museum , established in 1982 , with an archive and exhibit concerning Judaism , Zionism , and Sports . ) & nbsp ; The museum employ English - , Spanish - , and Hebrew-speaking guide . Over 40,000 visitor have passed through so far , mainly Israeli school and pensioner group and Jewish group such a Taglit-Birthright and Masa , but also & ndash ; somewhat surprisingly & ndash ; many individual non-Jewish tourist . & ldquo ; They want to understand the essence of this country , and sport is part of that , & rdquo ; explains Zur , a former Young Maccabi emissary in the US who is now director of the Maccabiah 's Education Department & nbsp ; & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s not easy to be a Jewish sportsperson nowadays , & rdquo ; she note . & ldquo ; Jewish athlete worldwide are increasingly afraid to identify with Israel . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Even more so their non-Jewish colleague , at a time when being pro-Palestinian is considered cool . & nbsp ; Within day of October 7 , the Maccabi World Union launched it Sportspeakup project , recruiting over 150 leading athlete from around the world & ndash ; including 15 non-Jewish former NBA basketball player & ndash ; who recorded social medium message calling for the release of Israeli hostage . & nbsp ; But it wasn & rsquo ; t easy . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Even though it & rsquo ; s a humanitarian issue not a political one , many of the sportspeople we approached said they were scared to participate . They didn & rsquo ; t want to deal with antisemitic cry from supporter at their game , & rdquo ; explains Zur . & nbsp ; Victory of sport over evilAs Israeli society slowly recovers from the trauma , the museum & rsquo ; s first planned temporary exhibition in July will concentrate on October 7 and sport . & ldquo ; Many sportspeople died that day , & rdquo ; Zur sigh . & ldquo ; There were some heart-wrenching story , a mixed reaction from the sport world to the event , and more antisemitism in sport . & rdquo ; The exhibition will recount the story of Israeli sport through the mirror of October 7 , focusing on the sporting victory in this most difficult year in the country & rsquo ; s history . Visitors will pas through three track that combine the sound of war and the roar of victory , between the battlefield and the sport field.The first track describes the reality for Israel & rsquo ; s sporting representative since October 7 , the humiliation and ostracism they face alongside the support and encouragement , and their victory on the sport field . Central to this part of the exhibition will be the historic gold medal of Israeli gymnast Artyom Dolgopiat , won at the World Championships on October 7 at 14:00 Israel time . The second track will memorialize the athlete murdered or wounded on October 7 and the ensuing war , while the third track will tell the story of the missing fan who will never wear their team color again . & nbsp ; The three track will converge to celebrate the victory of sport over evil & ndash ; the Olympic Games in Paris in July 2024 is due to include the largest Israeli delegation ever , and the 2025 Maccabiah look like it will be the biggest in history . This exhibition will convey two main message . To world Jewry : & ldquo ; You are not alone . & rdquo ; And to the world sporting community , & ldquo ; More Than Ever , & rdquo ; with record number of participant at the next Olympic Games and Maccabiah . ■ Staying on the mapFor decade , participation on the world stage wa every Israeli athlete & rsquo ; s dream . Nobody talked about winning & ndash ; until Maccabi Tel Aviv & rsquo ; s groundbreaking first basketball European Champions Cup in 1977 . That game is best remembered for captain Tal Brody & rsquo ; s prophetic after-game exclamation : & ldquo ; We & rsquo ; re on the map and we & rsquo ; re staying on the map & ndash ; not only in sport , but in everything ! & rdquo ; a sound bite that ha become a part of Israeli culture . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Israeli sport in general is continuing to improve , even through this tough period , & rdquo ; say Brody , now a sprightly 80 . & ldquo ; In the past few month , we & rsquo ; ve seen international achievement in judo , gymnastics , swimming , wind surfing , taekwondo , and even kick boxing . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; It & rsquo ; s time to stand up and be counted , even in sport that don & rsquo ; t make the big headline , explains Brody , who made aliyah from Trenton , New Jersey , in 1966 , forfeiting a budding NBA career.Still far from being a sporting powerhouse , Israel is beginning to make it mark on the world stage . Brody put this down to a cultural shift . & ldquo ; There & rsquo ; s far more physical activity here than in the past . The authority understand far better the importance of sporting facility , and now our city have bicycle lane , and the park are full of jogger . & ldquo ; Israelis are waking up in a sad mood nowadays . Many have lost loved one or have soldier on the front line . With all the sorrow , a the day go on sport give them spirit and pride . Our athlete have to go out to the world where people don & rsquo ; t understand the situation , where they hear false narrative and there & rsquo ; s an antisemitic atmosphere . But the people of Israel believe in the country , and our sportsman also feel this . Even a the war rage , our athlete are taking top place in competition in place like Qatar and Tashkent , proudly competing with the Star of David on their uniform . & rdquo ; & nbsp ;
title: sporting jew : the rise , fall , and rise of the ' muscular jew '

Body Text: The European Union condemned Sunday the Israeli announcement that an additional 800 hectare ( 1,977 acre ) of land in the Jordan Valley would be classified a Israeli state land . `` The European Union firmly condemns the announcement by Israeli Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich that over 800 hectare of land in the occupied Palestinian territory have been declared a & lsquo ; state land . & rsquo ; & nbsp ; This is the largest confiscation since the Oslo Accords , `` read the condemnation.The EU refuse to recognize change to borderThe EU reaffirmed that , in line with it longstanding position , it will not recognize change to the 1967 border that are not agreed upon by the party involved . `` Settlements are a grave breach of international humanitarian law , `` the statement went on , adding that EU leader condemned the decision to `` further expand illegal settlement across the occupied West Bank `` and urged Israel to reverse the decision.The EU went on to condemn Hamas and reaffirm it commitment to Israel 's security , saying that it position against Israeli expansion `` go hand in hand `` with this commitment and with `` ensuring that the horrific attack against Israeli civilian on 7 October will never be repeated . `` `` Settlement expansion run counter to this objective . It fuel tension and undermines prospect for a two-state solution , which remains the only sustainable guarantee for the long-term security of both Israelis and Palestinians , `` concluded the statement.Smotrich announced the expansion Friday , calling it `` another dramatic and important step for the settlement of the Jordan Valley and Judea and Samaria . `` The classification of the additional state land wa authorized by Smotrich , through his role in the Defense Ministry , and with the oversight of the Civil Administration.He noted that the declaration follows one made earlier this month that classified a state land 300 hectare in the area of Ma & rsquo ; aleh Adumin.The declaration of territory in Area C of the West Bank a state land is a bureaucratic step that open the door for the development of that land . & nbsp ;
title: eu condemns expansion of ' illegal settlement across the occupied west bank '

Body Text: On Monday , May 13 , siren will sound again in observance of Yom Hazikaron , Israel & rsquo ; s Remembrance Day for the fallen soldier and victim of terror , reopening the wound of the thousand who are reeling in the aftermath of the horrific October 7 massacre and ongoing war with Hamas . s terror victim & gt ; & gt ; & ldquo ; Maybe it is because I have spent so many year in mourning , but I could recognize myself within all this , & rdquo ; Shira say . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Last week , I cried for day , but I know that it is OK too , & rdquo ; Body Text: Recently , there ha been a flood of request for monetary help on serious health issue ; widowed mother of large family left destitute ; a haredi man who naively agreed to put an extra parcel in his luggage , not knowing that it contained cocaine , is languishing in prison , with his wife claiming that he is dying there ; and a whole bunch of other request for aid.Most are truly heartbreaking , but they raise certain doubt . Yehoshua , which cover the different stage in the life of the man considered to be the backbone of contemporary Hebrew literature.Among other participant will be actress Michal Bat-Adam , who directed and starred in the film The Lover ; Yair Kedar , who directed the film The Last Chapter of A.B . Yehoshua , part of which will be screened during the evening ; book reviewer Dan Meron , who wa also a close friend of Yehoshua ; and Prof . Eilat Shamir , who wa a student and friend of the author & rsquo ; s son Gidi Yehoshua.WITH REGARD to film , Roni Mahadav-Levin , the CEO of the Jerusalem Cinematheque , is giving film buff ample notice to save the date for the 41st annual Jerusalem Film Festival , which traditionally take place in the summer , while the annual Jewish film festival take place in the winter.The Jerusalem Film Festival will be held July 18-27 , 2024 , in an effort to restore what used to be perceived a normal life.The festival is being held with the support of the Culture Ministry , the Van Leer Foundation , and the Jerusalem Foundation . & ldquo ; Sadly , this is not the first time that the festival is being held in the shadow of war , & rdquo ; said Mahadav-Levin . & ldquo ; But both in good time and difficult time , we believe in the need to create and screen good film , in the belief in the power of the art of film in strengthening , healing , and giving hope that a different reality is possible . & ldquo ; This can be seen through the myriad of film that will be shown during the festival . & rdquo ; VP Harris view Oct . 7 documentary & nbsp ; FOLLOWING SCREENINGS in Israel of Screams Before Silence , the moving documentary in which philanthropist and former Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg meet Supernova music festival survivor and returned hostage , the film wa shown in part at the White House this week , where it wa viewed by Vice President Kamila Harris , who wa joined by Sandberg and returned hostage Amit Soussana.Soussana said that , while in captivity , she had no control over her mind , body , or soul . Yossi wa subsequently murdered . Eli & rsquo ; s fate is unknown . Bareket wa on hand with Hapoalim CEO Dov Kotler and Yoman Masa owner Itamar Peleg.AS ONE of his final ceremonial deed in office , Australian Governor-General David Hurley , a the representative in Australia of King Charles , conferred King Charles Birthday honor on more than 700 people , among them South African-born Prof . Vernon Van Heerden , director of the department of general intensive care at Hadassah Medical Center , in Jerusalem & rsquo ; s Ein Kerem.Van Heerden wa awarded the Order of Australia for & ldquo ; significant service to intensive care medicine , to professional association , and to tertiary education . & rdquo ; Hurley will be succeeded on July 1 by Samantha Mostyn , who will become Australia & rsquo ; s 28th governor-general.A truly remarkable woman , Mostyn & rsquo ; s CV is absolutely mind-boggling.Known for her exceptional service to the Australian community , Mostyn is a businesswoman and community leader with a long history in executive and governance role across diverse sectors.In 2021 , she wa appointed an officer of the Order of Australia for distinguished service to business , the community , and woman . She ha been a member of the Australian Faculty of The Prince of Wales & rsquo ; s Business & amp ; Sustainability Program for 12 year , and a senior associate in the international program.The daughter of an army officer , Mostyn is a lawyer by training , who launched her career a an associate in the Court of Appeal of the New South Wales Supreme Court , and ha worked at law firm Freehills and Gilbert and Tobin . She ha more recently been awarded an honorary doctorate of law from the Australian National University.Mostyn ha also had an extensive career in the Australian business community , including working at senior level in telecommunication and insurance company in Australia and globally . She ha also held senior nonexecutive role on board , including Transurban and Virgin Australia , and ha been chairwoman of Citibank Australia . She ha been president of the Australian Council for International Development and president of Chief Executive Women , a well a a National Mental Health Commission commissioner.The governor-general hold office at the pleasure of the king . However , the term is usually understood to be five year . It will be interesting to see what Mostyn will accomplish during that period.IT & rsquo ; S DIFFICULT to measure patriotism or even to define it . In Israel , the latter connotation usually go hand in hand with being called a leftist , whereas , when the boot is on the other foot , one of the unsavory epithet is & ldquo ; fascist . & rdquo ; A battle over patriotism is brewing between two social medium combatant , Yair Netanyahu , the elder son of the prime minister , and Ran Rahav , one of Israel & rsquo ; s leading public relation executives.In recent day , Yair Netanyahu released a video in which he denigrates IDF Chief of Staff Lt . - Gen . Herzi Halevi , Israel Security Agency head Ronen Bar , and former head of Military Intelligence Maj . - Gen . Aharon Haliva , who resigned after acknowledging the intelligence failure that led to the October 7 massacre.Accompanying a montage of the trio is a caption : & ldquo ; Who appointed you ? & rdquo ; Further along is an attack on Benny Gantz , who ha previously been targeted by Netanyahu Jr.Did his father not tell him that thing like that are not done in a time of war ? But until then , someone protected by his state can not open his mouth in a time of war . & rdquo ; A THREE-DAY day festival of tour and literary activity for the junior generation will be held at the National Library of Israel in celebration of Hebrew Book Week.Events will be held Monday through Wednesday , June 24-26 , 4 p.m . - 11 p.m . , and will include musical performance , meeting , tour , and various activity for child & ndash ; all dedicated to Hebrew literature and creativity.Among the event will be a musical performance on Monday , hosted by Lior Ashkenazi , to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of Israel & rsquo ; s poet laureate Yehuda Amichai . For more detail and to purchase ticket , visit the National Library of Israel website ( in Hebrew ) : http : / / book-week.nli.org.ilDALIAT AL-Carmel Mayor Rafik Halabi , who in another lifetime wa a prizewinning radio and television journalist , added his voice to those of Sheikh Muafak Tarif , the head of the Druze community , and Nazih Dabbour , the head of the Beit Jann local authority , in response to the death of fallen soldier Capt . Wassem Mahmoud , who wa due to be released from the Army on April 1 , but insisted on going back into Gaza to fight with his comrades.It is part of the Druze tradition to be absolutely loyal to the host country of which they are citizen , but the Israel government doe not respect this , and in the opinion of member of the Druze community , they are treated a second-class citizens.Halabi said that head of Druze local council had met with Netanyahu last week to express their concern about receiving inadequate budget from the state , and to continue their protest against the Nation-State Law.Halabi and Dabbour also made the point that on a percentage basis , Beit Jann ha the highest army casualty rate in the country.They could not understand why a community that ha given so much receives so little in return . Dabbour also noted that soldier who fall behind in paying their mortgage , or who have built home without the proper legal permission , go to fight in Gaza , and return to find their home destroyed on order by the Israeli authorities.Bedouin tracker , who are among the best in the country and are also serving in the IDF , if they live in illegal village may not find their home when they return from the army . Their home may have been bulldozed.How doe Israel expect to maintain the loyalty of it minority community , if it treat them in such an insensitive and disrespectful manner ? THE BIG question on the mind of many Israelis is will Israel recover fully from October 7 ? To anyone who experienced the Yom Kippur War , the answer is yes . The misery and uncertainty that now encompass the country were in a sense even more horrific then than now , because there were no mobile phone , no fax , and not every home possessed a ground line telephone . The IDF death toll wa 2,691 during a war that lasted for less than a month . As painful a the current IDF casualty rate is , there are far fewer fallen soldier over a much longer period , though there have been a larger number of civilian casualty , particularly on October 7 itself.In the early day after the Hamas massacre , Shani Louk , a pretty 22-year-old dual national who carried German a well a Israeli citizenship , became the global symbol of Hamas tyranny and inhumanity.Kidnapped at the Supernova music festival by Hamas terrorist wearing body cam , a video of her unconscious body on the back of a truck wa circulated around the globe.Her family clung to the hope that she wa still alive , especially after information filtered through that she wa being treated in a Gaza hospital.German Ambassador to Israel Steffen Seibert maintained close contact with the Louk family and helped to publicize it ordeal and Germany & rsquo ; s concern.On October 30 , Shani Louk & rsquo ; s death wa confirmed.On Wednesday , June 19 , at 7 p.m . , her parent , Ricarda and Nissim Louk , will talk about the beloved , happy-go-lucky , music-loving daughter they remember at a special evening honoring Shani & rsquo ; s memory . Sharing in that conversation , organized by Tribe Israel , will be Rabbi Shmuley Boteach.The venue is Capella , Hagag Tower , 28 Ha & rsquo ; arba Street , Tel Aviv . Admission is free of charge . The event is reserved for people in Shani Louk & rsquo ; s age-group.WITH THE ongoing transformation of the State of Israel that inter alia includes change in the law , politics , the skyline , and the value we once held dear , the question arises a to whether future change will include the establishment of a casino.The late casino mogul Sheldon Adelson wanted to establish a casino in Eilat so that the southern resort city would truly become the Las Vegas of the Middle East . But he wa strongly opposed by a cabinet minister , the late Yosef Burg , who wa afraid that a casino would become a den of vice , peddling drug and promoting prostitution . Adelson & rsquo ; s vision on that score wa never realized.In an interview with the writer of this column , during the period in which he wa still trying to convince the Israeli authority , Adelson said that he had never seen anyone have sex on a gambling table.Since then , he married an Israeli and built casino empire in Singapore and Macao.Israelis like to gamble , and when the Hilton Taba casino opened in 1994 , only 200 meter from the Israeli border , gambler crossed nightly from Eilat to Taba to place their bet . A lot of money that could have stayed in Israel ended up in Egypt.But before then and even afterward , several illegal and well-patronized casino opened across Israel , but were short-lived due to police raids.The only legalized gambling in Israel is the Mifal Hapayis national lottery , which ha increased the variety of game and prize available to the public , and Toto sport gambling.Sheldon Adelson , who died three-and-a-half year ago , wa a keen supporter of the Republican Party and one of it most generous bankrollers . Following his death , his wife Dr . Miriam Adelson wa a little more reserved in her donation to the party but , according to medium report , is now throwing her financial weight behind Donald Trump , who during his presidency honored her with the Presidential Medal of Freedom.Recently , Miriam Adelson and her son-in-law Patrick Dumont acquired the majority share in the Dallas Mavericks in order to give the Las Vegas Sands Corporation a foothold in the Lone Star State , where they hope to introduce casino . Texas is very conservative about casino gambling , so Adelson and Dumont will have a hard row to hoe.She also poured a lot of money into the election campaign of Dade Phelan , which helped him to be reelected a speaker of the Texas House of Representatives.If she succeeds in opening a casino in Texas , Adelson may turn her attention to Israel , where she is the publisher of the free , informative tabloid Israel Hayom.She is also a generous benefactor to various Israeli cause . She and her husband gave Yad Vashem it largest-ever donation , and they did not skimp on other cause they supported.At a time when Israel is experiencing an economic disaster , Adelson & rsquo ; s fiscal assistance to the nation may help to swing legislation in favor of casinos.greerfc @ gmail.com

Body Text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu wa coy about & nbsp ; medium report of a secret deal in which Israel agreed to purchase Russian Sputnik COVID-19 vaccine on behalf of Syria a part of last week & rsquo ; s prisoner exchange with Syria . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Not a single Israeli COVID-19 vaccine went for that matter , & rdquo ; Netanyahu said at a public appearance on Saturday , during which he wa quizzed on the issue by a KAN reporter . & nbsp ; Netanyahu referred to the deal brokered by Russian President Vladimir Putin in which a young Israeli woman who had wandered into Syria wa returned in exchange for the release of two Syrian shepherd . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; We brought back the young woman and I have thanked President Putin for this , but I respect Russia & rsquo ; s request not to say anything more , & rdquo ; Netanyahu said . & nbsp ; Speculation with regard to a secret component to the deal ha been fueled by an unusual secret government meeting held Wednesday night in advance of an otherwise seemingly simple exchange . & nbsp ; Labor Party head MK Merav Michaeli appealed to Knesset Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee chairman Zvi Hauser to hold a debate on the decision to censor information about the deal . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; There is a real concern , sir , that Prime Minister Netanyahu and [ Alternate Prime Minister and ] Defense Minister [ Benny ] Gantz have abused their authority and censored the full detail of the agreement to prevent a public debate & rdquo ; on the price of the deal , Michaeli said . & nbsp ; Among those who reported on the matter wa Richard Silverstein in his Tikun Olam blog . & ldquo ; Today , a well-informed Israeli source ha revealed the full extent of the negotiation . Israel agreed ( hence the cabinet signoff ) , & rdquo ; Silverstein wrote . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; But both Bibi Netanyahu and Benny Gantz do not want Israelis to know that they are offering such resource to Syria , especially because they are in the midst of the election campaign , & rdquo ; he added . & nbsp ; Syria & rsquo ; s state news agency SANA rejected the report . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Circulating such fabricated information about a secret term in the exchange process , related to getting coronavirus vaccine from the Israeli authority , aim to defame Syria and distort the patriotic and humanitarian side of the process , & rdquo ; it stated . & nbsp ; According to KAN News , Israel requested permission from Russia to disclose what wa promised to Syria under the prisoner swap deal , but the Kremlin reportedly ha not & ldquo ; changed it position on the issue . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The issue wa noted by Joint List faction chairman Ahmad Tibi in a Friday tweet . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Do we have to wait for a Jew to cross the border into Gaza in order for [ Palestinians ] to receive vaccine ? & rdquo ; Tibi wrote , following a comment on how he had raised a demand in the Knesset for vaccine to be transferred to Gaza . The young woman who crossed into Syria returned to Israel in the early hour of Friday , after government hostage negotiator Yaron Bloom headed to Moscow on Thursday night to bring her back . & nbsp ; On Thursday , the IDF handed over two shepherd to Red Cross representative through the Quentin Crossing in Syria , after they had been apprehended by IDF troop east of the security fence in the Golan Heights area in Israeli territory . & nbsp ; Following her return , Netanyahu spoke with the young woman & rsquo ; s mother who thanked him for his effort , according to a PMO statement . & ldquo ; Israel will always do everything in it power in order to help it citizen , & rdquo ; Netanyahu said . & nbsp ; The prime minister also issued a statement thanking Putin for his effort , noting he had spoken with him twice . & nbsp ; Gantz also released a statement explaining that he had spoken with his Russian counterpart on the matter and publicly thanked him . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Two week ago , we received an alert that an Israeli citizen had been taken into the custody of Syrian security force . Body Text: When Israel needed water in the desert , we created pioneering irrigation technology . When faced with non-conventional threat , we became a cyber empire . In the wake of the October 7 tragedy , Israel is still facing a whole new host of problem . These challenge , though new to Israelis , are too familiar to many country that experience natural and man-made disaster . Sadly , these disaster are growing in frequency and severity.The awful experience that October 7 forced upon u can break u or lead to the development of the most powerful impact-tech ecosystem the world ha ever seen , changing the trajectory of this space forever . This will not be an easy opportunity to seize , but we believe that we must go all in & ndash ; it will serve our recovery process , it & rsquo ; s an opportunity to play a role in addressing global challenge , and it offer an incredible economic engine if we do it right . Disasters are not going away , but our innovative response can turn adversity into opportunity.Much ha been written about Israel a the Start-up Nation , the blossoming , Middle Eastern tech miracle where there are more start-ups per caput than anywhere else on the planet.Israel & rsquo ; s tech ecosystem unsurprisingly focus on sector such a cyber , fintech , and enterprise solution ; and with good reason . The ecosystem grew under the influence of foreign tech leader and venture capitalist with background in corporates , the military , and finance , and wa fueled by innovation from the IDF . This influence ha paved the way for Israeli founder to focus on problem affecting company and institution in the US and Western society & ndash ; a sensible approach given the financial opportunity in these area and the first-hand experience of the ecosystem veteran who were able to mentor , fund , and support entrepreneur working on problem they knew.OCTOBER 7 and subsequent event have thrust all Israelis into uncharted territory . Despite struggling with disbelief and contending with a government that is untrusted and not functioning ideally , Israelis and their ally around the world have responded with what we believe will be remembered in history a one of the best community response to a disaster . CEOs became philanthropist , conference space became donation center , volunteer were organized to replace worker drafted into reserve service , and a jaw-dropping amount of donation wa collected.Unsurprisingly & ndash ; we also witnessed an extraordinary surge in ad hoc & lsquo ; emergency & rsquo ; hack . New tech solution were developed to identify and track people in distress , provide rapid response documentation solution in field condition , leverage CRMs for data management of displaced individual , utilize AI to identify missing and kidnapped people , and more.As Israel transition from emergency response to recovery , we are starting to see a similar innovative spirit in addressing long-term recovery issues.Innovating recoveryOne example is Citizen AI & ndash ; a fintech start-up that leverage it financial education platform to help individual and organization understand their right and navigate the complex benefit system . Utilization of right and financial health is not a new problem in Israel ( nor around the world ) , but now , the flood of people in need and the new program are driving focus and clarity to what is required.In the agriculture sector , program such a ReGrow Israel are not only focused on building what wa destroyed , but are also seizing the opportunity to build a more advanced , tech-enabled , and resilient agricultural ecosystem . These program have the potential to not only strengthen the food system that sustains the country and support the livelihood of family of farmer and other business on the value chain & ndash ; but also to provide critical insight and learning to fuel AgTech companies.We are seeing a surge in innovation in the physical and mental health space . With so many individual working to recover and integrate back into society and the dozen of people surrounding them , in a place like Israel , this can only mean one thing : more ground-breaking idea and solutions.One example is the Lev Hasharon Mental Health Center where cutting-edge technology such a VR are integrated into the care plan of mental health patient , in department such a hospitalization , daycare , and specialized clinic for sexual trauma and child-and-youth mental support . Patient feedback ha been exceptionally positive , with about 70 % reporting significant reduction in anxiety and stress levels.All these program and idea were not born in a vacuum . They were bred and incubated through an incredible impact-tech ecosystem that already exists in Israel . However , they are the minority , underfunded , and under-supported , and this must change . As these sector are growing globally and creating more demand & ndash ; now is the time to double down on these opportunities.This can be a defining moment or a grossly missed opportunity for Israel & rsquo ; s Tech Ecosystem and it national economy . We must take this terrible disaster and the challenge it forced u to experience & ndash ; and do what we do best . Solve . Innovate . Build . And scale for the greater good and the benefit of all.For this to happen , everyone need to play a role ; there is a lot of work to do . We need to close knowledge gap about new market , fund experimentation , and bring together people who are not used to collaborating with each other , such a social worker , engineer , NGO leader , investor , nurse , and salesperson & ndash ; we need them all to bring multidisciplinary knowledge and experience to the table.We built PollyLabs to bridge the tech gap and exponentially accelerate solution to the world & rsquo ; s most pressing need . Like everyone , October 7 threw u all into a stark place , both personally and professionally . It also brought into sharp focus the tremendous opportunity for Israel to build and heal itself and others like never before . & nbsp ; Let & rsquo ; s take on this role ; we were made for this.Bar Pereg is the CEO of PollyLabs . Alina Shkolnikov is the chief partnership officer at PollyLabs and a board member of the Devorah Forum .

Body Text: US State Department Spokesperson Ned Price said Wednesday that the US `` is extremely concerned by the level of violence in Israel and the West Bank , `` following the deadly IDF raid in Nablus on Wednesday . `` Today in Nablus , at least 10 Palestinians , including both militant and civilian bystander , were killed , and over 100 injured during an Israel Defense Forces counter-terrorism operation , `` he said in his daily press briefing . `` We wish a speedy recovery to those injured and our heart go out to the family of the innocent bystander who were killed today , `` Price added.He went on to say that the US `` recognizes the very real security concern facing Israel . `` US ' deeply concerned ' over loss of civilian life '' At the same time , we are deeply concerned by a large number of injury and the loss of civilian life , `` he continued . `` We had productive conversation in recent day with the party and US regional partner in support of effort to prevent further violence . `` `` We are deeply concerned that the impact of today 's raid could set back effort aimed at restoring calm for both Israelis and Palestinians , `` he added . `` Today 's event further underscore the urgent need for both side to work together to improve the security situation in the West Bank . `` `` We also call on all party to desist from action that inflame tension such a incitement of violence , eviction of family from their home , demolition , settlement advancement , and the legalization of outpost , `` Price continued . `` Israelis and Palestinians a we have consistently said , equally deserve to live in safety and security . `` & nbsp ;
title: u ' extremely concerned ' after israeli raid of nablus

Body Text: In February 2005 , during the government of then-prime minister Ariel Sharon , then-defense minister Shaul Mofaz and IDF chief Moshe Ya & rsquo ; alon ordered a moratorium of punitive house demolition against the family of Palestinian terrorists.A commission of top defense expert led by Maj . - Gen . ( re . ) Udi Shani had empirically studied whether house demolition over the last few year of the Second Intifada had increased deterrence against terrorist , concluding that the opposite wa true.Yet in 2023 , it seems that nearly the entire defense establishment is convinced that house demolition do deter future potential terror attacks.They are so sure that they even want to seal off the house of the family of the 13-year-old Palestinian who shot but did not kill , two Israeli victim & ndash ; which would be the first time that such a measure would be taken against an attempted murderer versus an actual murderer.What , if anything , changed between 2005 and 2023 about Israel , the Palestinians , house demolition and deterrence ? The 2005 committee found that house demolition , rather than deterring future terrorism , generally inflamed hatred and increased motivation for future attack by Palestinians against Israel.According to the defense commission , there had only been 20 case in which the threat of demolition deterred potential attacker or pushed their family to turn them in & ndash ; out of hundred of demolition since 2001.Fundamentally , the commission report simply pointed out that after hundred of demolition , the Second Intifada had not been put down.Furthermore , the report said that in many case house demolition hit family which , other than the one terrorist attacker , were not part of a greater terror group and were viewed by the greater Palestinian public a illegitimate collective punishment.This meant that sometimes new terrorist were even being created from family or neighbor of these family who might not have become a problem.Another part of the problem , the committee said , wa that different Palestinian group , whether the Palestinian Authority , Hamas or otherwise , frequently compensated family of terrorist and helped them rebuild new home , weakening possible deterrence.In addition , if there had been some short period earlier in the Second Intifada when a small number of demolition might have had a deterrent effect , a the policy went on longer , the deterrent effect wa lost.With some very limited exception , Israel stopped demolishing Palestinian house for punitive deterrent purpose from 2005-2014 & ndash ; almost a decade.It wa after Palestinian terrorist murdered three Jewish teenager that the then-government of Benjamin Netanyahu ( who went almost five year without demolition ) reinstated the demolition policy.The issue wa probed again by the Shin Bet ( Israel Security Agency ) during the 2015-2016 Knife Intifada , but this time the overwhelming majority of official found that the demolition were having a deterrent effect.Significant number of Palestinians who started toward an attack , but relented , or parent who turned in their kid before they could commit an attack in process , said that saving the family house had impacted them greatly.Some official did a victory lap on the issue in 2016 a one of the reason & ndash ; along with new technology and analysis of social medium & ndash ; that the Knife Intifada wa put down before it blew up into a & ldquo ; full Intifada . & rdquo ; The Jerusalem Post recently received additional confirmation from defense official dealing with some of the greatest Palestinian violence in the northern West Bank which concluded that demolition are still providing deterrence.They repeated the same updated 2022 testimony of Palestinians ( not just relying on the 2015-2016 data ) who pulled back from terror at the last minute or turned in their kid to stop them from terror.One fascinating point wa that some of these official did not even know that Israel & rsquo ; s moratorium on house demolition had gone on for so long , nearly a decade . In fact , they were quite shocked by the notion.Part of what is interesting about that is that the year 2005-2014 & ndash ; without house demolition & ndash ; were a much less violent time period than 2015-2023 ha been with house demolitions.Of course , one counterresponse to this argument is that this wa because the IDF hit Palestinian terror much harder and deeper during the Second Intifada , and it wa this that provided quiet.Some also say that if the IDF did house demolition faster , not with week or month of delay , then there would be greater deterrence . Maybe , but there is no guarantee there either , and there have been case where a terrorist & rsquo ; s family had nothing to do with their activity and rushing forward without figuring that out would have broken even Israeli law a it currently exists ( keeping in mind that though international law ha a place for house demolition , Israel is an outlier among democracy in actually performing them ) . Some other question worth askingBut it is worth asking ; when Israeli defense official in 2023 say they are sure that demolition provide deterrence , are they fully and seriously considering the opposing view ? If some of them do not even recall a world without house demolition , can they be said to fully consider that view ? And if Israel ha been doing them more aggressively than ever since March 2022 without ending the current wave of violence , what doe that say ? There are no easy answer to these question . But they are question that could be crucial to ask by security professional who seriously consider both side and who ignore partisan noise for and against the demolition on either political side of the spectrum .
title: demolishing house did n't stop terror in 2005 , why doe it work in 2023 ? - analysis

Body Text: A new opinion poll , carried out by the Arab Center for Research and Policy Studies , wa published on January 10 . The poll , which collected data from 8,000 Arab respondent from 16 country , aimed to determine how Arab population perceived the Israel-Hamas war.Amongst one of the many finding of the survey , it wa noted that 67 % of respondent perceived Hamas & rsquo ; s October 7 attack , categorized by the survey a & ldquo ; the military operation carried out by Hamas , & rdquo ; a & ldquo ; a legitimate resistance operation . & rdquo ; The survey result clarified that 19 % answered that the attack wa legitimate but & ldquo ; flawed , & rdquo ; 3 % said it wa legitimate but & ldquo ; involved heinous or criminal act & rdquo ; and only 5 % called the attack & ldquo ; illegitimate . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Why did Hamas attack , according to respondent ? While many have seen Hamas & rsquo ; s attack on Israel a a proxy war for Iran , only 2 % of respondent agreed , while 35 % of Arab respondent stated their belief that the number one reason behind the attack wa & ldquo ; The ongoing Israeli occupation of Palestinian land . & rdquo ; The second most given reason wa & ldquo ; Defending al-Aqsa Mosque against attack , & rdquo ; which 24 % of respondent affirmed a their believed reason . & nbsp ; The al-Aqsa Mosque ha been a source of tension a it is located above the Temple Mount , a holy site for both Jews and Christians . While non-Muslims now have permission to attend their holy site via the Moors Gate , they are forbidden from praying there which ha created increased tension . Jewish activist have repeatedly tried to pray at the site , which ha been met with escalating conflict . & nbsp ; While 24 % argued that defending the mosque wa the most important reason behind the attack , a Hamas rocket would have landed on the holy site in December , if Israel & rsquo ; s Iron Dome system hadn & rsquo ; t prevented the attack . & nbsp ; Only 8 % of the respondent felt the & ldquo ; [ t ] he ongoing blockade of Gaza & rdquo ; wa the main reason for the attack , with a further 12 % claiming it to be the second most important reason . & nbsp ; Israel withdrew citizen from Gaza in 2005 , creating a separate territory that wa taken over by Hamas in 2006 . Gaza border both Israel and Egypt , with crossing policed heavily by both country . Palestinians , before October 7 , had been permitted to enter Israel with proper documentation for work , medical treatment or for other reason . & nbsp ; Arab solidarity with Palestinians and HamasIn mass agreement , 92 % of respondent expressed they had a feeling of solidarity with Gaza & rsquo ; s Palestinian population . In addition , 69 % said they supported both the Palestinians and Hamas . Only 1 % said they had no feeling of solidarity with the Palestinians and 23 % said they had feeling of solidarity for Palestinians but opposed Hamas.Opinions on international partiesWhen asked about the response of regional and international power to the war , 94 % said they considered the United States position negatively , with 82 % clarifying they thought it wa bad . The same trend continued for other Western country with 79 % , 78 % , and 75 % of respondent viewed the position of France , the UK , and Germany negatively.In a different survey response , 81 % said that they did not believe the US wa serious about establishing a Palestinian state and 77 % of respondent named the US and Israel a the biggest threat to the security and stability of the region.US Secretary of State Andrew Blinken continued to advocate for a Palestinian state only yesterday , claiming that it wa the best way to marginalize Iran . & nbsp ; Additionally , while one May survey found that over half of Palestinians wanted a two-state solution , a November survey by the Arab World for Research and Development found that over 70 % of Palestinians support only a singular Palestinian state without a Jewish one.Arab opinion on Iran , Turkey , Russia , and China wa more split , with 48 % , 47 % , 41 % , and 40 % perceiving the country positively.Normalizing tie with IsraelWhen asked what step Arab government should take in response to the war , 36 % of respondent stated that Arab government should suspend all relation or normalization process with Israel , and a further 14 % said aid should be sent to Gaza without Israeli approval.A further 29 % of respondent suggested that Arab country should either & ldquo ; provide military aid to Gaza & rdquo ; or & ldquo ; announce military mobilization & rdquo ; against Israel .
title: 67 % of arab world : october 7 wa ' legitimate resistance ' against israel

Body Text: Following the War Cabinet 's decision to approve an increased fuel allowance for the Gaza Strip , both Former Prime Minister Naftali Bennett and National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir have publically criticized the decision , according to Israeli media.The Prime Minister 's Office announced on Wednesday night that it would be increasing the fuel allowed into Gaza in order to ward off an imminent humanitarian collapse a well a prevent disease outbreaks.The amount permitted to enter would be decided on a situational basis according to `` the morbidity situation and humanitarian situation . `` The Security Cabinet , this evening , approved the recommendation of the War Cabinet to allow a minimal supplement of fuel & ndash ; necessary to prevent a humanitarian collapse and the outbreak of epidemic & ndash ; into the southern Gaza Strip . & mdash ; Prime Minister of Israel ( @ IsraeliPM ) December 6 , 2023Dissatisfaction with the War CabinetBen-Gvir wa one of the dissenting vote in the War Cabinet , another wa Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich.During the meeting , Ben-Gvir said `` This fuel is used by Hamas . We said a few week ago that not a drop would enter and suddenly we changed the red line ? In order to defeat Hamas and terrorism , we must stop with the concept . `` While Bennett said `` Bringing fuel into Gaza during a war constitutes an injection of energy to Hamas . This is a grave error , certainly when it happens while our abductees are being held in inhumane condition and against international law , and are not even visited by the Red Cross . `` `` The fuel is the oxygen - in the literal sense - of Hamas . Without it , Hamas will collapse . Hamas us fuel for the ventilation and lighting system in the terrorist tunnel , for the movement of armed men , and for terrorist activity against u . Those who send our soldier to fight against a cynical enemy must know how to withstand pressure , also of friend , at such a crucial point in the war . `` Strategic Affairs Minister Ron Dermer defended the decision a `` critical `` citing the need for continued American support . This come a US official begin putting pressure on Israel to put more effort into protecting civilian in the Gaza Strip .
title: bennett , ben-gvir slam israel 's war cabinet for moving more fuel into gaza

Body Text: & ldquo ; Major pressure & rdquo ; is being applied on outgoing Efrat Mayor Oded Revivi to join national politics , he said in an interview with The Jerusalem Post last week.The pressure is not new and ha accompanied Revivi during the past five round of election since 2019 , he said.But now that Revivi is on his way out of office , the door is open to upgrade to the national level , he said , adding that while there are & ldquo ; major vector & rdquo ; pushing him in that direction , it is still too early to tell . & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s not attractive to go into national politics , & rdquo ; Revivi said . & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s way more frustrating . Body Text: Lihi Lapid , whose latest novel , On Her Own , wa just published in the US by HarperVia , ha a very unusual biography for a writer . & nbsp ; While she is the author of a previous novel , Woman of Valor , which wa also published in English to positive review , and several other book that came out in Israel , she is known around the world a the wife of Israel & rsquo ; s previous prime minister , Yair Lapid , now head of the opposition . & nbsp ; As we meet in the caf & eacute ; at the Israel Museum , a convenient location for the Tel Aviv-based novelist , who is set to attend a rally to protest the policy of the current government outside the Knesset in a few hour , where her husband will speak , many people recognize her and wish her well . & nbsp ; Lapid acknowledged them gracefully , displaying the poise that she ha acquired in a life in the harsh Israeli political spotlight . & ldquo ; I & rsquo ; m very involved in supporting Yair , not in term of political decision , but going out and campaigning , & rdquo ; she said . Still , it wa important to her to keep writing , and she did much of her work & ldquo ; in the twilight zone of the early morning hour , & rdquo ; during bout of insomnia.As the well-wisher drifted away , before I could ask a question , she turned to me with one of her own , one that any author would ask : How did I like the book ? My answer , that I thought it wa a moving and suspenseful story , filled with beautiful writing and vivid scene , and that I fell in love with the three complex woman at it center , pleased her a if she were a first-time writer , and led me into my first question : Where did she get the idea for it ? & nbsp ; The plot of the novelOn Her Own is about Nina , a teenage girl from Sderot born to Irena , a Ukrainian immigrant and single mother . A smart girl , Nina is nevertheless seduced by Johnny , a smalltime gangster who brings her for tryst to a Tel Aviv hotel . & nbsp ; One night when she is with him there , she witness a violent crime he is involved in , and she flees and take refuge with Carmela . & nbsp ; Carmela is a lonely widow with dementia who ha buried one son , a fallen soldier , and whose other son is busy with his family in America . Carmela ha moment that are partly dementia and partly wishful thinking when she feel that her late son is still alive.She ha also been dreaming that Dana , her granddaughter will come to visit , and when Nina show up at her door , she foggily embrace the girl , thinking & ndash ; or hoping & ndash ; that she is the grandchild she hasn & rsquo ; t seen in year . Meanwhile , Irena frantically search for her daughter on the eve of the Passover holiday.She created these character and told their story through a complex writing process that took her several year . One inspiration wa from a poem by Giora Fisher about a bereaved father with dementia . Lapid quoted the line : & ldquo ; Don & rsquo ; t tell me , oy , but he & rsquo ; s been gone a long time/Tell me , he just went out and he & rsquo ; ll be back soon . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; For her , this wa the & ldquo ; most heartbreaking poem I & rsquo ; ve ever heard . . . . When I heard that poem , I knew that wa the essence of Carmela , that she want to be in that place where in just a moment , he & rsquo ; ll return . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Nina came to life for her in a more circuitous route , when she imagined a teenage girl who is fleeing from a world of danger who meet Carmela on the stairs.For a long time , she had only vague thought about this scene and couldn & rsquo ; t figure out what the rest of the story should be . She spoke with a woman who worked a a counselor at a center run by Elem , for at-risk youth , about how girl like Nina are preyed on by men like Johnny . & ldquo ; And she told me , & lsquo ; It doesn & rsquo ; t happen all at once . & rsquo ; . . . . Gradually , girl are drawn into this world . & rdquo ; She also spent time speaking to single mother who were recent immigrant from the former Soviet Union . & ldquo ; One woman I have known for year . She is so talented and so smart , she ha two child from different father , she get up early , she work all day in the store so that her child will have a future . & nbsp ; She life for them . . . . And she exists almost completely in a Russian-speaking world . & rdquo ; Her brother , Deddy , who lived in the US for decade , wa an inspiration for the character , Itamar , Carmela & rsquo ; s son who life in America . Lapid & rsquo ; s brother passed away from cancer after the book wa finished and the book is dedicated to him . & ldquo ; We were very close . . . . He knew me better than I know myself . He knew I would become a writer before I knew . & rdquo ; Lapid may seem to be the ultimate Tel Aviv insider , and at first , it is surprising that she wrote about character who live on the margin of society , but a you speak to her more , you begin to understand that she can identify with these character because she also grew up feeling like an outsider.Born in Arad , a town where & ldquo ; you visit for a minute to get a cup of coffee and to go to the bathroom when the bus stop on the way to Masada , & rdquo ; she moved with her parent , who ran a Judaica store , to the Tel Aviv area when she wa in her teen and struggled to fit in . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The distance between a place like Sderot or Arad and Tel Aviv can be even longer than the distance between Tel Aviv and New York , & rdquo ; she noted . & nbsp ; Working a a photojournalist in Tel Aviv after the army , when she first met and then married Yair , she initially felt intimidated by his distinguished family . Yair Lapid wa an actor and author at that time , and his father , Tommy Lapid , wa a politician and a journalist , while his mother , Shulamit Lapid , is an acclaimed novelist . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I took literature course at the university to keep up with them , so I wouldn & rsquo ; t seem like an idiot at their family dinner , where they spoke about literature and art all the time . & rdquo ; She turned to writing after she suffered two miscarriage and wa put on bedrest when she wa pregnant with her son , Lior , and needed a way to express herself that didn & rsquo ; t involve running around Tel Aviv on a motorcycle with a camera . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; When Lior wa born , I understood that no newspaper is looking for a photographer who ha to nurse every four hour . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Another way in which Lapid look at the world differently from how you might expect is that her daughter , Yael , is on the autism spectrum . I have known Lapid slightly for many year because I also have a son on the spectrum the same age a her daughter , and she is the president of SHEKEL , an organization for people with special need in Israel . & nbsp ; Both of the Lapids have been upfront about their struggle raising their daughter . At first , after Yael & rsquo ; s diagnosis , Lapid wa consumed by trying to help her , to the exclusion of everything else . & ldquo ; I wa a wreck , I didn & rsquo ; t want to see anyone , I didn & rsquo ; t want to work , I just wanted to save her , I tried to do everything for her . . . . There wa a very dramatic moment , where Yair said to me , & lsquo ; You have other child who need you . & nbsp ; And you have me , and I need you . Yaeli will be who she is for life , she & rsquo ; s not a project for a couple of year , it & rsquo ; s not like she & rsquo ; ll go swimming with dolphin and then everything will be fine . . . . This ha to go back to being a happy home . & rsquo ; & rdquo ; Now , having a special-needs daughter is an important part of who she is , but not her full identity . & ldquo ; I am connected to Yael , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; I will always need to be there for her . But I & rsquo ; m also a writer , I & rsquo ; m also Lior & rsquo ; s mother and Yair & rsquo ; s wife . I & rsquo ; m also a friend . & rdquo ; It wa interesting for her to write the section about Nina and Irena & rsquo ; s relationship , because her relationship with her daughter is very different . & ldquo ; I have a daughter I can & rsquo ; t fight with the way Irena and Nina fight in the book . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; One aspect of the response to her book in Israel that ha pleased her is that , & ldquo ; People have said , it & rsquo ; s so Israeli . & rdquo ; Now that it ha been published in English , she isn & rsquo ; t afraid that reader in other country will find it too Israeli and won & rsquo ; t be able to relate to it . & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s like reading a book from abroad , a book like The Kite Runner , and it & rsquo ; s wonderful that it give you an authentic glimpse into another world , a window into the life of someone completely different . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Just before heading off to the rally , she said that since October 7 , she felt that the story of the bereaved mother in the novel wa even more relevant . & ldquo ; Every time I see a picture of a soldier who ha been killed , I think , there & rsquo ; s another mother like Carmela now , who will miss him for 30 or 40 year , who won & rsquo ; t be able to feel happy for 30 or 40 year . & nbsp ; They are soldier , but they are also our child . . . . Now that the book is being published in English , I think people who read it outside of Israel will have a greater understanding of what it mean to be Israeli , of the price we pay for our life here , that & rsquo ; s very meaningful to me . & rdquo ;

Body Text: For the first time in 50 year , Israel no longer enjoys the status of a & ldquo ; liberal democracy & rdquo ; due to & ldquo ; substantial decline in the indicator measuring the transparency and predictability of the law , and government attack on the judiciary , & rdquo ; according to the V-Dem Institute & rsquo ; s 2024 Democracy Report.V-Dem , short for Varieties of Democracy , is a research institute based in Sweden that measure the level of democracy worldwide based on a variety of what it defines a high-level principle of democracy . The institute publishes a yearly democracy report that split the world & rsquo ; s country into four category : Liberal democracy , electoral democracy , electoral autocracy , and closed autocracies.Electoral democracy , according to V-Dem , include & ldquo ; multiparty election for the executive are free and fair ; satisfactory degree of suffrage , freedom of expression , freedom of association . & rdquo ; Liberal democracy include the above , a well a & ldquo ; judicial and legislative constraint on the executive along with the protection of civil liberty and equality before the law . & rdquo ; Israel wa a liberal democracy since the 1970s , but in 2023 became an electoral democracy , the report said.According to the report , indicator that lowered Israel & rsquo ; s rating included a 2023 Knesset bill & ldquo ; stripping the Supreme Court of the power to invalidate law , thus undermining check on executive power . & rdquo ; A bill severely limiting the Supreme Court & rsquo ; s ability to strike down regular law and completely remove it power to invalidate Basic Laws , indeed passed it first reading in the Knesset , but did not pas into law.Regarding Israel , the report added that & ldquo ; indicator that are in substantive decline also include freedom from torture , & rdquo ; but did not expand.Yair Golan on Why Israel 's democracy got downgradedYair Golan , former IDF deputy chief of staff , Meretz MK and current candidate for leadership of the Labor Party , said in response to the report , & ldquo ; A full year of messianic dream , incessant threat against the judicial system , oppressive legislation , threat against the freedom of the press , harming fundamental right of demonstration , and appointing minister who are criminal , led u to lose our ranking a a liberal democracy . & rdquo ;
title: israel no longer ' liberal democracy ' for first time in 50 year , research institute say

Body Text: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and US President Joe Biden spoke on the phone Monday for the first time in over a month a tension between the two leader continue to increase.The conversation focused on Israel & rsquo ; s war against Hamas . The campaign , which is now in it sixth month , ha driven a wedge between the longtime ally that some are calling unprecedented . While the relationship between the US and Israel ha been dotted with disagreement and crisis , the alliance ha largely been considered steadfast and unwavering.Tensions between President Biden and Netanyahu were evident even before the war , a the Israeli government sought to promote a widespread reform of the country & rsquo ; s judicial system . While Netanyahu insisted that the reform would make Israel even more democratic , the US voiced it concern that the overhaul would concentrate power in Israel & rsquo ; s executive branch . The White House also criticized the inclusion of several far-right ultranationalist cabinet minister in the Netanyahu government.Immediate support after Oct . 7 , but is now it dwindling ? Following Hamas & rsquo ; surprise offensive against Israel , during which approximately 1,200 people were killed , President Biden set aside his difference with Netanyahu and moved to show immediate support for the Jewish state . In a visit to Tel Aviv just day after the attack , the American leader expressed solidarity with the Israeli people and vowed to continue the steady supply of arm to Israel . The US also mobilized aircraft carrier to the region to deter Israel & rsquo ; s other foe , mainly Iran , from joining the war.As the war continued , the US raised more question about Israel & rsquo ; s tactic and end-game strategy . Israel & rsquo ; s offensive in Gaza ha led to high casualty , with Gaza & rsquo ; s Hamas-run Health Ministry reporting over 31,000 Palestinians killed and 73,000 injured . The offensive ha led to widespread destruction in the territory that will cost billion of dollar to repair . Various international organization have also warned of famine in Gaza , upping the pressure on Israel to halt it offensive.In the past week , the tone adopted by senior American official toward Israel & rsquo ; s leader ha escalated . Earlier this year , the American president wa reported to have called Netanyahu a & ldquo ; bad f * * * ing guy , & rdquo ; which he denied having said . But last week , he went on the record saying the Israeli leader wa causing more harm than good to his country . & ldquo ; This is a unique crisis , both because it is in the midst of a war and because of what appears to be it very personal nature , & rdquo ; Dr . Shay Har-Zvi , head of the International and Middle Eastern Arenas at Reichman University & rsquo ; s Institute for Policy and Strategy , told The Media Line . & ldquo ; The personal criticism , rather than criticism of policy , make this crisis exceptional and perhaps one of the most acute . & rdquo ; The main point of contention is a pending Israeli military operation in Rafah , a city in the southern Gaza Strip . According to the United Nations , a majority of the approximately 1.7 million Palestinians displaced by the war are taking shelter in Rafah . Rafah is the only city in Gaza that ha not yet seen an operation of Israeli ground troops.As Israel delay it operation in Rafah , international pressure against operating in the city ha grown . Many country are warning of an exacerbated humanitarian crisis in Rafah , prompting Israel to consider how best to handle the city & rsquo ; s civilian population.Netanyahu ha vowed to operate in Rafah , saying that Hamas & rsquo ; senior leadership is hiding there . The city is also home to an extensive underground tunnel network that is believed to cross into neighboring Egypt . The tunnel are Hamas & rsquo ; main lifeline and source of weapon , making the target a critical one in Israel & rsquo ; s mission to dismantle the terrorist organization & rsquo ; s military capability . & ldquo ; The US feel Israel is not doing enough to meet the humanitarian need in Gaza and they want answer about how Israel intends to deal with the civilian presence in Rafah , & rdquo ; Har-Zvi said . & ldquo ; The humanitarian issue is at the core of the disagreement . & rdquo ; According to a White House readout of the call between the two leader , Netanyahu agreed to send a delegation to the US to & ldquo ; exchange view and discus alternative approach that would target key element of Hamas and secure the Egypt-Gaza border without a major ground operation in Rafah . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; The American perception is that because of Netanyahu & rsquo ; s political consideration , he is rejecting any possible solution , & rdquo ; Har-Zvi added . & ldquo ; He is not only missing what could be a historic opportunity , but also strategically entangling Israel by increasing the risk of a wider conflict and this will directly hurt American strategic interest . & rdquo ; Tensions on Israel & rsquo ; s northern border have also escalated , threatening to widen the scope of the conflict . These development have the White House increasingly on edge.Negotiations for a truce and a deal that would see the Israeli hostage being held by Hamas released could have a calming effect on the region . Those talk are currently underway in Qatar . & ldquo ; The US government is concerned that the failure of these talk will mean a regional escalation , & rdquo ; Har-Zvi said . & ldquo ; There is an understanding within the administration that the region is now at a critical crossroad . & rdquo ; During last month & rsquo ; s Democratic primary in Michigan , in which the incumbent president wa running uncontested , 13 % of voter voted & ldquo ; uncommitted & rdquo ; a part of a movement to protest his handling of the Israel-Gaza war . That result signaled to the White House that it Gaza policy wa putting the president at risk . & ldquo ; In the beginning of the war , Biden wa willing to pay the price for his support for Israel , but now the uncommitted vote appear to be gaining momentum and will likely influence Biden , & rdquo ; Har-Zvi explained.Over the weekend , Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer sharply criticized Netanyahu and called for early election in Israel . Schumer wa criticized both by Israelis and by US Republicans for interfering in internal Israeli affair . The president praised the majority leader & rsquo ; s speech , further upsetting Netanyahu.Although the current tension between Israel and the US have been called unprecedented , the two country have faced rocky period before . & ldquo ; There is a tendency to see crisis a & lsquo ; the worst & rsquo ; in the heat of the moment , & rdquo ; Zalman Shoval , a former Israeli ambassador to the US , told The Media Line.He said there have been & ldquo ; far worse & rdquo ; crisis than what Israel and the US are currently facing.In the aftermath of the 1973 Yom Kippur War , Israel and the US faced disagreement about how to prevent future conflict between Israel and Egypt . As a result of the disagreement , the US & ldquo ; reassessed & rdquo ; it relation with Israel and froze arm delivery to the country , leading to great tension between the ally . Israel later went on to sign a disengagement agreement with Egypt , likely due to American pressure.In the early 1990s , President George H.W . Bush announced that the US would withhold loan guarantee to Israel until it stopped building settlement in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.Both crisis appeared unprecedented and , to some , insurmountable.Israeli and American society have both changed significantly since the time of those crisis . The Israeli public ha increasingly shifted to the right , with consistently less support for a negotiated solution that would see the establishment of a Palestinian state . The Democratic Party ha also changed in recent year , with a growing progressive element that show more support for the Palestinians . & ldquo ; These change must not be underestimated , & rdquo ; Shoval said . & ldquo ; The political future of both country is unclear . & rdquo ; This future depends very much on the fate of the American and Israeli leader . President Biden is in the midst of an election campaign set to culminate in November 2024 . Netanyahu is lagging in the poll , and his increasingly unpopular government is not expected to last until the scheduled 2026 election . The outcome of election in both country will impact how the crisis play out . & ldquo ; The question is whether the US will continue to see itself a the leader of the Western world or if isolationist tendency will grow , & rdquo ; Shoval said.He added that personal chemistry between the two leader is not a significant a factor a many believe . Israel and the US still have mutual interest , and the country will eventually overcome the current crisis , Shoval said . & ldquo ; American defense support for Israel also stem from it own interest , including financial one , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; Unless there will be a fundamental shift in the US , this cooperation will continue . & rdquo ; Israel spends billion of dollar every year on American weapon system , military equipment , and services.The US appears eager to end the war , despite it stated support for Israel & rsquo ; s goal of dismantling Hamas . Public opinion in Israel , on the other hand , is very much in favor of continuing the war effort . This trend is evident in many poll and is independent of Netanyahu & rsquo ; s declining popularity . & ldquo ; When Americans come to express reservation about Netanyahu , they need to remember that there is overwhelming support in Israel for the war , & rdquo ; Shoval said . & ldquo ; I am not sure they understand the basic factor in the domestic politics here . & rdquo ;
title: us-israel relation tested a gap between president biden , netanyahu widens - analysis

Body Text: Labor MKs Gilad Kariv and Naama Lazimi announced on Sunday their support for former IDF deputy chief of staff Yair Golan to be the next leader of the party.The endorsement signal Kariv and Lazimi & rsquo ; s support for Golan & rsquo ; s plan to merge Labor into a larger party that will include supporter of the left-wing party Meretz and member of protest group against the government.Golan previously served a a member of the Knesset within Meretz . Current Labor chairperson MK Merav Michaeli refused to merge with Meretz ahead of that election , and Meretz eventually failed to pas the electoral threshold . & nbsp ; Golan said in a video statement that Kariv and Lazimi were `` excellent parliamentarian `` and added , `` After I am elected , we will together lead to many more merger in order to create a large and broad movement . `` `` The responsibility for change and hope is on u '' Lazimi said , `` The responsibility for change and hope is on u .
