Body Text: There are large gap in trust between Israelis , Palestinians and Arab-Israelis across Israel and the Palestinian territory , according to a recent survey by Tel Aviv University ( TAU ) . & quot ; Unsurprisingly , the Jewish public expressed very high level of distrust towards the Palestinians in Gaza ( 85 % ) and on the West Bank ( 84 % ) , & quot ; TAU said in it report . & quot ; But still , these are a bit lower than the level of total distrust of Hamas ( 97 % ) . Among respondent in the Jewish public , there is also distrust of Arabs who are citizen of Israel , except among left-winger , a three-quarters of them expressed trust in Arab citizen of Israel . & quot ; In comparison , mistrust of Palestinians and Arab-Israelis by the Jewish public is at & quot ; higher level & quot ; than that of the Arab public @ @ @ s perception of the Jewish public , which is reported to be at more & quot ; moderate & quot ; level . While the majority of respondent relayed their willingness to close said gap , by strengthening equality and cooperation between the side , Jewish respondent feel a need to strengthen & quot ; Jewish control & quot ; over the region following the most recent escalation and civil unrest that plagued the country in May & mdash ; Although that notion had low support from the left-wing Israeli supporter . Arab-Israeli respondent showed clear support ( 75 % ) for increasing equality among the Jewish and Arab group . & quot ; In contrast , the Arab public expressed more ambivalence regarding their level of trust for all three of the group mentioned , but among those who expressed opinion , a majority ( 61 % ) expressed distrust of Jewish citizen of Israel , & quot ; TAU explained . Zoning in on relation between the two opposing group , a larger majority of the Jewish public are for further coordination with Arab-Israeli citizen and Palestinians alike & mdash ; except those who stand in right-wing camp , who held split opinion on such a step . Arab-Israeli respondent additionally expressed their support ( 71 % ) for further cooperation between the group and an opposition to separating the group , although stood divided on policy that would increase Israeli control across the region . & quot ; Most of the left and center ( 95 % and 83 % respectively ) support increased equality for the two group , while half of the moderate right-wing support such move , & quot ; TAU said . & quot ; Among the right-wing , only 28 % expressed support . & quot ; Similar data appear for the four ideological Jewish group , regarding the level of opposition to an increase in separation between Arabs and Jews ( 85 % , 65 % , 55 % , and 27 % respectively ) . & quot ; With regard to the widespread civil unrest that plagued the country during the most recent IDF operation in the Gaza Strip , half of the Israeli public wa under the belief that former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu failed to deal with the violence properly , nor did they believe the violence wa justified but instead instigated by Palestinians and Arab-Israelis holding position of influence across the region , while the Arab public believed Netanyahu fueled the strife . Right-wing ( 81 % ) and moderate right-wing ( 74 % ) Israeli supporter both shared the belief that Netanyahu did not want to exacerbate the recent civil unrest that stormed through the mixed-cities across the country , while left-wing supporter ( 82 % ) and centrist ( 69 % ) thought the exact opposite & mdash ; displaying the mirror image of both camp with regard to the former prime minister . Similarly , although displaying further gap in opinion , right-wing camp believed Netanyahu did well to quell the violence while left-wing Israelis in greater majority believed that he aggravated the situation . The general Arab public tended to hold similar view with the left-wing camp across Israel , that instead of stamping out the violence , Netanyahu incited it to further the operation in Gaza . Both Arab and Jewish sector did , however , agree that the violence wa unjustified and only furthered the divide between the two side . When asked about the IDF @ @ @ s Operation Guardian of the Wall , around half of the Jewish public belief Israel & quot ; achieved more significant gain than Hamas in the recent fighting . & quot ; This is despite the feeling that the world perceives the operation a being of a & nbsp ; & quot ; disproportionate nature . & quot ; A larger majority support further military operation to bring the total collapse of Hamas in the Gaza Strip or long-term solution to the ongoing conflict . & quot ; Most of the Arab public support a long-term solution ( 57 % ) , but a third did not express their opinion , & quot ; TAU said . The most common answer given , however , across the Arab sector wa that they & quot ; did not know & quot ; who gained the upper hand in the fighting , and with regard to international opinion surrounding how the conflict played out , they are evenly divided on how the world view Israel in the aftermath of the violence believing that many country still support the Jewish State regardless . In the context of future negotiation and peace arrangement with the Palestinians , there ha been some opposition to & quot ; maintaining the present situation in comparison to previous survey , & quot ; with many reconsidering their position on the decades-long conflict , meaning that while a larger portion of the public prefer a one-state solution , the majority still support a two-state & mdash ; a well a additional consideration regarding annexation and a binational coexistence . & quot ; Among the respondent , most on the left ( 55 % ) and on the right ( 53 % ) responded that it had not led to reconsideration , while among the moderate right and the center , most answered positively , & quot ; said TAU in it report . & quot ; People on the right who responded that they were reconsidering their opinion were divided between those who said that they were weighing whether to support a military solution ( 33 % ) and those who stated that they were thinking about supporting an agreed upon political solution ( 16 % ) . & quot ; Centrists responded more commonly to a political solution ( 37 % ) , and in contrast , about a third of the Arab public did not respond , while about a quarter said they would consider & quot ; supporting an agreed upon political solution . & quot ; & quot ; Despite the growing dissatisfaction with the existing situation , there is no sign of change , when compared to the previous index , in answer to the question of which solution ha the highest probability of being achieved , a in the last index , continuing the present situation is the most frequent reply in the sample ( 46 % ) , & quot ; TAU explained . Noting the new unity government headed by Prime Minister Naftali Bennett and Foreign Minister Yair Lapid , which is without a leader currently on trial for public corruption ( i.e . Netanyahu ) , two-thirds of the respondent to the survey are categorically for a law that would prevent those accused of a criminal act from serving a prime minister . & quot ; The data received indicates stability , when contrasted to the previous index , in support of a law to prevent those accused of criminal activity from serving a prime minister ( 66 % in contrast to 65 % ) , including broad support among right-wing voter ( 69 % ) , & quot ; TAU noted . & quot ; Netanyahu & rsquo ; s proposal for direct election for prime minister also gain wide support among the right-wing ( 87 % ) and from the moderate right ( 71 % ) , compared to opposition from the centrist ( 63 % ) and from the left-wing ( 82 % ) . & quot ;
title: large gap in trust between israeli , palestinian and arab-israelis

Body Text: Egypt ha sent a convoy of engineer and building equipment to Gaza to begin reconstruction in the Palestinian enclave after the recent Israeli-Palestinian conflict , Egyptian state television reported on Friday . Dozens of bulldozer , crane and truck flying Egyptian flag lined up along the border to begin crossing into the Gaza Strip , television picture showed . Palestinians lined the street on the Gaza side of the Rafah crossing to welcome the convoy a it rumbled into the small coastal enclave . A Palestinian border official said 50 vehicle had crossed . & quot ; We rushed with all our money , equipment , and what we owned to join the Palestinians in the rebuilding . Every Muslim and every Egyptian wish to take part in [ the reconstruction ] , & quot ; Egyptian truck driver Mahmoud Ismail told Reuters in Gaza . Eleven day of conflict between Israel and Hamas , the Palestinian Islamist ruler of Gaza , erupted on May 10 . More than 250 Palestinians were killed in hundred of Israeli air strike in Gaza . Rockets fired by Gaza militant killed 13 people in Israel . Egypt played a major role in brokering a ceasefire between both side and ha said it would allocate $ 500 million to fund the rebuilding of devastated area in Gaza . Hamas spokesman Hazem Qassem on Friday reiterated the group @ @ @ s appreciation of Egyptian contribution to the rebuilding effort . Gaza & rsquo ; s housing ministry said 1,500 housing unit were destroyed during the fighting , another 1,500 housing unit had been damaged beyond repair and 17,000 suffered partial damage . A ministry official put the cost of rebuilding at $ 150 million . Egypt in February opened the Rafah crossing until further notice after Palestinian faction moved towards reconciliation following talk in Cairo . It had previously been opening the crossing for only a few day at a time to allow stranded traveler to pas . The 365-sq km ( 141-sq mile ) Gaza Strip , controlled by Hamas , is home to around 2 million Palestinians . An Israeli-led blockade ha put restriction on the movement of people and good for year .
title: egypt sends building equipment to begin gaza reconstruction

Body Text: The Israel Antiquities Authority ( IAA ) and the Lod Municipality discovered them by chance during excavation of a destroyed Jewish public building . Experts said they were evidence of the last Jewish revolt against Roman rule in Israel & ndash ; 1,650 year ago.The dramatic discovery is the first-ever evidence in Lod of the Gallus Revolt , the last Jewish resistance against Roman rule , between 351 and 354 CE.The excavation wa carried out on Nordau Street in the building from the late Roman-early Byzantine period that suffered violent destruction . Presumably , the coin , dating from 221 to 354 CE , were deliberately placed there in the hope that the owner would return to collect them when the situation calmed down.There is very little written evidence about the Gallus Revolt . However , text indicate that the force of Roman Caesar Flavius Constantinus Gallus destroyed major Jewish community such a Lod , Zipori , and Tiberias.Among the various find in the building were impressive stone and marble artifact , along with Greek , Hebrew , and Latin inscription , including one bearing the name of a Jewish man from a priestly family , which is still under examination.These inscription , coupled with the complete absence of pig bone from the bone assemblage uncovered on the site , attest to this building & rsquo ; s association with the Jewish community . ' An exciting , very emotionally moving find ' & nbsp ; According to IAA site excavator Shahar Krispin and Mor Viezel , & ldquo ; In all likelihood , this is a magnificent Jewish building that housed the city & rsquo ; s elder . From Talmudic writing , we know that Lod wa a most significant Jewish center in the aftermath of the Second Temple & rsquo ; s destruction in Jerusalem . Some of the renowned & lsquo ; Sages of Lod & rsquo ; are Rabbi Eliezer ben Horkanos , Rabbi Tarfon , Rabbi Akiva , Rabbi Yosi Ha & rsquo ; Galili , and many more . & ldquo ; The building , destroyed down to it very foundation , is a clear indication that the revolt wa forcefully put down with violence and cruelty and wa not simply a local uprising event , a some earlier study contended . This is the singular witness , thus far , to the extent and power of this revolt in Lod , which is located in the country & rsquo ; s center . & rdquo ; IAA council head Prof . Joshua Schwartz , who study Talmudic-period Lod , noted that & ldquo ; it & rsquo ; s hard to know if this magnificent building served a synagogue , study hall , meeting hall of the elder , or all three of these function a one.But what is clear is that the building & rsquo ; s size , the coin hoard , and the assemblage of archaeological find produced by the excavation fit well Lod/Diospolis & rsquo ; s description , in both Jewish and non-Jewish source , a a center of Torah-true Jewish life in the Mishna and Talmud period . Lod & rsquo ; s role a a leading community with elder continued from after the destruction through to this moment , when it wa cruelly cut down in the Gallus Revolt . & rdquo ; IAA director Eli Escuzido concluded that & ldquo ; the impressive find uncovered here reinforce our responsibility to investigate and to conserve Lod & rsquo ; s history and rich heritage . Along with the city & rsquo ; s new exhibition center of the beautiful Lod mosaic , we now bring this building to the awareness of the general public . & rdquo ; Lod Mayor Yair Revivo added that & ldquo ; this is an exciting and very emotionally moving find , another link in the chain of Lod & rsquo ; s Tannaitic period heritage a host to the author of the Mishna and Lod & rsquo ; s Jewish history . The find in the area prove that Lod is one of the oldest city in the world . We wish to thank the IAA for revealing our city & rsquo ; s past glory . I believe that now that it is uncovered , this site will bring many tourist and visitor to the city . Lod is connecting to it past and is looking forward to a bright future . & rdquo ; The finding will be published a part of the Central Israel Region Archaeological Conference , which will be held at Tel Aviv & rsquo ; s Eretz Yisrael Museum on June 20 and jointly hosted by Tel Aviv University , Bar-Ilan University , and the ( IAA ) . The event is open to the public at no charge . Details can be found on the Israel Antiquities Authority website .

Body Text: Israel & rsquo ; s budget deficit could run into double digit by the end of 2024 and could cause international financial actor to lose trust in Israel & rsquo ; s economy , opposition MKs warned in a Knesset Finance Committee session on Tuesday.The budget deficit is the difference between the government & rsquo ; s expense and it income or asset and occurs when a country & rsquo ; s spending exceeds it income . The updated 2024 budget that passed into law in March set the budget deficit ceiling at 6.6 % , but by the end of April already reached 7 % . Committee chairman MK Moshe Gafni ( United Torah Judaism ) held the session after nine committee member , all from the opposition , demanded he address the issue.Yesh Atid MK Vladimir Beliak , the coordinator of the opposition in the committee , pointed out at the beginning of the session that he had warned during the budget debate in March of this scenario , and criticized the government for rejecting step to decrease it expenditure , such a closing down ministry or reducing the amount of & ldquo ; coalition fund & rdquo ; which Beliak claimed were reserved for political purpose . & ldquo ; I want to know , what deficit will we reach ? I have not heard from the finance minister [ Bezalel Smotrich ] & hellip ; If we arrive at a double-digit deficit , what will the repercussion be vi - & agrave ; - vi the credit rating company ? What will the repercussion be on the social service that the state can provide ? & rdquo ; Beliak said.The deficit applies to the past 12 month , and the representative from the finance ministry & rsquo ; s budget department , Asaf Wexler , argued that the deficit will shrink back to within the 6.6 % limit by year & rsquo ; s end . According to Wexler , the sharp increase in the deficit reflected month of intense fighting and economic slowdown.It also reflected the & ldquo ; situation of very high uncertainty & rdquo ; a to when the fighting will end , and consequently to Israel & rsquo ; s economic performance . Wexler admitted , however , that if a war break out in Israel & rsquo ; s north , the finance ministry would likely need to update it deficit forecast.MKs criticized other aspect of the government 's performanceDuring the session , both Beliak and Labor MK Naama Lazimi criticized other aspect of the government & rsquo ; s performance on the economy . These included breaking 2023 & rsquo ; s deficit ceiling despite updating the 2023 budget in December ; the downgrade of Israel & rsquo ; s credit rating by both S & amp ; P and Moodys ; the fact that Gafni , who is ultra-Orthodox ( haredi ) , ha refused to pas several provision laid out in the budget to increase government income , to protest the withholding of fund he claim have not been given to the haredi school system ; the uptick in the cost of living and inflation remaining high at 2.8 % ; and other aspects.The session also came a day after the finance ministry published an updated version of what is known a the & ldquo ; numerator , & rdquo ; which computes expected government spending three year ahead . According to the numerator , the government ha already committed to spending billion more in the upcoming year than it is allowed to do by law . For example , the government ha already committed to spending NIS 600 billion in 2025 , higher than the legal limit of NIS 545 billion ; and it committed to spend NIS 615 billion in 2026 , despite a limit of NIS 569.8 billion.The result is that ahead of the 2025 budget , the state will either need to reduce it spending , which could affect it ability to provide service ; or raise tax . & nbsp ;

Body Text: On the 26 of Iyar , Israelis paraded to Mount Herzl , Jerusalem , to mark the Jewish holiday of ' The Day of Liberation and Rescue of the Jews of Europe from the hand of the Nazis . ' This year , 2024 , marked 79 year since the victory of the Allied force over Nazi Germany . The holiday wa established formally ten year ago to occur on 26 of Iyar - the Hebrew calendar date of the surrender of the Third Reich in France . & nbsp ; The holiday , which this year fell on June 3 , commemorates the victim of the Holocaust and the rescue of the survivor . The Jerusalem rally took place near the memorial for a quarter of a million Jewish men and woman who fell in the service of the Red Army , the Allied force , and the underground resistance in World War II . ' We will overcome'Jewish businessman Gabriel German Zakharyayev & nbsp ; spoke at this year 's event in Strasbourg : & ldquo ; Our generation ha endured bitter trial . [ . . . ] In the past , they managed to overcome difference of opinion and unite to liberate the world , to rise up from the ash of the ruin , and build a new world based on new , humane principle . [ We ] can do the same today . `` The day wa observed in Israel and around the world with Chief Rabbis , representative from the allied country , and Holocaust survivor in attendance . The Mount Herzl parade wa also attended by veteran who fought in World War II , IDF soldier , officer cadet , and invited guests.Retired General and serving MK Uzi Dayan told soldier that `` there is no comparison to the significant contribution the veteran made in the Second World War by defeating the Nazis , building the State of Israel , and ensuring it ongoing security . `` Addressing the fallen , he said : `` From you , we learned the true value of victory . ``

Body Text: Former US president Donald Trump already believed at the beginning of his administration that prime minister & nbsp ; Benjamin Netanyahu did not want peace with the Palestinians , former US ambassador to Israel David Friedman reveals in his soon-to-be-released book , Sledgehammer . That person is Ron Lauder , who once supported Netanyahu but had a falling out with him , though Friedman doe not name him in the book . Lauder told Trump that the Palestinians & ldquo ; were prepared to make peace with Israel on very favorable term , even to include conceding all of Jerusalem to Israeli sovereignty and giving up the return of refugee , but the problem wa that Bibi Netanyahu wa unwilling to negotiate peace . Trump then met one-on-one with Netanyahu , and 45 minute later , aide entered the room . The leader discussed Israel & rsquo ; s security , and Friedman suggested that they watch the video of Abbas & rsquo ; s speech . & ldquo ; With that we watched two minute of Abbas honoring terrorist , extolling violence , and vowing to never accept anything less than Israel & rsquo ; s total defeat , & rdquo ; Friedman recounted . & ldquo ; Abbas ranted that the blood of every shaheed & ndash ; literally a martyr but also a terrorist & ndash ; wa holy and would be avenged . & rdquo ; Friedman did not say the video included what Woodward & rsquo ; s book said , that it & ldquo ; sounded like Abbas wa ordering the murder of child . & rdquo ; After watching the video , Trump said , & ldquo ; Wow , is that the same guy I met in Washington last month ? He seemed like such a sweet , peaceful guy . & rdquo ; LATER IN the trip , when Trump met with Abbas in Bethlehem , he & ldquo ; laced into Abbas over the tape , demanding to know who he really wa , a peacemaker a he claimed in Washington or a terrorist a he proclaimed on the tape . & rdquo ; Friedman also reported that Abbas complained about Israeli security in the West Bank . & ldquo ; Trump asked him how much Israel wa charging the PA for those security service , & rdquo ; the ambassador wrote . & ldquo ; Abbas looked stunned . He wa incredulous that Abbas wa rejecting free Israeli security support when Israel wa the only player in the region that knew how to fight these implacable foe . & ldquo ; Abbas looked at Trump a if he had two head & ndash ; no one had ever spoken to him before with this brutal clarity , & rdquo ; Friedman recalled . Body Text: Former Justice Minister Tzipi Livni testified in Case 2000 , in which Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is accused of fraud with Yediot Ahronot publisher Arnon Mozes , Israeli medium reported on Wednesday.In her testimony , Livni stated , `` Between the two of u [ her and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu ] , there wa maybe one word of the `` Israel Hayom Law . `` Just before the session to pas the law , he called me to his office and informed me that the Knesset had agreed to bring the law to a free vote . As far a I am concerned , this wa a complete surprise . `` The `` Israel Hayom Law , `` otherwise known by it legal name , the `` Law for the Advancement and Protection of Print Journalism in Israel , `` would make it illegal to distribute a newspaper free of charge if it is a full-sized paper published six day a week . It received the more common name , `` The Israel Hayom Law , `` because Israel Hayom is the only Hebrew daily paper that meet this specific requirement . & nbsp ; `` As far a I wa aware , Netanyahu wa against the proposal of this law , and I assumed that he would propose an appeal even if it did pas , `` Livni said . `` By allowing the law proposal to go to a free vote , he gave it the green light to go to a vote in the Knesset without the Prime Minister being able to intervene . `` Livni denies that her firing wa related to the `` Israel Hayom Law '' Livni discussed the circumstance of her firing from Netanyahu 's cabinet , which she claimed wa also unrelated to the `` Israel Hayom Law . `` `` I wa invited to the Prime Minister 's office , we sat for around an hour , and the topic of firing never came up . We traveled to a ceremony at the President 's house , and after I left , I received a phone call from him [ Netanyahu ] saying that I 'm fired , `` she said . `` I remember that one of the reason for this wa because I met with Mahmoud Abbas a few time without his permission . I do n't recall that the topic of the ' Israel hayom Law ' came up once a a reason for my firing . `` In 2017 , the National Fraud Investigation Unit of the Israel Police began an investigation into claim that Netanyahu wa passing this legislation to cripple Israel Hayom in return for favorable coverage in Yediot Ahronot . Body Text: On Tuesday , the Jordan River crossing ( Kasser Al-Yahud ) hosted an event commemorating the historic crossing of the Jordan River by the Israelites approximately 3,300 year ago.Led by the Jordan Valley Trustees Association , the ceremony not only honored a significant moment in Israel & rsquo ; s history but also underscored the association & rsquo ; s call to recognize the Jordan River crossing a a national heritage site and reaffirm Israeli sovereignty in the Jordan Valley.Brig . - Gen . ( Ret . ) Uzi Dayan , chairman of the Jordan Valley Trustees Association , emphasized the importance of preserving historical site such a the Jordan River crossing and highlighted their profound significance in connecting the Jewish people to the Land of Israel . & ldquo ; The site symbolizes the deep and historical connection of the Jewish people to the Land of Israel , & rdquo ; Dayan stated , advocating for an annual state ceremony to commemorate the Israelites & rsquo ; crossing.The event drew participation from hundred of individual across the country who engaged in various activity , including a musical prayer service , guided tour in the Jericho area , and a symposium discussing the historical and cultural significance of the Jordan River crossings.Collaborating with regional council in the Jordan Valley and receiving support from organization such a Magen David Adom , the Aliyah and Integration Ministry , the World Zionist Organization , and the Jordan Valley Trustees Association highlighted the potential for developing tourism in the region.Dayan noted that the site attracts over 850,000 tourist annually and proposed the construction of hotel and visitor center to accommodate the growing interest , which could provide employment opportunity for resident and further establish Israel & rsquo ; s presence in the Jordan Valley.The Jordan River crossing is a cornerstone moment for the Israeli peopleAccording to biblical account and historical research , the crossing of the Jordan River by the Hebrews or Israelites is a pivotal moment in their journey to claim the Promised Land . As recounted in the Book of Joshua , after wandering in the wilderness for forty year , the Israelites , led by Joshua , stood on the eastern bank of the Jordan River , poised to enter the land of Canaan.Mirroring the miraculous crossing of the Red Sea led by Moses , Joshua ordered the priest carrying the Ark of the Covenant to step into the water of the Jordan . As they did , the river miraculously parted , allowing the Israelites to cross on dry ground , just a the slave generation had done 40 year earlier . This event symbolized the fulfillment of God & rsquo ; s promise to deliver the land to the Israelites and marked the beginning of their conquest and settlement of Canaan.Historical research corroborates element of this biblical account , suggesting that the crossing of the Jordan River likely occurred at a shallow ford near the modern-day site of Kasser Al-Yahud . Archaeological evidence and geographical study support the plausibility of such an event , with scholar proposing that the timing of the crossing coincided with the spring thaw when the river & rsquo ; s water would have been at their lowest .
title: israeli commemorate bible 's jordan river crossing 3,300 year ago

Body Text: Israel is expected to refrain from attacking the & ldquo ; no-strike & rdquo ; zone it created for Palestinian civilian in southern Gaza , US National Security advisor Jake Sullivan told reporter a the IDF battered that area of the enclave from the air and sea . & ldquo ; In those [ safe ] zone we do expect Israel to follow through without striking , & rdquo ; he said.The dilemma regarding the Gaza war , he said , is & ldquo ; how do you , on the one hand , allow a sovereign nation like Israel to go after terror target while on the other hand , have them do so in a way that minimizes harm to civilian , that is really where the rubber hit the road in all of this . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; Fundamentally we have laid our expectation that in the area that Israel ha asked people to go that it ensure the security and safety of civilian and that it doe so in the conduct of it military operation and that it doe so in the facilitation of humanitarian assistance getting to them , & rdquo ; he said.International pressure on IsraelSullivan spoke four day after the Gaza war resumed after a week-long pause ended on December 1 . Hamas ha asserted that close to 16,000 Palestinians have been killed in war violence since hostility began on October 7 after the terror group infiltrated southern Israel killing over 1,200 people and seizing 240 hostages.United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres called for a & ldquo ; sustained humanitarian ceasefire in Gaza , the unconditional [ and ] immediate release of all hostage , and unimpeded [ and ] sustained humanitarian aid flow to meet the need of the people throughout the Gaza Strip . & rdquo ; Lynn Hastings , who is the humanitarian coordinator for the Palestinian territory , panned Israel & rsquo ; s safety zone in the south . & ldquo ; Israeli military operation have expanded into southern Gaza , forcing ten of thousand of others into increasingly compressed space , desperate to find food , water , shelter and safety , & rdquo ; she said . & ldquo ; Nowhere is safe in Gaza and there is nowhere left to go , & rdquo ; she added . & ldquo ; The condition required to deliver aid to the people of Gaza do not exist . If possible , an even more hellish scenario is about to unfold , one in which humanitarian operation may not be able to respond . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; The quantity of relief supply and fuel allowed in are utterly insufficient . Despite the enormous effort of the Egyptian and Palestinian Red Crescent Societies , UN agency , and other partner , the use of only the Rafah crossing - meant for pedestrian - to bring in truck of good doe not work . & ldquo ; What we see today are shelter with no capacity , a health system on it knee , a lack of clean drinking water , no proper sanitation , and poor nutrition for people already mentally and physically exhausted : a textbook formula for epidemic and a public health disaster , & rdquo ; she said.The head of the Geneva-based International Committee of the Red Cross , visited Gaza on Monday , issuing a statement in which she said the level of human suffering wa intolerable , called for the protection of civilian , respect for the law of war , and the release of hostage held by Hamas . `` We would welcome Hamas laying down it arm '' In Washington , State Department spokesman Matthew Miller defended the resumption of Israel & rsquo ; s military campaign to oust Hamas from Gaza that began after the October 7 attack . He blamed Hamas for the war and said that more people should call for the terror group to lay down it arm . & ldquo ; It is Hamas that is putting [ Palestinian ] civilian in harm 's way . I am surprised that I do not hear more people say why doesn & rsquo ; t Hamas move out of school ? why doesn & rsquo ; t Hamas take additional step to protect civilian ? Because we think they should a we think Israel should . & ldquo ; We would welcome Hamas laying down it arm at any point , & rdquo ; he added . & ldquo ; They could do it today if they cleared about Palestinian civilian life . & rdquo ; Miller also called on Israel to do more to protect civilian in Gaza , a Hamas asserted that close to 16,000 Palestinians have been killed in war-related violence.The United States is watching IDF action in Gaza & ldquo ; very closely , & rdquo ; Miller said a he explained that there were difference between Israel & rsquo ; s military campaign that resumed on December 1 and the one that ended on November 24 . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Too many Palestinians were killed in the opening week of the conflict , & ldquo ; Miller said . & ldquo ; We have seen a more targeted request for evacuation & rdquo ; by Israel so that the army is focused on clearing specific point rather than asking an entire city to evacuate , Miller said.Civilians have been asked to relocate to & ldquo ; de-confliction zone rather than being asked to flee , Miller said.During US Secretary of State Antony Blinken 's visit to Israel last week , he clarified to official & ldquo ; We do not want a military campaign in the south that look like it wa in the north . & rdquo ; Blinken wa briefed & ldquo ; on plan intended to avoid mass casualty . & rdquo ; It wa understood that there would be civilian casualty , & ldquo ; that is true in all war zone and is particularly true here & rdquo ; given that Hamas operates from within civilian area , Miller said.Both Miller and Sullivan addressed the collapse hostage deal by which 81 woman and child were freed , but there are still some 17 or 20 woman and child among the captives.Qatar and Egypt mediated the deal . Sullivan said that Israel and US official are still in conversation with those two country to seek a way to resume hostage releases.Miller said that the hostage deal partially fell apart last week because Hamas wanted to prevent the remaining Israeli woman it hold in Gaza from talking about their time in captivity . & ldquo ; It seems one of the reason they don & rsquo ; t want to turn woman over that they have been holding hostage and the reason this pause fell apart is that they do not want these woman to be able to talk about what happened to them during their time in captivity , & rdquo ; Miller alleged during an emotional moment in the press conference.Later in the briefing , Miller clarified that he doe not know this claim to be a definitive fact.Separately , in the briefing in Washington , Miller addressed the issue of settler violence saying that the US ha also spoken with Israel about doing more to crack down on attack against innocent Palestinians in the West Bank , Miller said . & ldquo ; We have seen them take some step to respond to violence . We do not think those step have been sufficient . They need to prosecute people who engage in violence against [ innocent ] Palestinians , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; We have made very clear to the Israeli government that we will be taking additional step to hold people accountable for violent extremism , & rdquo ; he said , explaining that this could include visa restrictions.Miller also addressed the issue of rising antisemitism , condemning it in the strongest term . & ldquo ; We oppose antisemitism wherever we see it , & rdquo ; Miller said . It & rsquo ; s tragic that after October 7 , & ldquo ; one of the response ha been an increase in antisemitism that is extremely tragic and it & rsquo ; s incumbent on everyone in position of authority to speak out . & rdquo ;

Body Text: The draft of an import reform bill , expected to drastically cut Israelis ' cost of living , wa put forward for public comment by the Health Ministry Thursday . The bill is aimed at simplifying import of food marketed in the European Union and adopting more fully EU food and supplement regulatory standard , said the ministry.The proposal 's main goal is to adopt EU regulation in additional area of food safety , including regulation regarding what information must be provided to consumer about food product and gluten in food , regulation about adding vitamin and mineral to food , dietary supplement , and more . The ministry added that the proposal expanded the adoption of EU regulation from the four currently adopted to 20 . `` The move brings u towards harmony with European law for anything to do with food safety , `` said the ministry . & nbsp ; The ministerial Cost of Living Committee , chaired by Economy Minister Nir Barkat , approved the reform late last month . The legislation is expected to be completed by the end of April 2024.Following other legislation aimed at lowering cost of livingThe draft bill follows the 2021 Israeli Government 's decision to open the market to import and decrease the cost of living . By reducing the amount of red tape and paperwork that foreign manufacturer and importer face , the government hope to increase market competition within Israel , thereby reducing the steep cost of living.In January , State Comptroller Matanyahu Englman disclosed a report addressing the cost of living in Israel . & nbsp ; This report revealed that food price in Israel are 51 % higher compared to European Union country and 37 % higher than the OECD average.The draft is the first version of the law , and is available for public comment from now until March 22.Jerusalem Post staff and & nbsp ; Zachy Hennessey contributed to this report
title: import reform set to cut cost of living bill drafted

Body Text: Hezbollah is currently engaged in a war of attrition on the Israeli border , but it is not unlikely that they will receive order from Tehran to redirect force to another area they recently fought in & ndash ; northern Syria . In the past week , a wave of protest began in every district of the rebel-held Idlib province in northwestern Syria . This is the last stronghold of the Syrian opposition and the last remnant of the civil war in Syria from a decade ago , a war that ended in other area of the country in 2018.Syria 's Idlib district is not ready to surrenderAt the height of the civil war in Syria in 2015 , opposition force , led by Jabhat al-Nusra , a jihadist faction of al-Qaeda in Syria , united . The coalition of Islamist organization pushed the Syrian army out of the Idlib district and ha held most of it to this day . This is a district that the Syrian regime can not afford to ignore due to it strategic location . Idlib is very close to Latakia & ndash ; the stronghold of Syria 's ruling Alawite community , a well a to Russian military base in Syria & ndash ; the Russian-operated air force base in Hmeimim and the naval port in Tartus . Despite the relentless Syrian air force bombing on the Idlib district ( including even to the present day ) , the opposition maintains control of the area with impressive tenacity . It seems that in recent year , even Assad 's supporter have given up hope of seizing control of Idlib . Shi'ite militia have depleted their force in Syria , and most of Hezbollah 's men have returned to Lebanon . The Russians ' attention is elsewhere too , a they are deeply involved in the war in Ukraine.Bashar Assad 's army is not capable of effectively fighting , due to the significant wear and tear it ha endured . The economy of Syria is shattered , unemployment is rampant , and the currency continues to lose it value . There is no money to sustain the army or rebuild it significantly . However , this doe not stop Assad 's army from continuing to bomb the civilian of Idlib indiscriminately . The regime 's message is clear : life in the `` liberated `` territory will remain a hell until they return to Assad 's rule.The ruler of Idlib are trying to gain local legitimacy . They changed the name of their organization from Jabhat al-Nusra to `` Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham `` ( Organization for the Liberation of the Levant or HTS ) and seemingly distanced themselves from al-Qaeda , but they remain a jihadist fundamentalist group . The area under the organization 's control essentially are Islamic emirate with strict religious law . The region doe receive support from Turkey , mainly felt in civilian area , especially regarding food . However , Turkish aid is limited a Turkey itself is experiencing a complex economic crisis . Overall , the Idlib province suffers from severe poverty and unemployment.Israel is also involved without even knowing itBoth side , the Syrian regime and the opposition in Idlib , accuse each other of receiving Israeli support . The opposition constantly compare Assad 's bombing on school and hospital to the current situation in Gaza : to them , Assad and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu are two similar enemy . The only place in Syria where demonstration in support of Gaza have taken place since October 7 wa in Idlib province . By contrast , the Syrian regime accuses the opposition of seeking help from Israel , a the Israeli Air Force often bomb Assad 's supporter in Syria & ndash ; mainly Shi'ite terrorist group such a Hezbollah . It seems that in the Middle East , the enemy of your enemy can still be your enemy.Opportunity for the Syrian regimeLast week , protest began in various area of Idlib province against the rule of HTS and specifically against the leader of the organization , Abu Mohammad al-Julani . Al Jazeera recently covered the development in the province with concern.According to Al Jazeera , which is known for it support of Islamic organization , the protest arose due to two issue : political and economic & ndash ; the authoritarian rule of the provincial leader , accusation of corruption , and the severe economic crisis . Julani 's organization recently carried out a wave of arrest of around a thousand activist from various opposition organization in the province , including activist who had previously belonged to his organization . The released detainee reported severe torture of prisoner who were arrested on suspicion of collaborating with the Assad regime . Analysts attribute the deteriorating situation to the lack of a political solution and a significant reduction in international aid to the province in recent month . This crisis wa created due to the uncompromising and unyielding stance of the zealous jihadist ruler Julani , who is not willing to make any political concession . The current wave of protest openly call for the overthrow of Julani 's oppressive rule , which some compare to the repression of the Assad regime.The protester claim that the current situation is even worse than during Assad 's rule because it also includes religious repression in the style of ISIS . The protester demand the establishment of a local council to run the province . HTS is now trying to calm the protest by releasing more prisoner , monitoring price increase , and easing some tax . However , it seems that the protest have spiraled out of control and are only gaining momentum.Interpreters from the Lebanese Al-Mayadeen outlet revealed that behind the protest stand Turkey , which aim to undermine the control of Idlib from the hand of Julani and return it to the Free Syrian Army under Ankara 's direct control . The recent development undoubtedly weaken Julani , who still control about 75 % of Idlib . This mark the breakdown of the coalition after many year of unity.An opportunity for Assad , a problem for HezbollahThe division , anarchy , and turmoil in the Idlib region undoubtedly present a golden opportunity for control in Damascus , which may not return . Now Assad 's army could potentially enter the region with significant support to restore it to the embrace of the regime , after almost a decade of neglect . However , this would require substantial support force . For the occupation of Idlib , a significant asset for the Assad regime in particular , and the `` resistance axis `` in general , Iran would need to send substantial force . These force mainly include Shi'ite Popular Mobilization Unit militia from Iraq and Hezbollah force from Lebanon . However , Hezbollah can not afford a two-front war.Now , Iran 's axis of resistance , the Syrian regime , and Shi'ite militia face a crossroad : whether to continue the war in the Israeli arena or redirect force to northern Syria ? In the case of the Israel front , it is a purposeless war with Hezbollah already suffering over 230 casualty and no achievement against the highly motivated and prepared IDF . In the case of Idlib , however , it present an opportunity for a significant strategic victory against the disintegrating opposition.Will the Syrian arena affect our northern border ? Will Hezbollah agree to a compromise on our border in order to turn it attention to Syria ? Only time will tell.Dr . Yaron Friedman is a researcher , lecturer , and Arabic teacher in the Department of Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies at the University of Haifa . Yaron manages the newsletter This Week in the Middle East .
title: hezbollah 's concern : will assad unintentionally help israel ? - analysis

Body Text: The Israeli-Palestinian conflict is one of the most well-known conflict around the world . & nbsp ; Since it beginning shortly after the birth of the State of Israel , the conflict ha dominated regional geopolitics for over 70 year . And a the ongoing Israel-Hamas War show , the conflict 's importance and intensity show no sign of slowing down . & nbsp ; But what is the Israeli-Palestinian conflict ? Where did it start ? Who are the key player involved ? & nbsp ; Here is everything you need to know.Where is Israel ? Israel is a country in the Middle East , specifically in the Levant region . It is steeped in thousand of year of history and ha been the home of numerous civilization and religious faiths.Israel is bordered by Egypt , Jordan , Lebanon , Syria , and the Palestinian territory and is on the coast of both the Mediterranean Sea and the Red Sea . & nbsp ; While most country consider it capital to be Tel Aviv , Israel and a few other country , such a the United States , recognize Jerusalem a the capital.Where is Palestine ? Palestine is a self-proclaimed country , recognized largely a the Palestinian territory , located in the Middle East , specifically on the west bank of the Jordan River ( known colloquially a the West Bank ) and in a region along the Mediterranean coast known a the Gaza Strip . It is bordered by Israel , Jordan , and Egypt , with the Gaza Strip being on the coast of the Mediterranean Sea . & nbsp ; Though it proclaims Jerusalem a it capital , it de facto capital is Ramallah in the West Bank.Where is Gaza ? Gaza , known a the Gaza Strip , is a part of the Palestinian territory and is located along the Mediterranean coast . It border Israel and Egypt and ha three border crossing : the Erez and Kerem Shalom crossing with Israel and the Rafah crossing with Egypt.Has Israel recognized Palestine ? Israel ha refused to recognize a Palestinian state , though progress had been made following the Oslo Accords . & nbsp ; Currently , Israel officially support the idea of a two-state solution . Still , it is at odds with the proposed Palestinian border , a well a the issue of Israeli settlement in the West Bank and the possibility of Palestinian terrorist attack against Israel . & nbsp ; However , Israel doe recognize Palestinian control over certain part of the West Bank.Does Palestine recognize Israel ? Palestine technically doe recognize Israel , with then-Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat announcing it a such in 1988 . This wa reaffirmed following the signing of the Oslo Accords . However , the Palestinian leadership continues to have strong opposition to the State of Israel , and many Palestinian faction disagree with the recognition of Israel.Israel is oftentimes referred to by these body a the `` Zionist occupation . `` What is the Palestinian Authority ? The Palestinian Authority is the official ruling entity in the Palestinian territory . It is led by President Mahmoud Abbas and is controlled by his Fatah party . & nbsp ; The PA is based in Ramallah and exercise control over the Palestinian-run area of the West Bank , a well a claiming control over the Gaza Strip . & nbsp ; The government wa meant to be an interim body rather than a permanent political entity . & nbsp ; Officially a democracy , the Palestinian Authority is , in practice , an authoritarian entity , not having had election since 2006 , with further attempt at having election never actually manifesting . & nbsp ; Abbas wa elected to a four-year term in 2005 , though his term in office ha continued for almost two decade at the time of writing . & nbsp ; The PA ha also been accused of violating human right , censoring a free press , and engaging in widespread corruption . & nbsp ; Currently , the PA is fractured following the 2006 Palestinian parliamentary election , which saw the terrorist group and party Hamas win control of the parliament . Since then , a schism ha erupted between Fatah and Hamas , and attempt at mending this split have been unsuccessful.What is Hamas ? Hamas is a Palestinian Islamist terrorist group that wa founded in 1987 by Ahmed Yassin . Its origin lie in a Muslim charity organization , Mujama al-Islamiya , affiliated with the Muslim Brotherhood organization . & nbsp ; Since it official founding in 1987 , Hamas ha become infamous for it terrorist activity and it staunch refusal to recognize Israel 's right to exist . & nbsp ; Hamas won the 2006 Palestinian parliamentary election , but the Palestinian Authority dissolved the government and replaced it with a Fatah-led one , leading to the schism mentioned above.Hamas ha fought several armed conflict with Israel since taking over Gaza , with the current ongoing war being sparked by Hamas 's attack on southern Israel on October 7 , 2023 , which saw 1,200 people in Israel killed and 250 people taken hostage . & nbsp ; Hamas 's leadership is spread out between Gaza and Qatar . Its leader in Gaza is Yahya Sinwar , while the organization 's overall political leader is Ismail Haniyeh.When did the Israeli-Palestinian conflict begin ? The starting point of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is the subject of fierce debate since many believe the Palestinian national identity did n't begin until the middle of the 20th century . In contrast , others believe the Israeli national identity did not technically exist until the establishment of the State of Israel . & nbsp ; What is agreed upon , though , is that Jews and Arabs have conflicted with one another in the region since the late 19th and early 20th century . & nbsp ; This coincided with the arrival of Jewish Zionist settler into the future State of Israel to escape antisemitic persecution in Europe . At the time , the land wa ruled over by the Ottoman Empire , though by the end of World War I , the British took it over and instituted the British Mandate of Palestine . & nbsp ; Over the coming decade , the two demographic would grow increasingly in conflict a tension grew , with the Arabs staging multiple revolt in the mandate . In 1947 , a plan wa proposed by the British to partition Israel into Jewish and Arab state . The Jews agreed , but the Arabs did not . & nbsp ; A year later , Israel declared independence , and war wa declared . Surrounded on all side by enemy nation , Israel proved victorious , and many Arabs ended up fleeing their home - an event Palestinians refer to today a the Nakba . & nbsp ; Tensions exploded in the late 1980s a Palestinians launched the First Intifada , an uprising aimed at lashing out at what they perceived a an oppressive Israeli occupation . The intifada ended with the signing of the Oslo Accords , which many hoped would lead to a lasting peace . However , fierce opposition by hardliner among both Israelis and Palestinians prevented this , particularly with the assassination of Israeli prime minister Yitzhak Rabin and the election of a new right-wing Israeli government.In 2000 , the Second Intifada started up , lasting several year and seeing multiple casualty . It ultimately ended following the unilateral Israeli withdrawal from the Gaza Strip , though it continues to have control over Gaza 's border and airspace.While the most visible part of the conflict now take place in Gaza , there is still considerable tension among Israelis and Palestinians in the West Bank and east Jerusalem , where terrorist attack and bout of violence still occur.Are Israel and Palestine fighting over Gaza ? The ongoing Israel-Hamas War is fought largely in the Gaza Strip , but it is not a fight `` over `` Gaza . Only a small minority of Israeli lawmaker are calling for the full annexation of Gaza . Rather , the ongoing war is over the eradication of Hamas and the freeing of the hostage held in Gaza .
title: everything you need to know about the israeli-palestinian conflict

Body Text: The share of Israeli Jews who believe an Israeli and a Palestinian state can peacefully coexist ha plummeted since October 7 , according to a new survey.The figure of 19 % , reported in a study published Thursday by the Pew Research Center , wa the lowest since Pew started surveying Israelis in 2013 . It is down from 32 % in a survey released just week before the war broke out.In 2013 , according to Pew , nearly half of Israeli Jews & mdash ; and a majority of Israelis overall & mdash ; supported a two-state solution . In 2005 , another polling firm found that most Israeli Jews supported the establishment of a Palestinian state.This year , a quarter of Israeli adult overall & mdash ; including nearly half of Israeli Arabs & nbsp ; & mdash ; believe a Palestinian state and Israel can peacefull exist side-by-side . That takeaway is one of a number from Thursday & rsquo ; s Pew survey that show Israelis hunkering down for more conflict a the Israel-Hamas war is about to enter it eighth month . The survey of roughly 1,000 Israeli adult wa taken in March and April & mdash ; before Israel & rsquo ; s invasion of the Gaza city of Rafah and other recent development & mdash ; and ha a margin of error of 4 % . The survey also show wide gap between Jewish and Arab respondent . Among Arab Israelis , for example , 74 % say & ldquo ; Israel & rsquo ; s military response against Hamas in Gaza ha gone too far . & rdquo ; Only four percent of Jewish Israelis agree.And while 76 % of Jewish Israelis say Israel will achieve it goal in the war , only half a many Arab Israelis , 38 % , say the same.But Israeli Arabs and Jews share some of the same concern about the war : 61 % of both group are worried about the war spreading to other front & mdash ; a concern that ha been top-of-mind for many in the region and beyond after constant exchange of fire between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon , the first direct attack between Iran and Israel and violence on other fronts.And at a time when Tzachi Hanegbi , Israel & rsquo ; s national security adviser , said he anticipated the war will last until the end of this year , the poll found that significant majority of both group ( 77 % of Arabs , 66 % of Jews ) are worried about the war & ldquo ; lasting a long time . & rdquo ; Some 40 % of Israeli believe Israel should control Gaza postwarThe poll also measured one of the most vexing and divisive question of the war : Who should control Gaza when the battle are over . The lack of a detailed plan for a postwar scenario ha led to rift within Israel & rsquo ; s government a well a between Israel and the United States.The poll found that 40 % percent of Israelis , including half of the Jewish respondent , believe that Israel should continue to control the territory in a postwar scenario , while 18 % believe it should be run by a version of the Palestinian Authority & mdash ; which governs Palestinian population center in the West Bank but which Netanyahu ha shut out . Meanwhile , 14 % say people who live in Gaza should decide who governs them . Nine percent of Arab Israelis , and 2 % of Jewish Israelis , say Hamas should continue to rule the enclave.In addition to being taken before the launch of the Rafah operation , the poll wa conducted before other landmark development of recent week & mdash ; including a prosecutor for the International Criminal Court announcing he wa seeking Netanyahu & rsquo ; s arrest and President Joe Biden saying that he would suspend delivery of some large bomb to Israel in a bid to influence the scope of Israel & rsquo ; s Rafah invasion.But even before those event , the poll showed disapproval of Biden & rsquo ; s handling of the war rising in Israel . Biden wa broadly popular among Israelis for his embrace of the country following Oct . 7 , but by the time the poll wa taken , 60 % percent of Israeli Jews & mdash ; and 86 % of Israeli Arabs & mdash ; said they did not approve of how he wa handling the war.Also unpopular wa Netanyahu who , the poll found , had a lower favorability rating than at any point in the 11 year Pew ha asked the question , at 41 % . The two other leader in his war cabinet , Defense Minister Yoav Gallant and former Defense Minister Benny Gantz , fared better , with Gantz at 51 % and Gallant at 61 % . A more recent poll show that Netanyahu & rsquo ; s popularity , which nosedived after Oct . 7 , is recovering among the Israeli public .
title: after oct . 7 , only 19 % of israeli jew believe in peaceful coexist with a palestinian state - poll

Body Text: The Palestinian Authority ha instructed it security force to take all measure to halt increased lawlessness and anarchy in Hebron and it surroundings , a senior PA official said on Sunday . & ldquo ; The instruction from the Palestinian leadership are clear and firm , & rdquo ; the official told The Jerusalem Post . & ldquo ; There will be zero tolerance for anyone who break the law and intimidates the resident . & rdquo ; The instruction came in response to accusation by many resident , including senior Fatah official and head of local clan , that the PA wa not doing anything to stop the recent wave of violent crime in the Hebron area . On Saturday , PA Prime Minister Mohammad Shtayyeh visited Hebron , where he chaired an emergency meeting of the commander of the various branch of the Palestinian security force to discus the deterioration of the security situation in the city and it surrounding village and town . Body Text: The six small stand-up box contain three-dimensional doll in Inca costume , complete with their traditional design and surrounded by ceramic pot , also in the traditional style . Highly colorful , these miniature doll are amazingly made out of potato flour ! Peruvian artist Zuly Jimenez had been asked by Jerusalem-based artist David Moss to illustrate the Purim story a told in the Scroll of Esther a if it were set in the artist & rsquo ; s own surroundings . Jimenez decided to root her interpretation in Peru & rsquo ; s ancient culture , which meant going back to a time when the Incas ruled the land . One innovation among many wa the depiction of Haman leading Mordechai sitting on a llama , since , a she explained , the horse had not been introduced into this part of the world until the Spaniards came and conquered Peru.The experience of making these model wa for Jimenez & ldquo ; unforgettable & rdquo ; in that it combined art and history , legend and story-telling . It wa precisely the reaction that Moss wa looking for and had already received from his many guest artist from around the world over the previous thirty year when he started this unique project . & ldquo ; In 1990 , I wa in Bali , Indonesia , & rdquo ; he recalled , & ldquo ; searching for craftspeople for another project of mine , when I viewed the beautiful miniature being produced by the local artist . Bali , a traditional Hindu society , is full of palace , royalty , prince and princess , ceremony and ritual . All these thing strongly reminded me of the story of Esther and Purim . So when I went back the second time , I asked artist from two different village to do their take on the story . I gave them parchment and the story of Esther translated into Indonesian . I drew six small blank rectangle and I told them to imagine that this story wa happening right in their village . The six scene I asked them to envisage included Achashverus & rsquo ; s party at the beginning of the story ; the beauty contest in which Esther participates and win ; the reaching out of the scepter by the king to Esther ; Haman leading Mordechai on the king & rsquo ; s horse ; the hanging of Haman & rsquo ; s ten son ; and the writing out of the megilla to go out to all the land of the king & rsquo ; s massive kingdom . I didn & rsquo ; t want them to imagine Persia or anything to do with the original story . It had to be local in their own culture and style . I waited for the response . When I viewed the stunningly original crafted image they had produced , it gave me another thought : Perhaps I could expand this idea by seeking out folk artist from around the world willing to depict these same six scene in their own vernacular culture and style . Thus began a fascinating , bizarre thirty-year quest I & rsquo ; ve come to call Esther without Borders , & rdquo ; said Moss.Esther without BordersAlthough it wa initially happenstance that energized the beginning of the project , Moss & rsquo ; s enthusiasm only grew a he encountered folk artist from around the world who responded positively to his strange request . In the course of his ongoing project , he encountered artist from Ukraine , Russia , Bali , India , Italy , Ecuador , Colombia , Panama , California , New Mexico , and so on , thus echoing the megilla & rsquo ; s Achashveros , whose kingdom spread from & ldquo ; Hodu to Kush & rdquo ; ( India to Ethiopia ) . The original Purim ha a profoundly universal flavor . & ldquo ; I initially sought out folk artist , & rdquo ; said Moss , & ldquo ; although I & rsquo ; ve asked a few professional artist , too . Another change came about when I approached an artist in Italy whose charming work I had spotted in a small exhibition in the Piedmont region . He said he & rsquo ; d love to do the project but that he could not work in the miniature format I had been requesting . I told him to use whatever format he liked . He wa very imaginative , created a delightful accordion book , and also drew the main character from the story on the back of the work . He had a great sense of humor , depicting the eunuch of the king , for example , with a pair of scissors on his turban ! & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Once the mold wa broken , I let the rest of the artist do the image in whatever format they were most comfortable with . This came to mean the project ha been done on tile , fabric , icon , and envelope , a well a on paper and parchment . & rdquo ; Although Moss is a much traveled artist , the language of communication with the artist doe sometimes present problem . & ldquo ; With the Italian artist , I found a nearby gallery owner who helped locate and communicate with the artist . I use Google Translate to communicate with many of the artist . Fortunately , the Book of Esther is also in the Christian Bible , which ha been translated into hundred of language . I send the artist the entire book in their own language and highlight the six verse , & rdquo ; he explained . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; A friend wa headed off to Australia , and I asked her to propose the project to an Aboriginal artist if she came across one . She found Emma Burchill , a wonderful artist who did the project in their highly abstract , symbolic style . She explained to me how the Aborigines paint their work using dot a if they were looking down at the scene from a bird & rsquo ; s eye view . Therefore , she showed the feast viewed from above a their campfire , with the guest dancing the traditional corrobbree ceremony around the fire . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; He did not have to travel for every artist . Some came to him in his studio in Huzot Hayotzer beneath the wall of the Old City of Jerusalem . Moss met Boris Gozzo , a talented Ukrainian artist living in Israel whose illustration portrayed some of the men in the scene a drunken peasants.Most year , the art studio in Huzot Hayotzer play host to an international art and craft fair , so it wa that Moss met Rajendra Kumar Moktan from Nepal whose expertise is in the creation of mandela & ndash ; prayer wheel used in Buddhist and Hindu sacred rite and a an instrument of meditation . The detailed scene he painted on canvas truly convey the ceremony of Nepalese culture . & nbsp ; When I met Moss in his somewhat overcrowded studio , he had just got off the phone with a woman from Portugal . & ldquo ; Her name is Teresa , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; She work on Azulejo tile in the blue and white ceramic tradition from the 17th and 18th century . They were influenced by Delft tile . She had just sent me a sketch of what she is doing and wrote to me that she wa finishing the last tile . She had painted the station of the cross in ceramic for her local cathedral and the tile for the Esther story were done in this strong Portuguese , Christian tradition . & rdquo ; Not that every encounter is successful . & ldquo ; I tried a Chinese artist but didn & rsquo ; t like what he did . I & rsquo ; ll have to go back there and try someone else . Also , although I pay the artist whatever fee they request , if they ask more than I can afford , I let it go , & rdquo ; he said.It is perhaps not surprising that some of these artist became firm friend . & ldquo ; In Morro Bay , California , I met Philip Carey , who specialized in drawing delightful miniature scene on envelope and mailing them to their destination via the post office . They are whimsical and full of humor . I marveled how he translated the Esther story into his envelope art . He portrayed each of the figure a being from the animal world . So his king is a Monarch butterfly , Esther is a Morro Bay sea otter , Mordechai a bald eagle riding on a sea horse , Haman is depicted a a coyote , and so forth . Esther sends out the Purim story by & lsquo ; seamail & rsquo ; on seahorse , and & lsquo ; landmail & rsquo ; with roadrunner . Philip executed all these envelope image in ink and colored pencil and then sent them to me through the post office . We were in close contact over the year , but tragically he ha passed away . I treasure these miniature masterpiece that so embody who he wa . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Although Moss wa happy to give many of these artist some visibility , he came upon one group of unknown artist who had simply disappeared . These were the Mimbres , an extinct civilization from southern New Mexico who flourished between 1,000 and 1,150 CE and then vanished , leaving behind no writing . All that remains of them are the ruin of their building and their black-and-white pottery with unique stylized design . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I wa always captivated by the powerful design they left behind , and felt that it wa somehow unfair that I wa limiting my project to living culture . I decided to imagine myself a an ancient Mimbres artist and designed the six Esther scene a round , bowl-like image based on what wa recovered from their tradition , & rdquo ; he said . & nbsp ; Moss , an internationally recognized book artist , calligrapher , designer of ketubot and architectural design , appreciates how he ha succeeded sufficiently well to have the ability and willingness to help fellow artist who were not so fortunate . At the same time , he ha not rushed this project nor doe he have future plan for it . & ldquo ; I love that there is no end , goal , or deadline to this , & rdquo ; he confessed . & ldquo ; People have suggested that I turn it into a book , others that it should be exhibited . My daughter Elyssa run a center opposite my studio called Kol HaOt , which brings together art and Judaism . We did do a small show of these work there . But the beauty of this project for me is in the remarkable people it ha connected me with , the thrill and surprise of opening each new contribution , and the sheer joy of watching a simple idea unfold and blossom in so many surprising way . & rdquo ; Whichever way Moss decides , it would indeed be a pity if this impressive project were not viewed by a much larger audience . But maybe , a he joke , he & rsquo ; s going to wait until he reach 127 nation & ndash ; from India to Ethiopia and beyond ! ■
title: david moss 's purim project : esther without border

Body Text: Matching Purim character to the KnessetFormer Shas MK Yigal Guetta , who is now a radio and television broadcaster , wa bantering before Purim about what identity member of Knesset should take , and came up with a beloved character of fiction & ndash ; Pinocchio , the key figure in an Italian child & rsquo ; s novel written close to two century ago . Prior to the reading of the Scroll of Esther , or the Megillah a it & rsquo ; s generally known , at the Yad Vashem synagogue in Jerusalem , two senior staff from Yad Vashem & rsquo ; s guiding department , Naama Galil and Yochai Copenhagen , presented an intriguing lesson on the history of Purim , how it is celebrated and commemorated in different country and the special delicacy that are eaten.The reading of the scroll wa done by Prof . Jonathan Halevy , the president of Shaare Zedek Medical Center , whose style and perfect enunciation make him a much in demand Torah reader at various Jerusalem synagogues.The Yad Vashem synagogue , designed by prizewinning , internationally acclaimed , Israeli-born architect Moshe Safdie , is in itself a mini museum , showcasing sacred item that are remnant of European synagogue destroyed during the Holocaust . His final appeal wa for the preservation of national unity and love of Israel.The return of Adloyada & nbsp ; There wa considerable controversy in Jerusalem this year a to whether to hold an Adloyada parade during wartime . Those in favor said that the somber atmosphere of the nation should not be imposed on child , and that they should be allowed to celebrate and have fun . & nbsp ; Those against said it would be a travesty to parade through the street of the capital in joy , while the hostage kidnapped by Hamas were still languishing in Gaza.The various argument prompted Aryeh Halivni , the founder of Toldot Israel , the anthology of Israel & rsquo ; s contemporary history , to release an item about the beginning of the Adloyada tradition.For those who may not be aware , it & rsquo ; s customary to drink alcoholic beverage on Purim till one reach the stage of losing awareness . & ldquo ; Adloyada & rdquo ; is a conglomerate of three Hebrew word literally translated a & ldquo ; till he didn & rsquo ; t know . & rdquo ; The excerpt from Toldot Israel read a follows : & ldquo ; In December 1931 , the Tel Aviv Municipality held a contest to choose a new name for the annual Purim festival . The name stuck , and to this day , Purim celebration throughout Israel are known a the & lsquo ; Adloyada . & rsquo ; & rdquo ; Purim history & nbsp ; Currently doing the round on electronic medium is a story about a Purim song . They started to perform it for Sharett , who wa the product of a musical family . Soccer commentator Shlomo Scharf , in an interview with Shalom Kital on KAN Reshet Bet radio , mentioned that after his granddaughter wa murdered by Hamas on October 7 , not a single member of the government came to pay a condolence call . & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s a terrible thing when a grandparent ha to bury a grandchild , & rdquo ; said the former soccer player , coach of the national team , and the coach who led Maccabi Haifa to three championships.Meanwhile , he ha donated an ambulance to the Haifa Home for Holocaust survivor , to be used free of charge whenever one of the resident requires hospitalization . He is also a regular visitor to the home , assisting it resident with their various needs.Celebrations with the Baha ' i community & nbsp ; Like many other movement , organization , and institution , the Baha & rsquo ; i International Community , which last week celebrated it new year and the coming of spring , debated what kind of celebration it should have this year in view of the circumstance , or whether it should have a celebration at all , said David Rutstein the BIC secretary-general.In the final analysis , it wa decided to go ahead , but on a somewhat lower key than usual . This wa evident both in the floral decoration and in the musical entertainment.In past year , mini garden have been established in the lobby leading to the banquet room at the David Citadel Hotel in Jerusalem , where the BIC always celebrates it new year or Nowruz , a it is called in Persian.This year , the floral creation were subdued and consisted of two garden patch , each with a large yellow centerpiece to symbolize the hoped-for return of the hostages.There appeared to be more guest than in year gone by , including Russian Ambassador Anatoly Viktorov , who , socially speaking , ha paid the price for his president & rsquo ; s folly . He could not have known of the tragedy that would strike his country the following day.Following the terrorist attack in a Moscow concert hall , President Herzog called Viktorov to offer his condolence to the family of the dead , and sincere wish to all the wounded for a speedy recovery.Herzog condemned in the strongest term the barbaric terrorist attack perpetrated in Moscow , and emphasized that terrorism of any kind , especially jihadist terrorism , indiscriminately target all people , of all belief and religion , while sowing fear and destruction.Fighting terrorism is a major international challenge , and the country of the world must fight it together , he said.Chefs at the David Citadel outdid themselves in presentation and flavor . Commenting on the & ldquo ; strong and important relation between Baha & rsquo ; i and Israel , & rdquo ; he said that he is happy to welcome Baha & rsquo ; i volunteer from around the world to Israel.Underscoring the difficulty of celebrating while the hostage are still suffering in captivity , Sisso said : & ldquo ; We pray daily for their return . & rdquo ; Several of the Baha & rsquo ; i volunteer wore the national costume of their respective countries.Singing with soldiersAmong Israel 's most popular community singer is Einat Sarouf , who in her youth wa a great fan of Yaffa Yarkoni , who she say remains her source of inspiration , and she will be playing Yarkoni in a Habima musical during the summer.Meanwhile , before she figuratively step into Yarkoni & rsquo ; s shoe , she ha been singing to and with the troop and civilian in the same manner a Yarkoni , who died in January 2012.She ha also been traveling to America to raise the morale of Jewish community and Israeli expatriate . Body Text: Only 40 % of Israelis support a two-state resolution to the conflict with the Palestinians , even though it remains the most popular choice , according to a poll conducted by the Israel Democracy Institute . & nbsp ; Past IDI poll on this question have shown that Israeli support for two state ha fluctuated widely over the past 28 year since the signing of the 1993 Oslo I Accord in Washington . & nbsp ; Past poll on this topic by IDI show that support for a two-state resolution peaked at 70 % in 2007 during the Annapolis peace process brokered by former president George W . Bush between former prime minister Ehud Olmert and Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas . & nbsp ; It wa at it lowest point in 1995 with only 36.9 % support , based on IDI data . & nbsp ; From July 27 to 29 , the IDI polled 750 Israelis over the age of 18 by phone and over the Internet , including 151 Arabic-speakers . The margin of error is 3.59 % for the poll on a wide array of topic , including the Israeli-Palestinian conflict . & nbsp ; Participants were asked if they would back a & ldquo ; two-state solution with the establishment of an independent Palestinian state in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Israeli-Arabs were much more likely to support a two-state resolution than their Jewish peer . & nbsp ; Out of the 39.7 % who said they found such a resolution to the conflict acceptable , 33.8 % were Jewish Israelis and 68.8 % were Israeli-Arabs . & nbsp ; That answer flipped when it came to the 48 % of Israelis who opposed it , of which 53.6 % were Jewish and 20.5 % Arab . & nbsp ; The poll wa conducted in the absence of any peace process , with the United States and Israel appearing to prefer maintaining the status quo for the moment . & nbsp ; According to the IDI poll , out of the 37.1 % of Israelis who support maintenance of the status quo , 41.5 % were Jewish-Israelis and 15.4 % were Israeli-Arabs . & nbsp ; Similarly , Israeli-Arabs were more likely to oppose the status quo , with 69.5 % finding it unacceptable compared to the 37.2 % of Israeli Jews finding it acceptable . Overall , 42.6 % of those polled disapproved of the status quo . & nbsp ; The least popular option wa a one-state idea . Participants were asked whether they would back a & ldquo ; one-state solution incorporating both Israeli and Palestinian territory in which Israelis and Palestinians are treated a equal citizen , & rdquo ; implying a country that wa no longer intended to be an ethnic nationalist democracy for either Israelis or Palestinians . & nbsp ; That idea received only 21.1 % support among Israelis and 64.2 % opposition . Some 71.1 % of Israeli Jews found a one-state idea unacceptable , and only 14.1 % found it acceptable . & nbsp ; A majority of Israeli-Arabs favored it , with 56.1 % backing it , compared to the 29.5 % who dismissed it . & nbsp ; The poll wa conducted within the context of the Israeli Voice Index published by the Viterbi Family Center for Public Opinion and Policy Research . & nbsp ; IDI researcher Or Anabi clarified that while there is a drop in support for the two-state solution , it is hard to look at it comparatively over time , because IDI often asks the question in different way , which impact the result . & nbsp ; It is also possible that the lack of support could correlate to the absence of a peace process , Anabi explained . & nbsp ; People respond differently to concrete event a opposed to theoretical one , he said . Initial poll showed low support for a Sinai withdrawal , Anabi said , but the moment former Egyptian president Anwar Sadat landed in Israel , the attitude changed .
