Body Text: Love struck Rusalka ( soprano Alla Vasilevitsky ) meet a handsome prince ( tenor Alexei Dolgov ) in the same-titled opera by Czech composer Anton & iacute ; n Dvor & aacute ; k , now offered at the Israeli Opera.Sadly , she is a mermaid and he is a human . When she attempt to touch him , he think she is a wave in a pool . To leave her realm , Rusalka trade with the witch woman Jezibaba ( mezzo-soprano Edna Prochnik ) , exchanging her voice for legs.Will the prince see how much she love him when she is mute , and she will gain a human soul , or will he reject this pale , sad , silent woman and condemn her to change again & ndash ; this time to a murdering bog spirit ? Delighting opera fan for over 100 yearsThis much beloved opera , with it mythical and folk aspect , ha delighted opera fan since it world premiere in 1901 . Director Stefano Poda ha adapted it in a visually stunning , powerful manner . More conventional adaptation & ndash ; like the 1977 Czech film by Peter Weigl , or the 2017 Met Opera production directed by Sir Mark Elder & ndash ; have character move on stage from forest pool to palace and back a if in a fairy tale ; Poda flood the stage and make it an actual pool.When Rusalka & rsquo ; s father , the water spirit Vodnik ( baritone Ionut Pascu ) emerges , he rise from that pool . The element of water is massive . The nymph lay down and roll around Vodnik , unable to rise since , in this mythic logic , they don & rsquo ; t have foot . Pascus is able to sing beautifully , inhabits the role of the grieving father who lament the loss of his daughter to the human realm , and jump to the pool without missing a beat . Good opera is hard ; to sing submerged in water is an Olympian feat.Starring in the title role , Vasilevitsky offered a wonderful performance from start to finish . It wa a delight to watch her interact with Prochnik in the role of Jezibaba.Poda & rsquo ; s vision had the witch walk with a collection of iron item attached to her dark dress . When she tear a dagger and offer it to a distressed Rusalka , encouraging her to murder her prince , we sense that Jezibaba is reliving a past trauma of her own.This is implied by her strong insistence that Rusalka is motivated only by desire , and the witch & rsquo ; s taunt that the prince & rsquo ; s & ldquo ; kissy-kisses & rdquo ; were not what the mermaid - turned-human expected . Rusalka , who actually want a soul , pretend the witch is wise and all-knowing to get her to help.One of the few major world opera performed in Czech , Jezibaba often speaks in a diminutive form . When she say to Rusalka & ldquo ; by the devil you will have foot , & rdquo ; what she is actually saying is & ldquo ; by the devil you will have footsie-wussies to walk with . & rdquo ; Prochnik & rsquo ; s performance of the aria & ldquo ; Cury mury fuk & rdquo ; ( roughly translated a & ldquo ; abracadabra & rdquo ; ) during the potion-making scene wa outstanding.A gargantuan production , some thing were lost due to it grandeur . When Jezibaba meet the hunter ( baritone Oded Reich ) and the kitchen apprentice ( mezzo soprano Rona Shrira ) , they are meant to be scared of her . It is very difficult to convince the audience they are frightened if they were told to collect plastic bag from the water pool and keep on singing when a scary , evil witch is speaking with them.Like Rusalka , who gave her voice in exchange for a shot at a human soul and true love , this production traded some of the familiar aspect of this opera to gift the audience with a larger-than-life production many will remember with deep gratitude for year to come.Anton & iacute ; n Dvor & aacute ; k & rsquo ; s & lsquo ; Rusalka & rsquo ; will perform daily until Thursday , March 14 , at 8 p.m . & ndash ; except for one Friday performance on March 15 , given at 1 p.m . Three hour long , two intermission . Sung in Czech with Hebrew and English title . NIS 195-405 per ticket . Call ( 03 ) 692-7777 for booking . The Israeli Opera , 19 Shaul Hamelech St . , Tel Aviv .
title: a flood of talent in ‘ rusalka ’ - review

Body Text: Israel & rsquo ; s gross domestic product ( GDP ) grew in the first quarter at an annual rate of 14.1 % , according to the Central Bureau of Statistics & rsquo ; first estimation , published Thursday.The growth wa 3.3 % at the quarterly rate , according to this estimation.When comparing the first quarter of 2024 to the last quarter of 2023 , there wa also an annual increase of 26.3 % in private consumption , 7.1 % in public spending , and 32.7 % in the import of good and service , according to the CBS report.Public spending remains highThere wa also a drop of 10.4 % annually in the export of good and service not including diamond and export from start-ups in this quarter.Public spending continued to grow moderately in 2024 & rsquo ; s first quarter after it spiked in the fourth quarter of 2023 , meaning public spending is still abnormally high , the bureau said.The sharp increase in GDP wa attributed by the CBS to a significant increase in private consumption and investment in fixed asset after large drop in the fourth quarter of 2023 . They have yet to return to pre-war level , it said.First estimate number are still heavily impacted by the influence of the Israel-Hamas war on Israel & rsquo ; s economy , including from the large draft of reservist , payment for housing for evacuee , the shortage of worker in the construction industry , and more , the CBS said .

Body Text: Friday , May 14 , 1948 . The final hour of the British Mandate in Palestine ticked away . The mandate wa set to expire at midnight . David Ben-Gurion gave order for the ceremony to mark the birth of the Jewish state . He decided to make the historic declaration just before Shabbat came in.In the fevered atmosphere of the time , Ben-Gurion ’ s overriding concern wa security . If the location of the ceremony became public knowledge , a single terrorist bomb could wipe out the entire embryonic government of the new state , together with most of it notable . So it wa not until the middle of that Friday morning that official began telephoning the 200 people who had been selected to attend the ceremony . Only then were they told that it wa to take place in Tel Aviv ’ s Municipal Museum on Rothschild Boulevard , at exactly 4 p.m.Another 50 or so people also received a call that morning , instructing them to be present – the member of what wa then known a the Palestine Philharmonic Orchestra , comprised of Jewish musician – for by 1948 the national orchestra had become so identified with the Jewish people that an occasion of such historic significance wa unthinkable without their presence.ON MAY 15 , 1948 , the orchestra became the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra ( IPO ) , and it relationship with the people of Israel ha a deserved place in the reflection about nationhood , identity , and independence that mark Independence Day.As the National Council and the guest made their way to the ground floor area , the orchestra assembled in the museum ’ s upper gallery . At exactly 4 p.m . , Ben-Gurion rapped his gavel . This wa the prearranged signal for the orchestra to strike up “ Hatikvah . ” Unfortunately , someone missed the cue , and from above came only silence . Never one to lack initiative , Ben-Gurion promptly launched his uncertain voice into the anthem ; rather raggedly , the other member of the People ’ s Council joined in.But someone in the hall did respond to that gavel – a young radio engineer , Ralf Hellinger , who had been running the underground radio station of the Hagana , the clandestine Jewish self-defense force . Tipped off by American journalist about what wa to take place , Hellinger had arrived at the Tel Aviv museum that afternoon carting two of his cumbersome 78 rpm recording machine . After proclaiming the new State , Ben-Gurion invited the member of the People ’ s Council , one by one , to sign the document . As the last one put his name on the scroll , to thunderous applause , the orchestra finally made it presence known , and brought the proceeding to a close with “ Hatikvah . ” The audio recording of the event of that historic Friday afternoon have been preserved in the archive of the Israel Public Broadcasting Corporation , which today operates under the brand name Kan . When the musician assembled at the Municipal Museum that Friday afternoon , they did so a the Palestine Philharmonic Orchestra . By the time they played “ Hatikvah ” they had become the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra ( IPO ) . Give or take a few month , the orchestra itself wa 12 year old by that time . How had it come into existence ? IN THE early 1930s , Germany ’ s increasingly harsh race law roused the eminent violinist , Bronislaw Huberman , to a fury . In article and letter to the newspaper , he berated German intellectual for failing to make a stand for freedom of cultural expression ; and tried to mobilize world opinion against the Nazis ’ persecution of Jewish writer , artist , and musician . Finally , Huberman decided to do something practical to help those of his own profession who were being denied the right to perform inside the Third Reich . He began to persuade first-rank Jewish musician to emigrate to the Land of Israel , known then a Palestine . Against all the odds , he succeeded in setting up a viable orchestra , largely comprised of immigrant musician . Even more remarkably , Huberman wa able to persuade Arturo Toscanini , possibly the most eminent conductor in the world at that time , to conduct the opening concert of the orchestra . “ I am doing this for humanity , ” the maestro declared.The Unfinished by Franz Schubert ( 1797-1828 ) wa one of the two major work included in that first public performance by the orchestra on December 26 , 1936 . Present were the British high commissioner Lord Peel , Vera and Chaim Weizmann , Paula and David Ben-Gurion , and a vast audience , which included Signora Toscanini . The first year were not easy . Not only had the 75 player brought a wide diversity of style with them , but the diversity of language added further difficulty . Despite the problem , they quickly coalesced into an orchestra that renowned conductor were happy to lead , among others Bernardino Molinari ( 1880-1952 ) , William Steinberg ( 1889-1978 ) , and even Britain ’ s distinguished Malcolm Sargent ( 1895-1967 ) . The version of “ Hatikvah ” currently used by the orchestra is based on the orchestration by Sargent in those early days.While recognized remarkably early a a first-class orchestra , the Israel Philharmonic is today world-class . This transformation wa due to two towering figure in it history – famed conductor Leonard Bernstein and Zubin Mehta . The first a Jew , the latter a gentile , these two men share equal credit for forging the unique symbiosis between the orchestra and the people of Israel that is the outstanding characteristic of the IPO . No other top-flight orchestra in the world is so closely identified with it constituency a the Israel Philharmonic . City orchestra in the United States , the United Kingdom , Europe ; national orchestra in the Netherlands , Switzerland , and elsewhere , none are woven , a the IPO is , into the very fabric of their audience ’ s life . Where the Israeli people have gone , there ha been the orchestra , giving musical expression to the great event in the nation ’ s story.BERNSTEIN ARRIVED in Israel in October 1948 to open the first orchestral season in the State of Israel . The season included six special concert for service men and woman – the most spectacular in the town of Beersheba just captured from Egyptian troop . Braving bad road , sand and dust , the orchestra traveled from Tel Aviv with their own piano and played their concert on a makeshift stage before a thousand-strong audience of troops.That November , Bernstein broadcast from Israel to the United States . “ Last week , ” he said , “ we gave a concert in Jerusalem for soldier only . Imagine 2,000 soldier simultaneously given leave one morning in a city under siege ! “ Imagine them crowding into the Edison Theatre , filling every nook , suspended literally from the roof , curled up on window sash , packed into the aisle and staircase – all to hear a Brahms symphony . “ And at the end , the shouting and screaming wa an almost unbearable tribute . Yes , the orchestra is the lifeblood of Israeli culture , and I am dedicated to the task of seeing it flourish . ” That wa a commitment Bernstein honored to the full , in the year that followed.An unforgettable concert during the Six Day WarTOWARD THE end of May 1967 , with Israel ’ s Arab neighbor mobilizing on her border , the distinguished foreign conductor , who had been engaged for the summer concert series , took fright and hurriedly departed . In the middle of the six day of fighting that began on June 5 , Mehta arrived from Europe in a plane otherwise filled with ammunition , joining Daniel Barenboim and Jacqueline du Pré who were already performing with the orchestra . Close on their heel came Sir John Barbirolli and Bernstein.In July , with Jerusalem once again united , an unforgettable concert wa staged in the amphitheater on Mount Scopus . In the warm summer afternoon , before a packed audience that included then-prime minister Levi Eshkol and former prime minister Ben-Gurion , Bernstein conducted a performance of Mahler ’ s Resurrection symphony that life in the memory of those present a an almost unbearably moving experience.By this time , Mehta ’ s connection with the IPO wa strong , forged in his first season with the orchestra in 1961 . “ When I came on to the stage for the second rehearsal , ” he once recalled , “ the player applauded . ” How a musician from India , coming to this group of Jewish musician assembled from around the world , managed to ignite so extraordinary and lasting a chemistry is something of a mystery . Mehta himself sometimes ascribes it to the fact that he wa a member of the Persian “ Parsi ” minority in his own country , although , he always add : “ The Parsis have never experienced racism like the Jews . ” In the heady day that followed the Six Day War – day that saw the marriage of Barenboim and du Pré in Jerusalem – Mehta alternated with Bernstein in conducting the IPO in a series of victory concert . The opening of the 1968-69 season coincided with the announcement of Mehta ’ s appointment a musical director of the IPO , an appointment extended for life in 1981 . “ I will stay for a long a the player want me , ” declared maestro Mehta , in accepting the honor.It wa under his directorship that the IPO achieved acknowledged world-class status . He melded the rich string sound that come so naturally to European musician with the special quality of brass and woodwind that flourish in the United States . Mehta provided the inspired leadership that united a body of musician into a musical instrument that is greater than it part . Above all , he cherished and fostered the unique relationship that ha existed from the first between the orchestra and the people of Israel . Under the Indian Mehta ’ s baton , the IPO wa transformed into the musical expression of the Israeli nation ’ s very identity . 
title: 76 year of the israel philharmonic orchestra

Body Text: The Justice Ministry published on Wednesday the list of prisoner to be released a part of the expected deal with Hamas . Those to be released were tried in military and civilian court alike , according to media.Only 150 of the expected 300 prisoner are expected to be released in the first stage of the deal , according to Hebrew medium , adding that more prisoner from the published list will be released upon the further release of hostages.The majority of prisoner to be released , though not all , are under the age of 18 or are woman , according to the 15-page list . & nbsp ; Who are some of the prisoner expected to be released ? Body Text: Everything about the movie June Zero , which opened in theater throughout Israel on May 2 , is unusual.This includes the fact that the director and co-writer of this quintessentially Israel movie , which tell several story connected to the building of the oven that wa used to cremate Adolf Eichmann after his execution in 1962 , is an American : Jake Paltrow , and yes , he & rsquo ; s Gwyneth & rsquo ; s brother.Paltrow ha made several previous film , including the excellent 2007 The Good Night , about a man who want to achieve in his dream what he couldn & rsquo ; t accomplish while awake , starring Gwyneth Paltrow , Penelope Cruz , Danny DeVito , and Martin Freeman.Paltrow , whose late father , the director , Bruce Paltrow , wa Jewish , became interested in the story surrounding the Eichmann trial , especially concerning the fate of Eichmann & rsquo ; s body , and began researching them in detail . Deciding that for the sake of authenticity , any movie about this topic would have to be in Hebrew and needed a screenwriter who wa an Israeli native , he brought on director Tom Shoval , who made the movie Youth and Shake Your Cares Away , to collaborate with him on the screenplay.June Zero present three story that are connected thematically and create a vivid portrait of the diversity of life in Israel in the early & rsquo ; 60 . We know that Eichmann , the notorious Nazi commander who wa responsible for implementing the Final Solution and causing the death of million of Jews , wa hanged outside a Ramla prison on June 1 , 1962 . & nbsp ; However , people forget that he spent about two year in Israel , a investigator interrogated him before the trial , during his trial , and in the period of appeal that followed the trial . There wa a great fear on the part of the government & ndash ; a justified fear & ndash ; that a concentration camp survivor might assassinate him a revenge for the murder of their family . Since the vast majority of Holocaust victim were Ashkenazim , only Mizrahi police were allowed to guard Eichmann , and the movie focus on Haim ( Yoav Levi ) , his Moroccan-born main guard . & nbsp ; We hear Eichmann speak and see his foot and other part of his body & ndash ; such a his neck , in a harrowing scene when he is getting his hair cut and Haim worry that the barber will try to slit his throat & ndash ; but he is not a character in the film . Instead , we identify with Haim who faithfully carry out the bizarre task of ensuring that no harm come to one of the most notorious war criminal in history.Other story portrayed in the filmANOTHER STORY feature David ( Noam Ovadia ) , a mischievous 13-year-old immigrant from Libya , who ha been sent to work part-time in a factory run by a gruff owner ( Tzahi Grad ) . This factory is given the assignment to build an oven for cremation , a method of body disposal not used in Israel since both Jewish and Muslim religious law prohibits it use . The idea wa to cremate Eichmann & rsquo ; s body and scatter the ash outside Israel & rsquo ; s territorial water , so there would be no grave that could become a spot where pro-Nazis could make pilgrimage to . For the factory and it staff , it wa a race against time to create this oven that is unlike anything they have ever made before , and they are aided by David & rsquo ; s boldness and by the thoroughness of a survivor ( Ami Smolarchik ) , who struggle with his memories.The third section is set in Poland , a Micha ( Tom Hagy ) , a young Holocaust survivor investigating Eichmann & rsquo ; s crime , revisits the ghetto and other site where he and his family suffered and tell his story to visitor from abroad . There he meet a representative ( Joy Rieger ) of an Israeli delegation and the two engage in debate over how best to commemorate the Holocaust . She is critical of dwelling too long on the detail of what happened , while he feel it is his mission to tell his story to the world , and for all survivor to tell their stories.In a statement released by the producer , Paltrow , who visited Israel many time to research the movie , said that he felt that it wa urgent to tell story from the Holocaust to a younger generation around the world who may not understand what really happened and that he wanted to tell story people had not heard before . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; What distinguishes this film from other Holocaust film is the examination of the subject through the most obvious physical and political consequence of the Holocaust : the State of Israel . Israel is not only a country where Holocaust survivor and their descendant live , but it diversity creates a rare mosaic of culture and origin . The Eichmann trial wa a turning point in the young country & rsquo ; s understanding of the atrocity committed by the Nazis in Europe . & rdquo ; While many film , both documentary and drama , have focused on the dramatic Eichmann trial in Jerusalem , Paltrow chose to start the movie after the end of the trial . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Our film is intended to lay the foundation for understanding the complexity of Israel , from the aftermath of the Holocaust to today . This is not the story of the survival of a people in crisis , it is the story of the identity crisis of a people after survival . And throughout it there is also laughter , there is happiness , there is sadness and tear , conflict and drama , & rdquo ; he said.Tom Shoval spoke warmly and appreciatively about collaborating with Paltrow on the screenplay . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Jake got interested in everything connected to the Eichmann trial , it wa a way for him to connect to his Jewish root and identity , it & rsquo ; s something he & rsquo ; s spoken about a lot . & rdquo ; Paltrow became very interested in Israel in the early & rsquo ; 60 , Shoval said , and after he read an article about the building of the oven , he knew it would be the centerpiece of the film.PALTROW WAS visiting Israel to work on pre-production for the film when the COVID pandemic broke out , and he wa stuck in Israel for a few week . He and Shoval used the time to fine-tune the script . Paltrow even filed paperwork to emigrate to Israel so that he could stay in the country to keep working . & ldquo ; It wa a long journey , filled with unexpected turn , & rdquo ; said Shoval . At first , they had planned the movie to be mainly about the building of the oven , but then they realized it needed to be a & ldquo ; panorama of Israeli story of this period . This interested u and we found so many fascinating story , we knew we needed to include them . & rdquo ; The decision to move outside of Israel and back to Poland to tell Micha & rsquo ; s story wa also important in their writing process . & ldquo ; The movie is about memory and history , about what it is to bear witness to the past . . . Before the Eichmann trial , it wasn & rsquo ; t acceptable for Holocaust survivor to tell their story in public in Israel . . . and it wa at this moment when the survivor received a kind of validation of their experience . It wa a turning point and we wanted to show a character who experience this a part of the film . & rdquo ; The wealth of story they discovered & ldquo ; made it possible for u to present a varied wide-ranging portrait of Israel , to show the Ashkenazim and the Mizrahim , the secular and religious , the Jews and the Arabs , the survivor and those who weren & rsquo ; t in the Holocaust , and how it all came together in this story . . . & rdquo ; said Shoval . & ldquo ; It & rsquo ; s a story that hasn & rsquo ; t been told before , and it wa important to u to tell it . & rdquo ;
title: ' june zero ' : an obscure story about eichmann in israel after the trial

Body Text: Lebanon 's Hezbollah on Friday said in a statement that it had targeted Israeli soldier `` with appropriate weapon `` at the Lebanon-Israeli border.It added that it wa vigilant and ready a a resumption of fighting between it Palestinian ally Hamas and Israel fueled concern that clash across the Lebanese-Israeli border could also restart.Rocket siren went off in several town in northern Israel near the Lebanese border , sending resident in the area running for shelter . Body Text: & nbsp ; Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas told US and European Union official this week that he is ready to return to the negotiating table with Israel under the umbrella of the Quartet , which , in addition to the Americans and Europeans , also consists of Russia and the United Nations . & nbsp ; On Wednesday , Abbas repeated his readiness to resume the stalled peace process with Israel during a speech before the Arab Parliament , the legislative body of the Arab League . & nbsp ; Abbas & rsquo ; s talk about reviving the peace process came amid the war that erupted last week between Israel and Hamas . Abbas & rsquo ; s remark came in the context of his effort to show the Americans and Europeans that he is a relevant a ever and that they should look forward to working with him , especially regarding any future peace process with Israel . & nbsp ; Abbas , in other word , wa sending a message to everyone , including the Palestinians and Arabs , that he remains the one and only address for any arrangement or agreement concerning the Palestinians and the conflict with Israel . He felt the need to send this message a his rival in Hamas were negotiating with UN , Egyptian , Qatari , Turkish and other official around the world way of reaching a ceasefire with Israel . & nbsp ; THE 85-YEAR-OLD Abbas ha always been known a someone who like to be the center of attention . He enjoys making a drama out of anything that upset him . He also seems to relish the thought of keeping everyone in suspense regarding his future move , just a he did when he announced & ndash ; and later delayed & ndash ; the Palestinian parliamentary and presidential election , which were supposed to take place on May 22 and July 31 , respectively . & nbsp ; Abbas & rsquo ; s decision in late April to postpone the election put the spotlight on him again , even though he received a lot of negative coverage in the Arab and Western medium for using Jerusalem a a pretext to call off the vote . But in this case , Abbas seems to be going along with the famous quote : & ldquo ; I don & rsquo ; t care what the newspaper say about me a long a they spell my name right . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Abbas , however , did not foresee the consequence of his decision to delay the election and blame Israel for hindering the vote . His accusation against Israel , particularly surrounding the controversy over the participation of Jerusalem & rsquo ; s Arab resident in the Palestinian election , are seen by Palestinian political analyst a one of the factor that contributed to the eruption of violence in the city . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The president did not expect that his statement would add fuel to the fire , & rdquo ; said political analyst Ghassan Abu Omar . & ldquo ; Worse , he did not expect the demonstration , which began in Jerusalem and later spread to the West Bank , to turn into pro-Hamas rally . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Indeed , Hamas wa successful in it effort to take advantage of the violence on the street of Jerusalem to further bolster it standing among the Palestinian public . Hamas leader in the Gaza Strip were rubbing their hand with glee a they watched thousand of Palestinians in Jerusalem and the West Bank raise Hamas flag and chant : & ldquo ; We are all the men of [ Hamas military wing commander ] Mohammed Deif ! & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Buoyed by these scene , Hamas decided to take the risk of firing rocket at Jerusalem during the Jerusalem Day celebration a part of the Gaza-based terrorist group & rsquo ; s effort to present itself a the & ldquo ; defender & rdquo ; of the city and al-Aqsa Mosque . Apparently , Hamas wa expecting a limited response from Israel , one that would perhaps lead to only a few hour of fighting . & nbsp ; The rocket that Hamas launched at Jerusalem were directed not only against Israel , but against Abbas , too . The rocket were meant to show the Palestinian public , a well a all Arabs and Muslims , that while Hamas wa prepared to attack Israel to & ldquo ; deter & rdquo ; it from evicting Arab family from the east Jerusalem neighborhood of Sheikh Jarrah , Abbas wa doing nothing to stop the Israeli & ldquo ; aggression . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The Hamas attack on Israel made Abbas look very bad , & rdquo ; remarked a veteran Palestinian journalist from Nablus . & ldquo ; In the eye of the Palestinian people , Hamas became the hero , while Abbas wa continuing to conduct security coordination with Israel , making him appear a a traitor . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; To avoid a damaging loss of face , Abbas and his ruling Fatah faction leader joined call for a & ldquo ; day of rage & rdquo ; earlier this week in protest of Israel & rsquo ; s military strike on the Gaza Strip . Senior Fatah leader such a Mahmoud al-Aloul were even sent to participate in demonstration against Israel in some part of the West Bank . Fatah activist in Ramallah and other Palestinian city tried to turn the protest into pro-Abbas rally , but to no avail . & nbsp ; Moreover , masked gunman belonging to Fatah & rsquo ; s military wing , al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigades , appeared on the street of some Palestinian city in the West Bank to issue threat against Israel . This move wa part of a desperate effort by the Fatah leadership to counter the numerous appearance of masked commander and spokesman of Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad during the past week . It wa Fatah & rsquo ; s way of telling the Palestinian public that the faction ha not abandoned the armed struggle against Israel . & nbsp ; In his speech before the Arab Parliament on Wednesday , Abbas said that he wa still working to set a new date for the parliamentary and presidential election . He is also reported to have relayed the same message to US envoy Hady Amr and EU official with whom he met during the past week . & nbsp ; If true , this message prof that Abbas ha completely lost touch with reality . Any election that are held under the current circumstance would be disastrous for Abbas & rsquo ; s Fatah , given Hamas & rsquo ; s rising popularity among the Palestinians in the aftermath of the latest round of fighting with Israel . & nbsp ; Hamas leader are already claiming & ldquo ; victory & rdquo ; for firing thousand of rocket and missile into Israel and forcing million of Israelis into bomb shelter . & nbsp ; They are also taking credit for damaging relation between Jews and Arabs inside Israel and allegedly forcing Israel to & ldquo ; scale down & rdquo ; it measure in Jerusalem , including the suspension of visit by Jews to the Temple Mount , the removal of security barrier at the Old City & rsquo ; s Damascus Gate and the postponement of a court decision to evict the Arab family from their home in Sheikh Jarrah . & nbsp ; These & ldquo ; achievement & rdquo ; will be added to the fact that , a in previous round of hostility , the latest fighting did not end Hamas & rsquo ; s rule over the Gaza Strip . Hamas may have suffered severe blow due to the loss of some of it senior military commander and the massive destruction of it military facility and terrorist infrastructure , but a long a it retains it control over the Gaza Strip , that & rsquo ; s seen by it leader and many Palestinians a a & ldquo ; victory . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; This , in addition to the fact that Hamas once again succeeded in proving that despite the continued Israeli and Egyptian blockade on the Gaza Strip , it ha managed to amass large amount of rocket and missile . & nbsp ; Needless to say , any & ldquo ; victory & rdquo ; for Hamas is bad news for Abbas and Fatah . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; First , Abbas lost much credibility when he delayed the election , & rdquo ; explained Palestinian academic Marwan Abu Sbeih . & ldquo ; The Gaza war drove the final nail in his coffin . No one seems to take him seriously , not even the Arab leader . Not a single Arab head of state called President Abbas during the war to talk about the situation . The only people who were talking to him were the Americans and Europeans , who still believe that he is relevant . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; IN THE coming day and week , Abbas is likely to increase his effort to return to center stage in order to show his people and the rest of the world that he remains a major player in the Palestinian arena . But the event of the past few month have shown that he ha even lost control over his own Fatah faction , which wa planning to run in the parliamentary election on three separate list . The split in Fatah and the fear of a Hamas electoral victory are believed to be the main reason behind Abbas & rsquo ; s decision to delay the vote . & nbsp ; Even if the US and the EU manage to revive the peace process between the Palestinians and Israel , it & rsquo ; s hard to see how Abbas would be able to return to the negotiating table amid the fragmentation in Fatah and the soaring popularity of Hamas.As a former Fatah official in Ramallah commented this week , & ldquo ; If the Palestinians and Arabs no longer take this man seriously , why should anyone else , including the Israelis , Americans and Europeans , take him seriously ? & nbsp ; & ldquo ; This man [ Abbas ] ha divided Fatah , alienated many Palestinians and consolidated the division between the West Bank and Gaza Strip . The Palestinians need new face , new leader . & rdquo ;

Body Text: Hundreds of Jerusalem woman have taken to social medium in the name of the & ldquo ; silent majority & rdquo ; to protest the violence and civil disobedience that ha taken over Israel & rsquo ; s mixed city in recent day . The Facebook post are in all three language and state , & ldquo ; Not in my Name ! Women of Jerusalem , from all sector are saying not in our name . From the horrible event we are witnessing these day , we choose life and say no to violence . We call on all of you to join . This evening , together , we raise our hand to say , & lsquo ; Not in my Name . & rsquo ; & rdquo ; The hashtag # NotInMyName and it Arabic and Hebrew counterpart have hundred of post and thousand of comment & ndash ; some supportive , others by extremist who posted death threat . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Markose , who run the Jerusalem Model project that brings together the city & rsquo ; s diverse social activist , said that she doesn & rsquo ; t know of Palestinian woman who have shared the post so far . & ldquo ; In time of conflict for a Palestinian woman , expressing any political voice against violence and uprising is not a majority view and can be condemned by those around her to the point that it is scary , & rdquo ; Markose said . & ldquo ; There is a tension between wanting to strike when there is momentum and making it perfectly equal and symmetrical . The movie & rsquo ; s opening feature one of the funniest scene ever filmed involving a cat & ndash ; and it reveals a lot about Marlowe & rsquo ; s character , too . After those first few minute , you know him better than you know most movie hero after an hour.Netflix 's ' Mother of the Bride'NETFLIX & rsquo ; S Mother of the Bride , which star Brooke Shields , is a ( very ) watered-down version of Mamma Mia ! & ndash ; with all the element that made that movie so successful , because it play into a child & rsquo ; s fantasy of their estranged parent getting back together.Like Mamma Mia ! , Ticket to Paradise , and so many other movie , it feature a young couple holding a hastily arranged destination wedding & ndash ; in this case , it & rsquo ; s in Thailand & ndash ; that throw two ex among the couple & rsquo ; s parent together . You could set your watch by the predictable plot development , but you & rsquo ; ll likely watch it to the end if you start it , because it & rsquo ; s an efficiently constructed entertainment machine , like a pop tune you can & rsquo ; t get out of your head even if it annoys you.Mother of the Bride star a lot of actor who , like Shields , were A-listers a while ago and haven & rsquo ; t been on screen that much lately . There is an air of palpable gratitude among the cast at finding themselves back on camera . & nbsp ; Shields , who , it turned out , had a flair for comedy that she demonstrated in the Suddenly Susan series over 20 year ago , play & ldquo ; world-renowned geneticist & rdquo ; Lana , a widowed control freak workaholic whose daughter , Emma ( Miranda Cosgrove , best known for the series iCarly ) , decides to marry at a beach resort after her boyfriend , RJ ( Sean Teale ) , suddenly proposes.It turn out that RJ & rsquo ; s father , Will ( Benjamin Bratt , who played one of the police detective on the early iteration of Law & amp ; Order ) , wa the great love of Lana & rsquo ; s life and he dumped her after college without a word . Did you guess that he is now a billionaire venture capitalist ? So , by now , you have likely either started streaming the movie or stopped reading this , but if you need to know more , Michael McDonald play Lana & rsquo ; s wisecracking gay best friend , Rachael Harris is her wisecracking straight best friend , and Chad Michael Murray play the instantly smitten doctor who briefly challenge Will for Lana & rsquo ; s affection . Murray wa memorable in the role of Jake , the teen dream in Freaky Friday who fall for Jamie Lee Curtis when her daughter take over her body ( you can stream that movie on Disney + or Apple TV + ) . The tiny amount of new content in this old story is about Emma surrendering control of her wedding to a mean wedding planner in order to win & ldquo ; like & rdquo ; on Instagram & ndash ; and I won & rsquo ; t be spoiling anything to reveal that Emma eventually learns the value of spending time with family and trusting her own taste . & nbsp ; There is a scene where a couple fall into a pool and everyone jump in after them , another where the ex get stranded in a picturesque location , and a credit sequence where the cast performs a dance to a pop tune . If Shields wasn & rsquo ; t so likable , it wouldn & rsquo ; t work , but somehow it doe .

Body Text: In the wake of recent event , the necessity to learn from history and honor the memory of past atrocity ha taken on renewed urgency . As the global community gear up to commemorate Holocaust Remembrance Day , Yad Vashem & ndash ; Israel & rsquo ; s revered memorial to the victim of the Holocaust & ndash ; stand a a poignant reminder of the peril of forgetting the lesson of the past.Scheduled for Sunday evening , May 5 , the solemn State Opening Ceremony at Yad Vashem & rsquo ; s Warsaw Ghetto Square hold a particular resonance . The Oct . 7 massacre , where Jews living in southern Israel were brutally attacked and murdered by genocide-driven terrorist , felt unfathomably familiar . These event rang a familiar , unnerving tone : of the presence of unwavering hate and the dire consequence that await if we choose to ignore the history of event that led up to the persecution of Jews and the Holocaust.Eclipsed only by the global trend of antisemitism , these occurrence give u cause for renewed worry and angst . College and university campus , meant to be incubator of enlightenment and leadership , are once again being used a hotbed for hatred and extremism . This begs the question : If our future leader are being influenced , what kind of future is in store for Diaspora Jewry ? The theme of Holocaust Remembrance Day 2024It is therefore very appropriate that at the heart of this year & rsquo ; s Holocaust Remembrance Day is the theme & ldquo ; A Lost World : The Destruction of the Jewish Communities . & rdquo ; A profound acknowledgment of the devastation wrought upon the fabric of Jewish life by the effect of unchecked antisemitism . The Jewish community , a unique and autonomous social unit that characterized Jewish existence in the Diaspora for century , wa dealt a fatal blow that devastated the life and community of thousand of pre-war Jews , many of which had formed the very bedrock of Jewish existence.The rise of the Nazi Party and the establishment of German hegemony over Europe plunged Jewish community into a reality of persecution and terror . The establishment of ghetto only served to further isolate entire community , forcing these leader to enforce Nazi decree and assume duty formerly entrusted to governmental body . Finally , the ultimate campaign , the systematic extermination of Jews in Europe and North Africa , inflicted utter devastation upon thousand of community , leaving behind a landscape of destruction and loss.While the Oct . 7 massacre dealt a blow to our nation & rsquo ; s sense of security and serenity , the cruelty inflicted upon the Israeli-Jewish population did not mark another Holocaust . This nuanced reflection honor the individual life of each tragedy.Remembrance and education lie at the heart of a remedy for this disease known a antisemitism . That is why the annual memorial ceremony broadcast across the world in five language including Arabic is so critical . The symbolic Memorial Torch , to be lit this year by Holocaust survivor and Chairman of the Yad Vashem Council Rabbi Israel Meir Lau & ndash ; someone who epitomizes triumph of the human spirit over adversity & ndash ; must transcend into reality if we have any hope of fighting the scourge of antisemitism.Additionally , the story of the six torch lighter & ndash ; Pninah Hefer , Allegra Gutta , Arie Eitani , Raisa Brodsky , Michael Bar-On , and Izi Kabilio & ndash ; only serve to make the enormity of the atrocity more personal.Yad Vashem & rsquo ; s commitment to commemoration extends beyond the confines of mere ceremonial remembrance . For the second year now , it partnership with the Our 6 Million organization seek to personalize remembrance by allowing individual to pay homage to specific victim by lighting a memorial candle bearing the name of the murdered victims.Moreover , Yad Vashem , the World Holocaust Remembrance Center , ha launched an innovative initiative aimed at engaging individual from diverse background to raise public awareness about the Holocaust . The Who Is Your Holocaust Hero ? campaign invite international leader , influencers , diplomat , and actor to personally connect with the Holocaust by sharing the story of an individual who serf a their Holocaust Hero . Participants are asked to record a short video clip , one to two minute long , and share it on their social medium platforms.As the world pause to remember the six million Jewish victim of the Holocaust , Yad Vashem reaffirms it commitment to preserving their memory and educating future generation about the importance of remembrance and tolerance.Through solemn ceremony , innovative initiative , and ongoing campaign , Yad Vashem honor the legacy of those who perished , ensuring that their story endure a a beacon of hope and resilience for generation to come . ■
title: holocaust remembrance day : observing with renewed urgency post-oct . 7

Body Text: After he made Israelis fall in love with the wonder of Greek cuisine anew and sold more than 100,000 copy of the cookbook he published about this cuisine , the time ha come to go on a journey : Tzviki Eshet and Geo Tours teamed up for culinary tour to Athens and the island of Kea . The first voyage will depart between May 24-27.This is a 4-day journey that will begin on Friday , May 24 with an early landing in Athens and will close late at night on Monday , May 27 . The main event will take place in Athens and it surroundings , where Eshet and the Greco team promise to reveal to the participant restaurant and tavern hidden from view where mostly the local hang out . An in-depth tour will be conducted in the huge food market of Athens and the port city of Piraeus - which guarantee an encounter with artisanal producer based on long-standing production traditions.They will also go through the province around Athens and discover the extensive culinary scene that take place there . In order to get to know the real raw material , the Greeks ' `` asli , ” the journey will pas through various point , among them : in the ancient bakery in Greece , a fourth generation of traditional baking . They will visit a winery that specializes in the production of Retsina wine and in order to explore the taste of the sea , they will arrive at a secret tavern located on the shore of a magical cove , where everything on the plate ha risen an hour earlier from the sea . And how is it possible without Greek music ? There will be a lot of it too , in several genre that make the heart happy.The rural cuisine of Greece will also receive attention when the group go for a full day to the island of Kea ( about an hour and a quarter sailing from Athens ) . The first part of the day will be dedicated to a tour of the island 's village and a visit to the local producer . Later , at a rural farm , the group will go through a private cooking workshop not by professional chef but by `` mama `` who will reveal some of the knowledge and secret that are passed down from generation to generation.The rest of the day will be filled with relaxing activity , with the group being hosted after lunch and dinner at Kea Retreat - the retreat that opened 3 year ago on the island and is currently ranked in “ Vouge ” magazine a a must-visit hotel.Entrepreneur and restaurateur Zviki Eshet is one of the Israelis most identified with Greece and it food culture . In 2012 , he opened the first Greco , which became an empire and currently ha 10 branch that host over 5,000 people a day.The cost of the trip includes accommodation in a luxurious boutique hotel , all the culinary experience , participation in a private cooking workshop , a visit to the night club and more for 3,295 euro per person.The journey wa created and produced by Maya Karvat , owner of the agency Maya Karvat Communication and Content.To register please visit the website
title: tzviki eshet , greco to lead culinary journey following greek cuisine to athens , island of kea

Body Text: On US President Joe Biden & rsquo ; s flight to Tel Aviv on Wednesday , National Security spokesperson John Kirby said Biden would be asking Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu & ldquo ; some tough question . & rdquo ; Among those tough question were certainly one about what Israel would do to prevent a many civilian casualty a possible inside Gaza , what Israel would do to prevent a humanitarian crisis , and how Jerusalem planned to respond to Hezbollah provocation in the north.And one of those tough question wa surely a simple one : what is the endgame ? What is Israel & rsquo ; s plan and vision for the Gaza Strip the day after ? Israel clearly stated the goal of this war : to destroy Hamas and remove it control over Gaza . But what happens the day after ? Then what ? Amid the horror , shock , and fury that ha gripped this country since October 7 , there ha been little public discussion inside Israel of this issue and the future of the Gaza Strip.From an Israeli point of view , this is entirely understandable . With the blood still boiling from the horrific Simchat Torah massacre , the country & rsquo ; s focus is simply on uprooting Hamas , on delivering the terrorist organization a mortal blow . & nbsp ; Everything else can wait , including apportioning blame and responsibility for the catastrophe and thinking about what come next.But for Washington , a & ldquo ; we-will-deal-with-this-later & rdquo ; attitude is not enough , and for Biden to be able to sell continued support for Israel to his party and his country , he obviously want to know what policy he is supporting and what Israel want to do after Hamas is expelled.Hamas : Short-term v long-term goalsDelivering a devastating blow to Hamas and removing them from power in Gaza are short-term goal . But what is the long-term goal ? This is important to define because some will only support short-term goal if they know the long-term plan.And this place Israel in a dilemma because it ha never articulated any long-term plan for Gaza.Before October 7 , Israel & rsquo ; s policy toward Gaza could be summed up a containing terrorism until Hamas either realizes that it is not in their interest to pursue terror or something big happens and it is driven from power.Well , now something big ha happened , and Israel is determined to drive Hamas from power . Biden came here partly to hear from Israel what come next.On the face of it , the option are rather limited.The first option is that Israel re-occupies Gaza - - either the whole area or part of it - - and remains there indefinitely.The logic behind this is that the only way to ensure that , once kicked out , Hamas doe not return is for Israel to be in control.While two week ago this idea would have been dismissed a the ranting of the far-right , the Simchat Torah atrocity have brought discussion of that into the mainstream . Even though President Isaac Herzog ha said publicly that Israel ha no intention of doing this , the idea is out there.In a 60-minute interview on Sunday , Biden related to this and said that , in his estimation , such a move would be a & ldquo ; big mistake . & rdquo ; He certainly made that position clear in his meeting here on Wednesday.After dismantling Hamas , a second option is for Israel to hand control of it and it more than two million resident to the Palestinian Authority.The problem with this option is that the Palestinian Authority , both weak and highly unpopular among Palestinians , can barely control the area in the West Bank currently under it control , let alone take on a much bigger project . & nbsp ; In this scenario , handing Gaza over to the PA , which the Palestinian Authority lost control of in 2007 in a bloody coup , would likely necessitate Israel retaining the right to enter the Gaza Strip , a it doe currently in Palestinian town in the West Bank , for security reasons.A third option would be for Egypt to take control of the area , something Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi ha made abundantly clear he ha no interest in doing.And another option would be for Gaza to come under the administration of some kind of international consortium , perhaps an international peacekeeping team or a group of state from the Organization of Islamic Conference.This option , too , is considered unrealistic . First , few country are biting at the bit to take on this chore . Second , Israel & rsquo ; s experience with international peacekeeper keeping terrorist group out of territory ha not been good , a evidenced by the situation in southern Lebanon , where peacekeeper have been unable to keep Hezbollah from taking control and threatening Israel.In addition , inviting international actor into an area where Israel might continuously need to engage militarily is only inviting trouble.Since none of those possibility are particularly attractive , developing other , perhaps more creative idea is needed to present a an endgame.Having an endgame is essential not only to answer Biden & rsquo ; s question but also for other reason , including to help Israel & rsquo ; s public diplomacy effort a the war grind on and the focus , a is already the case , move from the October 7 massacre to the devastation in Gaza.Israeli spokespeople interviewed about the situation have so far been able to deflect question about an endgame by saying & ldquo ; first thing first , & rdquo ; first let the country defeat Hamas , and then Israel will deal with the future of Gaza . & nbsp ; But the country & rsquo ; s public diplomacy effort would be helped if the spokespeople said , & ldquo ; We are destroying Hamas today , and this is what we want to see happen tomorrow . & rdquo ; In the need for an endgame , Israel should learn from the experience of the 1967 Six-Day War . Israel won that war , but never succeeded in clearly defining what it hoped to see down the line . It never defined clearly , and still ha not defined clearly , what it endgame wa for Judea and Samaria . And it suffered from that lack of clarity.As the Palestinians demanded a complete return to the 1967 line , Israel always said what it wanted depended on what the Arabs said , what the Americans wanted , and what the Palestinians would agree to . But Israel never stated clearly what it wanted to do with the territory . It always depends , but depends is not policy . One can not achieve what one doe not define.Israel already need to define what it want to see happen in Gaza when the war end and Hamas is destroyed . Only then , maybe , will this be achievable .
title: israel already need a plan for the day after it topples hamas - analysis

Body Text: The IDF prosecution on Thursday filed an indictment in the Judea Military Court against Muntasir Shalabi for the alleged murder of 19-year-old Yehuda Guetta in a drive-by-shooting terror attack at Tapuah Junction on May 2 . & nbsp ; Shalabi , 44 , wa also indicted on two other attempted murder count due because two other 19-year-olds were wounded in the attack . & nbsp ; The indictment wa filed after evidence wa gleaned by the Shin Bet ( Israel Security Agency ) and the police . & nbsp ; Five other Palestinians have also recently been indicted for obstruction of justice by providing Shalabi with a hiding place during the initial manhunt and all five are being kept in police custody until the conclusion of their trial . & nbsp ; An additional suspect is also expected to be indicted shortly for harboring Shalabi in his effort to avoid authority . & nbsp ; Shalabi wa eventually arrested in the town of Silwad . & nbsp ; A resident of Jerusalem , Guetta wa a student in the Itamar Yeshiva . He is survived by his parent , four brother and two sister . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Yehuda in the last few day , we worried a you fought for your life , we prayed from the depth of our heart that you would overcome your wound , and across the entire country we begged for your recovery , but this morning , to our great sorrow , these prayer have turned to a eulogy , & rdquo ; the Mayor of Jerusalem , Moshe Lion , said solemnly at Guetta & rsquo ; s funeral on May 6 . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Our heart are broken & ndash ; but our spirit are strong , & rdquo ; Samaria Regional Council head Yossi Dagan said , calling on the government to establish a settlement near Tapuah Junction in Guetta & rsquo ; s memory . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I send sincere condolence to Yehuda Guetta & rsquo ; s family , & rdquo ; Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said within minute of hearing of the young man & rsquo ; s death . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; These are difficult moment for the Guetta family and the entire nation of Israel share in your sorrow , & rdquo ; he said . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; My heart go out to the Guetta family who lost Yehuda tonight , only 19-years-old , who wa shot during the heinous terrorist attack at the Tapuah Junction , & rdquo ; a statement by Defense Minister Benny Gantz read . & nbsp ; Tovah Lazaroff and Jerusalem Post Staff contributed to this report .

Body Text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu hinted that Israel would not shy away from military action against Iran when he spoke at the graduation ceremony for new IAF pilot on Wednesday . & ldquo ; We will not allow Iran to acquire nuclear weapon , & rdquo ; Netanyahu said . We do not take lightly the threat made against u , nor do we shy away from them , & rdquo ; Netanyahu said . & ldquo ; Our policy is clear and consistent : whoever try to harm u will suffer a crushing blow . & ldquo ; In the face of danger , the air force is ready to act forcefully & ndash ; at any range , in any arena and on any target , & rdquo ; Netanyahu stated . He promised that Israel would stand firm against Iran & rsquo ; s nuclear program and it entrenchment in Syria . & ldquo ; We will continue to act against attempt by Iran and it proxy to establish military base in Syria . Aviv Kochavi at an award ceremony on Monday . & ldquo ; We are hearing more and more threat against Israel coming from Iran , & rdquo ; Kochavi said . & ldquo ; If Iran and it partner . . . attack the State of Israel , they will [ pay ] a heavy price . & rdquo ; Tensions have increased between Iran and Israel , a well a between Tehran and Washington , in advance of the change of administration in the White House on January 20 when Joe Biden take over from US President Donald Trump . Body Text: Tensions are elevated in Jerusalem amid several devastating terrorist attack in the city over the past month . & nbsp ; The first , on a Shabbat evening in the Neveh Ya & rsquo ; acov neighborhood , left seven Israelis dead a they departed synagogue to go home to their meal . The next day , a 13-year-old Palestinian opened fire on Jewish worshiper in the City of David , leaving two civilian wounded . Shortly before sundown on Friday last week , a terrorist rammed his vehicle into Israelis at a bus stop , killing three & ndash ; including two brother aged six and eight . And there were two stabbing attack this past week , one by a 14-year-old.This is alongside record number of Palestinians being killed by IDF force in the West Bank during ensuing raid and arrest , leading to a general feeling of unease by everyone in the holy city . The Magazine spoke with a range of individual in the capital to find out how they feel , what they are doing differently , and where they see thing going.What did Israelis think about the violence in Jerusalem ? Views were diverse , depending on where they stood in the spectrum & ndash ; whether native-born Israeli , immigrant , secular or religious . For example , Samantha Levy , an activist who moved to Israel nine year ago , said that & ldquo ; the circumstance in Jerusalem lead me to seek out training in self-defense and how to handle security threat . & rdquo ; For native Israelis or those who have lived in the country for a long time , recent event have rekindled horrid memory from the day of the Second Intifada in the early 2000s . Noam Elia , an Israeli-American who grew up in Jerusalem and returned six month ago after living in New York for a decade , said that the situation is not like then , when bus were blowing up nearly every week . He added , however , that thing are moving in a dangerous direction . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I remember during the Second Intifada riding my scooter up Agrippas Street and wa about to turn into the Nahalot neighborhood when I saw a police officer at the end of the street . I decided not to turn , and a few second later a huge explosion went off . It is scary . & rdquo ; Noam Elia & ldquo ; I remember during the Second Intifada riding my scooter up Agrippas Street and wa about to turn into the Nahalot neighborhood when I saw a police officer at the end of the street . I decided not to turn , and a few second later a huge explosion went off . It is scary . & rdquo ; Although bomb are not going off today , & ldquo ; you have to keep an eye out for suspicious people or activity . Jerusalem is the center of all of this . & rdquo ; Emanuel , a tech entrepreneur , recalled what it wa like to grow up in Jerusalem . & ldquo ; You are exposed to persistent conflict from a young age . I remember being in school in the heart of the city , and you could hear the sound of attack while sitting in class . & ldquo ; The constant state of alertness , whether at bus stop or while taking public transportation , ha become a way of life for me . Despite this , I have not let it sway my choice of making Jerusalem my home . & rdquo ; Another resident , Isabella Swart , said there is a sense of anxiety in the air but that & ldquo ; Israel is a super-resilient country . We are not afraid because we are in our land with our people . & rdquo ; She continued with a suggestion to add cement barrier on sidewalk to prevent ramming . & nbsp ; Elya Cowland of Ramot , where the two child were killed last week , spoke somberly about an attack that wa close to home . & ldquo ; Despite not knowing the victim , I feel a heightened sense of tragedy and loss . When terror struck my neighborhood , the numbness I usually feel regarding these attack shattered . I saw with complete clarity the heinousness and horrific nature of the event . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Despite not knowing the victim , I feel a heightened sense of tragedy and loss . When terror struck my neighborhood , the numbness I usually feel regarding these attack shattered . I saw with complete clarity the heinousness and horrific nature of the event . & rdquo ; Elya CowlandRabbi Yehoshua Pfeffer of Ramot also spoke about the attack a he wa headed to the shiva for the victim , pointing out two way to view the situation . & ldquo ; On the one hand , this is a human tragedy & ndash ; and that is perhaps the first reaction , especially with this so close to home . These are bus stop where all our kid are , so you feel a certain sense of insecurity ; you don & rsquo ; t know who is going to be next . The result is a more tense atmosphere . & ldquo ; The religious response is to turn to God in prayer and strengthen element of practice . But there is also the political aspect . For example , people such a [ National Security Minister Itamar ] Ben-Gvir have promised to restore security in face of attack and threat . & ldquo ; He is always first at the scene and garnered support from even haredi and the youth . And yet , ha he done anything ? Is it all talk or will he actually do something that will give u a greater sense of security ? & rdquo ; He pointed out that Ramot is a primarily haredi area . & ldquo ; We don & rsquo ; t consider ourselves settler ; there is no settler consciousness here . This is happening to u , and what is the response from our rabbi and [ haredi ] politician ? Nothing . Just to pray . Of course we need to , but we also need policy . & rdquo ; Pfeffer lamented the imbalance between MKs and rabbi , who & ldquo ; can speak up on religious matter & ndash ; which are important & ndash ; but so are people & rsquo ; s life . If you have the privilege to be in power , you can not sit on the sideline . It is up to [ the politician ] to come up with some type of policy . & rdquo ; ARABS WHO live in east Jerusalem chose to remain anonymous when speaking with the Magazine . One said that he think that & ldquo ; the silent majority of east Jerusalemites don & rsquo ; t like attack on civilian because it hurt them more than it benefit them . However , I think the majority see attack on soldier and police a a win . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Others expressed outrage at the deadly shooting at the Neveh Ya & rsquo ; acov synagogue , saying that & ldquo ; attack on those leaving prayer service is crossing a line . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Yet it is evident that the general mood among Palestinians in east Jerusalem and the West Bank is reaching a boiling point . This is especially true in east Jerusalem . Arabs there are under complete Israeli sovereignty , yet lack the same service that are available to Israelis . This includes issue surrounding passport and visa & ndash ; flash point , a they desire the freedom to travel and work abroad . The reality is bleaker in West Bank city such a Nablus or Jenin , where many attacker come from.What happens going forward ? Policymakers are assessing how the terror attack will impact tourism and , in turn , the economy . Upward of four million people on average visit Jerusalem annually , with tourism a vital economic lifeline . Jerusalem Deputy Mayor Fleur Hassan-Nahoum , whose portfolio includes tourism , told the Magazine that & ldquo ; the recent terrorist attack have shaken our whole nation and left u in mourning . I understand the fear and concern among our resident and tourist alike , but Jerusalem is a city of strength and resilience . & ldquo ; It ha faced and overcome many challenge in the past , and these act of terror will not define it . & rdquo ; She continued that & ldquo ; necessary measure have been taken to ensure safety and security . I am confident that Jerusalem will continue to thrive and attract visitor from around the world . & rdquo ; HOW TO respond on an individual level is a question on the mind of many . Ben-Gvir ha pushed for expediting gun license for civilian , pointing to the fact that many terrorist are stopped quickly by armed Israelis . Those interviewed echoed this sentiment , expressing a desire to obtain a license and purchase a gun . Some are even carrying deterrent such a pepper spray or knives.Elia said he ha purchased pepper spray for himself and his family ; others said they keep an eye out for potentially dangerous situation . & nbsp ; Arguably , the most frightening reality about the current attack is just how unpredictable they can be . Unlike in the past , when attack were often carried out by centralized terror group , today & rsquo ; s terrorist may have no prior history of criminal behavior , yet find themselves so radicalized that they take up arm . & nbsp ; These type of & ldquo ; lone wolf & rdquo ; terrorist have sprung up across the world and are also a challenge for Israel & rsquo ; s police force . Though there is a common profile of these attacker & ndash ; single and unemployed & ndash ; the provocative rhetoric in the mosque and the proliferation of hateful messaging on social medium are also inciting brutal attack on civilian , young and old.WHERE THIS is leading to is anyone & rsquo ; s guess . Will it spiral into an all-out third intifada a some predict ? Though many hope not , the possibility is nevertheless being discussed . Even the smallest of perceived provocation , such a Ariel Sharon & rsquo ; s 2000 visit to the Temple Mount , can spiral out of control and be the catalyst of wide-scale disturbances.Levy pointed out that the lack of action or change in the political realm ensures that the status quo of terror will continue . & ldquo ; Our political figure have not been pursuing the change that we need . & rdquo ; As a result , & ldquo ; it make no sense that child should have to be killed by a ramming at a bus stop before Shabbat or that older people should be killed a they exit a synagogue after prayer . & rdquo ; Elia belief politician like Ben-Gvir and Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich are aiming for escalation , a & ldquo ; it can help reach a determination in the conflict . & rdquo ; In any case , it is clear from these discussion that despite the uptick in violence , no one is making plan to leave the country . This is their home , nowhere else . With that in mind , no amount of attack can stop people from continuing to move to the capital and start family . 
title: what do jerusalemites think about security on the street ?

Body Text: Every year , in April , the official Israeli Eurovision Amateur Club gather to celebrate the event and wish the Israeli representative of that year a safe journey.The annual event took place on Friday morning at the Centro Club in Tel Aviv . The ceremony opened with a moment of silence for the victim of October 7 and a call to return the hostage in Gaza , when a banner of their photo wa placed on the stage throughout the event.The first to take the stage wa the singer Ilanit , the first singer to represent Israel in the competition 50 year ago , in 1973.She wa followed by Mei Finegold , who represented Israel a decade ago in 2014 . When she wa asked what she thought of those who were against Israel in the competition , she answered - `` Those who hate will hate and die . Those who love will differ and have a long life . `` Eden Golan 's timeThen came the moment everyone wa waiting for : the appearance of this year 's act , Eden Golan , on the stage.Eden came with good energy but could n't stop the excitement when her song `` Hurricane `` wa played , and the whole audience joined her in singing.At the end of the song , she thanked the audience and explained how important and exciting it is to represent Israel this year when she said , `` Our song sits deep in my heart , I found myself in it word . I want to make people feel something . `` When asked if she had heard the other contestant ' song , she answered yes and `` If you put everything that happens in the political section aside , I really like the Swiss song , but I think I have a really good song and even the best in this year 's competition . `` Also performing at the event wa Israeli drag queen Kimberly Swann who performed `` My Heart `` - a song that Golan sang during her time on the Rising Star competition . Joining Swann onstage wa Ziv Abud , the fianc & eacute ; e of the abducted Elia Cohen , wearing a yellow dress with chain and picture of the hostage , and held a sign that said `` My fianc & eacute ; e is kidnapped in Gaza . `` Eden joined the other two in the performance.Eden admitted that she did n't know this performance wa going to happen . `` I could n't hold back the tear , it 's a subject I still ca n't digest to this day . `` She turned to Abud and told her `` It 's amazing to see you standing here , with all this & nbsp ; strength and I really want to put that on the stage and make our voice heard a a country to show everyone that we are here and that we must bring everyone home and no one will break u . `` We are here together , we are all a huge family . I feel everyone 's support and love so much and I really feel that the whole country is with me and that is something that I will never forget , `` Golan added . `` This year pierce so deeply into my heart and it is a huge privilege to be at Eurovision in such a year . ``
title: ' i could n't stop the tear ' : eden golan in tribute to the hostage before eurovision
