Body Text: Like most people in Israel , Ran wa awakened by siren on Saturday.He life in Tel Aviv . His full name can not be used for security reason . He is a soldier in Israel & rsquo ; s elite Lotar counterterrorism unit.Ran went to the shelter with his family , and then went back to sleep . Then there wa another siren , and he turned on the TV to see the horrific image the rest of the country wa waking up to.In another part of Israel , Tal Boorstein , a reservist and regiment commander in the 969th battalion , which is part of the 7643 brigade in the Gaza division , wa also called up on Shabbat . He left synagogue and said goodbye to his family in order to head to his unit , which is usually deployed in northern Gaza . & ldquo ; We took our uniform and equipment and went to the call-up , & rdquo ; said Boorstein . This would be his third operation in Gaza . Many reservist who had been out of the unit for year wanted to join and help.Meanwhile , Roe Bergman , a company commander in Kfir , wa also awakened at home . His unit wa deployed near Nablus in the West Bank . He , too , donned his fatigue , got his equipment and weapon , and began preparing for war . & ldquo ; I took my equipment and my rifle , and we headed south , & rdquo ; he recounted . & ldquo ; During the drive , we began to understand how large the attack wa , and we arrived near Kibbutz Re & rsquo ; im , driving from Netivot and then through the field . & rdquo ; Soon afterwards , the soldier heard the sound of fighting . They arrived at the kibbutz , where they met the unit & rsquo ; s commanding officer . The extent of the attack and horror of the day began to sink in.Twenty-five kilometer north of Re & rsquo ; im is another community , Or HaNer , near Sderot . Barak Cohen , a member of the kibbutz & rsquo ; s security team , wa also woken up by siren . The community is two kilometer from the border . He heard from his security team , the Kita Konenut , that they needed to go help their colleague in Erez , a kibbutz even closer to Gaza , just across the road.The men got their weapon and ammunition and rushed to Erez . The security detail living there were facing a difficult situation , with terrorist infiltrating from the border and shooting from bush and tree line . The civilian were all sheltering at home . It wa feared that the terrorist had already broken into the kibbutz . & ldquo ; Immediately , I and another member of the Konenut went to Erez ; we found the leader of Konenut , and he took u to the location . We saw one person dead , from Konenut , at the entrance to a house , and there wa a lot of shooting at u and bullet over our head . We tried to respond with fire . & rdquo ; It wa still early in the morning , but a the fighter began to arrive at various location , they became aware of the extent of the attack . The IDF wa still mobilizing . Many unit on the border had been overrun.Retaking Gaza border town after Hamas massacred hundred of civiliansNo one had any idea that already hundred of civilian were being massacred.THE COUNTERTERRORISM Lotar mission deal with complex hostage situation . In general , upon arrival it assesses the situation and us precision tactic and special tactic to neutralize terrorist . & ldquo ; I have to be certain about every shot that I take and be responsible for every bullet that come out of my rifle , & rdquo ; said Ran.The team is supposed to be an QRF ( quick reaction force ) , along with other elite unit such a Shaldag , Duvdevan , and Seyeret Metkal . On Saturday , it had to deal with a massive terrorist wave swamping the entire border and threatening 20 community and some 60,000 people.The QRF always ha a unit on standby that can proceed to a scene . By 7:30 a.m . , the first unit had arrived in Sderot . This wa a four-man team , and it wa confronting a situation where , according to some estimate , 250 terrorist had tried to infiltrate the city . & ldquo ; As the first team went to Sderot , my team member and I went to the unit and began mobilizing the team [ to operate ] alongside the Gaza Strip , from south to north , to see how we could create some safety net around the Strip in order to push and make it more organized when the entire military arrives and join the fight , & rdquo ; Boorstein explained.As he proceeded to join his unit , he said , all the reservist had received the gear that they needed . This wa in contrast to some report of reservist showing up and saying they lacked some important item . & ldquo ; Every soldier who came got a weapon and helmet and everything needed , including water , food , and ammunition . We have it all . & rdquo ; Meanwhile , Bergman & rsquo ; s Kfir unit had retaken Re & rsquo ; im . & nbsp ; There had been some 40 terrorist there , and they were neutralized . The unit killed 10 of them . Then they began to assist in the rescue of people . In one home , people were hiding in a shelter , and terrorist were in the house.The unit came to the door and managed to throw grenade , killing the terrorist and rescue those hiding.TWO TERRORIST body were found . It took two day to secure the entire area.Then the unit went to Kibbutz Be & rsquo ; eri , where there had been a massacre and more than 100 body were found . This wa a difficult battle.Now Bergman ha been sent to the North , and another unit had replaced theirs.For Ran and the QRF , the battle had just begun . & nbsp ; The Lotar went street by street in Sderot , clearing the city of terrorist . They killed at least 15 among the enemy . They said terrorist were operating in many place , and the initial chaos meant that the enemy seemed to be everywhere . One member of the Lotar wa killed in Sderot ; another wa wounded . The team of 12 , bolstered by other member who had just arrived , wa then led by the sergeant , who took over for the wounded commander . & ldquo ; By 8:30 to 9 a.m . , a lot of special force unit were joining u to create this safety net in Sderot , and they continued the fighting , & rdquo ; Ran recounted.The unit wa also involved in retaking and securing the military base near Nahal Oz , where , Ran estimated , there were 150 IDF casualty . Some were killed and burned alive , he said . & ldquo ; You can imagine what they did to the body , and the amount of thing I & rsquo ; ve seen , it & rsquo ; s not even close to what a human being is . I can & rsquo ; t imagine what drive them to do such thing . . . We saved a many soldier a we could ; some were trapped and hiding alongside the outpost . & rdquo ; After securing the area , they moved along the security fence to an IDF outpost called Taga.There , they found a scene from a horror movie . It wa quiet , silent even . Yet the war wa raging along the border . The Golani brigade wa supposed to be in Taga.The counterterrorism force had 28 member by this time , including some from Oketz , the unit that operates with specially trained dog . Ran praised one of the dog for saving life in the battle.As they moved through the outpost , which seemed abandoned , suddenly they saw two shape in the distance . It could be a hostage situation , they feared . But it turned out to be two terrorist , and the Israeli fighter shot them . It took about 30 minute to clear the area , and they saved five Golani soldier who were sheltering . & ldquo ; We scanned another site nearby that belongs to another Israeli security service of Israel . & rdquo ; When the area wa secure , they moved on to another mission and drove to Nir Yitzhak , a kibbutz . & ldquo ; It wa Saturday night . We were guarding around the kibbutz and making sure no terrorist were infiltrating the kibbutz line . By now , reserve team were mobilized to Be & rsquo ; eri . There wa a whole massacre there of 100 to 200 civilian ; none of them were armed , & rdquo ; he said.He then joined IDF unit from Shayetet , Shaldag , Yamam and others to retake the area . It took 18 hour of fighting . Then they helped evacuate people from Kissufim , Nir Yitzhak , Sufa , Kerem Shalom , and other places.ON OCTOBER 7 , the QRF faced an unbelievable challenge never seen before in Israel . With 20 location under attack and approximately six unit trained for these kind of situation , they had to prioritize where to go first . For instance , Shaldag and Seyeret Matkal went to Sderot . Others went to Be & rsquo ; eri and Ofakim.Many area were left for the local to defend , a they had to wait for the army to arrive . That wa the case in Erez . Cohen and his small team from the two community were able to save the kibbutz from slaughter by laying down fire and keeping the enemy away from the community & rsquo ; s entrance . However , they felt surrounded for many hour and knew there were enemy sniper nearby . & ldquo ; From 7 to 11 a.m . , no one came to support u , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; We didn & rsquo ; t know what wa happening . We wondered & lsquo ; Where is the army ? & rsquo ; Then we understood that there wa a large attack . & rdquo ; They felt alone . The enemy brought up an RPG ( rocket-propelled grenade ) and fired at them . It hit a house , but luckily the family inside survived . They heard the sound of tank in the distance but didn & rsquo ; t know what wa happening . At Or HaNer , there wa concern that terrorist could strike . Cohen faced the difficult choice of whether to send two member of the team back to his community or to keep them in Erez . They stayed in Erez . There wa a buzzing , perhaps a helicopter in the distance . But the din of shooting meant it wa hard to know.Eventually , the army arrived at 11 a.m . and rescued the security team . An entire community wa saved.Others had been massacred.Cohen wa then called up to his unit and began serving near his community . & ldquo ; The casualty we had wa the member of the Konenut who died , and two wounded that we managed to rescue from the terrorist , & rdquo ; he said . & ldquo ; We had a very complex situation . & rdquo ; He emphasized it is important to understand that in the most recent day of the war , his battalion experienced success . & ldquo ; We are approaching victory . We are a strong nation with a strong army . & rdquo ; BOORSTEIN & rdquo ; S UNIT defended community around Gaza during the fighting on Saturday and in the day after . He ha a long record of experience in these type of battle , having served in the 2006 Lebanon War and in this year & rsquo ; s Operation Break the Wave and Operation Shield and Arrow . Despite the initial setback on Saturday and the massacre of civilian , he stressed that Israel will win this war . & ldquo ; We will rebuild & ndash ; here and everywhere in Israel , & rdquo ; he said , adding that all of Israel saw the hellish story that unfolded on Shabbat . Everyone watched the news and saw & ldquo ; very difficult image . & rdquo ; & ldquo ; But despite how hard it is , we will win and change and become a stronger society a Israel know how to do . & rdquo ; 

Body Text: United Nations Secretary-General Ant & oacute ; nio Guterres spoke positively of a new grassroots plan to create an Israeli-Palestinian confederation when he met with it author in New York on Friday . & ldquo ; The secretary-general received [ former Israeli justice minister ] Yossi Beilin and [ former Palestinian negotiator ] Hiba Husseini , who presented him with their report on the & lsquo ; Holy Land Confederation & rsquo ; process , & rdquo ; Guterres & rsquo ; spokesman St & eacute ; phane Dujarric said after the meeting . & ldquo ; He thanked them for their useful contribution to try and achieve a lasting solution to the conflict , & rdquo ; he said . Guterres ha been a strong advocate of a two-state resolution to the conflict and reaffirmed that stance at the meeting . & ldquo ; The secretary-general reaffirms the UN commitment to supporting the party to achieve a just and peaceful solution to the conflict , including through the Middle East Quartet and the establishment of two state , based on 1967 line , with Jerusalem a the capital of both state , & rdquo ; Dujarric said . This would be & ldquo ; in line with UN resolution , international law and previous agreement , & rdquo ; he said . Friday & rsquo ; s meeting marked the end of a series of high-level conversation among a small group of Israelis and Palestinians last week in Washington and New York . They met with US Deputy Secretary of State Wendy Sherman and the nominee for assistant secretary of state for the Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs , Barbara Leaf , a well a number of Democratic member of Congress and the Senate , including Sen . Chris Van Hollen of Maryland . The meeting with Guterres lasted for 40 minute and included four of his adviser , Beilin said . The UN head said the plan could perhaps help revive the peace process , and he expressed regret at the absence of negotiation . Beilin said he had asked Guterres if he would include the confederation plan in his talking point with leader in the region and if he could help the group use the UN platform for debate and discourse on the confederation . & ldquo ; He [ Guterres ] promised that in his talk with his interlocutor , a he said , he will raise this option of a confederation , & rdquo ; Beilin said , adding that separately , & ldquo ; for the first time after many year , [ Guterres said ] he can have a dialogue with the Israeli government . & rdquo ; Brig . - Gen . ( ret . ) Shlomo Brom , Prof . Omar Dajani and Dr . Saliba Sarsar also participated in the meeting . When they met with Sherman , she wa particularly interested in the section about settler remaining in their home , given that the issue of evacuating the settlement is one of the most difficult one on the road to peace , Beilin said . Sherman did not endorse the plan , but she said it wa productive and that they had & ldquo ; not given up & rdquo ; and were trying to find a realistic path to peace , he said . The Holy Land Confederation plan proposes a European Union-style confederation of an independent Israeli and Palestinian state based on pre-1967 border a outlined by the 2003 Geneva Initiative . This new plan is not formally connected to the initiative or to the organization that continues to promote it . Beilin wa instrumental in the formation of the 1993 Oslo Accords and the Geneva Initiative , which he ha incorporated into his latest endeavor . Among the distinct feature of the plan is a joint Israeli-Palestinian narrative of the history of both people . The plan also provides a blueprint by which settler would remain in their home a resident but not citizen of a Palestinian state . In exchange , a similar number of Palestinians would be allowed to live in Israel a resident but not citizen . Beilin and Husseini have published their plan at a time when few Israelis and Palestinians are pursuing talk . The formal peace process ha been frozen for almost eight year . Prime Minister Naftali Bennett ha been blunt about his opposition to the creation of a Palestinian state , and US President Joe Biden ha not spoken of any intention to put forward a peace process at this time .

American medium outlet discovered Yachin many year ago and have featured him several time on television and in newspaper and magazines.Jerusalem 's upcoming Biennale ■ AMONG THE exhibitor in the upcoming Jerusalem Biennale running in the capital from March 25 to April 29 and directed by Ram Ozeri , is internationally-known photographer Joan Roth , whose work will be among thirty exhibition of varying art form that collectively come under the heading of contemporary Jewish art.Roth & rsquo ; s exhibition , which includes some of her early work , actually open earlier and go on display at the Black Box Gallery on March 11.More than half a century ago , Roth set herself a photographic mission to make Jewish woman visible.Judging by the tribute she received from the late Alice Shalvi , the founder of the Israel Women & rsquo ; s Network , and author with her late husband of an encyclopedia of Jewish woman , Roth ha obviously succeeded.Shalvi wrote : & ldquo ; Joan Roth ha the gift for seeing the significant moment , the meaningful gesture , the fleeting look which conveys an in-depth character , a lifetime of experience , an entire culture . . . Body Text: & nbsp ; Israel & rsquo ; s right to self-defense and to it ancient biblical capital of Jerusalem suffered a blow on Friday when an International Criminal Court ( ICC ) ruling advanced the possibility of war crime suit against Israelis . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; If the International Criminal Court is making a list of so-called Israeli [ war crime ] suspect , I ask that my name be put a the top of that list , & rdquo ; Yamina party head Naftali Bennett said on Sunday . & nbsp ; It wa not just a statement of bravado against the highest international criminal judiciary body . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; As a former defense minister , there is a very real possibility that he could one day be targeted by the court . & nbsp ; For the Palestinians , the ICC ruling offered a ray of hope to hold Israel accountable for alleged human right abuse . & nbsp ; Upon hearing of the ruling , Palestinian Authority Prime Minister Mohammed Shtayyeh responded by stating that perpetrator of crime will & ldquo ; not go unpunished . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; For many Israelis the idea that the court plan to target them with respect to action in Gaza and Israeli settlement activity , but ha not held human right abuser in Iran , Syria and or China accountable , speaks to the continued bias of international organization against the Jewish state . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; But how real is the possibility of war crime suit ? Who would be targeted and for what ? & nbsp ; & nbsp ; How harmful or helpful wa the ruling to either Israel or the Palestinian Authority , which first turned to the court in 2015 and asked that it adjudicate war crime suit ? & nbsp ; 1 . Is the probe only focused on Israel ? & nbsp ; No . The ICC will examine action by both Israeli and Palestinians , including Hamas . But the probe wa launched at the request of Palestinians and is expected to overwhelmingly focus on activity by Israelis against Palestinians . & nbsp ; 2 . Can all Israeli and or Palestinians action be considered war crime ? & nbsp ; No . The ICC will examine activity that occurred since June 13 , 2014 . The scope of the probe is also limited to only those incident which occurred over the pre-1967 line in east Jerusalem , the West Bank and Gaza . This includes Jerusalem & rsquo ; s Old City , the Western Wall and the Temple Mount , known to Muslims a al-Haram al-Sharif . Israelis are liable for such action , even though Israel is not a party to the Rome Statute which governs the ICC . The Palestinian Authority , in contrast , signed the statute in 2015 . & nbsp ; 3 . What three main issue will the ICC likely probe ? & nbsp ; The first is the 2014 Gaza war , including the question of disproportionate attack by the IDF and indiscriminate rocket attack by armed Palestinian group in Gaza , including Hamas . & nbsp ; The second is IDF use of lethal force against the Hamas-led & ldquo ; Great March of Return & rdquo ; along the Gaza border , which began in March 2018 and ended in December 2019 . & nbsp ; Third , the ICC would also look at the issue of whether settlement activity in the West Bank and Jewish building in east Jerusalem , since that June 2014 date , could be considered a war crime . Israel & rsquo ; s razing of Palestinian structure could be examined tangentially , but not a the main focus . & nbsp ; Other incident since that date could also be probed in the future , but the main immediate thrust is expected to be these three issue . & nbsp ; 4 . Is the state and or individual Israelis at risk ? & nbsp ; Both . On the policy level , Israel fear that a negative ruling on matter relating to Gaza would ultimately raise question about Israel & rsquo ; s right to self-defense and make it difficult for the IDF to operate against threat to the state and it citizen , particularly on Israel & rsquo ; s southern border . & nbsp ; A negative ruling on settlement and Jewish building in east Jerusalem , Israel fear , would undercut it legal claim to historical and religious right to it ancient Biblical territory and it legal claim to be indigenous to that territory . & nbsp ; If the Palestinians are successful at the ICC , then Israeli activity in both it biblical heartland of Judea and Samaria , otherwise known a the West Bank , and in it ancient capital of Jerusalem , would be a war crime . & nbsp ; The security cabinet mentioned the absurdity of both claim when it issued a statement against the ICC ruling on Sunday . & nbsp ; On the individual level , war crime suit could be leveled against people and not the state . This mean that leader such a Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and former defense minister Moshe Ya & rsquo ; alon , who held that post during the 2014 Gaza War , and Avigdor Liberman , who wa defense minister when the Great March began . Defense Minister Benny Gantz and his predecessor Bennett could also be targeted along with individual soldier and commander . & nbsp ; 5 . What wa Friday & rsquo ; s ruling and why did it matter ? & nbsp ; The ICC & rsquo ; s Pre-Trial Chamber ruled 2-1 that the court & rsquo ; s & nbsp ; Chief Prosecutor Fatou Bensouda had the jurisdiction to open an investigation into potential Israeli and Palestinian war crime on territory over the pre-1967 line in the West Bank , Gaza and east Jerusalem . Jurisdiction wa one of the earliest and most global ground on which the threat of an ICC war crime suit could have been averted both on the issue of Gaza and the settlement , had the three judge ruled against jurisdiction . & nbsp ; Their decision in support of jurisdiction can & rsquo ; t be appealed at this stage . The argument against jurisdiction can only be reopened at a later phase in the process , once individual charge have been filed to the court for approval . & nbsp ; 6 . Did the court & rsquo ; s jurisdictional ruling include recognition of Palestine a a state ? & nbsp ; No . The Pre-Trial Chamber specifically stated that such a move wa outside of it purview , but it said that it could be considered a such solely for the purpose of these issue of adjudicating war crime . & nbsp ; The basis of it ruling strengthened the status of de facto Palestinian statehood and the role of the United Nations in determining that status . The ruling upgraded the significance of the 2012 UN General Assembly Resolution that granted the Palestinians the status of a non-member state by legitimizing the de facto status it granted the PA to have the right of member state to sign UN treaty and statue , including the Rome Statute . It wa that signature which opened the possibility of war crime suit . & nbsp ; The Pre-Trial Chamber also relied on the text of that resolution to set the territory on which it had jurisdiction . It wa a move that upgraded the legal status and impact of such resolution , particularly with respect to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict . & nbsp ; 7 . How significant wa the dissenting opinion ? & nbsp ; ICC Judge P & eacute ; ter Kov & aacute ; c disagreed with his two other peer ; Reine Ad & eacute ; la & iuml ; de Sophie Alapini-Gansou and Marc Perrin de Brichambau , a well a with Bensouda herself . He said that Palestine could not be considered a de facto state for the purpose of the tribunal and that the court & rsquo ; s jurisdiction could not be fully extended to Gaza , the West Bank and east Jerusalem . & nbsp ; He took particular issue with the reliance his peer and Bensouda placed on the UNGA & rsquo ; s 2012 resolution , which he said wa non-binding and did not carry the legal weight attributed to it . & nbsp ; In a strongly worded 168-page option , that wa longer than the original 60-page one issued by the Pre-Trial chamber , he brought into evidence statement by PA official themselves a well a the UN , to the effect that Palestine is not yet considered to be a state . & nbsp ; Kov & aacute ; c argument lend legal weight to Israel & rsquo ; s contention that Palestine can not be considered a state . They reflect a lack of legal unanimity on the issue with the court and can be used later to bolster appeal claim . & nbsp ; 8 . What are the next step ? & nbsp ; Bensouda would inform the party and the court that she ha opened an investigation , at which time they would have 30 day to respond . & nbsp ; & nbsp ; Among the critical aspect of her investigation is the question of whether the Israelis or the Palestinians have adjudicated or would adjudicate issue with regard to Gaza and the settlement , according to Israel Democracy Institute Vice President of Research and legal expert Prof . Yuval Shany . The ICC is called into play often only in situation where the national court system is non-existent or ha not addressed the pertinent issue , he explained . & nbsp ; It is at this stage that Israeli probe or potential probe into criminal activity by it soldier in Gaza could sway Bensouda not to move forward on war crime allegation with regard to Gaza , Shany said . & nbsp ; Israel ha not simultaneously held criminal investigation into settlement activity & ndash ; which it considers to be legal & ndash ; and thus Bensouda is likely to move the matter of settlement forward to the phase of individual criminal charge . & nbsp ; Those charge against individual either with respect to Gaza or the settlement must be confirmed with the court . It is at that phase that individual charged could appeal , including on jurisdictional ground , Shany said . & nbsp ; The timing of the matter is likely to be crucial , since Bensouda & rsquo ; s term a chief prosecutor is slated to end in June and a new prosecutor will make decision on the case .

Body Text: It truly feel like we are living inside a chapter of the Bible . Yesterday , when news started to come in about the crash of the Iranian president 's helicopter , I saw that some people were quoting the verse from the Book of Proverbs , written by King Solomon : `` When the wicked perish , there is joy . `` When righteous people perish from the world , we are sad , and unfortunately , this happened a great deal since October 7th . But on the other hand , here is an opportunity to rejoice . When the wicked perish from the world & ndash ; there is joy in the world ; it is cleaner , purer , and better here without them.But there is another verse , the last verse of the Haftarah , that will be read in synagogue during this coming Shabbat : `` Behold , I am the Lord , the God of all flesh ; is there anything too hard for Me ? `` We are used to asking , `` What will be ? `` and getting answer from panel of retired commentator and expert . This verse reminds u that we do not exclusively determine the plot , and with all due respect to the expert & ndash ; reality often surprises.Sometimes , unfortunately , we have difficult scenario . Still , sometimes , event amaze u for the better : the progression of history toward a positive direction of success that we had n't even imagined.May we be blessed with many more good news story far beyond what we expected.Has anyone given you anything to pas along ? In the airport , on my way back from London , I wa asked the usual question by the custom agent : & ldquo ; Has anyone handed you anything to give to anyone ? & rdquo ; And the truth is that my answer is a resounding & ldquo ; Yes ! & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Someone & rdquo ; ha given me something precious : an abundance of support , concern , love , prayer , and feeling of unity from the Jewish community of London directly to Israel.It wa a privilege to be among the 40 speaker from Israel to travel to Britain on behalf of & ldquo ; Mizrachi UK & rdquo ; It wa a privilege to see how the huge turmoil since October 7th ha inspired people to do more : One person is making aliya ; another is organizing a rally ; someone else is organizing a special prayer service , and challah bake ; another is bringing the family of hostage to speak here , and yet another is raising fund and organizing solidarity mission to Israel.Yael Jackson , from the London suburb of Borehamwood , helped organize an event attended by many more people than expected ( a usual , they were looking for more chair ! ) . She shared the following insight : & nbsp ; & ldquo ; A few year ago , the Covid crisis separated u . Never before had we felt so isolated and alone . By contrast , the current crisis ha brought u together like never before . People we & rsquo ; ve never seen before have come to be with u . We & rsquo ; ve never been so united ! & rdquo ; Sderot then and now : Spot the differencesThis composite photo of Sderot from October 7th , 2023 , alongside that of Sderot from Independence Day 2024 , tell our story . To quote the prophet Micah : & ldquo ; Rejoice not against me , my enemy ; although I have fallen , I will rise & hellip ; & rdquo ; Kosher & hellip ; and the Beauty of ShabbatAt the start of the war , a soldier on reserve duty came to Muzi Anidger & rsquo ; s restaurant and wa disappointed to find that it did not have kosher certification . Then and there , Muzi decided to make all the necessary change so that his restaurant would be eligible for kosher certification . Since then , he & rsquo ; s delighted ten of thousand of customer in northern Israel with his offerings.Disproving all the naysayer , six month later , when it wa time to renew his kosher certification , Muzi announced to all that he wa continuing to run the restaurant according to the law of kashrut and Shabbat . & ldquo ; I always served fantastically delicious food , and it wa actually kosher , & rdquo ; Muzi wrote to me . & ldquo ; The only obstacle to receiving kosher certification wa that the business wa open on Shabbat . In the last half year , I learned to love Shabbat and the serenity that it brings to body and soul.Our family once again experience togetherness . The peace and the great atmosphere led me to understand that there is nothing that can compete with Shabbat . & rdquo ; Who said that the inspiration brought on by the war would be short-lived ? A response to the & lsquo ; Holy Stickers & rsquo ; Sara Shapiro teach at the Hebrew Academy in Marlboro , New Jersey . In response to my article about the & ldquo ; holy sticker & rdquo ; that can be found all over Israel with message from those who lost their life since October 7th , she sent me the following : & ldquo ; Based on your idea , I decided to do an activity with my middle-school students.We prepared a special & lsquo ; Yizkor plaque & rsquo ; and included selected quote in Hebrew and English . So , even if we can & rsquo ; t come to Israel right now , we & rsquo ; ll still be able to benefit from the impact of those message . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Translated by Yehoshua Siskin , Janine Muller Sherr.Want to read more by Sivan Rahav Meir ? Visit sivanrahavmeir.com

Body Text: Six month after Operation Guardian of the Walls , the defense establishment is preparing a it expects Hamas to try and damage the border fence between the Gaza Strip and the southern border by blowing up car bomb , infiltrating Israeli territory and hitting soldier . In an exercise held this week in the Gaza Division , the force practiced such scenario , including an infiltration into Israeli territory . The aboveground barrier , made of steel , is about 65 km long and six meter high . It will extend from Zikim Beach to the Kerem Shalom crossing and it purpose is to prevent terrorist from entering Israeli territory from aboveground . The defense establishment belief that Hamas leader understood , a part of the conclusion drawn from Operation Guardian of the Walls , that alongside the attack tunnel , which it people continue to invest in , the organization must develop additional option for operation that it ha used effectively in the past , but abandoned in recent year . The security tension and stalemate in talk with Hamas over an agreement for calm and a prisoner swap agreement , mediated by Egypt , could push the organization to take action against Israel . According to evaluation , a part of operational order for when the order is given , Hamas member are training for raid and infiltration into Israeli territory a well a the use of large explosive vehicle . As mentioned , the defense establishment is aware of the fact that Hamas is investing a lot of effort in digging new defensive and attack tunnel and in rehabilitating the tunnel damaged in the operation . It is estimated that the route of the attack tunnel is approaching the barrier area , although no tunnel out into Israeli territory is known . Israel ha noticed that in recent month Hamas ha been making a major effort to rehabilitate and improve it military capability , a a lesson from the operation in which it men found it difficult to hit IDF soldier and target along the border . Among the area in which Hamas is investing are : cyber warfare , unmanned aerial vehicle ( UAVs ) , various airspace method and anti-tank weapon . The IDF belief that the terrorist organization is not currently interested in a military confrontation due to the need to rehabilitate the Gaza Strip and it military capability . The defense establishment ha identified a large presence of Hamas restraining force in order to prevent clash with the IDF . Recently , Hamas force even aggressively arrested Palestinian Islamic Jihad ( PIJ ) terrorist operative , in order to maintain stability in the region at this stage . In Israel , it is believed that incident that may occur in security prison , such a the death of a hunger striking PIJ prisoner , could lead to a terrorist attack and it is estimated that the PIJ is already preparing to carry out attack . On the other hand , in recent month , Hamas leader have repeatedly sent message to the leadership of the PIJ that if the organization act contrary to the position of the joint faction , it people will not receive military assistance from Hamas , a ha already happened twice in recent year .
title: hamas may try to attack the border fence in next round of fighting

Body Text: Iron Dome always had a weakness . It shot down 85 % - 90 % of Hamas rocket in past round of battle & ndash ; and that wa out of the one which were projected to land in populated area . As long a the volume of rocket Hamas could shoot in a single salvo wa small , this wa almost a hermetic defense . But Israeli intelligence and national security official had long warned that Hezbollah had a sufficient number of rocket to pound the Jewish state with over 1,000 rocket in a day , an amount that could pierce the Iron Dome shield . This wa one reason the IDF ha been so careful when it came to Hezbollah . The terror group ha 150,000 or more rocket , including hundred of advanced one , which mean that 1,000 per day wouldn & rsquo ; t even dent it arsenal . Has Hamas now found it own way to undermine Iron Dome ? During the 2014 Gaza War , Hamas fired almost 4,000 rocket , but that wa spread out over 50 day . It usually fired dozen of rocket in a day at most , and spread them out over the day . Its high wa around 200 rocket spread over a whole day & ndash ; and out of the 50 day of the war , it fired more than 100 rocket per day for only around two week . Also , the vast majority of these rocket were fired at the Gaza corridor since Hamas had a limited number of rocket capable of reaching Tel Aviv and other area . For more on rocket attack against Israel & nbsp ; read here For more on Israeli strike on Gaza & nbsp ; read here For more on live rocket attack update & nbsp ; read here For more on riot in Israel & nbsp ; read here For more on world reaction to Gaza violence & nbsp ; read here & nbsp ; But on Tuesday and Wednesday morning , Hamas appeared to succeed in firing more than 100 rocket within minute , including a sizable number focused on Tel Aviv . This is a jump both in the number of rocket being used against Tel Aviv , and in the terrorist group & rsquo ; s ability to fire a high volume of rocket simultaneously . This is an ability that Hezbollah wa known to have , but wa thought to be some time away still for Hamas . DOES THIS mean the Iron Dome is no longer effective ? No . It still intercept the majority of rocket fired at Israeli population center although some are getting through . The bigger question is whether Israeli intelligence estimate are correct that Hamas ha only a few hundred missile which can reach Tel Aviv . If those estimate are accurate , then Hamas may have used up a large chunk of that arsenal , even if it ha thousand more which can hit Beersheba , Ashdod and community near the Gaza border . But if Hamas ha more of those longer-range rocket , this could impact Israel & rsquo ; s plan for this round of violence and especially the question of how long it want it to last . If Hamas can pierce the missile shield with 100 rocket in a few minute twice in one day , how much more damage can Hezbollah and Iran do with the longer , larger and more accurate missile it possesses ? Israeli decision-makers and military strategist will need to take this into account in deciding how long this can go on for and how quickly they will need to either escalate with a ground offensive to reduce Hamas rocket fire ( clearly the IDF & rsquo ; s extensive bombing on Tuesday did not succeed in that sufficiently ) or to find it way to a ceasefire more quickly and make new plan for the next round . The IDF will also need to rethink the speed with which it will need to move in a conflict with Hezbollah , let alone Iran .

Body Text: Former New York City mayor and philanthropist Michael Bloomberg convened a roundtable discussion of Israeli mayor in Tel Aviv on Thursday to launch a recovery and repair innovation initiative for the hardest-hit city in Israel amid the war ; it & nbsp ; wa unveiled exclusively to The Jerusalem Post.The initiative , under Bloomberg Philanthropies , intends to provide both support and expertise based on vast experience in other conflict zone to the most affected community across Israel that suffered following the massacre on October 7 and during the subsequent war.Committed to providing support for Israel during the war & nbsp ; & ldquo ; I know this continues to be an extremely difficult time for everyone & ndash ; and for Israel & ndash ; and that & rsquo ; s why I & rsquo ; m here , & rdquo ; Bloomberg said in his opening remark . & ldquo ; I have great confidence in Israel & rsquo ; s future & ndash ; because I believe in the power of those value . & ldquo ; Those value have been attacked before & ndash ; and they will be attacked again . But time and again , we have seen the power of people who believe in those value to overcome the worst in human nature . That is America & rsquo ; s story & ndash ; it is Israel & rsquo ; s story & ndash ; it & rsquo ; s the story of the free world and it endures because it connects to something deep within the human spirit that no government , and no terrorist group , can kill . & rdquo ; Seated at the roundtable were mayor from all sector , Jewish and Arab alike , including Tzvika Brot of Bat Yam ; Rafik Halabi of Daliat al-Carmel ; Miriam Fierberg of Netanya ; Mazen Ghnaim of Sakhnin ; Rotem Yadlin of Gezer Regional Council ; and Raed Daka of Baka al-Gharbiya.The group gathered at the Bloomberg Sagol Center for City Leadership at Tel Aviv University to discus a & ldquo ; new program that will help bring world-class expertise to support 65 locality , & rdquo ; according to Bloomberg.Tel Aviv University President Prof . Ariel Porat said , & ldquo ; The Israeli government failed to provide it citizen with all kind of different service . The municipality could and should play an important role . & rdquo ; Indeed , the program intends to see the development of regional innovation hub designed to serve each cluster & rsquo ; s community and their respective municipality and help them rebuild stronger , with particular focus on the hardest-hit region rather than individual city because & ldquo ; regional dependency and interdependence amongst community is such a big priority , & rdquo ; according to James Anderson , who established and lead the Government Innovation program at Bloomberg Philanthropies and is the architect of the organization & rsquo ; s work supporting mayoral leadership and driving local innovation in Israel.Speaking to the Post , he said community & ldquo ; really want our support . . . to enable and encourage that sort of regional thinking a community build back better . & rdquo ; The focus of Bloomberg PhilanthropiesBloomberg Philanthropies will focus specifically on bringing resource and capability in data science , the digitization of public service , program design , and collaboration management to develop and implement project emphasizing recovery , resilience , and regional connectivity.The mayor and municipal head in attendance , in a closed-door discussion , raised question and concern that may be met through the initiative , and in turn , Bloomberg & rsquo ; s team of professional is taking feedback , applying necessary customizations , and initiating customized program specifically to help each affected area.Anderson said , & ldquo ; The government innovation program at Bloomberg Philanthropies really come from Mike and the fact that he is the only major funder on the globe , who also happened to have been a mayor & rdquo ; and therefore & ldquo ; understands the unique role mayor can play in moving u forward at the community level , at the national level , at the global level . & ldquo ; We started our work in Israel 10 year ago , we brought our Bloomberg innovation model to Tel Aviv , Jerusalem Beersheba , and . . . all three of those city do extraordinary thing with that investment , & rdquo ; Anderson explained , adding that they are developing new program according to the need of city around the world , and this is informing their choice in Israel , whether they learned it in Kyiv due to the Russia-Ukraine war or in New Orleans in the wake of Hurricane Sandy last decade.Bloomberg revealed that & ldquo ; outside of the United States , we do more work with mayor in Israel than in any other country in the world & ndash ; and that & rsquo ; s something that I know would & rsquo ; ve made my mother and father very proud . It & rsquo ; s time like this & ndash ; time of crisis and conflict , when people are deeply worried about the future & ndash ; that mayor are more important than ever . & rdquo ; Indeed , Bloomberg & rsquo ; s personal experience in the centrality of mayoral leadership in time of crisis informed plenty of his work with mayoral program through Bloomberg Philanthropies.Bloomberg wa mayor of New York City from the beginning of 2002 , shortly after the September 11 attack in 2001 , during which four coordinated Islamist suicide terrorist attack were carried out by al-Qaeda against the US , including two plane crashing into the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center . & ldquo ; I learned very quickly that mayor have a unique opportunity to be beacon of hope & ndash ; and to rally people behind a shared vision that unites people of all background and all religion , & rdquo ; Bloomberg said . & ldquo ; They also have a powerful role to play in helping community recover and rebuild and to show resident that even in a crisis , government can work for them and get thing done , whether that & rsquo ; s building infrastructure or getting family back in their home and school . & rdquo ;
title: michael bloomberg launch regional innovation hub in war-stricken israeli city - exclusive

Body Text: Israel need a peace authority to pursue and maintain relation with it Arab neighbor and the Palestinians , former Israeli negotiator Gilead Sher told the Knesset Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee on Tuesday . & ldquo ; This authority will handle only peace , and peace-making and peace-preserving , & rdquo ; Sher told The Jerusalem Post after the meeting , adding that this new body would have & ldquo ; one mission statement . & rdquo ; This would be an independent authority with a commissioner that would be appointed by the Knesset , Sher said . He explained that this wa different from other governmental body such a the Foreign Ministry , the Prime Minister & rsquo ; s Office or the National Security Council , which handle a myriad of task . & ldquo ; This is a fresh new idea that is completely detached from politics of Left and Right , & rdquo ; said Sher . & ldquo ; This relates to the very basic fundamental of the establishment of the State of Israel with a Declaration of Independence of 1948 , which expressly say that Israel will seek peace and extend it arm toward it neighbor for peace and security . & rdquo ; Sher ha a long history with peace process , having served a an attorney and chief of staff for former prime minister Ehud Barak , a well a a negotiator for both Barak and former prime minister Yitzhak Rabin . Israel need to move beyond the paradigm of dealing with peace only a a necessary pursuit when the opportunity open and make it a permanent part of it national agenda , Sher said . Israel should & ldquo ; not be satisfied with short-time , ad-hoc administration whenever there is an opportunity to do something , & rdquo ; he said . During past peace process , he noted , there were temporary mechanism that were established and then dismantled . During the 2007 Annapolis process , there wa even & ldquo ; a peace administration , & rdquo ; but & ldquo ; it wa a very short-term administration without any continuity of the collective memory and the data that wa processed . & rdquo ; A Peace Authority , Sher said , would allow for a kind of continuity that is not absent . & ldquo ; This is a stable permanent body that would become one of the most important body in the state of Israel , & rdquo ; he said . Sher spoke at a time when the peace process with the Palestinians ha been frozen for almost eight year . It is also a time when Israel ha advanced peace with it neighbor under the rubric of the Abraham Accords , establishing tie with the United Arab Emirates , Bahrain , Morocco and Sudan . Sher said that the peace authority would work to shore up those relation a well a Israel & rsquo ; s peace treaty with Egypt and Jordan . In addition , it would prepare for normalized tie with additional Arab country . A senior fellow at the Institute for National Security Studies , Sher said this plan wa his initiative , and that when he put it forward , he did not represent any specific organization . He spoke during a meeting in which the FADC listened to proposal on how to advance Israeli-Palestinian relation and heard summary of pending problem area . MK Gaby Lasky ( Meretz ) told the Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee that she could not recall when such a forum had been convened . Lasky said the idea for an administration or a peace authority could be put into place fairly quickly . It ha been a mistake to rely so heavily on a military body to represent Israel in it tie with the Palestinian Authority . It would be important for a civilian body to exist that would upgrade Israel & rsquo ; s tie with the PA , Lasky said .

Body Text: `` Since he wa diagnosed , this is my war , & rdquo ; Meirav Funis told me . Her 10-year-old son , Neidav , wa diagnosed with leukemia in December , and they had been living at Schneider & ndash ; Children & rsquo ; s Medical Center while he received treatment . & nbsp ; I met Meirav at the Zichron Menachem annual four-wheeling trip , now in it 11th year . The Land Rover tour wa located in the Ben Shemen Forest , an area full of tree , field , and rocky terrain . Our Land Rover wa number 13 . Our driver & rsquo ; s name wa Zion , and he only had one hand . He lost his other hand in an accident in the IDF . He said he doesn & rsquo ; t let it stop him from living his life . & nbsp ; As we drove over the rock embedded in the ground , I asked Meirav about Neidav . Meirav ha four child ; her oldest is 17 . Their family life in Beit Aryeh . & nbsp ; The week before the trip , Neidav finished his treatment . & ldquo ; We beat cancer , we beat it , & rdquo ; Meirav said proudly . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Neidav is 10 , but ha a mind like a 50-year-old , & rdquo ; she said . She recounted that throughout his treatment he had stayed positive , with the understanding that there wa no other option but to fight . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; It wa all in the head ; there wa no other option but to win . & rdquo ; Meirav said he knew everything that wa going on , and his sibling knew a well.When they learned that Neidav wa going to lose his hair , the family threw a party . His brother , Be & rsquo ; eri , and his father both decided to shave their head with Neidav so he wouldn & rsquo ; t be alone.Be & rsquo ; eri sat with u in the Land Rover . However , Neidav wa not with u because he had a fever . Part of the effect of leukemia is an extremely weak immune system . As a result of this , Neidav ha not been able to attend school . Meirav belief he will catch up , though . She said that Neidav is very smart . & ldquo ; He learned English all by himself from TV show , & rdquo ; she said proudly . & nbsp ; Neidav had to undergo chemotherapy for five month . His mother confided that it had been an extremely difficult time , but that Neidav had continuously tried to be positive . Now that the treatment is over , they can finally see the light at the end of the tunnel . & nbsp ; When we got out of the Land Rover , there wa a barbecue waiting for u with all type of meat , salad , and chip . All the kid were handed water gun , along with the volunteer & ndash ; who were either in high school or doing National Service . During the water fight , nobody wa spared . Then , the volunteer led the kid in song I knew from summer camp . One young man had drum , and others held child on their shoulder . They all stood in a circle singing and dancing while their parent sat around , talking and relaxing . There were kid of all age , ranging from all sector of Israeli society , from secular to haredi.As I stood watching , I wa approached by Tomer Baum , a parent I had spoken on the early morning bus ride from Schneider Hospital in Petah Tikva to the forest . & nbsp ; Tomer had told me about his son Yair , who is 13 year old and wa diagnosed with Hodgkin lymphoma in December 2023 . Yair wa at a summer camp in the United States , but Tomer brought his son Aviv on the Land Rover tour . While Yair had been undergoing treatment at Sheba Medical Center , Aviv wa very scared and stressed , Tomer explained . & nbsp ; Yair & rsquo ; s treatment lasted six month . In addition to chemo , Yair & rsquo ; s doctor also attempted additional treatment . Tomer talked about the scariest day at this hospital for him , when the doctor tried to give Yair a & ldquo ; biologic & rdquo ; treatment . When the nurse left the room , Yair stopped breathing , Tomer recalled . & ldquo ; He turned purple . & rdquo ; It turned out that Yair wa having an allergic reaction to the medicine , causing the doctor to immediately cease the treatment . For Tomer , it wa the & ldquo ; worst day ever . & rdquo ; Now Yair is in remission , but the next five year are crucial , a period during which the disease could reappear . & nbsp ; Tomer said that knowing Yair had a trip to the US to look forward to during his treatment had given him hope . As Aviv wa also scared and stressed during his brother & rsquo ; s treatment , this Land Rover trip wa a way for him to have fun , relax , and be a kid , his father said.VolunteeringI ALSO spoke to Bram , a high school student who ha been volunteering with Zichron Menachem for a year and a half . As well a going on trip and helping at summer camp , he also assist individual family . & nbsp ; Bram told me about a family with five child that he began helping after the outbreak of the war with Hamas . The father wa on reserve duty , and the mother wa studying to be a doctor . One of the kid had cancer . & ldquo ; It felt like the house wa falling apart , & rdquo ; he shared . & ldquo ; I wa just trying to hold the house together . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Bram said that since the war began , there have not been enough volunteer , and many who used to travel to hospital or to help individual family could no longer do so . & nbsp ; Zichron Menachem ha several hundred volunteer . The organization wa founded 34 year ago by Chaim and Miri Ehrental , whose son Menachem battled cancer for over 14 year . According to the founder , the organization belief that the emotional well-being of his/her family is crucial to a child & rsquo ; s healing process.Zichron Menachem run a rehabilitative educational social day center , a hospitality center for family , study program , and club and workshop & ndash ; a well a annual vacation camp abroad for child during winter and summer break , and a spring camp for parent of child with cancer . Zichron Menachem also offer family vacation and fun day throughout the year.Another aspect of the organization & rsquo ; s activity is related to medical care . This includes organizing and funding various therapy and treatment , home assistance , a blood donor registry , wig-fitting , and more . Recently , it established a blood collection center for oncology patient . Additionally , for the past 12 year , in collaboration with the Pantene hair product brand , Zichron Menachem ha been running the Hair for Hope project , which collect hair donation to provide free wig for cancer patients.When I asked Bram why he continues to volunteer , his answer wa : & ldquo ; There is a lot of satisfaction . I can feel the effect I have on the kid . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; He added that they also have an effect on him . & ldquo ; I pay more attention to what I say . I & rsquo ; ve become more emotionally intelligent , & rdquo ; he said . & nbsp ; At the end of the trip , parent had to drag their kid home , sopping wet from the water fight . The volunteer , also sopping wet , grinned from ear to ear . They kept asking me , & ldquo ; Did you have fun ? & rdquo ; & ldquo ; Of course , & rdquo ; I replied . 

Body Text: The first group of an estimated 7,500 foreign passport holder trapped in Gaza since the Israel-Hamas war began on October 7 , were able to leave the besieged enclave for Egypt through the Rafah Crossing after week of intense diplomatic effort.At least 320 foreign national , including US and British citizen , and dozen of severely injured Gazans were among the first beneficiary of the Qatari-mediated deal brokered between Egypt , Israel and Hamas . & nbsp ; They were driven through the Rafah border crossing and underwent security check , official said . Kirby said.Biden discussed the arrangement with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu earlier this week . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; The State Department ha been in contact with US citizen in Gaza , telling them to be ready to leave and to await further instruction , & rdquo ; The terror group ha forcibly controlled Gaza since 2007.Hamas ha asserted that over 8,500 Palestinians in Gaza have been killed from war-related violence . Israel ha banned the entry of good , food , medicine and fuel into Gaza through it passage , but ha allowed a limited amount of humanitarian aid into the Strip through Rafah.The US ha pushed for a plan that would allow for 100 truck a day , but ha yet to meet that goal , although the number continues to rise . Israel said it had killed a Hamas commander in Tuesday 's attack.There wa no immediate word on possible casualty from the second explosion , but footage showed smoke billowing above the camp and people sifting through pile of rubble and carrying away the injured . `` It is a massacre , `` said one witness at the scene of what other witness said wa an Israeli air strike in the Fallujah district of the large camp in the urban sprawl of north Gaza.The Israeli military later issued a statement saying it fighter jet had struck a Hamas command and control complex in Jabalia `` based on precise intelligence , `` killing the head of the Islamist group 's anti-tank missile unit , Muhammad A'sar . `` Hamas deliberately build it terror infrastructure under , around and within civilian building , intentionally endangering Gazan civilian , `` the statement said.European Union foreign policy chief Josep Borrell said he wa appalled by the high number of casualty in Jabalia and he urged all side to respect the `` law of war and humanity . . . ``

Body Text: The Biden administration is opposed to the forced relocation of Palestinians from Gaza to neighboring Egypt , US Secretary of State Antony Blinken told Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas when he met with him in Ramallah on Sunday.Blinken & ldquo ; made clear that Palestinians must not be forcibly displaced , & rdquo ; State Department spokesman Matthew Miller said after their meeting.They also spoke about the importance of restoring stability to the West Bank and & ldquo ; the need to stop extremist violence against Palestinians and hold those accountable responsible , & rdquo ; Miller said.The two met during Blinken & rsquo ; s visit to the region close to one month into the start of the Gaza war . He met with Abbas after holding talk with Israeli official in Tel Aviv and Arab leader in Jordan over the weekend.In his meeting with Arab leader , such a King Abdullah in Jordan on Saturday , he attempted to assuage their fear over the possibility of a forced expulsion of Palestinians from Gaza.US President Joe Biden issued the same message to Abdullah when he spoke with the monarch last Tuesday.They & ldquo ; agreed that it is critical to ensure that Palestinians are not forcibly displaced outside of Gaza , & rdquo ; the White House said after the call.US National Security Council spokesman John Kirby echoed that sentiment in speaking with reporter last Wednesday.He rejected any report of a plan to expel Palestinians from Gaza . & ldquo ; I want to stress that is not our policy . That is not what we are after . We want to make sure that the people of Gaza , should they want to go back home , can go back home . But if they want to get out in the interim , they should be able to get out . & rdquo ; Palestinians flee home in Gaza to escape IDF bombing , failed rocket launchesSome 1.4 million of the 2.3 million resident of the Gaza Strip have fled their home in an attempt to escape IDF bombing or explosion from failed Palestinian rocket launches.Hamas claim that close to 10,000 Palestinians have been killed since the start of the war on October 7.Israelis have suggested that Palestinian civilian in Gaza should be temporarily allowed to relocate to Egypt for their safety until the war ends.Palestinians have voiced concern that this would be a second expulsion , akin to what happened to them during Israel & rsquo ; s War of Independence in 1948 when invading Arab country encouraged them to flee while they & ldquo ; pushed the Jews into the sea . & rdquo ; Some 750,000 Arabs fled or in some case were forcibly expelled from their home during the war , an event that Palestinians refer to a the & ldquo ; Nakba & rdquo ; ( catastrophe ) . PA envoy to the UN Riyad Mansour told the Security Council last Monday that & ldquo ; Israel want to depopulate the Gaza Strip completely . . . and throw them [ Gazans ] into the lap of Egypt in the Sinai desert . & rdquo ; Kirby last Wednesday stressed that & ldquo ; there is no US policy for endorsement for some sort of permanent settlement & rdquo ; of Palestinians outside of Gaza.The war in Gaza wa ignited by the infiltration into southern Israel of Hamas terrorist who murdered over 1,400 people and took more than 240 people hostage.Hamas official Ghazi Hamad told a Lebanese news outlet this week that his organization would execute more October 7 attack , because it doe not believe that Israel should exist . & nbsp ; Kirby said , & ldquo ; This is what is at stake for the Israeli people , that is what is at stake for the people of Gaza , that Hamas is willing to continue this fight and will continue to try and slaughter innocent Israelis . Those are chilling comment and we all ought to take them seriously . & rdquo ; Hamas , he said , can not remain in power after the war , he added.An Israeli diplomatic source told reporter on Sunday that the IDF must retain security control of Gaza after the war . & ldquo ; I don & rsquo ; t see a situation where Israel will not have supreme security responsibility in Gaza , & rdquo ; the source stated . Work must also be done to change the mindset of Palestinian society there , the source added . & ldquo ; It is not enough to restore Gaza . It must be put through a process of de-Nazification , & rdquo ; the source added.The source noted that the problem wa not limited to Gaza , but also included the West Bank . & ldquo ; This culture [ of wanting to kill Jews ] still exists in the Palestinian Authority , & rdquo ; the source said , warning during the conversation that West Bank settlement were in danger of Hamas attacks.Blinken told Abbas that Washington belief the PA & ldquo ; should play a central role in what come next in Gaza , & rdquo ; said a senior State Department official who briefed reporter traveling with Blinken.The official said the future of Gaza wa not the focus of the meeting but that PA official appeared willing to play a role.Abbas told Blinken that Gaza is & ldquo ; an integral part & rdquo ; of the state Palestinians want , according to an account of the meeting from the official Palestinian news agency WAFA , which suggested any PA role in governing Gaza would have to be part of a wider settlement of the decades-old conflict . & ldquo ; We will fully assume our responsibility within the framework of a comprehensive political solution that includes all of the West Bank , including east Jerusalem , and the Gaza Strip , & rdquo ; Abbas wa quoted by WAFA a saying.Reuters contributed to this report .

These statement are all the more severe a we are at war on all front , and such remark practically endanger the citizen of Israel . `` Minister Ben Gvir concluded his letter a he noted , `` Under these circumstance , I urge you to act immediately and instruct the law enforcement system to fulfill it role , at least with the same speed with which you send letter to me . ``

Body Text: Israeli soccer club who will be participating in European competition this coming season found out over the weekend who they will be facing in their respective qualifying tournaments.Maccabi Tel Aviv , Maccabi Haifa , Maccabi Petah Tikva and Hapoel Beersheba will all look to wind their way through the qualifying round in order to punch their ticket to the brand-new league phase of the UEFA Champions League , Europa League and Europa Conference League.The new league phase consists of 36 team for each competition and team will be drawn against eight different opponent , with four game being played at home and four away for the Champions League and Europa League , while the Conference League team will play against six different opponents.At the end of the league , team 1-8 will automatically qualify for the round-of-16 while team 9-24 will face each other in a knockout playoff round to advance , while team 25-36 are eliminated from all competitions.In the knockout phase , all tie are contested both home and away culminating in a one-match final.Maccabi Tel Aviv will participate in Champions League qualifying and is looking to advance to the league phase of the prestigious and lucrative competition for the first time since 2015 , where it played the like of Chelsea , Dynamo Kyiv and Porto in the group stage ( and lost all six game while scoring one goal ) . The yellow-and-blue will begin qualifying in the second round where it will play the winner of the first-round game between Virtus A.C . 1964 from San Marino and Fotbal Club FCSB of Romania , with the formerly known Steaua București being a heavy favorite to advance and play Maccabi.First match of the second round for MaccabiThe first match of the second round for Maccabi will be away from home July 23 to 24 with the home leg the following week , however due to the ongoing war that game will also take place on the road.Already , 29 team have qualified for the league phase with seven place being up for grab through the qualifying competition & ndash ; five being through the champion route and two via the league route.Fotbal Club FCSB wa founded in 1947 and play it game at the National Stadium in Bucharest . FCSB is considered to be the biggest club in Romania and ha won the most league championship ( 27 ) and cup ( 24 ) . In 1985/86 , it won the European Championship before it wa renamed the Champions League , when it defeated Barcelona on penalty and wa also the runner-up to AC Milan in 1988/89.Last season , FCSB won the Romanian championship after an eight-year drought , when it took the league by three point over second place Cluj.Maccabi Haifa will take on a relative newcomer to European soccer in FC Sabah from Azerbaijan in Conference League second round qualifying with the home leg taking place July 25 and the return leg slated for the next week in Baku . Sabah play at the 13,000 seat Bank Respublika Arena , and the game there will not be an easy task for the Greens.Sabah wa established seven year ago and quickly moved into the first division , where it ha been one of the best team in the country . Last season , the club finished in third place and the year before it ended the campaign in second place . That allowed it to compete in Europe for the first time , where it made it to the third round of Conference League qualifying before being eliminated by Partizan Belgrade.Hapoel Beersheba will also play in Conference League qualifying against Bulgarian outfit PFC Cherno More Varna , which finished last season in third place of it domestic league , just one point away from CSKA Sofia and 13 point off of first place Ludogorets.Cherno ha captured four league title over the course of it 111-year history , with the most recent coming way back in 1938 , with it last Cup and Super Cup having been won in 2015 which led to Europa League qualifying the following season.In 2008 to 2009 , the Bulgarian side played against Maccabi Netanya in the UEFA Cup qualifier and passed the Diamond City squad 3-1 on aggregate in the two game that they played.Maccabi Petah Tikva last played in the group stage of European competition back in the 2005 and 2006 UEFA Cup and the wait to feature in continental play may need to wait yet for another season a it will face Portuguese mainstay FC Braga , which finished in fourth place in domestic league action and play in the 30,000-seat Municipal Stadium.Daniel Sousa wa recently appointed a the club & rsquo ; s head coach after having worked for many year under Andr & eacute ; Villas-Boas and worked at Porto , Chelsea , Tottenham and Marseille among others before heading out on his own when he managed Gil Vincente in 2022 and 2023 and Arouca this past season .

Body Text: Hamas say it is confident it will score another victory in the upcoming Palestinian parliamentary election , according to source close to the Islamist movement . & nbsp ; The Islamist movement say it also ha no intention of accepting the condition of the Middle East Quartet ( US , UN , Russia and EU ) for the recognition of any Palestinian government , the renunciation of violence , the recognition of Israel & rsquo ; s right to exist and a commitment to abide by all agreement signed between the Palestinians and Israel . & nbsp ; Hamas & rsquo ; s election program will be similar to the one it used to win the heart and mind of Palestinians during the 2006 parliamentary election . & nbsp ; Then , Hamas candidate ran a part of a list named the & ldquo ; Change and Reform Bloc & rdquo ; under the slogan : & ldquo ; Islam is the solution . One hand build , another resists . Yes to reform , yes to change . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Hamas belief it chance of scoring another victory , if and when the parliamentary election take place , are very good , given the growing schism in Fatah and allegation of financial and administrative corruption in Palestinian Authority institution , the source said . & nbsp ; Hamas is also convinced that many Palestinians will vote for it candidate because they identify with the Islamist movement & rsquo ; s ideology . & nbsp ; There were two main reason why Hamas won the last parliamentary election . Secondly , there wa widespread frustration with rampant corruption of Fatah and PA leader . & nbsp ; Explaining it decision to participate in the 2006 election , the Change and Reform Bloc said in it election program : & ldquo ; The Islamic Resistance Movement [ Hamas ] belief it participation in the legislative election at this time , and in light of the reality in which the Palestinian cause is witnessing , come within the framework of it comprehensive program for the liberation of Palestine and the return of the Palestinian people to their land and homeland . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; In 1996 , Hamas boycotted the first parliamentary election because they were held under the umbrella of the Oslo Accords , which it continues to oppose . & nbsp ; In 2006 , however , Hamas changed it mind and decided to participate in the election to the parliament , the Palestinian Legislative Council ( PLC ) . The result wa a victory for Hamas , which received 44.45 % of the vote and won 74 of the 132 seat . & nbsp ; Addressing the Palestinian public ahead of that election , the Change and Reform Bloc said it wa seeking & ldquo ; to build a developed Palestinian civil society and direct the Palestinian political system and it political and reform program to achieve the national right of the Palestinian people . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The Hamas list emphasized that & ldquo ; historical Palestine is part of the Arab and Islamic land , and it is a right of the Palestinian people that doe not pas by the statute of limitation . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The Palestinian people , the list noted , & ldquo ; are still in the stage of national liberation , and they have the right to work to restore their right and end the occupation by using all mean , including armed resistance . Resistance in all it form is a natural right of the Palestinian people to end the occupation and establish the Palestinian state with Jerusalem a it capital . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; The Hamas list also promised to make Islamic law & ldquo ; the main source of legislation in Palestine and respect public freedom . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Palestinian blood is a taboo in Palestinian society , and dialogue is the only acceptable method for resolving internal Palestinian dispute , & rdquo ; it told voter . & nbsp ; Moreover , the Hamas list pledged to halt & ldquo ; political arrest & rdquo ; and vowed to & ldquo ; protect civil-society institution . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; But in July 2007 , the group staged a violent coup against the PA and seized control of the Gaza Strip . Dozens of Palestinians were killed during the violence . & nbsp ; Hamas ha since arrested thousand of Palestinians , especially those affiliated with it rival in Fatah , in addition to journalist , political activist , human-rights advocate and civil-society worker . & nbsp ; Hamas & rsquo ; s 2006 election campaign also focused on corruption , an issue that ha been bothering many Palestinians since the inception of the PA in 1994 . & nbsp ; & ldquo ; Public fund are the right of all the Palestinian people and should be used in financing comprehensive Palestinian development in a manner that achieves justice away from abuse , corruption and embezzlement , & rdquo ; Hamas said in it election program . & nbsp ; It promised to combat corruption & ldquo ; in all it form and enhance transparency and accountability . & rdquo ; & nbsp ; Hamas leader were scheduled to participate in a meeting of several Palestinian faction in Cairo on Monday to discus preparation for the parliamentary , presidential and Palestinian National Council ( PNC ) election . & nbsp ; If the faction reach an agreement , the parliamentary election will take place on May 22 , and the presidential election will take place on July 31 . The vote for the PNC , the PLO & rsquo ; s legislative body , ha been set for the end of August . & nbsp ; Aware that it chance of winning the presidential election are nonexistent , Hamas ha it eye set on the Palestinians & rsquo ; two parliament : the PLC and the PNC . & nbsp ; The PLC & rsquo ; s 132 member represent Palestinians living in the West Bank , Gaza Strip and east Jerusalem . The PNC parliament ha nearly 700 member and represents all Palestinians , inside and outside those area .

Body Text: The Movement for Quality Government in Israel ( MQG ) demanded in a letter on Wednesday a criminal investigation into action by former justice minister Ayelet Shaked after recording published by Channel 12 on Tuesday indicated that she agreed to appoint a judge after former Israel Bar Association chair Effi Naveh pressured her to do so for personal benefits.As part of their respective responsibility , both Naveh and Shaked were member of the Judicial Appointments Committee , which is responsible for appointing all of Israel & rsquo ; s judge . Haaretz reporter Chaim Levinson published recording last month of conversation from 2016 between Nave and the judge in question , Eitan Orenstein , in which Orenstein appeared to agree to a number of Naveh & rsquo ; s demand in exchange for an appointment a president of the Tel Aviv District Court . Orenstein eventually received the appointment.In the new recording that aired on Tuesday , Shaked said in response to Naveh that Orenstein had & ldquo ; no chance & rdquo ; of receiving the promotion . However , she commented to Naveh & ldquo ; This is the most important thing to you in the world , ah ? & rdquo ; and appeared to agree to Naveh & rsquo ; s demand . Naveh is heard explaining in the recording that his private law firm would benefit if Orenstein is appointed , since Orenstein would then have the power to choose favorable judge to preside over Naveh & rsquo ; s cases.MQG said in a statement that accompanied it letter , which it addressed to the Attorney-General , Israel Police Commissioner , and the police & rsquo ; s Investigations and Intelligence Division head , that & ldquo ; the conversation that were published yesterday are credible evidence for establishing reasonable suspicion that serious offense were committed in the field of standard in public life by senior official in the legal world . & rdquo ; The MQG added that & ldquo ; in view of the goal of the criminal procedure , it is important to complete the investigative procedure efficiently and quickly , in order to establish the truth and carry out the law with all those involved in the case . & rdquo ; Shaked said to Channel 12 on Tuesday in response to the report that she had been subject to & ldquo ; pressure from different people over the appointment of president of the Tel Aviv District Court & rdquo ; regarding more than one candidate , but that the decision in the end to appoint Orenstein wa made based on & ldquo ; professional consideration only , & rdquo ; and wa supported by then-Supreme Court Chief Justice and Judicial Appointments Committee member Miriam Naor.A history of conviction and accusationsNaveh ha a history of problematic conduct . He wa convicted and sentenced to a two-month suspended sentence in November for sneaking his partner past custom agent at Ben-Gurion airport in 2018 . He had engaged in the subterfuge because he wa in the midst of divorce proceeding at the time.The former Bar president wa also accused of promoting judicial candidate in exchange for sexual favor , and resigned over the scandal in 2019 . The case wa dropped in 2021 , a the deputy state attorney believed the case would lose in court.Naveh ran again to lead the Israel Bar Association in June 2023 but , supported by Justice Minister Yariv Levin , he lost by a landslide , winning just 19 % of the vote . HIs defeat wa seen at the time a a sign of opposition to Levin & rsquo ; s judicial reforms.Mike Starr contributed to this report
title: ngo demand criminal investigation of former justice minister shaked
